title: Millionaire Chess to Hit Las Vegas, in Gambit to Raise Games Profile With Big Prizes
description: Next month, more than 500 chess players from 39 countries will arrive at the Planet Hollywood Casino in Las Vegas to compete in a tournament with the biggest prize fund in chess history  $1 million. And despite all of the players paying at least $1,000 each in entry fees, the tournament organizers will almost certainly lose hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Study Suggests a Rebound for Union Jobs in New York
description: Just two years ago, labor leaders were fretting over the steady erosion of New York Citys reputation as a bastion of unionization. The share of working-age city residents belonging to labor unions was in what they feared was an inexorable decline.

title: A Donors Passion Animates the Gamecocks Success
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Under the generous shade of oak trees in a parking lot across the street from Williams-Brice Stadium last Thursday afternoon, as many as 100 people mingled between a catered buffet and a trailer with an amply loaded bar.

title: NATO Set to Ratify Pledge on Joint Defense in Case of Major Cyberattack
description: BRUSSELS  When President Obama meets with other NATO leaders later this week, they are expected to ratify what seems, at first glance, a far-reaching change in the organizations mission of collective defense: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.

title: Mental Floss Is Buoyed by Online Video
description: For decades, magazine editors often relied on a handful of maxims to attract readers: Young is better than old. Pretty is better than ugly. Rich is better than poor. Film stars outsell television and music stars. Anything sells better than politics, and nothing sells better than a dead celebrity.

title: Obama and the Warmongers
description: We seem to be drifting inexorably toward escalating our fight with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, as the Obama administration mulls whether to extend its limited bombing campaign into Syria.

title: Sport Turns a Corner and Sees Its Future, at 200 M.P.H.
description: SILVERSTONE, England  Some Spanish journalists know him as El Nio  the kid  while some English reporters have called him the Smiling Assassin, for his genial nature off the track and the killer instinct he displays once his helmet is on.

title: Amazon Bets on Content in Deal for Twitch
description: On Wednesday night, I spent time on Twitch.tv watching people watch people play StarCraft II, Call of Duty and League of Legends.

title: U.S. to Report Its Trade Balance, and E.C.B. to Convene
description: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IS EXPECTED TO WIDEN

title: Chris Kirks Torrid Round May Alter Some Ryder Cup Plans
description: NORTON, Mass.  Chris Kirk went head-to-head with the worlds top-ranked golfer Sunday and more than lived to tell about it. He matched that golfer, Rory McIlroy, shot for shot, beginning the day with two birdies and ending it the same way.

title: Labor Today
description: In the months before Labor Day last year, job growth was so slow that economists said it would take until 2021 to replace the jobs that were lost or never created in the recession and its aftermath.

title: Showboat Casino Closes Amid Tears and Questions About Atlantic Citys Direction
description: ATLANTIC CITY  One casino here closed on Sunday and another will be shuttered this week, the latest signs of the reckoning underway for New Jerseys faded gambling mecca.

title: How to Buy a Mine in Wisconsin
description: Last year, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and the Republican-controlled State Legislature approved the worlds largest open-pit iron ore mine, a gash in the northern part of the state that could be as long as 21 miles, a half-mile wide and 1,000 feet deep.

title: Desperately Dry California Tries to Curb Private Drilling for Water
description: FRESNO, Calif.  The small prefab office of Arthur & Orum, a well-drilling outfit hidden in the almond trees and grapevines south of Fresno, has become a magnet for scores of California farmers in desperate need of water to sustain their crops. Looking at binders of dozens of orders for yet-to-be-drilled wells, Steve Arthur, a manager, said, Weve got more stacked up than well do before the end of the year.

title: Tony Stewarts Return to Sprint Cup Series Ends With Blowout
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  In just a few blazing minutes, Tony Stewart unleashed pent-up racing emotion that had swelled for three weeks.

title: Start-Ups Accrue Funding in Case of Leaner Times
description: In 1999, right before the dot-com bubble popped, Lawrence Coburn quit his corporate job and dove into the Internet gold rush, raising $600,000 from friends and family  including his grandmother  for a consumer ratings site he founded called RateItAll. At the time, virtually any idea, no matter how far-fetched, seemed to hold the promise of a high-flying initial public offering, making it easy to attract financial backing.

title: Lifting the Soul, and the Spanish Economy, Too
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain  There are the pilgrims who hobble along with a staff, painstakingly making their way through a monthlong journey of contemplation. Then there are the others, looking all the fresher for walking a shorter route or paying a tour operator to carry their backpacks, and more likely to be clutching a cellphone or a guidebook.

title: P.R. Firm for Putins Russia Now Walking a Fine Line
description: In 2006, executives from the public relations firm Ketchum flew to Moscow to secure an account that has since been worth tens of millions of dollars.

title: Odd Strokes Delight in Era of Uniformity at U.S. Open
description: In a digital, mass-market age, the artisanal has plenty of cachet and the price tag to go with it.

title: More Workers Are Claiming Wage Theft
description: MIRA LOMA, Calif.  Week after week, Guadalupe Rangel worked seven days straight, sometimes 11 hours a day, unloading dining room sets, trampolines, television stands and other imports from Asia that would soon be shipped to Walmart stores.

title: Safer Electric Zoo Festival Brings Serious Beats and Tight Security
description: A year after deadly drug overdoses at the annual Electric Zoo music festival caused promoters to cancel the events final day, tens of thousands of ravers arrived on Randalls Island over Labor Day Weekend to find drug-sniffing dogs, a heavy police presence and guards who searched pockets, bags and even shoes for illicit substances.

title: Ukrainian Woman, Held Up to Public Abuse, Is Released
description: MARIUPOL, Ukraine  A woman whose public abuse by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine roused anger over her treatment and concern for her fate has been freed from detention and allowed to leave rebel-controlled territory.

title: The Voice of Horse Racing in New York
description: Tom Durkin inside his booth at Belmont Park in 2014 during his eighth and final chance to narrate the crowning of a Triple Crown winner.

title: A New Police Force in a Changed Camden
description: Sixteen months after Camden, N.J., eliminated its Police Department and replaced it with a county department, its crime rate has dropped and new policing strategies have helped ease tensions.

title: Camden Turns Around With New Police Force
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  In the summer of 2012, the year this city broke its own record for homicides, there were 21 people murdered here. This summer, there were six.

title: And Hes Off: A Track Legend Calls It a Career
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  It was noon, and Tom Durkin was marking up his program with pastel colors for a final time, matching a kaleidoscope of jockey silks to the appropriate horses in each race. His binoculars were within arms reach, as was the coat hanger with a makeshift clipboard that holds his program and hangs around his neck as the thoroughbreds he describes make their way around the racetrack.

title: Popular Demand
description: Breaking Bad and the male actors who won for their roles in the drama series, Bryan Cranston and Aaron Paul, dominated online activity during the Emmys. Julia Louis-Dreyfus, above, awarded lead actress in a comedy, and Jim Parsons, the lead actor in a comedy, also ranked high.

title: Sandy Wilson, Composer and Writer of The Boy Friend, Dies at 90
description: Sandy Wilson, the British composer and playwright whose hit musical The Boy Friend starred Julie Andrews in her Broadway debut, died on Wednesday in Taunton, England. He was 90.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 31, 2014
Redrawing a State in India Drives Land Prices to the Sky
description: AGIRIPALLI, India  In this belt of villages near the fertile Krishna River delta, much is as it has been for generations: The cotton soil is as black, the mango trees as heavy with fruit, the tobacco fields as fragrant and deeply green as ever.

title: The Most Interesting Shots in Tennis
description: Ernests Gulbis, Alexandr Dolgopolov, Sara Errani, and Agnieszka Radwanska have some of the most interesting shots in tennis.

title: With Power Ruling the Game, Monica Niculescus Slicing Forehand Stands Out at the U.S. Open
description: As flat power and topspin increasingly dominate tennis, one woman dares to be different. Very different.

title: Barclays Sells Some Spanish Assets to CaixaBank
description: The British bank Barclays said on Sunday that it had agreed to sell its retail and corporate banking business in Spain to CaixaBank for 800 million euros, or slightly more than $1 billion, the latest development in its plan to streamline itself by selling noncore businesses.

title: Memo on Guantnamo Detainee Medical Care
description: A document obtained by The New York Times in a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit indicates that the Pentagon has decided that it would be lawful to not evacuate a detainee held at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in a medical emergency, even if American troops at Guantnamo would be brought to the United States for treatment.

title: The Future of Guantnamo
description: The Timess Charlie Savage answers questions about the state of the Guantnamo prison today and the obstacles to closing it  or keeping it open.

title: Even at U.S. Open Practice Session, Roger Federer Is Hottest Draw to Fans
description: Prashanth Iyer and Ashwin Verghese were on their way to beginning a day of tennis watching at the Louis Armstrong Stadium when they came upon a commotion around the practice courts at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center.

title: Inspired by His Fathers Activism, Tim Wu Is Running for Lieutenant Governor as an Outsider
description: Not long after his father died, Tim Wu remembers, an uncle barged into his house in Toronto and snatched a fistful of Chinese-language materials from a file cabinet because of fears that the secret police would get them first.

title: Kathy Hochul, Cuomos Choice for Lieutenant Governor, Is No Stranger to the Spotlight
description: During her roller-coaster political career, Kathy Hochul has been a rising star in the Democratic Party, a victim of its upstate troubles and a retired government employee who became a banking executive. And that is just since 2011.

title: Germany Steps Up Its Response to Global Security Crises
description: BERLIN  In an indication of Germanys growing role on the world stage, the countrys top politicians on Sunday approved the delivery of thousands of machine guns and hand grenades, as well as hundreds of antitank missiles, to Kurdish forces battling Islamic militants in Iraq.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Interventions on Several Fronts
description: Season 2, Episode 8, Mirror, Mirror

title: The Guantanamo Docket
description: Documents and research related to the 779 people who have been sent to the Guantnamo Bay prison since 2002.

title: Camp X-Ray: A Ghost Prison
description: Camp X-Ray  with its kennel-like cages that were used for about four months when Guantnamo opened  is now overrun by vines, iguanas and banana rats.

title: Dont Catch What Ails Your House
description: In 1982, my husband and I bought a vacation home in the foothills of the Catskills. The inspector who checked out the property failed to note three critical facts: The house had three flat roofs (in snow country), no drainage from the muddy crawl space and no insulation under the floors.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) TRANCE (2013) Danny Boyles thriller begins in an auction house, where the heist of a Goya leaves Simon (James McAvoy), an employee charged with safeguarding the work, with amnesia and unable to reveal where the painting is. Vincent Cassel plays Franck, the leader of the men behind the theft  and, it turns out, Simons business partner. And Rosario Dawson, above, is the hypnotherapist who holds the key to Simons memory. Mr. Boyle, as always, works hard to cast a spell in Trance, and his energy and commitment to the audiences entertainment are evident in every scene, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film from the director of Trainspotting and Slumdog Millionaire. But there are times when it feels as if hes throwing everything at the screen  the throbbing music, bleeding fingers, narrative U-turns and the startling sight of a naked Ms. Dawson striding toward the camera as strategically shorn as a Renaissance nude  less because he wants to distract you from the big reveal than to obscure the materials thinness. She added, That doesnt lessen the movies appeal while youre watching it, though it drastically shortens the afterglow.

title: A Racing Giants Final Stretch
description: Amid pomp and circumstance, on a rainy Sunday at Saratoga Race Course, Tom Durkin offered his final race calls in much the way he always has.

title: Counterintuitive Adjustment Helps Caroline Wozniacki Upset Maria Sharapova at U.S. Open
description: Caroline Wozniacki adjusted and adjusted again, and finally found the secret sauce to upset Maria Sharapova at the United States Open on Sunday.

title: Decaying Guantnamo Defies Closing Plans
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  One sweltering afternoon last month, a Boeing C-17 military transport plane arrived at the American naval base here. It had come to take six low-level detainees to new lives in Uruguay after 12 years of imprisonment.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 1, 2014
description: Its a long way from being closed.

title: Corrections: September 1, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Ukraine Conflict Has Been a Lift for China, Scholars Say
description: Which country has emerged as a winner in the Ukraine crisis?

title: Samsung Groups Shipbuilding and Engineering Arms to Merge
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The shipbuilding and engineering arms of the Samsung Group announced a plan on Monday to merge by the end of the year, in another sign that restructuring is gaining speed at the company, South Koreas largest conglomerate, in apparent response to the faltering health of its leader.

title: Revisiting Life and Death in Africa
description: Correction appended below.

title: Fabio Luisi Has a New Gig
description: Fabio Luisi, the music director of the Zurich Opera and principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, has a new gig: On Monday, he will be named principal conductor of the Danish National Symphony Orchestra.

title: Heineken to Sell Mexican Packaging Unit to Crown Holdings
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Mexican packaging operations to Crown Holdings Inc. in a deal that valued the business at about $1.2 billion.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Emily Bazelon on Medical Abortion Through the Mail
description: Emily Bazelon, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about the online distribution of medical abortions. Bazelon, who is the Truman Capote Fellow for Creative Writing and Law at Yale Law School, is the author of Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy.

title: Fund Manager Neil Woodford Sells HSBC Stake on Risk of Fines
description: LONDON  Neil Woodford, an influential fund manager in Britain, said on Monday that he had sold his stake in the British bank HSBC over concerns about rapidly escalating fines by regulators in the banking industry.

title: Pakistani Protesters Ransack State Television Headquarters
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans political crisis deepened on Monday when protesters stormed the headquarters of the state-run television network, causing a temporary lapse in transmission until army troops regained control and secured the building.

title: Daily Report: Start-Ups Stockpile Funding for Harder Times to Come
description: Silicon Valley has more money than it knows what to do with these days, leaving venture capitalists and other investors practically begging elite start-ups to take their cash. And the entrepreneurs are happy to oblige, William Alden reports.

title: As Ukraine Talks Resume, Putin and Poroshenko Trade Barbs
description: MOSCOW  The presidents of Russia and Ukraine traded oblique criticisms of each other on Monday for the lack of progress in ending the conflict in southeastern Ukraine, even as mediators started a new effort to achieve a deal.

title: What Happens When Health Plans Compete
description: As a candidate in 2008, President Obama promised that health reform would reduce family premiums by up to $2,500, equivalent today to about a 15 percent reduction from the 2013 level. Though Mr. Obama might have been including the effects of premium subsidies in his calculation, a key premise of the Affordable Care Act is that competition among health insurers will drive premiums downward. So its worth asking: How much savings can additional competition produce?

title: Parent Stabs to Death 3 Students and Teacher at School in China
description: BEIJING  A man stabbed to death three students and a teacher and wounded five other students before jumping to his death in Hubei Province on Monday, according to a police statement issued in the municipality of Shiyan, where the school is located, and a Twitter post by China Central Television.

title: Democracy Backers in Hong Kong Face Tough Choices
description: HONG KONG  For more than a year, Democrats in Hong Kong have threatened to disrupt Asias most important financial center with a sit-in protest if the central government in Beijing put onerous restrictions on a voting plan here.

title: Foreign Forces in League With Hong Kongs Democrats Include Gandhi, King, Jesus
description: Chinas leaders are onto something. Hong Kong citizens pushing for more democracy are indeed, as Peoples Daily, the Chinese Communist Party newspaper, said, colluding with external forces. At the top of the list of foreigners influencing the movement: Gandhi, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Jesus Christ.

title: School Daze
description: TIMES INSIDER  Welcome to the September Times Insider Puzzle Pack. Everyone hopes for a mild and merciful transition from summer to fall, but whether we like it or not, well eventually need to be prepared for the cold weather.

title: New Nick Cave Sculptures, a History of High Heels and More from the Cultural Calendar
description: Monday, New YorkPick up prints from a duo of award-winning designers.Dexter Sinister is both an enterprise and an ethos. Stuart Bailey and David Reinfurt write, curate and publish their own boutique art books with a focus on power through efficiency. Their new presentation at the exhibition space of the bookstore McNally Jackson, W.A.S.T.E, offers ninelithographic prints coupled with essays and commentary on the profligate practices of todays publishing industry.Picture Room at McNally Jackson, 236 Mulberry Street, mcnallyjacksonstore.com.

title: German Broadcaster Is Urged to Speak for Press Freedom in China
description: Updated, 7:44 a.m. |

title: 1914: Russian Army Scores Victory
description: Every particle of evidence available indicates that Russia, in addition to the victories she has won over the Germans in Eastern Prussia, has inflicted a staggering defeat on the Austrian armies in Galicia. The Austrian right wing was turned and cut to pieces. The Russians took 30,000 prisoners. Along the Vistula, where the Russians attacked the Austrian left wing, fortune fluctuated for a little time, until the arrival of a strong body of reinforcements enabled the Russians to make an offensive movement of overwhelming effect and to drive back the enemy and capture a great number of cannon. The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1914

title: China Authorizes Local Governments to Issue Bonds
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Finance Ministry released on Monday a long list of amendments to the countrys budget law that included removing a 20-year ban on local and regional governments from issuing bonds.

title: Drone Developers Consider Obstacles That Cannot Be Flown Around
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The tech industrys enthusiasm for building small delivery drones may be getting ahead of figuring out what to do with them.

title: Is Rational Water Management Finally Emerging in Dry California?
description: I encourage you to read Felicity Barringers article on Californias effort (finally!) to exert some control on groundwater pumping.

title: Seeking Facts, Justices Settle for What Briefs Tell Them
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court received more than 80 friend-of-the-court briefs in the Hobby Lobby case. Most of these filings, also called amicus briefs, were dull and repetitive recitations of familiar legal arguments.

title: A Twitter Full of Made-Up Words, an Avant-Garde Fashion Instagram and More
Christie Studies Foreign Affairs for a 2016 Test
description: A few days after Russian forces invaded Crimea, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was asked at a confidential meeting of Republican activists how he would have handled the situation differently from President Obama.

title: High Health Plan Deductibles Weigh Down More Employees
description: Anita Maina was working on an arts and crafts project she found on Pinterest  creating a table out of wood and cork  when she ripped off a fingernail while removing staples from a piece of wood.

title: Obama Calls for Minimum Wage Rise and Equal Pay as Elections Approach
description: MILWAUKEE  President Obama on Monday renewed his call to raise the federal minimum wage and to protect the right to equal pay for women as the midterm elections come into sight.

title: Yves Carcelles Legacy
description: News of the death yesterday of Yves Carcelle, the longtime chief executive of Louis Vuitton who helped create one of the cornerstones upon which the modern luxury industry was built, has hit his former colleagues and competitors hard.

title: From Afar, the United States Seems at Odds With Its Ideals
description: Among the tear gas and the milk, the battle tanks and the upraised hands, the bottle bombs and the tender embraces, the protests in Ferguson, Mo., brought out a mysterious sign. The sign bobbed in the crowd one evening. Like so many tenuous claims, it even got to be on CNN. No one knew much about the sign, which made it more ominous. The sign said, ISIS here.

title: Business Fliers on a Budget, and Seats That Dont Budge
description: LAS VEGAS  BEN BALDANZA, chief executive of Spirit Airlines, does not seek out business travelers. Nor does Andrew C. Levy, president of Allegiant Air.

title: U.N. to Send Team to Iraq for Inquiry on ISIS Acts
description: GENEVA  The United Nations Human Rights Council decided Monday to send a fact-finding team to Iraq to investigate possible war crimes by Islamic extremists after hearing senior human rights officials detail mass killings and other atrocities committed on an unimaginable scale.

title: Politics-Minded Marine Group Targets Ocean Enemy #1
description: Randy Olson, who shifted long ago from an academic career in marine biology to a focus on filmmaking, science communication and effective storytelling, offered this Your Dot contribution on Ocean Champions. This group has the simple  if daunting  goal of electing or re-electing lawmakers who fight for the oceans. Congressional politics is a rough-and-tumble arena and the group, as Olson describes in the context of a Florida race, is not afraid to play hard. Heres his piece:

title: Ants on a Triangle
description: The first of our challenges this week came out of a recent conversation I had with Peter Norvig, director of research at Google. (Are you on fire to learn programming? Check out Dr. Norvigs Teach Yourself Programming in Ten Years.) This simple puzzle has plenty of room for exploration, so lets jump in. Its time for

title: Man, 20, Is Charged With Fatal Stabbing in S. I. Home Invasion
description: A man was charged on Monday with killing a man and seriously injuring his wife in a home invasion on Sunday night on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Israeli Couscous, Eggplant and Tomato Gratin
description: This is an eggplant Parmesan of sorts on top of a bed of Israeli couscous. If youve made fresh tomato sauce over the summer or youre still finding wonderful tomatoes at the farmers market, use fresh tomato sauce; otherwise, use canned tomatoes for your marinara sauce. You can substitute cooked grains for the Israeli couscous; if you dont tolerate gluten, try the recipe using cooked brown rice. I like to use Japanese or baby Italian eggplants.

title: Israeli Couscous with Sauted Cherry Tomatoes and Basil
description: This is a simple dish with few ingredients and lots of flavor. The sauce, inspired by Melissa Clarks Pasta with Burst Cherry Tomatoes, is incredibly sweet and wraps itself around each nugget of couscous deliciously. Cherry tomatoes break down in a hot pan in about five minutes, collapsing just enough to release some juice, which quickly thickens and caramelizes a bit. You want the tomatoes to stay mostly intact so you dont have skins floating in sauce, but you need to cook them long enough to achieve the caramelized flavor that makes a tomato sauce sweet.

title: Israeli Couscous, Bean and Tomato Salad
description: 3/4 pound ripe, sweet tomatoes, finely chopped (about 1 1/3 cups chopped)

title: Romaine Salad with Couscous Confetti
description: This is a lemony, colorful mix of romaine, couscous and peppers. You can use regular couscous or Israeli couscous. I categorize this as a salad with grains rather than a grain salad (I know, couscous isnt a grain, but it plays a grainy role here), as theres more lettuce than couscous.

title: Brown Rice and Barley Salad with Sprouted Red Lentils and Green Beans
description: Ive been making iterations of this hearty whole grain salad tossed with a creamy, curry-spiced dressing since my earliest days of vegetarian cooking. My choice of grains for this version was a function of what I found in my pantry and my refrigerator: enough brown rice and barley to combine for a salad but not enough for a more substantial dish. Farro or spelt would also work. The split red lentils, soaked just long enough to soften and begin to sprout, contribute color and texture along with their grassy flavor. Tossing the grains with lemon juice while theyre still warm intensifies the flavors.

title: Solar Company Seeks Stiff U.S. Tariffs to Deter Chinese Spying
description: In the daunting battle against corporate online espionage worldwide, one major solar company wants to deploy a powerful and novel weapon: higher tariffs.

title: Supporting South Carolina Football
description: Images of the Gamecocks supporters on the football teams opening night, including of the donors Joe and Lisa Rice and the universitys tailgating scene.

title: Parents Who Left Britain With Ill Son Fight Order to Return
description: LONDON  The wrenching tale of a British boy with a brain tumor and his parents, who were arrested after fleeing the country with him to seek treatment abroad, entered a new phase on Monday as the parents attended an extradition hearing in Madrid and refused to return to Britain.

title: A Photographers Paradise in America
description: Soon after arriving in New York in the mid-1960s, Jean-Pierre Laffont discovered that  unlike anywhere else  his new neighbors respected him and his profession.

title: On Rockaway Reef, Taking Dinner to Go, on the Point of a Spear
description: Aboard a vessel known as the Spearboat on a recent Monday afternoon, the squeak of rubber fins on a fiberglass floor mixed with the wheeze of divers taking in big gulps of air. Tanned hands rubbed diluted hair conditioner onto the inside of neoprene suits. The boats captain, a steely Russian immigrant named Yuri Krainov, eyes striped by sunglass tan lines, quieted the engine as he steered toward a spot over the artificial Rockaway Reef, in the waters near Breezy Point.

title: A Lab Among the Leaves
description: To prove a decades-old hypothesis about how nutrients are transported in plants, a biologist set up shop 40 feet high in a red oak tree.

title: In Interviews, 3 Americans Held in North Korea Plead for U.S. Help
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea granted two United States news organizations interviews with three incarcerated Americans on Monday, with each prisoner apologizing for violating its laws and beseeching Washington to send a high-level emissary to negotiate their release.

title: Exploring a Tree One Cell at a Time
description: PETERSHAM, Mass.  Not every scientist would choose to spend a peaceful summer Sunday morning perched on a jittery scaffold 40 feet up a red oak tree, peering through a microscope to jab a leaf with a tiny glass needle filled with oil.

title: The Role of Social Media in Wiping Out Passenger Pigeons, and Conserving Species Now
description: Updated, 8:15 p.m. | As you may have noted, this is the centennial of the extinction, on Sept. 1, 1914, of the passenger pigeon, which once darkened skies in flocks of a billion or more birds. First, heres a look back at one of the odder ramifications in 1937  a market in rare passenger pigeon eggs:

title: Giving Robots That Human Touch, How Trees Really Work, Low Carb Versus Low Fat
description: Robots may already think faster than we do, but they are just starting to be able to move like us; one researcher has set out to prove an 84-year-old hypothesis about how trees move nutrients around; a lower-carb, higher-fat diet may be better for you than a low-fat diet.

title: An Icy Answer to the Mystery of the Moving Death Valley Stones
description: Researchers have solved a longstanding mystery that has befuddled scientists and tourists alike: why rocks on a dry lake bed in Death Valley National Park in California occasionally move.

title: In Performance | Conrad Tao
description: The pianist and composer Conrad Tao performs the third movement of Prokofievs Seventh Piano Sonata.

title: Inflation, Septaphobia, and the Shock Doctrine
description: The bad news from Europe is a reminder that the basic insight some of us have been trying to convey, mostly in vain, ever since 2008 remains valid: the great danger facing advanced economies is that governments and central banks will do too little, not too much. The risk of elevated inflation or fiscal difficulties is dwarfed by the risk of ending up trapped in a deflationary vortex. This view has been overwhelmingly supported by recent experience  if you acted on what they were saying on CNBC or the WSJ editorial page, you would have lost a lot of money. Yet the power of the hard money/fiscal austerity orthodoxy (yes, market monetarists want one without the other, but they have no constituency) remains immense. Why?

title: Yves Carcelle, Empire Builder at Louis Vuitton, Dies at 66
description: PARIS  Yves Carcelle, the charismatic executive who transformed Louis Vuitton from a staid French maker of handbags and travel trunks into one of the worlds most recognizable luxury brands, died on Sunday in Paris. He was 66.

title: Novak Djokovic and Serena Williams Escape U.S. Open Heat as Quickly as Possible
description: Serena Williamss name had just been announced as the winner at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday afternoon when Novak Djokovic, the No. 1 seed in the mens draw, seemed to wake to the realization that he was battling more than just the veteran Philipp Kohlschreiber.

title: Kate Bush Bombards British Album Chart
description: Kate Bush set the bar high for herself when her 1978 debut single, Wuthering Heights, topped the British music charts, making her the first woman to have a self-written No. 1 in the United Kingdom. More than three decades later, Ms. Bush, 56, is setting records again.

title: How Fighting in Pakistan Affects War Against Polio
description: Fierce fighting in Pakistan is harming and helping the countrys drive to eradicate polio.

title: 1939: German Troops Invade Poland
description: War broke out in Europe yesterday at about dawn. Nazi German troops invaded Poland  Warsaw sources said on four fronts  and, last night, with bombing planes and tanks were striving to break down the resistance of Marshal Smigly Rydzs armies. As Warsaw invoked its pact with France and Britain, both nations prepared to carry out their pledge by decreeing general mobilization and warning Hitler the promise to Poland would be fulfilled if he did not halt hostilities and order his men back to the Reich. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1939

title: Carrying the Burden of Longevity
description: I met Meryl Comer once, briefly, at a conference, and recall the juxtaposition of her sleek beauty and harrowing personal story: her husband, once chief of hematology and oncology at the National Institutes of Health, debilitated by early-onset Alzheimers disease, and her mother with the late-onset variety, both living in her suburban Maryland home, under her care.

title: Tiny, Vast Windows Into Human DNA
description: In the history of biology, two little animals loom large.

title: Carol Vadnais, All-Star and Stalwart on the Rangers, Dies at 68
description: Carol Vadnais, a six-time N.H.L. All-Star who played for Stanley Cup championship teams with the Montreal Canadiens and the Boston Bruins and who became a mainstay of the Rangers defense in the 1970s and early 80s, died on Sunday in Laval, Quebec. He was 68.

title: Geckos on Mission Die Aboard Russian Spacecraft
description: MOSCOW  Five geckos launched into space by Russia for an experiment on sexual reproduction in near-zero gravity were found dead on Monday after their spacecraft returned to earth, the Russian space agency Roscosmos announced in a statement.

title: British Leaders Plan Targets Jihadists Passports
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron, trying to show toughness in the face of young British Muslims going off to fight in Syria and Iraq, proposed legislation on Monday that would give the police the power to seize the passports of Britons suspected of having traveled abroad to fight with militant groups.

title: Patient Voices: Pancreatic Cancer
description: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Seven men and women speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.

title: 2 Sides Cite Discrimination as Battle on Texas Voting Law Heads to Court
description: HOUSTON  Minority groups and Democrats in Texas have loudly opposed a state law requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification before casting their ballots. But one of the laws biggest critics can be found not in Texas but in Washington  Eric H. Holder Jr., the United States attorney general.

title: NATO Weighs Rapid Response Force for Eastern Europe
description: WASHINGTON  As Ukrainian leaders warned on Monday of a great war with Russia, NATO leaders meeting in Wales this week were expected to endorse their most concrete response yet to increased Russian military intervention in Ukraine: establishing a rapid-reaction force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe, officials of the alliance said.

title: With Coughlin Preaching Patience, a Rookie Receiver Is Taking Time to Heal
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For several months, Tom Coughlins mood when it comes to Odell Beckham Jr.s nagging hamstring injury has mirrored the attitude of most Giants fans.

title: From Jouvert to the Parade
description: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West Indian American Day Parade.

title: From Jouvert to the Parade
description: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West American Indian Day Parade.

title: Libyan Militias Seize Control of Capital as Chaos Rises
description: CAIRO  The government of Libya said Monday that it had lost control of its ministries to a coalition of militias that had taken over the capital, Tripoli, in another milestone in the disintegration of the state.

title: If 2 New Yorkers Shared a Cab ...
description: It may be anathema to New Yorkers. But a team of mathematicians and engineers has calculated that if taxi riders were willing to share a cab, New York City could reduce the current fleet of 13,500 taxis up to 40 percent, in that way unclogging traffic, conserving fuel and fighting air pollution.

title: Lars von Trier Returning to TV
description: The Danish director Lars von Trier is planning to make his first television series in two decades, a producer for the project recently announced. The English-language series will be titled The House That Jack Built and produced by Louise Vesth, who first spoke about the project while promoting her latest collaboration with Mr. von Trier, a five-and-a-half-hour directors cut of his film Nymphomaniac, at the Venice Film Festival.

title: Fast-Food Workers Seeking $15 Wage Are Planning Civil Disobedience
description: The next round of strikes by fast-food workers demanding higher wages is scheduled for Thursday, and this time labor organizers plan to increase the pressure by staging widespread civil disobedience and having thousands of home-care workers join the protests.

title: A Playwright Named Desire: The Battle for Art and Sanity
description: The first rule of biography, the writer Justin Kaplan was known to say, is: Shoot the widow. But John Lahrs new biography, Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh, originated with something closer to a literary commando raid.

title: A Call for a Low-Carb Diet That Embraces Fat
description: People who avoid carbohydrates and eat more fat, even saturated fat, lose more body fat and have fewer cardiovascular risks than people who follow the low-fat diet that health authorities have favored for decades, a major new study shows.

title: Painful Class Conflict and Youthful Disaffection: Everybody Sing!
description: In a black-walled basement room at an East Village karaoke bar, we received the welcome news: No one would be forced to sing. The makers of Dead Behind These Eyes, which is billed as a karaoke play, understand the need in this era of immersive theater to keep the bashful from bolting.

title: Renters Insurance Offers a Hedge Against Dorm-Room Mayhem
description: In the excitement of heading off to college, students may not stop to think about whether they need insurance for all the possessions theyre bringing with them. But that laptop, stereo and other expensive devices  not to mention textbooks  may be worth protecting with a renters policy.

title: Country Gal Feels the Pressure of Being Tough
description: BETHEL, N.Y.  Miranda Lambert has proved, over a decade-long major-label career, that vulnerability and nuance can share an agenda with her higher-proof concerns: the heady blend of whiskey, tobacco and reprisal that has defined a country-spitfire persona. Shes now one of the biggest names in her field, and evidently regards her platform as a chance for something greater than self-definition.

title: A Stroll Among the Racks
description: They still give tours of the New York garment district. In Dressing America: Tales From the Garment Center, a one-hour documentary Tuesday on WNET in New York, Michael Kaback, a tour guide, points out important buildings: 498, 500 and 512. If you were part of the rag trade, as people in the business seem to love to call it, you never bothered with the rest of the address (Seventh Avenue), he explains. But you may also notice the people walking on the sidewalk behind Mr. Kaback, almost all dressed in T-shirts and jeans.

title: New Music From Earth, Yob and Jeezy
description: EARTH

title: A Life Lost in Translation Without Much to Translate
description: Like his critically acclaimed 2008 best seller, Netherland, Joseph ONeills new novel, The Dog, concerns a man who finds himself increasingly isolated after the unraveling of a relationship, and stranded in a foreign city.

title: Readers Thoughts on Spotless Minds and Big Weddings
description: Social science

title: A Performance Hybrid as Unexpected as Dance on the Radio
description: Things not usually found in a modern dance show in New York: batons, bubbles, disco balls, tinsel and public-radio personalities. But those and other sparkly accouterments were on hand recently in a Brooklyn studio where the dancers Monica Bill Barnes and Anna Bass, in Rat Pack-style suits one minute and slinky sequin gowns with sneakers the next, rehearsed for the New York premiere of their show Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host, at Town Hall, Sept. 10 to 12.

title: The New History Wars
description: WASHINGTON  WITH the news dominated by stories of Americans dying at home and abroad, it might seem trivial to debate how history is taught in our schools. But if we want students to understand what is happening in Missouri or the Middle East, they need an unvarnished picture of our past and the skills to understand and interpret that picture. People dont kill one another just for recreation. They have reasons. Those reasons are usually historical.

title: Why New York City Opposed Abe Lincoln
description: New York may have been the largest city in the Union during the Civil War, but most of its inhabitants were strongly opposed to the conflict  if not downright hostile to the Unions war aims. During the secession crisis of 1861, the pro-Confederate mayor Fernando Wood even proposed seceding from the Union and establishing itself as an independent city-state, neither for nor against the North or the South.

title: The Pleasures of Drinking, and the Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Leveling the College Playing Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Defusing Bot
description: A robot with dexterous hands is able to uncover and disarm a mock improvised explosive device. The project was a collaboration of Johns Hopkins University, HDT Robotics, Synbotics and Silvus.

title: Idealism on Screen and Behind the Scenes
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  There is no place for cynicism in the reviewing of art. Those words  a line of dialogue from Mr. Turner, Mike Leighs splendid, sprawling film about the life and loves of an artist in mid-19th-century England  are a fine motto at any time, but they are especially germane in the season of film festival frenzy. Looking at movies and thinking about the prizes they might win is a relatively benign and locally contagious form of cynicism. The antidote is the idealism, the sincere love of the cinema, that also flourishes here, nearly 9,000 feet above sea level and almost six months away from the Oscars.

title: Clemency Project Gears Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Block Stacking Bot
description: Stacking blocks may seem like an easy task for a human, but robots have long struggled with such fine control. HDTs Adroit manipulator uses force-sensing and vision to accomplish the delicate task.

title: The Conundrum of American Power in Todays World
Upgrades, and Higher Prices, for Airport Hotels
description: The airport hotel, that bastion of utility and convenience for marooned travelers, is having a banner year. In the first four months of 2014, hotels in the United States situated near airports sold a collective 27.2 million rooms, a record, according to the hotel research company STR.

title: The Anchor as Buddy, Confessional but Chill
description: As a 12-year-old nightly news addict in Syracuse, David Muir wrote a letter to the lead anchor of the local CBS affiliate, Ron Curtis, asking him how to become a TV reporter.

title: Not Just to Get to the Other Side
description: Q. Why would slugs risk trying to cross a road, as I have observed on my morning jogs? Many of them dry out and die.

title: Brainy, Yes, but Far From Handy
description: STANFORD, Calif.  In factories and warehouses, robots routinely outdo humans in strength and precision. Artificial intelligence software can drive cars, beat grandmasters at chess and leave Jeopardy! champions in the dust.

title: The Oldest Known Muscle Tissues Are Found
description: The oldest known muscle tissues have been found, researchers report, in the fossilized tissues of a soft-bodied creature that shares an ancestor with modern sea anemones, jellyfish and corals.

title: Roadside Adventures Result in a Book on Business
description: IVE always loved traveling, but I dont think I ever loved flying. Its not that I get nervous, or even really get in a bad mood on the way to the airport. But Im just not crazy about flying.

title: Incentives Aid A.P. Science and Math Scores
Are Antidepressants Safe During Pregnancy?
description: Pregnant women often go to great lengths to give their babies a healthy start in life. They quit smoking, skip the chardonnay, switch to decaf, forgo aspirin. They say no to swordfish and politely decline Brie.

title: Six-Error Game Is Nothing New to the Mets
description: When you make six errors in a game, as the Mets did on Monday in losing to the Marlins, 9-6, in Miami, the inevitable question to ask is whether there has ever been a game in which their fielding was worse.

title: A Mission for Remote-Controlled Bugs
description: Researchers from North Carolina State University are trying to turn a living moth into a remote-controlled robot, or biobot. By attaching tiny electrodes to the moth, they can monitor the electrical signals the moth uses flight to communicate with its muscles. The researchers, also working on a similar project with cockroaches, believe that insect biobots could be used to search through rubble during rescue missions.

title: Signs of Literary Life for Two Booksellers on the Upper West Side
description: Print is not dead yet  at least not on the Upper West Side.

title: Birth Weight and Diabetes
description: African-Americans born at low birth weight are at an increased risk for Type 2 diabetes later in life, a new study has found.

title: Batting 1.000: Headley Has a Hit in Every Park
description: Chase Headley had one crack at it, one chance to do it after nearly eight full seasons in Major League Baseball.

title: A Benefit of Legal Marijuana
description: Policy makers have suggested a variety of strategies to reduce injury and death from prescription opioid overdose, including drug-monitoring programs, scrutiny of doctors writing prescriptions and improved access to substance-abuse treatment.

title: Of Little Help to Older Knees
description: Middle-aged and older patients are unlikely to benefit in the long term from surgery to repair tears in the meniscus, pads of cartilage in the knee, a new review of studies has found.

title: Obamas Messy Words
description: There are things that you think and things that you say.

title: Research Aimed at the Heart of the Sun
description: With the aid of a powerful instrument, researchers have detected subatomic particles produced by fusion reactions at the very core of the sun.

title: Seeing Discolored Lawns, California Businesses Apply Dab of Green
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  The spray-paint nozzle was aimed carefully at the edge as the painter stood back a few inches from the flat metal shovel meant to protect other surfaces. After laying down a couple of thin coats, he stepped back to admire his work.

title: On Authenticity, American Chopper and Investments
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, the media and popular culture.

title: Germany to Arm Kurds Battling ISIS
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel told lawmakers on Monday that her government had decided to break with a taboo on delivering weapons to conflict zones because Germany and all of Europe faced a security threat from the extremists of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Trying to Rebuild a Kurdish Defense Force
description: When ISIS militants rolled into Kurdistan in August, the collapse of the pesh merga left tens of thousands of defenseless residents in ISIS path.

title: Small Donations Fueled Most Wide-Open Mayoral Race Last Year, Board Says
description: At nearly every turn, the New York City mayoral election of 2013 was colored by the man who wasnt running: City Halls departing tenant, Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: An International Break
description: The decision by Tony Parker, Frances most famous basketball player, to skip the World Cup alters the countrys expectations but provides a reminder of an approaching eventuality.

title: Tarnishing a Reputation as Storied Warriors
description: ERBIL, Iraq  For decades, the pesh merga have enjoyed a fearsome reputation as unconquered mountain warriors, a storied band of guerrilla fighters who became the official guardians of the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq. But when fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria rolled into Kurdistan in August, the pesh merga fled the front line, just a half-hours drive from the territorial capital, Erbil.

title: France Realigns Without a Star
description: STRASBOURG, France  A few minutes after Frances national basketball team finished a training session recently, the players folded their considerable frames into chairs behind a row of tables with black markers scattered on them. For the next half-hour, the players dutifully signed their names for the smattering of fans who came to the tiny gym here on the outskirts of town.

title: The Revolt of the Weak
description: The toughest part of governing is the effect on the mind of those who govern. As Henry Kissinger said, once you get in government you are not building up human capital; you are just spending it down. People in senior positions are simply too busy to learn fundamental new viewpoints. Their minds are locked within the ones they brought into power.

title: For Novak Djokovic, One Point Makes the Difference at the U.S. Open
description: Tennis matches have defining moments where the noise of many points is reduced to the silence of just one.

title: Still Time for a Conservation Legacy
description: Wednesday is the 50th birthday of two of the nations most important environmental statutes: the Wilderness Act and the law establishing the Land and Water Conservation Fund. For those with long memories, it also commemorates a time when Congress could act productively in a bipartisan spirit that yielded not only these two laws but, within a few short years, landmark protections for clean air, clean water and endangered species.

title: After a Fathers Plea, Few in Missouri Try to Disrupt Traffic
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The father of the unarmed black teenager who was shot and killed by a white police officer here last month asked protest organizers on Monday to postpone their planned shutdown of highway traffic in the St. Louis region.

title: Boot Camp for Bankers
description: Robert Vickers struggled not to grin, but the camouflage-clad drill sergeant caught him anyway.

title: Billboard Drives Home Extent of Corruption as Schools Suffer
description: MEXICO CITY  All over Mexico, children have begun making their way to school for the start of a new year  many stepping into run-down buildings without running water, new textbooks or trained teachers.

title: The Human Toll of Offshoring
description: The subtitle of Beth Macys new book, Factory Man  How One Furniture Maker Battled Offshoring, Stayed Local, and Helped Save an American Town  gives every impression that it is going to be an upbeat read, a capitalistic feel-good story.

title: Ways to Reduce the Kidney Shortage
description: The United States and many other nations are confronting a heart-rending problem: The number of kidneys available for transplants falls far short of the need.

title: New Voter Guide Follows the Money
description: Can information about which candidates people give money to produce a better voter guide?

title: The New Political Rating System That Shows the Stakes This Year
description: Any one of five or six campaigns could determine which party wins control of the Senate in November. Yet the race in Iowa is worth an extra dash of attention, not only because its been among the most entertaining  full of target practice, hog castration and the Koch brothers  but also because of the ideological distance between the two candidates. Its even bigger than in many other races.

title: Father Seeks Answers in Death of Son, Who Police Say Shot Himself While Cuffed
description: NEW ORLEANS  Six months ago, the Rev. Victor White says, he stood over his sons dead body, searching for answers. What happened? How did he die? he asked as he stood in the morgue of Iberia Parish, a county in southern Louisiana best known for producing sugar cane and Tabasco hot sauce.

title: With Every U.S. Open Victory, Andy Murray Advances Gender Equity
description: Anyone who would like to see more female coaches in professional tennis might want to join the Andy Murray fan club.

title: Public Pension Funds Stay Mum on Corporate Expats
description: In the outcry about the recent merger mania to take advantage of the tax avoidance transactions known as inversions, certain key players have been notably silent: public pension funds.

title: Infrastructure Cracks as Los Angeles Defers Repairs
description: LOS ANGELES  The scene was apocalyptic: a torrent of water from a ruptured pipe valve bursting through Sunset Boulevard, hurling chunks of asphalt 40 feet into the air as it closed down the celebrated thoroughfare and inundated the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. By the time emergency crews patched the pipe, 20 million gallons of water had cascaded across the college grounds.

title: Universal Pre-K Takes Off
description: The start of public school on Thursday in New York City should be the usual merry scramble of chattering children and stressed (or relieved) parents. There will also be something new: a fresh crop of 4-year-olds, more than 50,000, embarking on the first day of free, full-day, citywide, city-run prekindergarten.

title: A Win for Chris Kirk, and a Boost for Others
description: NORTON, Mass.  The Darwinian nature of the FedEx Cup playoffs, along with the impending Ryder Cup selections, provided a host of possibilities as the 2014 Deutsche Bank Championship churned to its conclusion Monday.

title: New 96-Page Murakami Work Coming in December
description: Haruki Murakamis next book, The Strange Library, sounds surreal and experimental even for an author whose work features talking cats, giant frogs and malicious miniature people.

title: Years of Rape and Utter Contempt in Britain
description: ROTHERHAM, England  It started on the bumper cars in the childrens arcade of the local shopping mall. Lucy was 12, and a group of teenage boys, handsome and flirtatious, treated her and her friends to free rides and ice cream after school.

title: Black and White and Blue
A. J. Langguth, Author and Former Times Correspondent, Dies at 81
description: A. J. Langguth, a former Saigon bureau chief for The New York Times who went on to become an educator and an author of nonfiction books ranging from a study of the Vietnam War to a biography of the short-story writer Saki, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: Lacking a Coach, but Not an Upside
description: So, Jim Courier: If you were coaching Gal Monfils, just what would you try to change?

title: Militants Add Cluster Bombing to Tactics, Rights Group Says
description: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the extremist militant group now almost universally vilified for atrocities that include boastful beheadings, summary mass executions and enslavement in the areas it aspires to control, also has attacked enemies with cluster bombs, the banned weapons that kill and maim indiscriminately, Human Rights Watch said on Monday.

title: For Penn Station Diners, Nowhere to Go but Up
description: Some travelers entrust their stomachs, anxiously, to the tacos of Pennsylvania Station, where dark hairs and soda stains soil the dining tables above the tracks. Others make it as far as the soft pretzels, sagging meekly behind glass, or the pizza shops whose fumbled marinara sauce has fused semipermanently to the floor.

title: Visitors at Chelsea Galleries Encounter Cool Vibes, in More Ways Than One
description: Nicola Barbieri figures that during his monthlong visit to New York, he has stopped into about 60 galleries in Chelsea. And not once did he get even a hello from any of the workers at the reception desks.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 1, 2014
Israel: U.N. Chief Criticizes Seizing of West Bank Land
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations added his voice on Monday to the criticism of Israel over its seizing of nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land in a Jewish settlement bloc near Bethlehem. Israels action on Sunday, Mr. Ban said in a statement, risks paving the way for further settlement activity, which  as the United Nations has reiterated on many occasions  is illegal under international law and runs totally counter to the pursuit of a two-state solution. Palestinians, who aspire to create a state on territories captured by Israel in the 1967 war, denounced the new land seizure by Israel and said it would further aggravate relations, less than a week after a cease-fire agreement brokered by Egypt was reached to halt 50 days of fighting between Israeli forces and Palestinian militants in Gaza. American and British officials also criticized the land seizing, calling it counterproductive, while Egypts Foreign Ministry said it would have negative consequences on the peace process.

title: Champion Shows Few Signs of Slowing
description: There she was warming up in the midday sun, in pancakes of humidity that called to mind midsummer Manila, wearing a black petticoat. Just to look at her smacking balls in that garb was to feel the sweat start to trickle down your back.

title: More School Daze
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome back after the holiday weekend! Hope you all had a wonderful time enjoying the last days of summer.

title: Influx of African Immigrants Shifting National and New York Demographics
description: Threatened with arrest in 2009, Lamin F. Bojang fled Gambia after publicly contradicting its presidents claims that he could cure AIDS. Now 31, Mr. Bojang lives in Concourse Village in the Bronx with his wife and 2-year-old son and works as a receptionist at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, while working toward a bachelors degree in political science at City College.

title: U.S. Troops Take Action on Militants in Somalia
description: American military forces launched an operationin Somalia on Mondayagainst the Qaeda-linked militant networkthe Shabab, defense officials said.

title: On Sidelines, Researchers See C.E.O.s
description: In late 2012, Arkansas hired Bret Bielema as its football coach, paying him a salary of $3.2 million a year, plus bonuses, making him one of the best-compensated coaches in his industry and his states highest-paid employee.

title: Despite Strength, Cuomos Re-election Bid Is Hardly a Coronation
description: He has been snubbed by unions representing teachers and state workers. Editorial boards are skewering him. Political rivals are lobbing attacks from his left and his right.

title: A Rabbis Spiritual Playground Extends to the Surf
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Rabbi Hanniel Levenson had a problem. He had to teach Hebrew to a group of boys. It was his job.

title: Comparing Military Hospitals
description: Fifty-four military hospitals provide inpatient services in the U.S. and overseas. Many compare poorly to leading civilian hospitals on measures of safety in maternity and surgical care.

title: Smaller Military Hospitals Said to Put Patients at Risk
description: HINESVILLE, Ga.  Every year, more than 25,000 Americans undergo surgery to correct a hiatal hernia, a condition in which tissue from the stomach bulges into the chest cavity through a hole in the diaphragm. The hernias often return, but major complications are rare. Hospital stays are usually short.

title: After Years of Frostiness, a Selective Co-op Tries a Friendlier Facade
description: Even two or three years ago, it would have been all but impossible to write this column. At River House, the mythic and monolithic co-op overlooking the East River, the only thing stouter than the limestone brick walls towering above East 52nd Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive were the buildings standards. Those inside would call them traditions; everybody else might regard them as pretensions. Almost no one got in, and news barely escaped.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 2, 2014
description: People dont think about the fact that there are pipes under the ground that are 100 years old until one blows. You dont hear a politician say, Im going to make your pipes work.

title: The New Unofficial Scent of New York City
description: As a co-founder of the international fragrance design trade show Elements, Frederick Bouchardy has sniffed countless New York-inspired scents over the years  but I never found one that smelled like New York to me, the Manhattan native says. Next month, Bouchardy, who is also the brains behind the Brooklyn-based fragrance studio Joya, offers his olfactory take on his hometown with the launch of a new perfume oil, Foxglove. I grew up on the Upper West Side across the street from Central Park, he says, so the Park was my initial muse, and then it became an exploration of the entire botanical history of all the parks and wetlands here.

description: Updated, 12:52 p.m. |

description: transcendent \tran(t)-sen-dnt\ adjective

title: Childhood Diet Habits Set in Infancy, Studies Suggest
description: Efforts to improve what children eat should begin before they even learn to walk, a series of nutritional studies published on Tuesday has found. Taken together, the data indicate that infant feeding patterns persist far longer than  has been appreciated.

title: Corrections: September 2, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Idzik Says Jets Have No Regrets in Cutting Patterson
description: When the Jets announced last week that cornerback Dimitri Pattersons indefinite suspension had been lifted, and that he was eligible to return Monday, there seemed to be a chance that he would have a future with the team. If he made amends with his teammates and coaches, handled his punishment with grace, then perhaps he could become a Jet in good standing.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE STORY OF FROZEN: MAKING A DISNEY ANIMATED CLASSIC The Walt Disney Animation Studios open their doors to trace the evolution of the Oscar-winning blockbuster Frozen through interviews with the cast members Kristen Bell (the voice of Anna) and Idina Menzel (Elsa); John Lasseter, the studios chief creative officer; Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee, the films directors; and Robert Lopez and Kristen Anderson-Lopez, its songwriters. The program also visits the Norwegian villages and landscapes that inspired the fictional kingdom of Arendelle, above, and offers a preview of Big Hero 6, the studios next animation release. Josh Gad, who lent his voice to Olaf, hosts.

title: With Land Scarce, Chinese School Builds Rooftop Track
description: Updated, 12:27 a.m. ET| Space is at a premium in the cities of eastern China. Property prices have been surging for years. On Tuesday, the official Twitter accounts of Peoples Daily, Xinhua and China Central Television, all state news organizations, posted striking photographs of how one primary school in Tiantai County, Zhejiang Province, is coping with the urban squeeze.

title: Chinese Companys Shares Suspended on Critical Report
description: Updated, 8:45 a.m. | HONG KONG  Trading in shares of Tianhe Chemicals, a Chinese company that  raised about $650 million in a Hong Kong listing in June, was suspended late Tuesday morning after a report on a website affiliated with short-sellers described the company as one of the largest stock market frauds ever conceived.

title: National Goals Still Murky After Zhejiang Church Razings
description: Crosses continue to be torn down, churches bulldozed and shrines of folk religions destroyed in a campaign that began last winter in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, but the implications for national religious policy in China remain unclear, a leading Protestant expert on religion in China said.

description: Below are three paragraphs from A Bit of Caution Beneath the Thump, the Aug. 31 review of last weeks Electric Zoo concert in New York City.

description: Telecom Italia said on Tuesday that it had extended to Sept. 25 the deadline to complete the sale of its controlling stake in Telecom Argentina to the investment firm Fintech Advisory.

description: In An Icy Answer to the Mystery of the Moving Death Valley Stones, Henry Fountain writes about the longstanding mystery that has befuddled scientists and tourists alike at Death Valley National Park.

title: 3 Universities Pledge to Uphold Party Ideals on Campus
description: The Communist Party committees of three prestigious Chinese universities have pledged to uphold ideological controls over their students and faculty.

title: When Buildings Are Political, Should Architects Be Politicians?
description: Autocratic leaders have always sought to preserve a legacy in architecture, from Louis XIVs lavish palace in Versailles tomonumental fascist cities.

title: German Court Bans Uber Service Nationwide
description: Updated | LONDON  The most popular service of the ride-hailing company Uber has been barred from operating in Germany in one of the most severe legal restrictions the company has faced since it was founded five years ago.

description: Good morning.

description: Good morning on this sweatsock-like Tuesday.

title: How to Use Our Blog This School Year
description: Happy academic year 2014-15! Heres what weve got on our blog and how you can use it, whether youre a teacher, a student (of any age) or a parent.

title: Putin Tells European Official That He Could Take Kiev in Two Weeks
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has told a European official that he could take Kiev in two weeks if he wanted to, adding a new dimension to the tensions building in Ukraine as Russian forces become more involved in the fighting there.

title: Hong Kongs Democracy Dilemma
description: HONG KONG  On Sunday the Standing Committee of Chinas National Peoples Congress issued restrictive guidelines for the election of Hong Kongs next chief executive in 2017. Shorn of its technical details, the proposal in effect gives Beijing the means to control who could run for the top office in Hong Kong: Voters would get to cast a ballot, but only for one of just a handful of candidates pre-selected by the Chinese government.

title: Dollar General Raises Bid for Family Dollar as Buyout Fight Heats Up
description: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Dollar General is willing to pay more to win the bidding war over Family Dollar Stores. And its takeover effort could go hostile if Family Dollar does not begin sale negotiations.

title: What to Wear This Week: Sept. 2
description: Forecast: Brace yourself. Today will be in the low 90s, a little muggy with a possible sprinkle; the rest of the week will be in the high 80s, mostly clear.

title: Daily Report: How Video Gaming Became an International Spectator Sport
description: Having already upended the entertainment world, the games industry has turned its ambitions toward the lucrative world of professional video game competition, Nick Wingfield writes in the first part of a series about the phenomenon, known as e-sports.

title: Check-In Requirements
description: A few things we need to be sure of before you board.

title: 10 Reasons to Become an Entrepreneur
description: These days, it sometimes seems that almost everyone is thinking about becoming an entrepreneur. Whether they are pursuing fame and glory, self-satisfaction, an escape from a bad boss or just money, they tend to get a lot of encouragement  from friends, from parents, from the media. That was hardly the case when I chose this path more than 30 years ago.

title: Hong Kong Paper Drops Pro-Democracy Column
description: HONG KONG  A Hong Kong hedge fund manager who rallied support from bankers and brokers for the citys pro-democracy movement said Tuesday that a leading business newspaper had dropped his long-running column.

title: 8 Youths on Run in Tennessee After Detention Center Escape
description: The teenage offenders began leaving their rooms at a Nashville detention center around 11 p.m. Monday, Tennessee officials said, roughly 30 minutes after a shift change that left fewer adults supervising the complex.

title: ISIS Antiquities Sideline
description: The territorial gains made by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have provoked fears  as well as tentative news reports  that archaeological sites in those countries are being attacked and looted, much as sites in Iraq were at the outset of the second Iraq war.

title: The New Look of Smokers Litter
description: Sadly, theres plenty of conventional trash along the popular paths of Hudson Highlands State Park near our new old home in the village of Nelsonville, N.Y. But theres a new look to the litter, as well, as I discovered yesterday on a morning dog hike when I spotted this tossed e-cigarette pack:

title: 1-800-Flowers to Buy Harry & David
description: Already one of the biggest providers of flower deliveries, 1-800-Flowers.com now wants to add Royal Riviera pears and Moose Munch snacks to its offerings.

title: Elections 2014: Make Your Own Senate Forecast
description: Create and share your own forecast for who will win the midterm elections.

title: Morning Agenda: Evans Bank Under Fire
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, New Yorks attorney general, is said to be conducting a broad investigation into whether banks are deliberately choking off mortgage lending to predominantly minority communities, known as redlining, DealBooks Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. The investigation was expected to reach its first target as early as Tuesday, people briefed on the matter said, with Mr. Schneidermans office taking aim at Evans Bank, a regional lender whose business in the Buffalo area dates to 1920, accusing it of denying mortgages to African-Americans regardless of their credit.

title: Phrases We Love Too Much
description: A careful reader alerts us to a clich in the making: on the planet.

title: In Performance: Conrad Tao
description: Conrad Tao, a pianist and a composer, has been on a roll. Last year he produced a new music festival in New York, released his first major-label album, and wrote a piece for the Dallas Symphony Orchestra for the 50th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy. This year he will be the artist-in-residence in Dallas, play concerts around the country and the world, and open the New York Youth Symphonys season Nov. 23 at Carnegie Hall. And hes only 20.

title: Lord of the Rings Trilogy, With Live Orchestra, Coming to Lincoln Center
description: Until now, when someone mentioned going to see the Ring cycle at Lincoln Center, you knew what that meant: four nights of Wagner at the Metropolitan Opera, where a complicated tale of Norse gods and various mortal beings vying for control of the gold from the Rhine unfolds cataclysmically  lately, on an expensive and rather scary piece of stage machinery.

title: Moelis & Co. Hires Cantor, Ex-House Majority Leader, as Vice Chairman
description: When Eric Cantor suffered a surprising electoral defeat this year, Washington pundits wondered where the House majority leader would end up.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Norwegian Cruise Line to Buy Prestige Cruises for $3 Billion
description: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings agreed on Tuesday to buy the privately held Prestige Cruises International for $3 billion in cash and stock, including the assumption of debt, to add higher-end trips to its fleet of offerings.

title: A Rebel and a Subway Snooper
description: Dear Diary:

title: Cavalier and Clay
description: Simon de Pury makes his art-world comeback with a sensational ceramics show.

title: Plan for Thames Estuary Airport Near London Is Rejected by Panel
The Sand Storm, Starring Ai Weiwei
description: In Jason Wishnows film, Ai plays a water deliveryman in an arid world.

title: Homework and Consequences
description: Homework is probably the number one reason I get anxious about the start of school each year.

title: Can One Brand Serve Two Bosses? The Luxottica Question
description: Ive been writing a piece about the rise of the new one-designer-two-brand generation (out this Thursday! Start the drumroll!), and whether this is a good or bad trend. So it was interesting to get the announcement by Luxottica on Monday that the companys chief executive, Andrea Guerra, was stepping down to be replaced by co-C.E.O.s: Enrico Cavatorta as chief executive of corporate functions and a C.E.O. of Markets to be named in due course.

title: Grief at Staten Island School After Football Player Collapses and Dies
description: After a 16-year-old Staten Island student dropped to the ground during a sweltering football practice on Monday afternoon, his teammates figured he would get right up.

title: To Temper Unrest in Western China, Officials Offer Money for Intermarriage
description: BEIJING  Officials in the Xinjiang region of western China are offering cash and other incentives to encourage marriages between minorities and Han, the countrys dominant ethnic group, in an effort to soothe growing ethnic violence in the region.

title: Class Interests and Monetary Policy, Take II
description: Steve Randy Waldman has a long, thoughtful take on my speculations about the hard-money preferences of the wealthy. Basically I confessed myself somewhat confused: I get why creditors should hate inflation, but aggressive monetary responses to the Lesser Depression have been good for asset prices, and hence for the wealthy. Why, then, the vociferous protests?

title: A Sharp Debate in London Seeks to Address the State Of an Overworked Airport
description: LONDON  As any pilot knows, landing an aircraft in a crosswind is a challenge. So, too, is deciding where  or whether  to build a new airport runway.

title: Should Literature Be Considered Useful?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. The critic Kenneth Burke once called literature equipment for living. This week, Adam Kirsch and Dana Stevens discuss whether literature should be valued for its utility.

title: The New Neutral
description: Gray offers an urbane alternative to the ubiquitous black or brown leather bag.

title: Publisher of The Washington Post Will Resign
description: The Washington Post announced on Tuesday that its publisher, Katharine Weymouth, was stepping down, signaling the end of the Graham familys connection to the newspaper it owned for 80 years before selling it last year to Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon.

title: Compuware Agrees to $2.5 Billion Buyout
description: Compuware has agreed to sell itself to the private equity firm Thoma Bravo for about $2.5 billion, finally bowing out after years under pressure from the activist hedge fund Elliott Management.

title: 1889: British Traders in East Africa
description: ZANZIBAR  I have just returned from Mombasa, the headquarters of the Imperial British East Africa Trading Company, and I am pleased to be able to chronicle what a difference exists in the state of affairs at that place, and at the German settlements further south. If one excepts a few turbulent spirits, the native population of Mombasa may be said to be absolutely quiet, and to be very well disposed indeed towards the Company and its servants. I attribute the excellent feeling that there predominates between natives and Europeans, at a time when the entire coast line near Zanzibar is very much disturbed, owing to the repeated aggression of the Germans.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1889

title: A Prisoners Beard Offers the Next Test of Religious Liberty for the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court comes back from its summer break next month, it will pick up where it left off, returning to the subject of religious freedom. But the courts focus will shift from corporations to prisoners.

title: 10 Years On, Scaffolding in Harlem Is Still a Shelter for Noxious Acts
description: Most nights, Roy Scott Jr. sleeps in a wheelchair, with his left arm draped over a blue scaffolding pipe, his graying curls shielded from rain by the rusting planks overhead. This is not the reason that the tunnel-like wood-and-steel structures called sidewalk sheds shroud walkways across New York City. They are supposed to catch debris from repairs overhead.

title: New Life for Some Pulp Fiction by Gore Vidal
description: In the 1950s, when Gore Vidal was at the start of his career as a novelist, he did what lots of writers do to make ends meet. Between literary novels he cranked out pulp fiction, written quickly under a pseudonym  or, in Vidals case, three pseudonyms. As Edgar Box he wrote three mystery novels, which were reprinted with his approval during his lifetime (he died in 2012). He wrote a romance novel under the name Katherine Everard that remains a rarity. And as Cameron Kay  a name he borrowed from a great uncle  he wrote Thieves Fall Out, a crime thriller set in Egypt during the 1952 revolution there.

title: Airstrike in Somalia by U.S. Forces Targets Shabab Leader
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For nearly a decade, the United States has been trying to fight the Somali Islamist group known as the Shabab, using everything from its African allies and economic sanctions to American missile strikes and commando raids.

title: You Lose, We Win: Consultants Profit Even When Candidates Underperform
description: Labor Day signals the beginning of the fall campaign for both political candidates and the consultants whom they pay hundreds of millions of dollars to help them win in November. Will these hired guns be held accountable for their performance on Election Day?

title: How to Talk to Strangers on the Subway
description: Hi! How are you doing? What are you working onright now? Ha, I hear you  I procrastinate a lot, too! Well,Ill let you get back to it. Have a great day!

title: Loyal to the Royals, Hoping for a Renaissance
