The dynamic food scene draws an international clientele and chefs from bigger cities. Theres money to preserve historic buildings and revitalize neighborhoods, like Germantown, which was established by European immigrants in the 1850s. Add a farmers market, some enticing shops and a batch of very stylish hotel rooms, and its hard not to conclude that the city is changing its tune  or at least adding a few new riffs.

title: First Vaccine for Dengue Fever Shows Promise in 2nd Big Trial
description: An experimental vaccine against dengue fever being developed by Sanofi proved about 60 percent effective in its second large clinical trial. The results could clear the way for the introduction of the worlds first inoculation against the disease, which is mosquito-borne and becoming an increasing threat.

title: Michael Sam Gains Second Chance by Joining the Cowboys Practice Squad
description: The rookie defensive lineman Michael Sam, who was released by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday, joined the practice squad of the Dallas Cowboys on Wednesday. Sam, the first openly gay player drafted by an N.F.L. team, had failed to win a spot with the Rams despite a solid showing in the preseason in which he had 11 tackles and three sacks.

title: Finnish Conductor Will Be First Woman to Lead Helsinki Philharmonic
description: Susanna Malkki, a Finnish conductor who has appeared often in New York and has made a powerful impression in both new music and the standard repertory, has been appointed chief conductor of the Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra announced. She will be the first female music director of the orchestra, which was founded in 1882 and describes itself as the first professional symphony orchestra founded in the Nordic countries.

title: Gina Sanders Named President of Global Development at Cond Nast
description: After a summer of major changes at Cond Nast, the magazine publisher has created a new role for a longtime executive, Gina Sanders, who will become president of the companys global development.

title: An Artistic Clan Under One Roof
description: Blythe Danner should have no trouble finding her way around the title structure of The Country House, the new play by Donald Margulies. In this latest offering from the author of Dinner With Friends, Ms. Danner plays the high bohemian matriarch of an artistic clan. This enduringly graceful actress knows from creative offspring, being the mother of the film star Gwyneth Paltrow and the director Jake Paltrow.

title: Surviving Battle With Amazon, Entrepreneur Picks New Fight
description: In 2007, Alan Martin was attending Webster University, pursuing a masters degree in procurement and acquisitions at a campus in Utah, when he realized he was able to sell his used textbooks for about the same price he had paid for them.

title: Court Challenge to New Inversion Rules Would Face Long Odds
description: The Treasury Department is considering new regulations that would make corporate inversions less profitable. Hedge fund managers, investment bankers and others are handicapping the timing and scope of any new rules and to whom they would apply. Possibilities include further limiting earnings stripping, reclassifying certain debt held by United States subsidiaries of foreign corporations as equity or restricting the repatriation of untaxed offshore cash from corporations that have gone through an inversion.

title: In the Studio | Jason Wu
description: Jason Wu chats with Vanessa Friedman about his evolution from a doll clothing designer working out of his living room to an established fashion designer with a sizable and sophisticated showroom.

title: Whats Inside Jason Wus Office
description: Where does a collection begin? In the mind and imagination of a designer, of course, but also in a physical space, an insider sanctum that is almost never seen by consumers: the office and atelier. In many ways, these private spaces reflect the choices and points of view that inform fashion as much as any runway show. If in doubt, simply consider the outtakes from a series of behind-the-velvet-curtain videos in which designers from New York to Paris invited The New York Times into their professional lives. First up: Jason Wu, who opened his namesake label in 2006 and shot to fame as the designer of Michelle Obamas inaugural gowns, in his New York office. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Glenn Closes Characters
description: Glenn Close is returning to Broadway for the first time in nearly 20 years to star in Edward Albees A Delicate Balance. She talks about what has drawn her to various roles in theater and film.

title: Weekly Quandary: Should You Push a Child to Play a Sport?
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary came via email: Should you make a child who is not interested sign up for a sport?

title: Balancing Bliss and Dark Sadness
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me.  When Glenn Close first visited this beach town a decade ago, she walked into a kitchen and found a stuffed white bunny in a pot on the stove. It was yet another Fatal Attraction joke, but this time, Ms. Close laughed: She was smitten with the prankster, David Shaw, a venture capitalist she had started dating. Later, on the lawn of his waterfront home, they put on inflatable sumo wrestler suits and bumped bellies until Ms. Close was flailing like a turtle on its back. They married in 2006, and Ms. Close has since become a summertime Mainer, even mastering beach bocce ball with a zeal that would impress Patty Hewes, her cutthroat character on the cable series Damages.

title: Marching While Gay: Its Now O.K.
description: The organizers of New Yorks St. Patricks Day parade have bowed to pressure and will allow a group of gay NBC employees both to march and to acknowledge while they are marching that they are, in fact, gay.

title: Hit by Russian Boycott, European Union Increases Marketing Budget for Its Farm Goods
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions agriculture commissioner said Wednesday that he planned to double the amount of money available for promoting the sale of farm goods, in an effort to counteract the effects of a boycott by Russia, an important export market for European producers.

title: Short, Spare and Spirited
description: Keep it simple. Keep it short.

title: Superhero, Psycho, Statesman (Singing!)
description: The words Broadway and musical have become so tethered in the popular imagination that it is worth reminding people that much of the most innovative musical theater in New York  make that virtually all of the most innovative musical theater in New York  happens Off Broadway. While Broadway must play it safe, relying on tried (and trite) formulas to rope in the crowds, artists can take chances Off Broadway, where the stakes are lower, the audiences more adventurous and the landscape more nurturing to new ideas.

title: France Postpones Delivery of Warship to Russia
description: PARIS  France threw a highly contentious arms deal with Russia into doubt on Wednesday over the Ukraine crisis, saying it was premature to schedule the delivery of a sophisticated French-built warship to the Russian Navy.

title: New Kids, New Kids, What a Helluva Team
description: By November 1944, the director, producer, playwright, sometime actor and full-time theater maestro George Abbott had already exerted his legendary control over Jimmy Durante, various vaudevillians looking to go legit and even, in Jumbo, a live elephant. But the roomful of tyros that had assembled in rehearsals for On the Town posed a new challenge for the 57-year-old Mr. Abbott, as everyone called him.

title: Another Argument (and Diversion) Over a Reclining Seat
description: A third flight in less than two weeks made an unscheduled landing Monday night because of passengers fighting over reclining seats. Delta Flight 2370, on its way from La Guardia Airport to Palm Beach International, was diverted to Jacksonville when one passenger began yelling at the woman sitting in front of her for reclining her seat, ABC News reported.

title: It Was Fun Being the Hero Who Saves the Day
description: In a previous post, I offered a preliminary post-mortem in which I talked about some of the things we learned from our nearly disastrous handling of one customers order. In this post, I want to wrap up this series of posts by talking about how my thinking about my own role at the company has changed.

title: In Herms Agreement, a Rare Retreat by a Luxury Deal Maker
description: Bernard Arnault has conceded defeat.

title: The Five Best Mens Collections That Wont Be Showing During Fashion Week
description: For mens wear, New York Fashion Week has become less a traditional week of shows and more a smattering of presentations. Some designers have elected to forgo presentations and editors previews altogether, including these five up-and-comers who challenge the heritage-based all-American aesthetic that has become typical of many New York mens wear labels. Here T offers an exclusive first look at their spring/summer 2015 collections.

title: Chris Cillizza Plays Our Senate Forecasting Game
description: We are inviting political experts to play our Predict the Midterms game, and well be talking to them about their entries. Our first such entrant is Chris Cillizza, founder of The Fix blog at The Washington Post.

title: How to Find Special Characters on an iPad
description: Q. I connected a Bluetooth keyboard to my iPad Air, and by accident I found a few special characters like ,  and  that appear with certain keystrokes. How do I find out the key combinations for more international characters and symbols?

title: Diversity in Action, as Well as in Words
description: It seems like a parody put together by a coalition of the activist groups that have dogged television networks for years about their halfhearted (or less) commitment to presenting a range of racial and ethnic groups among their series:

title: ZenPayroll Gives Small Business the Tech Tools of Big Business
description: Despite all the talk of this being the entrepreneurial age, the times  and technology  still favor the big guy.

title: A Long Gestation for U2s Next Album
description: U2, the Irish band formed way back in 1976, has long been feeling like a lonely upholder of the mantle of the Big Rock Band: the kind that headlines stadiums and lodges songs deep in the public consciousness. Its pealing guitars and martial beat have cast a long musical shadow over all the bands in its wake  from Coldplay to OneRepublic to Imagine Dragons  who strive to write high-minded rock anthems. Yet U2 has also sought to expand, and at times escape, its own signature sound.

title: The Road to Amerli
description: Azam Ahmed is a Times correspondent in Kabul. This week he traveled with a photographer and a fixer to Amerli, the only town to have successfully defended itself against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, to interview villagers.

title: Inviting Young Readers to Take Sides in a Crayon-Labor Dispute
description: The Day the Crayons Quit, a cheeky illustrated book about a group of disgruntled crayons who go on strike, is the kind of surprise best seller that no one sees coming. The book, which has more than a million copies in print, recently went into its 10th printing. Its been on The New York Times best-seller list for more than a year. This past July, it was optioned for film by Universal Pictures.

title: D-Day for Pre-K
description: Across New York City, teachers and parents scrambled to be ready for the start of Mayor Bill de Blasios expanded prekindergarten program on the first day of the new school year.

title: Neiman Marcus to Join the Manhattan Elite
description: It took 107 years, but Neiman Marcus is moving to Manhattan.

title: Where to Print Those Vacation Photos
description: Barry Schwartz, the psychologist and author of The Paradox of Choice, once said: With so many options to choose from, people find it very difficult to choose at all. Thats how I feel when I want to print a few vacation photos. The Internet is rife with companies willing to print your digital snapshots for little more than the cost of a Cronut. But which sites produce the most eye-catching prints?

title: Sony and Asus Jump Into Smartwatch Fray
description: BERLIN  Many of the worlds largest technology companies are finding it tough to persuade people to splurge on new devices ike smartwatches and fitness bands.

title: Hamas Emerges Buoyant Despite Bloodshed and Devastation in Gaza
description: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip  Ismail Haniya, the top Hamas leader in Gaza, worked the crowd in what used to be the Boura neighborhood of this battered northern border town, kissing the cheeks of elders and the foreheads of masked fighters. He waved at the women standing in front of makeshift huts next to the homes flattened in Israeli attacks, as children watched from atop concrete piles where green Hamas flags were planted as though on conquered lands.

title: A Legacy Helps Young Photographers
description: PERPIGNAN, France  An exhibit of scholarship winners and runners-up of the Ian Parry Awards will show this week at Visa Pour lImage festival.

title: Commitments on Three Fronts Test Obamas Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  In vowing in Estonia on Wednesday to defend vulnerable NATO nations from Russia for as long as necessary, President Obama has now committed the United States to three major projections of its power: a pivot to Asia, a more muscular presence in Europe and a new battle against Islamic extremists that seems very likely to accelerate.

title: Casting Director Noah Shelleys Brooklyn-Centric New York Fashion Week Black Book
description: As one half, with Angus Munro, of the agencyAM Casting, Noah Shelley oversees the look of the runways for such design houses as Opening Ceremony and Maison Kitsun (in New York), Preen and Erdem (in London) and Ann Demeulemeester and Rick Owens (in Paris). An industry veteran who once ran the studio of the photographers Inez Van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, Shelley divides his time between Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn, and the Venice Beach section of Los Angeles, where he escapes for regular surf trips. T caught up with Shelley between New York Fashion Week castings to hear his suggestions for on-the-go eating, dressing and functioning in style.

title: Federal Judge, Bucking Trend, Affirms Ban on Same-Sex Marriages in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS  A federal judge here upheld the states ban on same-sex marriage on Wednesday, going against what had been a unanimous trend of federal court decisions striking down such bans since the Supreme Court ruled on the matter last year.

title: A Deep Breath Before the Runway
description: Founded in 2007 as public-relations triage in an industry oft-accused of both superficiality and excess, the Council of Fashion Designers Health Initiative has focused in years past on the problems of eating disorders and underage models. This year, it is urging deep breaths.

title: Antibiotics Eliminated in Hatchery, Perdue Says
description: Perdue, one of the countrys largest poultry producers, said on Wednesday that it would no longer use antibiotics in its hatcheries, one of the last places it was using such drugs routinely.

title: ISIS Is a Disgrace to True Fundamentalism
description: It has become a commonplace in recent months to observe that the rise of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, is the latest chapter in the long story of the anticolonial awakening  the arbitrary borders drawn after World War I by the great powers being redrawn  and simultaneously a chapter in the struggle against the way global capital undermines the power of nation states. But what causes such fear and consternation is another feature of the ISIS regime: The public statements of the ISIS authorities make it clear that the principal task of state power is not the regulation of the welfare of the states population (health, the fight against hunger)  what really matters is religious life and the concern that all public life obey religious laws. This is why ISIS remains more or less indifferent toward humanitarian catastrophes within its domain  its motto is roughly take care of religion and welfare will take care of itself. Therein resides the gap that separates the notion of power practiced by ISIS from the modern Western notion of what Michel Foucault called biopower, which regulates life in order to guarantee general welfare: the ISIS caliphate totally rejects the notion of biopower.

title: Joan Rivers Is Moved Out of Intensive Care
description: Joan Rivers was moved out of intensive care almost a week after she was first hospitalized in New York, her daughter, Melissa Rivers, said on Wednesday.

title: Isis, the Industry Group, Is Changing Its Name
description: Isis has a branding problem.

title: Uber Continues to Operate in Germany, Despite Court Ruling
description: BERLIN A day after Uber, the popular ride-hailing service, was barred from operating in Germany, the company was still taking bookings.

title: August Sales Fall for G.M. as Trucks Lift Chrysler
description: Though battered by the recall of millions of vehicles and revelations that it failed to fix a deadly defect in its ignition switches, General Motors maintained a monthly winning streak in selling vehicles since March.

title: Disney Details a New, Boy-Centric Animated Movie
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Disneys last animated movie, Frozen, made little girls go berserk. Is Disneys next big-screen cartoon, Big Hero 6, about to do the same thing for their brothers? What exactly happens in Big Hero 6, anyway?

title: Calico, Googles Anti-Aging Company, Announces New Research Facility
description: In the world according to Google, cars drive themselves, deliveries are dropped off by drones and eyeglasses double as computers. Also, people live forever.

title: Texas Abortion Clinic to Reopen After Ruling
description: An embattled abortion clinic in McAllen, Tex., which was the last provider of abortions in the vast Rio Grande Valley when new state restrictions forced it to stop last fall, will start operating again by this weekend, its owner said Wednesday, after last weeks favorable decision by a federal judge.

title: Serena Williams Romps at U.S. Open and Will Face Ekaterina Makarova in the Semifinals
description: Three games into her match against Flavia Pennetta on Wednesday night, Serena Williams had been broken twice and trailed by 3-0.

title: Putin on Ceasefire Plan With Ukraine
description: Russian president Vladimir V. Putin discussed the steps necessary for a ceasefire agreement between his country and Ukraine on Wednesday.

title: Out of Jail, British Couple Reunite With Ill Son
description: LONDON  The parents of a 5-year-old boy with a brain tumor who were arrested after taking him out of Britain to seek alternative treatment were reunited with him on Wednesday after their release from a Spanish prison.

title: What You Get for ... $2,000,000
description: VIEQUES, P.R.

title: A Better Flu Shot
description: For the past four years, doctors offices, medical clinics and pharmacies have offered older adults high-dose versions of the annual flu vaccine. The hope was that this alternative would better protect seniors, but scientific evidence proving its effectiveness has been lacking.

title: Its Not Me, Its the Story
description: In her long and enviable career, Julianne Moore has made a point of appearing in both big-budget pictures like Non-Stop, the recent Liam Neeson thriller, and in underfunded independent films like What Maisie Knew, where the costume budget was so skimpy she wound up lending the production some of her own clothes. This season, shes in the third installment of the Hunger Games trilogy, which opens Nov. 21, and also in David Cronenbergs newest film, Maps to the Stars, scheduled to be released before the end of the year. Though set in Hollywood, Maps was mostly shot in Toronto, to save money, and this time Ms. Moore had to scrounge some jewelry and handbags.

title: USA Today Cuts 70 Employees From Newsroom and Business Staff
description: USA Today, the Gannett Companys flagship paper, laid off roughly 70 people on Wednesday. The cuts appeared to be equally split between employees in the newsroom and other departments, and they equaled less than 10 percent of the total work force.

title: Wheelies: The Little Landie Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Kindred Spirits Try Something New
description: The last time most people saw Kristen Wiig and Bill Hader together, the two were probably wearing wigs while hosting a game show, making out with family members or giving unnecessarily detailed California traffic directions on Saturday Night Live. The next time audiences see them together, it wont be so funny. In the opening scene of the writer-director Craig Johnsons The Skeleton Twins, opening Sept. 12, the two actors best known for Gilly and Stefon wield their hard-won chemistry to portray a brother and sister who decide to attempt suicide on the same night.

title: Unusual Drama School in Rome Is Set to Expand
description: ROME  Changing peoples perceptions of mental illness has been a longtime mission for Dario DAmbrosi, an Italian avant-garde actor and author. For the past five years, he has led Teatro Patologico, or the Pathological Theater, an innovative drama school here that offers classes to people with mental disabilities. Now Mr. DAmbrosi is trying to turn his school into a full-fledged university.

title: How Ukraine Helped Galvanize NATO
description: A look at how the threat of further Russian aggression has helped to unify NATO.

title: Sound, via Bluetooth, Straight to Speakers
description: BLUETOOTH wireless technology is helping take music out of headphones and back into speakers. But finding the speakers that best suit your needs means deciding among shape, color and extra features you wouldnt normally associate with listening to music.

title: Rock and Enroll
description: Scholarly musicians prove that Ph.D.s can play.

title: David Hares Skylight Coming to Broadway From London
description: One of the biggest hits in London this summer, a revival of David Hares drama Skylight starring Bill Nighy and Carey Mulligan, will transfer to Broadway and begin performances on March 16 at the Golden Theater, the producers announced on Wednesday. Directed by the Tony Award winner Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot), Skylight is likely to be a force in the 2015 Tony races, given the strong critical acclaim by British and American theater critics for the production.

title: Conceptual Anarchy
description: PARIS  Pierre Huyghe has long loved Locus Solus, Raymond Roussels 1914 novel about an inventor who invites friends to a secluded estate to show off his creations, one of which is a tank filled with cadavers that re-enact the most important moments of their former lives, animated by a miraculous substance called resurrectine.

title: Prehistoric Tools to Matisse Cut-Outs
description: Check your frequent flier miles. The array of museum shows opening across the country this fall feels promising, almost an embarrassment of riches.

title: Upstairs, a Walk on the Wild Side
description: When the High Line at the Rail Yards, the final section of the elevated park, opens on Sept. 21, we will no longer have to stop at 30th Street and stare longingly through the construction gate at the Queen Annes Lace blooming in wild profusion along the old tracks.

title: In Museums, Masters Old and New
description: On paper, the 2014-15 art season looks unusually well balanced, with no foreseeable leaps in the dark, but not much dead space either. Its anchored by a substantial old-master lineup, including a big blast from Spain. Goya: Order and Disorder opens at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, on Oct. 12, and in early November acres of El Greco roll out at the Metropolitan Museum and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, commemorating the 400th anniversary of that ever-popular artists death.

title: Transforming, but Not Disrupting
description: The new building in Dudley Square in Boston doesnt look like anything else in sight. And yet it fits right in. Thats a good description of the tempered ambition of many American urban projects opening in the coming months: They arent disruptive but (their supporters hope) transformative, and their shapes, even their sparkle, come from understanding past civic hopes and redesigning them to meet the future. The curvaceous brick cornice of the Bruce C. Bolling Municipal Building in Dudley Square knits together three historic buildings, provides offices for 500 employees of the Boston Public Schools and incorporates an old rail track into its ground-floor plan, the better to connect the building to the adjacent bus station.

title: Grading Teachers, With Data From Class
description: Halfway through the last school year, Leila Campbell, a young humanities teacher at a charter high school in Oakland, Calif., received the results from a recent survey of her students.

title: Florida Prosecutors Face Long Odds When Police Use Lethal Force
description: MIAMI  For decades Florida has had a history of deadly, racially tinged police confrontations, many of them involving unarmed men, which have led to riots, protests and a steady undercurrent of rancor between minorities and the police. But in the past 20 years, not a single officer in Florida has been charged with using deadly force.

title: Buy Downstage, Sell Upstage
description: Anyone who took a bath in the 2008 economic crisis might feel a little nervous crossing the water to Governors Island to witness that dunking all over again. In Trade Practices, the director Kristin Marting and the designer David Evans Morris transform Pershing Hall, a handsome former administrative building, into the headquarters of Tender Inc.

title: Seeing Women as Key to Economy, Japans Leader Names 5 to Cabinet
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan unveiled a reshuffled cabinet on Wednesday that included five women, an apparent nod toward his promises to raise the status of women in the workplace. The appointments tie the record for the number of women in top political positions in Japan.

title: A Panoramic View From the Top of the U.S. Open
description: From the top of Arthur Ashe Stadium, a look at Tuesdays match in which No. 2 Roger Federer dispatched No. 17 Roberto Bautista Agut.

title: Damaged but Dogged, She Prays for Her Art
description: It could be a scene from A Clockwork Orange, or from Michael Hanekes sadistic film Funny Games. A pair of insouciant stalkers overtake a young couple outside the West Village building where they live and nudge them at gunpoint up the steps and into their apartment. Chatting desultorily, weapon at the ready, the marauders steal money, photographs, letters, a watch, a cape, as their helpless victims look on, fearful and incredulous. The thieves are two sexy and delectable 16-year-old girls in tie-dye head scarves and lime-green earrings. Their names are Rainey Royal and Tina Dial, and they are best friends. The heist was a stunt, a game to test their loyalty to each other  the wary warmth of equals  a game that went too far.

title: Jenna Lyons of J. Crews Beauty Routine
description: Jenna Lyons, the president and executive creative director of J. Crew, was born in Boston and raised in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. Known for her idiosyncratic mix of quirk, prep and tailoring, Ms. Lyons has emerged in recent years as a fashion star, including cameos on the HBO series Girls. She lives in SoHo with her 7-year-old son, Beckett. The J. Crew spring collection will be shown on Tuesday.

title: A U.S. Open Keepsake, Soaked With Sweat
description: With the match at Arthur Ashe Stadium nearing its apparent conclusion, the scramble in the stands began. Hordes of children  mostly boys, and many spurred on by eager parents  seemed to materialize from nowhere, racing down the aisles to the front row, behind the players chairs.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 1 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Ariana Grande Is No. 1
description: Susan Boyle and Ariana Grande may not have a lot in common, but they do share one distinction on Billboards album chart: they are the only female performers in the last five years to reach No. 1 with their first two records.

title: George Clooney to Direct Film on Phone-Hacking Scandal
description: LOS ANGELES  And Rupert Murdoch thought his newspaper phone hacking scandal had faded from the headlines.

title: Alexander Wangs Designs
description: A look back at Mr. Wangs collections.

title: After Slow Growth, Experts Say, Health Spending Is Expected to Climb
description: WASHINGTON  Government experts on Wednesday predicted a rebound in national health care spending as expansions in coverage and improvements in the economy take hold after four years of exceptionally slow growth in the nations medical bills.

title: Action Films May Spur the Need to Feed
description: Action films may get the heart racing, but they may expand your waistline, a new study suggests.

title: Picasso Museum to Reopen at Last, With New Leader
description: PARIS  With his horn-rimmed glasses and charcoal-gray suits, Laurent Le Bon is an unlikely Zorro to rescue the long-closed Muse Picasso here in the Marais quarter.

title: Alexander Wang, Serving Two Masters
description: The list of what the 30-year-old designer Alexander Wang does not look like is long.

title: A Passionate Version of Love That Scratches and Bites
description: The seam of feral imagery that winds through the love poems of the great Chilean writer Pablo Neruda gives them a visceral intensity that makes the romantic effusions of many English-language poets seem flowery and incorporeal. As the German chanteuse Ute Lemper sang her settings of Nerudas works at 54 Below on Tuesday evening, her beautiful but sometimes abrasive voice bit and scratched like a lover in the throes of uncontrollable passion.

title: Justine Kurlands Vivid, Haunting Photographs of Men and Cars
description: For more than a decade, Justine Kurland has taken photographs during annual cross-country journeys from New York to the Pacific Northwest that reveal the double-edged nature of the American dream. A lifelong nomad (she grew up traveling to Renaissance festivals, where her mother sold hand-sewn clothes), her tools are her 45 camera and her van, which allow her to dwell, briefly, in the worlds of the marginal figures she photographs. First, there were the girls she cast as runaways, forging into forests and swimming holes. Later came images of commune members in wilderness idylls and panoramas of westbound freighters and the hobos who ride them.

title: An App for Last-Minute Flights
description: Travelers who dig the spontaneity that services like Hotel Tonight afford will be happy to hear that the last-minute booking game has expanded to airline apps as well.

title: Advocating for the Regular Guy During Fashion Week
description: Everyone knows the mens wear element of New York Fashion Week exists in a kind of calendric no-mans land. For lots of reasons  market segment, scale of economic values, cultural disposition  womens wear is the big tent event at the circus. Though the mens wear shows start off the week, they do so mostly at out of the way locations with little of the hoopla that accompanies the womens wear shows at Lincoln Center, and for an audience of news media and buyers that seems like a traveling fraternity.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 1 Player Picks
description: Were very excited to welcome you back to a brand new fantasy football season.

title: Frozen Fever Burns
description: Is Frozen fever easing? Not if Disney can help it. The ABC special The Story of Frozen: Making a Disney Animated Classic drew about 4.7 million viewers on Tuesday night, according to Nielsen data.

title: Fox to Announce Deal With Smartphone Video App
description: When Paul Levy co-founded Burst in 2010, he envisioned a mobile application that would allow parents to record and share short videos of their children playing sports. Now, sports media companies are using Bursts technology at much bigger events.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Levitating With the Butterflies
description: A ROSY-CHEEKED young buck stood just past the entrance of the new Valentino flagship in Midtown at 5 p.m. on a recent Friday, proffering glasses of Champagne and those pastel macarons that have descended upon Gotham the last few years like a fleet of small U.F.O.s.

title: Yup, Those Guys Are Still Around
description: Sometimes the voice of an era is the one that you forget all about, the one that was so ubiquitous and inoffensive, it practically became background noise.

title: Patrick McEnroe Out as U.S.T.A. Player Development Head
description: With the doldrums of American tennis on display at the United States Open, Patrick McEnroe will leave his job as head of player development for the United States Tennis Association, the U.S.T.A. announced Wednesday.

title: Should The Times Have Observed a Complete Blackout on ISIS Video Images?
description: Where does newsworthiness end and manipulation begin? How should news organizations handle a brutally violent video that is clearly intended as a terrorist propaganda and recruitment tool?

title: Arts Center at Ground Zero Shelves Gehry Design
description: The board of the performing arts center planned for ground zero has scuttled the design for the building by Frank Gehry, the projects original architect, and will instead select a design from a field of three finalists.

title: Voices Unleashed, Paying No Mind to Limits
description: Every voice contains special notes. At the finals of the Operalia competition in Los Angeles last weekend, one soprano showed off a mostly ordinary sound in a selection from Bellinis La Sonnambula  but an ordinary sound capped by a stunning high F.

title: A Big Gain at World Youth Teams in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  The 15th World Youth Teams here last month had a new event for kids, this year for anyone born after Dec. 31, 1998. There were only seven teams playing, but the event will surely expand in the future.

title: How a Revelation About Hello Kittys Identity Blew Everyones Mind
description: Last week, The Los Angeles Times broke the news of the century. Or so it would seem by the shockwaves it sent through the Internet.

title: Bring a Connoisseurs Eye and a Toothbrush
description: The British sculptor Antony Gormley recently completed a work called Room. You can see it jutting from the upper floors of a 1926 building in the Mayfair neighborhood of London. For about $4,119 a night, you can book it.

title: A Gallery Gets Wider and Wackier
description: Steven Kasher has moved and expanded. His New York art-photography gallery is now in a 6,000-square-foot space at 515 West 26th Street. And part of the gallery, which opens Saturday, will be devoted to Kasher Potamkin, a new business headed by Mr. Kasher and Andi Potamkin. Asked to describe the product mix, Ms. Potamkin quoted Edgar Allan Poe: There is no exquisite beauty ... without some strangeness in the proportion. She may have been referring to several mounted fluffy rabbit derrires by Ghyslain Bertholon, or beaded taxidermy-like sconces by Nancy Josephson. Kasher Potamkin has adopted an instant-gratification sales policy: Buy it, walk out with it. This applies to everything in the shop, including Ms. Potamkins own desk, designed by her fianc, Jordan Blackmore. Prices range from $250 for a LEnchanteur ring to $60,000 for a pair of Haas Brothers Beast stools. Information: 917-265-8060 or kasherpotamkin.com.

title: Producing Concrete Results
description: Alessi, the Italian housewares company, is associated with objects that are gleaming and voluptuous, or bright and cartoonish, but certainly not concrete. Now, that popular industrial material has found its way to the collection through a competition for young designers sponsored by Italcementi, the manufacturer of a new cement mortar. Luca Galbusera from Italy prevailed in a field of 200 innovators working with the material, which is said to combine the strength of concrete with the malleability of plastic. His winning entry was a fruit bowl, named La Trama e lOrdito (warp and weft in Italian), after its basket-weave pattern. The bowls are 16 inches in diameter and 11 inches high and come in blue and red. They will be available in mid-October for $450. For information or to order: 212-941-7300.

title: Is It Done Yet?
description: Michael Robbins, a 31-year-old self-taught woodworker in Columbia County, N.Y., spent three years perfecting his latest introduction, the Taza lounge chair. The piece went through several experimental versions, including one with a seat of canvas webbing, but in the end, a leather sling won out. Mr. Robbins also recently rolled out his Bridle bench, right, which, like the chair, had been sitting around the shop for a while, he said. The solid ash top is laminated with bridle leather, and an arc of brass adds a nice architectural detail while supporting the structure. The Taza lounge is available in four woods and four shades of leather, for $2,850; the Bridle bench ranges in length from 5 to 10 feet, in a choice of four woods and four leathers; it starts at $1,675. Information: 315-761-8010 or mchlrbbns.com.

title: Discounts at ABC Carpet & Home, From the Source and Classic Rug Collection
description: All products are up to 80 percent off during ABC Carpet & Homes Bronx warehouse sale, through Sept. 14 (the Edge rustic dining table, originally, $2,995, is $1,599); 1055 Bronx River Avenue (Watson Avenue), Bronx; 718-842-8772.

title: Andrew Madoff, Who Told of His Fathers Swindle, Dies at 48
description: Andrew H. Madoff, the last surviving son of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff, died on Wednesday in a Manhattan hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment for cancer. He was 48.

title: Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella to Close on Broadway
description: The Broadway production of Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella will close on Jan. 3 after a run of nearly two years, the producers announced on Wednesday. The show opened in March 2013 to mixed reviews and went on to receive nine Tony Award nominations that year, including for Laura Osnes in the title role; it won only for the costumes by William Ivey Long.

title: Here, Ansel! Sit, Avedon!
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  It was in 2007 that Juergen Perthold, an engineer living in Anderson, S.C., strapped a tiny camera of his own design to the collar of his cat, Mr. Lee. When the images Mr. Lee captured while roaming around their neighborhood were posted online, they went, predictably, viral. Mr. Lee received a flurry of attention from the international media and became the star of a documentary, CatCam: The Movie, which made the film festival rounds in 2012 and even won a few awards.

title: In His Basement, the Bowery
description: Adam Woodward rarely leaves his Lower East Side neighborhood, and then only grudgingly. He hates the thought of missing even the smallest change on one of the strangest and most historic thoroughfares in the country, the 400-year-old stretch of road known as the Bowery, which has seen more than its share of demolition and transformation in recent years.

title: A House Built to Baffle
description: It took this reporter a few minutes to realize what was missing from the house that Paul Masi, owner of the architecture firm Bates-Masi, built two years ago for his family. While their three young children played upstairs, Mr. Masi and his wife, Liz, both 42, sat at a table in the open kitchen and living area, explaining their initial concern about building on the half-acre lot in the center of town, which they bought for $840,000 in 2012. It was when Mr. Masi mentioned the proximity to the main drag that everything clicked.

title: Your Grandmas Maker Faire
description: FALCON HEIGHTS, Minn.  In the 12 days leading up to Labor Day, more than 1.8 million visitors attended a design expo that has been held annually since 1859. Granted, most of them didnt know they were attending a design expo; they came for the midway or the mini-doughnuts. But as a popular showcase for American vernacular design, the Minnesota State Fair wins the blue ribbon.

title: Toronto Films Lurk in the Dark Heart of Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  The actor Jake Gyllenhaal recently explained Lou Bloom, the twisted crime videographer he portrays in the movie Nightcrawler, which is set for a world premiere on Friday night at the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and India.

title: Tony West, Top Nemesis of Big Banks, Is Leaving Justice Department
description: Wall Street will soon bid farewell to the man it loves to hate.

title: When the Visitors Dont Walk So Lightly on the Land
description: You dont need to be a Werner Herzog hero plunging into the Amazon to realize that backpackers seeking adventure can take a toll on the environment. Gringo Trails, a documentary from the anthropologist Pegi Vail, explores the impact of adventure vacations on communities and biodiversity.

title: Anti-Pop Star (Except for Those Hooks)
description: At this point, Charli XCX has been a pop star  or, at least, a sub-type of one  three times over. She was a Myspace prodigy (remember those?) when she was barely a teenager. She was then an on-the-rise singer with a distinct voice and pugnacious attitude. And lately, shes been the sort of singer-songwriter who helps those around her become even more famous and stays along for the ride.

title: Q. and A.: Cai Guo-Qiang on Art, the Death of Nature and Chinas Modern Reality
description: Last month, the artist Cai Guo-Qiang opened his new solo exhibit at the Power Station of Art in Shanghai with a literal bang  one of his trademark explosion events that this time had many local residents ducking for cover.

title: Music From the Beloved Country
description: Carnegie Hall is marking 20 years after the end of apartheid with a monthlong festival of music from South Africa, where the long history of tribal, urban, colonial and imported traditions continues to create unexpected hybrids. There are familiar names, like the high-stepping choir Ladysmith Black Mambazo (performing on Oct. 18 with additional guests) and the trumpeter Hugh Masekela, who is sharing a bill with the courageous and nimble-voiced singer and songwriter Vusi Mahlasela on Oct. 10, both at Carnegie Hall. Abdullah Ibrahim, the pianist from Cape Town, brings his rolling, sonorous vamps to Zankel Hall on Oct. 17.

title: Saluting a Labels Legacy
description: The emblematic concert program in Nonesuch Records at BAM  a 50th-anniversary celebration for a prestige record label, running Tuesday through Sept. 28 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music  will feature two founding fathers of Minimalism, performing landmark works. Or perhaps a magisterial yet mischievous singer-songwriter from Brazil. Or a brilliant jazz pianist in league with a virtuoso mandolinist. Or the former frontman of an era-defining hard-rock band, rolling up with a rootsy new caravan.

title: What Amy Sedaris Took from Dallas
description: Recently, Amy Sedaris, the actress, author and D.I.Y. enthusiast, introduced a line of home accessories at Fishs Eddy. Her 10-piece collection for the eccentric housewares emporium includes dish towels, glassware, food storage containers and trays, with patterns and phrases adapted from earlier projects.

title: The Death of Michael Brown: Teaching About Ferguson
description: On Nov. 24, a St. Louis County grand jury announced that it has brought no criminal charges against Darren Wilson for the fatal shooting of Michael Brown. Thousands took to the streets in cities across the country  from Los Angeles to Atlanta to New York  to protest the decision.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Eleanor Rigby
description: The writer and director Ned Benson narrates a sequence from his drama The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them.

title: Immersive Sound Fills a Factory
description: Basilica Soundscape, a two-day festival of sound, sight and taste in Hudson, N.Y., on Friday and Saturday, could one day be to New York City mavens of aggressive and immersive music what Glyndebourne, the opera festival 60 miles south of London, is to classical audiences.

title: Take Note of These Back-to-School Aids
description: ALL around the world, students in colleges and schools are getting back to work. And alongside traditional textbooks and notepads, millions of smartphones and tablets  which spent the vacation taking photos, making selfies and messaging friends  will be in book bags for more serious purposes. With the right apps, a mobile device can be a students best friend.

title: App Smart | Back to School
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will get you equipped for the new school year, including helping to keep track of test dates or homework deadlines.

title: Giving the Milky Way a New Sense of Place
description: For the first time, astronomers have outlined and named the network of galaxies that includes the Milky Way, adding a line to our cosmic address and further defining our place in the universe. They call it Laniakea, which is Hawaiian for immense heaven.

title: Step by Step, Scaling New Heights
description: Step by Step, Scaling New Heights

title: Tech, Meet Fashion
description: Its time we stopped calling the current crop of gadgets wearable tech. Instead, I propose we start giving them a more appropriate name: ugly tech. Because lets be realistic, most wearables today are really, really ugly.

title: Bring Back the Party of Lincoln
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  FOR all the differences between establishment Republicans and Tea Party insurgents, their various efforts to rebrand the Grand Old Party tend to start from a common premise: the belief that Ronald Reagan was the quintessential Republican, and that his principle of defending wealth and the wealthy should remain the partys guiding vision.

title: Nine Things to Hate About Packing School Lunches (and How to Fix Them)
description: There are far worse things than packing school lunches. In fact, I kind of like it  at no other time of day do I feed a captive, hungry audience with no other options who also cant ask me, ever so politely, if they can have something else. If I didnt want to do it, Id have my children do it; theyre in eighth, fifth and third grade and theyre capable. Instead, I choose to load the boxes  and once I identified, and largely eliminated, the things about the process that I hated, our mornings (and my evenings) improved.

title: New Roku and TiVo Devices Make Cutting the Cable Cord Plausible
description: CUTTING the cable television cord has always sounded nicer than it really is.

title: Tech to Cut the Cable Cord
description: Molly Wood reviews new devices from Roku and TiVo that offer Internet-enabled alternatives to costly cable TV plans.

title: At WWD, a New Owner Tries to Change Course
description: The day after Cond Nast announced last month that it was selling Fairchild Fashion Media for a reported $100 million, the new owner, Jay Penske, held several meetings with staff members of its crown jewel publication, Womens Wear Daily.

title: Tragedy or Triumph
description: Its more than two months since the Supreme Court issued its eagerly awaited decision in the recess appointments case, National Labor Relations Board v. Noel Canning. You may recall that by a vote of 9 to 0, President Obama lost this case, in as much as the court held that his recess appointments of three members of the labor board were unauthorized by the Constitutions recess appointments clause.

title: New York Fashion Weeks Shopping Events
description: Openings

title: A Montage of Iconic New Wave Movies, Via the New York Fashion Film Festival
description: In this new series, Chris Labzda and Bon Duke, the co-founders of the New York Fashion Film Festival, curate a short film each week for T.

title: Why Fashions Night Out Faltered
description: Amid the attention surrounding New York Fashion Week, few seem to have noticed the quiet disappearance of Fashions Night Out, which began with great fanfare in 2009 and lasted all of four years, going on hiatus in 2013.

title: Discovery and Rediscovery
description: The choreography of the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries all offer much to anticipate in the next six months. The early Danish ballet master August Bournonville  whose work cleanses the palate with both the felicity of its dance construction and its open temperament  has scarcely been represented in America since the 2011 visit of the Royal Danish Ballet. An end to this drought comes Jan. 13 through 18, when that companys soloists perform an anthology of his dances at the Joyce Theater.

title: Elephant in the Room
description: Over the next week, as the fashion world heads to Milk Studios in West Chelsea to see one of Made Fashion Weeks 15 runway shows, it will be greeted by a guest: a giant pink elephant.

title: Fest Packed With Artists Bursting Out of the Box
description: Crossing the Line, a playful and probing interdisciplinary festival now in its eighth year, hosts an array of artists who refuse to be bottled up and labeled. The pickings are eclectic, from the debut of the Argentine director and visual artist Fernando Rubio, who places seven actresses in white beds in Hudson River Park  in 10-minute cycles, they whisper memories to audience members  to Xavier Le Roys sophisticated yet accessible exhibition of movement and conversation, Retrospective, at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens. In other words, Crossing the Line, which runs from Sept. 8 through Oct. 20 at various New York locations and is presented by the French Institute Alliance Franaise, is nothing if not an adventure.

title: A Couple of Genius Moves
description: If much is expected of those to whom much is given, then the pressure on the choreographer Kyle Abraham is mounting. Since the 2010 debut of his first full-length piece, The Radio Show, the high-profile offers and lucrative prizes have been piling up. He has gotten commissions from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the ballerina Wendy Whelan. On top of many other awards, he was named  in 2013, at 36  a MacArthur Fellow, an honor that comes with $625,000 and the connotation of genius.

title: Fashion History, on the Catwalk Once More
description: On the eve of yet another cycle of fashion weeks, Olivier Saillard, the fashion historian and director of the Palais Galliera museum in Paris, is coming to New York with a message: We are in a moment thats very bizarre in fashion, he said. There are too many clothes.

title: Incoming! Video Games Zero In
description: Readers do not expect a years new crop of novels to eclipse the Western canon. Nor do filmgoers anticipate that this falls Oscar bait will surpass a centurys worth of cinema. Yet many video game players, wedded to notions of technological progress rather than artistic experimentation, believe that a new batch of consoles should be accompanied by a wave of games superior to all that came before.

title: Untold Stories After the Arab Spring
description: A new website and book feature the work of North African photographers whose projects show aspects of life overshadowed by the regions tumult.

title: Fashion Week Now Spring 2015
description: See what you missed.

title: Sugar, Spice and Guts
description: Girls grow up on big and little screens, and sometimes the thinking about girls and girlhood grows, too. Inspired by Richard Linklaters Boyhood  a magnificent film that tells the story of a boys life from 6 to 18  we are taking a look at how girls are growing up in the movies. American mainstream cinema, a timid enterprise dependent on formulas and genres, can be mind-blowingly retrograde when it comes to women and girls. And while an occasional woman or girl rules the box office, too many of their on-screen sisters are sidelined or just left out of the picture.

title: Modern Romance, With Laughs
description: Are you one of the people mourning the loss of the old-fashioned (as in 1990s) rom-com? Do you feel that romantic comedies havent been the same  or havent even existed  since the last time Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks made a movie together?

title: Argentine Economist Says Bond Holdouts Should Be Paid
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H.  Domingo Cavallo, the architect of Argentinas first debt restructuring deal in 2001, has a solution for the countrys worsening debt drama: pay the holdouts.

title: A Reading of In The Bois De Vincennes by Matthew Rohrer
description: The poet reads his verse about the City of Light.

title: Giving Up My Small-Town Fantasy
description: A few weeks ago, after a Pilates class in a studio above my former office, I rolled up a mat while the teacher spoke to another student, someone who seemed new in town  a potential friend. Lingering near the exercise bikes, I pretended to stretch, and then edged in to the conversation.

title: From Now On, Women Save the World
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood has long known that women are better customers than men. Its right there in the annual reports from the Motion Picture Association of America: Moviegoing in the United States and Canada was 52 percent female last year. Just as it was five years earlier.

title: It Was Good Enough for Frasier and Mary
description: A few weeks ago, when the New York Yankees were on the road playing the Baltimore Orioles, Brandon McCarthy, the Yankee pitcher, made this wisecrack via Twitter: forgetting to pack my wearable NO, I HAVENT SEEN THE WIRE sandwich board before coming to Baltimore has proven to be disastrous.

title: Shades of Hillary in TV Dramas
description: Shows like State of Affairs, Madam Secretary and Political Animals have characters with uncanny similarities to former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: As Football Season Appears, So Do the Fall Campaigns
description: MANY retailers and clothing companies have already started their autumn advertising efforts. Now comes the rest of Madison Avenue, taking advantage of the start of a new football season to bring out major campaigns intended to put consumers in the mood for fall shopping  and to begin thinking about, yes, Christmas.

title: Path of Stolen Credit Cards Leads Back to Home Depot Stores
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There are two tracks to finding the identity of a company that has been hit by cybercriminals. Both of them involve going backward.

title: Characters Inspired by You-Know-Who
description: It could have been that photograph of Hillary Rodham Clinton in the White House Situation Room watching, hand over mouth, as cameras showed the SEAL Team Six raid on Osama bin Ladens compound.

title: A Love Story: His and Hers and Theirs
description: Boy meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love, get married, start a family, confront a crisis, split apart. Its one of the oldest stories ever told, and writers and filmmakers are always searching for new ways to tell it: exactly the challenge that the screenwriter and rookie director Ned Benson faced in making The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby, which opens Friday.

title: Looking Back at Love, and Memories Differ
description: Imagine an extramarital love affair in which neither party can be blamed. Or, at the very least, both are especially hard to judge.

title: ISIS, Deep in the Heart of Texas
description: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, is coming  to Texas? Yes, if you listen to conservatives, particularly those from Texas.

title: Michael Bloomberg to Return to Lead Bloomberg L.P.
description: Michael R. Bloomberg has decided to reassume the leadership of his business empire only eight months after ending his final term as mayor of New York.

title: Tracing Cyberattacks
description: To the Editor:

title: After Beheadings, Pressure on Obama
description: To the Editor:

title: Community Service for Teenager Who Climbed Trade Center
description: Six months ago, Justin Casquejo, a 16-year-old from Weehawken, N.J., with a penchant for promoting his aerial exploits on Twitter, scaled 1 World Trade Center, making observers blanch and leaving officials unsettled.

title: E-ZPass and Rental Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirement on the Road?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevada and Tesla Hint at Site of Factory
description: The governor of Nevada and Tesla Motors, the electric car company with gigantic ambitions, will be making an affirmative announcement on Thursday about the construction of a huge battery factory, a person involved in the negotiations said on Wednesday.

title: Australian Leader Seeks Deal to Sell Uranium to India
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia announced in Parliament on Wednesday that he hoped to sign a deal this week to export uranium to India, even though India has not ratified the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

title: For New York Legislators, Indictments Are No Obstacle to Seeking Re-election
description: State Senator John L. Sampson, a Brooklyn Democrat charged with embezzlement and an attempted cover-up, has observed that an opponents military service helped ensure him of the presumption of innocence.

title: Walking Out of a Show
description: To the Editor:

title: So Good to Be Bad
description: Villain, nemesis  whatever the label, its not always easy being mean.

title: Drug Overdose Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Former First Lady of France Colors In Details of an Affair
description: PARIS  Now she has her say.

title: 3rd Missionary With Ebola Is Identified
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The third American sickened in West Africa with the Ebola virus was identified on Wednesday as a 51-year-old doctor from the Boston area who was delivering babies at a hospital in Liberia.

title: An Actor-Director Above Suspicion
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  They disliked me, then they liked me. They hated me, and now they love me.

title: Another Shadow in Ferguson as Outside Firms Buy and Rent Out Distressed Homes
description: Ethel Walker and her daughter Tasha pay $650 a month to rent a home in Ferguson, Mo., from an investment firm 1,800 miles away in Los Angeles. A few miles from the Walkers, Corey Bryant and his mother are renting a two-bedroom home in Ferguson from the same California firm.

title: Tax Break for Sports
After Decades on CBS, U.S. Open Will Switch Channels Full Time
description: When the United States Tennis Championships became the U.S. Open in 1968, CBS Sports televised the tournament from the Forest Hills section of Queens, with Bud Collins and Jack Kramer calling matches that featured Arthur Ashes milestone victory in the mens final.

title: New Rules May Allow Benefits Long Denied to Vietnam-Era Veterans
description: Thousands of Vietnam-era veterans barred from receiving benefits because of less-than-honorable discharges may be eligible for upgrades under a new set of guidelines released by the Defense Department on Wednesday.

title: Clip: The Boxtrolls
description: A scene from the film, directed by Anthony Stacchi and Graham Annable.

title: Justice Dept. Inquiry to Focus on Practices of Police in Ferguson
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department will open a broad civil rights investigation into police practices in Ferguson, Mo., where a white police officer killed an unarmed black teenager last month and set off days of racially charged unrest, the citys police chief and other officials said Wednesday.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. 1, Czech Republic 0
description: PRAGUE  Despite missing many of its veterans, the United States mens national team opened the cycle that will lead to the 2018 World Cup with a hard-fought exhibition win over the Czech Republic on Wednesday in Prague.

title: Searching for Ways to Improve Yankees Anemic Lineup
description: Some of the Yankees wear T-shirts under their jerseys with a three-word slogan  more like an exhortation  on the back: DO YOUR JOB! Carlos Beltran wore his on Wednesday. Like most of the hitters, though, he has not answered the demand.

title: A Civilization Separated by Manholes
description: Adapted from Alan Snows novel Here Be Monsters!, The Boxtrolls follows miniature beings who wear boxes and live beneath the towering town of Cheesebridge. That split makes for two distinct visual worlds in the movie, directed by Anthony Stacchi and Graham Annable, who moved away from the books illustrations.

title: Regulators Propose Rule to Reduce Risk of Derivatives
description: Federal regulators announced on Wednesday an overhaul of a murky Wall Street market that gained infamy during the financial crisis of 2008.

title: Final Touches Range From Flowery to Frantic as Expanded Pre-K Awaits Start
description: The sounds of scissors slicing through construction paper and transparent tape being torn from rolls filled every room at the Kaleidoscope Early Childhood Development Center in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday. After weeks of hiring teachers, filling seats and ordering furniture, the Kaleidoscope staff was putting the finishing decorative touches on its classrooms, readying for the first day of Mayor Bill de Blasios signature initiative: a vast expansion of full-day prekindergarten.

title: The Down Side of Reclining
description: I am trying to imagine how our national leaders would react if they got caught in a reclining airplane seat crisis. You know what I mean. If they were flying to some important meeting and the person in front flopped back into their personal space, crunching a laptop or bruising a knee.

title: To Lure Tourists, a Remote Village in Spain Turns Its Eye to the Arts
description: GENALGUACIL, Spain  This Spanish village has a new cemetery, though no one has ever been buried in it. Built before the onset of the financial crisis, and against the wishes of residents who wanted their final resting place to be in the old village cemetery, it was yet another Spanish investment plan that failed.

title: Credit Rating Reform Comes Up Short
description: At the center of the financial crisis was the corrupted process by which bad mortgages were packaged into toxic securities with stellar credit ratings. The credit rating agencies that gave out those high grades were paid by the banks, which securitized the loans and sold them to investors.

title: Michael Brown Never Faced Serious Felony Charge, St. Louis Officials Lawyer Says
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Michael Brown, the unarmed black teenager shot and killed by a white police officer here last month, had no serious felony cases filed against him as a juvenile, a lawyer for a St. Louis County official said Wednesday.

title: Steven Sotloff, U.S. Hostage Slain by ISIS, Was Also a Citizen of Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The beheading of Steven J. Sotloff, the American journalist from Miami who had been held hostage by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, suddenly loomed larger for many Israelis on Wednesday when it emerged that he held Israeli citizenship and had lived and studied in the country for a few years.

title: The Innocent on Death Row
description: The exoneration of two North Carolina men who spent 30 years in prison  one on death row  provides a textbook example of so much that is broken in the American justice system. And it is further evidence (as though more were needed) that the death penalty is irretrievably flawed as well as immoral.

title: Wes Welkers Suspension Gives Broncos One More Dose of Uncertainty
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  Football coaches tend to be fluent in John Wayne-ese. So Colts Coach Chuck Pagano got on a call with reporters on Wednesday and described Denver quarterback Peyton Manning as a mans man.

title: House Candidate Testifies of Pressure to Hire Rowland for Campaign
description: NEW HAVEN  I happen to like John Rowland, and I liked meeting him, Mark Greenberg said on Wednesday from the witness stand at the federal courthouse here. But, he explained, I was not interested in signing a $35,000 contract for the campaign with him.

title: Detroit Plan for Its Debt Is Debated in Court
description: DETROIT  A lawyer for this city on Wednesday urged a judge to approve Detroits blueprint for shedding $7 billion of its debts and devoting about $1.5 billion toward restoring city services over the next decade, describing the plan to emerge from bankruptcy as Detroits last, best chance for a comeback.

title: Fund-Raiser Pleads Guilty to Organizing Straw Donors for Michael Grimms Campaign
description: A woman who raised funds for Representative Michael G. Grimm pleaded guilty on Wednesday to illegally funneling money to his 2010 campaign.

title: Cuts at W.H.O. Hurt Response to Ebola Crisis
description: With treatment centers overflowing, and alarmingly little being done to stop Ebola from sweeping through West African villages and towns, Dr. Joanne Liu, the president of Doctors Without Borders, knew that the epidemic had spun out of control.

title: Back in Politics, Quinn Will Be Adviser on Abortion-Rights Strategy
description: Christine C. Quinn, the former speaker of the City Council, is the first to admit that her restful year out of the spotlight was a change of pace. It wasnt what I planned, she said this week, laughing. But you know what they say: People plan, and God laughs.

title: Missing Russian Photographer Was Killed in Ukraine
description: The Russian photojournalist Andrei Stenin, who went missing while embedded with separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine last month, was killed in an attack on a convoy four weeks ago, Russias state news agency reported on Wednesday.

title: Pakistan: Protesters Told to Pull Back
description: Protest leaders in Islamabad saidWednesdaythat their supporters would vacate the Parliament area, where they converged last week, after violent clashes with the police. Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a firebrand cleric, made the announcement but told supporters, We will not leave Islamabad till the resignation of Nawaz Sharif, the prime minister. Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaaf, the political party of the opposition leader Imran Khan, has also ordered its workers to leave the area. Mr. Qadris and Mr. Khans parties are now negotiating with the leaders of other parties to break a deadlock that has paralyzed the city. Formal talks between representatives of the government and protesters are expected Thursday.

title: Go Crazy
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  The entry IN PEN for the clue Improper way to take the SAT made me laugh, not because using pen is such an egregious mistake, but because I have seen how students look at the SAT as a life experience and, from what I saw, using a pen was the least of their worries.

title: Christie Addresses Trade in Mexico
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey arrived in Mexico on Wednesday as part of a three-day trade mission.

title: Lifting Trophy and Profit
description: SEATTLE  These are salad days in the N.F.L.s Pacific Northwest outpost. After years of false starts and near misses, the Seahawks are the reigning Super Bowl champions. Their brash defense, energetic offense and outspoken coach are beloved in this region.

title: In Speech on Mexico Trip, Gov. Christie Lays Out Vision for Energy Renaissance
description: MEXICO CITY  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey offered a prescription for what he called a North American energy renaissance in an expansive speech here, calling for an end to Washingtons 40-year ban on crude oil exports, faster approval of natural gas pipelines between the United States and Mexico, and construction of the Keystone XL pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

title: Mazda Unveils All-New Miata
description: Mazda revealed its all-new 2016 MX-5 Wednesday, holding simultaneous press events in Japan, Spain and California. Popularly known as the Miata, the MX-5 is the best-selling two-seat sports car ever, and nearly one million have been sold since Mazda introduced it in 1989 for the 1990 model year. The car is expected to go on sale next year.

title: Which Colleges Do Students Pick?
description: A survey of 104,000 students reveals how students chose when admitted to two or more colleges.

title: Bail Is Revoked for Driver in Crash That Killed 4-Year-Old
description: An unlicensed teenage driver who fatally struck a 4-year-old girl while fleeing the police last year had his bail revoked on Wednesday after he was arrested in a similar episode.

title: Tour Championships Unlikely Pairing
description: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo.  The seed was planted by Hunter Mahan, who described his proudest accomplishment in golf as a Sports and Leisure question worthy of Trivial Pursuit.

title: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Gives $14,000 Back to Chicago for Travel
description: CHICAGO  Mayor Rahm Emanuel paid back about $14,000 to the city this year after courting campaign donors while traveling at taxpayer expense, a spokesman for the mayor said Wednesday.

title: VFiles: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 3, 2014
Giants Still Working to Solidify Front
description: The Giants on Wednesday signed a new offensive lineman, Adam Snyder, a 10-year veteran released last week by the San Francisco 49ers. At the same time, the Giants put one of their chief off-season acquisitions, the free-agent guard Geoff Schwartz, on a restricted form of injured reserve, which will allow Schwartz, if healthy, to return to play at midseason.

title: Aural Journey Into the Spiritual
description: Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, took a lot of kidding, even some carping, from concertgoers and critics when she inaugurated the White Light Festival in 2010. The lofty goal of this venture was to explore the power of music and the arts to reveal the dimensions of our inner lives. The programs, Ms. Moss asserted, would offer a spectrum of artistic expression that moves us inward and expands our spirit.

title: First, the Sound of Violins
description: No mere gala fluff for these openings.

title: Preview: Green Bay Packers at Seattle Seahawks
description: 8:30 p.m., NBC

title: Divas Vocal Itinerary Makes Stop in Venice
description: Carnegie Halls Perspectives Series, which offers artists at the height of their careers a chance to program their favorite repertory and highlight new discoveries, features the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato this season. A complete artist whose virtuosity meshes to vivid effect with her charismatic stage presence, Ms. DiDonato has programmed some of the composers who have long been an integral part of her career.

title: Scotlands Identity, Put to a Vote
description: In two weeks, Scottish voters will be asked to answer a simple question  Should Scotland be an independent country?  with a simple yes or no. The choice, of course, is far from simple.

title: Andrew McLaglen, Director in the Heyday of TV Westerns, Dies at 94
description: Andrew V. McLaglen, a British-born director whose work in American westerns on television and in the movies starred such notable screen cowpokes, gunslingers and lawmen as John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, James Arness and James Stewart, died on Saturday at his home in Friday Harbor, Wash. He was 94.

title: A Nations Musical Blend, Unfurled
description: Ubuntu: loosely, I am because you are. This fall, the Nguni Bantu term for human kindness, in usage across South Africa, becomes the rallying cry for Carnegie Halls festival dedicated to the music of that nation. As such, it celebrates a sense of community that has been tested for much of that countrys recent history, and that continues to be redefined today, 20 years after the arrival of democracy.

title: Surviving an ISIS Massacre
description: ISIS massacred hundreds of Iraqi military recruits in June 2014. Ali Hussein Kadhim survived. This is his improbable story. [Includes graphic images.]

title: De Blasio Endorses Hochul, Cuomos Pick for Lieutenant Governor
description: When Kathy Hochul served in Congress, she received an A rating from the National Rifle Association. As the Erie County clerk, she took a hard line on undocumented immigrants, pledging to inform the local sheriff about anyone who arrived at her office without valid papers.

title: With Sense of Balance, Caroline Wozniacki Quiets Critics
description: It is an oft-repeated maxim in many sports, but there is room for questioning it when it comes to tennis: Can defense win championships?

title: Escaping Death in Northern Iraq
description: DIWANIYA, Iraq  Ali Hussein Kadhim, an Iraqi soldier and a Shiite, was captured with hundreds of other soldiers by Sunni militants in June and taken to the grounds of a palace complex in Tikrit where Saddam Hussein once lived.

title: When Reporting Is Dangerous
description: My heart broke for Steven Sotloff, the second American journalist beheaded in Syria, not only because of the barbarity ISIS inflicted on him but also because he died trying to push back against the trend in news coverage.

title: Charles Bowden, Author With Unblinking Eye on Southwest, Dies at 69
description: Charles Bowden, an author and journalist acclaimed for his vivid, unsparing and often lyrical portrayals of life in the Southwest, particularly the brutality on the border between the United States and Mexico, died on Saturday in Las Cruces, N.M. He was 69.

title: Another Endurance Test on the Way to the Semifinals
description: For the second time in three days, Kei Nishikori found himself battling through a fifth set, fighting fatigue as much as his opponent, and somehow ending up the last player standing.

title: In Irish Enclaves, Support and Relief as St. Patricks Parade Lifts Ban on Gay Groups
description: The decision to allow gay groups to participate in the New York City St. Patricks Day parade was met mostly with support and relief on Wednesday in the citys Irish neighborhoods and bars.

title: Kuroda Is Sharp, Even if Some of the Yankees Play Is Not
description: The first hit Hiroki Kuroda allowed Wednesday night glanced off him and caromed just to the left of second base. Derek Jeter ranged over carefully, cleanly scooped up the ball and fired it to first base, just a split second late, as the runner crossed the bag.

title: Granderson and Mets Pondering Spring
description: MIAMI  The Mets still have almost a month of games remaining, but it seemed understandableon Wednesdaythat their manager was discussing Curtis Grandersons season in the past tense. It has been one to forget for Granderson, who has three years left on his expensive contract. The spring cannot come soon enough.

title: David Carr Interviews Dean Baquet
description: On Wednesday evening, David Carr, a media columnist, interviewed Dean Baquet, the executive editor, before an audience of Times Premier subscribers. Mr. Baquet also answered questions from the audience.

title: Ryan McGinleys Nude Model Wallpaper
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: E.C.B., Despite Mounting Pressure, May Wait and See
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank is expected to leave its main interest rate at a record low on Thursday, waiting to see the effect of a program to encourage bank lending before it resorts to more powerful but riskier measures to stimulate the faltering eurozone economy.

title: Rdio Moves to Free Music Model to Compete with Spotify and Others
description: In the face of growing competition in the streaming music market, Rdio, a four-year-old service that charges for online subscriptions, has moved into a new phase with abundant free music  as well as free musics ever-present companion, advertising.

title: Vice Lands 2nd Investment, to Fuel Expansion
description: Vice Media, the rabble-rouser of the news and entertainment business, has landed a pair of investments totaling $500 million to fuel the expansion of its media empire.

title: Eclectic Lineup for CBGB Festival
description: The indie bands We Are Scientists and Surfer Blood will rub shoulders with 70s and 80s groups like Devo and Janes Addiction, the R&B singer Macy Gray and the electronica artist Robert DeLong at the third CBGB Music and Film Festival, a five-day celebration of diverse streams of rock and alternative music  as well as film about the music world. The festival will run Oct. 8 through Oct.12, organizers said, at sites in Manhattan  including Times Square, Center 548, Bowery Electric, City Winery and Pianos  and in Brooklyn, at Babys All Right, the Bell House, Saint Vitus, the Knitting Factory and the Trash Bar.

title: Put the Physical in Education
description: When confronted with an overly active child, many exasperated teachers and parents respond the same way: Sit still! It might be more effective, though, to encourage the child to run. Recent research suggests that even small amounts of exercise enable children to improve their focus and academic performance.

title: Word of the Day | skinflint
description: skinflint \skin-flint\ noun

title: The Race Gap in Americas Police Departments
description: Hundreds of police departments across the nation have forces with a white percentage that is more than 30 percentage points higher than the communities they serve.

title: W.H.O. Leader Describes the Agencys Ebola Operations
description: Dr. Margaret Chan, director general of the World Health Organization, based in Geneva, flew to New York on Monday for several days of meetings in the United States focused on the international fight against the Ebola outbreak. Before walking to her first meeting and then tucking into her favorite East Side noodle dive, she sat down for an interview about Ebola.

title: Why Colleges With a Distinct Focus Have a Hidden Advantage
description: Take a look at any of the most widely followed ratings of Americas colleges and universities, and almost all of the top-ranked schools will have this in common: They want to appeal to everyone, or at least everyone with a brilliant mind and a work ethic to match.

title: For Stan Wawrinka, Margin Between Winning and Losing at U.S. Open Is Thin
description: With so many momentum swings, so many spectacular points, so many half chances and incredible shots and ridiculous winners down the line, what ultimately mattered the most in the quarterfinal match between Kei Nishikori and Stan Wawrinka?

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 12:45 A.M. (TCM) FANNY AND ALEXANDER (1983) Two young Swedish siblings (Bertil Guve and Pernilla Allwin) find their joyful lives in 1907 Uppsala upended when their father suddenly dies, and their mother (Ewa Froling) marries an authoritarian bishop (Jan Malmsjo) and moves with her children into his bleak palace, haunted by the ghosts of his dead wife and daughters, with nothing but the clothes on their backs.
