Even as you watch Ingmar Bergmans new film, Fanny and Alexander, it has that quality of enchantment that usually attaches only to the best movies in retrospect, long after youve seen them, when theyve been absorbed into the memory to seem sweeter, wiser, more magical than anything ever does in its own time, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. This immediate resonance is the distinguishing feature of this superb film, which is both quintessential Bergman and unlike anything else he has ever done before.

title: Breaths of Fresh Acting Talent
description: Katherine Waterston, Inherent Vice

title: The U.S. Open Under the Lights
description: A panoramic view of Arthur Ashe Stadium after nightfall during Roger Federers match against Roberto Bautista Agut.

title: In China, Seeking Equality in Education for Disabled Migrants
description: Theyre migrants, theyre children, and theyre disabled  a combination that means they are almost entirely overlooked in society.

title: Novak Djokovic Defeats Andy Murray to Reach U.S. Open Semifinals
description: Andy Murray blasted forehands as he had perhaps never blasted forehands before. He played with fire and conviction, but there has rarely been a tennis champion better at absorbing pace and ambition than Novak Djokovic.

title: Corrections: September 4, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 4, 2014
description: Its about time. Discrimination has no place on Americas streets, least of all on Fifth Avenue.

title: Untold Stories After the Arab Spring
description: Egypts Port Said riot, in which fighting among soccer fans in 2012 left more than 70 dead and 1,000 injured, is one of the deadliest in history. The most haunting images showed hundreds of mourners gathered around coffins, chaos and stampedes of people with fire blazing behind them.

title: Chinese Editors Are Detained in Extortion Investigation
description: Eight people, including editors for a leading Chinese business publication, were detained on Wednesday, accused of extorting money from companies in return for positive coverage, according to reports in the state news media.

title: 6 Qs About the News | After Beheading of Steven Sotloff, Obama Pledges to Punish ISIS
description: In After Beheading of Steven Sotloff, Obama Pledges to Punish ISIS, Julie Hirschfeld Davis writes about President Obamas response to the killings of American journalists kidnapped in Syria.

title: Balfour Beatty to Sell Consulting Business for $1.35 Billion
description: LONDON  The British construction and services company Balfour Beatty has agreed to sell its Parsons Brinckerhoff consulting business to WSP Global for $1.35 billion.

title: Chekhovs The Seagull, Adapted and Updated for Beijing
description: Anton Chekhov said of his play The Seagull that it had little action and lots of talk about love, according to Gavin Quinn, the director of a zany adaptation of the Russian classic that opens Thursday at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing.

title: Test Yourself | The Simpsons Marathon Draws Large Audience
description: Below are six paragraphs from the Sept. 3 article The Simpsons Marathon Lifts Ratings for Fledgling FXX Network.

title: A Debate Fueled by Carbs (or the Lack Thereof)
description: A new study has found that a low-carb diet may be better for cardiovascular health and weight lossthan a low-fat one. However, Anahad OConnor writesat The New York Times that the findings are unlikely to be the final salvo in what has been a long and often contentious debate about what foods are best to eat for weight loss and overall health.

title: Do You Like Watching Other People Play Video Games?
description: Video game tournaments are packing sports arenas and offering multimillion-dollar prizes. In fact, a League of Legends championship last October attracted as many online viewers at its peak as the deciding game of professional hockeys Stanley Cup finals in June.

title: In Southeast Asia, Indonesia Is an Unlikely Role Model for Democracy
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  For a while, it looked as if Indonesias bad old days had returned.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Add an L to Q70, Get a Longer Infiniti
description: Like a lot of people, Ive found myself a little confused by Infinitis recent shift in nomenclature. The Q70 sport sedan, for instance, was known until the 2014 model year as the M; now Infiniti has thrown another letter into the alphabet soup by offering a long-wheelbase version for 2015, the Q70L.

title: New York Today: Back to School
description: Good morning on this unseasonably warm Thursday.

title: Al Qaeda Opens New Branch on Indian Subcontinent
description: NEW DELHI  Al Qaeda has released a video announcing the establishment of a new branch on the Indian subcontinent, saying it is meant to revive jihadist activity in a region that was once part of the land of Muslims, until the infidel enemy occupied it and fragmented it and split it.

title: Daily Report: Tracing Stolen Credit Cards, Road Leads Back to Home Depot
description: There are two tracks to finding the identity of a company that has been hit by cybercriminals. Both of them involve going backward, Nicole Perlorth reports.

title: New York Fashion Week Morning Report
description: New York Fashion Week has just begun, and if youre a completist, youre already fashionably late.

title: Obama and Cameron Call on NATO to Confront ISIS
description: CARDIFF, Wales  President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain have called on NATO to reject isolationist impulses and confront the rising terrorist threat posed by Sunni militants in the Middle East, saying the United States and Britain will not be cowed by barbaric killers.

title: Why Many Small Businesses Cannot Be Sold
description: Many business owners have a dream of selling their business some day. But many of those businesses will never be sold. You can see this simply by reviewing the number of businesses listed for sale each month on the website BizBuySell.com.

title: Bank of England Resists Change to Interest Rate
description: LONDON  To raise or not to raise, that is the question  in Britain, at least.

title: Europes Bank Takes Aggressive Steps
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, is reaching deep into his toolbox to revive the regions moribund economy.

title: 1954 | The Picture That Cost the Picture Editor His Job
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

title: Cisco Has a Server-Centric Vision for Itself
description: With the introduction of some impressive new products, the networking giant Cisco may be looking for more than sales. It may be trying to change the conversation about itself.

title: Chinas Education Gap
description: BEIJING  EVERY September, the campuses of Peking and Tsinghua Universities, often called the Harvard and M.I.T. of China, brim with eager new students, the winners of Chinas cutthroat education system. These young men and women possess the outlook of cosmopolitan youth worldwide: sporting designer clothes and wielding high-end smartphones, they share experiences of foreign travel and bond over common fondness for Western television shows like The Big Bang Theory and Sherlock.

title: 1939: Fighting on Western Front
description: Guns roared yesterday on the western front. A Nazi imitation of Von Tirpitzs submarine the Frightfulness (Schrecklichkeit) was held responsible for the sinking of the 13,500-ton British liner Athenia, carrying 1,400 passengers, of whom about 300 were Americans, off the northwest coast of Scotland. In the furious fighting in Poland, the Germans were reported to have employed asphyxiating and mustard gas, together with an unknown chemical. Royal Air Force planes made an uneventful round trip into Germany during which they scattered more than 6,000,000 leaflets containing a proclamation to the German people, London announced.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 5, 1939

title: Taliban Attack Intelligence Base in Eastern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 14 Afghans, 12 of them security personnel, were killed Thursday in a Taliban attack in the southeastern city of Ghazni, Afghan officials said.

title: More Thoughts on Alexander Wang
description: Profiling Alexander Wang was an interesting experience for me because, as much as anything, it made me rethink my assumptions about the one designer/two brand thing, as well as, to a certain extent, about Mr. Wang.

title: Morning Agenda: Bloomberg Returning to His Company
description: Michael R. Bloomberg has decided to resume the leadership of his business empire only eight months after ending his final term as mayor of New York, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in The New York Times. On Wednesday, Mr. Bloomberg told close confidants and senior executives of Bloomberg L.P., a financial data and media company, that Daniel L. Doctoroff, its chief executive and a longtime friend and lieutenant, would leave the company at the end of the year and that he would take over.

title: Bloomberg Memo
description: The memo from Daniel L. Doctoroff to the Bloomberg staff announcing the return of Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: An Ominous Trade Center Beacon
description: Dear Diary:

title: Fashion Week Begins With Cocktails at the Mayors House
description: The fashion world and the mayor are starting to get more comfortable with each other.

title: Memo to Bloomberg Staff
description: The memo from Daniel L. Doctoroff to the Bloomberg staff announcing the return of Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Iraqis Identify Prisoner as Chinese Islamist Fighter
description: BEIJING  The Iraqi Defense Ministry has posted on its Facebook page photographs that it says show a captured Chinese man who was fighting on behalf of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni jihadist group.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Dozens Killed as Bus Plunges Into Stream in Northern India
description: A bus carrying dozens of members of a wedding party plunged off a mountainous road and into a deep, fast-running stream in the Jammu region on Thursday, killing nearly everyone aboard, the Indian authorities said.

title: Total Transparency
description: Exposing the intricate bones of an 18-karat white gold timepiece, Cartiers spectacular new Tank Louis Sapphire Skeleton features blued steel hands, a sapphire crystal and case back and a movement with 159 individual parts, including 21 jewels  leaving very little to the imagination in the most imaginative way possible. $53,500, cartier.com

title: Think Like a Doctor: Weaker and Weaker
description: The Challenge: A 19-year-old man collapses at work after months of increasing weakness. Can you figure out why?

title: Elizabeth Warren at CUNY
description: She and I will be having a dialogue, moderated by Janet Gornick of LIS, starting at 7:30. You can watch the live stream here.

title: Incident of the Actor for the First Time
description: As Alex Sharp, 25, was preparing to graduate from the Juilliard School in May, he steeled himself for the life of a struggling actor, making distressed-wood coffee tables with plumbers-pipe legs to sell on Craigslist.

title: My First Time (Its a Little Scary)
description: So you want to be on Broadway?

title: Almost Famous
description: A recent graduate of the Juilliard School, Alex Sharp tackles a breakout role in the Broadway debut of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.

title: Mattress Firm Holding to Buy Rival Sleep Train
description: The Mattress Firm Holding Corporation, one of the countrys big sellers of Sealy and Serta mattresses, has agreed to acquire a West Coast rival, the Sleep Train chain, for about $425 million, solidifying its position as the biggest mattress retailer in the country.

title: Hundreds of Fast-Food Workers Striking for Higher Wages Are Arrested
description: Hundreds of fast-food workers and labor allies demanding a $15-an-hour wage were arrested in sit-ins around the country on Thursday, as the protesters used civil disobedience to call attention to their cause.

title: The Genetically Blessed of Fashion Week
description: One of the great things about models is that they keep making new ones. The supply is inexhaustible. Not to worry if it seems that the well might dry up of East London lads or toned Iowa farm boys or wan Eastern European starvelings. There is always another mall to scout; another vein to mine.

title: Bigger Fines Against Wall St. Should Not Result in More Lawyers
description: Geoffrey A. Moore is a business adviser, speaker and author of Crossing the Chasm, Dealing with Darwin and Escape Velocity.

title: Ken Follett: By the Book
description: The author of The Pillars of the Earth and, most recently, Edge of Eternity cant stand whimsical fantasy: If there are no rules, and anything can happen, then wheres the suspense? I hate elves.

title: The Food Start-Up Hampton Creek Adds Tech Talent
description: The flow of techies seeking to shake up the food business is picking up.

title: The Odds and Ends of New York
description: From a human perspective, theres no such thing as an objective object. Anything that comes to a persons attention  a rock, a tree, a dog, a painting, another person  will evoke ideas, feelings, memories and fantasies. Every object tells a story.

title: Groups Accuse Apple Supplier in China of Labor Violations
description: HONG KONG  With its stock near a high and its latest iPhone expected to be introduced on Tuesday, Apple is facing new accusations of violations of labor rights and workplace safety at a supplier in China.

title: 1964: New York Disappoints French
description: PARIS  French tourists find New York not worth more than a four-day stay, the afternoon newspaper Paris-Presse said today [Sept. 4]. Among their complaints according to the papers New York correspondent are that they catch cold from the air-conditioning, to which they are unaccustomed, that there is nothing worth seeing in New York aside from the three major museums, that the Worlds Fair is too hot and over-commercialized, that there are no bidets in hotel rooms, and that no one understands French.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 5, 1964

title: European Central Bank President on Rates
description: Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, announced that the bank would cut interest rates to an all-time low.

title: 51,000 Answer de Blasios Bell for New Pre-K
description: In the classrooms at Pinocchio Childrens Palace in Brooklyn on Thursday, there was a discussion about sharing the toy cash register, there was talk about the importance of saying Im sorry, there was dancing. And there were some tears.

title: How People Feel About Their Employer-Sponsored Health Plans
description: Were still waiting to get really good information about how people who have bought health plans on the new state marketplaces are liking them. Theres some early polling evidence that people are happy to have coverage  but also some accounts that people are frustrated by small doctor networks and struggling to afford medical care even after getting insurance.

title: Why Flunking Exams Is Actually a Good Thing
description: Imagine that on Day 1 of a difficult course, before you studied a single thing, you got hold of the final exam. The motherlode itself, full text, right there in your email inbox  attached mistakenly by the teacher, perhaps, or poached by a campus hacker. No answer key, no notes or guidelines. Just the questions.

title: Toronto Festival 2014: Glamorous Actresses Playing Tarnished Characters
description: Updated, 5:15 p.m. | TORONTO  It takes a brave actress to rough herself up and appear on-screen without all the tricks and trade-craft that make beautiful people even more so in the movies.

title: Tracing Jewish History Along the Rhine
description: In the summer of 1963, when I was 12, my parents, German-speaking Jewish refugees from Vienna, took us children on a boat trip up the Rhine. It was our first time in Germany, the country that had annexed our parents native Austria and sent them running for their lives. Family sentiments ran strong: longing spiked with anger, nostalgia with regret. All I really cared about were the castles crowning every slope and the chocolate-covered marzipan. But when we rounded a boulder-strewn bend in the river  The Lorelei, the legendary perch of the siren who lured boatmen to their doom  my mother was so moved she leapt up and declaimed, in German: I dont know whats come over me, / That I should be so sad.

title: Teaching Children Empathy
description: When Harvard Universitys Making Caring Common Project released their report, The Children We Mean to Raise: The Real Messages Adults Are Sending About Values, many parents and educators  myself included  were surprised to learn that despite all our talk about instilling character and empathy, kids may value academic achievement and individual happiness over caring for others. In the report, the authors explained that the childrens values reflected what they believe adults value.

title: Stephen D. Isaacs, Journalist and Educator, Dies at 76
description: Stephen D. Isaacs, who at 26 became city editor of The Washington Post and went on to become a prominent journalist and academic at Columbia University, died on Aug. 28 in Austin, Tex. He was 76.

title: Michael Aram on the Artisans of Delhi
description: When the home dcor designer Michael Aram first toured the bazaars of Old Delhi, in 1988, he didnt expect to return to his home in New York City with a new profession, let alone one that would lead him to set up shop in India.

title: Death, Recovery and Hope at a Hospital During Drawdown
description: These days most NATO forces in Afghanistan rarely, if ever, leave the secured perimeters of their bases. While safer, life on base produces a complicated proximity to the realities of war  were both close and far away. At Bagram Airfield north of Kabul, the line between life and death is often clearest in the largest American hospital in the country, Craig Joint Theater Hospital.

title: Europes Big Push for Growth Is More About Trust Than Anything
description: Earlier this summer, Mario Draghi pulled out his big guns, threatening to deploy vast financial firepower to try to jolt the European economy out of its cycle of stagnant growth and falling inflation.

title: Rogue Trader Jrme Kerviel to Be Released From French Jail
description: PARIS  A French appeals court has accepted a request from Jrme Kerviel, a former trader convicted of rogue dealings at Socit Gnrale, that he be released from jail and allowed to serve out his three-year sentence with an electronic monitoring bracelet, his lawyer confirmed on Thursday.

title: Independent Now a Real Contender in the Kansas Senate Race
description: It has been clear for some time that Pat Roberts, a Republican senator from Kansas, was in a lot more trouble than he ought to be in a deeply Republican state. Plagued by residency issues, he won the Republican nomination with only 48 percent of the vote, and polls showed a surprisingly tight race in one of the most conservative states in the country.

title: How Sticker Shock Led to a Sale
description: For the first of her four years at Parsons the New School for Design, Sabrina Banta lived in a siren-tormented dorm on East 15th Street near a hospital. She later moved to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for three years, sharing two different light-deprived rentals with several roommates.

title: In Defense of Chain Links
description: As old-school chain cuff links face an existential threat, one man makes a stand for true closure.

title: Hanks and Tomlin Among New Kennedy Center Honorees
description: WASHINGTON  The letter informing Lily Tomlin that she had been selected as one of this years five honorees by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts sat unopened on her desk for days.

title: BP May Be Fined Up to $18 Billion for Spill in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS  In the four years since the blowout on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig killed 11 workers and sent millions of barrels of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, BP has spent more than $28 billion on damage claims and cleanup costs, pleaded guilty to criminal charges and emerged a shrunken giant.

title: Will the New Autocorrect Steal Your Soul?
description: Autocorrect may fix some of your mistakes, and make some amusing ones of its own. But will its successor correct more than your spelling, essentially hijacking your personality?

title: Puerto Rico Hires Supervisor for Utility Restructuring
description: Puerto Ricos electric power authority, which has been in negotiations with lenders over its debt burden, said on Thursday that it had hired the consulting firm AlixPartners to supervise its restructuring.

title: Argentine Dinosaur Was an Estimated 130,000 Pounds, and Still Growing
description: PHILADELPHIA  Eighty-five feet long, 30 feet tall, 130,000 pounds and still growing when it died, a newly described dinosaur is among the largest land animals that ever lived  so big its discoverers are calling it the Dreadnoughtus.

title: Scientist Discusses Dreadnoughtus
description: Dr. Kenneth J. Lacovara, a paleontologist at Drexel University, discussed the oversized dinosaur remains found in the Patagonia region of Argentina.

title: Terrorism Around the World, 50 Years Ago
description: A look back finds unrest in some unlikely spots, and some likely ones too.

title: A Measurement of Terrorism in 1964, Canada Included
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Canadians Concern on Terrorism Rises appeared on Sept. 1 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: NATO Prepares New Sanctions Over Russian Action in Ukraine
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Amid talk of a possible cease-fire between Ukrainian forces and Moscow-backed separatists, President Obama and European leaders at a NATO summit meeting here on Thursday prepared a new round of sanctions against Russian officials, banks and enterprises that could be imposed as early as Friday.

title: Shellshocked Ukrainians Flee to New Lives in Russia
description: DONETSK, Russia  Oksana Shevelina, 62, who came here with her elderly mother just a few days ago from their home in eastern Ukraine, squinted at a map of the Russian Federation.

title: Seeking a Pipeline, U.S.T.A. Turns to the College Game
description: On Thursday, some of the nations best college tennis players made a rare appearance at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. The occasion was the start of a four-day tournament, sponsored by the United States Tennis Association and held with the blessing of the N.C.A.A., that is part of a high-profile initiative to reinvigorate and promote intercollegiate tennis.

title: Wheelies: The Thrifty G.M. Pickups Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: F.C.C. to Promote Choices for High-Speed Broadband
description: WASHINGTON  Americans lack real choices among providers of high-speed Internet service, with fewer than one in four homes having access to two or more providers of the broadband speeds that are quickly becoming table stakes in modern communications, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday.

title: New York Fashion Week Spring/Summer 2015: Antonio Azzuolo
description: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Unicef Report Details Endemic Violence Against Children
description: UNITED NATIONS  One in 10 girls worldwide have been forced into a sexual act, and six in 10 children ages 2 to 14 are regularly beaten by parents and caregivers, according to a report issued Thursday by the United Nations childrens agency, Unicef.

title: Today in Small Business: Suppose Your Company Name Is Isis
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Poetry Pairing | The Properly Scholarly Attitude
description: We ring in the new school year with our first Poetry Pairing of the season: Adelaide Crapseys poem The Properly Scholarly Attitude and the Op-Talk feature Children Need Free Play, but Are Unschoolers Giving Them Too Much? by Hanna Kozlowska.

title: A New Food Tour in Prague
description: The food tour company that started in Rome and expanded into London and Amsterdam has made its debut in Eastern Europe.

title: Collection | Poetry Pairings
description: Our Poetry Pairings feature, a collaboration with the Poetry Foundation, has been going strong since the summer of 2010, presenting classic and contemporary poems alongside New York Times articles and photography.

title: Miranda Lambert and Blake Shelton Among Country Music Award Nominees
description: When the Country Music Association hands out its annual awards in a ceremony televised from Nashville on Nov. 5, Miranda Lambert and her husband, Blake Shelton, will be direct competitors. Both are nominated for the entertainer of the year honor, as well as for single of the year (Automatic in Ms. Lamberts case; Mine Would Be You, in Mr. Sheltons). The association announced the award nominees on Wednesday.

title: Chicago Symphony Association Names a New President
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra Association had been searching for a new president since Deborah F. Rutter announced in December that she planned to leave in June to become president of the Kennedy Center. Now the board has named Jeff Alexander to the post, starting Jan. 12. The association oversees the orchestra and related entities.

title: Father Charged With Murder in Hot-Car Death, and Death Penalty Is Weighed
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  The suburban Atlanta father whose toddler died in June after being left in a hot vehicle was indicted Thursday on murder charges.

title: IV Misplaced in Oklahoma Execution, Report Says
description: An official report released Thursday about a bungled execution in Oklahoma in April says that an improperly placed intravenous line in the prisoners groin allowed the drugs to perfuse surrounding tissue rather than to flow directly into his bloodstream.

title: Dynamic Planet: Under the Volcano in Papua New Guinea
description: A caldera is the cauldron-like depression formed when a volcanic eruption empties a shallow chamber of magma and the cone collapses. If the volcano is at sea level, the result, after the passage of time, can be a fine harbor.

title: Report on Clayton Lockett Execution
description: The Oklahoma Department of Public Safety released this report of its review of the events leading up to and during the bungled execution of an inmate in April.

title: Stan Goldberg, Who Drew Archie for Decades, Dies at 82
description: Stan Goldberg, who drew Archie comics for more than 40 years, notably a series beginning in 2009 in which an adult Archie finally marries  both Betty and Veronica, in alternate timelines  died on Sunday at a hospice in the Bronx. He was 82.

title: No Comment Necessary: 30 Years in Jail for Nothing, but the Process Worked
description: Henry Lee McCollum and his half-brother, Leon Brown, were released from prison in North Carolina on Wednesday after having spent decades in jail for a crime they did not commit. That night, ThinkProgress asked Thom Tillis, the North Carolina House Speaker and Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate seat currently occupied by Kay Hagan, if anything needed to change in light of the case.

title: Sergio Rodrigues, Father of Brazilian Furniture Design, Dies at 86
description: Sergio Rodrigues, whose tables, chairs and other living accessories set the standard for modern furniture design in his native Brazil and who forged a path to the international market for his countrymen, died on Monday at his home in Rio de Janeiro. He was 86.

title: Russia Resettles Refugees From War-Torn Eastern Ukraine
description: Russia is promoting a huge resettlement program to encourage refugees to put down roots in far-flung cities across Russia.

title: BCBG Max Azria: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Hurricane Sandy Recovery Program in New York City Was Mired by Its Design
description: The night Hurricane Sandy struck, Jayme and John Galimi swam out the front door of their home in Broad Channel, Queens, into the rising waters of Jamaica Bay with their five children, the youngest clinging to his fathers back.

title: Wedding Q.&A.
description: Suddenly, a Fianc Appears

title: Getty Grants for Personal Photo Projects
description: This years winners have tackled themes from South Africas post-apartheid generation to the lives of Arab women.

title: Living With Schizophrenia: The Importance of Routine
description: I can remember the early days of having schizophrenia. I was so afraid of the implications of subtle body language, like a lingering millisecond of eye contact, the way my feet hit the ground when I walked or the way I held my hands to my side. It was a struggle to go into a store or, really, anywhere I was bound to see another living member of the human species.

title: Michael Katz, Who Challenged View of Poverty, Dies at 75
description: Michael B. Katz, an influential historian and social theorist who challenged the prevailing view in the 1980s and 90s that poverty stemmed from the bad habits of the poor, marshaling the case that its deeper roots lay in the actions of the powerful, died on Aug. 23 in Philadelphia. He was 75.

title: A Day in the Life | Rosetta Getty
description: T follows fashion designer Rosetta Getty through a day in New York City as she works on her spring/summer 2015 collection, takes in a show at Gagosian and scouts locations for a lookbook photo shoot.

title: A Book Bound in Human Skin? Sorry, Not This Time.
description: Three months after scientists at Harvard confirmed that a 19th-century French treatise in one of its libraries was almost certainly bound in human skin, another institution has put a supposed anthropodermic binding in its possession to the test and come up wanting.

title: Coach: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Senegal Is Only the Start
description: The first Senegalese dish I ate at Caf Rue Dix looked a lot like Vietnamese spring rolls: pale, crackly bundles with bubbled bits of rice paper shearing off, backed by frills of kale. They came with a dark dipping sauce as vinegary and lime-bright as nuoc cham.

title: Senate Forecast Update: What Will Greg Orman Do?
description: How does the big political news out of Kansas affect the odds in our Senate forecasting model?

title: Ruling on the 2010 Gulf of Mexico Oil Well Blowout
description: U.S. District Court Judge Carl J. Barbier ruled on Thursday that BP was grossly negligent in the oil rig explosion that killed 11 workers, spilled millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches.

title: Rosetta Getty Prepares for New York Fashion Week
description: Since launching her namesake ready-to-wear line last fall, the Los Angeles-based fashion designer Rosetta Getty has been quietly assembling a wardrobe of easy, elegant garments for women like her, who want to be able to seamlessly and stylishly transition from grade school drop-offs to after-work events. Instead of one-off looks, Getty creates collections that build off each previous seasons pieces, which lends a thoughtful cohesion to her line. As she prepared to unveil whats next for spring 2015, Getty gave the filmmaker Marissa Kaiser a glimpse into her creative process on the eve of fashion week in New York.

title: Googles F.T.C. Tab for Charges Rung Up by Children: $19 Million
description: Here are some reasons people might not want children to play with their phones: They dont want them to accidentally call their boss. They dont want them to become mindless phone addicts like themselves. Also, they dont want get stuck with a $200 bill for digital coins, virtual lives and other video game perks that cost real-world money.

title: National G.O.P. Moves to Take Over Campaign of a Kansas Senator
description: WASHINGTON  National Republicans on Thursday moved to take control of the campaign of Senator Pat Roberts of Kansas by sending a longtime party strategist to the state to advise him, a day after his hopes for re-election and those of his party for taking control of the Senate were threatened by the attempted withdrawal of the Democrat in the race.

title: Former Israeli President Proposes Global Peace Initiative in Talks With Pope
description: ROME  Shimon Peres, the former president of Israel, met with Pope Francis on Thursday to present his plan to create a sort of United Nations for religions to address the nature of contemporary conflicts.

title: When Protge Resents Mentor
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Libya Militia Fighting Takes Toll on Civilians, U.N. Says
description: GENEVA  Fighting among militias in and around the Libyan cities of Tripoli and Benghazi in recent weeks has killed hundreds of people, including many civilians, the United Nations said Thursday in a report that described summary executions, abductions and torture taking place in a growing climate of fear.

title: Al Qaeda Announces New Branch in India
description: In a video posted online, the Al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahri announced the establishment of Qaedat al-Jihad in the Indian Subcontinent.

title: How Caffeine Evolved to Help Plants Survive and Help People Wake Up
description: Every second, people around the world drink more than 26,000 cups of coffee. And while some of them may care only about the taste, most use it as a way to deliver caffeine into their bloodstream. Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychoactive substance in the world.

title: Guinness World Record Book Acknowledges Metallica, Eminem and Miley Cyrus
description: Metallica, Eminem, One Direction and Miley Cyrus are among the musicians who have found their way into Guinness World Records 2015, which will be published next week.

title: M.L.B. Hires Bryan Seeley to Lead Investigations Unit
description: Major League Baseball on Thursday appointed Bryan Seeley as its new head of investigations, the latest step in an overhaul of the department since the Alex Rodriguez doping case.

title: Brauns Old Look Is New Again
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Braun.

title: Throwback Thursday | Back to School, 1940
description: On Sept. 8, 1940, The New York Times reminded 1,100,000 children and 40,000 teachers that New York City schools started the next day.

title: First Arrest Made in 2012 Steroid Medication Deaths
description: Federal authorities made the first arrest in the case of the New England Compounding Center, a Massachusetts-based drug maker whose tainted steroid pain medication killed dozens of people across the country in 2012.

title: Federal Judge Orders Ohio to Undo Cuts to Early Voting
description: A federal judge on Thursday blocked Ohios cuts to early voting and ordered the state to establish additional polling days before Novembers elections, saying the reductions would disproportionately harm the poor and members of minority groups.

title: Lending Club May Need to Justify Its Valuation
description: Lending Club is positioning itself as one of the biggest challengers to American banks. The company is growing quickly, has backing from the likes of Google and counts the former Morgan Stanley chief John J. Mack and former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers among its directors. Its also planning an initial public offering. But there are reasons to be cautious.

title: Former Governor in Virginia Guilty in Bribery Case
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were convicted of corruption in federal court on Thursday, after a trial that shattered the political career of the onetime Republican star and peeled back the couples private life to the bone.

title: New Light on Hamas Role in Killings of Teenagers That Fueled Gaza War
description: JERUSALEM  The abduction and killing of three Israeli teenagers in the occupied West Bank in June, which helped fuel the biggest escalation in Palestinian-Israeli tensions in years, was set in motion by Hamas operatives from a local Palestinian clan and was financed with about $60,000, mostly obtained through a relative who worked for a Hamas association in Gaza, according to official Israeli documents released on Thursday.

title: Apple Plans Smartwatch and Larger iPhones
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Apple wants to make a big splash, it returns to its history.

title: New York Police Officers to Start Using Body Cameras in a Pilot Program
description: The New York Police Department will begin equipping a small number of its officers with wearable video cameras, a pilot program geared toward eventually outfitting the nations largest police force with technology that promises greater accountability.

title: Jameis Winston Case Said to Be Subject of Florida State Inquiry
description: Nearly 21 months after a female student accused Jameis Winston, Florida States marquee quarterback, of sexually assaulting her in his apartment, the university has begun a disciplinary inquiry into the case, the womans lawyer said Thursday.

title: Cornered, They Reach for Their Sex Pistols
description: The distance between riot grrrl and suburban mom is quite a stretch. But as middle age approaches, time has a way of landing mouthy young rebels in roles they never expected to inhabit. Take Juliette Lewis, the personification of scary defiance alongside Woody Harrelson as her partner in crime in Natural Born Killers.

title: DreamWorks Chooses Chief From Ranks of Television
description: LOS ANGELES  Steven Spielbergs struggling live-action movie company, DreamWorks Studios, announced on Thursday that it would part ways with its longtime chief and named a former television executive to succeed her.

title: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the Rookies, Part 2
description: The conventional wisdom in fantasy football has traditionally been to avoid rookies. While some are more flash than substance, rookies should not be underestimated or ignored.

title: Celebrating American Quilts in Shows and Books
description: Quilt scholars are debunking a few myths this fall.

title: Intimate Feelings, Especially for Herself
description: The title of Wetlands strongly suggests a nature documentary, and thats not so far off the mark. Doing  and smelling and tasting  what comes naturally is the singular obsession of the films rollicking heroine, Helen (Carla Juri, sensational), an 18-year-old student of vaginal flora and bodily fluids. Helens cheerfully experimental sex life and rebellious attitude toward personal hygiene may shock her Catholic mother, but her unwavering affection for her body, in all its secreting glory, is nothing less than thrilling.

title: Obamacare Challengers Lose Again
description: On Thursday morning, as almost everyone predicted it would, the federal appeals court in Washington, D.C., voted to toss out a three-judge panels ruling upholding the latest attempt to kill Obamacare. The full 11-member court is scheduled to rehear the case on Dec. 17.

title: Renee Zellweger in Red-Hot Carolina Herrera
description: The Star: Renee Zellweger

title: Mazda Reveals Little About the 2016 Miata
description: MARINA, Calif.  Well, the new Mazda MX-5 Miata looks pretty.

title: Between Gaza and Israel, a Border Crossing in Need of Travelers
description: EREZ CROSSING, at the Israel-Gaza border  At 375,000 square feet, the terminal through which travelers pass between Israel and the Gaza Strip is a vast, high-tech hangar with a capacity of 45,000 people per day. Current traffic: 400 or fewer.

title: Joan Rivers, a Comic Stiletto Quick to Skewer, Is Dead at 81
description: Joan Rivers, the raspy loudmouth who pounced on Americas obsessions with flab, face-lifts, body hair and other blemishes of neurotic life, including her own, in five decades of caustic comedy that propelled her from nightclubs to television to international stardom, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Joan Rivers: 50 Years of Funny
description: Moments from the groundbreaking career of Joan Rivers.

title: Joan Rivers Overcame the Handicap of a Woman Comic
description: Joan Rivers, the irreverent comedian known for her sharp wit and sharper tongue, died Thursday in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: For Dante de Blasio, Its Back to School (With Mayoral Escort)
description: Exiled parents sulked on a tree-lined block in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, across from a high school where administrators were gently  but insistently  making it clear that the time had come to let go.

title: Greetings From the NYT 4th Down Bot
description: Hello again, my friends. My name is NYT 4th Down Bot, and I exist for just one purpose: to encourage smarter thinking about N.F.L. fourth downs. I analyze every single fourth down of every game, every week, in real time. I come in peace.

title: 4th Down: When to Go for It and Why
description: This post is meant to be a quick tutorial on fourth-down strategy, neatly summarized in the chart above. (You can also read a post that explains the history of me  the NYT 4th Down Bot.)

title: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Dangerous for Evil
description: It is ideas, not vested interests, which are dangerous for good or evil. So declared Keynes at the end of The General Theory; although I dont think he appreciated the extent to which vested interests can buy the ideas they want to hear. Anyway, this seems relevant to Brad DeLongs flashback to 2009, when I was lamenting bad ideas from freshwater economists and Justin Fox was dismissing them as having no influence on policy.

title: Warhols Presley and Brando Head to Auction
description: Whom would you prefer to live with, Elvis Presley or Marlon Brando?

title: A Princess Bride in a Digital Forever
description: Ari Folmans genre mash-up The Congress could use a freakier title, something either more appealing or appalling to go with the weird, sometimes wonderful visions flowing through it. Not that its all entirely strange. Theres the opening image, for starters  a close-up of Robin Wrights face, a familiar, delicate facade thats well enough known to ignite a chain of signification: beauty, actress, star, Sean Penn, House of Cards, The Princess Bride, middle age, under-sung, career rebirth.

title: Relentless, With No Off Switch
description: Her delivery was like an automatic sprinkler: fast, relentless and sometimes prone to stick, soaking a comic riff into a muddy swamp.

title: Doctor Zhivago Musical Coming to Broadway
description: A musical adaptation of Doctor Zhivago is expected to begin performances at the Broadway Theater in the spring of 2015, with another new musical, King Kong, in discussions to move into that theater after the Zhivago run ends, according to three theater executives familiar with the plans. The Broadway, a prime house for musicals, is coming open with Wednesdays announcement that Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella will close on Jan. 3.

title: Opposition Grows in Europe to Google Antitrust Proposal
description: BRUSSELS  Microsoft and the German publishing industry on Thursday stepped up pressure on the European Unions antitrust chief to make radical adjustments to a proposed antitrust settlement with Google, or effectively leave resolution of the case to his successor.

title: For NATO Yes, For Kiev No
description: Over the last few weeks, heavier Russian incursions into the Ukrainian east reversed Ukraines push to reclaim its separatist provinces, and over the last weekthe West has responded  with a French decision to (finally) suspend a promised warship sale to Russia; with news that the upcoming NATO conference will consider the creation of a new rapid reaction force for Eastern Europe; andwith a forceful Obama speechthis week in Tallinn, Estonia, that both condemned Russian aggression and strongly reaffirmed NATOs official commitment to the defense of the Baltic states. And these Western steps may (or may not, who can say?) have influenced Moscows sudden enthusiasm for a cease-fire and peace talks  albeit, of course,on terms favorable to Vladimir Putins desire to keep Ukraine divided, Russian-influenced and weak.

title: Getty Grants for Personal Photo Projects
description: PERPIGNAN, France  The Getty Images editorial grant winners were awarded today at Visa Pour lImage festival.

title: Senate Modeling
description: The stakes in this years midterms arent as high as in some elections; Republicans are sure to retain control of at least one house, Obama will still be president, so gridlock continues. Still, some things will be at stake  for example, whether the Congressional Budget Office turns into an adjunct of the Heritage Foundation. And whatever happens, it will be held up as giving somebody or other a mandate for something or other. So its definitely interesting to watch.

title: Stories Writ in Eyebrow Pencil
description: JOHN WATERS has been thinking a lot about the half-century lately.

title: Duckie Brown: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Jazz to End Summer in Rockaway Beach and Brooklyn
description: With relatively comfortable temperatures and the dynamic mix of activities that his brood has undertaken, the last several weeks made up one of the more fulfilling Augusts the Miser can remember. Is it so wrong, then, to want to eke out one last weekend in the warmth of the sun?

title: Gareth Pugh on Nick Knight, Holiday Packages and the Enduring Appeal of The Wicker Man
description: Today, the London-based designer Gareth Pugh, who has received years of acclaim for his bold collections and sometimes outlandish runway shows, will present at New York Fashion Week for the first time. Except its not a fashion show per se, but rather whats being touted as a live, immersive fashion experience, incorporating videos by Pughs longtime collaborator Ruth Hogben and choreography by Wayne MacGregor.

title: Gay-Marriage Bans Fall in Wisconsin and Indiana
description: Only nine days after hearing arguments in the case, a federal appeals court in Chicago declared the bans on same-sex marriage in Indiana and Wisconsin to be unconstitutional on Thursday, adding to the list of marriage cases that could wind up before the Supreme Court in the year ahead.

title: Time Out Dubai
description: The number of serious literary novels that take for their setting the desert city of Dubai could be numbered on a hands digits, with the thumb, ring finger and pinkie unused. When the editors of Time Out Dubai enumerated their Top 10 Books about  and set in  Dubai, they came up with, among others, the following: Carte Blanche, a James Bond novel by Jeffery Deaver; Ben Mezrichs get-rich-quick story Rigged; and Candace Havenss Charmed and Dangerous: Bronwyn the Witch No. 1. Of that last, the venerable travel guide remarks: This chick-friendly romance by U.S. resident Havens takes an adventurous turn when Bronwyn, a 25-year-old witch from Texas, accepts a job with the British prime minister and finds herself traveling to Dubai, where she meets a sheikh who insists she accept the use of his private jet. You get the picture.

title: The Big Sweep
description: Few writers, once established in the public consciousness, have changed their style as drastically as James Ellroy. In his early days, Ellroy wandered through the boneyards of 1980s pulp, channeling Jim Thompson and Dashiell Hammett before he found his own voice with a trilogy of contemporary novels about a troubled, racist genius cop named Lloyd Hopkins. Hopkins was morally despicable in the day-to-day, but compared with the monsters he fought in the neon-drench of underworld Los Angeles, he was quasi-angelic. When Ellroy closed out the Hopkins trilogy with Suicide Hill in 1986, he shuttered his interest in topical culture as well and moved into the second incarnation of his career, that of the wildly romantic yet increasingly bilious chronicler of Los Angeles in the years immediately following World War II.

title: SS-Obersturmbannfhrer (Retired)
description: Ever since his capture in the early 1960s, Otto Adolf Eichmann, who was in charge of Jewish affairs during the Third Reich, has been the subject of unsettled and passionate controversy  centered, above all, on Hannah Arendts portrait of him at his 1961 trial. Her Eichmann in Jerusalem in many ways mirrored Eichmanns own self-presentation. She insisted that, contrary to expectations, the man in the dock was not some kind of demonic Nazi sadist but a thoughtless, relatively anonymous, nonideological bureaucrat dutifully executing orders for the emigration, deportation and murder of European Jewry. Arendts insights  that genocide and bureaucratic banality are not necessarily opposed, that fanatical anti-Semitism (or for that matter, any ideological predisposition) is not a sufficient precondition for mass murder  remain pertinent.

title: On the Border, a Fall From Grace
description: The image of Ed Harris in a cowboy hat, astride a horse, in Frontera is as resonant a symbol of American stoicism as Gary Cooper, glowering and tight-lipped, in High Noon. In this first feature directed by Michael Berry, Mr. Harris, the square-jawed 63-year-old actor who portrayed John Glenn in The Right Stuff, plays Roy, a retired sheriff in southern Arizona. And when the camera gazes up at him, tall in the saddle, he exudes a righteous, buck-stops-here stubbornness.

title: Refuge and Renewal on Lake George
description: Its the fireflies, and the stars, that get me every time. Those winking lights, bobbing along the ground and filling up the night sky with their impossible density, signal an alternate reality to the artificially haloed urban evening Im accustomed to in the San Francisco Bay Area. In this little corner of the Adirondack Mountains, other signals  cellphone, for one, or car headlights  are spotty, or altogether absent. Much of modern life is filtered out through the dense trees and mountains on the winding approach to Lake George. What remains  a place to run around in the woods  is time-tested and true.

title: Art From a Sojourn or Two to India
description: Francesco Clemente: Inspired by India, at the Rubin Museum of Art, ties the peripatetic Italian-born painter to a single country. The exhibition is also something of a comeback, the first Clemente retrospective in New York in more than a decade, although at just 20 works or so, its not exactly comprehensive.

title: What Was Your Favorite Joan Rivers Joke?
description: Joan Rivers was admired for her fashion sense, her perseverance and the longevity of her career. But she was best remembered for her jokes. For that reason, The Times asked readers on Twitter to share their favorite zingers and one-liners delivered by Ms. Rivers over the arc of her comedic career.

title: A Singer of Soul Goes in Search of His Own
description: Everything is artifice, declares Willis (Willis Earl Beal), the melancholy, creatively blocked singer, songwriter and restless dreamer at the heart of Memphis, a soulful cinematic tone poem written and directed by Tim Sutton. This luminescent second feature from Mr. Sutton was inspired partly by the legend of O. V. Wright, an African-American blues and gospel singer who had several R&B hits in the 1960s and early 70s and died in 1980 at 41.

title: How Rotherham Happened
description: To the American ear, the town of Rotherham, nestled in the West Riding of Yorkshire, sounds romantically British. And while a cursory Google Image search reveals the redbrick rowhouses, idyllic front gardens and august churches one expects in such a locale, a quick glance at recent coverage of the town divulges its sinister underside.

title: Garmin Blends an Activity Tracker With a Smartwatch
description: Is it an activity tracker or a smartwatch?

title: Marin Cilic Reaches U.S. Open Semifinals; Bryan Brothers and Martina Hingis Close In on Doubles Titles
description: More than four years have passed since Marin Cilics last Grand Slam semifinal appearance, an eternity in tennis years. The span included the peak of Cilics years as a Croatian prodigy, a player graced with size and skill, but he never seemed to live up to the promise.

title: Early Voting in Ohio, Despite Republican Objections
description: A federal judges decision this morning to allow early voting in Ohio is a big victory for those who think voting should be easier and more accessible. It was also a remarkable decision in purely human terms, showing a deeply compassionate understanding of the lives of the low-income people who have been the most harmed by Republican efforts to put barriers around the ballot box.

title: The Middle East Revealed: A Female Perspective and Syria in 1940
description: The four-artist show called The Middle East Revealed: A Female Perspective is an apt addendum to the New Museums Here and Elsewhere, an exhibition of contemporary art from the Arab world. But this show deals in Middle Eastern and Arab stereotypes, intending to criticize them, but only, in some cases, reinforcing them.

title: New York Is Named Best U.S. Bicycling City, Potholes and All
description: Despite its pothole-pocked pavement, oblivious pedestrians, vocal anti-bike contingent, traffic-weaving cab drivers and legions of delivery guys riding the wrong direction, New York has been chosen the best cycling city in the country by the editors of Bicycling magazine.

title: Joan Riverss Death Under Investigation by New York State Health Department
description: The New York State Health Department is investigating the circumstances that led to the comedian Joan Riverss death on Thursday, one week after she lost consciousness at an outpatient surgery clinic on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a spokeswoman for the agency said.

title: F.D.A. Allows First Use of a Novel Cancer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first of an eagerly awaited new class of cancer drugs that unleashes the bodys immune system to fight tumors.

title: Rene Ricard: Remember
description: This bittersweet show is a poignant reminder of the polymorphous talent and erudition of the poet, painter, aesthete and man about town Rene Ricard, who died in February at the age of 67. It contains 13 works dated from 1978 to 2012. Most are thrift store paintings to which Ricard added excerpts from, or the titles of, his poems in cursive, using a paint-laden brush.

title: Tech Giants Embrace the Smart Home, but Consumers Remain Skeptical
description: BERLIN  Tech companies want to make your house smart.

title: Georgia Hilmer Transforms Backstage at Creatures of the Wind
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Georgia Hilmer before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Bernard and hair by Anthony Turner.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Warm Up
description: Details magazine, Style.com, VFiles and Standard hotel get an early start on New York Fashion Week.

title: Amie Siegel: Provenance
description: Stylish aesthetics and fashionable conceptualism trump documentary realism in Provenance, an extremely suave film by Amie Siegel. The 40-minute movie is an instance of institutional critique, an art genre that tries to expose and subvert the workings of the capitalist art market. Specifically, its about the trade in furniture produced for Chandigarh, the utopian city in northern India whose master plan was conceived by Le Corbusier and his team and built between 1951 and 1965.

title: Peter Coffin: Living
description: In the basement of Red Bulls lavish studio facilities in Chelsea is the latest iteration of Peter Coffins best-known work: Music for Plants, a project started in 2002 in which a wall of plants, nestled under the sidewalk grating  the original version was actually a greenhouse  is accompanied by music specially commissioned from Pauline Oliveros, Yoko Ono, Alice Coltrane, Arto Lindsay, Laurie Anderson, Sonic Youth and other artists.

title: Witnesses to the Collapse
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about Last Days in Vietnam, Rory Kennedys eye-opening documentary about the 1975 evacuation of the American Embassy in Saigon, is how calmly it surveys what was once among the angriest topics in American political life. The story is full of emotion and danger, heroism and treachery, but it is told in a mood of rueful retrospect rather than simmering partisan rage. Ms. Kennedy, whose uncle John F. Kennedy expanded American involvement in Vietnam and whose father, Robert F. Kennedy,  became one of the ensuing wars most passionate critics, explores its final episode with an open mind and lively curiosity. There are old clips that have never been widely seen and pieces of information that may surprise many viewers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Germany, Indonesia and Brooklyn.

title: Visionaries Inhabiting the Margins
description: Its thrilling to start the season with an in-depth introduction to an outstanding artist youve barely heard of. That thrill is currently provided by the American Folk Art Museum and its concise, electrifying survey of Willem van Genk, a Dutch self-taught outsider who died in 2005 at 78. In addition, this show is brilliantly paired with one devoted to the formidable folk painter and well-known New Yorker, Ralph Fasanella (1914-97), that focuses on what might be called his history paintings. The fertile exchange between these ambitious, encompassing visions is one of the best things youll see this fall.

title: Mortgage Problems When Buying Outside the Box
description: Homes deemed unusual may be desirable for some to own, but even borrowers with excellent credit may have trouble obtaining sufficient financing to buy them.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: For Tavi Gevinson, Fashion Takes a Back Seat, for Now
description: Tavi Gevinson, the teenage fashion star turned Broadway actress, wont be much of a player at New York Fashion Week this season.

title: Unmasked, a Rapper Exults in Tradition
description: In June, a rapper named Your Old Droog posted a self-titled EP on his Soundcloud page  no photos, no videos, just songs. The music was scratchy boom-bap hip-hop, in the vein of New York rap before the flash of the mid-1990s swallowed it whole. Your Old Droog rapped forcefully, in breathless complex rhyme, and with a sly, mildly scraped tone that to many, sounded a little too familiar.

title: What the Monks Can Teach Us
description: The Rule, a film about St. Benedicts Preparatory School in Newark, opens with the implied promise that the methods used there can solve all of urban Americas educational problems. Though it has interesting elements, it doesnt really deliver on that promise, leaving it feeling more like a promotional video than like a rigorous documentary.

title: In Orlando, a Farm-to-Table Focus
description: The Grande Lakes Orlando resort, an enclave near Walt Disney World and Universal Orlando, is embracing the farm-to-table movement with new restaurants and a microbrewery.

title: Making Wispy Summertime Music in Glasgow
description: If the music of the Scottish indie-pop group Belle and Sebastian sets your teeth on edge, then prepare for extreme dental discomfort after watching God Help the Girl, the directing debut of one of the bands founders, Stuart Murdoch.

title: A Lightning Rod in a Game With Bats
description: The Dock of No No: A Dockumentary is Dock Ellis, the Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher who famously claimed he had thrown his 1970 no-hitter against the San Diego Padres while on LSD. In recounting Elliss career, the director, Jeffrey Radice, deftly crosscuts interviews with Ellis, who died in 2008, with those ofteammates, friends and former wives, to depict an occasionally volatile athlete who was more thoughtful than many assumed and who became a dedicated addiction counselor.

title: Puss Battles Sourpuss Over Old Magicians Fate
description: THUNDER AND THE HOUSE OF MAGIC

title: The Jill Soloway Starter Kit
description: While working on my profile of Jill Soloway in the Aug. 31 magazine, I learned that a true picture of who she is  someone who gathers people, someone who constantly questions cultural norms  can be seen by looking at a history of her work. Soloway has been exploring themes like community, gender and relationships since the early 1990s. Heres a sparse sampling of her work:

title: At This School, B Is for Blood
description: INNOCENCE

title: Liquidity for Banks, This Time Defined
description: The total capital ratio is well in excess of the 10 percent regulatory threshold.

title: History Loves Company
description: On the night of Aug. 8, 1974, many Americans gathered before their television sets to watch Richard M. Nixon announce his intention to resign as president of the United States. That moment is part of Edge of Eternity, the last and fattest installment in Ken Folletts 20th-century trilogy. And for him, the political is always very personal. So a man and a woman sit watching Nixons fall. They have been platonic friends for years. They cheer, and then they start kissing, and wind up having fantastic sex. (Duration: half a page out of 1,098.) This is Mr. Folletts favorite way to keep history interesting.

title: For a Don Giovanni Fan, a Hedonism Driven by Fear
description: Over 10 years ago, in the documentary Cinemania, Angela Christlieb and Stephen Kijak profiled a few obsessive New York moviegoers, cranky and snobbish devotees of the citys bountiful repertory cinemas. With Naked Opera, Ms. Christlieb gives us another eccentric fanatic in Marc Rollinger, a man of mysterious means from Luxembourg who spends his cash on Don Giovanni performances across Europe and on a succession of what seem to be male escorts.

title: Gov. Andrew Cuomos Disservice to Democracy
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, who has a huge war chest, is presumed to be far ahead in Tuesdays Democratic primary race. That assumption, however, should not allow him to shrink from a debate with Zephyr Teachout, his gutsy opponent. Ms. Teachout, a Fordham University law professor, has already appeared alone on NY1 on Tuesday after Mr. Cuomo refused to participate in a debate. At Democratic clubs and other forums, the governor has avoided taking on his opponents, and, on Thursday, Ms. Teachout debated Rob Astorino, the Republican nominee, on WNYC  also minus the governor.

title: Excerpt: The Wayside Motor Inn
description: Kelly AuCoin and Quincy Dunn-Baker in a scene from the A.R. Gurney play, at the Signature Center.

title: Down to Rio With a Haunted Avenger
description: FALCON RISING

title: Off the Runway: Day 1
description: Photos from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Hitchhiker on an Electronic Road
description: If you want someone to praise or blame for the relentlessly wired, chatty, information-soaked 21st-century world we inhabit, the artist Nam June Paik is an apt candidate. Credited as the founder of video art in the 1960s, he turned television into an interactive vehicle for radical theater. He invented the phrase electronic superhighway and imagined beta versions of smartphones, Google Glass, distant learning, YouTube, Instagram and the Internet itself.

title: Letting the Brain Out to Play
description: PIZZA, terminators and weird Turkish cinema will jostle for position on Sunday in the first annual Brooklyn Brain Jam, a festival of fascinating but generally useless information at the Bell House in Gowanus. The event brings together four of New Yorks leading purveyors of out-there entertainment  Nerd Nite, the Story Collider, the Big Quiz Thing and Kevin Geeks Out  in a mixed rotation that suggests live-show channel surfing.

title: An Elvis Impersonator Whos the Real Deal
description: The son of a preacher man has a secret past in The Identical, a jukebox musical that takes time revealing its goofy absurdity.

title: Young Love, in the Shadow of 9/11
description: BUT ALWAYS

title: Investment in Latin America Falls 10% in First Half
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Private equity and venture capital investments in Latin America dropped by 10 percent in the first half of this year compared with figures in the period a year earlier, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said on Thursday.

title: Destination: Atlanta
description: One hot August day in 1864, Cpl. Joseph W. Ely of the 19th Michigan sat down in his camp in northern Georgia to write his sister Adelia. Elys regiment had been engaged in almost constant marching and fighting since the Atlanta Campaign began three months earlier. Now the men were on the outskirts of Atlanta, hunkered down in trenches under deadly rifle and artillery fire.

title: You Dont Like That Routine? Just Wait Five Minutes
description: The DanceNow festival confronts one challenge  that of performing dance on the tiny stage at Joes Pub  by adding another: No work may exceed five minutes. This makes for a speedy show, even though 10 different acts share each of the four evenings. Adding to that forward-driving energy is a contest. Each night, the audience chooses a winner, who receives a creative residency in Bucks County, Pa. On Sept. 13, the top 10 return for an encore presentation. A check, a residency and support for a fully produced show go at the end to one contestant chosen by the organizers.

title: Inside the Players Lounge at the U.S. Open
description: In a lounge on the second level of Arthur Ashe Stadium, players competing in the United States Open can play foosball, watch television and relax with their coaches and family members. The photographer Mark Peterson, who most recently shot Rand Paul for the magazine, visited the lounge during the tournaments first week.

title: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Tome: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Garth Brooks Embraces Digital Music and Unveils Online Store
description: Garth Brooks has finally gone digital, with an iTunes rival of his own.

title: 8 Portland, Ore., Meals for $8 or Under
description: Portland, Ore.  bike-friendly and, to this New Yorker, shockingly affordable  might also be the most delicious small city in America. So, finding myself there with about 30 hours to spare at the end of a West Coast trip earlier this week, I didnt have to think too hard about a plan: rent a bike and look for a few cheap meals around the city.

title: Block That Scam
description: My godfather is nearing 80. He retired comfortably but is not rich. Over dinner, he mentioned some projects that made my husband and me fear that he is being taken advantage of: He sent $15,000 to a foreign country to help an aid group build a farm; he sold his home to an overseas buyer, but first he redecorated it to suit the purchasers taste. He is independent and seems sharp, but these stories set off alarm bells. Should we share our concerns?

title: At Coach, Side-Swept, 70s-Style Mock Bangs
description: At Coachs spring/summer 2015 show today, the models side-parted hair was combed over to create curtainlike, 70s-inspired faux bangs. The look complemented the retro teenage-Americana theme of the collection  pastel miniskirts, fluffy snorkel jackets, metallic clogs  as did the makeup, a slight wash of sparkling eye shadow and barely pink mouths that looked as if theyd been glazed with strawberry Lip Smackers.

title: Chianti Classicos Emotional Tug
description: Wine School, a monthly column, invites you to drink wine with Eric Asimov. Septembers wine was Chianti Classico; Mr. Asimov shares his reaction to the wine and addresses readers thoughts and questions below the assignment.

title: Appeals Court Says Men Alleging Sex Abuse Waited Too Long to Sue Yeshiva University
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled on Thursday that dozens of men who say Yeshiva University covered up their sexual abuse at the hands of rabbis cannot sue for damages because too many years had elapsed since the abuse took place.

title: Holding Onto That Summer Glow at Creatures of the Wind
description: The start of New York Fashion Week might mark the unofficial beginning of fall, but backstage at Creatures of the Wind this morning, the designers Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters were still in summer mode. Dressed in t-shirts and looking laid-back as usual, the pair talked about exploring distant horizons with their prints and patterns, and the casual appeal of their debut shoe collection (theyre really meant to be an extension of a summer shoe, Gabier said, glancing at the sporty slip-ons at his feet). The models hair and makeup evoked the same breezy vibe. Everything is relaxed and easy, with a certain softness to it, Peters said. During casting earlier this week, on a day marked with humidity and thunderclouds, the makeup artist James Boehmer noted the natural flush evident on everyones skin. So instead of using bronzer on the cheeks, he dabbed on the new Nars Lipstick in Ligueria (out this spring) to recreate that moment. This gives you that overheated effect, he explained, tapping in the golden beige pigments. Outside the show, where the temperature was in the low 80s, the same tawny glow was easy to spot.

title: You Asked About Football; Our Reporters Answered
description: The N.F.L.'s regular season began Thursday night, when the Seattle Seahawks, the defending Super Bowl champions, defeated the Green Bay Packers, 36-16. On Sunday, Rex Ryans Jets will play host to the Oakland Raiders, and on Monday night, Eli Manning and the Giants will take on the Lions in Detroit.

title: U.S. Panel Proposes Subjecting MetLife to Stricter Regulation
description: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | A federal panel is proposing to assign MetLife to a club it does not want to join, by initially voting on Thursday to deem it a systemically important financial institution and thus subjecting it to more intensive regulation than most other life insurers.

title: Pretesting and Other New Ideas to Help Kids Learn
description: Pretesting has become one of the hottest areas of learning science. As Benedict Carey describes in Why Flunking Exams Is Actually a Good Thing, the idea is pretty straightforward in classrooms: Give students an exam that includes the material that will be tested on the final, but doesnt replicate that exam. The (bombed) first-day test tunes students brains to receive the material to come  and they tend to do better in class.

title: New York Fashion Week: Duckie Brown Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: I.M.F. Considers Rules to Force Bondholders to Share Cost of Restructuring
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H.  The International Monetary Fund is moving closer to formalizing standards that would give it the option to require private-sector bondholders to share the financial burden when countries with serious debt problems seek assistance from the fund.

title: Ideas to Relieve a Kidney Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Scarce Resources to Save Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: Call It Ageism
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Equality in Parade
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Spirits in the Venezuelan Jungle
description: Thought to possess two spirits, the transgender women of Venezuelas Warao people are seen as being close to the ancestor spirits that roam the jungle.

title: Creatures of the Wind Debuts Its Own Striking Shoe Collection
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Federal Inquiry of Ferguson Police Will Include Apparent Racial Profiling
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments civil rights investigation into the police department in Ferguson, Mo., will focus on whether officers there made discriminatory traffic stops, mistreated prisoners or used excessive force in the years before last months fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white officer, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Thursday.
