title: Why Do Doctors Commit Suicide?
description: NEW HAVEN  TWO weeks ago, two medical residents, in their second month of residency training in different programs, jumped to their deaths in separate incidents in New York City. I did not know them, and cannot presume to speak for them or their circumstances. But I imagine that they had celebrated their medical school graduation this spring just as my friends and I did. I imagine they began their residencies with the same enthusiasm for healing as we did. And I imagine that they experienced fatigue, emotional exhaustion and crippling self-doubt at the beginning of those residencies  I know I did.

title: Roosevelts to the Rescue
description: The Obama presidency is mired in mediocrity, his and ours. Foreign policy is cribbed and cautious, moving along with a deliberative pace our do-it-now society doesnt tolerate. At home, Obamas greatest achievements  health care for millions, and raising an economy from the dead while Europe couldnt get out of the grave  are almost unknown.

title: Joan Riverss Fashion Victims Remember Her Sharpest Zingers
description: For more than a decade Joan Rivers was known in the fashion world for her caustic one-line fashion critiques. She looked like a decorative toilet seat cover, Ms. Rivers said of the actress Tina Fey at the 2010 Golden Globe awards.

title: New Book Says C.I.A. Official in Benghazi Held Up Rescue
description: CAIRO  Five commandos guarding the C.I.A. base in Benghazi, Libya, in September 2012 say that the base chief stopped them from interceding in time to save the lives of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and an American technician during the attack on the diplomatic mission there.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 5-11
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 1
description: Though Thursday was the official beginning of New York Fashion Week, models walking the shows have had the event on their mind for weeks, if not for months. To prevent their excitement from turning into stress, Donna Karan hosted a healthy breakfast and reminded them to stay Zen.

title: Fashion Week: The Timess Fashion Director Revs Up for the Runways
description: Its Fashion Week in New York City, which marks the beginning of a month-long season of runway shows and collection presentations in New York, London, Milan and Paris. Vanessa Friedman, the fashion director and chief fashion critic for The Times and The International New York Times will be there.

title: Jailed for Protests, Activists in Egypt and Bahrain Turn to Hunger Strikes
description: Three years after they helped lead street protests demanding democracy in Egypt and Bahrain, prominent Arab Spring activists in both nations are now starving themselves in prison, hoping to draw attention to intensifying crackdowns on dissent there.

title: The Race to November Is Getting Off to an Unsavory Start
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Yes Is Better Than No
description: SUPPOSE someone you know slightly arrives at your home, baggage and all, and just barges in and stays overnight. When you protest, the response is, Well, you didnt say no.

title: As Islamist Militants Advance, Residents Flee a Nigerian City
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Amid fears that Islamist militants were closing in on the major city in Nigerias northeast, hundreds of residents were said to be fleeing Maiduguri on Thursday in the face of doubts that the army could repel an attack on the metropolis of more than one million people.

title: Promise From European Central Bank Is Also a Gamble
description: By promising to rev up the printing presses, the European Central Bank has created hope in the markets that Europe may finally start to overcome its economic challenges.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 5-11
description: Mad. Sq. 200

title: At Trial, Arab Banks Lawyer Spars With Witness
description: For three days, the former chief of the Israeli militarys Palestinian Affairs Department delivered important, if a bit dry, testimony in the terrorism financing trial of Arab Bank in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Reclaiming  We the People, One Person at a Time
description: About two years ago, I had the opportunity to participate in a retreat led by the renowned author and activist Parker J. Palmer. The retreat was based on a methodology called a Circle of Trust, drawn from Palmers writings, intended to help people step back from the noise of modern life, reflect, and return more centered and effective in their vocations. I was amazed at how, in just two days, this process brought 40 individuals together into respectful and strikingly honest discourse. It helped participants connect to their core values and sparked many new relationships.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 5-11
description: Readings Around Town (through next Friday) A wide range of authors will be in the spotlight next week, starting on Monday at the Strand Book Store, where crime and suspense are the focus of a reading with Megan Abbott, whose latest novel is The Fever, and Chelsea Cain, who recently released One Kick. At 7 p.m., 828 Broadway, at 12th Street, East Village; purchase of either book is required for admission. Also on Monday, at 7 p.m., Donald Antrim, a MacArthur fellow, will read from his new collection of stories, The Emerald Light in the Air, at McNally Jackson, 52 Prince Street, between Lafayette and Mulberry Streets, SoHo; free.

title: Nevada a Winner in Teslas Battery Contest
description: After pitting five potential host states against one another in a quest for hundreds of millions of dollars in incentives, Tesla Motors said Thursday that it had struck a deal with Nevada for construction of its sprawling factory to build batteries for electric cars and the power grid.

title: As Prekindergarten Expands in New York City, Guiding Guided Play
description: On Thursday, more than 50,000 public school children in New York embarked on their formal education as the city officially began its expanded prekindergarten program, the marquee undertaking of Bill de Blasios mayoralty. The days leading up to the start of the school year were as frantic as anyone might have predicted  staffing and supplying the program have been compressed into just a few months. Facing safety concerns and other issues, several centers were unable to open; others faced delays.

title: Joseph Persico, Rockefeller Speechwriter and Best-Selling Author, Dies at 84
description: Joseph E. Persico, a biographer and popular historian and a former chief speechwriter for Nelson A. Rockefeller, died on Saturday in Albany. He was 84.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Todd Snyder: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: On Schedule, Pools Workers Drain the Last Drops of Summer
description: The last inches of water glistened tantalizingly in the twilight at the Van Cortlandt Park pool, where the air was warm and heavy on Tuesday evening. A bandage floated in one lap lane. An abandoned swim shirt billowed in another. A few fallen leaves, harbingers of autumn, drifted listlessly.

title: A Ferguson Activist in New York
description: On a day of protests to demand higher wages and a union for fast-food workers, activists from Ferguson, Mo., decided to protest in New York City as a sign of respect for Michael Browns family.

title: Hackers Breach Security of HealthCare.gov
description: WASHINGTON  Hackers breached security at the website of the governments health insurance marketplace, HealthCare.gov, but did not steal any personal information on consumers, Obama administration officials said Thursday.

title: A Soccer Team Struggles to Remake Its Identity
description: CARSON, Calif.  It was 20 minutes before kickoff, and the Commander stood ready. Richard Escuita, a retired Army sergeant who introduces himself by his nom de guerre, was dressed in black commando boots, military supply pants, black gloves, a black beret and a black Chivas de Guadalajara jersey.

title: Requiem for a Pomeranian
description: This is a chance for you to commune with Logan, said Lucy Morganstern before tucking her violin under her chin and launching into an improvised minor-key dirge that at times seemed to evoke a puppys plaintive cry.

title: A Lost Way, a Lost Year for the Red Sox
description: The Boston Red Sox made their final Bronx statement of 2014 on Thursday with a collapse that fit their season. Koji Uehara served up homers to Mark Teixeira and Chase Headley in the bottom of the ninth that lifted the Yankees to a 5-4 victory.

title: The Body and the Spirit
description: Like everyone, I was revolted by the beheadings of the American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff. It wasnt just that they had been killed  though that is horrendous enough  it was the monstrous way the deed was done.

title: Bloomberg Returns to an Organization Looking for a Vision
description: IN late 2007, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rolled his chair over to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroffs desk inside the bullpen at City Hall and suggested that they go to a nearby table to talk. The mayor knew that Mr. Doctoroff was six weeks away from leaving city government to return to Wall Street. But he had another idea.

title: Fed Says Growth Lifts the Affluent, Leaving Behind Everyone Else
description: WASHINGTON  Economic growth since the Great Recession has improved the fortunes of the most affluent Americans even as the incomes and wealth of most American families continue to decline, the Federal Reserve said Thursday.

title: The Deflation Caucus
description: On Thursday, the European Central Bank announced a series of new steps it was taking in an effort to boost Europes economy. There was a whiff of desperation about the announcement, which was reassuring. Europe, which is doing worse than it did in the 1930s, is clearly in the grip of a deflationary vortex, and its good to know that the central bank understands that. But its epiphany may have come too late. Its far from clear that the measures now on the table will be strong enough to reverse the downward spiral.

title: For Coed U.S. Open Event, Reaction Seems to Be Mixed, Too
description: On Friday, before the womens singles semifinals at Arthur Ashe Stadium, two Grand Slam champions will be crowned at the United States Open. But most fans will have no idea who they are.

title: Classic Cherry Hills Course Gives Nothing Away
description: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo.  Rory McIlroy was lining up his second shot, a putt from off the green, on the par-4 second hole at Cherry Hills Country Club on Thursday when a duck emerged from the lake to the left of the green, flapped its wings and, between pecks at the grass, craned its neck in McIlroys direction, as if angling for a better look.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 4, 2014
Hong Kongs Democrats Clamor for Spot on Crowded U.S. Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Pro-democracy advocates in Hong Kong are girding for what some predict will be a tense final showdown with the Chinese government over whether Beijing will permit genuine democracy to take root in the former British colony.

title: For Immigration Lawyers, a Surprise Speaker Who Asks Them to Change Lives
description: The fresh-faced lawyers included refugees from violence and persecution in Central America, as well as the grandchildren of refugees from Eastern Europe. They arrived at the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, on Thursday in similar shades of gray and black suits, poised to continue their training in a new program to help represent immigrants.

title: Town Becomes a Beer Ad, but Residents Dont Feel Like a Party
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo.  Workers have been busy in this bucolic, out-of-the-way ski town: The streets have been painted blue, as have the light poles. Blue props and fencing have been hauled in, rendering the place almost unrecognizable. And as final preparations take place for a three-day party, many residents are fuming, cursing the town for approving a clandestine deal to let a giant beer company turn it into a living advertisement in exchange for $500,000.

title: In Afghanistan, Time for Compromise
description: Having spent several weeks auditing ballots in Afghanistans fraud-plagued presidential vote, election officials there are expected to declare a winner within days. If the two candidates vying for the post fail to reach a power-sharing deal beforehand, the announcement could easily kick off a wave of unrest that would all but guarantee a catastrophic wind-down to Americas longest war.

title: A Blunt Defense of Marriage Equality
description: As important as the federal appeals court ruling was on Thursday declaring same-sex marriage bans in two states to be unconstitutional, the clarity and blunt reasoning behind the decision was equally momentous.

title: Encouraging End-of-Life Talks
description: There is reason to hope that a degree of sanity may be returning to the touchy issue of advance planning for medical care at the end of life. Just five years ago, Republican politicians, Sarah Palin prominent among them, were falsely charging that President Obamas health care reforms would create death panels that could cut off care for the critically ill to save money on health care costs.

title: Blurring Line Between Snack and Meal, Mac and Cheese to Graze On
description: SITTING down to three square meals daily is going the way of the landline, as consumers increasingly graze throughout the day and eat what had once been standard between-meal fare like yogurt and granola bars as meals. Americans eat only snacks, including produce like fruit and cut vegetables, at mealtimes 40 percent of the time, and that is expected to increase over the next five years, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm.

title: Sunday Talk Show Guests
description: Since 2008, more than 1,500 people have appeared on five Sunday news and political talk shows: Meet the Press, Face the Nation, This Week, Fox News Sunday and State of the Union. Many are familiar faces in Washington, where lawmakers, consultants and pundits routinely sound off on the week's news, while others come from the worlds of entertainment and sports. Researchers at American University have collected more than 9,000 appearances. Below is a listing of those guests, excluding network employees or contracted regular guests.

title: High Whimsy and Low Expectations at the Meat Market
description: Perhaps you have sometimes wondered, when youve run out of worthier things to think about, what that airiest of musicals, The Fantasticks, might be like if it developed a social conscience.

title: Back in the Kitchen, They Have Lives, Too
description: In the back of a ritzy Upper East Side restaurant, busboys in black jackets fill breadbaskets, garnish plates, roll napkins and silverware into tidy cylinders. Their gestures are precise, their actions rote. Its a slog. Its a dance. Its a living.

title: Strangers in the Night, No Glances
description: The lives of people in transit intersect without actually touching in The Wayside Motor Inn, a minor-key but cleverly constructed play by the veteran A. R. Gurney, being revived by the Signature Theater Company. From our point of view, the characters seem to share the same space, a tidy but soul-crushingly generic room in a motel on the outskirts of Boston. But we soon gather that each of the plays five pairs of characters occupy different rooms. Their stories  of broken marriages, sexual ambivalence, late-life malaise, father-son conflict  are merely superimposed upon one another so that they seem to be taking place simultaneously.

title: Eugenia Washington to George Washington
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  If you have ever seen an ambigram, which is a word or phrase that reads the same way in different orientations, youll understand what Joe Krozel has done here. Except that hes taken it in a totally different direction and done it with Morse code.

title: Why Dont Americans Take Vacation?
On Ukraine, the West Sidesteps a Fraught Term
description: BRUSSELS  Whether on the streets of Budapest in 1956, the mountains of Afghanistan in 1979 and again in 2001 or in the swampy forests of Grenada in 1983, invasions have tended to be noisy, unmistakable affairs that screamed their purpose from the start.

title: Israel Documents on Hamas Role in Killings of Teenagers
description: The documents relate to an investigation and indictment of the man suspected of leading the kidnappers, and provide no evidence that the top leaders of Hamas directed or had prior knowledge of the plot to abduct the three Israeli youths.

title: Their New Offense Maturing, Jets Hope for a Growth Spurt
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan says the difference between where Geno Smith was in his development as a rookie last season and where he is now is night and day.

title: Study of Jewish Women Shows Link to Cancer Without Family History
description: Women of Ashkenazi Jewish descent who tested positive for cancer-causing genetic mutations during random screenings have high rates of breast and ovarian cancer even when they have no family history of the disease, researchers reported Thursday.

title: From Looms Came Computers, Which Led to Looms That Save Fashion Week
description: Just back from Madagascar with suitcases full of clothes for Fashion Week, Emily Thornton, a designer, could see what was missing from the collection she would be helping to mount for the Edun clothing line.

title: Syria May Have Hidden Chemical Arms, U.S. Says
description: The United States expressed concern on Thursday that Syrias government might be harboring undeclared chemical weapons, hidden from the internationally led operation to purge them over the past year, and that Islamist militant extremists now ensconced in that country could possibly seize control of them.

title: Police Shoot Unarmed Man in Harlem Park
description: A New York City police officer shot an unarmed man in the chest during a confrontation in a Harlem park on Thursday afternoon, police officials said.

title: Preschool Director Is Sentenced to Two Years in Prison
description: A man who ran preschool programs for children with developmental disabilities in New York was sentenced to two years in prison on Thursday after he admitted to stealing more than $2 million meant for special education services in a plea deal.

title: Events on Long Island for Sept. 7-13, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: New York State Gives Health Insurers Average Rate Rise of 5.7%
description: Health insurance companies in New York State will receive average rate increases of 5.7 percent next year, less than half the increases they had requested for individual and family plans, Benjamin M. Lawsky, the states financial services superintendent, said on Thursday.

title: State Senate Race Turns Contentious as 2 Democrats Vie to Represent West Bronx
description: If Iowa is a stamping ground for presidential candidates, the BronxWorks Morris Innovative Senior Center on East 181st Street has become one for those who want to represent the west Bronx.

title: Events in Westchester for Sept. 7-13, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: As Cuomo Lies Low, Teachout Debates a Stand-In: Astorino, the G.O.P. Rival
description: For many political candidates, the days before an election are a period of pandemonium. For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, they are a prime time to remain out of sight.

title: With Hopes Going, Going, Yankees 9th-Inning Blasts Are Gone, Gone
description: David Ortiz stopped for a second and watched, holding his pose, his bat in his right hand, as the ball he had just clobbered sailed into the night sky. The Yankee Stadium crowd gasped and then let out a hushed murmur as Ortiz rounded the bases, patted his chest and, at home plate, pointed to the sky. For a moment, it felt like October.

title: British Premier Offers to Expand Assistance to Kurdish Forces in Iraq
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain offered on Thursday to arm Kurdish forces fighting Islamist militants and refused to rule out British airstrikes in Iraq and possibly Syria. Britain has delivered nonlethal supplies to Kurdish fighters, who are on the front line of the battle against the militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and it has helped to transport ammunition provided by others. Mr. Camerons comments suggest that Britain could begin to supply ammunition directly to Kurdish forces. In a BBC interview, Mr. Cameron refused to rule out airstrikes but said they would not take place in Iraq before the formation of a new government in Baghdad. He also suggested that there might not be any legal impediment to attacking militants in Syria without the agreement of Syrias government because it had committed war crimes against its own people and was therefore illegitimate.

title: Events in New Jersey for Sept. 7-13, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Questions Come Up Again Over a Candidates Dual Roles
description: AUSTIN  As a practicing pharmacist and former board director of the Texas Pharmacy Association, State Senator Leticia Van de Putte, the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, has raised some eyebrows over the years by sponsoring dozens of bills that affect her profession.

title: In Testimony, Ex-Governor Is Portrayed as Carrying Baggage
description: NEW HAVEN  Mark Greenberg, a businessman who entered Connecticut politics in the 2010 election cycle, and Marc Katz, a business partner who ran two of his three campaigns for Congress, each testified in federal court here on Thursday to being star-struck by former Gov. John G. Rowland in conversations they had with him about Mr. Greenbergs prospects.

title: Apple Says It Will Add New iCloud Security Measures After Celebrity Hack
description: Apple said on Thursday that it would strengthen its security measures after a recent episode where hackers broke into the Apple accounts of a number of celebrities, stole their nude photos and leaked them on the Internet.

title: Highest Court to Weigh in on a Dispute Over Water
description: AUSTIN  Steve Lipskys tainted water well has already stirred a national debate about the impacts of oil and gas production. Now it stars in a free-speech dispute that has landed in the states highest court  the biggest test of a law meant to curb attempts to stifle public protest.

title: In U.S. Open Womens Semifinals, 2 Players Are in a New Setting
description: For the sixth straight Grand Slam event, a woman will be in the semifinals of a major for the first time. This United States Open actually has two final-four debutantes in Peng Shuai and Ekaterina Makarova.

title: Animal Traffic
description: The trade in illegal wildlife is a $19 billion annual business with ties to the Russian mob and Islamic extremists, and theres one place the world turns to investigate the crime: a federal forensics lab (and curiosity cabinet) in a hippie town in Oregon.

title: The Rise of Canadian Comfort Food in the Big Apple
description: Canadian staples like smoked meat with fries and cheese are migrating to Manhattan. The arrival of Acadian cuisine is just gravy.

description: The Brazilian artist Beatriz Milhazes evokes the dreamy languor of a late summer afternoon in Paris, as described by Matthew Rohrer.

title: Seahawks Trounce the Packers to Begin Their Title Defense
description: SEATTLE  Happy hour started at lunchtime across this city on Thursday. Desk jockeys called in sick. Children stayed home from school. Parents left the errands for another day.

description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes Staten Island football players grieving for a teammate and preparations for the city school students return to class.

title: Chris Christie, on Mexico Tour, Unplugs the Amplifier
description: MEXICO CITY  He has not scolded. Nor mocked. Nor lectured.

title: On Way Out, Making a U-Turn
description: Gal Monfils very nearly did enough on Thursday night to break up the all-star coaches reunion.

title: Unlikely Relief Team Helps the Yankees Prevail
description: The basic premise is elementary: Teams that allow more runs than they score almost always have losing records. Yet the Yankees defied this last season and are doing so again as they claw for a wild-card berth in the playoffs.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) SAVING MR. BANKS (2013) Tom Hanks stars as Walt Disney in this Disney movie about the making of a Disney movie: specifically Mary Poppins, which, at the time of its creation in the early 60s, was the most expensive live-action film the studio had produced. Eventually it became one of the most beloved, too, and one of the biggest moneymakers. Emma Thompson (above, with Mr. Hanks) is the author P. L. Travers, who conjured the magical nanny, and is something of a crank. I wont have her turned into one of your silly cartoons, she says of her creation, stiffly, lips pursed. Theres a back story too, in which Travers is a little girl (Annie Rose Buckley) in a dusty town in Australia, where her hopelessly alcoholic father (Colin Farrell) can barely hold on to his bank job. Fans of the book and the earlier movie will know that Mr. Banks is the father of the children cared for by Mary Poppins, but even those entirely innocent of her previous literary and cinematic incarnations  if such people exist  will find this movie accessible and enjoyable, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this movie directed by John Lee Hancock. That is part of the Disney brand, of course: fun for everyone, with a spoonful of therapeutic medicine to help the sugar seem nutritious.

title: Hunting for Autographs at the U.S. Open
description: For some tennis fans at the United States Open, chasing down players for autographs is as fun as watching the matches.

description: Colts at Broncos

title: Steve Moore Settles Lawsuit Against Todd Bertuzzi and Canucks
description: Steve Moore, a former Colorado Avalanche forward, announced Thursday that he had settled his lawsuit against Todd Bertuzzi and the Vancouver Canucks, closing one of the most violent on-ice episodes in N.H.L. history.

title: The King of Collectibles
description: Brandon Steiner, the founder of Steiner Sports Marketing, has a booming business at Yankee Stadium and at his warehouse in suburban New Rochelle.

description: The New York Times film critics review The Congress, Kelly & Cal and Last Days In Vietnam.

title: Corrections: September 5, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 5, 2014
description: Be a good boy. And no biting.

title: Weighing In on Paid Interethnic Marriages in Xinjiang
description: This week, The New York Times reported on officials in a county in the western region of Xinjiang offering cash and other incentives to encourage more interethnic marriages, with the goal of defusing ethnic tensions. Many Chinese officials are concerned about increasingly violent conflicts between Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking, mostly Muslim people who populate large parts of Xinjiang, and the Han, the dominant ethnicity in China. At a two-day work forum on Xinjiang in May, President Xi Jinping called for new policies to better assimilate Uighurs into mainstream Chinese society.

title: Two Spirits in the Venezuelan Jungle
description: A chance encounter with an anthropologist in Caracas led lvaro Laiz to Venezuelas remote eastern edge, where an indigenous people known as the Warao have lived for millenniums.

title: In California, Jerry Browns Opponent Makes Most of Lone Debate
description: SACRAMENTO  It was the only scheduled debate in this years contest for California governor, so Neel Kashkari  the little-known and underfunded Republican trying to unseat Jerry Brown, the Democrat seeking re-election  sought to make the most of it.

title: Company Backed by Robert Diamond Increases Stake in Nigerian Bank
description: LONDON  The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former Barclays chief executive, said on Friday that it had increased its stake in Union Bank of Nigeria in its latest bet on the African financial sector.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Joan Rivers, a Comedic Stiletto, Dies at 81
description: In Joan Rivers, a Comedic Stiletto, Dies at 81, Robert D. McFadden writes The Timess obituary for the trailblazing comedian.

title: Test Yourself | Drake and Lil Wayne Take the Stage
description: Below are six paragraphs from the Aug. 28 article Duelists Armed With Banter and Mutual Admiration.

title: Looking for John McCain? Try a Sunday Morning Show
description: For 11 weeks this year, Americans did not see John McCain, the Arizona Republican senator, on any of five Sunday news shows.

title: So Bill Gates Has This Idea for a History Class ...
description: In 2008, shortly after Bill Gates stepped down from his executive role at Microsoft, he often awoke in his 66,000-square-foot home on the eastern bank of Lake Washington and walked downstairs to his private gym in a baggy T-shirt, shorts, sneakers and black socks yanked up to the midcalf. Then, during an hour on the treadmill, Gates, a self-described nerd, would pass the time by watching DVDs from the Teaching Companys Great Courses series. On some mornings, he would learn about geology or meteorology; on others, it would be oceanography or U.S. history.

title: Readers Respond: On the Threat of ISIS
description: The violent ascent of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria calls for a cautious, well-planned response by the United States, most commenters agreed in responses to Thomas Friedmans Wednesday column, Ready, Aim, Fire. Not Fire, Aim, Ready.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 5
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes Staten Island football players grieving for a teammate and preparations for the city school students return to class.

title: Should Students Be Able to Grade Their Teachers?
description: States around the country are trying to better assess how teachers are performing in classrooms. They are primarily using standardized test scores and observations by administrators. But shouldnt students be included in the conservation too? After all, arent they the ones who spend the most time with their teachers?

title: The Man Who Spins Pinstripes Into Gold
description: Brandon Steiners mind was churning as he watched the groundskeepers carrying their rakes off the Yankee Stadium infield.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Movies That Really Move
description: Good morning on this muggy Friday.

title: Joan Rivers, as Remembered by Nocturnalist
description: Joan Rivers, the pioneering comedian who died on Thursday, was a woman of many firsts.

title: Daily Report: Apple Expected to Unveil Smartwatch and Larger iPhones
description: When Apple wants to make a big splash, it returns to its history, Brian X. Chen reports.

title: New York Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 2
description: The revels have begun. Yes, New York Fashion Weeks starting line is ever-shifting, jumping ever backward. But one good place to take your cue is from Europe, whose editors have a way of arriving just in time to make the Friday shows. When the Old World arrives to check out the New  well, now were underway.

title: Lawsuit Raises Questions Over Chinas Internet Censorship
description: Updated, 5:54 a.m. | A man in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen has sued his Internet service provider over his inability to access Googles online services, which have been largely inaccessible since the beginning of this summer.

title: Justice Dept. Promotes Lawyer to No. 3 Post
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Justice Department lawyer who defended same-sex marriage, President Obamas health care law and the governments right to collect bulk phone records has been promoted to the departments No. 3 position, officials said Friday.

title: Across Eastern Europe, Military Spending Lags
description: WARSAW  A window-rattling F-16 passed just above the main control tower at the Polish militarys 32nd Air Base, screaming across the same stark plains that have seen armies sweep across them throughout the nations history.

title: Why #RussiaInvadedUkraine Matters
description: Last week, Russias president, Vladimir V. Putin, said he could take Kiev in two weeks. This week, he disavowed a cease-fire, then proposed a peace plan. Now a cease-fire is in effect. These zigzags did their job, leaving the West confused about his intentions, just as the European Union and NATO were meeting to figure out how to counter them.

title: Teenagers in the Times | August 2014
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it all in one handy spot.

title: Dalai Lama Said to Be Denied South African Visa
description: BEIJING  The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has been denied a visa by the South African government to attend a Nobel peace conference in Cape Town next month, his representative in South Africa, Nangsa Chodon, told Reuters on Thursday.

title: Toronto Festival 2014: The Downey-Duvall Show
description: TORONTO  The director David Dobkin, whose drama The Judge had its debut at the Toronto International Film Festival on Thursday evening, took a moment before the screening to commend the festivals directors for a new policy that kept its first four days clear of films that had already shown elsewhere in North America (read: at the competing Telluride Film Festival).

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
NATO Plans a Special Force to Reassure Eastern Europe and Deter Russia
description: NEWPORT, Wales  NATO struggled to find responses to new challenges as it concluded its summit meeting here on Friday, announcing limited steps to deter Russia in Eastern Europe and starting to marshal broader international support to confront radical Islamists in the Middle East.

title: Democracy in Hong Kong
description: Beijing starts to squeeze.

title: Where Prices Dont Want to Rise
description: EUROPE has an inflation problem. Prices are not rising fast enough.

title: Morning Agenda: Europes Bond-Buying Bet
description: E.C.B. GAMBLES ON BOND-BUYING PROGRAM | Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday that the bank would soon start to buy bonds that are backed by loans made to consumers and companies, DealBooks Peter Eavis and Alexandra Stevenson write. With the move, the central bank is gambling on a complex securities market that for several years has been struggling to get back on its feet. The purchases could make up a substantial share of the roughly 1 trillion euros, or $1.3 trillion, that Mr. Draghi implied that the bank was prepared to spend.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Job Growth Is Sluggish, Raising Fear of Malaise
description: Missing: nearly three million American workers.

title: The Pedicab Was the Last Straw
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Whale of a Recovery for Californias Blue Whales
description: The blue whale, the biggest animal on the planet, was hunted with abandon in the Pacific Ocean until the early 1970s. The species has been rebounding ever since, but a slowdown in the growth of the population frequenting waters off the California coast was a concern. Now it turns out to be a promising sign of recovery.

title: Alibaba Said to Pick New York as Kickoff for Roadshow
description: The Alibaba Group may be one of Chinas Internet giants, but the e-commerce behemoth is planning to start investor presentations for its long-awaited initial public offering in New York.

title: Taking a Naked Selfie? Your Phone Should Step In to Protect You
description: What should smartphone makers do about nude selfies? Should they encourage us all to point our phones away from our unclothed bodies  or should they instead decide that nakedselfies are inevitable, and add features totheir products thatreduce the chance thatthese photos could gethacked?

title: Theres More to Estate Planning Than Just the Will
description: WILLS, health care directives, lists of passwords to online accounts. By now, most people know they should prepare these items  even if they havent yet  and make them available to trusted family members before the unthinkable, yet inevitable, happens.

title: Documents to Share
description: Here are some of the documents that advisers suggest family members make available to each other.

title: Obamacare Life Spiral
description: Ezra Klein directs us to the latest from the Kaiser Family Foundation, which asks what the average Obamacare 2015 premium increase will be for those places for which we have full information  and finds that premiums will actually decline slightly. Ezra tries to get us to appreciate just how good the Obamacare news has been with a thought experiment:

title: Family Dollar Rejects Revised Bid by Dollar General
description: Despite eliciting a higher takeover bid by Dollar General, Family Dollar remains unswayed by its rivals acquisition efforts.

title: Jobs Report: Not Good, but Not Terrible Either
description: First, the good news, if it can be called that: The new numbers on how the United States job market fared in August arent cover-your-eyes terrible. Nothing in this report should send anyone running to the hills in fear.

title: Billy Reid and Alabama Chanins Homegrown Cotton
description: An inside look at the pairs two-year process behind a new limited-edition collection, which began with an organic crop in Alabama.

title: British Response to Election Limits Upsets Activists in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  For months, democracy advocates in Hong Kong have called for an open election for the citys leader and for international pressure to be exerted on Beijing to not interfere with Hong Kongs autonomy.

title: Ukraine Deal Imposes Truce Putin Devised
description: KIEV, Ukraine  After five months of intensifying combat that threatened to rip Ukraine apart and to reignite the Cold War, the Ukrainian government and separatist forces signed a cease-fire agreement on Friday that analysts considered highly tenuous in a country that remains a tinderbox.

title: Ebola Is Taking a Second Toll, on Economies
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Airlines have canceled their flights to the countries most affected. Prices of staple goods are going up, and food supplies are dwindling. Border posts are being closed, foreign workers are going home and national growth rates are projected to plummet.

title: Corner Closet Opens Up a Bit Wider
description: After C1 Financials chief executive, Trevor Burgess, rang the opening bell and posed outside the New York Stock Exchange with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers cheerleaders on Aug. 14 to celebrate his Florida-based companys first day of trading, he received a message from Jason Grenfell-Gardner, the chief executive of the pharmaceutical company IGI Laboratories:

title: Chiquitas Inversion Plan Hits Snag as I.S.S. Recommends Vote Against Deal
description: Chiquita Brands Internationals plans to strike an inversion deal suffered another blow on Friday, as two influential shareholder advisory services suggested that the company instead entertain an unexpected takeover offer from an unlikely pair of Brazilian buyers.

title: Joan Rivers and the Front Page
description: Joan Rivers was a popular comedian, no doubt. But we asked Dean Baquet, the executive editor, why he decided to place her obituary on the front page this morning.

title: Poor Start Dooms Tomas Berdych Against Marin Cilic at U.S. Open
description: You cannot read too much into a players form after one game, but Tomas Berdychs start in his quarterfinal match against Marin Cilic was an ominous sign in an eventual 6-2, 6-4, 7-6 (4) loss.

title: Phil Ochs Archives Go to Woody Guthrie Center
description: Phil Ochss archival materials, including lyrics, scrapbooks filled with articles by and about him, photos and posters, have been donated to the Woody Guthrie Center, in Tulsa, Okla. The center is an archive and educational facility that opened in April 2013 with the goal of preserving not only Woody Guthries materials  his complete archives are housed there  but also the archives of musicians and artists in other disciplines who were influenced by him.

title: Vienna State Operas Music Director Resigns
description: The Vienna State Opera was thrown into turmoil just days after its new season began when its general music director, Franz Welser-Mst, abruptly resigned on Friday and withdrew from all his scheduled performances there, citing irreconcilable differences of opinion regarding the companys artistic planning and profile.

title: 1914: Italian Mobilization Expected
description: ROME  It is said that a general mobilization is imminent, and that General Nava will immediately assume chief command of the Italian army. The order for the general mobilization has not yet been signed, but it is believed it will be signed during the day. In the meantime the mobilization is proceeding actively by means of individual orders. Throughout the kingdom enlisting is proceeding actively. On the other hand, despatches from Milan say that between Bozen and Franzens Feste travellers have noticed numerous entrenchments prepared by the Austrian army, armed with guns turned upon Italy. In the north of Venetia large Italian forces are ready to march. The despatch of an ultimatum to Austria is expected every minute.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 6, 1914

title: Wary Normal in Ferguson, Mo.
description: Nearly a month has passed since Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, was fatally shot by a police officer, Darren Wilson, in Ferguson, Mo. The confrontation sparked a string of protests that lasted for more than a week. A small stretch of West Florissant Avenue, where businesses were looted and nightly protests would sometimes crescendo into violent clashes, became the backdrop for a national debate about racism and the militarization of police forces.

title: Letters: Poor Little Lambs
description: Poor Little Lambs

title: Medical Memoirs
description: INTERNAL MEDICINE  A Doctors Stories  By Terrence Holt  Liveright, $24.95.

title: Brandishing a Gun to Woo Voters
description: They call me a long shot, Estakio Beltran, a congressional candidate in Washington state, declares in a TV ad, never once disclosing that hes a Democrat but taking aim with his shotgun at a piata  an elephant piata in case anyone doubts what hes gunning for. Bam! the gun goes off and the sad-eyed, paper-tattered toy elephant topples. Mr. Beltrans ad is one of many bamming and kerpowing across the land from candidates pandering to gun enthusiasts. He may not win an election, but his seems the most entertaining or at least the silliest. Particularly so when he racks the empty shell from his gun in macho triumph and rides off like Clint Eastwood, heading east toward the Capitol on a loping donkey (a Democratic donkey?).

title: Getting to the Heart of Things
description: Matthew Thomass debut novel, We Are Not Ourselves, is reviewed this week by Maggie Scarf.

title: Family Circle
description: As a young woman training for a graduate degree in nursing administration, Eileen Tumulty longs for the day when she will marry and take another name. Its the thoroughgoing Irishness of Tumulty, with its redolence of peat bogs and sloppy rebel songs and deep defeat, from which she yearns to detach herself. She wants the sort of bland, decorous WASP name that will label her as an unhyphenated American. Bright, attractive and strong-willed, Eileen is passionately ambitious, determined to shake off the poverty-haunted, alcohol-ridden atmosphere of her childhood and achieve not only wealth and comfort but a sense of belonging. Shame is the deeply buried force that drives her.

title: Paperback Row
description: REIGN OF ERROR: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to Americas Public Schools,  by Diane Ravitch. (Vintage, $16.95.) In her influential 2010 book, The Death and Life of the Great American School System, Ravitch joined the vocal opposition to school choice and testing. In Reign of Error, she focuses more directly, and polemically, on the attempt to replace public schools with a free-market system, which she argues has fed on the myth that schools are failing.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BONE CLOCKS,  by David Mitchell. (Random House, $30.) In this latest head-spinning flight into other dimensions from the author of Cloud Atlas, all borders between pubby England and the machinations of the undead begin to blur.

title: Inside the List
description: Going Viral: Twenty years ago, Richard Preston scored a nonfiction hit with his scientific adventure story The Hot Zone, about an outbreak of Ebola virus among quarantined monkeys in Virginia  the book spent almost two years on the hardcover and paperback lists before fading away in June 1996. (That was a good time for science journalism. During its run, Prestons book shared space on the list with Oliver Sackss collection of neurological case studies An Anthropologist on Mars and Nicholas Negropontes technology primer Being Digital, which predicted the end of fax machines and CD-ROMs.) Now, with Ebola back in the news because of its fatal spread through West Africa, readers are returning to The Hot Zone. The Associated Press reported last month that Anchor Books, the paperback publisher, had printed 70,000 new copies, and the book is currently at No. 17 in its 50th week on the paperback nonfiction list. The thing is, Preston told CNN early in August, Ebola has been pulling surprises on all of us. I dont think anybody really expected that Ebola had the potential to do something like get into the cities and get out of control. But, you know, most of the experts Im talking to are saying that they are pretty well convinced that, you know, they will be able to get it under control, but theres huge concern about the possibility that Ebola could get into a major city. The viruss return is obviously bad news. But it does retroactively absolve The Hot Zone of a charge Colin Harrison leveled against it in the Book Review a few years after its publication. The outbreak in Virginia resulted in exactly zero human cases, Harrison noted, complaining about the happy frenzy of media attention the story had received. It was the first time that everyone knew about a disease that nobody had. It was the first time that a virus was famous for being famous. Now we know we were right to panic.

title: Between Women
description: Elena Ferrante is one of the great novelists of our time. Her voice is passionate, her view sweeping and her gaze basilisk. Her subject is the domestic world, and part of her genius lies in her capacity to turn this sphere into an infernal region, full of rage and violence, unlimited in its intellectual and emotional reach. Ferrantes view of family life is anything but sentimental, anything but comforting.

title: Future Footprints
description: For the first time in history, a sentient species, Homo sapiens, has become a force of such magnitude that our impacts are being written into the fossil record. We have decisively changed the carbon cycle, the nitrogen cycle and the rate of extinction. We have created new atomic isotopes and plastiglomerates that may persist for millions of years. We have built megacities that will leave a durable footprint long after they have vanished. We have altered the pH of the oceans and have moved so many life-forms around the globe  inadvertently and intentionally  that we are creating novel ecosystems everywhere. Since the late-18th-century industrialization that marks the Anthropocenes beginnings, humans have shaken Earths life systems with a profundity that the paleontologist Anthony Barnosky has likened to an asteroid strike.

title: Girlhood Gone
description: It seems endemic to the enterprise that fiction writers must fall good and hard for their characters  how else could we stand to live with them for weeks, months, years, in sometimes tortuous isolation? As in marriage or a long affair, this abiding attraction can twist and turn into revulsion or obsession. It can also wax and wane. The writer can stray and then beg for forgiveness, banging on a shut door to be let back inside. In conjuring The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, Mark Twain became captivated by Huckleberry Finn, Toms idle and lawless and vulgar and bad sidekick, so much so that Twain rode Huck on to glory with his subsequent masterpiece. J. D. Salingers beloved Holden Caulfield appeared in several stories, both published and unpublished, before he found his home in The Catcher in the Rye. And, as any fan knows, Salinger had a hell of a time kicking the Glass family to the curb; its members own or make appearances in all three of Salingers story collections, as well as in new collections (fingers crossed) that are rumored to be forthcoming.

title: Impossible Mirrors
description: Early in 10:04, Ben Lerners frequently brilliant second novel, the central character  a refraction or avatar of this Brooklyn-based author  describes visiting the Metropolitan Museum with a female friend: We often visited weekday afternoons, since Alex was unemployed, and I, a writer. Together they look at a melodramatic 19th-century genre painting of Joan of Arc, which the narrator claims is one of his favorite pictures. Lerner uses the strikingly unlovely word coconstructed to describe the shared nature of their experience: We would work out our views as we coconstructed the literal view before us. A few paragraphs on, he and an 8-year-old boy are seen coconstructing a shoe-box diorama. Later he can be found letting an Occupy protester shower in his apartment, wondering if its possible to coconstruct a world in which moments can be something other than the elements of profit.

title: His Manifest Destiny
description: In 1527, the Castilian conquistador Pnfilo de Narvez and a crew of 600 men sailed from Spain to the Gulf Coast of the United States to claim La Florida for the Spanish crown. Laila Lalami recounts the voyage  and its brutal aftermath  in her new novel, The Moors Account, from the perspective of Estebanico, a Moroccan slave of one of the explorers. Its a fictional memoir, told in a controlled voice that feels at once historical and contemporary, that seeks to offer a truer account of the expedition than the official (and hopelessly biased) version of events provided by lvar Nez Cabeza de Vaca, one of the other three survivors.

title: Toxic Relationships
description: A sinister oily sludge  improperly buried toxic waste reasserting itself  has wormed its way out of the ground in a small Texas town. Birth defects and cancer rates have soared; houses have been abandoned and razed. Now, years later, a peculiar collective amnesia has set in, and only one woman is still fighting the City Council, which has cleared the land for redevelopment, and the predictably sleazy real estate magnate who will profit from the job.

title: Weird Science
description: Its a very now premise: the confessional narrative of a food scientist complicit in the development of a chemical additive that has played a sneaky role in Americas obesity epidemic. The nonfiction shelves already abound with gastro-exposs (hello, Michael Pollan, Marion Nestle and Michael Moss), so why not fiction?

title: Hour of the Wolf
description: Early in William Giraldis fierce, extraordinary new novel, Hold the Dark, the nature writer Russell Core tracks a pack of wolves deep into the Alaskan tundra. The wolves, it seems, have been taking children from a nearby village, and Core, a wolf expert, has been summoned by the latest victims mother to get her boys bones and maybe slaughter the wolf that took him.

title: Minority Report
description: Theres nothing subtle or coy or particularly evocative about the title of Big Little Man: In Search of My Asian Self, a memoir by the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Alex Tizon. In fact, the title is so straightforward that when I was asked to write this review, I felt vaguely offended by the idea that my editor would push such an obvious identity-politics project on me, perhaps believing that I, by dint of being Asian-American, must therefore have some special insight into Tizon and this search for his Asian self. I am 20 years younger than Tizon and grew up in snooty college towns and attended schools where I was taught that there was a hierarchy of race writing. The immigrant experience was not enough in itself, and when I read the self-evident title of Tizons book, I flashed back to a fiction workshop in Columbias M.F.A. program and a professor who told me that the book I was working on  a book much like Tizons  could definitely be published, but wondered if there was anything I could do to elevate it into something more interesting. I recognized the code immediately  anything labeled the immigrant experience would be considered earnest and dclass, and would therefore need to be gussied up in fashionable literary frills. For the next year, I wrote bad evocations of Lydia Davis, Lorrie Moore, Barthelme and Borges. My protagonists, God help them, became whiter and whiter.

title: Dubliners
description: We spend our lives tumbling through time, carried along as it eddies and pools, buckles and loops, stutters and flies. As T. S. Eliot put it in the opening lines of Burnt Norton, Time present and time past / Are both perhaps present in time future, / And time future contained in time past. We like to think that time is ours to waste, but it is we who pass through time, wasting only ourselves.

title: The Age of Hobsbawm
description: A 1980 television film written by the British director Stephen Poliakoff depicted an interminable train journey through Europe, in which a young Englishman is trapped in a cramped compartment with a pompous Viennese matron, played by Peggy Ashcroft. The woman is rude and vain, but the film, Caught on a Train, refuses to despise her: Instead it recognizes that she is an elderly ambassador for a world that is about to pass away, the lost civilization of prewar Europe.

title: Art of Murder
description: Sooner or later, every writer of small-town mysteries must confront the occupational hazard of running out of murderers and victims. Louise Penny, who sets her enchanting stories in a sheltered Quebec village she calls Three Pines, keeps inventing new ways to avoid the inevitable reckoning. In THE LONG WAY HOME (Minotaur, $27.99), she makes the task more challenging by putting her detective out to pasture. Chief Inspector Armand Gamache has retired from the Sret du Qubec to live a contemplative life, enjoying the company of his eccentric neighbors and hoping to be anointed with the balm in Gilead that will make the wounded whole and cure a sin-sick soul. Gamache is moved by the plight of one neighbor, Clara Morrow, a painter whose husband, Peter, left home when her artistic reputation eclipsed his own  promising to return in exactly one year, presumably after intense soul-searching. But that anniversary has come and gone without any word, and Clara is afraid Peters in terrible trouble, might even be dead. Clutching at a few meager clues, the most intriguing being some atrocious paintings Peter sent to his sisters child, Gamache and Clara follow the lost artists perilous journey to find himself.

title: The Earth Stood Still, but the Game Played On
description: The split screen convergence of important news this summer  from Russia, Ukraine, Israel, Gaza, Syria, Iraq and Ferguson, Mo.  recalls an astonishing day 50 years ago next month. On Thursday, Oct. 15, 1964, the Yankees played the Cardinals at Busch Stadium in St. Louis. It was the deciding game of that years World Series, and, off the field, it seemed that all hell was breaking loose.

title: New Yorks Once and Future Mansions
description: When the architect/designer Ogden Codman Jr. built himself a splendidly self-indulgent 40-foot-wide limestone mansion on East 96th Street in 1913, he built it to last, and it did.

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Watching the Sun Set on the Summer Movie Season
description: Ross Douthat: Now is the Indian summer of our moviegoing discontent, when the temperatures still feel appropriate to midsummer blockbusters but the studios are dumping dreck that would be more at home in the wintry graveyard of late January. (As well as satisfying the millions who were apparently clamoring for a Forrest Gump IMAX re-release.) But there are still interesting things to talk about, and Ill start in with the movie thats supposed to be the great exception to the current doldrums Love Is Strange, in which John Lithgow and Alfred Molina play longtime companions who tie the knot, only to have Molinas character lose his job as a music teacher at a Catholic school because the bishop found out about his nuptials, which forces them to sell their tastefully shabby New York apartment and crash (separately, miserably) with their relatives while they try to get on the list for a rent-controlled living situation, with various uncomfortable interpersonal consequences for everyone concerned.

title: Under Cover: What Is Bill Gates Smiling About?
description: Do an image search for Bill Gates, and youll find plenty of photos of him speaking at events but few formal portraits. So when Dan Winters, a photographer based in Austin, Tex., agreed to shoot Gates for the cover of the Sept. 7 Education Issue to accompany the story by Andrew Ross Sorkin, he knew he wanted to do it in classic portrait-style fashion  in a way that is timeless and not pegged to any one time or concept, as he put it. Recently, Winter spoke about what it took to getone of the wealthiest people in the world to crack a smile.

title: Regulator Tightens Grip on Video Streaming Websites
description: The Chinese governments main regulator for entertainment on Friday tightened control over the broadcasting of foreign content over the Internet, dealing a blow to the nations booming online video streaming market.

title: Joan Rivers Is Remembered at a Book Party for Betty Halbreich
description: On Betty Halbreichs desk at Bergdorf Goodman are a number of mementos shes held on to during her 37 years there as a personal shopper: a photo of Isaac Mizrahi with Ms. Halbreichs daughter Kathy; a pincushion given to Ms. Halbreich by the costume designer William Ivey Long, whom Ms. Halbreich helped on a number of Broadway shows. Also a chocolate gun in a plastic box that was sent over a year or two ago by her close friend and client Joan Rivers.

title: Puerto Rico Luring Buyers With Tax Breaks
description: Alex Lemond is among a new wave of New Yorkers trading in their Manhattan condominiums for beachside villas in Puerto Rico. The former hedge fund honcho moved to San Juan from New York last year, and his company, the Encanto Group, is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in developing luxury real estate on the Caribbean island.

title: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
description: 100 Years Ago

title: Today in Small Business: Target and Starbucks Go Small
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Eichmann Before Jerusalem
description: This week, Bettina Stangneth talks about Eichmann Before Jerusalem; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Dana Stevens and Adam Kirsch discuss whether literature should be considered useful; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Eichmann Before Jerusalem
description: This week, Bettina Stangneth, Dana Stevens and Adam Kirsch.

title: In Crackdown on Corruption, Even Mooncakes Are Not Exempt
description: For generations, Chinese families have celebrated the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Monday this year, by coming together under the light of the years brightest full moon to share mooncakes, sweet pastries stuffed with fillings like lotus seed or red bean paste whose round shape symbolizes unity.

title: Strikes Killed Militant Chief in Somalia, U.S. Reports
description: NEWPORT, Wales  After four days of monitoring cellphone traffic, questioning Somali officials on the ground and poring over reports from both American and British intelligence agencies, the Pentagon on Friday announced that American airstrikes against the Shabab, the Qaeda-linked militant network in Somalia, had succeeded in killing the groups leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, one of the most wanted men in Africa.

title: Obama Enlists 9 Allies to Help in the Battle Against ISIS
description: NEWPORT, Wales  President Obama escalated the American response to the marauding Islamic State in Iraq and Syriaon Friday, recruiting at least nine allies to help crush the organization and offering the outlines of a coordinated military strategy that echoes the war on terror developed by his predecessor, George W. Bush, more than a decade ago.

title: Anatomy of an Authentic Apology
description: Words can sometimes, in moments of grace, attain the quality of deeds.  Elie Wiesel

title: 1939: Roosevelt Signs Neutrality
description: President Roosevelt signed a proclamation of United States neutrality in the European conflict and followed this action by another proclamation wherein was invoked the arms embargo against belligerents under the neutrality act. Safety measures for ships transporting Americans from the war zone to the United States appeared to be summarized in two ideas:

title: Settlement Is Approved in Central Park Jogger Case, but New York Deflects Blame
description: A $41 million settlement for five men whose convictions in the 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned was made final on Friday, with the deal including unusual language that sought to absolve New York City from blame.

title: The Women of West Point
description: Few collegians work as hard as the U.S. Military Academys 786 female cadets.

title: The Jobless Rate: The Worst Benchmark, Except for All the Others
description: The unemployment rates reputation as a reliable economic indicator has taken a beating in recent years. But whats the better alternative?

title: A Wedding Dress I Never Expected: A Sari
description: Ten minutes after meeting my future mother-in-law, I was wearing only underwear and socks. Acres of magenta chiffon and piles of gold sequins and faux-emerald jewelry  the regalia for my engagement ceremony  lay on the bed. I sucked in my stomach as she deftly wrapped the fabric around my waist. But in the Kolkata humidity, the sari clung to my skin like Saran Wrap. My consternation must have been apparent, because she rushed to reassure me. Dont worry! she said warmly. You will look sundor! That means beautiful in Bengali.

title: Who Made That Cocktail Shaker?
description: In 1848, George Foster, a reporter for The New York Tribune who spent his nights searching for good stories in the citys seedier quarters, marveled at the way a bartender made a drink: With his shirt sleeves rolled up, and his face in a fiery glow [he] seems to be pulling long ribbons of julep out of a tin cup.

title: Reply All: The 8.24.14 Issue
description: IS EUGENIE BOUCHARD TENNISS NEXT BIG SHOT?

title: Is It Wrong to Watch Football?
description: Ive recently begun to question my support for the N.F.L. I suspect that the recent discoveries about concussions and the prevalence of early-onset dementia among players are just the tip of the iceberg. Is it unethical to support a league that seems to know it is detrimental to the health of its participants? And if so, what should my response be? Dont go to games? Dont buy merchandise? Dont watch on television? Start actively opposing the N.F.L.? Write letters? DARREN WILLIAMS, DALLAS

title: Louisiana Judge Rejects Suit Over Landrieus Residency
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  A state district judge on Friday threw out a challenge to Senator Mary L. Landrieus bid for re-election in Louisiana.

title: The Happiest Meal of Your Life
description: Plus, sleep like a cave man; the hat heard round the world.

title: Idris Elba, No Stringers Attached
description: The actor talks to Amy Chozick about embracing his sinister side, coming to America and clubbing in Ibiza.

title: Home and Occasional Film Set
description: The filmmaker Ira Sachss two-bedroom apartment on lower Fifth Avenue, where he has lived for 15 years, is a much happier place than it used to be. He memorialized the sad times by using the art- and book-filled apartment as a primary location for his 2012 movie, Keep the Lights On, a fictionalized version of his tumultuous 10-year love affair with an addict.

title: Make Music New York Going Global With Talk Series
description: Make Music New York, the citywide festival that takes place on the summer and winter solstices, began experimenting in January with a new series, Make Music Monthly, at which public discussions of musical topics were presented at the Cornelia Street Caf and were made available as podcasts on Make Music New Yorks website.

title: Along West Florissant
description: Scars from days of unrest remain along the main street in Ferguson, Mo., as residents and businesses try to get on with their lives.

title: Prabal Gurung Steps Into Footwear
description: Prabal Gurungs runway shoe collaborations with Casadei, Nicholas Kirkwood and Manolo Blahnik have, in recent seasons, proven as creative as his clothes. Now, for spring/summer 2015, the New York-based Nepalese designer is launching his first complete footwear range under his own label. Inspired by Gurungs favorite artists  Tracey Emin, Zaha Hadid, Cecily Brown, Georgia OKeeffe, Cindy Sherman and Frida Kahlo  the heels, flats and boots will appear for the first time at his runway show on Saturday. We kept to how we design clothes  mixing luxurious textures and vibrant colors, Gurung explains. Styles are finished off with black insoles for a graphic effect, while the spiky silver buckles, he says, give everything that bite.

title: The Shearing of the Rockfall
description: Its a perfect crime, really. Theres no blood, and there are no sign of struggle, no marks at all, although plenty is missing. Certainly, the statute of limitations has long ago passed in the case of the mutilation of the intricate front of the Rockfall apartment house, at 111th Street and Broadway. But then, is facade-icide even a crime at all?

title: A Spotlight on Sarasota Architecture
description: Fans of the mid-20th-century Sarasota School of Architecture have been visiting the Florida city for years, seeking out examples of buildings that architects designed to adapt modernist principles to the tropical environment.

title: Big Ticket | Duplex Sets a Record at $71.3 Million
description: A much-coveted front corner duplex apartment at 740 Park Avenue, New York Citys billionaire magnet, sold for $71,277,500 after a masters-of-the-universe-only bidding war that spiked its $48 million asking price skyward. It was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Peter Som: Spring 2015 RTW
description: NEW YORK

title: Ned Benson Narrates a Scene From The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby
description: In this video, the writer and director Ned Benson discusses the opening sequence from his film The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them. The director has made three different versions of his film, which tell the story of a couple (James McAvoy and Jessica Chastain) from various points of view.

title: George R. R. Martin to Appear at 92nd St Y
description: The Seven Kingdoms will meet the Five Boroughs  or Manhattan, at least  when George R. R. Martin touches down at the 92nd Street Y on Oct. 26 for his only United States appearance this year discussing and promoting his new book, The World of Ice and Fire: The Untold History of Westeros and the Game of Thrones.

title: Reading The Times With Delia Ephron
description: Delia Ephron, the author, most recently, of the memoir Sister Mother Husband Dog (Etc.), reads The Times at around 8 in the morning, while stretched out on a window seat, ideally with the sun streaming in. She says she always reads The Times as a real newspaper: in print.

title: New Answers About Carbs and Fat
description: New research showing that a low-carbohydrate diet is better for weight loss than a low-fat diet has renewed interest in low-carb eating. To help explain how the latest study is changing the way we think about dieting, the New York Times health writer Anahad OConnor replies to an edited selection of comments and questions from readers.

title: Bonanza of Talent Out West
description: Saturdays college football game between 13th-ranked Stanford and No. 14 Southern California provides more than an early-season peek at how competitive the powerful Pacific-12 Conference is. It demonstrates just how competitive it is to be a Pac-12 quarterback these days.

title: A View Worthy of an Aria
description: A spacious two-bedroom co-op at the Hampshire House that captivated the Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti some 30 years ago with its treehouse vistas of the entirety of Central Park is poised to enter the market at $13.7 million.

title: Hiring Data Isnt Strong Enough to Lift Democrats Hopes for November
description: WASHINGTON  With Fridays disappointing jobs report for August, Democrats can pretty much give up any remaining hopes that voters will shake their gloom about the economy before this falls midterm elections.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: mold, antidepressants and new research on diet.

title: Jane Pratt: Shes Still So Sassy
description: Jane Pratt is the creator and editor in chief of the website xoJane, where beauty stories like How Sunless Tanner (And Other Beauty Rituals) Helped Me Finally Quit Smoking run beside columns by celebrity friends like Courtney Love and the popular confessional series It Happened to Me. Ms. Pratt, 51, has been a media maven since the 1980s, when at age 24 she started Sassy, a magazine for teenagers, which had fans including Johnny Depp. In 1997, she founded Jane magazine to cater to the aging Sassy demographic. Ms. Pratt lives in a loft in TriBeCa with her daughter, Charlotte, 11, and two dogs, Balloon, a Shih Tzu-poodle mix, and Lemon, a Maltese.

title: Malnutrition Crisis in Sudan
description: Heres an internal UNICEF document citing stunning figures for malnutrition in Sudan, particularly in Darfur. It has been 11 years since the killing began in Darfur, and the news coverage has abatedpartly because it is so difficult to get access to the story (I havent received a Sudan visa in years). But this document suggests that the suffering continues at horrifying levels.

title: Obama: The Goal Is to Dismantle ISIS
description: The president commented on the battle against the Islamic State during a news conference at the NATO summit in Wales.

title: Atlanta Orchestra Leaders Make a Plea for Musicians During Labor Talks
description: Since the days when it was led by Robert Shaw, the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra has won a reputation far outside the South for its tours and Grammy Award-winning recordings. It continues to win accolades far and wide under the musical leadership of Robert Spano.

title: Billy Reid and Alabama Chanins Homegrown Cotton
description: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of natures seasonal yield of ingredients.

title: What I Learned on My Vacation
description: My first vacation epiphany occurred while taking my two dogs for a walk on the beach at 6 one evening in early August. Ive always considered walking the dogs obligatory but not especially enjoyable, and I fobbed it off on my wife as often as possible, since she seemed, mysteriously, to enjoy it. But on this night, with the waves lapping on the shore and almost no one in sight, I found myself in a state of deep quiet and contentment. I was happy, nearly rapturous, just walking and taking in the scene.

title: Every Night Its As If Weve Never Had to Make Dinner Before.
description: Meet Julie.

title: Credit Card Offers Are Not Always What They Seem
description: The offers stuffing your mailbox can sound enticing: Transfer a balance from a high-rate credit card to a new card and pay no interest for six months, a year or even longer.

title: Negotiators on Ukraine Cease-Fire
description: Two pro-Russian rebel leaders, the Ukrainian president and an envoy for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe discussed the cease-fire reached between the separatists and Ukraine.

title: For Torontos Little India, a New Crowd
description: Sari shops and curry emporiums still dot Gerrard Street, the main artery in Torontos Little India. But over the last decade, much of the citys South Asian population has decamped for suburbs like Brampton and Rexdale. Now, as artists and young families move into the neighborhoods neat single-family homes, Gerrard Streets affordable storefronts are attracting creative entrepreneurs priced out of trendier districts. The fresh crop of businesses is giving this east-end enclave a vibe thats both edgy and homey. And with a wave of Irish immigrants settling nearby side streets, a distinctive lilt can now be heard on the strip.

title: Mud, Worms and Ropes: A One-Day Survival Course
description: When foraging in the wild, one of the best reliable sources of protein is an earthworm. To serve: Use your fingers to wring the slime past the midsection. Snap off the bottom half  mostly intestines anyway  and put the rest in your mouth. Swallow quickly so it doesnt wiggle on the way down.

title: To Ride Again Another Day in Colorado
description: If you ride a bicycle more than casually, you probably already know about Boulder, Colo. Its altitude, endless hills and nearly perpetual sunshine make it a big draw for the pedal-powered and regularly ensure it a top spot on lists of Americas most bike-friendly cities.

title: Some Chinese Tourists Visit New York but Sleep in New Jersey
description: The day began early. By 7:30 a.m., the 56 tourists from China were standing in line in the parking lot of the hotel in which they had spent the night.

title: Tanya Taylor: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: A Slow-Forming Bond
description: Maria Nedwidek and Eric Moore were married on Aug. 17, at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church in New York.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Mazda Celebrates 25 Years of Miata
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Vice Media Employs Old-School Traits in Fund-Raising
description: Vice Media likes to seem anarchic, but it is making a virtue of some industry orthodoxies.

title: Investing to Make a Difference Is Gaining Ground
description: IF there is a traditional path to becoming an impact investor, it is the one taken by David Keller, who made a lot of money at a young age and retired from Cisco Systems in his 40s in 2002.

title: The Math (and Chemistry) of Marriage
description: In 1986, Eric Moore sat just two seats away from Maria Nedwidek in an honors chemistry class at the renowned Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan. And their yearbook photos were just two rows apart. Yet he rarely spoke to her.

title: Answers to Questions About New York City Parks
description: Q. Can you tell me about the park in Washington Heights that a man created to honor his wife after he was accused of poisoning her?

title: Simply Unacceptable
description: Chris Dillow makes a good point about economics and maybe public affairs in general: There is often a tendency to go for simple stories that arent true as H.L. Mencken said, For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong. But it also often happens that the answer is simple, but people refuse to accept that simple answer. That is, the reverse of Menckens proposition also applies: For every simple problem there is an answer that is murky, complex, and wrong.

title: What Made Me | Nick Anderer
description: Chef Nick Anderer shares how a college summer abroad in Rome inspired him to open the restaurant Maialino and his latest venture, Marta.

title: Elizabeth II (And Me)
description: Well, they messed up the livestream of my dialogue with Elizabeth Warren, but here it is as video on demand.

title: For Kayden Kross, the Family Business Happens to Be Porn
description: I met Manuel seven years ago on the set of my first porn shoot. I was quiet and nervous and huddled away on a couch in a back room, burning through coffee and the W-9 tax packet I had been handed on my way in.

title: Book Review Podcast: Eichmann Before Jerusalem
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Steven Aschheim reviews Bettina Stangneths Eichmann Before Jerusalem. Mr. Aschheim writes:

title: September Rewards the Fig Lover
description: If you are a fig lover, as I am, and there are fig trees nearby, you enjoy watching every moment of their growth, even if much of that involves waiting for things to happen.

title: Damaged Buildings and Psyches Challenge Schools in Gaza
description: GAZA  Here is the vexing math problem educators in the Gaza Strip are trying to solve in order to start school Sept. 14, three weeks later than originally planned:

title: The Beveridge That Refreshes
description: Claims that there is a huge skills gap, that much of our unemployment is structural, reflecting an inadequately prepared work force or something like that, generally rest on claims that we have an unusual situation in which many jobs are vacant even as many workers remain unemployed. For example, at the beginning of this year Jaime Dimon co-authored a piece on the alleged skills gap that began,

title: When The Hokey Pokey Just Doesnt Cut It
