title: Chief Umpire, Stepping Down, Will Leave Indelible Legacy
description: John Isner planted a backhand half-volley over the baseline on the Louis Armstrong Stadium court, losing a tiebreaker and heading toward defeat at the hands of Philipp Kohlschreiber.

title: An IndyCar Champion Who Stays Sharp by Driving Go-Karts
description: Will Power won his first IndyCar championship on Aug. 30 after finishing second in the series three times in the past four years. Among the perks of being champion were a visit to Late Show With David Letterman on Thursday and good seats to Roger Federers comeback victory over Gal Monfils at the United States Open that night. That is nothing compared with the reception that awaits him in his hometown, Toowoomba, Australia. He is the first Australian champion of a major motor sports series since 1980. Power, 33, talked to editors of The New York Times last week about his journey. The interview has been condensed and edited.

title: Evidence Grows of Russian Orthodox Clergys Aiding Ukraine Rebels
description: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine  On an overcast day in April, staff members at the municipal museum in this eastern Ukrainian town noticed strange goings-on next door at a cultural center run by the Ukrainian arm of the Russian Orthodox Church.

title: Kansas Governor Hopefuls Hurl Barbs in First Debate
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan.  Debating for the first time in a tight governors race, the two major candidates offered few specifics on their visions for the state, but lobbed sharp attacks at one another Saturday before a feisty crowd at the Kansas State Fair that seemed befitting of a football game.

title: Pachinko Hopes for a Comeback
description: A Japanese industry is trying to lure the countrys youth with big, clean, luxurious casinos as many of its older gaming halls close.

title: To Draw in New Crowds, an Industry Bets on Itself
description: NAGOYA, Japan  Part pinball and part roulette, with the lure of quick cash winnings and little silver balls ricocheting off pins and bumpers, the Japanese game of pachinko once seemed a permanent feature of the nations postwar landscape, its arcade-style sounds and lights providing a blinking, cacophonous backdrop to life in Japan during the boom years.

title: Rex Ryans Words Stay Bold, but a Little Less Brash With the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A recent conversation with Rex Ryan veered into unexpected territory: adjectives.

title: Texas Candidate Reveals Personal Tale of Two Abortions
description: HOUSTON  For more than 11 hours last summer, Wendy Davis stood on the floor of the Texas Senate, reading letter upon letter from women describing their personal ordeals in deciding to end their pregnancies and seek abortions.

title: Celebrity Guest Blogger Matt Bai: All-Encompassing
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its not often that the stars align so wonderfully when I go in search of a celebrity guest blogger.

title: Analytics: Is Eugenie Bouchard Overrated?
description: The following graphic appears on the Reply All page in the Sept. 7 issue of the magazine.

title: Light Pre-Election Schedule in Congress Matches Legislative Goals
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress return to the Capitol on Monday with very little time to do very little work.

title: Christian Siriano: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Roger Federer Is Ousted by Marin Cilic in Semifinal
description: The draw to an 18th Grand Slam title, which he had been targeting since winning Wimbledon in 2012, had never looked more inviting for Roger Federer when he stepped on the court to play Marin Cilic late Saturday afternoon in the semifinals of the United States Open.

title: Redactions in U.S. Memo Leave Doubts on Data Surveillance Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has released a newly declassified version of a May 2004 legal memo approving the National Security Agencys Stellarwind program, a set of warrantless surveillance and data collection activities that President George W. Bush secretly authorized after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. But questions about the program remain.

title: At Baja East, A Hot Mess of a French Braid
description: French braids have popped up on multiple New York Fashion Week runways, but the best example weve seen might be the version at todays Baja East show. The design duo extended the vibe of its laid-back, coastal unisex collection to the hair: an undone French braid that looked like it had a little roll around in the sand.

title: Tibi: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: For Jihad Recruits, a Pipeline From Minnesota to Militancy
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It was a friendship that began in high school and ended in militant jihad.

title: Conservatives Focus on Degrees of Conservatism
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Aqua Sock-Style Woven Pumps at Alexander Wang
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: A Live Action Comic Book Brings Zygon to Life
description: AUSTIN  The touring show The Intergalactic Nemesis is an adventure story featuring robots, aliens, time travel and magical powers. But its special effects take place exclusively in the audiences mind, created through an alchemy of old media and imagination. Twin Infinity, the third book in the trilogy, premiered Friday night at Austins Long Center for the Performing Arts. The first book, Target Earth, will play in Houston on Sept. 30.

title: Lillian Gobitas Klose, 90, Dies; Stood Against Mandatory Pledge
description: Lillian Gobitas Klose, whose refusal, on religious grounds, to recite the Pledge of Allegiance as a seventh grader in a Pennsylvania public school in 1935 ignited national indignation, as well as a roiling legal fight that led to an expansion of First Amendment rights, died on Aug. 22 at her home in Fayetteville, Ga. She was 90.

title: Texas A&M Fans Are Fluent in the Science of Yelling
description: If a crowds cheers bolster players resolve and lead to better performances, that is usually a bonus. Cheers are intended primarily for the fans benefit: to make them feel helpful or, failing that, to give them something to do.

title: Refugees Reshape Their Camp, at the Risk of Feeling at Home
description: AL FAWWAR, West Bank  Up a rutted alley, mothers in head scarves, seated under flapping cloth canopies, sip tea and weave baskets. Theyve gathered in a dusty, sun-bleached square, not much bigger than a pocket park, made of limestone and concrete, shoehorned into a warren of low, concrete and cinder-block houses. The square isnt much to look at.

title: Amid the Bustle, Derek Jeter Has a Quiet Day at the Plate
description: On the wall to the right of Derek Jeters locker is a poster of the Yankees 2014 schedule. No days are crossed off. None are circled. Nonetheless, he is surrounded by reminders that his career is running out.

title: New York Fashion Week: Ralph Rucci Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Andreas Joseph.

title: Alexander Wang: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Nursing Facilities Blast Three Strikes Proposal
description: At a hearing in August to evaluate the state agency responsible for Texas elderly residents, State Senator Charles Schwertner singled out seven of the 1,200 nursing homes licensed by the Department of Aging and Disability Services.

title: Judge Orders Texas to Pay Fees for Districts in Finance Case
description: If the Texas school districts that are challenging the constitutionality of the states school finance system ultimately prevail in their lawsuit, a result could be billions of dollars in extra funding from the states coffers for public education.

title: Feat of Historic Proportions for an Italian Grandmaster
description: Fabiano Caruana turned in one of the most dominant performances in the games history at the Sinquefield Cup in St. Louis. He won his first seven games and clinched first place long before the tournament ended on Saturday.

title: Building Good Will in a Troubled Afghan District, but Not Without a Fight
description: AZRA, Afghanistan  It was hard to place the thick scent filtering into the American military helicopter as it landed here on a recent summer day.

title: The Trick Behind the Sporty Ponytails at Alexander Wang
description: Athletic shoes have a cultish appeal among fashion designers, and it would seem that beauty pros are similarly obsessed. Backstage at Alexander Wang this afternoon, both the hair and makeup teams talked about trainers as the inspiration behind the slicked-back, sporty looks given to the models. It started with a fetish about sneakers, said the makeup artist Diane Kendal of her conversation with the designer. There were references to Stan Smith, Michael Jordan, New Balance. The hairstylist Guido Palau ran with that concept, putting a new spin on the classic gymnasium ponytail. Its a bit futuristic, he said of the low-slung style. The tail is dry but there is a high gloss to the head. Palaus technique involved tightly combing back strands with generous amounts of Redken Hardwear 16 Super Strong Hair Gel around the crown, then misting Redken Diamond Oil High Shine Airy Mist (available in October) all over to provide a glistening effect. To finish, he secured hair with a simple black tie at the nape. I cant really move my neck too much! joked the model Mari of the ultra-sleek result. Still, she proved to be a good sport. But I cant wait to see how it will look on the runway.

title: Notre Dame Gives Michigan a Powerful Parting Shot

title: In the Wee Hours, Japan Erupts in Celebration

Kei Nishikori, the countrys 24-year-old tennis sensation, had just powered past Novak Djokovic to book a place at a Grand Slam final  a first for a Japanese player, and for a man from Asia.

title: Factors at BMW, but Afterthoughts at Ryder Cup

One United States-born player birdied eight of his first 12 holes at Cherry Hills Country Club. Two others were in first and second after the third round.

title: Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off
description: One night in June, Sheng Tianxing made good on his name, which translated literally means sky travel. With a single click online, he paid $100,000, about a third of his annual income, for a seat on a rocket that will carry him into space.

title: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks

Films like Searching for Sugar Man and Incendies were distributed by the classics unit.

title: New Drug Policy Is Likely for N.F.L.
description: The N.F.L. and the N.F.L. Players Association are nearing an agreement to overhaul the leagues drug policy. After years of negotiations, the sides have all but agreed on introducing testing for human growth hormone. The league may raise the threshold for triggering penalties for marijuana to bring the policy more in line with Major League Baseballs. Penalties for out-of-season positive tests for amphetamines may also be loosened.

title: 1889: Research May Help Prolong Womens Fertility
description: Dr. Brown-Squard, who recently returned to Paris from Brighton, where he has been passing his summer holidays, is still pursuing his investigations and experiments in reference to the method of increasing vitality. His studies are now directed towards accomplishing for women the same result that he maintains has been reached in the case of men  that is to say, the period of capacity for conception can be prolonged by subcutaneous inoculations with substances primarily obtained from female dogs. These researches have not yet arrived at a sufficiently advanced stage to convince Dr. Brown-Squard that any practical application can be made in this direction at present, but several women have already called upon Dr. Brown-Squard, and offered themselves as subjects for these inoculations.   The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 8, 1889

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (Al Jazeera America) EDGE OF EIGHTEEN The Oscar-winning documentary maker Alex Gibney (Taxi to the Dark Side) is an executive producer of this new series, which chronicles life as a teenager in the United States in six episodes filmed from January through May by a group of 17- and 18-year-olds. These 15 students, including Brandon McCauley of Lebanon, Ohio, above, traveled to New York for a crash course in filmmaking from the directors Alexandra Pelosi (Journeys With George), Sam Pollard (When the Levees Broke) and Mr. Gibney. They received equipment and learned about storytelling, interviewing, cinematography, sound recording and editing. Then they returned home to document significant events and interview parents, teachers and other important people in their lives as professional producers sometimes worked alongside them to help them develop their stories.

title: 1914: French Press Misjudges U.S. Ambassadors
description: Judging from their comments, some of the French newspapers take a rather erroneous view of the arrival in Paris of Mr. W. G. Sharp and Mr. Robert Bacon. The idea seems to prevail that the United States is now represented in Paris by a sort of diplomatic triumvirate. Such an idea, of course, is amusingly inaccurate. Mr. Myron T. Herrick, the American Ambassador, is in sole charge of the Embassy, and will remain in sole charge until the end of the existing crisis. Mr. W. G. Sharp, who will take over the Embassy when conditions permit Mr. Herrick to retire, is in Paris for the purpose of arranging details connected with the preparations for his residence here. As regards Mr. Bacon, who made a host of friends during his term as Ambassador, he is visiting Paris at this time on private business. The French press, in fact, in trying to read diplomatic significance into the presence in Paris of the three eminent diplomatists, is wasting its ingenuity.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 8, 1914

title: One Last Appearance at Fashion Week for Joan Rivers

title: How to Get the Purple Hazy Eyes at Derek Lam
description: I like when beauty has a little twist to it, said the French makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage this morning. When workshopping the concept behind the beauty look at Derek Lam, Pecheux tried a few different options for the designer. The first was all natural, no makeup, blah blah, he said. The girl looked like a flat wheel. So I said, Lets try a nude color, which was pretty but boring. Eventually the face painter grabbed a rich violet color and smudged it over the lids: et voil, that did the trick. Derek said, Oooh, I like that! exclaimed Pecheux, with an amused smile. Still, the bruisey shade, as Pecheux described it, required careful application. To avoid the illusion of being punched in the face, he traced MAC Fluidline in Deep Deep Brown along the upper lashes, then brushed on MAC Lipstick in Violetta, creating a soft pinky-lavender wash over the lids and up to the brows. The lipstick is bright, so you only need a thin layer, he insisted. To finish, he swept on a metallic taupe eye shadow, then etched a thin streak of white kohl pencil under the eyes to lend contrast. The last step: sheering out everything with his hands. This is your best friend, Pecheux said, waving his finger in the air. Using your fingers with makeup brings so much sensuality and femininity to the face, and thats what I want for spring and summer.

title: U.S. Open 2014: For Kei Nishikori, a Bold Move to Chase a Tennis Dream
description: TOKYO  Kei Nishikori is the first Japanese man to reach a Grand Slam singles final, but in Japan he is seen as a most un-Japanese sports hero.

And the ladylike updo on last nights runway, a slicked back bun encased with netting that matched models hair colors, reinforced the sophisticated yet youthful tone.

title: Natural Dam Collapses in Nepal, Washing Away Bridges
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  A natural dam created by a huge landslide last month across the Sankoshi River collapsed on Sunday, allowing a wall of water to course down the river and sweep away a giant excavating machine and many bridges.

title: Britain Pledges More Self-Rule for Scots if They Reject Scottish Independence

title: Oil Scandal Erupts Again as Brazilians Near Election

title: Guardians Draws Most at the Box Office, Identical Very Few
description: The weekend after Labor Day is typically the worst of the box office year, as vacationing Americans return to the grind, and studios hold back new films. But multiplexes over the last three days were particularly moribund: The Top 10 ticket sellers were all holdovers, and the only new wide-release movie, a musical drama called The Identical, bombed in 11th place.

description: There is an emerging subgenre of British nonfiction in which journalists from The Guardian fearlessly recount their own derring-do in David-and-Goliath battles waged against omnipotent state interests in the pursuit of Big Important Truths.

title: Traditions Meld Deftly to the Contemporary
description: The strongest contrast between the two programs in this years Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance was atmospheric. The first show, back in late August, was outdoors, against a backdrop of New York Harbor, Statue of Liberty and setting sun that both glorified the dancing and competed with it. The second installment, on Friday, took place inside the relative ordinariness of the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.

title: Suitcase Yields a Monet
description: A Monet landscape is the latest lost treasure to surface in Cornelius Gurlitts trove of European art. The painting was recently found in a suitcase that belonged to Mr. Gurlitt, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gurlitt died in May at 81, a little more than two years after approximately 1,280 paintings and drawings by Picasso, Chagall, Gauguin and other modern masters were confiscated from his Munich apartment.  Mr. Gurlitt had inherited the paintings from his father, Hildebrand Gurlitt, a Nazi-era art dealer. The suitcase containing the Monet was left at a hospital where Mr. Gurlitt had stayed and was turned over to a court-appointed task force handling his estate, The A.P. reported. The work, a light-blue landscape painted on paper, is estimated to have been created around 1864.

But we certainly dont treat it as a national treasure: This once magnificent watercourse, which runs through New York, Pennsylvania and Maryland toward the coast, is today an ecological disaster  largely thanks to four hydroelectric dams, built along its lower reaches between 1904 and 1931.

title: With Videos of Killings, ISIS Sends Medieval Message by Modern Method
description: The ostensible purpose of the recent videos that show the beheadings of two American journalists by Islamic militants is to deter attacks  your missiles on our positions will beget our knives on Western hostages  but the true aim is to spread dread and terror.

title: Honoring Arthur Gelb
description: The family of Arthur Gelb will hold a public service on Tuesday at 1:30 p.m. honoring Mr. Gelb, the former editor and critic for The New York Times who died in May at 90. Celebrating the Life of Arthur Gelb, at the Eugene ONeill Theater at 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan, will feature former colleagues, friends and family members as speakers. They include Maureen Dowd, Frank Rich, Bernard Kalb, Robert Klein, Gay Talese, Marian Wood and Mr. Gelbs son Michael. Kelli OHara and Eric Owens will perform songs selected by the Gelb family. Its a not a memorial service, Mr. Gelbs other son, Peter,  the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, said Sunday by phone. Its meant to be a celebration of his life. Admission is free.

title: Making Art on the Spot and on the Fly
description: Midway through Task, the come-one, come-all art party that Oliver Herring had organized in Madison Square Park on Saturday night, Mr. Herring was hoisted by his own petard. His formerly white shirt, finely cut and nicely tailored, was covered in splotches of bright color.

title: With Fervor, an Acolyte Breaks Out on Her Own
description: As a beloved former member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, Annmaria Mazzini already has a loyal audience, or so it seemed on Saturday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, where a full and enthusiastic house turned out for a performance by her three-year-old troupe, Mazzini Dance Collective. Her impressive roster of guest artists didnt hurt, either: The lineup included two works by a fellow Taylor alum, Orion Duckstein, and appearances by the current Taylor dancers Francisco Graciano and Robert Kleinendorst.

title: Ascending Without Zeppelin
description: Im always in a state of flux, I think, Robert Plant said, then corrected himself. I hope.

title: Betrayed by Her Body, a Dancer Connects Online
description: Picture this: A New York City Ballet soloist, unusually radiant with creamy skin, eloquent feet and a vintage luster to her drama, watches in horror as her body begins to deteriorate. Her hair falls out. Her migraines become debilitating. The pounds pile on. If, in dance, the body is an instrument, what happens, as with Kathryn Morgan, when it betrays you?

title: Schools Become Homes for Refugees in Iraq
description: Schools in Dohuk, Iraq, in the Kurdish north, are filled with displaced Iraqis who fled the advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria this summer.

title: Trying to Figure Out Her Patients and Herself
description: Every day, the young psychiatrist in Marcelo Gomess Once Upon a Time, Vernica treats ailing visitors at a public hospital in her city, Recife, Brazil. Some patients cant quite convey their woes; they seem stymied by an ingrown inability to articulate their problems. The same might be said about their doctor, Vernica, whose rootlessness and vexation Mr. Gomes gingerly records in this poised feature.

title: Luck and Skill Prevail at Cavendish Open Pairs
description: There were 52 pairs vying for the Cavendish Open Pairs title in Monaco last week. They played almost a complete round robin, with two boards against 50 other pairs. Then the top 12 pairs moved into Final A, which consisted of two sessions of a two-board round robin  a total of four boards against each of the other 11 pairs.

title: DKNY: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Black Magic Item
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I was frankly too busy to acknowledge my last milestone birthday, but luckily for us, we have Dan Schoenholz to remind us about THE BIG FIVE-OH.

title: Royals Respectfully Decline to Go Along With a Perfect Yankees Script
description: Derek Jeter rocked back and forth on his feet, his head down, his hands behind his back, as the Yankee Stadium crowd chanted his name: Der-ek! Je-ter! The fans grew louder and would not stop, so he waved again and took the microphone. They were there for this ceremony, for Derek Jeter Day, and he expressed his gratitude.

title: Man Dies One Week After Shootout With Police in Brooklyn
description: A 22-year-old man who wounded a police officer in Brooklyn late last month before being shot by other officers died over the weekend after complications of surgery, the police said.

title: Serena Williams, Queen of Queens, Embraces Elusive Milestone
description: Serena Williams was asked last week what the number 18 meant to her.

title: Tracy Reese: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: SWAT: Mission Creep
description: SWAT teams were created in the 1960s to combat hostage-takings, sniper shootings, and violent unrest. But today theyre often used in more controversial police work.

title: Bruce Levensons Email to Hawks Executives
description: In an email sent in August 2012 to General Manager Danny Ferry and other members of the Atlanta Hawks ownership, Bruce Levenson pointed out the teams continued struggles to attract fans and corporate sponsors from Atlantas white community.

title: The Rise of the SWAT Team in American Policing
description: Posse comitatus is not a phrase that trips lightly off every tongue. It is typically translated from Latin as force of the county. Anyone who has ever watched an old Western movie will instantly recognize the first word as referring to men deputized by the sheriff to chase down some varmints who went thataway. (Rappers and their tag-alongs later gave posse a different context.) The full phrase is more obscure, but the concept that it embraces is enshrined in American law. The Posse Comitatus Act, passed in 1878 at the end of Reconstruction and amended but slightly over the decades, prohibits the nations armed forces from being used as a police force within the United States. Soldiers, the reasoning goes, exist to fight wars. Chasing local wrongdoers is a job for cops.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Sept. 8
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Sam Harriss Vanishing Self
description: Sam Harris is a neuroscientist and prominent new atheist, who along with others like Richard Dawkins, Daniel Dennett and Christopher Hitchens helped put criticism of religion at the forefront of public debate in recent years. In two previous books, The End of Faith and Letter to a Christian Nation, Harris argued that theistic religion has no place in a world of science. In his latest book, Waking Up, his thought takes a new direction. While still rejecting theism, Harris nonetheless makes a case for the value of spirituality, which he bases on his experiences in meditation. I interviewed him recently about the book and some of the arguments he makes in it.

title: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2015 RTW
description: NEW YORK

title: Who Owns Fashion?
Princeton Faculty to Vote on Altering Sexual Misconduct Policies
description: Princeton University may soon make significant changes in the way it handles allegations of sexual misconduct, including lowering the standards required to find someone guilty in its disciplinary proceedings.

title: Politico Top Editor Quits Over Strategic Differences With Founders
description: Richard L. Berke, the executive editor of Politico, has resigned from his position, he said in an email to his staff on Sunday, citing a disagreement over strategy with the organizations founders, John F. Harris and Jim VandeHei.

title: A Sheet of Papers 9/11 Journey
description: Dear Diary:

title: Success of Apples iWatch May Rely on Health Care Partnerships
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is trying to have another iPod experience.

title: Responding to Ebola: The Back Story
description: The Ebola outbreak has incited concern  and criticism. Critics blasted international organizations, particularly the World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, for a bumbling, insufficient response to an alarming global threat. Sheri Fink set out to investigate.

title: Margaret Sullivan: By the Book
description: In a new Insider feature, Pamela Paul, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, extends the By the Book column to Times writers and editors, beginning with Margaret Sullivan, the public editor.

title: Crime, Bias and Statistics
description: Discussions of the relationship between blacks and the criminal justice system in this country too often grind to a halt as people slink down into their silos and arm themselves with their best rhetorical weapons  racial bias on one side and statistics in which minorities, particularly blacks, are overrepresented as criminals on the other.

title: Scots, What the Heck?
description: Next week Scotland will hold a referendum on whether to leave the United Kingdom. And polling suggests that support for independence has surged over the past few months, largely because pro-independence campaigners have managed to reduce the fear factor  that is, concern about the economic risks of going it alone. At this point the outcome looks like a tossup.

title: Ukraine and Russia Face Gaps in a Truce and a Chasm on the Issues
description: MOSCOW  Scattered fighting threatened a shaky cease-fire in eastern Ukraine on Sunday as officials now confront a task even more formidable than maintaining the truce: fashioning some form of decentralized governance in the war-ravaged region that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will accept and that President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine can deliver without turning his country against him.

title: Miners Battle Black Lung, and Bureaucracy
description: Black lung disease, the lethal hazard for coal miners that was thought to be on the wane, is far from finished. Autopsies of 24 miners who died in the Upper Big Branch mine explosion four years ago found that 17 of them had black lung, the crippling respiratory disease that left generations of miners hooked up to oxygen tanks.

title: Giants New Tandem Eager to Prove Itself
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Nine months ago, Eli Manning and Ben McAdoo barely knew each other. On Monday night in Detroit, though, their fates will be joined.

title: Legal Use of Marijuana Clashes With Job Rules
description: DENVER  Brandon Coats knew he was going to fail his drug test. Paralyzed in a car crash when he was 16, he had been using medical marijuana since 2009 to relieve the painful spasms that jolted his body. But he smoked mostly at night, and said marijuana had never hurt his performance answering customer calls for a Colorado satellite-television provider.

title: The Ebb and Flow of Health Spending
description: The latest federal estimates of health care spending offer some good news: The growth rate for spending in 2013 will remain at a low level for the fifth straight year. But the bad news is, spending is expected to rise faster than growth in the economy over the next 10 years.

title: A Fairer Shot for Student Debtors
description: This year, the federal government will pay companies that collect student loan payments about $600 million. Too often, those collectors fail to help millions of borrowers manage their accounts. Worse, some actually drive them deeper into debt.

title: Voter ID on Trial in Texas
description: In April, a federal judge in Wisconsin invalidated that states voter-identification law, finding that it would disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of eligible voters in a phony attempt to prevent a problem  in-person voter fraud  that does not exist.

title: Airlines Take the Bump Out of Turbulence
description: Just a few years ago, airlines got their weather reports by telex. Pilots pored over reams of paper and compared the forecasts with their flight plans. Once airborne, they depended on radio communications and rudimentary radar to avoid bad weather.

title: Despite Sanctions, Cash Keeps Flowing at Playground for Russias Rich
description: FORTE DEI MARMI, Italy  In this seaside resort town that is Italys version of a Russian Riviera, where furs dangle in shop windows in August and beach clubs keep chilled bottles of vodka, a temblor of anxiety unnerved hoteliers and restaurateurs in March. Usually, the phones would ring with Russians booking rooms, villas, even helicopters. But the phones suddenly went quiet.

title: Celebrating Glory, With Little Hope to Add to It
description: Michael Jordan finished his Chicago Bulls career by making a shot that clinched an N.B.A. championship. Jordan did not quit for good right then, but popular mythology freezes him forever as a winner, his final moment unfolding like a dream.

description: On Sunday, Picassos Le Tricorne was removed from the Seagram Building, where it had been on display for 55 years. Moving a canvas that age and size required extreme delicacy.

title: Two Brothers Plus One More Title Equals 100
description: Bob and Mike Bryan capped off a remarkable decade with a century.

title: Political Shift Stalls Efforts to Overhaul Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  By the time Senator Angus King called the White House to warn President Obama against taking executive action to overhaul the immigration system, officials were well aware they had a problem on their hands.

title: The Moon Comes Around Again
description: As the moon wheels around Earth every 28 days and shows us a progressively greater and then stingier slice of its sun-lightened face, the distance between moon and Earth changes, too. At the nearest point along its egg-shaped orbit, its perigee, the moon may be 26,000 miles closer to us than it is at its far point.

title: Tennis World Wobbles as Competitive Axis Begins to Shift
description: It takes a bold soothsayer to proclaim that Mondays mens final at the United States Open between Kei Nishikori of Japan and Marin Cilic of Croatia represents the end of the oligarchical tennis era ruled by the so-called Big 4.

title: Veteran Democrat Faces Hurdles to Re-election
description: PEABODY, Mass.  Representative John F. Tierney, an embattled nine-term Democrat, knows about tough races.

title: Questions of Bracket Biases After a U.S.C. Leaders Outburst
description: Although the game most pregnant with national-title implications over the weekend was Oregons defeat of Michigan State, the 65-pound, gold-and-steel National Championship Trophy sat several hundred miles south on Stanford Stadiums sideline during the Cardinals game against Southern California.

title: After 55 Years in Vaunted Spot, a Picasso Is Persuaded to Curl
description: In the dead of night, a 95-year-old Picasso went under the knife.

title: Mark McNairy New Amsterdam: Spring 2015 RTW
description: NEW YORK

title: New Yorker Festival to Feature Larry David
description: Quintessential New Yorkers lead the lineup for next months New Yorker Festival. The Manhattanites Larry David, Stephen Sondheim and Phil Jackson will appear in conversation with contributors to The New Yorker, organizers announced on Sunday. Mr. David, who is making his Broadway debut in Fish in the Dark  in March, will be paired with the editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick. I think were going to do an in-depth discussion of Palestinian Chicken,  which is maybe the best episode of sitcom TV ever, Mr. Remnick said in a phone interview, referring to a 2011 installment of Curb Your Enthusiasm. The festival, taking place Oct. 10 to 12, will also feature the films Listen Up Philip, directed by Alex Ross Perry, and The Humbling, directed by Barry Levinson; both directors will attend. Musical performers include Randy Newman and Sharon Van Etten. In addition, Edward J. Snowden and Ai Weiwei are scheduled to join via live stream and answer audience questions. More information is available at newyorker.com/festival; tickets go on sale Friday at noon online and at the School of Visual Arts theater box office in Chelsea.

title: Palestinian Leader Assails Hamas, Calling Unity Pact Into Question
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority lambasted his factions longtime rival, Hamas, at a meeting of the Arab League over the weekend, deepening doubts about the durability of their reconciliation pact and potentially complicating reconstruction of the Gaza Strip.

title: Police in Spain Arm Themselves With Social Media to Fight Crime
description: MADRID  When a European arrest warrant was issued recently for Brett and Naghemeh King, who took their cancer-stricken child out of a Hampshire hospital in the south of England without permission, the Spanish police did what has become increasingly common in the search for missing or wanted people: They posted an alert on Twitter.

title: New York Fashion Week: Tim Coppens Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: At Beckham and Altuzarra, Risks Work
description: Sometimes the trickle-down theory works in ways you least expect. President Obamas foreign policy catchphrase, Dont do stupid stuff, for example, may have pundits in a dither over whether it is a cop-out or realpolitik deserving of praise, but for some designers in New York, it is clearly a principle that appears to make a whole lot of sense.

title: Filmmaker Pins Hopes on a Beach Boy
description: TORONTO  The film producer William M. Pohlad has made his name in Hollywood backing award-winning films like 12 Years a Slave and Brokeback Mountain. But he first tried his hand at directing, and his 1990 debut feature, Old Explorers, went virtually unseen, losing money for friends and family.

title: Destroying ISIS May Take Years, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria that may take three years to complete, requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to senior administration officials.

title: Grandmas Meat Loaf? Hardly. Her Retirement Home Now Has a 3-Star Chef.
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  Some of the toughest reservations to get in this affluent suburb of Chicago are for the early tables at the Mather, a senior community of $1 million condominiums near Lake Michigan. Citrus-dressed duck breasts and tomahawk pork chops are on the menu, along with vegetables from a cooperative farm in upstate Wisconsin and house-made gelato.

title: Searching for a Leagues True Scale of Bigotry
description: For the second time since April, the N.B.A. has been rocked by a disclosure from a team owner that the presence of blacks at games negatively affects the bottom line.

description: Lodged in the bowels, or more precisely the great heaving stomach, of the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue on Saturday morning, I really felt for Prabal Gurung, who was showing there.

title: Penelope Niven, Carl Sandburg Biographer, Dies at 75
description: Penelope Niven was a high school English teacher, nearing 40, when she began work on a biography of Carl Sandburg. She had never written a book before. She didnt have a Ph.D. in literature and hadnt even been that familiar with Sandburgs work.

description: DETROIT  After General Motors emerged from bankruptcy and a government bailout five years ago, the board of directors of the new G.M. was expected to keep a more watchful eye on a company that had gone seriously off track.

description: Even on a Friday morning, the Macon branch of the Brooklyn Public Library in Bedford-Stuyvesant was buzzing: Every computer was being used, laptops had been lent out, patrons were asking for rsum advice and more than a few people were reading actual books.

description: LUMBERTON, N.C.  The most memorable moment of the trial that put Henry McCollum and Leon Brown behind bars for three decades for a hideous 1983 rape and murder was a display of brilliant courtroom theatrics.

description: Fusion, the joint online and television venture between Univision and the Disney-ABC Television Group, is expected to announce on Monday that it has hired Tim Pool, a digital journalist known for his use of cutting-edge reporting technologies and his marathon live-stream reporting during the recent controversy in Ferguson, Mo., and the Occupy Wall Street protests.

Mr. Golan, who died last month at the age of 85, and Mr. Globus were cousins who released through the Cannon Group cinematic sex romps like Bolero with Bo Derek, bloody vigilante sequels with Charles Bronson, and the occasional msalliance with respected filmmakers like John Cassavetes and Jean-Luc Godard.

title: Gustavo Cerati, a Star of South Americas Pop Scene, Dies at 55
description: Gustavo Cerati, the Argentine singer-songwriter who led Soda Stereo, one of the most popular and influential Spanish-language rock and pop groups of the 1980s and 90s, died on Thursday in Buenos Aires, four years after he lapsed into a coma. He was 55.

title: Popular Demand
description: Box office is down so far this year compared to 2013, so studios have less to divide. The top three each grossed more than $1 billion, with Sony fourth at $948 million. Guardians of the Galaxy took over No. 1 overall last week, so Disney may pass Fox, which has gone with a tried-and-true strategy: of its top six movies, all were sequels except for The Fault in Our Stars and Mr. Peabody and Sherman, above. Coming this year, several potential blockbusters, including an all-star Exodus: Gods and Kings (Fox), Dumb and Dumber To  (Universal) and Annie (Sony).

title: A Few of Phillip Lims Favorite Fashion Week Things
description: Though Phillip Lim has a reputation for keeping things low-key, this New York Fashion Week is a splashy one for the designer, who opens a new 3.1 Phillip Lim flagship store on September 10 at 48 Great Jones Street in NoHo. The 3,500-square-foot space, designed in collaboration with the London agency Campaign, features vintage furniture and artwork curated by Lim himself. Its look was inspired by Lims design studio, which he calls the only space that I am offered where ideas become realized and my daydreams are romanced into realities. The opening will also celebrate the release of a book showcasing photographs of the store in progress by the artist Bill Jacobson. Here, in honor of New York Fashion Week, the SoHo resident lists a few of his go-to things and places around town.

title: First Moves
description: Timepieces with a mesh band are boyishly understated  and as appealingly retro as a pair of Jordache jeans.

description: The broken window has long had a particular hold on the New York City psyche; at turns an emblem of disrepair and an inspiration for the policing strategy that has helped guide the New York Police Department for more than 20 years.

description: The Welsh actor Michael Sheen, currently starring as the bow-tied sexologist William Masters on Showtimes Masters of Sex, will be stepping into the shoes of a less buttoned down midcentury figure: Dylan Thomas.

description: Harvard University on Monday will announce the largest gift in its history, $350 million to the School of Public Health, from a group controlled by a wealthy Hong Kong family, one member of which earned graduate degrees at the university.

description: Digital video may be most popular with children and young adults, but it increasingly is being embraced by viewers of an older set.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) BEHIND THE CANDELABRA (2013) Michael Douglas, above, in a Golden Globe-winning role, stars as Liberace, and Matt Damon is Scott Thorson, his chauffeur, lover and adopted son, in this film from the director Steven Soderbergh and the screenwriter Richard LaGravenese. Set in Las Vegas; Los Angeles; and Palm Springs, Calif., the film chronicles the mens relationship, as Liberace has Mr. Thorson cosmetically altered in his image and legally adopts him before discarding him for a younger model. Theres something uncanny, even brilliant, about Mr. Douglass impersonation of Liberace, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Sashaying across Las Vegas stages and epic suburban living rooms with a drum majors puffed-up grandeur and a lounge lizards predatory smile, Mr. Douglas gives a performance so assured, so free of camp or cringe, that you quickly surrender any doubts you might have had about his playing a famously flamboyant, closeted-in-plain-sight gay entertainer. Still, a cerebral gloss on, and satire of, a big old Hollywood biopic, Mr. Hale added, the film is full of smart, funny details  perfectly sewn in place, like the rhinestones on one of Mr. Douglass blinding costumes  but its short on heart, or heat.

title: Fashion Squares Off Against Fandom
description: The first few days after Labor Day are always busy in New York, but this was really something. New York Fashion Week. The first Sunday of the N.F.L. season. Serena Williams and Caroline Wozniackis final at the United States Open. The Joan Rivers funeral.

title: Murong Xuecun Says He Is Target of Twitter Smear Campaign
description: Over the past week, links to a series of articles titled The Past and Present Life of Murong Xuecun have been retweeted more than a thousand times by more than a hundred Twitter accounts. The 10-article series portrays Mr. Murong, a prominent author and critic of the Communist Party, as a sexually promiscuous, wife-beating, money-hungry hypocrite.

The buildings were bathed in golden light and crumbling with age. Five stories high, they stood tall on the desolate landscape. They seemed almost human, and very sad.

title: Mitch McConnells Path to Re-election Is Looking More Assured
