description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 8
description: Thursday was the last day of New York Fashion Week, but by far not the weakest. Ralph Lauren started the morning off with a safari-inspired collection that seemed more appropriate for a gala in New York than for the African plains and attracted a front row crowd that included Julianne Moore.

title: Beleaguered Pakistani Capital Inches Back to Normal
description: ISLAMABAD  If there were just one image to evoke the chaos of the protests that have paralyzed this city and brought Prime Minister Nawaz Sharifs government to the brink of collapse over the last month, it would surely be that of a shipping container.

title: Sale in Utah Ends Fears of a Crimp in Tourism
description: DENVER  A bitter fight in Utah over prime skiing terrain and millions of dollars ended Thursday, to the relief of town officials and business owners who feared that the feud could upend wintertime tourism in the mountain idyll of Park City.

title: Imaan Hamman Transforms Backstage at Marc Jacobs
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Imaan Hamman before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars and hair by Guido Palau.

title: Esquire Partners With 3 Agencies to Promote Male Mentorship
description: ESQUIRE magazine is teaming up again with Madison Avenue for a new cause-marketing initiative, seeking to encourage more adult men to mentor boys and young men.

title: Missouri Enacts 72-Hour Wait for Abortion
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Republican-controlled Missouri legislature has enacted one of the most stringent waiting periods for women seeking abortions, overriding a veto by the states Democratic governor, Jay Nixon.

title: Marc Jacobs: Spring 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Noel W. Hinners, Voice for Scientific Research at NASA, Dies at 78
description: Noel W. Hinners, a geologist and soil chemist who helped NASA launch some of its farthest-reaching scientific probes into space  to retrieve moon rocks, map the surface of Mars and peer beyond intergalactic dust to where stars are born  died on Friday in Littleton, Colo. He was 78.

title: Richard Kiel Dies at 74; Played Jaws in Bond Films
description: Richard Kiel, an actor whose intimidating frame and striking features made him a natural choice to play thugs, giants, alien creatures and villains of various stripes  notably Jaws, the assassin with metal dentition in two James Bond films  died on Wednesday in Fresno, Calif. He was 74.

title: If Scotland Goes, Bankers Fear Britain Could Exit European Union
description: LONDON  Tremors over a possible breakup of the United Kingdom have been felt here in recent days, as markets gyrate and banks make contingency plans.

title: Obamas Speech on Terror Draws 34 Million Viewers
description: President Obamas speech on the terror group ISIS attracted an audience of just over 34 million viewers Wednesday night, according to the Nielsen company.

title: New Comic to Anchor Update on S.N.L.
description: The new season of Saturday Night Live will have a significant change in its cast and its most prominent segment, Weekend Update.

title: Bolstering a Vulnerable Russian Neighbor
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagels visit last weekend to Georgia was a reassuring gesture to a former Soviet republic that has assisted the United States in recent conflicts and is increasingly worried about Russias expansionist streak.

title: Past, Present, Prologue at Calvin Klein, Hugo Boss and Proenza Schouler
description: The fact that the final day of the New York collections also happened to be Sept. 11 is the sort of jarring coincidence that portends a collision of worlds: On that day, in this city, a tragedy occurred. Remembering it, how can we sit merrily by and look at skirts? It seems an impossible disconnect.

title: Budget Cuts Reshape New Yorks Public Housing
description: The crushing news came less than a year after Diane Robinson and her 24-year-old son moved into an airy two-bedroom apartment in the Bronx. The city, which helps pay her rent, wrote this summer to say she would have to downsize into a one-bedroom apartment or pay $240 more a month in rent.

title: North Carolina Cuts Prison Time for Probation Violators, and Costs
description: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C.  Andr Duckett, 43, had an unpleasant surprise when he came in to see his probation officer. After missing some previous appointments, he had just failed a drug test, the officer told him, and he was going to spend the next three days in jail.

title: Stressed Borrowers Rattle Resurgent Subprime Lending Industry
description: Subprime lenders have surprised everyone in recent years by churning out billions of dollars in loans that have not led to a pileup of bad debts.

title: After a Two-Year Trek, NASAs Mars Rover Reaches Its Mountain Lab
description: After two years of Mars enthusiasts asking, Are we there yet? the mission managers for NASAs Curiosity rover can finally yell back, Yes, were there!

title: War Sweeps an Israelis Davis Cup Swan Song to Florida
description: Win or lose, it was to be the grandest of goodbyes, and right in the veritable backyard. Tennis players are the most transient of athletes, but for his vocational finish Andy Ram had assembled a guest list of family and friends, swelling to nearly 500.

title: On New York City Beaches, Endless Summer
description: For most New Yorkers, Labor Day marks the end of the beach season, slamming the door shut on summer and shooing the crowds back to work and school.

title: Pesticide Levels in Waterways Have Dropped, Reducing the Risks to Humans
description: The development of safer pesticides and legal restrictions on their use have sharply reduced the risk to humans from pesticide-tainted rivers and streams, while the potential risk to aquatic life in urban waters has risen, according to a two-decade survey published on Thursday.

title: Aid Worker Recovering From Ebola
description: Dr. Rick Sacra, an American aid worker stricken with Ebola in Liberia, is making a remarkable recovery, his wife and doctors said Thursday.

title: The Reluctant Leader
description: Moses, famously, tried to get out of it. When God called on him to lead the Israelites, Moses threw up a flurry of reasons he was the wrong man for the job: Im a nobody; I dont speak well; Im not brave.

title: Father of 5 Slain Children Had Been Investigated
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The authorities in South Carolina conducted two inquiries this year into the behavior of a man suspected of killing his five children and abandoning their bodies in rural Alabama, but neither review led state officials to assume custody of the children.

title: Upon Further Review
description: The National Football League will have a hard time recovering from its cavalier mishandling of the domestic abuse case against Ray Rice, the gridiron star who punched his then-fiance unconscious in February in an elevator in Atlantic City. At first, the league sought to minimize the incident by ordering a mere two-game suspension of the Baltimore Ravens running back, despite a security video excerpt showing him dragging the limp body of Janay Palmer, the woman who is now his wife, from the elevator. A police charge of felony assault followed soon after. As controversy grew, the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, apologized for his misjudgment and promised stronger punishments for players who attack their domestic partners.

title: Legal Authority for Fighting ISIS
description: As the Pentagon gears up to expand its fight against ISIS, a fundamentalist Sunni militant group that controls large areas of Iraq and Syria, Congress appears perfectly willing to abdicate one of its most consequential powers: the authority to declare war.

title: Yura on Madison: A Magnet for School Parents
description: It is back-to-school season, and for many on the Upper East Side, that means it is time to go back to Yura on Madison.

title: Banks Did It Apples Way in Payments by Mobile
description: JPMorgan Chases chief financial officer, Marianne Lake, took the stage at a financial conference on Tuesday under strict orders not to mention her companys involvement in Apples new payment system.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 11, 2014
That Selfie Is So Good, It Could Help You Pay for College
description: WHEN 18-year-old Kiana Neisig added up her expenses for college, she found herself short of funds, even after receiving grants and student loans. So in June, a friend set up a profile for her on a crowdfunding website to help her seek donations of roughly $2,000.

title: Ray Rice Is an Outlier: Most Domestic Abuse Suspects Play On
description: Brett Myers, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, was charged with assaulting his wife on a Boston street in 2006 after witnesses said he struck her in the face and pulled her hair. The Phillies put him on the mound as their starting pitcher about 36 hours later.

title: Amid Tie Tacks, a Ring Worn by an Ancestor Who Was President
description: On the death of a family member, some things may be ridiculous to keep but impossible to throw away. In 2001, an 86-year-old man, retired from a brokerage house, died. His only grandson ended up with a worn leather case filled with the usual mess of things men of his grandfathers generation tossed into jewelry boxes: cuff links, tie tacks, an Eisenhower campaign button and a few other pieces, including a big, worn ring.

title: App Lists Exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
description: Sree Sreenivasan, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts chief digital officer, provides helpful criteria for someone looking to evaluate the museums new app.

title: With Eye on Scotland, Catalonia Hails Its Secession Bid
description: BARCELONA  The worlds attention may be riveted on Scotland and its secessionist drive, but Thursday was Catalonias turn, as hundreds of thousands of flag-waving citizens rallied in the streets in what Catalan leaders hoped would be the prelude to the regions own vote on independence from Spain.

title: Philadelphia Nears Deal to Ease Marijuana Laws
description: People in Philadelphia caught with small amounts of marijuana or smoking it in public may soon face no more than a written citation and a modest fine as the City Council moved Thursday to decriminalize the drug after a reversal by Mayor Michael A. Nutter.

title: Witness for Arab Bank Says Disputed Payments Were Humanitarian
description: The witness talked about Arab Banks policies to guard against money laundering, and its efforts to identify transactions that might be linked to terrorists. He spoke of how Middle East terrorism hurt the banks business, and even how it affected his family.

title: De Blasios Goal to Aid His Agenda: Put New York Senate in Democrats Hands
description: In a windowless conference room in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday morning, Mayor Bill de Blasio laid out his next political battleground: the New York State Senate.

title: Without Glamour of Dream Team, U.S. Is Again Dominating in Barcelona
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The modern-day version of USA Basketball began here 22 years ago, a group of superstar N.B.A. players (as well as Christian Laettner, who was leaving Duke) coming together to form the first Dream Team and bossing its way through the 1992 Olympics.

title: U.S. Pins Hope on Syrian Rebels With Loyalties All Over the Map
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Obamas determination to train Syrian rebels to serve as ground troops against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria leaves the United States dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting, with no shared leadership and with hard-line Islamists as its most effective fighters.

title: Try as He May, John McCain Cant Shake Falsehoods About Ties to ISIS
description: Senator John McCain was one of the earliest advocates of American military action against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. So it has been vexing for Mr. McCain to be battling persistent  and false  Internet rumors that he not only helped invent the group but also knows its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-proclaimed caliph of the Muslim world and Americas latest Public Enemy No. 1.

title: Interview: Jeremy Jordan & Anna Kendrick
description: The stars of the musical The Last Five Years discuss their film.

title: This Weeks Movies | Sept. 12, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review The Drop, The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby and The Skeleton Twins.

title: Desperate Fledglings, Flung From the Nest
description: Just watch these bodies in motion: loping, flying, dancing, vamping and writhing at an altitude known only to the permanently high and perpetually crashing.

title: Queens Music
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Even though this is only Michael Wiesenbergs second puzzle in The New York Times (in case you missed it, you can solve his debut puzzle here), hes an old hand at constructing, which he will tell you more about in his notes below. You can tell that hes done this before, because todays puzzle is chock-full of interesting and unique entries, and very little junk, DEAR READER.

title: Notre Dame and Under Armour Seek Win-Win With Apparel Deal
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Adam Clement, Under Armours creative director for team sports, traveled to Notre Dames Gothic-inspired campus last November after his upstart sports clothing company heard that one of the most valuable college programs might soon be in need of new sponsorship.

title: Former Microsoft Executive and Obama Adviser Joins Venture Firm
description: SEATTLE  Kurt DelBene worked at one of the technology industrys largest companies and helped clean up one of the governments biggest technology messes. Now hes focusing on smaller organizations, joining a venture capital firm to help start-ups.

title: Arabs Give Tepid Support to U.S. Fight Against ISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Many Arab governments grumbled quietly in 2011 as the United States left Iraq, fearful it might fall deeper into chaos or Iranian influence. Now, the United States is back and getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with leading allies like Egypt, Jordan and Turkey all finding ways on Thursday to avoid specific commitments to President Obamas expanded military campaign against Sunni extremists.

title: Former Assemblyman Turned Informer Avoids Prison
description: Nelson L. Castro, a former Democratic state assemblyman from the Bronx who secretly recorded conversations as a government informant, avoided prisonon Thursday, largely because of his cooperation that a judge characterized as by all accounts extraordinarily valuable, and indeed historic.

title: Bunny Mellons Keen Eye Is a Boon to Sothebys
description: UPPERVILLE, Va.  Few people have ever visited Oak Spring Farms, the grand home here of Rachel Lambert Mellon, better known as Bunny. If they had, they would have seen a Pissarro, unframed like a flea market find, above the living room fireplace. Upstairs, a still life by van Gogh hung above her bathtub. Antique porcelains  cabbages, asparagus, artichokes  were artfully arranged on practically every surface.

title: Runners Take the Place of Models During Fashion Week
description: The models at the Oiselle fashion show in New York this week were the first to admit it: They were more at home on a running track than on a runway.

title: Waiting on the Wind
description: On a late August afternoon, an adventurous group gathered on the second floor of a wind-battered former seaplane factory, eager to fly. They wiggled into their wet suits, tethered themselves to harnesses and inspected their winglike kites. There was only one thing left to do: wait for the wind.

title: Data for a New York Smellmap, Collected Sniff by Sniff
description: If smell can define a place, New York in the summertime is not exactly a meadow of flowers. In the war between a sensitive nose and the city streets, the streets have the upper hand, assailing the nose with the odors of urine, decomposing garbage and clammy armpits. Mouth breathing is not only acceptable, but often necessary.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Leaders Ray Rice Inquiry Poses Risk
description: CBS altered its planned opening for the first night of its coverage ofThursdayNight Football to cover the Ray Rice story.

title: Doctor Present at Joan Riverss Procedure Wasnt Authorized at Clinic
description: An ear, nose and throat specialist was present in the clinic operating room where Joan Rivers underwent a procedure last month  and where she went into cardiac arrest  even though the doctor was not authorized to practice medicine in the clinic, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Nationals Help Turn Mets Thoughts to Next Year
description: Across from the Mets dugout, high above Citi Field, hangs the out-of-town scoreboard, an array of boxes, tiny baseball diamonds, and lights. Between innings, Manager Terry Collins often glances up at it. He likes to keep track of the Mets next opponent, in particular, to see who is pitching and if the teams bullpen is spent.

title: Retired Gen. John R. Allen in Line to Lead Effort vs. ISIS
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  John R. Allen, the retired Marine general who served as the top American commander in Afghanistan, has been picked by the Obama administration to coordinate the international effort against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a senior administration official said Thursday.

title: $290 Million Lost in Penny Stock Fraud, Prosecutors Say
description: Investors would hear about the companies through newsletters emailed from websites that tout penny stocks, with names like PennyPic.com, OxofWallStreet.com and MonsterStox.com, their missives full of hyperbolic language and exclamation points.

title: Yankees Hits Are Few, but Ex-Met Has a Big One
description: If the Yankees somehow reach the postseason, they may look back on Thursday night as the turning point in their difficult quest.

title: FedEx Cup Leaders Share First Place in Tour Championship
description: ATLANTA  Tiger and Phil are absent. One-third of the field are first-timers at the Tour Championship. Conditions seemed ripe for some capricious results in the closeout event of the PGA Tour season.

title: Takata Air Bag Defect: Relevant Documents
description: Regulatory documents from a 2009 federal investigation into Takata air bag ruptures.

title: Under Pressure From Fans, Giants Count on Eli Manning to Find His Feet
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  With Eli Manning struggling so far to acclimate to the Giants West Coast offense, the new offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo, was asked Thursday if perhaps Mannings skills were not suited to the new style of play.

title: Air Bag Flaw, Long Known to Honda and Takata, Led to Recalls
description: An air bag exploded in a Honda Accord in 2004 in Alabama, shooting out metal fragments and injuring the cars driver. At a loss to explain the incident, Honda and its Japanese air bag supplier deemed it an anomaly and did not issue a recall or seek the involvement of federal safety regulators.

title: T.J. Lane, Killer in School Shooting, Is Caught After Prison Escape in Ohio
description: A 19-year-old Ohio man serving life in prison for killing three students in a high school cafeteria in 2012 briefly escaped from prison on Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Jack OConnell: Lust for Life
description: The actor is raw, uncensored and trying to keep it together long enough to live up to Hollywoods expectations.

title: The Personal Arcadia of John Richardson
description: Like the art historian himself, his Connecticut estate is grand, refined and a bit naughty.

title: Art Basel Lends a Hand to Arts Crowdfunding Efforts
description: One of the worlds most prominent art fairs is hoping to garner support for nonprofit art organizations by lending them some street cred.

title: Word of the Day | vivacious
description: vivacious \v-va-shs also vi-\ adjective

title: Notre Dames New Look
description: In its deal with Under Armour, a tradition-rich university is updating its team uniforms while keeping its treasured symbols.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) JAMES McNEILL WHISTLER AND THE CASE FOR BEAUTY Kevin Kline lends his voice to Whistler (1834-1903), above, and Anjelica Huston narrates this documentary on the life of the American-born, London-based visionary and dandy who helped steer painting toward abstraction and what eventually became known as Modern art. Nearly 200 etchings, paintings and photographs provide an overview of Whistlers art while shedding light on the reasons for his controversial reputation. Animations and re-enactments explore the creations of several of his most famous paintings  among them, Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1, popularly known as Whistlers Mother, as well as The White Girl, The Balcony and The Peacock Room. The film, directed by Karen Thomas, coincides with Whistler exhibitions at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington and at museums in Japan. In Royal Paintbox, at 10, Charles, Prince of Wales, presents drawings, watercolors and oil paintings created by generations of Britains royal family  including some of his own  set against the estates of Balmoral Castle, Birkhall, Highgrove House, Windsor Castle, Frogmore House and Osborne House.

title: What Might Happen If Iran Becomes Americas Covert Ally?
description: In his speech to the nation Wednesday night, President Obama authorized strikes against ISIS, the militant group ravaging Syria and Iraq. The United States and its allies, the President said, will aim to degrade and ultimately destroy the group.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 12, 2014
description: The other leagues had better be paying attention. They need to demonstrate to society that there is zero tolerance against domestic violence.

title: Corrections: September 12, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Conversation With Peter Thiel
description: Even for a self-made billionaire, Peter Thiel has strong opinions.

title: A Trial Concludes, but for South Africans, the Debate May Be Just Starting
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  The murder trial of the Paralympic star Oscar Pistorius lurched to a close on Friday when he was convicted of culpable homicide in the shooting death last year of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp. But in a case that reflected South Africas complicated obsession with race, crime and celebrity, many South Africans found understanding the verdict to be as difficult as trying to fathom exactly what was in Mr. Pistoriuss mind the night he pulled the trigger.

title: China Expands Investment in Tanzania
description: Next to the busy port of Dar es Salaam, the business capital of Tanzania, work is starting on a Chinese-financed, 150-acre logistics hub that will contribute to the already booming trade between China and Africa.

title: Test Yourself | The Mystery and Familiarity of Stonehenge
description: Below are six paragraphs from the Sept. 9 article Among the Ancient Stones, Magic as Potent as Ever.

title: Chinese Dissidents Trial Is Cut Short After Lawyers Refuse to Attend
description: HONG KONG  The trial of one of southern Chinas most prominent dissidents was cut short Friday after he and another defendant said they would remain silent and their lawyers boycotted the proceedings. The lawyers said the trial was postponed and would resume at a later date.

title: Virgin Money Names Chairman as It Contemplates an I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Virgin Money, the British financial services company partly owned by the billionaire Richard Branson, has named Glen R. Moreno, the chairman of the publishing firm Pearson, as its chairman.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Obama, in Speech on ISIS, Promises Sustained Effort to Rout Militants
description: In the article Obama, in Speech on ISIS, Promises Sustained Effort to Rout Militants, Mark Landler reports on President Obamas address to the nation.

title: Paul Ryan: I Call This Getting Wienermobiled
description: The congressman talks to Jim Rutenberg about summer jobs, the government shutdown and his next chapter.

title: Is Breakfast Really the Most Important Meal of the Day?
description: Perhaps you sit down to a balanced meal of eggs, bacon and sliced fruit before school. Or a bowl of cereal with a banana. A Greek yogurt. A frozen waffle. A doughnut. Breakfast-to-go from a local fast-food joint. Or maybe you just skip it all together. How do you eat breakfast?

title: In Iran, Mothers Dream of Missing Sons
description: Fatemeh Behboudi grew up surrounded by grief. She was born in Tehran during the 1980-88 war between Iran and Iraq. As the bodies of missing soldiers were discovered years after the war, her family attended mass funerals in their honor. Later, she covered these rites as a photographer.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 12
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images outside Joan Riverss memorial service and scenes from the primary election.

title: The Lady Reappears
description: PARIS  A small portrait of Anne Sinclair as a blue-eyed little girl hangs in her impressive townhouse on the Place des Vosges here. Nearby, theres a late Picasso watercolor of a figure in a wide-brimmed black hat. A replica of a Picasso still life  the original is in a vault  has pride of place above the living-room fireplace.

title: Australia Raises Terrorism Alert Level to High
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Tony Abbott raised Australias terrorism alert level from medium to high on Friday, after warnings from security officials that a growing number of Australians joining extremist groups, including the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, represents an increased threat to the country.

title: NATOs Hopes for Russia Have Turned to Dismay
description: LONDON  The NATO summit meeting last week in Wales was dominated by Russias military intervention in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea.

title: Barclays Names John McFarlane as Next Chairman
description: LONDON  Barclays said on Friday that John McFarlane, the chairman of the British insurer Aviva, would succeed David Walker, its chairman, who is set to retire next year.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Last Chances for Art
description: Good morning on this practically chilly Friday.

title: Google to Give Start-Ups $100,000 in Cloud Computing Credits
description: Google would like to make more money selling data storage on other services on its Google Cloud Platform, and its going after it the old-fashioned Internet way: Give stuff away and make it up on volume.

title: Week 2 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Dolphins (1-0) at Bills (1-0)

title: U.S. and European Sanctions Take Aim at Putins Economic Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and the European Union dealt a blow on Friday to Russian efforts to develop future oil sources in the Arctic and elsewhere, broadening and deepening the range of sanctions imposed on Moscow in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine despite the potential cost to Western firms like Exxon Mobil and BP.

title: NYTLNreads | Recommendations From a Humanities Class at High Technology High School
description: This week we announced an experiment were calling NYTLNreads. We hope it will be a quick, informal way for your students to explore The Times and share the stories that interested them most.

title: Ebola Outpaces Global Response, W.H.O. Says
description: GENEVA  A month after declaring the Ebola outbreak in West Africa a global health emergency, the World Health Organization warned on Friday that the disease is still outpacing the international response to contain it.

title: Thieves Follow the Money to Corrupt Officials Homes
description: The mid-20th century American outlaw Willie Sutton is often cited as saying that he robbed banks because thats where the money is. Some thieves in China have gone after corrupt cadres for the same reason.

title: The Fadeout of the Mileage Run
description: In February, a friend told me he couldnt meet for dinner in Washington because he was flying to Amsterdam for the weekend. Emphasis on the word flying. His itinerary had him spending most of the weekend traveling, but hed stay in Amsterdam for only 14 hours, after connecting through Paris and Istanbul to get there; his return trip involved a layover in Minneapolis.

title: Daily Report: Government Threatened Steep Fines in Push for Yahoo Data
description: The federal government was so determined to collect the Internet communications of foreign Yahoo customers in 2008 that it threatened the company with fines of $250,000 a day if it did not immediately comply with a secret court order to turn over the data, Vindu Goel and Charlie Savage report.

title: 1939: Radio Station Charged
description: WASHINGTON  Charging that New York radio station WMCA has been intercepting secret government military messages from London and Berlin and rebroadcasting them as news, the Federal Communications Commission demanded today [Sept. 12] that the station show cause why its license should not be suspended. The investigation is the first case in which the commission has used its authority to deal with an offender under the terms of the neutrality act. Meanwhile, after an all-day session, representatives of the three major American broadcasting chains announced that they had agreed to present war news broadcasts so as to avoid undue horror and suspense and will try to be temperate, responsible and mature in selecting material and the manner in which the facts are made public. As far as possible, the chains said they would attempt to have the European broadcast conducted by Americans to insure the greatest degree of impartiality.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 13, 1939

title: Morning Agenda: Banks Bow to Apple Pay
description: BANKS BOW TO APPLE PAY | As Apple looks to assume a more central role in the financial universe with its new payment system, Apple Pay, the eagerness of banks and credit card companies to work with the technology giant underscores both its influence and the recognition among financial institutions that they face bigger challenges from upstart technology ventures, DealBooks Nathaniel Popper writes. Apple Pay could threaten some revenue streams, but the banking industry appears willing to invest in programs like Apples that still respect the traditional financial system.

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
Battle for Club Med Heats Up as Chinese and French Investors Increase Bid
description: PARIS  The battle for Club Mditerrane took a sharp last-minute turn on Friday when the Chinese and French investors who had originally sought to buy the vacation resort operator came back with an improved counteroffer just before the deadline for action.

title: Scotlands Pick-Me-Up
description: Independence makes for a stiff drink.

title: Germany Bans Support for ISIS
description: BERLIN  Germany on Friday announced a ban on activities that support the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, including any displays of its black flag, as part of an effort to suppress the extremist groups propaganda and recruitment work among Germans.

title: New York Vs. London: Which City Wins the Fashion Buzz Wars?
description: As the fashion flock moves to London and Part Two of the fashion marathon, competition is heating up between the two cities for the new-ish accolade Top Fashion Buzzword for 2014.

title: Making Top Colleges Less Aristocratic and More Meritocratic
description: Education is supposed to be Americas primary engine for social mobility, but growing economic inequality is vividly reflected in our nations top colleges. At the nations most selective 193 colleges and universities, affluent students (those from the richest socioeconomic quarter of the population) outnumber economically disadvantaged students (those from the bottom quarter) by 14 to 1.

title: Student Loan Debt Burdens More Than Just Young People
description: JANET LEE DUPREE, 72, was surprised when she received her first Social Security benefits seven years ago. About one-fifth of her monthly payment was being withheld and she called the federal government to find out why.

title: As Investors Salivate, Alibaba May Raise Price of I.P.O.
description: The Alibaba Groups initial public offering was long expected to be a blockbuster. But a flood of orders for shares in the Chinese e-commerce giant has proved stronger than expected.

title: 2 Navy Fighter Jets Crash Into Pacific
description: WASHINGTON  Two Navy fighter jets crashed into the Pacific Ocean on Thursday evening, according to the Defense Department.

title: Foreign Journalists in China See Decline in Reporting Conditions
description: Conditions for foreign journalists working in China have gone from bad to worse over the past year, with the Chinese authorities increasingly seeking to influence coverage by intimidating reporters and their interview subjects, barring journalists from large portions of the country or by withholding visas and blocking the websites of overseas news outlets, according to a report issued on Friday by the Foreign Correspondents Club of China.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: On Set | Jack OConnell
description: Photographer Bruce Weber films actor Jack OConnell on the set of Ts Fall Mens issue cover shoot.

title: Mexican Rights Groups File Suit for Systematic and Widespread Abuse by Army and Police
description: Several Mexican human rights groups said on Friday that they had filed a complaint with the office of the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, asking it to investigate the systematic and widespread abuse of thousands of civilians by the army and the police in their fight against organized crime.

title: Congress Responds to the President
description: On Capitol Hill on Thursday, the immediate response to President Obamas address was a rare show of bipartisan support for military action against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Ian Paisley Dies at 88; Longtime Voice of Hard-Line Ulster Who Then Made Peace
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, Northern Irelands firebrand Protestant leader, who vowed never to compromise with Irish Catholic nationalists, then, in his twilight, accepted a power-sharing agreement that envisioned a new era of peace in Northern Ireland after decades of sectarian violence, died on Friday in Belfast. He was 88.

title: Autumn in New York, 2001
description: Dear Diary:

title: Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide
description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa declared that Oscar Pistorius, the Olympic runner, is guilty of culpable homicide, equivalent to manslaughter, after being acquitted of murder.

title: The Man Who Put the K in Kops
description: Mack Sennett (1880-1960) is famous for discovering Charlie Chaplin, creating the Keystone Kops, coining the term bathing beauty and being, as his front-page obituary in The New York Times called him, the film pioneer whose name was synonymous with slapstick comedy. All true, but as demonstrated by the 50 mainly short films digitally restored and gathered in a three-disc Blu-ray set, The Mack Sennett Collection Volume One (Flicker Alley), he was something more.

title: When One Word Might Be the Wrong Word
description: Sometimes, as I read The Times, a word will stop me cold. That happened yesterdaymorning as I read the photo caption on a timely Room for Debate about the videotaped assault by Ray Rice on his wife, Janay Palmer, that has been so much in the news. The word: altercation.

title: Bright Green Pesto That Wont Fade
description: This is not the first time that Ive devoted a week of recipes to pesto genovese  basil pesto. But it is the first time that I can vouch for a basil pesto that retains a gorgeous green color. Ive been forever flummoxed by the color problem with pesto, the way it goes from bright green to olive drab so quickly. Ive tried this and that  been told about citric acid, covering the pesto with olive oil, or even lemon juice (which makes little sense to me because acid usually turns bright green olive). Anyway, I read up on the problem this week and decided to try blanching the leaves.

title: Writing as a Soldier and a Civilian
description: It is 12 a.m. in the land of the midnight sun. Seventy-two hours until deployment. I should be at home with my wife, Jen, and 6-month-old son or unpacking the house we bought recently. Instead, Im on my bike riding home from the University of Alaska, Anchorage. A rowdy group rides down another trail that merges with mine, cycling in a pack in front of me. They laugh, pull beers from messenger bags, see me and offer me one. The exchange is tour-worthy. An anonymous rider pulls out a cold Olympia and reaches toward me. His eyes remain on the trail ahead, as do mine. I extend a blind left hand, close the gap, find the front of the can. For a moment we are connected by cheap beer. Then he lets go and it is all mine. I toast the rowdies and ride ahead.

title: Toronto Festival 2014: Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan on The Last Five Years
description: TORONTO  A couple sings its way through the exciting beginning and the difficult unraveling of a relationship in The Last Five Years, Richard LaGraveneses film adaptation of Jason Robert Browns Off-Broadway musical. In this video, Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan their roles, and their songs, in the film.

title: Maastricht in a Kilt
description: Simon Wren-Lewis says more clearly what Ive been trying to get at with regard to the economics of Scottish independence. It would be one thing to make the sober case that independence is worth it despite the economic costs and risks; but the SNP has been claiming that there are no costs and risks, which is just wrong.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: New York Commemorates a Somber Date
description: The city paused to honor the dead and pay tribute to the first responders on the 13th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Good News for Fair-Weather Fans
description: Also, what Tony Soprano and Hello Kitty have in common; emojis, assessed.

title: Reply All: The 8.31.14 Issue
description: THE DAWN OF THE POST-CLINIC ABORTION

title: Why Everyone Should Be Waiting for Grimess Next Album
description: Earlier this year, Claire Boucher, the 26-year-old Canadian musician known as Grimes, briefly dabbled in the world of Billboard-chart pop. She wrote a song for Rihanna. After that, she went to a group songwriting boot camp, as she entertained the idea of receding from the intensifying spotlight shed earned as an electro-pop phenom. I thought, Oh, I dont want to be a front person, she says. I want to write.

title: Viola Davis as Youve Never Seen Her Before: Leading Lady!
description: Even when I get the fried-chicken special of the day, I have to dig into it like its filet mignon, Viola Davis said. She was speaking not of meals, but of roles. During her 30-year career as an actress, Davis has played a crack-addicted mother (Antwone Fisher), the mother of an abducted child (Prisoners) and the mother of James Brown (Get On Up). Her characters often serve to hold up the wall of the narrative, she said, like the empathetic best friend in Eat, Pray, Love or the kindly stranger in Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close. Or the kindly mental-institution psychiatrist in Its Kind of a Funny Story, the kindly rape-treatment counselor in Trust or the kindly medium in Beautiful Creatures.

title: Hood by Airs Collective Fashions
description: Shayne Oliver began the clothing line Hood by Air in late 2006 with almost no formal training. He and his collaborators  assembled largely from the downtown night life circuit  communicated their visions to fabricators via visual aid. Wed go around with huge bags of clothes that had details we liked: This stitch needs to look like this stitch,  Oliver says, because we didnt know the technical terms. Some ideas were hard to convey: At one point, we wanted to make men look like schoolgirls, and we were explaining a piece to a seamstress. Its a schoolgirl basketball short. She was like, That makes no sense. So we got a schoolgirl skirt and made a new pattern out of it, to show her it was feasible.

title: Paying for a Need for Speed
description: A friend and I spent the weekend camping. On Monday morning, we were late getting on the road. I was going to be late for a summer course and asked my friend to hurry. At some point, I noticed that we were traveling at 130 m.p.h. I did not say anything because I wanted to make it back to class. Shortly after, we were stopped for speeding. My friend thinks I should help pay for the $500 ticket. I did not tell him to drive 130 m.p.h. Do I have an obligation to help with this ticket? NAME WITHHELD, HOUSTON

title: Quvenzhan Walliss Secrets: Work Hard, Play Hard, Think About Polar Bears
description: Quvenzhan Walliss career started with a little fib: that she was 6 years old. It was the minimum age to audition for the lead role in Beasts of the Southern Wild, and she was just shy. It worked. She landed the part and shot the movie in a soup-swampy Louisiana bayou town called Montegut, a short drive from her familys home. A lesser child actor might have evaporated into the films momentous plot, but Wallis  with her watchful gaze, physical grace and talent for banshee-level shrieking  suffered no such fate, becoming the youngest person ever nominated for an Academy Award for best actress. Now 11 and in the sixth grade, she has built up a tiny but luminous list of credits that includes 12 Years a Slave and a remake of Annie due out this December, in which she plays the title character.

title: Who Made That Windshield Wiper?
description: In the winter of 1902, an Alabama woman named Mary Anderson visited New York and was appalled by how the weather slowed down streetcars. Snow and sleet obscured the trolleys two-paneled windshields, forcing drivers to open both panes and peer through the gap between them. In her notebook, Anderson sketched out a solution: a squeegee wiper on the outside of the windshield, connected to a lever on the inside.

title: How Trajal Harrell Mixes His Moves
description: When the dancer and choreographer Trajal Harrell is working on new ideas, he likes to arrange his performers across islands  foot-and-a-half-high platforms padded with foam rubber. I spread the islands out in different configurations, and the dancers improvise on them, Harrell says. All of a sudden the body is on a small white space. I can see very clearly what each dancer is doing. Its a way to sketch. Its an information generator. Last month, Harrell, who divides his year between the United States and Europe, drifted amid islands in a Berlin rehearsal space. He gave the dancers directions that ranged from the blunt  stop doing that  to the fanciful  move with the smell of fashion. This session was practice for Practice, a not-quite-performance that Harrell was preparing to give in New York at the Museum of Modern Art, in which he would invite spectators to spy on his creative methods. Its a nightmare in many ways, he says, because Im very private about my process.

title: The Family That Strays Together
description: It was 75 degrees out and sunny. My sister-in-law decided that the afternoon was perfect for a hike, so my mother consulted her woefully outdated Appalachian Mountain Club guide, which she treats with a reverence that others reserve for the Bible; to her, revelations are contained in its pages.

title: Living Art
description: Performers at Pageant of the Masters, an annual festival in Laguna Beach, re-enact Vermeers The Allegory of Painting and The Concert.

title: The Surreal Fine-Art Spectacle in Laguna Beach
description: Paparazzi, if they had existed in 1880s France, would have followed Amlie Gautreau in a permanent cloud. Crowds gathered when she appeared in the streets of Paris. Newspapers reported her outfit changes. Royalty asked to meet her. Traditional beauty is rarely so exciting, but hers was unorthodox: She had a long neck, a big nose and skin so uncannily white that people argued over whether it was real or fake. Theories included that she covered her entire body with makeup or strategically dosed herself with arsenic. In an era of puffy, body-swallowing gowns, she wore snug dresses that showed off her curves; she put red makeup on the tips of her ears, just for extra drama. She was rumored to be sleeping with half the men in Paris. Every painter wanted to paint her, to be the great hero who fixed her image for a culture desperate to stare at it. But art  the translation of three-dimensional life into a flat, static illusion  was an act of magic with serious consequences. In a time before mass-produced cameras, an image was a heavy thing, laborious to make and hard to distribute. Instagram was Duragram. Amlie always refused.

title: A Life-Saving Salt Binge
description: Decoding a young mans exhaustion and mysterious craving for sodium.

title: Referendum in Scotland, Dissected by Investor
description: Growing up with the name James Stewart, I never thought of Scotland as anything but independent.

title: David Lynch on His First Retrospective of Original Artwork
description: Although hes best-known for his middle-America-meets-the-macabre movies, David Lynch started out as a painter and has not put down his brushes in 40-something years. Not surprisingly, the director known for his darkly visceral vision creates canvases that are anything but pretty pictures.

title: China Court Sentences 3 to Death Over Attack at Railroad Station
description: HONG KONG  A court in southwest China on Friday sentenced three people to death and another to life in prison after finding them guilty of killing 31 people in a slashing rampage at a railroad station in early March, the official news media reported.

title: Hispanic-Americans Work to Bolster Philanthropy at Home
description: ALBERTO BEECK is having what would be considered a solid year for any businessman-philanthropist. In February, Mr. Beeck, who was born in Peru and fled to the United States after his countrys 1968 military coup, and his Cuban-born wife, Olga Maria, gave Georgetown University $10 million to start the Beeck Center for Social Impact and Innovation.

title: What the Numbers Show About N.F.L. Player Arrests
description: Off-the-field violence by professional football players is coming under new focus this week after the release of a video involving the star Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice, followed by a bungled response by the National Football League.

title: Marc Jacobs: A Slower Pace
description: And so the first leg of the four-week marathon that is fashion month (lets be honest here) came to an end  with a thought: Theres been so much going on. Can we move the house to a place where nothing ever happens and things are slower? Ill be happy there.

title: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: U.S. Retail Sales Gain Slightly
description: Anyone who waited to buy school supplies in a snaking checkout line at Staples last month may not be surprised that on Friday the Commerce Department reported a healthy 0.6 percent increase in retail sales for August.

title: Kutiman Returns With More YouTube Sampling Madness
description: For Ophir Kutiel, a stylistically omnivorous musician and producer based in Tel Aviv, conventional sampling  taking a musical fragment from an existing recording to help build a new one  is kids stuff. Mr. Kutiel, who performs and records under the name Kutiman, has transformed sampling into a multimedia art, building his songs from bits of YouTube clips  the video as well as the audio  with amateur and instructional videos as his favored sources. He plans to post ThruYOU Too, his second collection of these pieces, on his YouTube page on Oct. 1. In the meantime, he is posting one song, Give It Up today as a teaser.

title: Elderly New Yorkers, Here for the Duration
description: Chuck and Cindy Nemser have lived in a townhouse in Park Slope for 47 years. Until she began suffering from unexplained nerve pain a few years ago, Ms. Nemser, 77, an art historian and writer, would happily retreat to her third-floor office where she could work undisturbed. Theres plenty of wall space for the couples art collection, and ample storage for Mr. Nemsers cache of fishing poles.

title: A Rebound Takes Root in Michigan, but Voters Gloom Is Hard to Shake
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  Another blustery Midwestern winter approaches, but along a blue-collar stretch of Leonard Street in this conservative, famously button-down city, an economic springtime has arrived.

title: Let Us Help You, Hedge Funds Tell Puerto Rico
description: Forget, just for a moment, depictions of sharp-elbowed hedge funds, seizing Navy ships from deadbeat nations or pushing for federal investigations into the companies they are betting against.

title: 10 Militants Held in Shooting of Malala Yousafzai, Girls Education Advocate, Pakistan Says
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Ten militants have been taken into custody in connection with the 2012 shooting of Malala Yousafzai, a teenager who defied the Taliban with her outspoken calls for girls education, a spokesman for the Pakistani military said Friday.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: airline seats, averting diabetes and sleeping for productivity.

title: Queens Library Leader on Leave as Inquiry Goes On
description: As federal and city officials continue their investigation into spending at the Queens Public Library, the librarys board of trustees has placed its embattled leader on paid administrative leave.

title: Massachusetts Town Shudders After Discovery of Dead Infants
description: When officers responded to a report of a crying, possibly neglected child at a modest house a block from police headquarters in Blackstone, Mass., they unwittingly uncovered a situation so horrifying that the police chief on Friday said it had tested the entire town.

title: Today in Small Business: Dying Malls
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Bushwick Takes the Spotlight
description: The appearance of a scantily clad, twerking Miley Cyrus at a recent party in Bushwick, Brooklyn, may be stealing headlines, but the arrival of new-construction condominium developments for the first time since the 2008 real estate crisis has also attracted attention.

title: How Women Talk About Clothes
description: Whos wearing a hand-me-down? Leanne Shapton, one of the editors of the new book Women in Clothes, asked a largely female audience at a recent celebration for the book at powerHouse Arena, a bookstore and event space in Dumbo, Brooklyn. Numerous hands shot up in the air.

title: No Comment Necessary: The Saudi Arabia-Syria Border?
description: A White House official said on a Wednesday conference call that he was confident many countries would join a broader coalition through a range of actions to fight ISIS. He noted that governments in the region view ISIS as an existential threat and that Saudi Arabia has an extensive border with Syria.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Henry Kissingers World Order
description: This week, Henry Kissinger discusses World Order; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Lawrence Wright talks about Thirteen Days in September; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Henry Kissingers World Order
description: This week, Henry Kissinger and Lawrence Wright.

title: Talking Bare Faces, 70s Supermodels and Macarons with Francois Nars at Marc Jacobs
description: Last night, the Marc Jacobs spring/summer 2015 show officially closed the curtain on New York Fashion Week. Backstage beforehand, the mood was decidedly mellow, as if everyone was relieved at having reached the final mile of a marathon. Classical music played, photographers casually milled about and the model Edie Campbell even chilled in a chair doing a crossword puzzle.

title: Paperback Row
description: BLEEDING EDGE,  by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin, $17.) The horror of Sept. 11 looms over Pynchons novel of New York in the vortex of the dot-com boom. When Maxine Tarnow, a fraud investigator pinballing between work and family, starts looking into a computer-security firm and its corrupt chief executive, she finds herself mixed up with an array of hackers, drug runners and entrepreneurs, some of whom begin turning up dead. Our reviewer, Jonathan Lethem, called this shaggy-dog conspiracy tale dazzling and ludicrous.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE DOG,  by Joseph ONeill. (Pantheon, $25.95.) In ONeills disturbing, elegant novel, his first since Netherland, a lost and tormented New York lawyer recognizes more darkness within himself than in the iniquitous place he works, Dubai.

title: Inside the List
description: Unsolved Mysteries: Do women write the best crime novels? Thats the thesis of a recent essay in Salon by the critic Laura Miller, who argues that mysteries by men have grown sclerotic and predictable  locked into a hard-boiled formula little changed since the days of Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett. Meanwhile (Miller continues), women are mixing their crime stories with other genres, mining the emotional terrains of home and family to advance a field the editor Sarah Weinman calls domestic suspense. One novel that features prominently in Millers analysis is The Secret Place, by Tana French, which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. A thin vein of the uncanny runs through most of Frenchs novels, Miller notes: mysteries that go unsolved, premises that flirt with impossibility, paranormal occurrences that may or may not be imagined. I dont know if Miller is right about men and women; who is? But shes not wrong about French, whose books really do cultivate an appealing lack of resolution  at least in part, no doubt, because she jumps in without a plan. When I start writing, I have the narrator, the basic premise and a load of coffee, French told The Sunday Times of London in 2008. I dont even know whodunit.  Not that she would let uncertainty keep her from a genre she loves. Crime fiction is one of the best barometers of whats going on at any different moment, she added. Its about societys highest priorities and deepest fears.

title: Book Review Podcast: Henry Kissingers World Order
description: In The New York Times Book Review, John Micklethwait reviews Henry Kissingers World Order. Mr. Micklethwait writes:

title: Letters: Fabulist Tradition
description: Fabulist Tradition

title: The Sound of the Words
description: Since the early 1990s, John Darnielle has moved from cult favorite to mainstream success with his indie-rock band the Mountain Goats. (During its early years, the band was just Darnielle.) The New Yorker has called him Americas best non-hip-hop lyricist, and fans once petitioned the government to name him United States poet laureate.

title: Poetry
description: WOLF CENTOS  By Simone Muench  Sarabande, paper, $14.95.

title: True Detective
description: Nobody would dispute the fact that Hercule Poirot, the elegant Belgian detective, he of the patent-leather shoes and the waxed mustache, is dead. Agatha Christie brought him to an end in her appropriately named novel, Curtain: Poirots Last Case, and The New York Times itself marked his death with a fictional obituary. But the demise of the hero, and of the author, no longer needs to be the end of the story. The literary executors of James Bonds creator, Ian Fleming, have held this view for some years, and there seems to be no end to the publics enthusiasm for rewritten versions of a whole host of literary favorites.

title: The Bodys Temple
description: When Anne Darwin died just after her 10th birthday in 1851, her father lost the joy of the Household. No longer could he see as plainly as others do, and as I should wish to do, evidence of design and beneficence on all sides of us. There seems to me too much misery in the world. Charles Darwins faith was gone; he began writing On the Origin of Species. As Ian McEwan has told interviewers, rather like Darwin when his favorite daughter died, on Sept. 11 he felt, more than ever, that there was no God, and that religion was distinctly unhelpful in making compassionate, reasonable judgments about peoples lives. On the whole, the secular mind seems far superior in making reasonable judgments. In McEwans early novels, intelligent characters had often slithered along the axis of belief and unbelief, just as he had. Not anymore. Atheism and the secular state are under attack, and he must defend them.

title: Facts, Lies and Artifacts
description: The 19th century was the Golden Age of Collectors. Or, depending on your perspective, the Gilded Age of Plunderers. From Lord Elgins marbles to Alfred Russel Wallaces tropical fauna (over 80,000 beetles!) to Edward Drinker Copes dinosaur bones to Charles Frederick Newcombes Northwest Coast totem poles, it was the unquestioned privilege of the enlightened world to amass the specimens and relics of the dark one, and to study, paint or display them in cabinets and museums  or sell them. The nadir of this frenzy may have occurred when Robert Peary brought six Inuits from Greenland to New York to be housed at the American Museum of Natural History, an event that most likely inspired Andrea Barretts novel The Voyage of the Narwhal.

title: Southern Exposure
description: Tony Earleys elegiac new collection, Mr. Tall, begins in playful rhyme, with a couple named Darryl and Cheryl from Argyle, N.C. It ends some 240 pages later with a plea: For Gods sake, dont close this book.

title: Mission Almost Impossible
description: It was June 2010, and American intelligence agencies were desperate to track down Anwar al-Awlaki, the American cleric who had joined Al Qaeda and was believed to be plotting from the wilds of Yemen. But Awlaki had other things on his mind. From his hide-out, he sent an encrypted email to Morten Storm to thank him for dispatching to Yemen the Croatian convert to Islam who had become his third wife. She had turned out to be even better than I expected and better than you described, Awlaki wrote, adding a lascivious smiley face.

title: Shakespeare for Survivors
description: Emily St. John Mandels fourth novel, Station Eleven, begins with a spectacular end. One night, in a Toronto theater, onstage performing the role of King Lear, 51-year-old Arthur Leander has a fatal heart attack. There is barely time for people to absorb this shock when tragedy on a considerably vaster scale arrives in the form of a flu pandemic so lethal that, within weeks, most of the worlds population has been killed.

title: Deciphering a Lost World
description: Published in quick succession this year, Jeff VanderMeers Southern Reach trilogy has kept readers on tenterhooks as theyve waited for the latest installment of this pure reading pleasure. Annihilation, Authority and Acceptance  the titles suggest an especially terrible session of behavioral therapy  introduce Area X, a slice of coast in what appears to be the Florida panhandle. VanderMeer carefully grounds us in that regions ecology: the palmettos, the black damselflies and the wealth of birdlife, from warblers and flickers to cormorants and black ibis. But he also immerses us in its everyday human life: bowling alleys, dive bars, mobile homes. This science fiction happens in our backyard.

title: Worth Its Weight
description: If you said that a principal cause of the 2008 financial crisis was an explosion in credit, most economic commentators would nod their heads in agreement. If you then said this credit boom was due to lax monetary policy, youd still earn a healthy fraction of nods. If you then asserted that Americas departure from the gold standard caused the lax monetary policy, not many folks would be nodding. Nevertheless, this attenuated causal chain has been embraced by a motley collection of wonks, cranks and presidential candidates: Michele Bachmann, Glenn Beck, Steve Forbes, David Stockman and politicians whose last name is Paul. These gold bugs have a deep suspicion of fiat currency. They fret that governments that can just print money will be tempted to print even more, triggering inflation, currency depreciation and worse. Most citizens do not share this obsession, but they might share an unease about the dollar being backed by nothing more than a social convention to treat greenbacks as if they are worth more than the paper they are printed on.

title: Jimmie Johnson on Nascars New Rules
description: The six-time champion stopped by The New York Times to explain the new elimination-style Sprint Cup format.

title: Its True, You Cant Fight City Hall
description: For much of the summer, roof repairs shrouded City Hall in a shimmery coat of white linen-like construction netting, barely visible as breezes rippled the sheets. Over the last two centuries, change has often been in the wind for City Hall and its surrounding park, as mayors, agencies, visionaries, grafters and others put forth ideas for an appropriate civic center  including getting rid of City Hall entirely.

title: The Mystery of Apple Watchs Battery Life
description: Apple had plenty to brag about at its event earlier this week. Bigger iPhones. Sharper screens. Faster speeds. A shiny new watch. So it was particularly noticeable when Apple left out an important detail for the Apple Watch: the battery life.

title: The End of a Week of Cooking, and a Weekend Plan
description: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches one family, and all of us, in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal. Find all the Boot Camp recipes here.

title: 1964: Dr. King in East Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN  The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. filled two churches to overflowing in Communist East Berlin today [Sept. 13]. So many East Berliners showed up to hear him deliver a sermon tonight in the Marienkirche, Berlins oldest Protestant church, that a second sermon was arranged in another church. Both talks stressed religious, rather than political, themes but in an obvious reference to the Communist-built wall that divides the city, Dr. King declared that Christian love will overcome all man-made barriers. His crossing into East Berlin was easier than most. When he arrived at the border, he realized be had forgotten his passport. But police at the Checkpoint Charlie crossing point recognized him and allowed him in without it. At a press conference, he had some sharp words for Republican presidential candidate Sen. Barry Goldwater. His election would bring dangerous signs of Hitlerism, he predicted.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 13, 1964

title: Nascar Drivers Adjust, Slowly, to New Postseason Format
description: CHICAGO  Nascars newly formatted postseason will begin Sunday at Chicagoland Speedway, with 10 races to decide this seasons champion. Changes include a host of new bells and whistles, more drivers and bracket-style elimination rounds with catchy names.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Black Ties at Radnor
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Conversation Pieces (Not That He Needs Them)
description: For years the CBS Sunday Morning correspondent Mo Rocca lived in Chelsea, moving from one rental to another. It was fine, said Mr. Rocca, who is also a contributor to CBS This Morning as well as the host of My Grandmothers Ravioli on the Cooking Channel and a panelist on the NPR news quiz Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! Yes, it was fine, but also, frankly, a bit guilt-inducing to keep throwing away money on rent.

title: Interview: Benicio Del Toro
description: The actor discusses playing the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar in the film Escobar: Paradise Lost.

title: Playing Piano, and Blaming Woody Allen
description: Jeff Goldblum slipped behind the piano in Bemelmans Bar at the Carlyle Hotel one afternoon this week, to tinkle away at Stella by Starlight and to practice for the shows that he and his jazz band, the Mildred Snitzer Orchestra, will begin playing at the Caf Carlyle on Tuesday night, in the groups first New York engagement.

title: Stopping Homebound ISIS Fighters
description: A look at how governments around the world have been dealing with citizens turning jihadists.

title: New Contemporary Label Teams Composers With Artists
description: The enterprising composer and impresario Paola Prestini is starting a new contemporary music label, VIA Records, an offshoot of VisionIntoArt, the interdisciplinary arts production company she founded in 1999. And in the spirit of the parent company, the label will present collaborations between composers and artists in different fields: for the labels first three releases, the company has commissioned visual artists to work with the composers to create companion video works.

title: Off the Air, Onto the Stage
description: Before you see Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host, you hear it. The male and female voices bantering in the darkened theater cheerfully argue about whether to begin the proceedings with talk, rather than dance, so as to start with an idea, the implication seeming to be that movement is less fit for conveying content.

title: For Teachout, the Thrill of Defeat
description: Early in the summer, after Zephyr Teachout announced what appeared to be a quixotic bid to challenge Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary for governor, I met her for breakfast with a childhood friend of hers and a wealthy ideological soul mate she had known for some time through leftist circles in Brooklyn. The candidate was looking for someone to hold a fund-raiser for her, and not having much luck.

title: Tavern on the Greens Chef Leaves, Five Months After Its Reopening
description: Less than five months after the revered but troubled Central Park restaurant Tavern on the Green reopened with a costly renovation, a new management and a new menu, its executive chef, Katy Sparks, has left.

title: Toronto Festival 2014: Benicio Del Toro on Playing Pablo Escobar
description: TORONTO  Family man, politician, ruthless drug lord. All of these sides of Pablo Escobar are explored in the thriller Escobar: Paradise Lost, directed by Andrea Di Stefano and featuring Benicio Del Toro as Escobar. The film follows a Canadian surfer named Nick (Josh Hutcherson), who, while spending time in Colombia, falls for Escobars niece (Claudia Traisac) and finds himself pulled into the drug kingpins dark world. In this video, Mr. Del Toro discusses his approach to the role.

title: A Live Performance Extravaganza Comes to the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles has gone through plenty of changes lately, beginning with the hiring of a new director, Philippe Vergne. One of Vergnes first orders of business upon arriving was giving the confident staff he inherited  including the curator Bennett Simpson and the MOCAtv director Emma Reeves  the green light to move ahead with Step and Repeat, a monthlong series at the Geffen Contemporary. Over four consecutive Saturdays starting September 13 and ending October 4, the bill will be filled out with poets, DJs, bands, performance artists and comedians, including both familiar names and fledgling artists, in a kind of West Coast multimedia analog to MoMA P.S.1s summer Warm Up series. Its a major step forward in providing a showcase for live performance in Los Angeles.

title: The Scorekeeper
description: For those keeping score, mark it as the 901st regular season game for the man in the khakis and T-shirt settling into the press box at CitiField on Tuesday night.

title: In Greece, a Run With Some History
description: The ultra marathon runner Dean Karnazes will join participants of all ages and abilities for the Navarino Challenge, a series of runs through olive groves and along the country roads of Messinia in the southwest Peloponnese of Greece.

title: Are You Catholic and Divorced? Share Your Experience
description: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.

title: No Need to Flip-Flop? An Argument for the Power of Persuasion
description: Elected officials may have more power to shape public opinion than they realize.

title: A Showplace for Art
description: An extravagant townhouse on Central Park West that retains its fanciful 1887 Queen Anne exterior, but received a rigorous renovation in 2006 that fast-forwarded its interior into a stark showplace for contemporary art, is poised to return to the market at $27.75 million. The annual property taxes on the residence, whose unusual attributes include a 60-foot lap pool and an onion dome skylight encircled by a Guggenheim-esque stairway, are $48,000.

title: Making Romescada, the Catalan Fish Stew
description: Romesco, the delicious rust-colored sauce from the Catalan region of Spain, is justly popular, served alongside grilled fish or as dip for vegetables. It is typically made with fresh and dried red peppers, roasted almonds and hazelnuts, a fair amount of garlic, and day-old bread fried in olive oil. These ingredients are pounded together (or, these days, whirled to a rough consistency in a machine), and olive oil is added until the mixture resembles a rough reddish mayonnaise.

title: Dungeons, Dragons & Documentaries: A Film Conjures a Battle
description: For a certain sort of fan, the crowdfunding pitch was impossible to resist. Here was a chance, it announced, to support a documentary about the immortal saga of the legendary game that all but revolutionized modern life. No pressure.

title: Truce Is Strengthening, Ukraine President Says
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A week into a cease-fire between pro-Russia separatists and government forces in the east of Ukraine, President Petro O. Poroshenko said on Friday that the pact appeared to be growing stronger by the day, in remarks that conspicuously avoided direct criticism of Moscow.

title: Big Ticket | Mansion in the Making for $45 Million
description: An imposing brick-and-limestone building that has stood guard at a historic corner of Greenwich Village for more than a century and performed a series of humble if necessary services  Catholic school, nursing school, training center for one of the citys oldest charities, New York Foundling  sold for $45 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Where Their Designs Do the Talking
description: Long the kooky aunt of Fashion Weeks, Londons show schedule has gotten busier and slicker since Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter, was appointed chairwoman of the British Fashion Council. Speeches given this morning while I was still stumbling through customs emphasized tech, mobile devices, e-commerce, avatars, Twitter saturation and the online initiatives of the councils chairman and so-called digital and innovation pillar president, Peter Fitzgerald.

title: Troubleshooting a Balky Trackpad
Middle-Aged Man Without a Horn
description: CINCINNATI  The elevator opens on the 20th floor of Carew Tower, a landmark 1930 office building overlooking the Ohio River here. On this overcast July morning, though, the space is not a bank or an insurance company, but the headquarters of Columbia Records circa 1980.

title: Riffs on the Rock Documentary
description: Even before the first-time feature directors Jane Pollard and Iain Forsyth knew how their film about the rock musician Nick Cave would take shape, they had a very clear sense of what it would not be. While most music documentaries are about an artist unmasked  the man behind the myth  or an artist battling band mates or record executives or inner demons, none of that applied to Mr. Cave.

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Looking Out for Yourself With Disability Insurance
description: In case anyone has forgotten, were all basically on our own here in personal finance land.

title: Nations Trying to Stop Their Citizens From Going to Middle East to Fight for ISIS
description: UNITED NATIONS  France wants more power to block its citizens from leaving the country, while Britain is weighing whether to stop more of its citizens from coming home. Tunisia is debating measures to make it a criminal offense to help jihadist fighters travel to Syria and Iraq, while Russia has outlawed enlisting in armed groups that are contradictory to Russian policy.

title: Russia Scolds the U.S. Over Syria
description: Vladimir Putins latest foray into the international debate over Syria took chutzpah.

title: Mike Mills Designs Pajamas for Sleepy Jones
description: Now that New York Fashion Week has ended, those involved would love nothing more than the chance to sink into a pillow and doze off. Just in time for the most exhausted moment of the year, the artist and filmmaker Mike Mills has designed a limited-edition set of pajamas for Sleepy Jones, Andy Spades line of stylish lazywear. The navy-and-white sets, available in mens and womens tops and bottoms ($74-$165), come printed with Millss illustrations of the various sleep aids and anxiety pills taken by his friends. My sleep is the first to go when I start worrying, thinking too much, when life turbulence hits, Mills says. I let all the thoughts you dont want to think in. Though its not the first time that the prescriptions we pop have made for a pop-art-meets-fashion motif (see Damien Hirsts pharmaceutical-studded backpack for the Row), the pill pattern, in the case of these soft cotton pieces, offers both metaphorical and literal comfort.

title: Young Households Are Losing Ground in Income, Despite Education
description: YOUNG families are better educated than ever before, but they are earning lower real incomes.

title: The Memories Are Woven In
description: When it comes to sentimentality, there are few events in life more steeped in it than the typical wedding. But when it comes to dressing for the occasion, many brides cant wait to get their hands on the latest design from Vera Wang or Carolina Herrera.

title: Orioles Lose Chris Davis to Drug Suspension Before Edging Yankees
description: BALTIMORE  The Baltimore Orioles played their first game Friday without Chris Davis, the slugging corner infielder who was suspended earlier in the day for amphetamine use. It was devastating news because the 25-game suspension extends well into the postseason, where the Orioles seem destined to play.

title: Can the Apple Watch Woo Traditional Watch Fans?
description: The Watch.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

title: Ford Recalling Older Escapes for a Stalling Problem
description: Ford is recalling about 70,000 older Ford Escape and Mercury Mariner crossover utility vehicles because the electronics may overheat and cause the vehicles to stall, the automaker said in a report posted Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Parenthood Denied by the Law
description: The Marriage Equality Act, which New York State passed in June 2011, allowed Jann Paczkowski to marry her partner, Jamie, with the assurance that the marriages of same-sex and different-sex couples would be treated equally in all respects under the law. But when the couple separated and Ms. Paczkowski sought joint custody of the 2-year-old boy they were raising together, she discovered the limits of that assurance. On June 30, 2014, a judge in Nassau County family court ruled that Ms. Paczkowski did not have legal standing to seek access to the boy  because even under the Marriage Equality Act, she was not his parent.

title: Veterans of Elite Israeli Unit Refuse Reserve Duty, Citing Treatment of Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  Denouncing Israels treatment of Palestinians under occupation, a group of veterans from an elite, secretive military intelligence unit have declared they will no longer take part in the states actions against Palestinians in required reserve duty because of what they called our moral duty to act.

title: Brain Trauma to Affect One in Three Players, N.F.L. Agrees
description: The National Football League, which for years disputed evidence that its players had a high rate of severe brain damage, has stated in federal court documents that it expects nearly a third of retired players to develop long-term cognitive problems and that the conditions are likely to emerge at notably younger ages than in the general population.

title: Arturo OFarrill: (Dont) Take Five
description: Arturo OFarrill, the Grammy Award-winning pianist and composer, spends his Sundays in a frenzy of improvisation. By day he directs a youth orchestra, the Fat Afro Latin Jazz Cats. By night he takes the stage himself with his own group, the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra, at Birdland. On Sept. 20, the two groups will play together at Pueblo Harlem, a cultural festival. Mr. OFarrill, 54, lives in Park Slope with his wife, Alison Deane, 62, a classical pianist. I made one rule for myself, and I really try to live it: Play music you love, with people you love, for people you love, Mr. OFarrill said. If I cant be that kind of musician, Ill drive a cab. Creating music based on art and giving away from your spirit is more important than making a living.

title: Cara Delevingnes London Fashion Week Shortlist
description: Today, the 22-year-old British model Cara Delevingne returns to her hometown of London to walk in the spring/summer 2015 shows there. The fashion-world darling, who introduced her eponymous Mulberry collection at an event in New York City on Monday and who stars in the new Burberry fragrance campaign alongside Kate Moss, is excited to be home with her family. When she has more time in London, she ventures out to Hackney Farm and London Zoo to frolic and play. But she has less ambitious plans for this whirlwind of a trip (including a pit stop at the Mulberry Store on New Bond Street to look at my bags, she says). Here, in five words or less, the girl with more Instagram followers than Lady Gaga shares her top 5 places to hang during London Fashion Week this season.

title: More Time in the Sun for Club Meds Shareholders
description: Club Mditerranes shareholders have been vindicated for refusing to throw in the towel.
