description: The Union of Concerned Scientists said on Tuesday that in 60 percent of the United States, electric vehicles are now responsible for fewer heat-trapping global warming emissions per mile than even the most efficient hybrids.

title: 800 Million People Still Malnourished, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  More than 800 million people worldwide do not get enough to eat, even as the world produces more than twice as much food as it needs, according to new figures released Tuesday by the United Nations.

title: Today in Small Business: The Case Against Tipping
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Venturing Into ISIS Recruiting Territory: A Reporters Chronicle
description: Hacibayram, a ramshackle neighborhood in the heart of Ankaras tourist district, has morphed into an recruiting hub for the Islamic State over the past year. Locals say that up to 100 residents have gone to fight for the group in Syria. Ceylan Yeginsu, a Times correspondent who is from Turkey, visited Hacibayram to report on recruitment efforts and to find out why young boys from the area enlist as fighters for the group, often referred to as ISIS. Here she describes how she got her front-page story.

title: U.S. Moves to Reduce Global Warming Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday announced a series of moves aimed at cutting emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, powerful greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.

title: Martin Amiss Zone of Interest Makes European Publishers Squirm
description: PARIS  In France, they say theyre puzzled by the humor. In Germany, they say it will be difficult to market. Martin Amiss latest novel, The Zone of Interest, a satire set in a concentration camp during the Second World War, is having trouble gaining traction in Europe, where his longtime French and German publishers have rejected it.

title: A Rock Pilgrims Progress
description: The only true currency in this bankrupt world, Philip Seymour Hoffman (as Lester Bangs) says to a young rock journalist in the movie Almost Famous, is what you share with someone else when youre uncool.

title: CBS Replacing Rihanna Song on Football Broadcast After Singer Complains
description: After a series of Twitter posts from the singer Rihanna criticizing CBS for dropping her song from last weeks premiere of Thursday Night Football, the network has decided to remove the song from its telecasts for the remainder of this season.

title: A Health Care Hot Potato
description: Despite the success of the Affordable Care Act in Kentucky, state Democrats are having a hard time winning over even those Republicans who admit they are benefiting from the law.

title: Versace Helps a Restoration
description: This Friday, Versace is opening a new boutique in Milans more-than-a-century-old landmark, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the latest example of luxury houses helping to refurbish historic sites throughout Italy.

title: Anya Hindmarch: Upstaging the Merchandise
description: LONDON  It was to hell in a handbag basket at Anya Hindmarch.

title: Number of Children Living in Poverty Drops Sharply, Census Bureau Reports
description: WASHINGTON  The poverty rate declined last year for the first time since 2006, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday. But at the same time, it said, there was no statistically significant change in the number of poor people or in income for the typical American household.

title: London Fashion Week: Simone Rocha Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

title: What Does British Style Really Mean?
description: LONDON  On the penultimate evening of London Fashion Week, Samantha Cameron, Britains first lady and British Fashion Council ambassador, and Natalie Massenet, the councils chairwoman, co-hosted a cocktail event at 10 Downing Street to celebrate what both women were careful to call British fashion, a.k.a. the most successful of our creative industries, according to Ms. Cameron  bigger than film, music and advertising.

title: Chiquita Offers Concessions to European Regulators for Fyffes Merger
description: LONDON  Chiquita Brands International and Fyffes said on Tuesday that they were in discussions with European regulators about a series of possible concessions to obtain clearance for their proposed inversion deal.

title: A Last Word on the Cruz Affair
description: My Sunday column used Ted Cruzs now-famous performance at a summit organized to raise awareness of Christian persecution in the age of ISIS as a window into the difficulties that the Middle Easts swiftly-disappearing Christians have finding patrons in the American political scene. The column didnt have space to do justice to the various arguments raised in defense of Cruzs provocations the most notable of which was hischallenge to a mostly-Arab audience to acknowledge that Christians haveno greater ally than the Jewish state, which prompted boos and sent thingsspiraling downhill. So let me say a word about those arguments here.

title: Pitch Strikes a Raw Nerve
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Before the game, the Tampa Bay Rays gave Derek Jeter a kayak, a check and a uniform top; thoughtful gifts to honor a 20-year career, which is coming to an end in frustrating, unfamiliar fashion. Later in the game, they gave him and his teammates reason to fight.

title: Y Combinator, a Start-Up Incubator, Goes to College
description: Stewart Brand, a counterculture icon of the 1960s, is known for a phrase technologists love to quote: Information wants to be free.

title: E.P.A. Cuts Size of Loan New York Sought for Tappan Zee Bridge
description: In a significant blow to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos plan for financing a new Tappan Zee Bridge, the federal Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday rejected most of New York States request for a $511 million low-interest loan to help pay for the project, saying the state had planned to use the money almost entirely for construction, rather than its required purpose: enhancing the environment.

title: Inside a Souvenir From France
description: The age of French dining in New York that blossomed in the unpromising soil of the Corona ash dumps during the 1939 Worlds Fair, at the French Pavilions restaurant, seemed to come to its close about 10 years ago as mastodons like Lutce lumbered into the fossil record. Today, that seems less like the end of an epoch than a salutary cooling-off period.

title: Bessie Awards to Honor Arthur Mitchell and Chuck Davis
description: Arthur Mitchell, a founder of Dance Theater of Harlem and Chuck Davis, the founder of DanceAfrica, will be honored at the 30th annual Bessie Award ceremony on Oct. 20 at the Apollo Theater, officials announced. Mr. Mitchell will receive an award forlifetime achievement in dance and Mr. Davis will receive an award for outstandingservice to the field of dance.

title: Grand Jury in Michael Brown Shooting Gets More Time
description: A judge has given an extension of 60 days to the grand jury considering whether to indict Darren Wilson, the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who killed Michael Brown, 18. The jury must decide by Jan. 7 whether Officer Wilson, who is white, will be criminally charged in the death of Mr. Brown, who was black and unarmed.

title: A Night at the Museum
description: Hotels dotted with paintings and prints are hardly rare, but taking a cue from Als Grand Hotel  Allen Ruppersbergs bookable, seven-room installation, which popped up on Sunset Boulevard for six weeks in 1971 and was restaged at this years Frieze New York  more and more properties are blurring the lines between artwork and accommodation. The 21c Museum Hotel in Louisville, Ky., recently commissioned Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe to create Asleep in the Cyclone, an immersive architectural collage that doubles as a 500-square-foot guest room. Everything inside (from the geodesic-domed ceiling to the fake books and magazines) has been created or curated by the American art duo to evoke a 60s-era hippie commune. Across the pond, one of the suites at the Beaumont in London  set to launch this fall in the Mayfair district as the first hotel from the restaurateurs behind the Wolseley and Brasserie Zdel  has been designed by Antony Gormley as a three-level inhabitable sculpture. Featuring fumed-oak interiors, the conjoined cubes of stainless steel mimic the British artists own body, a recurring theme in his work. Next spring, Living Architecture plans to unveil A House for Essex in the U.K., designed by the Turner Prize winner Grayson Perry in collaboration with the architecture firm FAT. With its ceramic-tile facade and aluminum roof sculptures, not to mention the handmade tapestries and artworks inspired by a fictional local character, it looks like something out of a fairy tale.

title: Program Pairs Low-Income Students with Elite Colleges
description: Many selective colleges are outsourcing their search for low-income students to a program called Questbridge.

title: Temporary Agreement Is Intended to Allow Gaza to Import Materials for Rebuilding
description: UNITED NATIONS  Momentum for the rebuilding of the Gaza Strip advanced on Tuesday, with a senior United Nations diplomat briefing the Security Council on a temporary deal between Israeli and Palestinian officials to import cement and other building materials.

title: Long-Running Art Moscow Fair Canceled
description: Art Moscow, Russias longest-running contemporary art fair, has been canceled this year because of international tensions and a virtually nonexistent local market, its founder and organizer, Vasily Bychkov, has announced in an interview with The Art Newspaper Russia.

title: May the Force Be With You
description: On display at the London Design Festival this week is Nouvel Rebel: four lamps, a set of candlesticks and a martini glass all designed by Lee Broom in marble, crystal or some combination of both. The collection features two styles of pendant lamps with Carrara marble centers encased in lead crystal, and a globular table lamp with a crystal hemisphere. But the most impressive of the lot may be an exceedingly thin (5 mm) marble tube with a single strip of LEDs inside. When lit, the lamp, called Tube (shown), looks like a glowing light saber. It was inspired by the very basic fluorescent tube light you would get in factories or warehouses, said Mr. Broom, a former theater designer based in the East End. I wanted to create something very industrial, but very hand crafted. Tube is about 35 inches long and 2.75 inches in diameter, and costs about $5,310. The Future Perfect design store is taking advance orders. Information: 212-473-2500 or thefutureperfect.com.

title: Former Putin Aide Reinforces Dangers of Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  President Obama has warned Russia that there will be costs for its policies in Ukraine. European leaders and the head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have done the same.

title: Bertrand de Billy Cancels Vienna State Opera Appearances
description: The Vienna State Opera continues to bleed conductors. Less than two weeks after the surprise resignation of its music director, Franz Welser-Mst, the French conductor Bertrand de Billy announced this week that he was canceling his upcoming performances there because of differences with the companys management.

title: Hoping War-Weary Tourists Will Return to Israel
description: On a recent afternoon in the Old City of Jerusalem, while fighting raged in Gaza, Bilal Abu Khalaf hosted a group of Israeli tourists at his textile store in the Christian Quarter  one of Jerusalems tourist gems.

title: Exploring the Worlds Jewish Communities
description: Why does everything about Jewish history have to be long and sad and filled with persecution? This was the refrain Harry D. Wall said he heard all too often from his children during their travels, so he set out to correct that with Jewish Discoveries.

title: French Premier Prevails in Confidence Vote
description: PARIS  Frances embattled Socialist government survived a parliamentary vote of confidence on Tuesday aimed at shoring up support for tough economic policy changes at a time when the economy is flat and President Franois Hollandes popularity is the lowest of any French president in decades.

title: Stratford Festival to Offer Shakespeare in Movie Theaters and on TV
description: If youve been meaning to catch some of the Stratford Festivals renowned Shakespeare productions but havent been able to get up to Ontario, the festival has a remedy at hand. As the first installment of a long-term project, in which the festival hopes to document its productions of the entire Shakespeare canon, three of this years stagings will be filmed in HD. The films will be screened in cinemas around the world in 2015 and television broadcasts by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation will follow, as will on-demand digital releases.

title: Alibabas Governance Leaves Investors at a Disadvantage
description: Lucian Bebchuk is professor of law, economics and finance and director of the program on corporate governance at Harvard law School.

title: Bill Targets Pro Sports Leagues Tax-Exempt Status
description: Amid uproar over the N.F.L.s handling of domestic abuse cases involving some of its players, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, has introduced a bill that would disallow major professional sports leagues, most notably the N.F.L., from claiming status as tax-exempt nonprofits.

title: In Rotterdam, Produce Real and Digital
description: Rotterdams spacious indoor market, Markthal, will have a colorful opening on Oct. 1, with the Horn of Plenty digital mural that adorns the walls and ceiling of the arch-shaped building.

title: LoyalBlocks Simplifies Mobile App Creation for Small Merchants
description: One of the biggest challenges small, brick-and-mortar businesses face is marketing, with many spending their budgets on efforts that dont have much of an impact on sales. One alternative some have tried is creating loyalty apps, but creating a mobile app is not something most small-business owners know how to do and the platforms that exist are often too complicated and expensive.

title: London Fashion Week: Fashion East Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Senators Take Auto Agency to Task Over G.M. Recall
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top auto regulator faced withering criticism across Capitol Hill on Tuesday over its failure to identify a deadly defect in General Motors cars  even as its top official tried again and again to shift the blame back to the automaker.

title: A History of Misses for RadioShack
description: In an alternate universe, RadioShack would rule the world, supplying all of your electronics needs from computers to cellphones, and even making them. But in this world, RadioShack is almost bankrupt, having missed almost every opportunity to be the center of the technology revolution.

title: Gelato for Breakfast? You Bet
description: Wait a second. Brooks Headley, the pastry chef from Del Posto, is encouraging you to make an ice cream sandwich with store-bought white bread and a tub of Ben & Jerrys Cherry Garcia?

title: If Desserts Could Wear Tattoos
description: When you flip open a cookbook called Fancy Desserts, you dont expect to find a photograph of two elephants mating.

title: On New Measurements of Aging
description: Pediatricians chart childrens growth at every visit, tracking how they conform to age-appropriate standards. What if standard measures of aging were similarly available?

title: You Cant Feed a Family With G.D.P.
description: The most important thing to know about the state of the United States economy was revealed in a report Tuesday morning that Wall Street barely noticed.

title: Employee of Law Firm Wilson Sonsini Charged With Insider Trading
description: Federal authorities, for the second time in three years, charged an employee of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati, a prominent law firm, with using confidential information about corporate deals to make illegal trades in stocks.

title: Abenomics Meets Ibiza in K.K.R.s Latest Investment
description: Henry Kravis is spinning a different sort of club deal. The old kind, in which several private equity shops would make an acquisition together, led his Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to join the recent hefty settlement of a lawsuit over allegations of collusion with other firms. In this new version, K.K.R. is buying Pioneers D.J. audio equipment business for $550 million. Mr. Kravis is laying down a smooth groove in a funky M.&A. market.

title: At Buckingham Palace, a Dancing Guard Throws Decorum to the Wind
description: The guards who stand sentry outside Buckingham Palace are the embodiment of decorum and regularity. Many British children have grown up with little dolls of them in their sentry boxes (I was one). Innumerable tourists over decades have watched them make their nobly pointless little marches to and fro between A and B. They are absurd, glorious, dependable, stiff-upper-lip, constant: They mean Therell always be an England.

title: Chinese Leader Visits Sri Lanka, Challenging Indias Sway
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  President Xi Jinping of China arrived in Sri Lanka on Tuesday for a 23-hour trip to this island nation to sign a raft of agreements as China chips away at Indias traditional dominance in the region.

title: Dempsey and Hagel Speeches and Protests
description: Comments by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on the United States campaign against ISIS were interrupted by anti-war protesters.

title: Scottish Referendum Could Hinge on the Undecided
description: Public opinion polls show Scotlands independence referendum is too close to call ahead of the Sept. 18 vote, which could come down to those still undecided  at least 6 percent of potential voters have not made up their mind.

title: How to Fake Your Next Vacation
description: Zilla van der Born, a Dutch national, spent five weeks traveling through Southeast Asia and documented the trip in photos on Facebook. Sheposed for pictures while diningon dumplings, snorkeling among colorful fish in azure waters and visiting ornately decorated Buddhist temples  compiling the lot into a series of videos for her Vimeo account. All in all, Ms. van der Born seemed to have enjoyed a busy, albeit conventional, trip to Phuket, Luang Prabang or some other regional tourist hub.

title: Governor and Sponsors Voice Concerns With N.F.L.
description: The N.F.L., it seems, has been unable to keep up with the roiling storm over its handling of multiple domestic violence cases that have captured the nations attention and started to eclipse the action on the field.

title: Campus Cops With M-16s
description: After Ferguson cops greeted unarmed protesters with tear gas and combat vehicles, there was public gnashing of teeth over whether police departments really need military gear, acquired from the Pentagon through the federal 1033 transfer program. Some national politicians, notably Republican Senator Rand Paul, criticized the militarization of law enforcement.

title: Craig Green: Fashions Newest Wunderkind
description: The designer creates clothing out of junk and lives with his parents.

title: Q. and A.: What Would an Independent Scotland Entail?
description: Scotland has been Englands junior partner in the United Kingdom since 1707. But three centuries is no time at all in the view of many Scots, who regularly re-enact 14th century sword battles they had with the English and have insisted on self-determination, on and off, ever since. That prospect is now nearer than ever. Scottish voters will decide on Thursday whether to become independent once again.

title: Federal Judge Upholds U.S. Effort to Regulate Overseas Trading
description: Updated, 7:54 p.m. | A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the Obama administrations effort to rein in the sort of overseas trading that imploded in the financial crisis, upending Wall Streets plan to roll back the regulatory overhaul.

title: Pennsylvania Officials Identify Suspect in Ambush at Barracks
description: The Pennsylvania authorities on Tuesday identified a 31-year-old man with antigovernment leanings as the suspect in last weeks ambush at a state police barracks that left one trooper dead and another wounded.

title: Letter From the Environmental Protection Agency
description: In its decision to reject most of the states request for a $511 million loan, the E.P.A. wrote that construction activities arising from transportation projects do not advance water quality.

title: Fourth Downs in Week 2: When Risk-Taking Paid Off
description: The season is only two weeks old, and Im sorry to report that the name-calling has already started: Some of my readers are calling me an Internet troll.

title: London Fashion Week: Meadham Kirchhoff Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

title: A Bar Boulud in Boston and Other Restaurant News
description: Headliner

title: Gehrys Changes to Memorial Rejected by Eisenhowers
description: The modifications proposed by the architect Frank Gehry to his design of a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for the Washington Mall are insufficient, members of the Eisenhower family say.

title: Excerpt: Red Band Society
description: The new Fox series takes place in a youth hospital.

title: Food News Around New York
description: To Post: Mini-Portraits of American Chefs

title: Ferguson, a Month Later
description: Last week Frances Robles, a national correspondent, reported on changes in the way that Ferguson, Mo., handles arrest warrants and municipal fines. She shared her experience reporting the story, and what the town is like a month after the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager who was killed by a white police officer.

title: Around the N.F.L., the Catch-and-Run Is Gaining
description: In the N.F.L., the short pass is the new run. Through two weeks, teams have completed 63.5 percent of their passes, a rate that would easily break last years record-setting 61.2 percent. Thirty-four quarterbacks have attempted at least 30 passes this season, and half of them have completed at least 64.9 percent of their passes. In many ways, it has never been easier for a quarterback to complete a pass.

title: The Unions Fake Canadians
description: In August 1864, two dozen black men gathered at Benton Barracks in St. Louis to be mustered into the Army. Each registered as a substitute for a draftee, and each was paid an enlistment bounty. But, according to the rolls, there was something remarkable about these men: All of them were foreigners. William Thompson, Washington Taylor and Henry Taylor were from England, the rolls attested; William Wood was from Jamaica, and the remaining 20 men were from Canada.

title: 2 Companies Will Take Americans to Space Station
description: Boeing and the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation are the winners in the competition to carry American astronauts to the International Space Station, NASA announced on Tuesday.

title: Hostage Saved, Time to Get the Kids
description: The opening scene is straight out of the TV Cop Show Clich Handbook: a high-speed chase, a car wreck, a hostage-taking, a put-down-the-gun standoff. Right out of the handbook, that is, until the officer in that standoff, having shot and wounded the suspect, pulls out a wet wipe to clean the blood off the hostage.

title: Excerpt: The Mysteries of Laura
description: The new NBC series stars Debra Messing as a detective.

title: Stream the New Album From Japans Original Indie Rock Star, Shintaro Sakamoto
description: In Japan, Shintaro Sakamoto is a bona fide star. His former psychedelic-rock trio, Yura Yura Teikoku, sold out large venues whenever they played; they even toured the United States with the indie stalwarts Yo La Tengo. But since disbanding the group in 2010, he has favored a more low-key approach, eschewing live shows and retreating to the studio to produce his first solo album, How to Live with a Phantom, in 2011. That release, a mellow affair with jazzy guitar, Latin percussion and soft sax, called to mind the chilled-out feel of 70s yacht rock and the sonic perfectionism of Steely Dan. When the label arm of the influential New York record emporium Other Music issued it in the United States, it became a cult classic. (The former Girls frontman and Hedi Slimane muse Christopher Owens, for one, has professed his love in multiple interviews.)

title: A Pakistan Airlines Delay Leads to a Near Mutiny
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Flight delays are nothing unusual at Pakistans ailing state carrier, Pakistan International Airlines, long hobbled by political interference, a bloated staff and epic financial losses.

title: After American Airlines-US Airways Merger, Agents Vote to Unionize
description: Customer service agents for the merged American Airlines and US Airways have voted overwhelmingly in favor of union representation, the National Mediation Board announced on Tuesday.

title: Images of an Uzbek First Daughter Under House Arrest
description: A British public relations firm released images on Tuesday showing Gulnara Karimova, the flamboyant eldest daughter of President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, under house arrest.

title: Joan Rivers Biography Is Acquired by Little, Brown
description: Joan Rivers was an assiduous chronicler of her own life, in print as well as during her stand-up routines. In her 81 years, she produced a string of advice and humor books and several revealing memoirs, with self-mocking titles like I Hate Everyone  Starting With Me.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Keeping True to an Iranian Vision, Minus Big Money
description: Newsha Tavakolian returned a 50,000-euro prize rather than see her work about contemporary Iran be controlled  distorted, she says  by the financier whose foundation selected her.

title: Restaurant Report: Le Canon in Nice, France
description: Initially, Le Canon, a bistro that opened in Nice early this year, comes off as the sort of hipster restaurant that might easily be spotted in Brooklyn or Shoreditch in London: Edison bulbs overhead; 50s-era cafe chairs and Formica-topped tables; a soundtrack heavy on funk. But when Sbastien Perinetti, the friendly owner and a Nice native, props the daily chalkboard menu up on a chair, its a great read that could be found only on the French Riviera.

title: Hotel Review: The Langham, Chicago
description: Rates

title: Globalization Is in Retreat? Not So Fast
description: Not long ago, executives at the Dutch multinational Royal DSM, a globe-girdling maker of nutritional supplements and high-tech materials, used to require a battery of internal studies to decide where to do a deal or locate a new manufacturing plant.

title: Obama Presses Leaders to Speed Ebola Response
description: ATLANTA  President Obama on Tuesday challenged world powers to accelerate the global response to the Ebola outbreak that is ravaging West Africa, warning that unless health care workers, medical equipment and treatment centers were swiftly deployed, the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives.

title: Feather-Trimmed Slippers at Simone Rocha
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: To Aid Childrens Cancer Care, Mothers Go Bald
description: A mother stands in front of my camera. I dont know what Im supposed to do, she says anxiously, so she smiles stiffly, as you might in a school picture. Just be yourself, I encourage. When she leaves my makeshift studio, set up at the Prudential Center in Boston for the occasion, I feel Ive failed. The images reveal nothing about how she was feeling. Instead, Ive taken a smiling portrait of a woman with no indication that she was about to undergo a serious, emotional transformation.

title: Judge Lifts Temporary Ban on Uber
description: Arne Hasse, a judge in a district court in Frankfurt, announced that a temporary ban on Uber, a car-sharing service, had been lifted in Germany.

title: 6 Kids and a Billionaire at Home in the Hospital
description: There are so few obstacles left for middle-class teenagers to struggle against. Parents and teachers are permissive, bullying is stomped upon, acne can be treated, and only the most exacting religions discourage gay or interfaith relationships.

title: If You Wear Your Heart on Your Sleeve, Expect to Get It Moshed
description: Mere seconds after the band Joyce Manors introductory guitar punch at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, the crowd started an eager mosh, exultantly tossing cups of beer into the air. Up onstage, the frontman Barry Johnson was in upheaval, too, but mostly of the internal kind.

title: Clip: 20,000 Days on Earth
description: A scene from the film.

title: Batter Up, Onstage With Songs
description: ATLANTA  The success rate for transforming major league movies into major league musicals isnt particularly impressive. In baseball parlance its considerably less than .500. For every Billy Elliot or Hairspray there are a raft of also-rans  but I wont salt the wounds by going down the list.

title: An Image Thats Hard to Shed
description: Chris Brown begins X, his new album, in a buck-passing mood. The opening song, the title track, begins, If youre only as good as the company you keep/Then Im-a blame you for what they say about me.

title: A Rocker Covers a Lot of Ground in One Day
description: Memory is what we are. Your very soul and your very reason to be alive are tied up in memory.

title: Fantasy Football: Waiver Wire Priorities for Week 3
description: If last week was Kevin Ogletree week, this is most definitely injury week.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Kirsten Dunsts Sexy Yet Serious Ferragamo Dress
description: The Star: Kirsten Dunst

title: A Blaze Hungry for Dreams
description: You might think an hourlong musical is an inadequate vehicle for capturing the Triangle garment factory fire of 1911, a horrifying and shameful episode in American history involving the deaths of 146 garment workers, most of them female immigrants.

title: Drug Maker That Did an Inversion Seeks to Block One
description: Endo International, a pharmaceutical company that struck an inversionlast year and reincorporated in Ireland, is now trying to stop an inversion by smaller rival, Auxilium Pharmaceuticals.

title: A Great Symphony, and Then Two More Takes on It
description: Mahlers great, valedictory Ninth Symphony, about 90 minutes long and prevailingly intense, is more often than not left to fill an evening by itself. But the Argento Chamber Ensemble and the JACK Quartet built an ambitious program around it on Monday evening in the Music Mondays series at Advent Lutheran Church on the Upper West Side, adding two shortish contemporary works more or less based on the Ninth.

title: Changing States of Matter, and a Whole New Meaning to Vaping
description: On Friday afternoon at MetroTech Commons in Downtown Brooklyn, the mercurial dancer known as Ghost came out of character for a minute to address the crowd assembled around a small outdoor stage. Surrounding him were fellow members of the Bed-Stuy Veterans, a dance crew devoted to the Jamaican-born style brukup, which migrated from Caribbean dance halls to Brooklyn streets in the mid-1990s. The lunch-hour show was part of the third annual BEAT Festival, an eclectic series of theater, music and dance throughout Brooklyn.

title: Is Hubby Unfaithful? And Other Household Intrigues
description: Sometimes a play is more interesting in the future than in its own time. The Fatal Weakness, a domestic comedy with a drama at its core, was apparently unloved in its day; its 1946 Broadway premiere ran for only 119 performances despite having Ina Claire, a prominent stage actress, in the lead role. But here in 2014, the Mint Theater Company is making this George Kelly work an amusing, affecting reminder that the institution of marriage has been under siege for much longer than we tend to think.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Brazil and India.

title: NBC Lands Another First-Place Finish Among Networks
description: NBC put an exclamation point on its prime-time turnaround Tuesday by announcing (a week early) that it will end the television calendar year  September to September  in first place among the viewers it sells to advertisers.

title: A Planning Site That Cuts to the Chase
description: Finding the right hotel in a destination can be time-consuming, comparing destination information to maps, restaurant reviews and more. Expedia found travelers visit an average of 38 websites before booking a vacation package.

title: Web Hosting Company Rackspace Decides to Go It Alone
description: Rackspace, a web hosting company,said in May that it was exploring strategic alternatives, including a possible sale. Potential buyers had approached the company hoping to strike a deal,and the company wanted to conduct a thorough review of its options.

title: Classics on 4 Wheels or 2 at the Radnor Hunt Concours
description: MALVERN, Pa.  Each September, the Radnor Hunt clubs manicured pastures and bucolic hills become a stage for some of the finest classic cars and motorcycles in North America.

title: Recent Commerical Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Vote for Independent Scotland Could Prompt Battle Over Energy
description: LONDON  Scotlands separatists assume that secession would mean that their country holds the bulk of North Sea energy assets. And many experts agree that, under international maritime law, those Scots are right.

title: Independence Movements Energy Wager Could Prove Risky for Scotland
description: LONDON  Scottish nationalists have long argued that being governed from London has deprived their country of its fair share of the wealth from Britains oil and natural gas fields, which mostly lie in North Sea waters off their shores.

title: Julia Bergshoeff Transforms at Tom Ford
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Julia Bergshoeff before (left) and after (right) makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Sam McKnight.

title: William M. Raveis Jr.
description: Mr. Raveis, 69, is the founder, chairman and chief executive of William Raveis Real Estate, Mortgage and Insurance, a family-owned company with headquarters in Shelton, Conn. William Raveis has 108 company-owned and affiliate offices in the Northeast and more than 3,500 sales associates.

title: New York State Judiciary Adopts Rules to Protect Debtors
description: The New York State court system adopted rules on Tuesday to protect people in debt and make it harder for debt collection companies to win default judgments.

title: Pair Charged in Manhattan Apartment Rental Fraud
description: There is a certain kind of desperation that just about anyone who has rented an apartment in Manhattan can recognize.

title: A Week of Focaccia
description: A couple of months ago, at the height of the summer tomato season, I gave you a recipe for a delicious whole wheat focaccia with tomatoes and fontina. I was so enthralled with the bread that I decided Id come back to it and post a weeks worth of focaccia recipes.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Guest
description: Adam Wingard narrates a sequence from his film The Guest, written by Simon Barrett and featuring Dan Stevens and Maika Monroe.

title: London Fashion Week Social Media Roundup
description: Though short in terms of time (it lasts exactly five days), London Fashion Week packs a punch. Just ask Alexandra Jacobs, who developed an entirely new phobia from the sheer stress of dashing from show to show: F.O.N.G.T.O.T., or Fear of Not Getting There On Time  #fongtot for those who are on Twitter. Fortunately, hashtags and acronyms didnt slow the critics down too much as they surveyed the offerings both of megabrands like Burberry and Tom Ford, and of less established designers like Simone Rocha, Margaret Howell and Hunter. The truncated week brimmed with moments: unexpected ones (Birkenstocks at Burberry), unnerving ones (a moving runway at Anya Hindmarch) and even political ones (Vivienne Westwoods comment on the Scottish referendum).

title: A Dangerous Visitor Makes Himself at Home
description: As one of the sharper young horror directors working today, Adam Wingard likes to take familiar genre setups  the serial killer or the home invasion  and warp them just enough to pique our interest. Together with the writer Simon Barrett, whose canny scripts flip and swerve at unexpected moments, Mr. Wingard is building a rsum that pays at least as much attention to character and story as it does to scares and body count.

title: Strange, Gorgeous Art Made From Single-Cell Organisms Under a Microscope
description: Perhaps youve never done much thinking about the beauty of algae, but the Victorians did. Microscopists of the era used to arrange diatoms  single-cell organisms encased in jewel-like glass shells that likely date to the Jurassic Period  into stunningly beautiful mosaics that resemble stained glass in miniature. The last surviving diatomist is an Englishman named Klaus Kemp, who became fascinated with the practice as a teenager. Because the Victorians left no records behind, Kemp had to figure it out for himself. Hes still at it today, supporting himself by selling his creations to a small but avid group of collectors. The filmmaker Matthew Killip spent an afternoon with Kemp at his home in England in December of 2013, documenting his unique practice at the intersection of science and art. Killips film, The Diatomist, premieres exclusively here.

title: Gunman Gets 20 Years in Georgia School Seizure
description: DECATUR, Ga.  Nearly 13 months after he clutched an assault rifle and seized an elementary school here, a Georgia man with an extensive history of mental illness was ordered on Tuesday to serve 20 years in prison.

description: Add a new mystery to the bizarre lore of the Mets, which includes the black cat that spooked the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium during the 1969 pennant race and the Great Wall of Flushing, which was originally erected at Citi Field to the dismay of the teams hitters.

title: Walmart Vice President Forced Out for Lying About Degree
description: David Tovar, the vice president for corporate communications at Walmart, was forced to resign after the retailer discovered that he had lied about receiving an art degree from the University of Delaware.

title: Judge in Patz Case Limits Questions on Confessions
description: In the videotaped confessions of a man accused of killing Etan Patz, most of the attention was given to how the suspect said he lured the boy to a store cellar and killed him.

title: Israels N.S.A. Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  IN Moscow this summer, while reporting a story for Wired magazine, I had the rare opportunity to hang out for three days with Edward J. Snowden. It gave me a chance to get a deeper understanding of who he is and why, as a National Security Agency contractor, he took the momentous step of leaking hundreds of thousands of classified documents.

title: The New York Times/CBS Poll
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds that Mr. Obamas approval ratings are similar to those of Mr. Bush in 2006 when Democrats went on to sweep both houses of Congress in the midterm elections.

description: A breakdown of the issues voters will consider Thursday in Scotlands referendum on independence.

title: Trade Schools Sued for Lending Practices
description: A federal agency sued Corinthian Colleges, a major for-profit trade school chain, on Tuesday, charging that it lured students with lies about job placement and used illegal tactics to collect on student loans. The agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, asked a court to erase $569 million in debts arranged by Corinthian for current and former students. The company, which denied the charges, faces heavy losses and sanctions by government regulators, and it agreed in July to sell or close nearly all of its more than 100 campuses. The company said the new lawsuit would make that process more difficult.

title: Tony Stewart Case to Go Before Grand Jury
description: A grand jury will determine if the Nascar champion Tony Stewart will be charged in the death of Kevin Ward Jr., a 20-year-old driver who was killed when he was struck by Stewarts racecar at Canandaigua Motorsports Park near Rochester in August.

title: Syrian Plane Shot Down as Attacks by Groups Intensify
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The warring parties in Syria have launched newly assertive attacks on several fronts in recent days, seeking to gain ground and psychological advantage ahead of an intensified United States campaign against extremist Islamic State militants that could include the first American airstrikes inside Syria.

title: Lets Reject the Inevitable
description: This Sundays Peoples Climate March in New York City could be the biggest demonstration yet for action on climate change. The march is scheduled to coincide with the United Nations Climate Summit, which begins two days later. Despite the advance billing and the official nature of the summit, the march is what matters. The U.N. Summit will be a clubby gathering of world leaders and their representatives who will try to figure out ways to reward polluters for pretending to fix a problem for which theyre responsible in the first place; a fiasco.

They even showed off their affection for the system in the opening ceremony of the 2012 London Olympics.

Accused of murdering a child named Etan Patz 35 years ago, Mr. Hernandez stood not much taller than the shoulders of the shortest of the court officers who led him into State Supreme Court in Manhattan this week.

The question now is whether ramped-up medical assistance from the United States and other countries will arrive fast enough to change the course of the rapidly expanding epidemic.

title: U.S. Steels Canada Subsidiary Files for Creditor Protection
description: U.S. Steel Canada was granted creditor protection on Tuesday, the latest chapter in its tumultuous recent history. U.S. Steel said that the Canadian company, known as Stelco before its purchase in 2007, has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years. With the filing, the Canadian units results will no longer be included in U.S. Steels financial statements. In 2009, U.S. Steel shut down the Canadian operation and locked out its workers while demanding pension changes. That prompted a lawsuit from the government of Canada, charging that the company had failed to live up to foreign investment laws. An agreement to make further investments in Canada ended that action, although the company continues to battle unions. A lawyer for U.S. Steel Canada told the Ontario Superior Court that it had liabilities of between 3.86 billion and 4.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.52 billion and $3.9 billion), and assets worth between 1.9 billion and 2.3 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail. The largest creditor is U.S. Steel, which the court was told is owed 1.6 billion Canadian dollars. It will provide the subsidiary with up to 185 million Canadian dollars to keep it operating until the end of 2015.

title: Court and Brooklyn District Attorneys Office Revisit 2 Contested Convictions
description: A former Brooklyn prosecutor took the stand on Tuesday to defend his handling of a case nearly two decades ago.

title: To Help Unaccompanied Minors, New York City Posts Representatives at Immigration Court
description: The hundreds of children who recently arrived in New York City from Central America have encountered a justice system that appears more forgiving than many faced by their counterparts elsewhere. In an immigration courtroom in Lower Manhattan, they have often met judges who have steered them through the legal process with a gentle hand.

title: New York Man Charged With Trying to Support ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  A Rochester man was indicted Tuesday on charges that he tried to provide material support to the Islamic State by helping three men who said they would travel to Syria to engage in violent jihad alongside the groups militants, according to the Justice Department.

title: Long Road From Fringe to Scottish Referendum

title: Does Moving Poor People Work?
description: Twenty years ago, federal poverty experts, inspired by the forceful arguments in the landmark book The Truly Disadvantaged, as well as by definitive research on the harmful effects of segregation, initiated a government experiment that moved 855 low-income predominantly African-American and Hispanic families out of public housing in poverty-stricken urban areas into less impoverished neighborhoods.

title: Climate Report Details Flood Risk to Sites in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  The nations capital is likely to see record flooding by 2050, putting about $7 billion worth of property, three military bases and parts of the National Mall at risk as a result of climate change that is raising sea levels all over the world, according to a report released Tuesday by the research group Climate Central.

title: N.F.L. Players Union Appeals Ray Rices Longer Suspension
description: The N.F.L. Players Association filed an appeal on behalf of Ray Rice on Tuesday night to protect the due process rights of all players, the union said. It said that Rices indefinite suspension by the league last week, which came after the release of video showing him punching his fiance, was not a fair and impartial process, including the role of the office of the Commissioner of the N.F.L.

description: The Brooklyn Public Library needs $300 million across its 60 branches for repairs and restorations, but the city budget allocates around $15 million per year for capital improvements, so the library system decided to look elsewhere.

description: HONG KONG  With industrial production growing at the slowest pace since the worst of the global financial crisis and foreign direct investment in a tailspin, China appears to have taken the unusual step of using monetary stimulus in an attempt to forestall further economic weakness.

title: Late Summer Play

He was 67.

description: In a partnership that appears to be the first of its kind, Anthem Blue Cross, a large California health insurance company, is teaming up with seven fiercely competitive hospital groups to create a new health system in the Los Angeles area. The partnership includes such well-known medical centers as UCLA Health and Cedars-Sinai.

title: Report Cites Forced Labor in Malaysias Electronics Industry
description: Nearly one in three migrant workers in Malaysias thriving electronics industry toils under forced labor conditions, essentially trapped in the job, a factory monitoring group found in a report issued on Wednesday.

title: MacArthur Awards Go to 21 Diverse Fellows
description: Twelve men and nine women, whose work is as diverse as studying the racial elements in perceptions of crime and translating contemporary Arab poetry, have been named the 2014 fellows of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. The fellowships, based on achievement and potential, come with a stipend of $625,000 over five years and are among the most prestigious prizes for artists, scholars and professionals.

title: Sit Less, Live Longer?
description: If people need motivation to get up from their office chairs or couches and become less sedentary, two useful new studies could provide the impetus. One found that sitting less can slow the aging process within cells, and the other helpfully underscores that standing up  even if you are standing still  can be good for you as well.

title: Mexico: Tourists Being Airlifted After Hurricane Odile
description: Military and police planes began airlifting tourists from the resort town of Los Cabos on Tuesday as residents began to tally the wreckage left by Hurricane Odile, the strongest storm to hit the Baja California peninsula in almost 50 years. The Category 3 storm smashed luxury hotels and swept away poor neighborhoods, but officials said there were no deaths. Electricity and phone service were cut off across the state of Baja California Sur, and the Los Cabos airport was closed to commercial flights.

title: South Korea: American Fails in Effort to Swim to North
description: An American was arrestedTuesdaynight on a river that borders North Korea, the South Korean news media reportedon Wednesday. The South Korean news agencyYonhap, quoting an anonymous government source, said that the American man had attempted to swim to North Korea. All we can say at this point is that our border guards arrested an American man last night on the riverbank near the border, said a Defense Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the inquiry was continuing. Yonhapsaid that the American, in his early 30s, had been found on the riverbank shortly beforemidnight. After he was apprehended, he told South Korean officials that he had intended to go to North Korea to meet its leader, KimJong-un, Yonhap reported. The United States Embassy said it was aware of the reports and had been in touch with the appropriate South Korean authorities.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 6:30 P.M. (Showtime) FRUITVALE STATION (2013) On Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, a 22-year-old African-American father, was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., his killing captured on cellphone. Ryan Cooglers feature directorial debut reconstructs the final 24 hours in the life of Mr. Grant (played by Michael B. Jordan, above, with Ariana Neal) who, after two stints in a state prison, had returned to selling drugs after losing his job at a supermarket because of chronic lateness. Octavia Spencer plays his mother, still able to boss him around, and Melonie Diaz the mother of his daughter, with whom hes trying to stay. Mr. Cooglers main intention  and his great achievement, as well as Mr. Jordans  is to make Oscar a fully human presence, to pay him the respect of acknowledging his complexities and contradictions, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The radicalism of Fruitvale Station lies precisely here, in its refusal to turn a man into a symbol. Nearly every black man, whether or not he is president, tends to be flattened out by popular culture and the psychopathology of everyday American life, rendered as an innocent victim, a noble warrior or a menace to society. There is a dehumanizing violence in this habit, a willed, toxic blindness that Fruitvale Station at once exposes and resists.
