description: Family Dollar Stores again rejected on Wednesday a $9.1 billion takeover approach from Dollar General and urged shareholders not to tender their shares to the discount retailers bigger rival.

title: An Eternal Hipster, Riffing at a Timeless Venue
description: The actor Jeff Goldblum, when off the screen, personifies the type of smart guy you might describe as the Eternal Hipster. Never at a loss for words, never losing his cool, he wears a sly smile.

title: My Late Invite to the Marriage
description: Amanda Majeski, a soprano who is making her Metropolitan Opera debut on Sept. 22 as Countess Almaviva in Mozarts Le Nozze di Figaro, talks about how she landed the role at short notice.

title: Stella Jean: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Eike Batistas Assets Are Frozen in Wake of Insider Trading Charges
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A judge in Rio de Janeiro has ordered the freezing of the personal bank accounts of the Brazilian businessman Eike Batista while investigations proceed into allegations of insider trading.

title: In Brutal Year, 7th Journalist Is Killed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Afghan woman has become the seventh journalist killed in Afghanistan so far this year, an Afghan media group said Wednesday, adding to a toll that has already made 2014 by far the deadliest year for the news media here since the fall of the Taliban.

title: Jordan Finds Energy Sources in Unlikely Places
description: When the oil gusher lottery came to the Middle East, Jordan seemed to have drawn a losing ticket. And now that some of the neighbors it depended on for fuel supplies, like Iraq and Egypt, have convulsed with political or sectarian strife, Jordan is frantically looking for other sources  and finding them in unexpected places.

title: Gucci: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Promise Made for Harlem Watchtowers Restoration, but Not in Ink
description: Manhattan is about to lose its last antebellum watchtower.

title: 1914: Paris Auto Trade Stalls
description: In common with so many other businesses, the automobile industry has been brought almost to a standstill by the war. A walk up the Champs-Elyses is sufficient to prove this. Hoardings block nearly all the window fronts of the numerous auto shops. Other shops have been turned into workrooms, where scores of women may be seen sewing diligently. One of the few auto firms still doing business in Paris is the Packard Company. An advertisement in the Herald announces that Packard automobiles may be hired for journeys in France at 1 franc 50 per kilomtre.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 18, 1914

title: Adam Scott Splits With Caddie, Who Hopes to Travel Less
description: Adam Scott is in the market for a caddie after parting with Steve Williams, who helped guide him to his only major championship, the 2013 Masters, and to the world No. 1 ranking during their four-year partnership.

title: U.S. Army Chief Says Ground Troops Will Be Needed Against ISIS
description: WIESBADEN, Germany  The United States general who beat back Islamic extremists in Iraq in 2007 suggested on Wednesday that the battle against Islamic State jihadis would only succeed with the use of ground forces.

title: Will Congress Bother to Debate War Against ISIS?
description: As the American war against the Islamic State escalates, Congress is about to shut its doors for the election season and head home. The most it will do is authorize some limited assistance to Syrian rebels, but the Senate will probably not even take a vote on that, instead burying the aid inside an emergency spending bill so that its members wont have to be held accountable.

title: Post-Lehman, Money Market Fund Protections Still Weak
description: Jennifer Taub is a professor at Vermont Law School. Her book Other Peoples Houses was published in May by Yale Press.

title: 1939: Soviets Invade Poland
description: The Soviet Union entered the war at dawn yesterday by invading Poland along its entire 500-mile eastern frontier, an hour after the Polish Ambassador in Moscow had refused to receive a note of explanation from the Soviet government. Violent fighting between Polish and Russian troops was reported at Molodeczno, sixty-five miles southeast of Vilna. At almost the same time, German artillery and planes began a day-long bombardment of the center of Warsaw.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 18, 1939

title: Fake News Story Causes Real Headache at Coney Island
description: For fans of the new Thunderbolt roller coaster at Coney Island and anyone who might be thinking of riding it, an article making the rounds on social media last week contained sobering news.

title: Union Square: A Place to Converge, and Buy Kale
description: When Victoria Baradi Anderson moved into the Union Square neighborhood in 1998, she was attracted to its central location and easy subway access. I was single and enjoying the night life, she said. After graduating from college and living with her parents for a year, she bought a studio on East 14th Street for less than $100,000. There was little in the surrounding streets that appealed to her, including the 3.6-acre park that gave the area its name and was not as nice as it is now, she said.

title: How Insurers Are Finding Ways to Shift Costs to the Sick
description: Health insurance companies are no longer allowed to turn away patients because of their pre-existing conditions or charge them more because of those conditions. But some health policy experts say insurers may be doing so in a more subtle way: by forcing people with a variety of illnesses  including Parkinsons disease, diabetes and epilepsy  to pay more for their drugs.

title: Words to Live By
description: After R. J. Palacios Wonder was published in 2012 and became a middle-grades juggernaut, many hoped the author would continue the story of August Pullman, the Manhattan boy born with serious facial deformities, and his friends and family. Wonder ends as Auggie is finishing fifth grade at Beecher Prep, his first year in school after being home-schooled for the surgery-filled first decade of his life. He is given a special award recognizing his courage by the schools principal. But then what? Palacios characters were hard to say goodbye to, and in the current series-heavy world of childrens books, it seemed natural that there would be more to come.

title: IBM Offers Workers Training and Pay Cuts
description: IBM is cutting the pay of some employees in its services business by 10 percent for six months while they spend up to one day a week in training programs.

title: Best Seat in the House
description: When Jonathan Anderson took over as Loewes creative director last September, he had a clear mandate: to liven up the 168-year-old Spanish fashion and leather goods label. In just over a year hes done precisely that, spearheading a seaside ad campaign featuring archival and newly commissioned images by Steven Meisel and unveiling youthful newtakes on Oxford shoes and crocodile bags. But that wasnt enough for the London-based fashion darling who is now reimagining a wood-and-leather armchair that the architect Javier Carvajal designed in 1959 for one of Loewes Madrid stores. There was something so pure in the wooden archetype of the chair, says Anderson, who gave it a splashy new color palette. I wanted to interrupt that aesthetic.

title: The Ultimate Cuban Comfort Food: Picadillo
description: Here is one of the great dishes of the Cuban diaspora: picadillo, a soft, fragrant stew of ground beef and tomatoes, with raisins added for sweetness and olives for salt. Versions of it exist across the Caribbean and into Latin America. James Villas, the elegant hedonist who for many years was the food and wine editor of Town & Country magazine, championed one from St. Lucia, in the Lesser Antilles. But many Cubans claim the dish as their own, a taste of the pre-revolutionary island at its homey best. Picadillo has a sentimental resonance, said Betty Cortina, a Cuban-American food writer who is the editor of The Miami Heralds lifestyle magazine, Indulge. She even took a recipe for picadillo with her to college at the University of Florida. Everyone who is of Cuban descent has a recipe for it, and each one of those is the most authentic. Its a comfort food, probably the most consummate example of one in Cuban cuisine.

title: What Blade Runner Got Wrong
description: Ubiquitous, intrusive advertising has long been a feature of dystopian fiction  directors and writers seem convinced that one of the many things that will make the future terrible is its sheer density of ads.But we now live in the future that dystopians of the 1980sand 1990swere predicting, and whats happened isnt quite what they feared  though, to some, its still pretty scary.

title: N.F.L. and Union Agree on Drug Plan
description: The N.F.L. and the players union announced Wednesday that after several years of feuding over drug-testing protocols, they had reached an agreement on a new plan. The most significant change is that players will be tested for human growth hormone for the first time.

title: What You Get for ... $1,100,000
description: IRON RIVER, MICH.

title: Eres Catlico y Divorciado? Comparta Su Historia
description: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.

title: Vous tes Catholique et Divorc? Partagez Votre Exprience
description: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.

title: Voc  Catlico e Divorciado? Compartilhe Sua Experincia
description: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.

title: House Hunting in ... the Dominican Republic
description: A BEACHFRONT VILLA IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

title: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Peter Thiel Mocks Pot-Smoking Twitter Management
description: Updated, 2:20 p.m. |

title: Ada Kokosar, Stylist and Street-Style Star, on Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Unwind in Milan
description: A cursory glance at any leading street-style site will invariably turn up images of the freelance stylist Ada Kokosar, a striking blonde whose refined fashion sense and patrician looks call to mind a latter-day Carolyn Bessette Kennedy. The Slovenian-Italian is also gaining notice for her editorial shoots for a range of international glossies. And though shes currently based in New York, she grew up outside Milan and lived there for 10 years. Here, to kick off Milans spring/summer 2015 fashion week, she shares a comprehensive list of her favorite haunts there.

title: Heavy Rains Swell Rivers in Serbia
description: Residents in the Serbian village of Tekija cleared areas of debris as streams flowed through their housing and buried cars in the mud.

title: Valeants Last Shot to Woo Owners of Botox Maker Allergan
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals gets one last shot to woo Allergan owners. The two drug companies have dropped litigation and locked in a mid-December date for a special vote by Allergans shareholders on replacing a majority of the companys board. That vote could set the stage for a $51 billion hostile takeover. Before then, the focus will be on Valeants results. Its the buyers last best hope, assuming the Botox maker Allergan doesnt find another deal first.

title: 36 Hours in Central Park, New York
description: With its endless trails, hidden nooks, museums and nearby night spots, Central Park is that rare tourist destination that is also a pleasure ground for locals.

title: Unsigned Music Competition Names a Winner: Goodbye June
description: Goodbye June, an eclectic Nashville band with Southern hard rock and metal influences, has won the top prize in the third annual Unsigned Only Music Competition, a contest open to bands and solo performers not signed to major labels or their affiliates.

title: 36 Hours: Central Park, New York
description: In 1859, the sanctuary of undulating hills, bridges and lakes taking shape in the heart of Manhattan was described in The New York Times as a noble work, which is so clearly destined to be the honor and delight of New York. Neglect and decline in the 1970s threatened to snuff out that utopian vision of Central Park, but today, after years of restoration, it is verdant and flourishing  the rare tourist destination that is also a pleasure ground for locals. Depending on the season and cycle of life, one might be sunbathing or ice skating, sailing a toy boat or rowing a real one, listening to Shakespeare, rock music or the call of one of 230 species of birds.

title: Official on Arrest of Russian Tycoon
description: Vladimir Markin, the Russian Investigative Committee spokesman, discussed the investigation of the Sistema chairman Vladimir Yevtushenkov on charges of money laundering.

title: When Plan to Help Others Sell in China Fails, a Start-Up Changes Tack
description: In 2012, Frank Lavin, who had raised $5 million from family and friends, went live with an e-commerce platform, Export Now, that was conceived as an easy, low-cost way for American small businesses to sell their goods in China. The basic pitch: Sell into China without leaving your desk.

title: Can the U.S. and China Find Harmony in Pursuing Climate Progress?
description: Jeff Goodell, whos written fine books on big coal and the batch of climate-manipulating ideas known as geo-engineering, has written an invaluable feature on Chinas energy and climate plans for Rolling Stone: China, the Climate and the Fate of the Planet.

title: Classical Playlist: Puccini, Messiaen, Schubert and More
description: PUCCINI: La Fanciulla del WestEva-Maria Westbroek, Carlo Ventre and other singers; Frankfurt Opera and Chorus; Sebastian Weigle, conductor(Oehms Classics OC 945; two discs)The more I listen to Puccinis La Fanciulla del West (The Girl of the West), set in California during the Gold Rush, the more I am coming around to the conviction of many Puccini scholars that this may be the composers harmonically richest and most thematically integrated score. Those qualities come through strongly in a new recording, taken from live performances in 2013 at Oper Frankfurt, conducted with sweep and subtlety by Sebastian Weigle. The winning cast is headed by the gleaming, expressive soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek as Minnie, the title character. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Swiss Pump Maker in Merger Talks With Dresser-Rand
description: Sulzer, a Swiss maker of pumps and other industrial equipment, said on Wednesday that it was in talks with the Dresser-Rand Group about a deal that could be valued at $5.5 billion or more.

title: Pay Gap Is Smaller Than Ever, and Still Stubbornly Large
description: The Census Bureau released new data Tuesday on the pay gap between men and women, showing a statistically insignificant increase. But the news is better than it might seem.

title: Today in Small Business: When You Dont Love Your Company Name
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Jameis Winston Suspended for First Half of Florida State-Clemson Game
description: Florida State said Wednesday that quarterback Jameis Winston, last seasons Heisman Trophy winner, would be suspended for the first half of the top-ranked Seminoles home game Saturday against No. 22 Clemson after he shouted an obscene statement in the student union Tuesday.

title: Have You Tried Selling Products in China?
description: Weve just published a conversation with Frank Lavin, who introduced an e-commerce platform two years ago, Export Now, that was conceived as an easy, low-cost way for American small businesses to sell their goods in China. The basic pitch: Sell into China without leaving your desk.

title: A Time-Traveling Stoppard Play
description: Indian Ink was the last play Tom Stoppard wrote that didnt soon become a New York event. When it opened at the West End in the mid-90s, his Arcadia was a London hit and played in a star-studded production at Lincoln Center. But for some reason, Lincoln Center, which went on to produce his The Invention of Love, The Coast of Utopia and Rock n Roll, passed on Indian Ink, an intellectually lively, time-traveling drama that moves between a poet in the 1930s and an academic in the future examining her life.

title: Panel Urges Overhauling Health Care at End of Life
description: The countrys system for handling end-of-life care is largely broken and should be overhauled at almost every level, a national panel concluded in a report released on Wednesday.

title: Billionaire Placed Under House Arrest in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The house arrest of a billionaire sent shock waves through the Russian stock market on Wednesday in a case that for its sheer size, if nothing else, was already drawing comparisons to the jailing of the oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

title: With the iPhone 6 Plus, Apple Aims for Versatility
description: Its time to make peace with the term phablet.

title: House Votes to Authorize Aid to Syrian Rebels in ISIS Fight
description: WASHINGTON  An unusual but overwhelming coalition in the House voted Wednesday to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant Islamic State, backing President Obama after he personally pleaded for support.

title: Tray Tables With a Contemporary Twist
description: With circular tops and clean lines, a midcentury workhorse enters the modern era.

title: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: N.H.T.S.A. Posts Recall of 25,000 Fiat 500L Models
description: Fiat Chrysler is recalling some 25,500 of its 2014-15 Fiat 500L models because a knee air bag designed to protect the drivers legs in a frontal impact may malfunction, according to a report from the automaker posted on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The report is dated July 30, but the agency did not post it until Wednesday.

title: Clip: The Equalizer
description: A scene from Antoine Fuquas film The Equalizer, featuring Denzel Washington and Chlo Grace Moretz.

title: The ISIS Threat: Teaching About the Complex War Raging in Iraq and Syria
description: Update | March 17, 2015: We have published a related lesson, Teenagers and Extremism: Investigating the ISIS Recruitment Pipeline.

title: Lethal Violence in Chimps Occurs Naturally, Study Suggests
description: Are chimpanzees naturally violent to one another, or has the intrusion of humans into their environment made them aggressive?

title: U.N. Leader Plans Stronger Presence in Ebola Zone
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said on Wednesday that he planned to establish a new on-the-ground mission in West Africa to coordinate the struggle against Ebola, a move that signaled his concern with the response so far and the limitations of the World Health Organizations abilities.

title: Syrian Forces Are Seen Stepping Up Attacks on Rebels as U.S. Sets Sights on ISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  One bomb struck an insurgent meeting place and weapons storehouse. Another hit the Islamic law court. A third hit a heavy machine gun position, but not just any position  the leader of the largest local insurgent formation was manning a gun there, and was killed.

title: Forever Wild at Heart
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was in 1967 that David Lynch had his Road-to-Damascus moment. Then a promising student at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts here, he was working one night on a dark painting of a garden when it seemed to him that wind was rushing out of the painting and the plants were moving. Im looking at this and hearing this, he recalled years later, and I say, Oh, a moving painting. And that was it.

title: Lecrae, a Christian Rapper, Hits No. 1
description: Anomaly, the latest album by the Christian rapper Lecrae, makes its debut at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart for the week ending Sept. 14. The album, Lecraes seventh, is his first to top the all-genres chart; his last album, Gravity (2012), reached No. 3. That said, Anomaly is also No. 1 on two other Billboard charts  gospel, which Lecrae has now topped six times, and Christian, where Anomaly is his fifth No. 1.

title: 20 Years After Its Perfectly Normal, Whats Changed?
description: Its Perfectly Normal, the go-to guide for teenagers and adults on adolescent sexual health and development, was first published 20 years ago, in 1994. Fifteen years ago, the author Robie H. Harris and the illustrator Michael Emberly followed it with Its So Amazing, subtitled A Book About Eggs, Sperm, Birth, Babies and Families (what else could you even need to know?).

title: With New Health Law, Shopping Around Can Be Crucial
description: If you bought health insurance at an Affordable Care Act marketplace this year, it really pays to look around before renewing your coverage for next year.

title: Fed Signals No Hurry to Raise Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is in no hurry to raise interest rates.

title: Costume Institute to Work With Wong Kar-wai in a Show Focused on China
description: With the help of the film director Wong Kar-wai, the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take on its biggest subject yet next year: China and the countrys influence over centuries on fashion, art and film.

title: Fantasy Football: Matchup Breakdown for Week 3
description: One could build a fantastic fantasy football team with only the players who left Week 2 games with significant injuries.

title: Occupy Wall Street Activists File Suit Over Control of Twitter Account
description: Three years after the Occupy Wall Street movement began, an unlikely conflict has emerged over one of the causes most precious tools: a Twitter account.

title: Reading The Times With Billy Collins
description: The former poet laureate Billy Collinss ideal day begins with coffee and poetry. Either he reads someone elses poems or writes one of his own. Then, he says, I feel its safer to enter the larger world! Mr. Collins sometimes reads The Times online, but prefers print on big pages. The pages of The Irish Times are even bigger, like sails or flags, and, of course, knowing how to fold a newspaper is an art, as with sails and flags, he says.

title: N 21: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Adam Wingard Narrates a Sequence From The Guest
description: Music adds to the mysteries found in The Guest, the new thriller from the director Adam Wingard and the screenwriter Simon Barrett starring Dan Stevens. In this video, Mr. Wingard discusses a sequence between David (Mr. Stevens) and Anna (Maika Monroe), the girl whose parents have offered the drifting David a place to stay. Mr. Wingard says the scenes featured song, Haunted When the Minutes Drag by Love and Rockets, inspired the films style.

title: Let the Phone Be Your Political Adviser
description: LIKE it, loathe it or tolerate it with gritted teeth, politics influences our daily lives. One way to keep on top of the latest in political intrigue is on your smartphone.

title: App Smart | Keeping Track of Politics
description: As we head into election season, Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will help you stay on top of news, analysis, and when politicians are using double-speak to make their points.

title: Bad Vaccine Kills Dozens of Children Inside Syria
description: An improperly mixed or possibly sabotaged measles vaccine has killed as many as 50 children in insurgent-held areas of northwestern Syria, volunteer medical organizations and physicians reported Wednesday, forcing the suspension of a large-scale United Nations vaccination campaign intended to stop the spread of measles, rubella and polio.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Alberta Ferretti Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Limits on Testosterone Drugs
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  An expert panel voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday for the Food and Drug Administration to impose strict new limitations on the multibillion-dollar testosterone drug industry, recommending that the agency tighten labels for the medicines so they are not prescribed to men who only have problems related to aging, such as low energy and libido. The F.D.A. often takes the advice of such panels.

title: F.T.C. Fines Yelp and TinyCo for Violating Childrens Privacy Rules
description: Updated | WASHINGTON  Tiny Pets, Tiny Zoo, Tiny Monsters and other mobile apps aimed at children have been downloaded more than 34 million times, often  not surprisingly  by children. But TinyCo, the maker of the apps, failed to recognize that strict rules apply to collection of information from children online, according to federal regulators.

title: Obama Vows No U.S. Ground War in Iraq
description: In an address at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida, President Obama insisted that the United States would not get drawn into direct combat in Iraq.

title: Can Harry Potter Change the World?
description: If youre on Facebook, theres a big chance youve seen a friend list 10books that have stayed with them in some way. And if youve seen such a list, theres a big chance the Harry Potter seriesbyJ.K. Rowling was among the 10.

title: London Fashion Week Street Style
description: Here are our highlights from show-goers style.

title: U.S. Security Officials on ISIS Threat
description: American security officials outlined threats to the United States from the terrorist group the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, during a congressional hearing on Wednesday.

title: Getty Foundation Announces Grants for 20th-Century Buildings
description: As part of a new philanthropic effort focused on the conservation of 20th-century architecture around the world the Getty Foundation in Los Angeles on Wednesday announced the first 10 grants for significant modern buildings.

title: Lashing Out at His Tormentors, at Last
description: As he held a giant hamburger, Mike Hadreas, who records as Perfume Genius, noticed that his nail polish perfectly matched the bottle of ketchup on a restaurant table. When I play shows, Ill do it up more with some lipstick, he said.

title: Off-the-Record Session With the President on ISIS Raises Concerns
description: President Obamas session last week with opinion columnists and magazine writers included some journalistic big guns. And the subject could not have been more important: his strategy on dealing with the terrorist group known as ISIS.

title: Grungy Waves at No. 21
description: Complete with embellished red plaid and army-green jackets, No. 21s spring 2015 collection featured its fair share of grunge. To complete the mood, perfectly messy hair was parted down the middle and kept off the face to reveal a very 90s, bordeaux-colored lip.

title: Fausto Puglisi: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: A Connection as Vital as It Is Toxic
description: Nothing you read about Elena Ferrantes work prepares you for the ferocity of it. And with each new novel in her revelatory Neapolitan series, she unprepares you all over again. The story follows the lifelong friendship-hateship of Lila and Elena, two women from an impoverished neighborhood in Naples, a city that seemed to harbor in its guts a fury that couldnt get out and therefore eroded it from the inside.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Time-Lapse: Scenes From a Marriage
description: A time-lapse video of the transformation of New York Theater Workshop for its production of Scenes From a Marriage, conceived by Ivo van Hove.

title: A Generation of Unintended Laughs
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif.  A relic of a bygone time. The uncoolest show on TV. Inexplicably never-ending, like a Cher farewell tour.

title: On Film, a City Shows Its Noir Side
description: Boston is a city of venerable neighborhoods, rich cultural history and academic distinction. But lately, at least on film, it seems as if its a city of melancholy. It has taken a turn for the bleak on the big screen, where in little more than a decade, films like The Town, The Departed and Mystic River have depicted a sense of corruption and unrest, with characters often at a breaking point. The darkened streets and bad behavior are once again illuminated in The Equalizer, opening Sept. 26 and featuring Denzel Washington as a man with a mysterious past who seeks solace, and an ordinary life, in the city. But trouble is often nearby (mostly in the form of Russian gangsters and crooked cops), and he must take matters into his own hands in an effort to make the dark side of the city a little brighter.

title: Justice Department Urges Banks to Implicate Employees
description: The Justice Department has a suggestion for banks hoping to avoid criminal charges: Rat out your employees.

title: The Fed Is Boring Again. Thats a Relief.
description: WASHINGTON  FOR the last six years, Federal Reserve policy has been sexy, or at least as sexy as monetary policy can ever be.

title: A Musical Gala With a Cinematic Spotlight
description: Its been a little hard to figure out exactly when the New York Philharmonic was officially opening its season this fall. The subscription series concert season begins on Tuesday with a substantive and enticing program at Avery Fisher Hall: Alan Gilbert will conduct Mahlers First Symphony and the American premiere of the compelling composer Unsuk Chins Clarinet Concerto.

title: Magdalena Jasek Transforms Backstage at Alberta Ferretti
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Magdalena Jasek before (left) and after (right) makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Guido Palau.

title: Artificial Sweeteners May Disrupt Bodys Blood Sugar Controls
description: Artificial sweeteners may disrupt the bodys ability to regulate blood sugar, causing metabolic changes that can be a precursor to diabetes, researchers are reporting.

title: Tension, Quiet and Whats in Between
description: Molissa Fenleys dances flourish in wide-open spaces, where the air around bodies becomes just as tangible as the sculptural shapes she creates for her dancers. Its hard to say if that quality relates to her early years growing up in Nigeria, but an uncluttered space like Judson Memorial Church, where her company returned Tuesday evening, provides a luminous setting for the breadth of her movement in her refined and systematic modern dances. Somehow, its like gazing into the horizon of a foreign land.

title: Apartment Accommodations, Hotel Services
description: Travelers who like the less-touristy idea of booking an apartment when theyre visiting a new city but also want the amenities of a hotel can now have both with BeMate.com, a service that launched Wednesday with 2,500 apartments in 10 cities including New York, Miami, Florence, Amsterdam and Madrid.

title: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
description: EDINBURGH  The people of Scotland decide Thursday whether national pride outweighs economic risk.

title: New Genius Grant Winner Alison Bechdel to Write New Graphic Memoir
description: The cartoonist and graphic memoirist Alison Bechdel was in a castle in Umbria as part of an artists residency in Italy when she learned that she had been selected as one of 21 MacArthur genius grant recipients this year. She bought a case of prosecco to share with the other artists in residence.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Fausto Puglisi Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: David Lynchs Paintings and Drawings
description: A new exhibition of the artist and filmmakers work is at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

title: Multinational Companies Court Lower-Income Consumers
description: BANGALORE, India  When General Electric engineers here wanted to develop a more affordable baby warmer for Indias small, private hospitals, they initially replaced the fat, rubberized wheels standard on high-end models with smaller metal ones. They figured it was a quick, easy way to cut costs.

title: Air France Strife Shows Challenges for European Business
description: PARIS  The airline industry, particularly in Europe, is a highly competitive international business. But old, border-bound ways can be hard to eradicate.

title: Gotham City, Emphasis on the Goth
description: The star of Gotham, perhaps the most anticipated new drama of the television season, is not Batman, who probably wont make an appearance (in that form) for the entire run of the series.

title: Theres a Lesson Here; All You Have to Do Is Listen
description: I couldnt have been more skeptical. I couldnt have been more wrong.

title: Consumer Finance Agency Seeks to Broaden Oversight of Auto Loans
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to expand its oversight to include an important player in the auto loan market: non-bank auto finance companies.

title: Artists Take Over Two Outdoor Malls in Massachusetts and Florida
description: As the daughter of two art collectors  the fashion designer Lisa Perry and the hedge fund manager Richard Perry  Samantha Perry David grew up surrounded by Jeff Koons sculptures and Andy Warhol paintings. Now the head of upMarkets, a division of the retail real estate firm WS Development, David realized there was adearth of public art at two of its properties, the luxury shopping center The Street in Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Hyde Park Village in Tampa, Fla. So she called on two of her mothers friends, Yvonne Force Villareal and Doreen Remen of Art Production Fund,to do something about it.We were compelled by this notion because there is no public art within that community, Force Villareal says, and we always strive to bring the vision of contemporary artists to new audiences that have little exposure to such projects.

title: A Devil Dog Tears Into People, and Other Tales
description: Even if youre pleased to be living during the golden age of television, you might find yourself overdosing on oversexed political soap operas or noir detectives with anguished back stories. For those moments when you want something a little different  well, more than a little different  theres Adult Swim, which this week adds two new shows to its catalog of late-night, 15-minute transgressions against coherence and good taste.

title: India vs. Wales at Commonwealth Championships
description: The 4th Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships took place in Glasgow last week.

title: A New Crew Salvages Old Molly Brown
description: DENVER  In a rehearsal room here, the librettist-lyricist Dick Scanlan and the director-choreographer Kathleen Marshall were watching their cast read through a scene when someone flubbed a recently altered line. I know its hard when we change everything, but thats the gig, Mr. Scanlan told the weary-looking ensemble.

title: Offstage Maneuvers Torpedo a Musical
description: Two veteran Broadway producers helped torpedo an Off Broadway theaters premiere of the high-profile musical American Psycho and are now in talks to bring it directly to Broadway next fall, several theater executives with the show said on Wednesday.

title: New York State Judge Rejects Word in Redistricting Ballot Question
description: A New York State judge ruled on Wednesday that a ballot question on the formation of a commission to redraw legislative district lines could not refer to the proposed panel as independent, because most of its members would be appointed by leaders of the Legislature.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Serbia, Israel and Turkey.

title: Embellished Shower Slides at Fausto Puglisi
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: In the Cascades, a Trifecta for Outdoor Enthusiasts
description: It is the outdoor enthusiasts trifecta: spectacular scenery, great lodging and food, and no crowds. Two out of three is easy enough to come by. National Park jewels like the Yosemite Valley have iconic views and great places to stay and eat, but also trails so crowded you wish theyd install passing lanes. Backpacking is a great way to access mind-blowing scenery without the traffic jams, but the quality of your lodging and food will be limited to what youre willing to carry.

title: A Wine Region Flourishes in Central Washington
description: When the apple market collapsed about 15 years ago in the region around Lake Chelan in central Washington State, a handful of farmers decided to make the transition from apples to grapes. Though the apple market has recovered, theres been no turning back for these erstwhile orchardists. Along the shores of Lake Chelan, wineries have been popping up as quickly as bubbles in a newly uncorked bottle of Champagne.

title: Q. and A.: Xiao Zhen on Trying to End Gay Conversion Therapy in China
description: A 30-year-old man going by the pseudonym Xiao Zhen has attracted attention in recent months as the first person in China to file a lawsuit against a clinic offering gay conversion therapy, treatments aiming to change sexual orientation that many medical experts criticize as ineffective and harmful. With the help of the Beijing LGBT Center, an organization representing gay, bisexual and transgender people, Xiao Zhen has sued the Xinyupiaoxiang Counseling Center in Chongqing, as well as Baidu, Chinas leading Internet search engine, for posting the ads that led him there.

title: Total Failure on Auto Safety
description: Here is one clear lesson from the General Motors recall debacle: Congress badly needs to strengthen the federal agency responsible for investigating auto defects. Reports released this week paint a disturbing picture of how regulators failed to identify an ignition defect in millions of G.M. cars that has now been linked to at least  19 deaths and could be responsible for many more.

title: On Ground Troops in Iraq, Obama and his Generals Appear at Odds
description: Speaking to military personnel at CENTCOM in Tampa on Wednesday, President Obama was unequivocal about his unwillingness to deploy ground troops again in Iraq.

title: Proposal Would Require Think Tanks to Disclose Funding by Foreign Governments
description: WASHINGTON  Expressing concern that prominent think tanks may be covertly trying to push the agendas of foreign government donors, the House of Representatives is considering a rule that would require that their scholars testifying on Capitol Hill disclose any such support  a proposal that won immediate bipartisan endorsement on Wednesday.

title: A Bezos Company Will Make Engines for Rockets
description: The space race is shaping up as a matchup of billionaires, with Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, facing off against Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX and Tesla, over the future of human spaceflight.

title: Fed to Cut Bond Buying
description: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said that the Federal Open Market Committee would taper monthly bond buying to $15 billion to keep interest rates near zero.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 12 through 15 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 854 said they were registered to vote.

title: Obama Faulted in Terror Fight, New Poll Finds
description: For the first time in his presidency, more Americans disapprove of President Obamas handling of terrorism than approve of it, as discontent about his management of foreign affairs and the fight against Sunni militants in Iraq and Syria weighs on an anxious and conflicted public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The Moment at Hand
description: Two stories appeared on the website of The New York Times within hours of each other early this month. One reported that the drugstore giant CVS had stopped selling tobacco products in its 7,700 stores. The other announced: Gay Groups to March in St. Patricks Day Parade as a Ban Falls. These two developments had nothing obvious in common beyond their newsworthiness. And yet to anyone who has spent the past couple of decades living on planet Earth, the two stories conveyed the same powerful message: Look how times have changed. What was scarcely imaginable not too many years ago has come to pass.

title: Fiction Long List Announced for National Book Awards
description: The long list of nominees for the 2014 National Book Award for fiction, due to be released on Thursday, is an eclectic collection that includes two debut volumes of short stories, a first novel from the lead singer and songwriter for the indie folk rock band the Mountain Goats and a dystopian novel, as well as works from literary heavyweights including Jane Smiley, Marilynne Robinson and Richard Powers.

title: Tracking a Microtrend Among Affluent Parents
description: Penelope Green, a Home section correspondent, writes about parents who buy second homes in order to be closer to their children at boarding schools.

title: Punishment or Child Abuse?
description: WASHINGTON  THE indictment last week of the N.F.L. player Adrian Peterson by a Texas grand jury for reckless or negligent injury to a child has set into relief the harmful disciplinary practices of some black families. Mr. Peterson used a switch, a slim, leafless tree branch, to beat his 4-year-old son, raising welts on the youngsters legs, buttocks and scrotum. This is child abuse dressed up as acceptable punishment.

title: On Johnnys Knee
description: My phone pinged.

title: On Eve of Alibabas I.P.O., Senator Urges S.E.C. to Look at Risks in Some Chinese Offerings
description: The Alibaba Group may be preparing for a new life as a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange. But one senator is urging securities regulators to take care in letting certain other Chinese companies do the same.

title: Eddie Adams: 10 Years On, and War Will Never Be the Same
description: A decade after the death of Eddie Adams, does photojournalism risk being supplanted by propaganda or fabricated images?

title: Kent & Curwen: Playing a Game With New Rules
description: Kent & Curwen is an estimable British house that bills itself, on its website, as outfitters to gentlemen of sport. Chunky cricket sweaters, loud polo shirts, fulsomely striped college ties  you know, what used to pass for mens wear.

title: Bringing Beauty Fanatics and Makeup Muses Together
description: BeautyCon, a 3-year-old conference held in Los Angeles, draws thousands of teenage and 20-something women who are hoping to be the next Michelle Phan.

title: U.S. Courts Close 2 Payday Lenders Accused of Fraud
description: Federal agencies have taken legal action to shut down two networks of online payday lenders, saying they made fraudulent loans to unwitting consumers and then used the loans as a pretext to withdraw millions of dollars from their bank accounts.

title: Where Old Friends Show Off
description: In May, the Paris-based Galerie Kreo, which is known for experimental contemporary design and flashy clients like Karl Lagerfeld and Azzedine Alaa, opened a London outpost near Berkeley Square in Mayfair. For its latest exhibition in the new space, Kreo is showing off rare works by old friends, including Jasper Morrison, Pierre Charpin and Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. The exhibition, called Des Formes Utiles, explores the relationship between function and form with restrained interpretations of mirrors, tables, lights and ladders, including Studio Wieki Somerss flowerlike Aoyama Lamp ($42,000, edition of six), and Konstantin Grcics London Calling a Shaker-pure set of oak library steps (about $46,000, edition of eight).

title: Curiously Recycled
description: The Los Angeles artist Clare Graham, refashions humble materials in interesting ways  say, thousands of bottle caps wired together to form snakelike sculptures. In Clare Graham & MorYork: The Answer Is Yes, his comprehensive new show at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles, the artist has created his own cabinets of curiosity.

title: Japanese Classics, Every Day
description: Sheridan Coakley, founder of the British furniture company SCP, admires Japanese designers for their mastery of the art of the everyday. With Reiko Kaneko, he has organized Simplified Beauty, an exhibition of specially commissioned Japanese objects displayed in his store in the East London neighborhood of Shoreditch.

title: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler, Design Within Reach, Gracious Home and Jensen-Lewis
description: Broadway Panhandler is discounting some knives, cookware and glassware by up to 62 percent, Friday through Sept. 28, or while supplies last (a set of eight Riedel Ouverture Magnum red wine glasses, regularly $96, is about $60); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), 212-966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

title: A Celebration of Silver, Seen in Ravishing Detail
description: Like ones reputation, sterling silver requires vigilance, lest they both tarnish and lose their luster, writes Murray Moss in the new monograph Georg Jensen: Reflections (Rizzoli New York, $85). Mr. Moss, the design curator and consultant, leaves behind the well-trod path of history and instead explores what makes people want to care for the 110-year-old Danish companys wares.

title: New York City Police Add Security Amid a Call for Attacks
description: The police in New York stepped up security on Wednesday in response to the possible threat of a terrorist attack in Times Square, even as officials cautioned that they had no information about specific plans against the city.

title: Getting Help to Ebolas Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Fiction Writers Take a Rosier View
description: Imagine living in a weird science-fiction story where everything you dreamed up actually came true.

title: Protecting the Barrier Reef
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Succeed in College
description: To the Editor:

title: The New York Times/CBS News Poll
description: A New York Times/CBS News Poll finds support for United States airstrikes in Iraq and Syria, but also shows how torn Americans are about wading back into war in the Middle East.

title: Stars and Lighthouses
description: To the Editor:

title: Japans Nuclear Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforming Rikers Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Roy McMakin: His Art Is Anothers Furniture
description: The 58-year-old artist Roy McMakin insists that he is not a furniture designer. He calls his latest introductions  a chair, a sofa, two tables, a cabinet and a chest of drawers, all on display at the Lora Reynolds Gallery in Austin, Tex.  a grouping, not a collection. Mr. McMakin developed a cult following for his functional art after opening Domestic Furniture, a Los Angeles showroom, in 1987. He shut its doors in 1994, moved to Seattle and, three years later, founded Big Leaf Manufacturing, a workshop that produces Domestic Furniture designs. He now lives in San Diego while maintaining architecture and design studios in Seattle. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Thursday's Matchup: Buccaneers (0-2) at Falcons (1-1)
description: 8:25 p.m., CBS

title: San Francisco Official Says He Takes Truvada to Prevent H.I.V., and More Gay Men Should, Too
description: Scott Wiener, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, made an unusual public announcement on Wednesday: He takes Truvada, a daily antiviral pill, to greatly reduce his risk of contracting H.I.V.

title: Should We Remove Grab Bars from the Bathroom Before Trying to Sell?
description: Q. Our bathroom is outfitted with grab bars, anti-slip mats and other safety features. Should we remove them before trying to sell?

title: At First Blush
description: LOS ANGELES  Gigi Gorgeous needed a break.

title: F.T.C. Wary of Mergers by Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON  As hospitals merge and buy up physician practices, creating new behemoths, one federal agency is raising a lonely but powerful voice, suggesting that consumers may be victimized by the trend toward consolidation.

title: Brokers Countersue to Thwart Suits by Unhappy Investors
description: Ron Vaerewyck was making his way through the convention floor at the annual World Money Show in Orlando, Fla., in February 2008 when he stopped by the booth for Reef Securities of Richardson, Tex.

title: For Casting of Shark Tank, Cities Are Smaller, but Ideas Stay Big
description: AUDITIONS for Shark Tank, the ABC show where aspiring entrepreneurs pitch their businesses as an investment opportunity to a panel of successful businesspeople, called sharks, are usually held in major cities like Chicago, Los Angeles and New York.

title: Getting Pay and Credit for a Legal Education
In Debut, Benghazi Panel Leaves Sparring to Others
description: WASHINGTON  The special House committee on Benghazi seemed determined to prove on Wednesday that it would not be the bickering, partisan panel that many expected. But the outside political class did not get the memo.

title: Housewares by Modern Architects
description: The designs of modernists like Le Corbusier, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Frank Lloyd Wright are like the classics of rock n roll: groundbreaking works that inspired legions of followers.

title: Five Years Later, Chryslers Gamble on Ram Trucks Is Paying Off
description: WARREN, Mich.  In December, the sprawling, four million-square-foot factory here where workers assemble Ram pickup trucks, along conveyors that weave for more than 30 miles, suddenly went quiet.

title: Poor Fitness in Military Poses Peril, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  An increase in the number of overweight and out-of-shape service members who are unable to run long distances or perform physical tasks like push-ups poses a direct threat to the United States ability to defend itself, a group of retired military leaders fighting for improved childhood nutrition said Wednesday.

title: The Catwalk Serves as a Billboard
description: AS FASHION WEEK(S) churn on, one talking point that continues to dominate conversation is the corporatization of fashion.

title: Shopping for Flair? The Moto X Smartphone Fits the Bill
description: MOST phones look about the same. Without a case, they are flat rectangles with slightly rounded edges and they come in black, white and occasionally gold.

title: On Spanking and Abuse
description: According to reports about the Adrian Peterson felony abuse indictment, Petersons 4-year-old son pushed another of Petersons sons off a video game. Peterson then retrieved a tree branch  called a switch  stripped off its leaves, shoved leaves into the boys mouth and beat him with his pants down until he bled.

title: Gap Between Manhattans Rich and Poor Is Greatest in U.S., Census Finds
description: Manhattan is becoming an island of extremes.

title: Sunrise, Sunset and a Space for Each
description: When a design-conscious couple from Los Angeles moves to New York, the last thing youd think would appeal to them is what some people refer to as a developer special: a big new building with little to distinguish it beyond the fact of its newness.

title: Life With Hundreds of Birds
description: Michele Raffin has hundreds of birds in her California backyard, also known as Pandemonium Aviaries, where she cares for talkative parrots and is breeding endangered pigeons.

title: 362 Birds, and Unruffled
description: LOS ALTOS, Calif.  Michele Raffins approach to life, love and especially birds has changed dramatically since the day nearly 15 years ago when she stopped to rescue an injured dove by the side of a road.

title: Venezuela: Move to Revoke Actresss Citizenship
description: The government said Wednesday that it would seek to revoke the citizenship of the actress Maria Conchita Alonso, left, a fervent critic of its socialist-inspired policies. Ms. Alonso was born in Cuba and moved to Venezuela as a child, becoming a naturalized citizen. She has lived for years in the United States. The Interior Ministry will take judicial action to revoke her citizenship, according to the Information Ministry website. In May, Ms. Alonso said in an interview with the Voice of America, I wish that the United States would invade with bullets to remove all those wretched communists from Venezuela. Venezuela is mired in an economic crisis, with inflation of 63 percent a year and shortages of basic goods, problems for which the government frequently blames its opponents. Ms. Alonso competed in the Miss Venezuela pageant in 1975 and has appeared in many films, including Predator 2.

title: Miss New Yorks Red-Cup Juggling
description: On Sunday, the Miss America pageant crowned its latest winner, Kira Kazantsev, the third consecutive winner from New York (labeled a three-peat by Twitter users). For the talent portion, Ms. Kazantsev sang Pharrell Williamss Happy while tapping and flipping a red plastic cup, a routine that some assumed was inspired by the 2012 musical comedy Pitch Perfect, starring Anna Kendrick as an a cappella singer. Others thought it looked like a college drinking game. Making matters worse, the following tidbit appeared on the screen during her performance: Loves anything Jane Austin. This misspelling of the renowned authors name added to the barrage of tweets.

title: New York City Council Hears Push for Benefits by Jazz Veterans
description: In the middle of a City Council committee hearing at City Hall on Wednesday, notes began to stream, slowly and unexpectedly, from a flugelhorn, alternating between blares and warbles, but unmistakably forming the spiritual Nobody Knows the Trouble Ive Seen.

title: Wisconsin: Full Court Asked to Halt Voter ID Law
description: Opponents of a law requiring voters to provide photo ID asked a federal appeals court on Wednesday to reconsider a ruling last week that cleared the way for the law to take effect for the Nov. 4 elections. Arguing that the abrupt reinstatement of the requirement would create chaos and confusion and prevent some residents from voting, the opponents, including the American Civil Liberties Union, asked that judges from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit re-examine the decision last week by a three-judge panel of the court. The law was first approved by lawmakers and signed by Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican, in 2011, though it has been delayed since 2012 as legal fights play out in state and federal courts.

title: Michigan: One-Week Delay Ordered in Bankruptcy Trial
description: A trial on Detroits plan for erasing debts and remaking city services will be delayed for a week, a federal bankruptcy judge said on Wednesday. The delay, which will halt testimony in the case for all of next week, is to give the remaining critics of Detroits plan a chance to rework their legal case after another critic, Syncora Guarantee, a bond insurer, unexpectedly dropped its objections and settled with the city. The trial over the exit plan proposed by Detroit, the largest city ever to seek bankruptcy protection, began on Sept. 2 and is scheduled to run into October.

title: A Sobering Future for New Yorks Dive Bars
description: As a dive bar should, the Subway Inn smelled like stale beer and sweat one Thursday last month as a throng of well-wishers crowded three deep for a last hurrah.

title: Fashion Photography Is the Art Worlds Rising Star
description: Fashion photographers are the new painters, Peter Lindbergh said as he prepared the show of his dramatic black-and-white images that opened last week at the Gagosian Gallery in Paris. Who would have guessed in the heady 1980s  when Mr. Lindberghs new, natural images of Linda Evangelista, Cindy Crawford and others created the supermodel  that the art world would lose its disdain for fashion photographys commercialism?

title: Sex Is the Least of It
description: Let us all contemplate the fact that Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina is running for re-election unopposed.

title: A Shortcut to Comic Celebrity
description: Josh Ostrovsky, who is Jewish and weighs a paunchy 250 pounds, would prefer that you not call him a fat Jew.

title: Rob Ford to Be Treated for Unusual Cancer
description: OTTAWA  Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto will soon undergo chemotherapy for treatment of two unusual, malignant tumors, a physician told reporters on Wednesday.

title: A Dutch Town Honors U.S. Soldiers Wartime Bravery at Germanys Edge
description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands  When Henny Meijer was 2 years old, his hometown was liberated by American soldiers. Hearing the commotion on the street, his 8-year-old brother ran to greet them with a neighbor  a woman who was handing the Americans orange flowers  when a soldier threw himself on the boy.

title: Tests for a Still Broken Iraq
description: It is tempting, but shortsighted, to believe that the recently reconfigured government in Iraq is a dependable ally in the new military operation the Obama administration began this week to take back territory seized by the Islamic State, a Sunni extremist group.

title: London Fashion Week Accessories
description: Fur slippers at Simone Rocha, ear-cuffs at Julien MacDonald and more details from the spring 2015 shows.

title: Closing Arguments Ahead in Rowlands Corruption Trial
description: NEW HAVEN  As former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut politely observes the proceedings from his front-row seat, the gloves have been coming off all week here at his federal trial on corruption charges, with both sides trying to tie up loose ends before the closing arguments on Thursday.

title: Calling Ripleys: The Fanny Pack Is Cool, and More Shopping News
description: The fanny pack as we know it has been reinvented as a belt bag. Now a city-sleek accessory, the old-time tourist essential could make going hands-free cool, and everyday practical. It will look best with other streamlined basics: slung low over a striped shirt and jeans, say, or a leather skirt and crisp button-down.

title: Vacillations on Discipline Put a Behemoth on Shaky Ground
description: We take for granted that politicians are compromised at best, corrupt at worst, and that misconduct within the financial industry is a given.

title: Kerry on U.S. Strategy Against ISIS
description: Secretary of State John Kerry reiterated to lawmakers that there would be no American ground troops in combat against ISIS fighters in Iraq and Syria.

title: V.A. Official Acknowledges Link Between Delays and Patient Deaths
description: WASHINGTON  In a contentious hearing before Congress, a senior official from the Department of Veterans Affairs watchdog agency acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that delays in care had contributed to the deaths of patients at the departments medical center in Phoenix.

title: Elizabeth Whelan, Who Challenged Food Laws, Dies at 70
description: Elizabeth Whelan, an epidemiologist who crusaded against what she called junk science by starting a national organization to question conventional wisdom on food, chemicals and the environment, died on Sept. 11 in Manahawkin, N.J. She was 70.

title: At Bushwig, Pushing the Boundaries of Drag
description: In the age of RuPauls Drag Race, it may seem that all aspiring drag stars are slick and waxed, not a polyester hair out of place. But not in Bushwick.

title: Scotland: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
description: In the week ahead of a historic referendum on Scottish independence, campaigners from both sides took to the streets to sway the vote, which could break a three-century-old union.

title: Biden, a Catholic School Kid, Praises Nuns Under Fire From the Vatican
description: DES MOINES  At a Vatican meeting a few years ago, Pope Benedict XVI unexpectedly asked Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for some advice. You are being entirely too hard on the American nuns, Mr. Biden offered. Lighten up.

title: Amazon Refreshes Its Kindle Line
description: It has been said that people dont want tablets, they want iPads.

title: Police Marksmanship Contest Held in Albuquerque Amid Protests
description: ALBUQUERQUE  At a shooting range on the western edge of this mountain-fringed city, a police marksmanship competition being held this week has all the trappings of a tailgate party in the desert: Men smoke cigars in the parking lot and lounge under tents in foldout chairs. The scent of hot dogs wafts across the range as bullets sail into human-shaped targets.

title: Milwaukee Brewers Look to End Season of Extremes on an Upswing
description: ST. LOUIS  The last time the Milwaukee Brewers reached the postseason, in 2011, Kyle Lohse pitched for the St. Louis Cardinals. At this point in that season, the Cardinals outlook was bleak.

title: Screening a Show and Shaking the Tree
description: You are not who you think you are. That seems to be the main point of Finding Your Roots, a PBS series that begins its second season next Tuesday. On the show, Henry Louis Gates Jr., one of the hardest working academics in show business, traces the lineage of notable guests to uncover secrets and shake family trees.

title: For Posteriors Sake
description: When Jen Selter couldnt decide what to do with her life after graduating from high school, she got a job working at the front desk of a gym. She took to working out after shifts and posting photos of herself in colorful fitness clothes. About a year ago, the photos started gaining a certain kind of fame for what many considered Ms. Selters best asset: her bottom.

title: From D.C. to Syria, a Mess
description: President Obamas rollout of a military campaign in Syria against the Islamic State gets messier by the day.

title: Leaving Home, but Not the Folks
description: A few weeks ago, boarding school students in the Northeast began moving into their dorm rooms armed with all the usual clatter. The Indian print tapestries, the athletic gear, the odd beanbag chair. But a few of them arrived with some extra equipment: their parents.

title: Deciding Who Gets Overtime Pay
description: Under federal labor law, if you are an employee making, say, $11.50 an hour  which passes for decent pay these days in many jobs  you would be entitled to time-and-a-half for every hour beyond 40 hours a week. However, if you earn $460 a week in salary you often are not entitled to time-and-a-half for overtime no matter how many extra hours you work  even though your salary works out to $11.50 an hour.

title: Altered to Withstand Herbicide, Corn and Soybeans Gain Approval
description: The Agriculture Department has approved the commercial planting of corn and soybeans genetically engineered to survive being sprayed by the herbicide known as 2,4-D, according to documents it posted on a federal regulatory website on Wednesday.

title: Busy Days Precede a March Focusing on Climate Change
description: In a three-story warehouse in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, hundreds of people are working to turn the Peoples Climate March planned for Sunday into a visual spectacle.

title: With New Leader After Bridge Scandal, Port Authority Moves to Add Transparency
description: One year after an intentional tie-up of traffic at the George Washington Bridge highlighted its secretive culture, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey lurched out of the shadows on Wednesday.

title: Unrest by Palestinians Surges in a Jerusalem Neighborhood
description: JERUSALEM  Mohamad Sami, a Palestinian truck driver, was eager to offer a tour of the landmarks from this summers violence in his neighborhood, Issawiya.

title: Store Openings, New Collections and Sales Starting Sept. 18
description: Openings And Events

title: A Host of Possible Objections to Expanded Airstrikes in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS  Airstrikes on Iraq were a fairly easy sell. The government in Baghdad asked for help in combating the Islamic State, and the United States answered its request.

title: Surrogates and Couples Face a Maze of Laws, State by State
description: When Crystal Kelley, a Connecticut woman who had signed a contract to bear a baby for a couple in her state, was five months pregnant, a routine ultrasound showed that the fetus had a cleft palate, a brain cyst and heart defects. The couple for whom she was carrying the baby asked her to have an abortion, offering to pay her $10,000 to do so.

title: Jack Wayman, Impresario of Consumer Electronics Show, Dies at 92
description: Jack Wayman, a sales executive who saw the future and said it was consumer electronics, organized the industrys first trade show in the era of black-and-white television and fought Hollywoods endeavor to smother the videocassette-recorder business, died on Aug. 30 in Boulder, Colo. He was 92.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 17, 2014
Obama Promises Again Not to Send Ground Troops to Fight Militants
description: TAMPA, Fla.  President Obama promised a military audience here on Wednesday that he would not send troops into combat in the campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq, as the White House sought to dispel growing confusion over exactly what role American soldiers are going to play on the battlefield in the unfolding operation.

title: Fractured Ownership Troubles Atlanta Hawks
description: ATLANTA  Two weekends ago, with sports fans focused on the opening of the N.F.L. season, the N.B.A. and the Atlanta Hawks issued coordinated announcements about an embarrassing development: The teams controlling owner would sell his share after the league became aware of a racially insensitive message he sent to his partners.

title: A Surrogate and a Mother: Partners in Pregnancy Share Their Story
description: Roshael Rose: My interest in surrogacy sort of started a long time ago. I was a young mother, and back when I had my first, people talked to me about options. Adoption wasnt really my thing, but I knew that there were people who had trouble having babies and I knew that someday I wanted to help.

title: After Nearly 23 Years of Legal Struggle, a Conviction Is Reversed
description: Everton Wagstaffe, who refused to leave prison on probation because he viewed it as a surrender of his claim of innocence in the death of a teenage girl, learned on Wednesday that he had prevailed in a struggle that he began from behind bars nearly 23 years ago.

title: Brace Yourself, Shes Going to Share
description: Youve heard it before. Maybe youve said it before.

title: Soul-Stifling Jobs in the Land of Plenty
description: Olga, Reina and Juana spend their days in an upstate factory, knifing breasts from chicken carcasses. At night they eat and pray and take Motrin to soothe their aching arms, still wearing layers of sweaters. After the factorys chill, they cant get warm.

title: Places Where You Can Hear a Pin Drop
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I have to spell out my last name a lot, especially when Im on the phone. You might have the same issue. The name Amlen can be heard many ways  Ive had some doozies, including the technical support person who wanted to know if I had invented Ambien  and spelling it out is the only way to clarify things.

title: Womens Views on N.F.L. Dim in Wake of Domestic Violence Cases
description: This time of year, families throughout the Chicago area schedule their weekends around the Bears. Nearly half the citys televisions tune in to Bears games when they play, and an empty seat is rarely seen at Soldier Field.

title: New York State and City Join Effort to Shield Stabilized Leases
description: New York City and state officials have thrown their weight behind an elderly widow fighting to keep her rent-stabilized lease from becoming an asset with which to pay off her creditors, arguing that it would undermine the safeguards that both bankruptcy and rent laws are supposed to provide.

title: Theodore J. Flicker, Director and a Creator of Barney Miller, Dies at 84
description: Theodore J. Flicker, a writer and director who led an influential improvisational theater troupe in New York in the 1960s, wrote and directed the comic film The Presidents Analyst and helped create the sitcom Barney Miller, died on Friday at home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84.

title: Obama Thanks Congress for Vote on Syria
description: President Obama addressed members of Congress at the White House Congressional Picnic after the House voted to authorize aid to Syrian rebels fighting the Islamic State.

title: Sicilian Town on Migrants Route Cares for the Living and the Dead
description: POZZALLO, Sicily  The 18 coffins were placed in two neat rows beneath the late-afternoon sun as the mayor and other dignitaries took their seats inside the hilltop cemetery. A Catholic vicar-general offered a homily. A Muslim imam unfurled a small rug and knelt in prayer, his singsong voice rising above the stone mausoleums toward the blue of the Mediterranean.

title: Moving Up the Ranks
Somber Note for Yankees After Victory Ends Trip
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  On Wednesday afternoon, a day after the Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays almost came to blows in an ugly dugout-clearing incident, Joe Girardi went to his starting pitcher, Brandon McCarthy, and told him to put the whole matter aside.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 17, 2014
description: These people have nobody. So I thought, At least they can have me.

title: Ad Duel in Governors Race Turns Toward the Trivial

He pursues the ball like Alshon Jeffery and changes direction like Brandon Marshall and strides like Santonio Holmes. Powell dons a pinny adorned with the number of whichever Chicago receiver he is tasked with simulating and then, for that play, becomes him.

title: Art Man of Alcatraz
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Judging from the large bags of colorful Legos on the floor and dozens of plastic base plates piled on tables, this room could have been the activities station for a well-funded summer camp. And the five women and men drifting in and out, slicing open boxes and rooting around for the right size toy bricks, were young enough to pass as camp counselors.

title: Independence Referendum Is a Win for Scotlands Children
description: GLASGOW  The people of Scotland will make a momentous decision on Thursday about the fate of a 307-year-old union. They will vote yes or they will vote no on the question of whether Scotland should become a country independent from Britain. There has been much rhetoric on both sides of the divide about the potential ill effects of separation (or not) on Scottish children. Everyone agrees that nothing less than the well-being of future generations is at stake. And yet it is worth noting, amid the crossfire, that one effect of the referendum on our children is overwhelmingly positive: They are experiencing participatory democracy at its height.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 7 P.M. (NBC Sports) CENTRAL PARK HORSE SHOW Some of the worlds best show jumpers and dressage riders  among them, Jessica Springsteen, the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patti Scialfa, and Georgina Bloomberg, above, a daughter of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Susan Brown  compete against a backdrop of the New York City skyline in this four-day event, held for the first time at Trump Wollman Rink in Central Park. The competition begins with the $200,000 Central Park Grand Prix, followed by the 1.45-meter speed class on Friday, the dressage challenge on Saturday and polo on Sunday.

title: Updates on the Scottish Independence Referendum
description: After voters streamed to the polls in great numbers to vote on an independence referendum in Scotland Thursday, The Times is tracking the counting of the ballots, which is expected to stretch into the early hours of Friday morning. (Estimates vary, but the final tally is expected to be announced after 6 a.m. local time, or 1 a.m. Eastern time.)

description: EDINBURGH  Voters in Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum that had threatened to break up the 307-year union between them, according to projections by the BBC and Sky News early Friday.

title: Beijing Police Say Uniform Vendor Instigated Veterans Protests
description: Updated, 4:44 a.m. ET| The Beijing police said on Thursday that they had arrested a man they accused of stirring up disgruntled military veterans and exploiting their protests for profit. In an announcement posted on their official Sina Weibo account, the police said that the man, identified only by his surname, Liu, had sold imitation uniforms for the veterans to wear during their protests, earning the equivalent of thousands of dollars.

title: We Can Save the Caribbeans Coral Reefs
description: PARROTFISH eat algae and seaweed. These brightly colored fish with beaklike mouths inhabit coral reefs, the wellsprings of ocean life. Without them and other herbivores, algae and seaweed would overgrow the reefs, suppress coral growth and threaten the incredible array of life that depends on these reefs for shelter and food.

title: How Gary Harts Downfall Forever Changed American Politics
description: On a scalding July day five years ago, I found myself hiking in Red Rocks Park, just outside Denver, with Gary Hart. The copper cliffs were brilliantly lit in the midday sun, which burned our uncovered heads as we trudged up a steep incline toward the amphitheater that Franklin Roosevelts Works Progress Administration ingeniously carved into the boulders.

title: Your Surgeon Seems Qualified, but Can He Type?
description: Like many clinics nationwide, my surgery office recently started using electronic medical records. Headaches and glitches abound, but over all, it has been a godsend: no more lost forms, deciphering lousy handwriting or waiting endlessly for someone to pull the chart if you want to look up a patient. Everythings in one centralized computer system, accessible anywhere.

With residents of Scotland going to the polls to vote for independence, with Alibaba expected to price its huge initial public offering and with investors still puzzling over the latest pronouncement from the Federal Reserve, markets today could be in for plot twists.

title: Work, Love and Therapy, in So Many Bytes
description: The opening images of The Zero Theorem could hardly be more arresting: a man, naked and hairless, sits in front of an oversize computer screen in surroundings that are at once archaic and futuristic. The technology is advanced, while the dcor hovers somewhere between late Victorian and mid-20th-century modern. The mans name, which people often forget or get wrong, is Qohen Leth. He lives in an abandoned church and commutes on foot through chaotic city streets to a soul-crushing job doing something with data for a corporation owned by an elusive Big Brother-like figure known only as Management.

description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  It was not an ordinary political rally, but it has been anything but an ordinary election.

title: A Poets Advice to Go Ahead & Like It
description: In our digital era of numbly clicking like as we impassively watch our friends lives scroll by on Facebook and Instagram, along comes an analog antidote: Go Ahead & Like It, a new art book/self-help guide by the Los Angeles poet Jacqueline Suskin. The 29-year-old is well known around town for Poem Store, a self-described performance poetry piece she sets up at farmers markets, events and weddings. To create each poem, she asks for a subject and then briskly pecks out evocative lines on a vintage Herms typewriter in exchange for whatever amount the recipient deems it to be worth.

description: How do certain celebrities wind up in the front row at fashion shows? Trying to make sense of front-row celebrity seat assignments is a recurring question as the third round of spring 2015 shows races along in Milan.

title: Visa to Evaluate Stake in Monitise, a British Mobile Payment Processor
description: LONDON  Shares of Monitise, a British mobile payment developer and processor, lost more than a quarter of their value on Thursday after Visa said it was considering its options regarding its stake in the company.

title: A Straw Purchaser Gets 8 Years in Prison
description: Dawn Nguyen, 25, was sentenced on Wednesday to eight years in federal prison for being the straw purchaser of guns that were later used to kill two upstate New York firefighters.

title: John Lahr: By the Book
description: The author of Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh is not a fan of science fiction. Life on earth is mysterious and terrifying enough.

title: Id Walk 1,700 Miles With a Camel
description: Tracks, a high-mileage, low-energy story about an Australian woman, her trusty dog, four charming camels and the siren call of adventure, comes coated in a layer of sand. At times, the sand rolls on and on like an endlessly unfurling, magically variegated carpet that shifts from blood red to burnt sienna, pale pink and dung brown. At other times, it violently rises off the desert floor, swirling and churning into dusty whirlpools. The adventurer, Robyn Davidson (Mia Wasikowska), may blink  at the sandy dust and one deranged hallucination  but she keeps going, at times with nothing other than some cloth between her and a seemingly asphyxiating end.

title: Living City | A Tale of Two Bridges
description: With thousands of bridges in New York State deemed structurally deficient, there are two choices: repair or rebuild. The 60-year-old Tappan Zee Bridge and the Brooklyn Bridge are the latest examples.

title: With Eye on 2016, Christie Resists Climate Change Plan
description: WASHINGTON  As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey explores a 2016 presidential campaign, he is under growing pressure from his State Legislature to rejoin a regional cap-and-trade program that would limit New Jerseys carbon emissions  and likely hurt his chances for the Republican nomination.

title: Skeleton of Tappan Zee Bridges Successor Begins to Surface in the Hudson
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  The shape of the new Tappan Zee Bridge is emerging from the green-gray waters of the Hudson River.

title: Scotland, Self-Interest and Self-Government
description: From the perspective of Americas national interest, the prospect of an independent Scotland which could, though probably wont, become a reality after todays referendum vote  has relativelylittle to recommend it. Scottish secession would hardly be disastrous for the U.S., but it would come with all sorts of modest downsides: It would weakenour most reliable ally for the long term and create an immediate (if likely manageable) crisis at a time when the world is quite sufficiently unstable already; it would lead to various military and strategic headaches(again: none insurmountable, but not ideal right now); and it would sow further instability in secession-prone regions across Europe where political differences might not be settled quite so civilly (including one within the British Isles themselves).

title: Li Na, Two-Time Major Winner, Is Retiring With Knee Woes
description: The former French Open and Australian Open champion Li Na, the first Asian player to win a Grand Slam singles title, announced Friday morning in Beijing that she was retiring because of worsening of knee injuries that had plagued her throughout her career.
