description: Jonathan Weisman, a congressional reporter in Washington, wrote todays front-page article on the Houses vote to authorize aid for the rebels in Syria. Mr. Weisman shares how he separated the facts from the spin to cover both sides of the debate.

title: Womens Project Theater to Present New Laura Eason Play
description: The world premiere of a new play by Laura Eason (Sex With Strangers) is a highlight of the 2014-15 season of the Womens Project Theater. The season is the organizations first since Lisa McNulty became its producing artistic director in July.

title: Sciences Sexual Assault Problem
description: AS, Norway

title: Fantasy Football: Week 3 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Readers Respond: The Great Unraveling
description: They were the best of comments. They were the worst of comments.

title: Scottish Voters Cast Referendum Ballots
description: Alex Salmond, the leader of the Scottish National Party, and voters, sounded off after casting their ballots.

title: Military Looks March Through the Spring/Summer 2015 Runways
description: Marc Jacobs always manages to have his finger on the pulse. After his uniform-inspired spring/summer 2015 collection closed out New York Fashion Week, military details  utilitarian pockets, camouflage and desert khakis  have crossed the Atlantic to Milan. No. 21s and Guccis shows, with their 70s and grunge themes, respectively,had green, surplus-inspired dresses peppered into the mix.

title: Behind the Poster: 3 Christs
description: Three paranoid schizophrenics, each of whom thinks he is Jesus Christ, come together in the play 3 Christs, now being staged at Judson Memorial Church by the Peculiar Works Project. The show recreates a University of Michigan experiment by Dr. Milton Rokeach, who had the men live and work together to see what would happen. Rokeachs published study, The Three Christs of Ypsilanti, is the basis for the stage adaptation by S. M. Dale and Barry Rowell.

title: Fingers Stand In for Forks
description: The description ground mildly spiced chickpeas does not prepare you for what arrives, which looks less like a self-sufficient dish than a sauce or a displaced soup, as red as the desert. Its not that mild, either, thanks to a nice shock of berbere, an Ethiopian spice blend dominated by red chile, with gentler warming notes from cinnamon, cardamom and cloves.

title: Poroshenko Makes Appeal to U.S. Congress
description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine has appealed to the United States Congress for support of his strategy in handling Russian-backed separatists.

title: Iran and the Coalition of Repenters
description: No one has presented a more articulate case for Iran to Western audiences than the foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. He and President Hassan Rouhani proved that last year when they attended their first United Nations General Assembly after Mr. Rouhanis election.

title: U.S. Aims to Curb Peril of Antibiotic Resistance
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday announced measures to tackle the growing threat of antibiotic resistance, outlining a national strategy that includes incentives for the development of new drugs, tighter stewardship of existing ones, and improvements in tracking the use of antibiotics and the microbes that are resistant to them.

title: To Get More Out of Science, Show the Rejected Research
description: In 2013, the federal government spent over $30 billion to support basic scientific research. These funds help create knowledge and stimulate greater productivity and commercial activity, but could we get an even better return on our investment?

title: Finding Their Gym on the Citys Streets
description: AS dawn began its daily blanching of the bright lights in Times Square one morning, a cluster of early birds cheerfully dragged one another in wheelbarrow formations, pair by pair, up the steps of the TKTS booth. Yawning workers in suits hustled past, while police officers looked on ambivalently. A couple of tourists raised their cellphones to capture the spectacle for posterity, or at least for Instagram.

title: Upgrading to iOS 8 on an Old Phone? Prepare for Trouble, but Do It Anyway
description: Do you have an old iPhone or iPad? Have you been planning on upgrading to iOS 8, Apples newest operating system, which was made available this week? Are you excited about the switch, fancying a free way to have a better-looking interface with new features?

title: Fantex Signs Chicago Bears Alshon Jeffery for an I.P.O.
description: Alshon Jeffery, a 24-year-old wide receiver for the Chicago Bears, had an inauspicious start to his football season this month when he injured his hamstring in a loss to the Buffalo Bills.

title: A Show of Stevie Nicks Portraits by Stevie Nicks
description: The Morrison Hotel Gallery, which specializes in music photography  not only photographs of musicians, but also photography by musicians  will present a show of self-portraits by Stevie Nicks from between 1975 and 1987. The pictures for the show were selected by Dave Stewart, the Eurythmics guitarist, who co-produced her In Your Dreams album.

title: In France, Artifacts of Americas Role in World War I
description: At 3 a.m. on Nov. 3, 1917, as the men of Company F, 16th Infantry Regiment, First Division were mostly sleeping in trenches and dugouts near the French village of Bathelmont, the Germans attacked with artillery and shock troops.

title: Text to Text | The Giver and The Dark Side of Young Adult Fiction
description: The Giver, a powerful and provocative novel, is sure to keep older children reading. And thinking.

title: Pradas Platform Patchwork Boots
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Leader Vows French Role in Airstrikes on ISIS in Iraq
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande said Thursday that France was willing to join the United States-led campaign against the Islamic State, including airstrikes against militants in Iraq, saying the world was confronting unremitting brutality.

title: Confession to Etan Patzs Killing Came Hours Into Interview, Detective Testifies
description: A man accused of murdering Etan Patz in 1979 at first denied having anything to do with the boys disappearance during an eight-hour interview in 2012 with the police. He averted his eyes when detectives first showed him a poster with a photograph of Etan, a 6-year-old blond-haired boy. He said he had never seen him.

title: Hagel on the Fight Against ISIS
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told lawmakers that the fight against the Islamic State would not be brief or easy.

title: Prada: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: New York Citys Unemployment Rate Drops to Lowest Level Since 2009
description: New York Citys unemployment rate fell faster in August than in any month on record, to 7.3 percent from 7.8 percent in July, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: Flower Power Ponytails at Fendi
description: At Fendis spring 2015 show today, ponytails were topped with colorful leather pieces almost as long as the models hair. The pretty flowers even inspired the makeup look; but instead of trying to recreate the exact shade of blue found inthe leather flowers, makeup artists snipped off someof the leather from the headpieces and glued thestripsabove the lash line. Talk about a double-duty hair accessory.

title: A Pakistani Scholar Accused of Blasphemy Is Shot Dead
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  A liberal Muslim scholar who had been accused of blasphemy for a speech he gave during a visit to the United States was shot and killed in Karachi on Thursday, the city police said.

title: Stand-Up Man
description: There are at least two vexing revelations within the pages of Mark Whitakers wonderfully thorough biography of Americas most accomplished comedian. The first is how remarkably unfunny Bill Cosbys countless riffs and bits come across on paper. (Its the Lord, Noah! Right! Sure.) The second is the number of failed or short-lived television series  other than the one that forever altered television  that bear the name Cosby. Both are keys to the mans complicated ascendance.

title: Donating the Body
description: All his adult life, Paul Ward heard his parents say they wanted their bodies given to a medical school after their deaths. They felt that training a new doctor would be a gift to society, he said.

title: Pabst Is Sold to Russian Beverage Company
description: A Russian beverage company said on Thursday that it was acquiring the Pabst Brewing Company, which makes the Pabst Blue Ribbon beer popular with barflies and hipsters alike and other brands like Colt 45 and Old Milwaukee.

title: Clip: A Walk Among the Tombstones
description: A scene from the film.

title: James Morris and Michael Volle to Join Mets Meistersinger
description: They are once and future Wotans: James Morris, who positively owned the role at the Metropolitan Opera for 16 complete Ring cycles, and Michael Volle, who will pick up Wotans spear when the Ring returns to the Met in the 2018-19 season.

title: Clinton Shifts to Domestic Issues, With a Focus on Women
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton has spent the past several months discussing her foreign policy record as secretary of state, but on Thursday she officially dived back in to kitchen table issues during a panel discussion about equal pay for women, affordable child care and paid sick leave.

title: Allergan-Valeant Fight Holds Lessons for All Corporate Shareholders
description: This is quite a horse-choker of a bylaw. And tell me what the defense to that is, Chancellor Andre G. Bouchard of the Delaware Chancery Court skeptically said to Allergans lawyer last week.

title: Security Council Unanimously Passes Ebola Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council, in a highly unusual move, on Thursday declared the Ebola crisis in West Africa to be a threat to international peace and security, unanimously passing a resolution that calls on countries worldwide to urgently send medical personnel and supplies to contain the outbreak.

title: At the Met, Honoring Kimonos and a Scholar of the Same
description: The textiles historian Terry Satsuki Milhaupt had nearly finished her comprehensive book on kimonos when she committed suicide in 2012. Her widower, Curtis J. Milhaupt, heroically completed her work, Kimono: A Modern History (Reaktion Books/University of Chicago Press), and a show of the same title, based on her scholarship, opens on Sept. 27 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and runs through Jan. 24.

title: Forget About Scotland. Crucial Metallica Vote Is Under Way.
description: Cant get enough of Metallica? If thats the case, you probably already know that the band, like many others  the Allman Brothers, Widespread Panic and Pearl Jam, among them  has been making soundboard recordings of nearly all its concerts, available for download at livemetallica.com for the last decade. The concerts are available in a variety of audio formats, mostly priced between $9.95 (for mp3s) and $17.95 (for HD FLAC), with more than two dozen concerts, including a San Francisco show from this year, available free.

title: Man Down
description: There are places in America where life is so cheap and fate so brutal that, if they belonged to another country, America might bomb that country to liberate them. This book is a mesmeric account of such a place  a ghetto near Newark  that asks the consummate American question: Is it possible to reinvent yourself, to sculpture your own destiny?

title: Larry Ellison to Step Down as Oracles Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley just got a little less colorful.

title: Silent Star Gets Full Orchestration
description: A CENTURY after his Little Tramp character first appeared on screen, Charlie Chaplin is remembered for many things: as the derby-hatted, mustachioed comic symbol of the silent screen; as one of the first true international superstars; as an actor, writer and director who helped elevate film to a respected art form even as he enjoyed enormous popular success.

title: 1913: Arguing With Einstein
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: TerraCycles Struggle to Turn Trash Into Compelling TV
description: As we began filming TerraCycles reality-television show, Human Resources, we quickly became aware of the challenges of walking the line between promotion and entertainment. We wanted our clients, customers, vendors, investors and staff to be comfortable with the direction of the show. But we also wanted to keep the content engaging and entertaining enough for viewers.

title: Moyers Says Show Really Is Ending This Time
description: Updated, 5:07 p.m. | Bill Moyers has notified public television stations that his weekly series Moyers & Company will end after the Jan. 2 program.

title: Wheelies: The Lotus Layoffs Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: New-Look M.L.S. Considers a Season Without Chivas USA
description: Major League Soccer unveiled new logos for the league and its teams on Thursday, but it may soon put one of those teams in storage.

title: An Infamous Art Forger on His Most Convincing Works
description: When, in 2011, the Times first told the story of Mark Landis  the prolific art forger who, over the course of 30 years, duped nearly 60 American museums into accepting his facsimiles of art works  the article raised as many questions as it answered. Where was Landis now? Why was he doing this? And did his donations  which he delivered in the name of philanthropy, sometimes while costumed in the robes of a Jesuit priest  actually constitute breaking the law?

title: Moschino: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: School of Visual Arts Showcases Work of Cinema Graduates
description: When the Miser thinks of film schools in New York City, the big two, Columbias (famous alums: Kathryn Bigelow, James Mangold) and New York Universitys (Amy Heckerling, Martin Scorsese) spring to mind. But when it comes to Hollywood credits, another local institution, the School of Visual Arts, better known for its fine arts and design programs, has bragging rights of its own.

title: Net Neutrality Comments to F.C.C. Overwhelmingly One-Sided, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  More than 3.7 million comments poured into the Federal Communications Commission over the four months that it was seeking public input on its proposal for Promoting and Protecting the Open Internet, also known as net neutrality.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Dsquared Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Looking to Adopt, but Finding Trouble
description: The elements are familiar in Alan Whites thriller Reclaim: white, affluent Americans stuck in a lower-income tropical city with police officers of ambiguous morals (one played here by Luis Guzmn); foot pursuits through slums; and car chases with gunplay on winding country roads. Theres even an auto teetering on a cliff as the driver tries to yank the passengers out just in time.

title: Out of the Freezer and Into the Fight Ring
description: ICEMAN

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, show times and ticket information are available at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: For This Con Artist, No Crime That Pays
description: Mark A. Landis, the cadaverous, soft-spoken art forger profiled in the documentary Art and Craft, is not a fictional character, except perhaps in his own mind. In 30 years of deception, he has donated at least 100 pieces  many of them doctored photocopies of small works  to at least 46 museums in 20 states.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: If Youre Unhappy and You Know It
description: HECTOR AND THE SEARCH FOR HAPPINESS

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Concert Not Live, but Always Living
description: Ragnar Kjartansson and the indie rock band the National have made a wonderful thing in A Lot of Sorrow, their six-hour video at Luhring Augustine Bushwick. It is Minimalist in structure: the same song over and over again, yet unimaginably expansive.

title: Arizona Cardinals Distance Themselves From Jonathan Dwyer
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  A few months ago, the Arizona Cardinals teammates Jonathan Dwyer and Larry Foote and their wives flew to San Diego for a Christian couples conference. The men had both played for the Pittsburgh Steelers from 2010 to 2013, and they bonded over their religious beliefs. Foote remembered Dwyer and his wife attending numerous Bible studies together. He thought they had a strong connection.

title: Pop/Rock Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: This Land is Your Land
description: Woody Guthrie wrote the iconic song in a rooming house at Avenue of the Americas and 43rd Street.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: They Know Martial and Other Arts
description: BRUSH WITH DANGER

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Dance

title: Hector and the Search for Happiness
description: A scene from the film starring Simon Pegg.

title: Citigroup Tells Appeals Court of Its Argentina Quandary
description: Argentina is holding a gun to the head of Citigroup, a lawyer for the bank told a three-judge panel in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: Art Listings for Sept. 19-25
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children, for Sept. 19-25
description: New York on Location

title: Beware the Old Sailor Bearing Tea
description: TUSK

title: At Home in War. In War at Home.
description: A story about finding peace during wartime, Fort Bliss turns on the struggles of an Army medic, Maggie Swann (Michelle Monaghan), whos trying to make it back to normal after a tour in Afghanistan. You first meet her while shes dodging battlefield bullets. Soon shes slicked in someone elses blood, and on her way to a commendation. A few beats later, though, Maggie has moved onto the El Paso base that gives the movie its name and is trying to reconnect with her confused, alienated 5-year-old, Paul (Oakes Fegley), after a lengthy separation.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 19-25
description: Photoville (through Sept. 28) Drop-bys are definitely encouraged at this photographic village, held inside and outside 63 shipping containers at Pier 5 in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Joralemon Street and the East River, Fulton Ferry. Presented by United Photo Industries, this is the third year of this free event, which also features panel discussions, workshops and other activities, some interactive. Among the images on display are untitled works like the portrait above by Nicole Wells, a finalist in the Head On Portrait Prize in Australia, and the one by Stanley Greene, top, one of 10 large prints in Zaatari, a collection focusing on a Syrian refugee camp that includes works by other photographers. Doug Menuezs Geek Sex. Adobe Systems, Mountain View, California, 1991, below, from his book Fearless Genius: The Digital Revolution in Silicon Valley 1985-2000, captures a mirthful mood. In a highlight event on Sept. 27 at 6:30 p.m., Tyler Stableford will discuss his photos documenting farmers, ranchers, beekeepers and others across the country; a reception will precede the talk at 5 p.m. Photoville hours: Fridays and Thursday, 4 to 10 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 10 p.m.; and Sundays, noon to 8 p.m. A beer garden is on site, Pier 5 in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Joralemon Street and the East River, throughout the event. More information is available at 718-215-9075 or photovillenyc.org. Its a view of the world from the shores of the East River. (Anne Mancuso)

title: A Down Yankees Fan Gets a Pinstripes Pick Me Up
description: HENRY & ME

title: For Trees Under Threat, Flight May Be Best Response
description: The whitebark pine grows in the high, cold reaches of the Rocky and Sierra Mountains, and some trees, wind-bent and tenacious, manage to thrive for more than a thousand years.

title: A New Way to Build Equity
description: The conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute has found an unlikely ally in the Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America, a housing advocacy organization, to help roll out a new 15-year mortgage designed to allow borrowers to build equity more quickly.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Prada Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Good vs. Evil, Both Bloody
description: Nasty, brutal and unforgiving, A Walk Among the Tombstones is one of those rare contemporary cinematic offerings: intelligent pulp. It was written and directed by Scott Frank, a script writer whose credits include Get Shorty and Minority Report, which means that hes spent time transposing the likes of Elmore Leonard and Philip K. Dick to the screen. Mr. Frank is working with uglier, less pleasurable material here: a 1992 novel by Lawrence Block featuring his continuing character Matthew Scudder. Its a story of good and evil in which men are as tough as nails and women little more than meat. The nail image is a metaphor; the meat less so.

title: In Empires Remnants, Wonders of Survival
description: What are we losing? News reports tell us that the terrorist group referred to as the Islamic State is not only destroying architectural monuments in Syria and Iraq, but is also doing brisk business selling looted antiquities abroad. The specifics of these sales  what has gone where  are so far unclear. But you can get a sense of what might be heading for destinations unknown with a visit to Assyria to Iberia at the Dawn of the Classical Age at the Metropolitan Museum, a big, complicated, magnificently esoteric show of a kind the Met persists in doing better than anyone, even as audiences increasingly shy away from the unfamiliar.

title: Pallbearers Par Excellence
description: Shortly after Judd Altman discovers his wife in bed with his boss, he learns that his father has died. The old mans dying wish was that the Altman family  his widow and their four children  observe the Jewish custom of sitting shiva, even though he was never especially religious. That means spending seven days together in a big suburban house, accepting condolences amid platters of food. For Judd, embodied by Jason Bateman with his usual air of beleaguered responsibility, a family reunion following a marital calamity is a nightmare. For This Is Where I Leave You, Shawn Levys adaptation of Jonathan Troppers comic best seller, its a promising start.

title: Two Ways to Accessorize Power
description: A minaret at sunrise and the soft lament of a Muslim call to prayer. Nobody needs to wait for a location  Damascus, Baghdad, Tehran  to be tapped out in military-style type.

title: Alibaba Raises $21.8 Billion in Initial Public Offering
description: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet juggernaut, raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial stock sale on Thursday, as investors flocked to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating Chinas burgeoning e-commerce industry.

title: Christies to Sell Works From Twomblys Collection
description: When Cy Twombly collectors hear that Christies is planning to sell 11 works from his foundation on Nov. 12 and 13, they will immediately assume they will be a selection of that artists work from all periods and media.

title: Clip: The Maze Runner
description: A scene from the film, directed by Wes Ball.

title: Get Out the Magnifying Glass
description: My eye has brushed over an 1880s stereoview of a hotel at Broadway and Fifth Avenue many times. But I was paying closer attention last spring, and something behind the hotel caught my notice only then: a fuzzy, half-obscured fragment of architecture with the pointed arches and polychromed voussoirs that are a trademark of the Venetian Gothic style, very rare now in New York.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: fake sugar, ebola and longevity. Test your knowledge of this weeks developments.

title: A Life-Size Labyrinth Is the Bane of These Boys
description: THE MAZE RUNNER

title: SAP Buys Concur Technologies for $8.3 Billion
description: SAP said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Concur Technologies, an enterprise software company based in Seattle, for about $8.3 billion.

title: Long Gone, and Still Elusive
description: Under the direction of Janet Eilber, the Martha Graham Dance Company has been on a mission to demystify. One part of that effort is Graham Deconstructed, a series of behind the scenes performances, wrapped in commentary, that take place in the Graham studios. There, on Tuesday and Wednesday, the program began with an open rehearsal of Grahams 1947 Errand Into the Maze, a lucid rendering by PeiJu Chien-Pott and Ben Schultz. But then came something odder: not a deconstruction of Grahams 1953 Voyage, or a reconstruction of it, but, instead, a new Grahamesque work imagining its creation.

title: John Cantlie and ISIS Video Strategy
description: Some background on how video plays a big role in the propaganda strategy of the militant group the Islamic State.

title: Never Prejudge a Pack Rat
description: From its name, the Irish-Swedish co-production Lifes a Breeze might sound like a jaunty romp, but the title actually comes from an air freshener. The device hangs on a wall after the siblings of the symbolically named Small family surprise their dotty mother, Nan (Fionnula Flanagan), by cleaning her cluttered home. The thing is, theyve tossed the mattress where she has secretly stored 50 years of savings, which she estimates at just under one million euros ($1.3 million).

title: A Very Barbie Beauty Look at Moschino
description: Jeremy Scott sent Barbie down the runway in his spring/summer 2015 Moschino collection today. Even without the clothes, the beauty look alone  long, bouncy hair and brightpink lips  was enough to immediately conjure up Mattels classic doll. Backstage, the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni explained that she even wanted the models skin to look like a luxury plastic, but elegant. A touch of M.A.C.Mineralize Skinfinish added what she called a waxy-gloss touch to the cheekbones. And of course no Barbie look would be complete without a little bit of artifice: two kinds of false lashes on each girl, one short (for depth) and one long, Pieroni explained, for extra fluffiness.

title: Home Depot Says Data From 56 Million Cards Was Taken in Breach
description: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | SAN FRANCISCO  Home Depot said on Thursday that the account information of 56 million cardholders was compromised in what is the largest known breach of a retail companys computer network.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Failed Banks Broken Vows Mean Little
description: Where were the regulators when small banks across the country were succumbing to the lure of easy money and embarking on a strategy of rapid growth that would end up destroying many of them?

title: M. Lamar: Negrogothic, a Manifesto, the Aesthetics of M. Lamar
description: With Negrogothic, a Manifesto, the Aesthetics of M. Lamar, the composer M. Lamar offers a bracing alternative to the dispiriting traffic in blandly competent art clogging the New York gallery system these days. Surrealistic, campy and ferociously expressionist, Mr. Lamars multimedia work is a heady blend of music, performance, film and political allegory that grapples with the legacy of slavery in America.

title: Anger Management
description: When our children were growing up (they are in college now), one of our neighbors did not invite our daughter to her childrens birthday parties. My husband insisted we invite all the neighborhood children to our parties. For years, I have harbored anger toward this woman who excluded our daughter. (Who would make a child so miserable?) Now, we are giving a neighborhood party for another couple that is moving away. Do I invite the family I have hated for 13 long years?

title: Bible Belt Soul Search
description: In Roberto Minervinis Stop the Pounding Heart, nonprofessional actors play versions of their real-life selves. This practice, which can blur the distinction between drama and documentary and allow a glimpse at truths otherwise invisible to the camera, flourished in the Italian neorealism of the 1940s and the work of Iranian filmmakers like Abbas Kiarostami and Mohsen Makhmalbaf in the 1990s. Mr. Minervini, an Italian director who has now made three features in rural Texas, extends this tradition with impressive sensitivity and skill.

title: Anissa Mack: Deep Deep Pepsi
description: Anissa Macks abiding interest in Americana has taken many immersive, socially minded forms. In what is probably her best-known project, The Last Full Weekend Each September, she produced entries for every single category of a crafting contest at a county fair in Durham, Conn. Her latest works, however, seem made for a different kind of fair: an international art fair, with its own list of approved categories for visual expression. This shift is depressing, even if its intended as a comment on the absence of soul and authenticity in the art-fair system (and in some places, youre not sure that it is.)

title: Kansas Justices Back Senate Candidates Withdrawal
description: The Kansas Supreme Court on Thursday sided with the Democratic candidate for Senate in his attempt to drop off the November ballot, creating a tougher contest for the Republican incumbent, Pat Roberts, in a race with a strong independent candidate.

title: The Nurse, the Musician and the Video Artist
description: SWIM LITTLE FISH SWIM

title: Harun Farocki: Parallel
description: The death of the German filmmaker and writer Harun Farocki this summer at 70 was a huge loss. Few artists of his international standing so consistently combined formal daring and probity with an agitators temperament. Beginning in the 1960s, his films, using images old and new, staged and documentary, concentrated on examining mechanisms of political control embodied in the chemical weapons industry, the prison system, consumer culture and surveillance or other electronic technology.

title: Alone in a Skull, Talking to Himself
description: Close your eyes. No, no  not right this second. Wait until you get to the theater. You wont want to close them then, but do.

title: Before a Night at the Opera, a Day Backstage
description: Sara Krulwich, The Timess culture photographer, spent a day chronicling the intense backstage work that precedes opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Sophie Crumb and Aline Kominsky-Crumb
description: At 66, the artist/cartoonist/writer Aline Kominsky-Crumb has emerged from the shadow of her husband, Robert Crumb, the underground comics great. Her first solo in a New York gallery was in 2007. Now she is showing new work in tandem with her daughter, Sophie Crumb. Emphasizinganother family tie may not be the bestidea right now, especially since she could easily have handled the whole space.

title: A Life in Journalism, Written in the First Person
description: Gail Sheehys memoir is extremely effusive, mostly about herself. Some of that takes the form of writerly self-congratulation. Some attests to her wild sexual allure. Some consists of exaggerated claims for the importance and originality of her work. And the worst involves editorial choices that could easily have been avoided. Memoirists, you need not include every flattering remark that anyone ever made about you, even in the interest of full disclosure.

title: Cannibalistic Gerbils and a Cryogenic Mother-in-Law
description: SPACE STATION 76

title: Fill er Up, but Hold the Gas
description: Produced in conjunction with the nonprofit Fuel Freedom Foundation, Pump is less a movie than a webpage in motion. But the arguments have an appealing logic for those concerned about the environment. The film explores Americas dependence on oil, from John D. Rockefeller to the dismantling of the nations streetcars, and traces oils effects on the broader economy.

title: In Lilting Singsong, Dublins Burbling Essence
description: James Joyces last recorded words as he lay dying in Zurich in 1941 were, Does nobody understand? If Joyce had his Finnegans Wake in mind, probably not. One of the most famously difficult works of 20th-century prose, the novel is a linguistic mash-up of slang, pun, poetry and nonsense.

title: Share Your Experiences in New Yorks Work World
description: We want to hear about the biggest changes that have taken place in your working life over the last few years as the city has struggled its way out of a historic recession.

title: Man Arrested in California Wildfire
description: Authorities in Northern California have charged a man with arson in connection with a fire that has raged across Northern California.

title: Finding My Own Rescuer
description: Im alive.

title: Angsty Reunion of Callow Collegians
description: Watching Hollidaysburg feels a bit like being conscripted into a focus group. This slight rom-com by Anna Martemucci is the first fruit of The Chair, a contest on the Starz network in which two novice directors vie to make the better movie from the same screenplay. Depending on how well audiences respond, Ms. Martemucci could win $250,000. (Disclaimer: I have not seen any episodes of The Chair.)

title: Pictures of the Day: Scotland and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Scotland, Germany, Washington and Syria.

title: This Land Is His Land
description: YOU say you want to have a close encounter with Woody Guthrie, to follow his footsteps to greatness, to lay eyes on the places where American music history was made: where Woody first met Pete Seeger; where Bob Dylan first showed up on Woodys doorstep; where Woody strummed and plucked with Lead Belly, Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee; where he wrote This Land Is Your Land, Vigilante Man, The Sinking of the Reuben James and many, many hundreds of other songs; where he painted This Machine Kills Fascists on his guitar; where he raised his kids, more or less; and where his short, hard, full life ended.

title: Color, Chemistry and Creativity
description: Color Field painting arrived, in the late 1950s, at a moment of simultaneous exhaustion and innovation: fatigue with the Abstract Expressionist hegemony on the one hand, and radical new developments in paint chemistry on the other.

title: A Sexploitation Filmmakers Work and Relationship
description: Opens on Friday

title: A Day at the Operas
description: We go backstage at New Yorks Metropolitan Opera, as singers, musicians, wig makers, scenic artists and others race to be ready for the big season opening on Sept. 22.

title: On Road to Scotlands Decision, Gambles and Fateful Steps
description: EDINBURGH  Over a Michelin-starred dinner of Scottish venison and red Burgundy in February 2012, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain outlined his strategy for defeating a Scottish independence referendum.

title: Congress Gives Final Approval to Aid Rebels in Fight With ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate gave overwhelming approval on Thursday to the training and arming of Syrian rebels, then fled the Capitol with the House for the fall campaign, sidestepping the debate over the extent of American military action until the lame-duck session of Congress later this year.

title: Labor War Over, Mets Operatic Army Mobilizes
description: The trucks pulled in behind the Metropolitan Opera House, and stagehands began unloading sets for Bizets Carmen, hauling them onto a mammoth elevator, similar to those on aircraft carriers, and storing the disassembled pieces of Spain below the stage between a patch of Scotland from Verdis Macbeth and bits of Paris from Puccinis La Bohme.

title: Reign of Blood and Costume Design
description: A roistering spectacle, heavy on intrigue, murder and fabulous brocaded gowns, Patrice Chreaus Queen Margot (1994) returns on Blu-ray and DVD (courtesy of the Cohen Film Collection), restored to the original 159-minute directors cut awarded the third-place Jury Prize at the 1994 Cannes Film Festival. The Palme dOr went to Pulp Fiction, a title that could have fit Chreaus blood-soaked, lustful chef doeuvre as well.

title: Under New Plan, Iraqs Fight Against Militants May Fall to Its Provinces
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Gov. Atheel al-Nujaifi wants his province back.

title: Black Fathers, Present and Accountable
description: Zun Lee has produced a photo book that challenges the persistent narrative that African-American fathers are absent from their childrens lives.

title: What Were They Thinking?
description: A whole industry has materialized to exploit the fear that were all much stupider than we need to be. Supposed brain-workout apps like Elevate. Pills that claim to improve memory and concentration. On Friday night, the Science Channel works the same territory with a three-part dose of nonsense called Hack My Brain, an Australian import in which a guy youve probably never heard of submits himself to assorted exercises that are alleged to improve neuro-this-and-that.

title: Independent Nation With Films to Match
description: Squeezed between the Black and Caspian Seas, as it was among the Roman and Persian, and Ottoman and Russian empires, Georgia is a small realm with a spectacular natural setting and a proud past. I am a representative of the last living Mediterranean culture that has its roots in antiquity, the self-exiled Georgian filmmaker Otar Iosseliani once told an interviewer in a bit of patriotic hyperbole.

title: Waiting Until November to Weigh In
description: Texas is about to hear from a group of voters who skip the primaries but turn out for general elections. We have the Democrats, the Republicans and the Novembers.

title: Before a Night at the Opera, a Day Backstage
description: As the Metropolitan Opera prepared for this seasons opening night, Sara Krulwich, a New York Times staff photographer, spent a day backstage documenting the intense preparations. Although a labor dispute almost derailed the season, there is no shortage of work to be done: More than 1,500 people work there some days, and this time of year is the busiest.

title: In China, Dreams of Vying for an Oscar
description: BEIJING  The question that hounds every major Chinese film director was put to Jiang Wen at a news conference here this month. Mr. Jiang and his business associates had organized the event to generate buzz over the coming Gone With the Bullets, a gangster film set in 1920s Shanghai that is a follow-up to Let the Bullets Fly, the top earner in the Chinese film industry four years ago.

title: Marta Placzek Transforms Backstage at Prada
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Marta Placzek before (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

title: The Civil Wars Most Famous Clown
description: A clown ran for public office  and no, thats not the beginning of a joke. On Sept. 15, 1864, Americas most famous circus clown, Dan Rice, accepted the Democratic nomination for the Pennsylvania State Senate. And it was just his first foray into politics: Even while continuing his career as a clown, a state convention later considered him as a candidate for Congress, and, in 1867, he made a brief but legitimate run for president.

title: The Senate Ducks a Clear Vote on Aid for Syrian Rebels
description: Its a pretty significant issue, Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska, said angrily this afternoon in the understatement of the day.

title: A Prada Show Worth Waiting For, Purple Sand and All
description: Marc Jacobs had his pink house and Miuccia Prada had her purple sand.

title: Soft-Core Auteurs Love Story
description: Her breasts were quite fantastic, Peggy Steffans Sarno is saying early in The Sarnos: A Life in Dirty Movies as she watches a sensuous scene in one of the old soft-core pornographic films directed by her husband, Joseph W. Sarno. To lie down and still have a breast  most of them just lie flat when you lie down. So she was really good. And I forget her name.

title: This Weeks Movies | Sept. 19, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review A Walk Among the Tombstones, Tracks and This Is Where I Leave You.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: When Medicine Is Futile
description: MY father would have been thrilled to read Dying in America, a new report by the Institute of Medicine that argues that we subject dying patients to too many treatments, denying them a peaceful death. But he would have asked what took us so long. A physician from the late 1950s to the late 1990s, my dad grew increasingly angry at how patients died in this country, too often in hospitals and connected to machines and tubes he knew would not help them.

title: Happy in Tehran Dancers Are Given Suspended Sentences
description: TEHRAN  A group of young Iranian men and women known as the Happy in Tehran dancers, arrested in May for videotaping themselves cavorting to Pharrell Williamss popular dance hit, were informed on Thursday of their punishments: 91 lashes and six months of imprisonment for each.

title: State Invites More Toll Roads Amid More Signs of Resistance
description: AUSTIN  Billions of dollars in toll roads are being developed across Texas, but leaders say the state is still a hot spot for new projects.

title: Events in Westchester for Sept. 21-27, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Death on a Bike
description: She was doing all the right things in the morning commute, traveling in the bike lane, wearing a helmet, following the rules of the road. In an instant, Sher Kung  new mother, brilliant attorney, avid cyclist  was struck and killed by a vehicle making a turn in downtown Seattle last month.

title: Against the Odds, Finding Refuge in El Paso
description: EL PASO  In a seafood restaurant where most of the wait staff and clientele preferred Spanish to English, Dekha Hassan-Mohamed mustered some dry wit that reflected how she was slowly adapting to her surroundings on the Texas-Mexico border.

title: Jackie Cain, of the Jazz Duo Jackie and Roy, Dies at 86
description: Jackie Cain, who teamed with her husband, Roy Kral, to form probably the most famous vocal duo in jazz history, melding popular tunes and sophisticated harmonies for more than half a century, died on Monday at her home in Montclair, N.J. She was 86.

title: Border Agency Is Authorized to Open Criminal Inquiries
description: Federal border security officials, who have been sharply criticized for failing to respond to accusations of abuse by border agents, have new authority to conduct criminal investigations of claims of excessive force or corruption by those agents, a senior Department of Homeland Security official said Thursday.

title: Strategy for Fighting the Islamic State
description: To the Editor:

title: Jimmy Carter Speaks to Students
description: Students asked the former president wide-ranging questions during his annual town hall meeting with freshmen at Emory University in Atlanta.

title: Ex-President Carter in Hot Seat, on Subjects Vital or Not
description: ATLANTA  President Jimmy Carter had already greeted an Emory University student dressed as a skeleton Wednesday night when a woman read aloud the evenings first randomly selected question: What is your favorite ice cream?

title: A Knowing Voice for the Affluent Traveler
description: AN old-school tactic in advertising is getting a prominent role in an effort to generate awareness for a new brand in travel marketing.

title: Ray Rice: A Focus on Violence Against Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving to Cleaner Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chance to Go From Hard Lives to Healing
description: Like too many young men in his East Oakland neighborhood, 21-year-old Shaka Perdue spent the earlier part of his youth living like I was becoming a statistic, as he put it. At 16, he landed in juvenile hall after robbing a pedestrian in broad daylight. Two years later a friend was shot right in front of him in a drive-by. In Oakland, you run into all the people you have problems with, he explained.

title: Cuomo Presses Candidates to Back Womens Equality Act
description: Seeking to pressure lawmakers into fulfilling the campaign promises they make, and to mobilize female voters to support his re-election, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday called on state legislative candidates to sign a pledge endorsing his 10-point Womens Equality Act, which would bolster laws against sexual harassment, domestic violence and salary discrimination.

title: Liberal Jewish Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mobile Payments: Concerns Amid the Hype
Ebola Presents Challenge, and an Opportunity, for U.N. Leader
description: UNITED NATIONS  Ban Ki-moon, in his seventh year as the secretary general of the United Nations, has a full plate of unsolved problems, from a widening war in Syria to conflicts in the Central African Republic and South Sudan  to say nothing of climate change.

title: Global Heat Records Set for Month and Season
description: The globe smashed more heat records last month, including earths hottest August and summer, federal meteorologists said on Thursday. May, June and August all set global heat records this year. Meteorologists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the average world temperature in August was 61.36 degrees Fahrenheit, breaking a record set in 1998. Scientists at NASA, who calculate global temperature in a slightly different way, also found that August was the hottest on record. The month was especially hot in the Pacific and Indian Oceans and Africa, but cooler in parts of the United States, Europe and Australia. For the United States, it was the coolest August and summer since 2009. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration records go back to 1880. But it is more than just one month. It was the warmest meteorological summer  June, July and August  on record for the globe, again beating out 1998. This year so far is the globes third warmest on record. Its not a done deal, but we are increasingly moving toward breaking the hottest year record set in 2010, said Derek Arndt, NOAAs climate monitoring chief. This is the outcome of warming over the long term. (AP)

title: Murder in the Mediterranean
description: Refugees fleeing wars and conflict in Syria, Gaza and Africa know the journey in smugglers boats across the Mediterranean is fraught with perils. Add now the risk of mass murder by their traffickers.

title: Tops in E-Commerce, Alibaba Is Now Taking On Chinas Banks
description: When Jack Ma started a new retail site to rival eBays dominance in China, he called it a fight between an ant and an elephant. Mr. Ma, the chairman of the Alibaba Group, even briefly considered making the sites mascot the ant.

title: Fed Rebukes U.S. Branch of Santander
description: The Federal Reserve has reprimanded the United States unit of Banco Santander of Spain for paying a cash dividend to shareholders even though it was forbidden to do so.

title: As Moscows Landfills Near Limits, Recyclers Do Whatever It Takes
description: MOSCOW  It was five years ago, Andrey Protasov recalls, that he and his wife, Elena, decided to begin doing a very un-Russian sort of thing: recycling their garbage.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Stricter Rules for Truck Driver Training
description: WASHINGTON  Despite being ordered twice by Congress to come up with training requirements for commercial truck drivers, the Transportation Department has yet to do so, leaving Americans sharing the road with big-rig operators who spend only 10 hours in a classroom before hitting the highways.

title: In Closing Arguments, Arab Banks Role in Flagging Terrorists Is Debated
description: What should the role of a bank be when it is forced to operate in areas torn apart by terrorist attacks?

title: George Hamilton IV, Singer Who Gave Up Pop for Country, Dies at 77
description: George Hamilton IV, a clean-cut country singer whose string of wholesome hits in the 1960s, including Abilene and Before This Day Ends, helped him become an enduring draw at the Grand Ole Opry and on concert stages around the world, died on Wednesday in Nashville. He was 77.

title: Fear of Ebola Drives Mob to Kill Officials in Guinea
description: The bodies of eight officials and journalists who went to a remote village in Guinea to dispel rumors about the deadly Ebola outbreak gripping the region were discovered after a rock-hurling mob attacked the delegation, claiming that it had come to spread the illness, a government spokesman said Thursday.

title: Events in Connecticut for Sept. 21-27, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Rush to Invest in Alibaba, but Concerns Linger About Companys Future
description: When the Alibaba Group starts trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, many people may be asking, Ali who?

title: In Georgia, Politics Moves Past Just Black and White
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  A gated community of regal brick homes with impeccable landscaping and $450,000 price tags might seem an unlikely place for a voter-registration drive. The neighborhood, with its swimming pool and tennis courts, evokes stability and a sense of having arrived.

title: The Importance of Taping Interrogations
description: Confessions are among the most compelling and critical pieces of evidence in a criminal trial. Even without any physical evidence tying a defendant to a crime, a few simple words can be enough for a conviction.

title: Iraq: Deadly Attacks Strike Baghdad
description: At least 29 people were killed and more than 65 wounded on Thursday night in attacks in and around the predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Kadhimiya in Baghdad, raising the days death toll to at least 45. The attacks were part of a broad upswing in sectarian violence in the capital since the Sunni extremists calling themselves the Islamic State surged toward the city a few months ago. Bombings and assassinations against both Sunnis and Shiites have become a daily occurrence. Earlier Thursday, at least 16 people were killed and dozens were wounded by four explosions and a mortar attack in and around Baghdad, police officials said. Then in the Kadhimiya area, two car bombs killed at least 24 people. A short time later, a dozen mortar rounds fired into the same area killed at least five more. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attacks.

title: Syria: Opposition Investigates Vaccine
description: Officials of the Syrian opposition coalition said Thursday that they had created a commission of inquiry into the deaths of children in insurgent-held Idlib Province caused by adulterated measles vaccine administered this week. The announcement came amid new indications that the disaster had been the result of negligence and not sabotage, and that it was possibly caused by a mixing of vaccines and an anesthetic used to relax muscles during surgery. The opposition coalition, which considers itself the interim government in that part of the country, said on its website that the commission would submit a final report on Sept. 25. The announcement also said 30 children had died. Conflicting accounts on Wednesday said 15 to 50 children had died within minutes of receiving the vaccine. The World Health Organization and Unicef, which have been overseeing an extensive vaccination campaign in Syria, have expressed concern that the vaccine disaster will discourage parents from protecting their children from measles, rubella and polio. The diseases are making a comeback in Syria because of the war and the collapse of public health services. Save the Children, a charity that helped plan the vaccination campaign and financially supported it in Idlib, said in a statement that it was deeply saddened and shocked by the deaths and expressed readiness to ensure there is clarity about how this tragic situation occurred.

title: New York City ID Cards Coming With Cultural Benefits
description: The municipal identification cards that New York plans to start issuing next year in an effort to make life easier for undocumented immigrants will come with an added benefit so enticing that many others may sign up for them too: an offer of free tickets or discounts at 33 of the citys leading cultural institutions.

title: Events on Long Island for Sept. 21-27, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: After the Bridge Scandal, Fixes for the Port Authority
description: Just over a year ago, aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey deliberately tied up traffic heading to the George Washington Bridge, in an apparent act of political retribution. The incident led to the resignations of several top officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, including its chairman. It also prompted lawmakers in both states to press for reforms in the operations of an agency that controls bridges, airports and other major facilities and is vital to the regions economic prosperity.

title: A Thin Blue Line in Battle Fatigues
description: The nation was stunned at the sight of local police officers armed for a military siege in Ferguson, Mo., when protesters took to the streets last month after the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager. Armed with assault rifles, laser scopes and tear gas grenades, the police appeared primed for a domestic Desert Storm, not a crowd of impassioned citizens.

title: California Chrome, Rested and Renewed, Returns to His Blue-Collar Roots
description: BENSALEM, Pa.  When last seen, neither California Chrome nor Steve Coburn was doing very well. California Chrome, the Kentucky Derby- and Preakness-winning colt, had lost a chunk of his heel and the Triple Crown, at the Belmont Stakes. Coburn, his cowboy-hat-wearing co-owner, was ranting on national television about how unfair it was that fresh horses could skip the first two legs of the series and spoil California Chromes bid for immortality.

title: Events in New Jersey for Sept. 21-27, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Errors and Emissions
description: This just in: Saving the planet would be cheap; it might even be free. But will anyone believe the good news?

title: U.S. Goal Is to Make Syrian Rebels Viable
description: REYHANLI, Turkey  In a secret office near the Syrian border here, intelligence agents from the United States and its allies are laying the groundwork for what they hope will become an effective force of Syrian rebels to serve as ground troops in the international battle against the extremist Islamic State.

title: Restrictions Are Eased for Ex-Preschool Intern Accused of Sex Abuse
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan on Thursday agreed to let a former preschool intern shed his ankle monitor and move more freely about the city while they continue to investigate accusations that he inappropriately touched 13 children.

title: Apple and Amazon Take Baby Steps Toward Digital Sharing
description: Quietly nestled in Apples new iOS 8 mobile operating system is a feature called Family Sharing.

title: With Vikings Focus Fixed on Adrian Peterson, a Suspended Coach Returns
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Seven of the nine satellite trucks were gone, the surest sign the news media contingent at the Vikings practice facility at Winter Park had thinned out. Only seven reporters and two cameramen awaited Mike Priefer, the special-teams coach, at a small lectern outside the locker room Thursday, about one-tenth the number who attended a news conference the day before about Adrian Peterson.

title: Startling Adult Friendships
description: Somebody recently asked me what I would do if I had $500 million to give away. My first thought was that Id become a moderate version of the Koch brothers. Id pay for independent candidates to run against Democratic or Republican members of Congress who veered too far into their partys fever swamps.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 19, 2014
description: The judge is brought down to the level of football players. You dont normally see people talking about those two occupations in the same paragraph.

title: An Effort to Raise Awareness of Sepsis, Led by Families Touched by It
description: One evening in late spring, Ken Fitzgerald, a US Airways pilot, was on a layover in a hotel near Kennedy International Airport when people he had been in touch with by email and phone, but whom he had never met, called him. Would he like to join them for a burger?

title: Congresss Inaction Could Be Legal Basis for Stronger Executive War Powers
description: WASHINGTON  As lawmakers grapple with President Obamas claim that he already has congressional authorization for airstrikes against the Islamic State, legal specialists are saying that even legislative inaction could create a precedent leaving the executive branch with greater war-making powers.

title: When Geeks Rule
Alibaba, With Its I.P.O., Mints Millionaires and Risk-Takers
description: HANGZHOU, China  This leafy manufacturing hub two hours southwest of Shanghai is best known for its scenic lake, Buddhist pagodas and tangy fish-head soup.

title: Comments by Brandon Marshall, Bears Top Receiver, Reflect Complexity of Abuse Issue
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  With the N.F.L. reeling from the recent string of abuse charges against a number of prominent players, the Chicago Bears Brandon Marshall, a five-time Pro Bowl wide receiver, addressed the issue of his own past with domestic violence at an often contradictory news conference Thursday at his teams practice facility.

title: Norway the Slow Way
description: A journey in which I travel north, on the worlds most beautiful voyage, searching for the specter of my grandfather and a glimpse of the ever-elusive midnight sun.

title: U.S. Faces Tough Struggle on Ground to Oust ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  The American air campaign to thwart the advance of fighters from the Islamic State has been the easy part of President Obamas strategy in Iraq and Syria. Soon begins the next and much harder phase: rolling back their gains in Mosul, Falluja and other populated areas, which will require American advisers to train and coordinate airstrikes with Iraqi forces.

title: Titans of Artisanal Food Expand in Crowded New York City Arena
description: By the lunch rush on Monday, the sun had maneuvered around the Midtown towers, warming a bustling three-block slice of Broadway, from 41st Street to 39th. In the pedestrian plaza, Robertas mobile wood-burning pizza oven was firing its sopressata-topped pies, for which the line seemed to stretch back to the restaurants Brooklyn home.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 18, 2014
BMI Reports a Record $977 Million in Revenue
description: BMI and Ascap, two of the music industrys oldest and biggest licensing organizations, are struggling to adapt to the digital age. But both groups are also collecting more and more money as their songs are played on all kinds of media.

title: Brattons Numbers on Use of Force by New York Police Raise Questions
description: When Police Commissioner William J. Bratton appeared before the New York City Council on Sept. 8, he brought three large charts showing a two-decade decline in the use of force by officers.

title: A Nutty Professor Is Dangling Above You
description: David Koteles makes bold claims in the program notes for Teach, Teacher, Teachest. His script, inspired by Eugne Ionescos The Lesson, is a work that bends the rules of communication and explores the breakdown of language. Sure, some of that may have happened. But all I know for certain is that I laughed quite a lot.

title: The Muted Melancholy Between the Lines
description: The dying art of putting pen to paper to exchange news is being celebrated on Broadway this fall. Love Letters, A. R. Gurneys durable epistolary play, in which two actors sit on comfortable chairs onstage and read from the lifelong correspondence between a man and a woman from the East Coast upper crust, has made it to the big time, commercially speaking.

title: After Vote, Obama Addresses ISIS Fight
description: President Obama spoke about the strategy to train and arm Syrian rebels after the Senate passed a measure approving the plan.

title: New Lease on Life
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well, this one was just beautiful. Not to bring up the Troubles of Sept. 11s Patrick Blindauer puzzle, but it just makes me want to weep tears of gratitude when I can dive into a late-week puzzle and have it solve so normally. Add to that the terrific mixture of new and old and relative dearth of junk  except for a tough northeast corner  in Finn Vigelands fill, and we have one super Friday puzzle.

title: A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Take for Granted
description: Everything comes wrapped in silence in The Valley of Astonishment, Peter Brook and Marie-Hlne Estiennes wonder-struck contemplation of the enigma of the human mind, which opened on Thursday night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

title: A White House Position That Stands on a Narrow Definition of War
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama takes the podium at the United Nations next Wednesday to speak to the General Assembly, it will be the third time in three weeks that he makes the case for military action against the Islamic State  a remarkable sales campaign for a reluctant warrior.

title: Lawyers Present Contrasting Motives at Rowland Trial as Jury Begins Deliberations
description: NEW HAVEN  After 12 days of testimony laying bare some of the dirty tricks and subterfuge that can course through political campaigns, the defense lawyer appealed to jurors not to let any distaste they may have for the political process sway them in weighing the seven felony counts against his client, former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut.

title: Florida Man Fatally Shoots Daughter and 6 Grandchildren
description: A grandfather shot and killed his daughter and her six young children before killing himself at his home in north-central Florida on Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Putnam County Rape Case Ends in Acquittal, but the Feud It Incited Endures
description: CARMEL, N.Y.  The rape case that transfixed Putnam County for more than a year has long been decided, but the feud it incited between the district attorney and the sheriff rages on.

title: Once a Star, a Cricketer Is Now an Exile
description: There were no television cameras, and the spectators were not at a manicured cricket ground in England, but seated in lawn chairs at a small park in Brooklyn. Still, Jermaine Lawson bowled as if the eyes of the world were on him at an international test cricket match.

title: Pennsylvania Killing Suspect on F.B.I. Wanted List
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. said Thursday that it had added a 31-year-old man accused of killing a state trooper last week in Pennsylvania to its Ten Most Wanted Fugitives list.

title: Europes Markets Rise, Then Sputter After Scotland Votes No
description: Financial markets in Britain and around Europe generally welcomed Scottish voters rejection of independence on Friday, reflecting relief that the United Kingdom would not face a tumultuous breakup and a prolonged period of uncertainty.

title: In N.F.L. Locker Rooms, Reflecting on the Turmoil
description: A collection of voices from inside the locker rooms as the N.F.L. deals with the backlash over its handling of multiple abuse cases.

title: Michael Korss Locked-Up Luxury
description: For a long time as a private citizen and for some number of years as a journalist, I thought a lot about fashion, both about the individual choices people made when they got dressed in the morning and about what it meant culturally and socially when those choices began strikingly to resemble one another. It became a consuming pastime to see what trickled down and what migrated up  round-toe platform stilettos, for instance, from the world of 11th Avenue at 3 a.m. to the world of Madison Avenue and 65th Street at noon.

title: Corrections: September 19, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Schools in Session for Eager Rangers Coach, and Name Tags Would Help
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On June 13, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault was crestfallen as he sat on a podium at Staples Center, barely able to speak after a wrenching defeat in the Stanley Cup finals. On Thursday, he was as excited as a schoolboy.

title: Against Blue Jays, Derek Jeter and Yankees Show Signs of Life
description: The flashbulbs portion of the season has finally arrived. That was one of the first surefire signs of Derek Jeters final regular-season homestand at Yankee Stadium: the winking lights from digital cameras greeting his every at-bat.

title: The Other Side of a Derek Jeter Hustle Play
description: The young man from the Lansing Lugnuts front office offered an email address for Ken Huckaby. Youre welcome to try, but I should tell you that someone did a story recently on the Derek Jeter thing and Ken kind of regretted it, said Ben Owen, the teams digital media and marketing manager.

title: Former Jets Captain Returns to the Site of Past Heroics and Strife
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Pittsburgh Steelers were troubled by off-the-field problems when they dealt wide receiver Santonio Holmes to the Jets before the 2010 season in a transaction that appeared to revolve more around making a statement about conduct than football.

title: Court Ruling in Kansas Makes Senate Race a True Tossup
A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman
description: Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman size up a smelly fork, a SmartRing and cookies made of bugs.

title: Three Rising Talents Spotted at the London Design Festival
description: While the London Design Festival is known for extravagant installations and special commissions for the industrys top talents, the city is also a breeding ground for new designers and brands. Set apart from the commercial pressures and intense competition of design capitals like Milan, London has an anything-goes attitude that attracts some of the best and brightest. And in various projects there  including the Airbnb-sponsored project A Place Called Home centered in Trafalgar Square  top-shelf names can share the spotlight with those just building their portfolios. Here, a few standout rising talents we spotted this week.

title: Loose Waves Parted Down the Middle: the Ultimate Spring 2015 Hairstyle
description: During New York Fashion Week, we were convinced that braids would be the ultimate spring/summer 2015 beauty look (Donna Karan, Michael Kors, Suno). But today, its become clear that long, loose waves parted down the middle will be the way to wear your hair when the weather warms up again next year. (Or, for that matter, right now.)

title: Word of the Day | reparable
description: reparable \re-p(-)r-bl\ adjective

title: The Muddled Message in ISIS Latest Agitprop Video
description: The latest propaganda video by the Islamic State is horrible to watch, but the message is muddled.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (E!) FASHION POLICE: CELEBRATING JOAN Melissa Rivers leads a 90-minute tribute to her mother, Joan Rivers, above, who died Sept. 4, in which the Fashion Police team of Kelly Osbourne, Giuliana Rancic and George Kotsiopoulos narrates behind-the-scenes footage and outtakes from the show and recounts personal stories. The special crowns an all-day marathon, from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., of Fashion Police episodes, including Ms. Riverss 80th-birthday celebration and her last stints dissecting the good, the bad and the downright ugly at the MTV Video Music Awards and Primetime Emmys.

title: Scotlands No Vote: A Loss for Pollsters and a Win for Betting Markets
description: Thursdays Scottish referendum was interesting not just for what it said about Britain, but also for what it said about the state of political forecasting. Im calling it a loss not only for the pro-independence movement  the No campaign won 55.3 percent of the vote  but also for the pollsters.

title: Milan Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 3
description: How do you know youre at the shows in Milan and not one of the other stylish capitals?

title: After Losing Scottish Independence Vote, Alex Salmond Will Resign
description: EDINBURGH  Alex Salmond, who led Scotlands failed bid for independence, announced on Friday that he would step down as first minister of Scotland and leader of the Scottish National Party later this year.

title: Chinese Fans Celebrate Li Nas Historic Career
description: The announcement by the Chinese tennis star Li Na that she was retiring triggered an outpouring of support from Chinese fans who said they were sorry to see her leave the court but endorsed her decision to stop after her latest injury.

title: Woody Guthrie, New Yorker
description: The celebrated folk singer spent 27 years in New York. Two of his grandchildren, Anna Canoni and Cole Rotante, visit some of the New York locations where he lived.

title: Vivendi Picks Telefnica in $9.3 Billion Deal for Brazilian Telecom Unit
description: LONDON  The French conglomerate Vivendi said on Friday that it would sell its Brazilian telecommunications unit to the Spanish carrier Telefnica for 7.24 billion euros, or $9.3 billion, paving the way for Vivendis exit from the telecommunications business.
