title: Should Texting While Driving Be Illegal in Every State?
description: Arizona, Missouri and a handful of other states still do not have any ban on texting while driving. And most states still allow driving with a hand-held cellphone. This, despite the fact that 3,328 people were killed in 2012 alone in distracted driving crashes, and motor vehicle crashes are the No. 1 cause of death for teenagers in the United States.

title: Black Fathers, Present and Accountable
description: An anxious little girl hugs her father as a shark swims overhead in an aquarium. A man feeds his baby as he keeps a mindful eye on his three other rambunctious children. A single father reveals the tattoo on his forearm that depicts him as his sons guardian angel. A young man poses proudly with the teacher he sees as a father figure.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 19
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images of preparations for the Peoples Climate March and construction of the new Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: China Fines GlaxoSmithKline Nearly $500 Million in Bribery Case
description: HONG KONG  Global multinationals have invested billions of dollars in China over the last decade, with the prospect of selling to 1.4 billion people. But the promise of Chinas growth is increasingly offset by the dangers of being caught up in the countrys anticorruption campaigns and rising economic nationalism.

title: Scotland Says No to Independence
description: The Scottish referendum returned a majority for staying in the United Kingdom.

title: Sportmax: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Cubs Owners Are Rebuilding While Root, Root, Rooting
description: It is a typical Sunday at Wrigley Field, that old Eden of a ballpark, with the sun beaming bright, a breeze blowing in from the lake, a good crowd on hand and the last-place Chicago Cubs already losing, 7-0. As is his custom, Tom Ricketts strolls through the aisles of the upper deck, greeting the fans.

title: New York Today: Storm-Soaked Photos
description: Good morning on this cool Friday.

title: When Tips Are Not Enough
description: A new program seeks to raise hotel housekeepers pay by soliciting tips from guests but some say forcing workers to rely on gratuities perpetuates inequality.

title: Obama Unveils Push for Young People to Do More Against Campus Assaults
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has tried to use the power of his office to combat sexual assaults on college campuses. On Friday, he got some help.

title: Alibabas Shares Close Up 38% on First Day of Trading
description: The Alibaba Group, the e-commerce giant, closed the day at $93.89 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up 38 percent from its initial public offering price in a strong trading debut. The stock began the day at $92.70 a share.

title: Russian Steelmaker Evraz Considers I.P.O. of North American Unit
description: LONDON  Evraz, the largest steelmaker in Russia, said on Friday that is was considering an initial public offering of its North American unit.

title: Congressional Conservatives Tip Scales to the Right on the Sunday Shows
description: The parade of politicians on the Sunday morning talk shows veers to the right, not the left.

title: Chemical Maker Arkema in Talks to Buy Totals Adhesive Unit
description: LONDON  The specialty chemical maker Arkema said on Friday that it had offered to buy Bostik, one of the worlds largest adhesive makers, from the French oil giant Total in a bid that values the unit at 1.74 billion euros, or about $2.2 billion.

title: Business Owners Share Their Frustrations With Social Media
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners discussed their approaches to social media. The conversation quickly turned to Facebook.

title: Big Weekend for Apple May Herald Strong Demand for iPhone 6
description: For Apple, the unveiling of the new iPhones is like the debut of a blockbuster movie. Eager fans lined up to be the first to experience the new gadgets. And investors will closely watch first-weekend sales, in much the same way movie producers track box office numbers.

title: Iraqi Clerics Speech Strikes a Balance
description: BAGHDAD  Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the influential Shiite cleric, on Friday urged vigilance against Western political interference in Iraqi affairs but stopped short of opposing the American-led military campaign against the extremists of the Islamic State.

title: Daily Report: Ellison Retires as Oracles Chief
description: Silicon Valley just got a little less colorful.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Scotland Rejects Independence From Britain in Historic Vote
description: In the article Scotland Rejects Independence From Britain in Historic Vote, Alan Cowell and Steven Erlanger write about the results of the independence referendum.

title: In Milan, a Different Front Row
description: In February, after Katy Perry arrived nearly an hour late to Moschinos fashion show in Milan, she was greeted by a chorus of boos when she posed for photographers before taking her front row seat.

title: Morning Agenda: Alibaba Makes Its Debut
description: ALIBABA MAKES ITS DEBUT | The Alibaba Group raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial public offering last night, as investors rushed to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating Chinas burgeoning e-commerce industry, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports. The shares priced at $68 each, the top of an already raised range, giving the e-commerce behemoth a market value of about $168 billion  much more than eBay, Twitter and LinkedIn combined. The stock sale was among the largest on record, surpassing offerings from Facebook and General Motors. Alibaba could still raise more money if its underwriters make use of an overallotment option to sell more shares.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: South Korea Says It Fired Warning Shots at Patrol Boat From North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A North Korean patrol boat crossed a disputed western sea border with South Korea on Friday and retreated after warning shots were fired by the South Korean Navy, according to the Souths military.

title: Voting in Scotlands Independence Referendum
description: Voters in Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum that had threatened to break up a 307-year union.

title: Parents, the Children Will Be Fine. Spend Their Inheritance Now.
description: Once people hit retirement, they do not know how long they will live or how long their money will last. Still, the vast majority of retirees with children cling to an intention to leave something behind, even though many of those offspring have no expectation of receiving an inheritance.

title: Chinese React to Scotlands Display of Self-Determination
description: Now that Scottish voters have rejected independence at the ballot box, Chinas senior leadership is undoubtedly breathing a sigh of relief.

title: NYTLNreads | What Did You Read in The Times This Week?
description: Did your students read The Times this week? What articles, graphics, videos, photographs or Op-Eds did they find most interesting? What would they recommend to others? Why?

title: Astorino Forces Encounter With Cuomo as They Court Business Leaders
description: BOLTON LANDING, N.Y.  After sparring through commercials and news releases, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Rob Astorino came face to face here on Friday.

title: The Expanding American Waistline
description: Average waist circumference  but not body mass index increased significantly in the United States between 1999 and 2012, a new study reports.

title: After a Night of Suspense for Business Leaders in Scotland, a Return to Normal
description: EDINBURGH  Scottish business leaders largely expressed relief on Friday after a sleepless night of watching the vote returns come in.

title: Lockdown Begins in Sierra Leone to Battle Ebola
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  The most ambitious and aggressive government campaign against the Ebola epidemic gripping parts of West Africa began on Friday when Sierra Leone ordered everyone in the country to remain indoors for three days, suspending commerce, emptying the streets and halting this beleaguered nation in its tracks in an attempt to stop the disease from spreading.

title: Life in the Young, Hip and Fast Lane
description: Dear Diary:

title: Book Excerpt: The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher
description: This story appears in Hilary Mantels forthcoming collection, The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher (A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt & Company). Her most recent novels, Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, both won the Man Booker Prize.

title: Risks of Investing With Alibaba
description: Steven Davidoff Solomon, the Deal Professor columnist, looks at just how much we still dont know about Alibaba and its business.

description: The latest womens collection from Missoni at Milan Fashion Week. [See the live stream.]

title: Lawyer Nominated as Ambassador to India
description: NEW DELHI  The Obama administration on Friday nominated Richard R. Verma to become the next ambassador to India, just days before Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India is expected to fly to the United States.

title: Exile in Brooklyn, With an Eye on Georgia
description: AT the Smorgasburg food fair in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Mikheil Saakashvili motored in fluorescent green sneakers among bearded men with tattoos and women in revealing overalls. They lined up for Cheese Pops, Dun-Well Doughnuts and other local delicacies. He ordered a fresh coconut.

title: All the Bylines Fun to Print
description: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999. Kevin Roche, a news technology specialist, contributed.

title: Household Net Worth Has Rebounded
description: THE net worth of American households is now 20 percent higher than it was before it began to decline in 2007, the Federal Reserve reported this week. It said the households together were worth $81.5 trillion at the end of the second quarter, higher than ever and up 10 percent from a year earlier.

title: Modern Love | Together We Stand
description: After two failed marriages, Anna March finally found love, security and happiness with Adam.

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
Milan Fashion Week: Sportmax Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Marco de Vincenzo: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Milan Fashion Week: Blumarine Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

title: Derek Jeter, a Yankee Before the Pinstripes
description: One summer morning in 1991, Dick Groch was driving to a baseball game in Battle Creek, Mich., when he made an unplanned detour to a high-school field in Mount Morris, somewhere between the states thumb and forefinger. Groch, a scout who covered the Midwest for the New York Yankees, decided hed stop by a talent identification camp there. He didnt expect to see anything special; the event, he figured, was just a way for some local coach to make a little extra money. Besides, the Yankees were considering Jeffrey Hammonds, an outfielder from Stanford, and Jim Pittsley, a hard-throwing right-hander, as possible picks in the next draft. But Groch thought, why not break up the day?

title: Reply All: The 9.7.14 Issue
description: BILL GATESS BIG IDEA FOR A HISTORY CLASS

title: Why Is Our Sci-Fi So Glum About A.I.?
description: When I was 12, I invented a superhero named Boy Genius, a guy my age who awakens one morning with access to 100 percent of his brain power. This allows him to tap into frightening and exhilarating gifts  telekinesis, telepathy, teleportation. Like most superheroes, Boy Genius is both blessed with and plagued by his abilities. The U.S. government becomes aware of his existence, which means he dodges men in black while also fending off middle-school bullies and tormentors.

title: Turning Microcelebrity Into a Big Business
description: In the bowels of the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., two D.J.s  Andrew Taggart (short, Ken-doll hair, cocky smile) and Alex Pall (tall, thick-rimmed glasses, cocky smile), known together as the Chainsmokers  were led down a hallway by a gaggle of people in lanyards, followed by their manager and the photographer who travels with them and documents their every move  for their future presidential library, I have to assume. It was late June, and they had just come in from Canada, where they played another gig a few hours before. Had it not been for the double booking, their manager swears they would have been closer to the top of the bill.

title: David Suchet: Part of Me Died With Him
description: The actor talks to Hope Reeves about embracing Christianity, joining Twitter and saying goodbye to Hercule Poirot.

title: Bitten to the Quick
description: In the spring of 2013, a family of pigeons nested in scaffolding outside my apartment building two blocks off St. Nicholas Avenue in Manhattans Washington Heights. From the window of my first-floor apartment, I heard the cheeping of baby birds and affectionately observed their downy forms and tiny black-tipped beaks: my very own slice of nature.

title: A Quick-Change Artist
description: My next-door neighbor, who recently quit her job to pursue painting, asked if she could practice by making a portrait of my child. She said she would charge me the cost of supplies since it was for practice, and I agreed. When she finished the painting, she notified me that she had decided to charge me several hundreds of dollars because she had learned inart class the importance of correctly pricing her work. Although I was upset by the change in price, I did not want to ruin the relationship, so I paid what she asked. What was the right thing to do? NADIA, CHICAGO

title: Investment Kitty
description: A mortgage comes with a cat; a swine pheromone has an effect on dogs.

title: Who Made That Maraschino Cherry?
description: The modern maraschino cherry is a real cherry with the cherry flavor removed, explains Darcy ONeil, a chemist and the author of Fix the Pumps, a history of the soda fountain. The original version, by contrast, was a marasca cherry  a sour, dark variety cultivated on the coast of Dalmatia (now part of Croatia) beginning in the mid-19th century. It was brined in ocean water, then preserved in a liqueur made from its own juices, as well as leaves and ground-up pits.

title: Let a Hundred McMansions Bloom
description: In the Dianshan Lake region, less than 40 miles west of central Shanghai, the appetite for speculative real estate has driven developers into Chinas most fertile land, the Yangtze Delta. Only about half of the luxury villas like those on the following pages, which can be as big as 6,300 square feet and sell for as much as $1.5 million, are occupied  mostly as second homes. The rest sit empty, as the housing sector staggers under a surplus. The photographer George Steinmetz, who visited the area last fall, describes the transition as converting rice farms to high-end McMansions. As that process plays out, the countrys domestic rice consumption is set to soon outpace rice production. Marnie Hanel

title: Apple Versus Cops
description: With the release of its latest phone software this week, Apple took an important step forward in protecting the privacy of its customers by giving them more control over their data.

title: Europe Reacts to Scotlands Vote
description: Leaders from Britain, Scotland, Spain and the European Commission spoke after Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: In Senate Battle, the Wild Cards Become Alaska and Kansas
description: The last few weeks of public polling have offered contradictory and surprising results, like surveys showing the Democratic Senate candidate in Colorado either up by six percentage points or down by eight. Nonetheless, the polls have clarified the fight for the Senate. States like North Carolina and Michigan have moved toward the Democrats, while Arkansas and Louisiana have drifted toward the Republican column. The result is that the list of battleground states has shrunk, with perhaps only Alaska, Iowa and Kansas remaining as true tossups.

title: Introducing Our Newsletter
description: Welcome to The Upshots weekly newsletter. Well be sending this out on Fridays, always with at least one brand-new piece, like Nate Cohns above. Well also be giving you a chance to catch up on some of our best material from earlier in the week, and we'll give you a sense of what you can expect in coming days. Let us know what you think, via Twitter, Facebook or in the comments on this page. A couple of notes on subjects that have attracted high reader interest in recent days:

title: Thinking Twice on Alibaba
description: Investors love a good story.

title: Distilling Portland in a Glass
description: Portland, Ore., has earned a reputation as a haven for the Birkenstocks-wearing, unicycle-riding, kombucha-guzzling overeducated and underemployed, as I wrote about in a column this week.

title: Tropical Storm Brings Manila to Standstill
description: MANILA  The worst flooding to hit Manila this year brought the city of 12 million to a standstill on Friday, killing at least one person and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of others.

title: Digging In on Election Fight, Hong Kong Students Prepare for Boycott
description: In September 2012, some 8,000 black-clad students assembled in front of the main library of The Chinese University of Hong Kong to protest the governments push to introduce so-called national education into Hong Kong schools. The proposed curriculum changes, denounced by protesters as political indoctrination by the Chinese Communist Party, were shelved indefinitely.

title: Made in L.A. | Blue Nelson
description: T Contributing Editor David Netto meets Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.

title: Big Ticket | Mansion of a Different Hue for $42.5 Million
description: In another example of the increasingly expensive quest for stand-alone downtown mansions, a relatively new building at 802 Greenwich Street, oft-castigated for having a forbidding salmon-hued exterior devoid of traditional Greenwich Village charm, sold for $42.5 million and was the weeks most expensive sale, according to city records.

title: The Lobby Curator
description: Alexander DiPersia has deep roots in real estate. In 1924, one of his great-grandfathers, William Kaufman, established a Manhattan development firm that today manages nearly four million square feet of commercial space. Mr. DiPersia, an actor, never joined the family business, but through a family-cultivated appreciation for art, he happened onto an auxiliary career as a curator for private and public spaces that started with several lobbies in the Kaufman portfolio.

title: Dumbo Roars
description: Not all that long ago, before the Brooklyn waterfront became a must-do on seemingly every tourists list, Dumbos converted warehouses and Belgian-block streets were inhabited by artists and young families, drawn by cheap rents, postindustrial architecture and relative isolation.

title: The Car Whisperer
description: Meet Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.

title: Today in Small Business: The Bacon Bowl
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Harry Truman, Five-Card Stud and the Cold War
description: This photograph may seem to show President Harry Truman, behind closed doors, playing poker while pondering the future of the Cold War world.

title: Etro: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Wedding Q.&A.
description: Not Much Left for a Tip

title: 1939: Slovaks Are Terrorized
description: COPENHAGEN  Reports reaching here indicate that new acts of terrorism are being perpetrated in Bohemia and Slovakia. Following a revolt at the Skoda works, the Gestapo made hundreds of arrests. In many cases, families of arrested workers received a few days later the papers of the member of their family arrested and a primed notice warning them that they were not to wear mourning or to speak of the death. It is believed probable that the Gestapo carried out executions at Prague, in the basement of the Petchek Bank. Other executions have been reported from Brno, where a revolt has been suppressed. Rudolf Beran, former Premier, has been arrested. A number of executions have taken place at Zilina, in Slovakia, without the Slovak authorities being advised. To their inquiry the Gestapo replied that it was obliged to take all measures of prudence necessary to prevent acts directed against the German Army. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 20, 1939

title: Etros Swaying, Bohemian Footwear
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: 1964: Khrushchev to Help Africans
description: MOSCOW  At a Kremlin reception for the 1,000 delegates to the leftist World Youth Forum here, Mr. Khrushchev declared Soviet support for Angolan fighters against Portuguese Fascism, the struggle of Negroes in the Congo against conquerors and traitors and the struggle against racist oppression in South Africa. If they want arms, we are ready to discuss the question in a brotherly fashion and give our help, he said. Mr. Khrushchev told the youth forum delegates: I did not look at hydrogen or atomic bombs, but I saw an assortment of weapons used for infantry, artillery, tanks and rockets. I saw them and I said: See what man has built for man. Its terrible. In his 45-minute extemporaneous speech, Mr. Khrushchev gave his third clarification of his remarks last week about Soviet weaponry. He was quoted then as saying the Soviet Union had a terrible new weapon. Today he said he had been misquoted in the bourgeois press.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 21, 1964

title: Home Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: The Weighty Responsibility of Inheriting a Collection
description: AFTER her mother died, Jaye Smith surveyed the boxes around the big, rambling house where she had lived on Staten Island for 50 years and thought, Well worry about them later.

title: Week 3 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Broncos (2-0) at Seahawks (1-1)

title: Civil War (and Family) History
description: Laird Hunt set out to research a very particular slice of Civil War history while writing his novel Neverhome, reviewed by Karen Abbott this week, about a woman who disguises herself as a man to fight for the Union.

title: Letters: When the Troops Came Home
description: When the Troops Came Home

title: Shadows of War
description: FROM A DISTANCE  By Raffaella Barker  Bloomsbury, paper, $17.

title: A Musical Tour of the World
description: Which rhythms keep the kids of Curaao on their feet all night? Which beats keep the Burkina Faso markets bumping all day? Immersive travelers who want to know the tunes the locals are humming can get an assist from a new app on Spotify.

title: A Believer in Vacant Lots
description: Karen Washington, a community activist who has been called urban farmings de facto godmother, found her bliss when she moved to the Bronx nearly 30 years ago and began growing vegetables in her backyard. Gardening was not part of her heritage.

title: Not Dead Yet
description: Stone Mattress, Margaret Atwoods first collection since Moral Disorder in 2006, begins with three linked stories about women who have been romantically involved with a middling poet named Gavin Putnam. Constance, the protagonist of the first, has become a fantasy novelist in the decades since their relationship ended (she calls herself C. W. Starr, in the tradition of J. K. Rowling and P. D. James), famous for an invented world called Alphinland that she claims Gavin never understood: It was a dangerous place, and  granted  preposterous in some ways, but it was not sordid. The denizens of it had standards. They understood gallantry, and courage, and also revenge.

title: Bloody Hell
description: God alone mightve written the Bible, but the Irish provided the punctuation. While the Roman Empire collapsed into the vernacular across the European continent, monks in the cold stone monasteries of that cold stone island hand-copied Latin and Greek versions of Scripture. Their manuscripts revived antiquitys systems of notation, resurrecting spaces between words and pauses between thoughts, and turned the Flesh of body text into the Word of divine revelation through the sacrament of quotation. The first thing God says to the first man, Adam, is, Dont pick the fruit from a certain tree. The second thing God says is that the man must have a partner, and so He puts Adam to sleep and removes a rib He turns into a woman: a half-formed thing, a dependent.

title: Behind Closed Doors
description: In Sarah Waterss previous and much-acclaimed novels, whether theyre set in the Victorian period (Tipping the Velvet) or in the 1940s (The Night Watch), the tectonic plates beneath the storytelling are formed by British society  how its attitudes shift, how they dont. Along class lines. About lesbian sex. Concerning the place of women.

title: Serrated Edges
description: Elliptical is an adjective often used to describe Deborah Levys jagged, imagistic style. Her snapshots of relationships, most of them disintegrating, are blunt, rueful and deadpan. Her characters confess a Didionesque anomie toward lifes limited possibilities.

title: In Cleveland, Adding Life Where Grit Once Prevailed
description: About two miles west of downtown Cleveland, the gritty Detroit-Shoreway was once a vibrant neighborhood before it was hit hard by the exodus of big manufacturing companies in the early decades of the 20th century. Lately, new businesses, arts groups and residents have settled in the Gordon Square Arts District, a revitalized mile-long stretch of Detroit Avenue. A recent $30 million capital campaign included new streetscapes and signage. Visitors can catch a show at the Cleveland Public Theater, walk through galleries at 78th Street Studios or grab a late-night bite at XYZ Tavern. And this spring, the Near West Theater will have a $7.3 million new home.

title: On the Lewis and Clark Trail
description: The author and illustrator Maira Kalman sketches her observations from a trip in search of history  and espresso.

title: Inside the List
description: Ijan Makjuan: The British novelist Ian McEwan  whose latest book, The Children Act, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 4  keeps a tally on his website of academic dissertations and theses discussing his work. There are dozens of them, as befits a writer of McEwans stature, and their titles should give even unversed readers a fair sense of his interests (as well as the interests of literary scholars today): Pervasive Perspectives: Gender Relationships in the Fiction of Ian McEwan; The Child in Time: Postmodern Representations of Childhood in the Novels of Ian McEwan; A Mind With a View: Cognitive Science, Neuroscience and Contemporary Literature; The Epistemology of Evil in Ian McEwans Novels. Sex, childhood, postmodernism, science, the nature of evil: Yep, thats McEwan. (The paper about evil was written by a Serbian philosopher, Zorica Djergovic-Joksimovic, who later expanded her research into a book with the wonderful title Ijan Makjuan: Polifonija Zla, or Ian McEwan: The Polyphony of Evil.) McEwan recently told The Wall Street Journal that fans sometimes stop him in the street. But literary fame is quite delightful compared to Hollywood fame or rock n roll fame or footballer fame, he said, because the kind of people who like literary fiction tend to come up blushing or squirming with embarrassment, trying to make themselves disappear but just wanting to tell you before they fade away that your work has meant a great deal to them. And then they vanish before you can even say thank you.

title: Paperback Row
description: JONATHAN SWIFT: His Life and His World,  by Leo Damrosch. (Yale University, $22.) Swift (1667-1745) distinguished himself as novelist (Gullivers Travels), satirist (A Modest Proposal), essayist, poet and political pamphleteer. Damroschs commanding biography aims at sweeping away misconceptions about Swifts parentage, love life and moral and religious views  many of which were encouraged by Swift himself.

title: Editors Choice
description: THIRTEEN DAYS IN SEPTEMBER: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David,  by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $27.95.) How marathon sessions of bare-knuckle diplomacy forged a framework for peace between Israel and Egypt in 1978.

title: Bookshelf: Laughs
description: New picture books include Mac Barnetts Sam and Dave Dig a Hole.

title: Be Polite With Your Books
description: What is the etiquette anyway regarding the making of a literary reference in casual conversation? Say, for instance, you want to refer to your newborns recent gastric exclamation as an airborne toxic event. The allusion is self-contained enough  i.e., your audience will be amused even without knowing its provenance  that you dont need to footnote it with DeLillo. White Noise.

title: Past Treatment
description: There may be no bigger mystery to a child than her own family  those adults who pretend not to notice even the most glaring issues, who make peculiar requests and then refuse to explain a thing. For Julia, the central character in Margaret Forsters psychological puzzle-box of a novel, even basic factual information can be mystifying. Were her actions as a girl harmless or grave? She herself doesnt know, and the uncertainty colors the rest of her life.

title: She Wears the Britches
description: How do you solve a problem like Ash Thompson? The heroine of Neverhome, Laird Hunts enthralling new novel set during the Civil War, is at once sentimental and aloof, a savior and a killer, a folk hero who shuns her own legend, a fierce and wounded woman who finds strength in her troubled past. Above all she is a liar, but one whose every word has the sheen of truth. I was strong and he was not, she begins her tale, so it was me went to war to defend the Republic. Yet it becomes clear that Ash is hardly motivated by patriotism, and that an equally devastating war awaits her return home.

title: This Is What a City Under Bombardment Looks Like
description: Who believes today that war can be abolished? No one, not even pacifists, writes Susan Sontag in a2002 essay for The New Yorker, Looking at War. We hope only (so far in vain) to stop genocide and bring to justice those who commit gross violations of the laws of war. We seek, too, to stem the suffering of those caught in wars cross hairs.

title: Walks on the Wild Side
description: Someone goes on a journey is one of the guiding precepts of narrative; Are we there yet? is one of the guiding precepts of childhood. Picture books must inhabit the middle of this Venn diagram, offering stories as scenic and driving as any novel, at a pace more novel than driving through scenery. Four new package deals have come across my desk; lets see what we can book.

title: Secret Histories
description: Early in Meg Wolitzers acclaimed novel The Interestings, two boys at summer camp indulge in unlikely late-night mischief when, by the glow of their flashlights, they sneak passages of All the Presidents Men. Wolitzers characters are often wildly bookish. In her first novel, Sleepwalking, three death girls worship Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton and another, invented, suicidal poet; in The Uncoupling sex lives are undone by a high school production of Lysistrata; and in The Wife, the heroine marries her college creative writing professor. In Belzhar, her second novel for young readers  after the ingenious The Fingertips of Duncan Dorfman, a middle-grade book  Wolitzer tells a flashlight-worthy story that illuminates some dark corners of adolescent desire.

title: Rare Bird
description: A book called Nest with a main character called Chirp might seem almost too cute. But Esther Ehrlichs debut middle-grade novel is anything but saccharine; in fact, its ambition is to be rigorously realistic about tragedy in a childs life. That so grave a work would festoon itself with whimsy speaks to the books virtues and its potential limitations. This is a book to take seriously, that has a lot to say. But is it for the child readers its targeting?

title: Waging Two Wars
description: On Feb. 17, 1919, the 369th Infantry Regiment returned to New York from France. Under a bright sun and cloudless sky, before a crowd of 250,000, the most decorated African-American combat unit to serve in World War I marched under the newly erected Victory Arch at 23rd Street and up Fifth Avenue. White observers were awed by the spectacle of some 3,000 black soldiers in French helmets, bayonets gleaming, parading in disciplined lock step formation, while black residents flooded the streets and cheered wildly, welcoming home their loved ones and heroes. Capped by this extraordinary moment, the 369th was etched in history as the Harlem Hellfighters.

title: My Reddit AMA  Put Me on the Spot!
description: Next week Ill hold another AMA (Ask Me Anything) on reddit. Ill be taking questions on my new book with Sheryl WuDunn, A Path Appears, on how to make a difference, as well as anything else you care to ask me about. (The book comes out Sept. 23, so if you order now and speed read, you can ask me about stories in the book.)

title: Putting Soul Back Into Business
description: The most important and inspiring business book Ive ever read was written by a first-time author from Belgium who self-published his book in March. Its called Reinventing Organizations: A Guide to Creating Organizations Inspired by the Next Stage of Human Consciousness, and the authors personal story is nearly as inspiring as the content of the book.

title: Notes on a Shortstop
description: A scouts musings on the teenage Derek Jeter  provided by The New York Yankees, from Steiner Sports  notes his active feet and long lean sinewy body.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Cosby: His Life and Times
description: This week, Mark Whitaker talks about his biography of Bill Cosby; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jeff Hobbs discusses The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Cosby: His Life and Times
description: This week, Mark Whitaker and Jeff Hobbs.

title: Dont Make Me Land This Plane
description: One day, not too long ago, my two daughters, seated in the same room, found themselves at a standoff. One wished to watch a Rainbow Loom video. The other wanted to read in a quiet, video-free room. Things escalated, as these things do; there were available compromises, but it seems one couldnt be reached. After a period of loud dispute, both were ejected from the room by the authorities, and not without harsh words. Both eventually resumed their activities in other locations.

title: South Korea Is Awarded Berths in 2018 Olympic Tournaments
description: South Koreas mens and womens national teams have been granted automatic entry into the Olympic ice hockey tournaments at the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, the International Ice Hockey Federation announced Thursday, despite the countrys low ranking in the sport.

title: The Look of Milan 2
description: As fashion week moves on, styles from Prada, Blumarine, Moschino, Sportmax, Just Cavalli and more.

title: At Moschino, Barbies Sexy New Wardrobe
description: MILAN  Flattened like a panini by the large crowd waiting to get into the Moschino show at the Palazzo Serbelloni on Thursday evening, I was reminded of the notorious Black Friday stampedes at Walmart.

title: Weeknight Dinner Success Starts With Lemon, Olive Oil and Salt
description: I have 24 kinds of chiles and over 50 dried herbs and seasonings in my spice drawer. There are dozens of oils and vinegars stuffed into my pantry, fresh herbs in pots on the deck, and a collection of condiments that I suspect is multiplying like bunnies behind the refrigerator door.

title: Missoni: Summer 2015 RTW
description: Mian

title: Exxon Halts Oil Drilling in Waters of Russia
description: Exxon Mobil announced on Friday that it was winding down its $700 million exploration in Russias Kara Sea, the first major sign that Western sanctions are biting into the companys ambitious plans to explore for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Etro Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: Alibaba is the name on every traders lips today as shares of the e-commerce giant  which raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial public offering yesterday  began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The Hangzhou-based company opened at an astonishing $92.70, making it roughly the size of J.P. Morgan.

title: Scotlands Pro-Unity Vote
description: In the end, Scottish voters stepped back from breaking with the rest of Britain. The decision to maintain the 307-year-old union was the right one. Scotland already enjoys a significant degree of autonomy, and Britains prime minister, David Cameron, has promised more. Besides, separation would have been a plunge into a dangerous unknown. But this will not be the end of the dream of independence  not for the Scots, nor for the Catalans, Flemish, Basques and other people who nurture the dream.

title: Back in Public, Vowing to Do More
description: After more than a week out of view with a national debate raging over domestic violence and the future of the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that he would form a committee to lay the groundwork for overhauling the leagues personal conduct policy.

title: British Food Delivery Giant Forms Joint Venture in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Just Eat, the British online food-ordering giant that has been expanding globally, has decided to join the competition in Brazil rather than continue fighting it.

title: The Bradbury Chronicles: Hundreds of Items Owned by Author Going to Auction
description: About 450 items owned by Ray Bradbury, the prolific science fiction author who died in 2012, are to be auctioned Sept. 25 by Nate D. Sanders, a Los Angeles auction house. The offerings include letters, contracts and other signed items; awards; personal memorabilia; and a collection devoted largely to animation and science fiction art. There is also furniture and even a couple of bottles of vintage wine. Bradburys estate expects the auction to bring between $800,000 and $1 million.

title: Reporting Bad Behavior to Facebook
description: Q. If I report hate speech from a friend on Facebook to the site, does that person get notified that I filed a complaint?

title: Video Reviews of A Walk Among the Tombstones, Tracks and This Is Where I Leave You
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on A Walk Among the Tombstones, Tracks and This Is Where I Leave You. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: The New Conservative Love Affair With Canada
description: You may remember your liberal friends threatening to move to Canada after George W. Bush was re-elected. But something surprising has happened in the last few years: Conservatives have fallen in love with Canada. The conservative journalist John Fund wrote in National Review this month that Canada is becoming more American than America. Thats the same John Fund who wrote a 1995 Wall Street Journal staff editorial calling Canada an honorary member of the third world. A lot can change in two decades.

title: Rare Jane Austen Manuscript Goes on Exhibit
description: The Jane Austen news just keeps coming.

title: Rule Changes Increase Flexibility in Pretax Health Care Accounts
description: AS open enrollment season approaches for those with workplace health benefits, employees may want to take a fresh look at health care flexible spending accounts, if their employers offer them, because the rules for the accounts have changed.

title: Michael Bloomberg, Now a U.N. Climate Envoy, Presses the Case for Urban Action
description: I recently had a chance to ask former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg about the fresh push hes making for urban action to blunt climate impacts and greenhouse gas emissions as the new United Nations Special Envoy for Cities and Climate Change. Hell be a very busy man next week, as the city hosts the Peoples Climate March, a U.N. summit on climate change and Climate Week.

title: Bright Future Not Certain for British Oil and Gas Production
description: LONDON  The vote to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom removed a cloud of uncertainty for the British energy industry. But the long-term challenges still loom.

title: Review: This Is Where I Leave You
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews This Is Where I Leave You.

title: Barred From Facebook, and Wondering Why
description: MICHAEL LETWIN, a lawyer living in Brooklyn, went to sign into his Facebook account, as he does almost daily, and received a surprising  and unpleasant  message.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman
description: Malcolm Gladwell, longtime New Yorker scribe, counterintuitive theorist and entertaining public speaker whose best seller David and Goliath challenges the way we think about adversity and success, takes on Sarah Silverman, controversial comedian, actress and equal-opportunity offender who once sang Youre Going to Die Soon to a group of senior citizens. An album of her HBO comedy special, We Are Miracles, is out now.

title: The Fresh-Air Amenity
description: In a city that can treat its courtyards like walled-off terrariums  things to behold but not to touch  443 Greenwich Street is taking a different approach and creating a space to be enjoyed like a park.

title: Book Review Podcast: Cosby: His Life and Times
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Neil Drumming reviews Mark Whitakers Cosby: His Life and Times. Mr. Drumming writes:

title: After Woman Is Struck, Debate on Cycling in City Is Revived
description: The long-simmering conflict between bicyclists and pedestrians in New York City flared again after a 58-year-old woman was struck by a bicyclist and critically injured in Central Park on Thursday afternoon.

title: Facts & Figures: Dont Know Much About Government
description: A new survey finds that Americans dont know much about government.

title: Review: A Walk Among the Tombstones
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews A Walk Among the Tombstones.

title: Day for Night in Norway
description: The Hurtigruten website modestly describes its cruise up the Norwegian coast as the worlds most beautiful voyage. When I read this, I could not help but think of that old Monty Python skit in which a man writes the worlds funniest joke  a joke so funny that everyone who reads it instantly dies from laughter. I wondered if beauty, pressed toward hyperbole, could become similarly perilous. Would the decks of the ship be littered with tourists smitten by the sublime?

title: Larry Ellison Keeps a Hand on the Wheel at Oracle
description: Larry Ellison is ceding the drivers seat at Oracle while keeping one hand on wheel. The founder of the software giant is stepping down as chief executive officer, but his 25 percent stake in the company  and dual role as chairman and chief technology officer  ensure hes far from relinquishing control. Splitting his former job between two executives could, however, lead to a bumpy transition.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Missoni Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: What Are the Guerrilla Girls Doing Now?
description: Q. In reading about Pussy Riot, the female Russian punk rockers who protest the leadership of Vladimir V. Putin, I have seen references to the Guerrilla Girls. What are they up to now?

title: Taking Their Umbrage Where They Can Get It
description: Like many candidates attacked over budgets, Thom Tillis, a Republican running for the Senate from North Carolina, responded in a recent debate by disputing his opponents numbers.

title: Tune Into The Times
description: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

title: A Beltway Battle Thats a Bipartisan Dream: Washington-Baltimore World Series
description: WASHINGTON  Few words in America draw as much disdain as the Beltway, a roadway connoting political dysfunction, dowdy hemlines and general cultural remove.

title: In Hope Solo Case, Soccer Turns a Blind Eye Toward Domestic Violence
description: There were smiles all around Thursday night when Hope Solo extended her shutout record to 73 in the United States national womens soccer teams 4-0 victory over Mexico in Rochester.

title: Weighing a Political Comeback, Sarkozy Says He Will Seek His Partys Presidency
description: PARIS  Former President Nicolas Sarkozy used his Facebook page on Friday to announce that he would seek the presidency of his party, a first step toward declaring his candidacy to run once again for the presidency of France in 2017.

title: Court Dismisses Citibank Appeal in Argentina Case
description: Citigroups impassioned call to the United States Court of Appeals to reconsider a judgment by a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan has failed to gain support.

title: Do You Need a Worse Phone?
description: As America prepares for the advent of a phone you can wear on your wrist, some are calling for a move in the opposite direction: toward worse phones, not better.

title: A Well-Received Concerto of Curves
description: Ian Callum, the design director for Jaguar, apparently has his touch on the pulse of the market even when he isnt trying.

title: Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Is Convicted in Campaign Finance Case
description: NEW HAVEN  Former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, who nearly a decade ago was forced to resign from office in disgrace, was found guilty in federal court on Friday of engaging in corrupt political acts even after serving prison time for his previous conviction.

title: A Conversation With Michael Harris, Author of The End of Absence
description: Michael Harris, a former magazine editor, is the author of The End of Absence, a book that tries to remind people what life was like before the Internet.

title: Marni Hosts a Pop-Up Flower Market in Milan
description: I love flowers for their liveliness and vitality, says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni. And it shows: For the past two decades, blossoms have been a significant and recurring component in Castiglionis witty, often deeply personal collections. While it remains to be seen whether Castiglioni will send any garden motifs down the runway this Sunday, Marni flower power promises to be in full effect at the nearby Rotonda della Besana in Central Milan, where the brand will host a one-day pop-up flower market open to the public on the same day to celebrate its 20th anniversary.

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Passing Tips in Post-it Insider Trading Ring
description: A former mortgage broker from Brooklyn admitted on Friday to being the glue that held together an insider trading ring that involved the passing of stock tips on Post-it notes and napkins in meetings at restaurants in Midtown Manhattan and at Grand Central Terminal.

title: A Pop-Beat Mask for Melancholy
description: The changes that fame has wrought on the life of the Swedish pop singer Tove Lo start with the pronunciation of her name. You can say too-veh loo if you want, thats the way I say it in Sweden, she said. But every country besides Sweden says Tove [rhymes with rove] Lo, so Ive just kind of gotten used to it.

title: A Dancers Creative Evolution
description: Theres an electricity in the air at New York City Ballet in September. On a recent day, wan-cheeked young women carried limp practice tutus over their arms, scurrying down fluorescent-lit hallways like Alices White Rabbit, perennially pressed for time. The bustle has been particularly intense this year, with four new works scheduled, three at the companys opening night gala at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday. (A new ballet by Alexei Ratmansky will be unveiled next month.)

title: Haunted by Eternity, the Cosmos or the Confines of a Grim Life
description: Jesse Winchester

title: Catalan Secessionists, Despite Scotland Independence Loss, Continue Push to Leave Spain
description: MADRID  Undaunted by the defeat of the Scottish independence movement a day earlier, separatists in the Catalonia region of northeastern Spain pressed ahead on Friday with plans to hold a similar vote there.

title: Jane the Virgin Aims Beyond Its Latin Ethnicity
description: At first glance, the protagonist of Jane the Virgin bears little resemblance to any other character on television, never mind any viewer.

title: A Proving Ground For Young Stars
description: The song recital, which requires attention and patience from both performers and audiences, is perpetually an endangered species. (Full-scale opera, with its costumes and grandeur, comes across as rather more fun.) But since they value intimacy, textual specificity and communicative ability, recitals remain crucial proving grounds for young artists. Voce: Rising Opera Stars in Recital, a series at Pace University started last year by the veteran impresario Matthew Epstein, has already been a valuable addition to the vocal scene. This seasons first concert, on Sunday, features the potent combination of the soprano Julia Bullock, a star at the Juilliard School in recent productions of Massenets Cendrillon and Janaceks The Cunning Little Vixen, and the tenor Joseph Kaiser, over the past few years a Met stalwart in Mozart, Handel and Britten. (3 p.m., Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan, 212-346-1715, schimmel.pace.edu.)

title: The Case for Delayed Adulthood
description: ONE of the most notable demographic trends of the last two decades has been the delayed entry of young people into adulthood. According to a large-scale national study conducted since the late 1970s, it has taken longer for each successive generation to finish school, establish financial independence, marry and have children. Todays 25-year-olds, compared with their parents generation at the same age, are twice as likely to still be students, only half as likely to be married and 50 percent more likely to be receiving financial assistance from their parents.

title: Rock Star in All His Permutations
description: People who have doubts about the David Bowie exhibition opening at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago on Tuesday may find some misgivings soothed by the shows ambitious catalog. It documents Mr. Bowie as a musical and performance pioneer whose means of visual expression included drawings, paintings and many shape-shifting, gender-bending ensembles  sometimes his own designs  for stage, cover art, videos and photos. Only about a third of the garments made the trip from the shows point of origin, the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. But they will include 11 for Ziggy Stardust, Mr. Bowies best-known character, and the Union Jack coat he collaborated on with Alexander McQueen. There will also be ephemera dating to Mr. Bowies childhood (he was born David Robert Jones in 1947) and examples of handwritten lyrics and projections of his most influential music videos. The material should convey Mr. Bowies wide-ranging achievement and also  as the museums news release says  repatriate him into the territory of cutting-edge visual and performing art that is his natural home. (mcachicago.org.)

title: Anticipated Premieres
description: In their respective genres  ballet and contemporary dance  the choreographers Justin Peck and Kyle Abraham have been blessed and cursed by critics as the potential voices of their generation. Both have highly anticipated premieres this week. Hype aside, both are smart and refreshing artists, consistently offering satisfying theatrical experiences.

title: A 50th High School Reunion, and a Generation to Follow
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J.  TONI DEGIROLAMO and Dick Worthington had been seeing each other for a while when they decided to go on a date to the Garden State Drive-In a half-century ago.

title: Olivia Benson as Mama Bear
description: After 15 seasons as the heart of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, Sgt. Olivia Benson has pretty much been there, done that, when it comes to crime and punishment. But gunshots, stabbings and kidnappings  or having Taylor Swift name her kitten after you  are nothing compared to her latest task: motherhood. The seriess 16th round, debuting Wednesday at 9, finds Bensons primal instincts raging when the biological mother of the foster son she inherited in last seasons finale is burned almost beyond recognition. That murder leads Benson and her squad to a sex-trafficking ring that markets its under-age prostitutes on Craigslist. When its members threaten the life of Bensons child, hello mama bear.

title: Milan Fashion Week: Tods Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: 2015 Cadillac Escalade
description: Its glory days of the mid-2000s are long past, but the redesigned Cadillac Escalade seems content to coast on its reputation.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Lebanese Soldiers Near Border With Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two Lebanese Army soldiers were killed and two were wounded on Friday when their convoy was hit by a roadside bomb outside the town of Arsal, near the border with Syria. The town was the scene of battles that erupted last month between the army and militants from the group Islamic State and the Nusra Front, which is affiliated with Al Qaeda.

title: Japans Premier Seeks Summit Meeting With South Korean President
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The office of President Park Geun-hye said on Friday that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan had sent a letter proposing a summit meeting, a conciliatory gesture after years of tensions between Americas most important allies in Northeast Asia.

title: John Boehners Theory of the Leisure Class
description: And, Im back  Ive been in a grueling battle against deadlines, which is not quite over, so blogging may remain scarce for a while longer. But Im sticking my toe in for the moment  and whaddya know, oops, he did it again. John Boehner says that unemployed Americans are pretty clearly malingerers, bums on welfare who have decided that they dont feel like working:

title: The Secret to Last-Minute Tart: Keep Pastry Dough in the Freezer
description: If I have a sweet pastry shell in the freezer, I know Im ready to entertain. A dinner party requires a dessert, and what is more pleasing than a beautiful fruit or lemon tart?

title: How to Get the Fresh-Faced Glow at Blumarine
description: This morning in Milan, fresh-faced models stepped into Blumarines spring 2015 collection of garden-party frocks, skirts and coats (no pants in sight!). Sure, they had just gotten a good nights sleep. But the makeup artist Tom Pecheux helped enhance their bright and even complexions with a mix of skin-care products, foundation, concealer, blush and bronzer. The inspiration is youth, he said, explaining that he aimed to create the superfresh and young girl that acts like a woman. On the runway, models eyes were wide and bright thanks to a bit of shimmer on the inside corner of the eye, some gloss on the brushed eyebrows and the absence of dark mascara. The finishing touch was the sexy and easy-to-pull-off-in-real-life hairstyle that seems to be dominating runways this season: relaxed waves, parted down the middle.

title: Expedia and HomeAway Expand Rental Partnership
description: Expedia and HomeAway have decided to expand a pilot partnership begun last year offering HomeAway listings through Expedias website.

title: U.S. and Mexico Aid Tourists Stranded After Hurricane Odile
description: MEXICO CITY  Several days after a powerful hurricane hit one of Mexicos most popular Pacific resorts, the American military, the State Department and the Mexican authorities continued to airlift stranded tourists from an area afflicted by looting and still lacking electricity and potable water.

title: Phoney Baloney (Personal and Trivial)
description: Just to say: What is it with the huge lines waiting for the new iPhone? Yes, smartphones are quite useful and sometimes even fun; Im not a heavy app user, but Im still on the thing many times a day. But even if the iPhone 6 has nifty new features, how can you get so excited over something that is, when all is said and done, an incremental change?

title: Chinese Media Company Signs On To Broadcast Broadway Shows
description: Broadway has been slow to embrace the high-definition broadcasts increasingly beamed out by performing arts organizations around the world. A new venture hopes to speed that up.

title: Summery Turbans at Missoni
description: There were swaths and swaths of silk on Missonis spring 2015 runway  even on the models heads, where hair was wrapped up in an array of silk scarves printed with the same colors and patterns as the clothes. The turbans lent an extra summery feel to the light, breezy collection.

title: Versace: Summer 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: Obama Starts Campaign Against Assault
description: President Obama announced a new nationwide public service campaign, Its on Us, aimed at urging young people to do more to prevent campus sexual assaults.

title: Jack Devine: The Spymaster Who Goes to Mass
description: Speaking about life after the Central Intelligence Agency, Jack Devine became nostalgic. Im having a lot of fun, he said, but Im not allowed to overthrow governments. Mr. Devine, 73, who chronicles his 32 years at the C.I.A. in the memoir Good Hunting: An American Spymasters Story, had a role in the Iran-contra affair, the arming of Islamist rebels against the Soviets in Afghanistan, and the capture of Pablo Escobar. After leaving the C.I.A. in 1999, he helped start a corporate intelligence firm, the Arkin Group. He and his wife, Patricia, split their time between the East 70s and Ocean City, N.J., where he rows competitively in summers. Does he miss overthrowing governments? Im lying if I say I didnt, he said.

title: Their Latest and Greatest Adventure
description: When Breezy Jackson went to Antarctica in 2009 for a job driving what she calls monster trucks for the United States Antarctic Program, friends who had worked on the ice warned her that the community of seasonal workers there had a reputation for temporary relationships.

title: You See Your Boys, You Stop: At Le Basket in Greenwich Village
description: Youre a bike messenger in New York City and youve just finished your day, clocking in more than 50 miles racing around town contending with traffic and chaos. Youd like to unwind with your colleagues over a beer. The obvious, if unlikely, choice is Le Basket, a deli at the corner of Broadway and East Third Street whose utilitarian outdoor seating area doubles as a beer garden where, thanks to the bike messengers who stop there on their way home, its always happy hour.

title: As Central Park Gondolier, He Helms a Love Boat
description: Dusk was descending on Central Park Lake when a couple from Connecticut stepped onto Andrs Garca-Peas gondola.

title: What Would We Do Without It?
description: With summer just about officially over, we can dispassionately explore what the world was like a little more than a century ago, before Willis Carrier installed his apparatus for treating air in a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, printing plant.

title: How That Meal Got to the Table
description: I rarely go to the market with a blank slate. Some notion of the ultimate goal  dinner  informs my shopping. Nonetheless, I frequently let the market guide me; dinner is not a rigid paint by numbers affair, even if I plan a particular dish. Its more like a pencil sketch, with some elements that may be erased and redrawn, the way a chef comes up with a daily special.

title: Where They Danced the Virginia Reel
description: From the 1830s to the 1850s, East Fourth Street was a high-society Manhattan address with neighbors named Astor and Vanderbilt. Charles Dickens and Washington Irving sojourned in the area, which then was called Bond Street. The MERCHANTS HOUSE, at No. 29, built in 1832, stands as a testament to that period, seeming as unchanged and as fragile as Miss Havishams wedding dress. It is also imperiled.

title: Salesforce Boss Tips His Hand on Companys Big News
description: Marc Benioff raised the bar against himself last week, accidentally announcing that his company would do something big in data analytic technology that customers access through so-called cloud computing.

title: Hook, Line and Ring
description: For couples who still want to cast the net  for fish.

title: What Does a Whole Lot of Cash Do to a Designer?
description: Over two years, the two fashion giants, LVMH and Kering, have opened a new front in their war for fashion supremacy, aiming at gobbling up as many young designers as possible. Kering has taken stakes in Christopher Kane and Joseph Altuzarra, while LVMH has invested in J.W. Anderson, Maxime Simoens, Nicholas Kirkwood and Marco de Vincenzo.

title: To Save the Planet, Dont Plant Trees
description: NEW HAVEN  AS international leaders gather in New York next week for a United Nations climate summit, they will be preoccupied with how to tackle the rising rate of carbon emissions. To mitigate the crisis, one measure they are likely to promote is reducing deforestation and planting trees.

title: Scandinavians Split Over Syrian Influx
description: THE narrow victory of the left-leaning Social Democratic Party in Swedens elections last Sunday marked a broad shift in its politics. But a new coalition government is unlikely to reconsider one of the countrys most challenging policies: its response to the Syrian civil war. Sweden has taken an open-door approach to people fleeing the conflict, accepting more Syrians than any other European country.

title: Sad Dads in the Empty Nest
description: WASHINGTON  MY mother-in-law called the other day to see how I was doing. My husband and I had just taken our daughter  our firstborn  to college, renting a giant Lincoln Navigator to transport the requisite duffel bags and notebooks and drawer units and bedding and mini-fridge and Keurig. Now we were home, contemplating her room and the beloved detritus of her childhood  old snow pants, dog-eared Pendragon books, corkboard photo collages  and my mother-in-law wanted to make sure I was holding up.

title: Guided By Voices Calls It Quits, Cancels Tour
description: The innovative and often experimental indie band Guided by Voices announced on its website on Thursday that it was calling it quits, again. The band, led by the prolific singer and songwriter Robert Pollard, was founded in 1987 and broke up, the first time, in 2004. Mr. Pollard reconvened the groups most successful lineup  the version that toured and recorded from 1993 to 1996  in 2010, and made six albums with the band, including two (Motivational Jumpsuit and Cool Planet) released this year.

title: Debate on Independence Lingers in Scottish Homes
description: GLASGOW  Fiona Ivanski and her husband, Vincent, woke early the morning after the Scottish independence referendum, even though they had barely slept. Anxious to discover the verdict on Scotlands future, they sat down on their living room couch at 6:08 a.m. Friday and turned on the television.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Sierra Leone, Scotland and New York.

title: U.S.T.A. Faces Suit Over Sabbath Schedule
description: A senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members is suing the United States Tennis Association over its refusal to change a tournament schedule to accommodate the players observance of the Sabbath.

title: Bach, Played in Living Color
description: The juxtaposition was peculiar, no question. Hearing Christian Tetzlaff play Bachs sonatas and partitas for unaccompanied violin, some of the most intellectually stimulating and emotionally fulfilling music ever written, on Thursday evening, I kept thinking of a childs coloring book. Bach drew those wildly imaginative and fanciful but spare lines of melody and counterpoint, leaving it to the player to add color.

title: Up From Pain
description: I WAS away at college doing much of nothing, just pushing back against sorrow as it pressed down. My mother called. She told me someone wanted to speak to me. There was a silence on the line, and then words: Whats going on, boy?

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Detroit Muscle in a Jersey Warehouse
description: The setting may have lacked the glamor of Pebble Beach or Amelia Island, but the cars being auctioned by the U.S. Marshals Service were blue-chip collectibles.

title: Right Up to Retirement, Derek Jeter Is Still Playing the Game
description: He flexed his knees and settled into the batters box like a man into his garden, needing just another moment to root his right foot into the dirt. Then he pulled his left shoulder in, as if to fit into a crowded subway car, waggled his bat and awaited the pitch.

title: The Berlin Walls Fall, Commemorated by Light
description: The 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall will be observed with miles of light during the weekend of Nov. 7 to 9.

title: Ondria Hardin Transforms Backstage at Etro
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Ondria Hardin before (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by James Pecis.

title: The Wolf Sits Down Within the Flock
description: Many colleges assign common reading to their incoming freshmen, in the hopes that a book like The Kite Runner or The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks will inspire uplifting campuswide conversation about ethics, values, justice and the good life.

title: Have Questions About Fall Cooking?
description: Fall is quickly approaching, so what better way to welcome the season than by cooking a comforting, hearty meal, or indulging in a fall fruit dessert?

title: Milan Fashion Week: Versace Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: And Then My Car Chimed In, After It Nudged Me in the Rear
description: Your car has something to tell you: Hello. Goodbye.

title: New Script, but Still Playing the Heavy
description: Were accustomed to product placements in movies, so when I took my 4-year-old son to see the animated Planes: Fire and Rescue, I wasnt surprised to see a Cadillac Escalade on the screen. The characters name, just to drive home the point, is Cad Spinner.

title: Seized and Sold: The Marshal Holds a Muscle Car Auction
description: LODI, N.J.  The first car offered was a 1970 Ford Mustang, a rare 21,000-mile Boss 429 model in Grabber Green. Not that anyone could tell the color  the lighting, a splotchy mess of glare and shadow, was that bad.

title: Coal Fades, So Electrics Get Cleaner
description: Almost as soon as modern mass-market electric vehicles became available, skeptics began asking if they actually delivered an environmental benefit. After all, they argued, charging batteries from a generating plant that burns fossil fuels simply relocates the greenhouse gas emissions to someone elses neighborhood.

title: In a Daze, Reaching for Clarity
description: Marissa Perel has a show at the Chocolate Factory Theater, but she wont get out of bed. It isnt a case of indolence, exactly, or even fatigue. The bed is onstage, and her lying in it is the central conceit of More Than Just a Piece of Sky. The work, which I saw on Thursday, is supposed to be like a dream.

title: Where Drums Glow, and Dreams Go Dark
description: For centuries, the archetypal characters of commedia dellarte have been mined so thoroughly by composers, dancers and dramatists that you would think that there is nothing fresh to uncover. Thankfully, the composer Amy Beth Kirsten did not feel this way.

title: Two Couples, Refracted Through a Prism of Emotion
description: Ivan Viripaev, a well-regarded Russian playwright and screenwriter, apparently likes a challenge. He certainly sets himself one with Illusions, his New York debut, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Its as if he asked himself, Can I create a play out of four actors who dont act so much as recite, and who never address one another?

title: The Scots Decision: Lets Stay British
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: The Weekly Wrap
description: Hello, Times Insiders. Dont miss this weeks highlights. Among them:

title: Readers Respond: On Spanking and Switching
description: Race, righteousness and revulsion threaded through reader conversations about the lines between spankings, whoopings and abuse in responses to opinion pieces regarding NFL player Adrian Petersons indictment on child abuse charges.

title: A Drug Mule for the Medicare Set
description: My mother has many attributes, but athleticism has never been one of them. She always hesitates before stepping onto an escalator and rarely walks beyond our circular driveway. So when her physician ordered her onto a treadmill last winter, it hardly seemed surprising that her heartbeat jumped dramatically, even when the pace was not brisk. She is 80, after all.

title: For the Red Bulls, Nearly Every Game Is a Must-Win
description: Last year at this time the Red Bulls were on their way to winning the first significant trophy in club history  the Supporters' Shield, which is given to the No. 1 team over all during Major League Soccers regular season.

title: Gemma Wards Comeback, Michelle Obamas Fashion Fete and Cara Delevingnes Acting Gig
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: On Raising Children Outside of Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Lung Disease: The Mining Associations View
description: To the Editor:

title: The Paleo Lifestyle: The Way, Way, Way Back
description: Which is more primal, hard cider or a strawberry margarita?

title: A 10-Step Paleo Immersion Plan
description: Want to turn back the clock 20,000 years? Here are 10 steps to becoming a full-time Paleo-ite.

title: Josh Charles Almost Takes a (Comedic) Wrong Turn
description: The actor Josh Charles was having drinks at the Derby on Orchard Street last Tuesday, on his way to a comedy show upstairs at the Slipper Room, when he spotted a blond woman walking outside whom he recognized.

title: Themes for a March: Solar City, Natural Haven
description: When the Workers Arts Coalition, a group of union members and artists, gathered to plan their float for the Peoples Climate March this Sunday, they had no shortage of design ideas: A sculpture of a human body decorated with different ecosystems? A performance piece with union guys singing in light-up vests? There was a robot, of course, said Jaime Lopez, an electrician and a founder of the group. A Climatron, Mr. Lopez said, built out with all kinds of awesome weapons, fighting climate change.

title: Under Cover: Gary Hart, First of Many
description: In the Sept. 21 cover story, Matt Bai writes about Gary Hart, a onetime shoe-in for the Democratic presidential nomination whose political career came to an end when The Miami Herald reported that he was having an affair. While early cover concepts included portraits of Hart in Red Rocks, Colo., where he announced his presidential bid in 1987, the art direction quickly shifted to include images of other politicians brought down by scandals  because, as Gail Bichler, the magazines design director, points out, Bais story really deals with the media crossing a line for the first time and making a politicians personal indiscretions into news.

title: Vocabulary Renewed, a Dialogue Continues
description: Cuban music tends to involve a direct discussion: between voice and drums, between voice and chorus, between horn sections. Jazz tends to spread a discussion around, or build a hive of many discussions at once.

title: A Band of Many Identities, but Always Furious
description: The calm, professorial demeanor of Robert Fripp  King Crimsons founder, guitarist, composer and core member since 1968  may well be rocks longest-running feat of misdirection. Starting the bands four-night stand at Best Buy Theater on Thursday night, Mr. Fripp sat in the back row of King Crimsons new seven-man lineup, facing the band more than the audience and directing most of his attention to his guitar throughout the concert.

title: Amy Cuddy Takes a Stand
description: The TED conference has made a star of many unlikely people, but perhaps no one more so than Amy Cuddy, a social psychologist and associate professor at Harvard Business School, whose talk promises personal transformation with nary a pill, cleanse or therapy bill.

title: Making a Splash on Campus
description: When Louisiana State University surveyed students in 2009 to find out what they most wanted in their new recreation complex, one feature beat out even massage therapy: a lazy river.

title: The Climax in a Tale of Green and Gritty
description: If the newest, last stretch of the High Line doesnt make you fall in love with New York all over again, I really dont know what to say. Phase 3 of the elevated park, which opens on Sunday, is a heartbreaker, swinging west on 30th Street from 10th Avenue toward the Hudson River, straight into drop-dead sunset views. It spills into a feral grove of big-tooth aspen trees on 34th Street.

title: Fatal Flaws: Crisis in Auto Safety
description: The New York Times has exposed missteps and delays by automakers and federal safety regulators in responding to deadly defects in automobiles during what became a record year for recalls.

title: Walls of Photos Uniting Little Italy
description: An outdoor exhibit on the walls of a Little Italy landmark features a local photographers then-and-now images spanning 75 years.

title: Chairmans Team Wins Commonwealth Championship
description: The 48-board final of the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Team Championship in Glasgow last week was between Wales (Gary Jones, Tim Rees, Patrick Jourdain, Tony Ratcliff, John Salisbury and Mike Tedd) and the Chairmans team (David Bakhshi, Andrew McIntosh, David Mossop and Paul Hackett and his twin sons, Jason and Justin, all from England).

title: Torturer to the Stars
description: On a recent afternoon, Sebastien Lagree knelt down and plucked a spring rigged up to an elliptical machine. He climbed aboard the Frankenstein-ian creation, one of many scattered about the Burbank, Calif., headquarters of his company, Lagree Fitness, which occupies a warehouse that brings to mind a mad scientists lab.

title: Disrupting the Playground
description: Car service app seeks to disrupt the disruptors with permits  CNBC.com

title: Lola Kirke: No Sisterly Shadow
description: AGE 23

title: Evening Hours | Grand Dames
description: Celebrating Carnegie Hall and Angela Lansbury.

title: Friday Night Music: Cheryl Wheeler, Summer Fly
description: Now that Im revisiting  I couldnt find a live performance with good sound, so heres the record performance. I think this was my favorite song of hers; resonates with a lot:

title: The Birth of DoBro
description: Every day for the past few years, the photographer Jason John Wrm has left his apartment in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, turned right at his front door and walked through Fulton Mall to the Jay Street subway station. He began to notice changes: old stores closing, new stores moving in, construction projects getting underway  your basic gentrification.

title: North Korea Agrees to Weigh Steps on Human Rights
description: GENEVA  More than half a year after a landmark report by a United Nations commission of inquiry pinned responsibility for crimes against humanity on North Koreas leadership, the Norths ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva said Friday that the North had accepted a wide range of recommendations for improving its human rights record.

title: Fraud Charges for Strip-Club Owner Who Publishes a Westchester Newspaper
description: WHITE PLAINS  He is the gadfly of Westchester County, the publisher of a free weekly newspaper who regularly rips into the countys political establishment with shoot-from-the-hip accusations that embarrass their targets even if the details are not always on target.

title: A Kingdom Still Whole, but Far From United
description: EDINBURGH  Scotland chose decisively against independence on Thursday, but it was not a vote for the status quo in Britain.

title: Redskins Doomed Debate: Pizza Edition
description: Ive lately taken to asking sports fans in Washington what they think is the over-under on how long the pro football team in Washington will be called the Redskins. One person this week told me five years  and someone overhearing the conversation immediately said, Under. On Friday, a political journalist whom I asked guessed one year.

title: New Leader Likens Poland to Reasonable Polish Woman
description: WARSAW  Polands incoming prime minister, Ewa Kopacz, said Friday that she intends to take a somewhat different, more feminine approach to the job.

title: Big Factories Go to Work on Biofuel
description: EMMETSBURG, Iowa  Charlie Kollasch, a farmer supplying raw material to a huge new ethanol factory here, stood inside a big red shed on his property, showing off the V-shaped metal frame studded with prongs that he and his son had installed on top of a flatbed truck.

title: Sculptor and Photographer Shine Light on Relics
description: The conceptual sculptor Michael Combs and the photographer Ulf Skosbergh both find poetry in the banal and express it by deconstructing and reconstructing historys detritus. But their perspectives and processes are very different. Mr. Combs, who was born on Long Island, subverts the idea of tradition, fabricating irony from raw building materials. Mr. Skogsbergh, born in Sweden, romanticizes American tradition using digital technology.

title: After Sweep, Australia Adds Security at Parliament
