title: Q. and A.: Glen Peters on China and Climate Change
description: Government leaders from across the world will gather at the United Nations in New York on Tuesday for a summit meeting on global warming, and China is at the heart of contentious negotiations on how to cut the greenhouse gas emissions behind that warming.

title: Eton Johns
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  If you think that the crossword is devoid of news, you would be wrong. Oh, sure, its an entertaining diversion from the front page, but the central down entry in Ian Livengoods puzzle, to me, was a report on the results of the Scottish referendum last week, where the country voted by A WEE BIT (55 percent, versus 45 percent voting to secede) to remain part of the United Kingdom.

title: Paul Taylors American Modern Dance Sets New Season
description: The choreographer Paul Taylor startled the dance world earlier this year by reinventing his company as Paul Taylors American Modern Dance, which he said would perform his works along with those of other modern dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers.

title: Modis Diplomacy
description: Indias Prime Minister Narendra Modi is pushing for the resolution of a border dispute with China.

title: In a Mattress, a Lever for Art and Political Protest
description: You can, for the moment, call Emma Sulkowicz a typically messianic artist, and she wont object. I used the phrase, sitting in her tiny studio at Columbia University on Thursday, as we discussed Carry That Weight. This is the succinct and powerful performance piece that is her senior art thesis as well as her protest against sexual assault on campus, especially the one she says she endured.

title: Obama to Lead U.N. Effort to Halt Movement of Terror Recruits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will preside this week over an unusual meeting of the United Nations Security Council poised to adopt a binding resolution that would compel all countries to put in place domestic laws to prosecute those who travel abroad to join terrorist organizations and those who help them, including by raising funds.

title: China Clamps Down on Web, Pinching Companies Like Google
description: HONG KONG  Googles problems in China just got worse.

title: Prozac: Revolution in a Capsule
description: When Prozac was introduced in 1988, the green-and-cream pill to treat depression launched a cultural revolution that continues to echo.

title: Bottom-Up Climate Fix
description: NEW HAVEN  WORLD leaders are at the United Nations this week, at the invitation of Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, to champion an ambitious vision anchored in action that will enable a meaningful global agreement on climate change next year.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 22
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Cancer Battle We Can Win
description: THE war against cancer can be confusing, with providers, insurers and policy makers debating the effectiveness of treatments, prevention programs and research. But there is one significant victory within our grasp. There is, increasingly, a consensus that CT screening for lung cancer can save thousands of lives each year.

title: Selling Prozac as the Life-Enhancing Cure for Mental Woes
description: When it came to pharmacological solutions to lifes despairs, Aldous Huxley was ahead of the curve. In Huxleys 1932 novel about a dystopian future, the Alphas, Betas and others populating his Brave New World have at their disposal a drug called soma. A little bit of it chases the blues away: A gramme  Huxley was English, remember, spelling included  is better than a damn. With a swallow, negative feelings are dispelled.

title: The Week Ahead: Citizens Financial Stock Offering, and a New BlackBerry
description: CITIZENS FINANCIAL GROUP TO HOLD I.P.O. IN NEW YORK

title: Why Poor Students Struggle
description: I WAS rushing to change trains at Delancey Street in downtown Manhattan earlier this year when a tall young man stepped in front of me, blocking my way through the crowd. He said my name and I looked up.

title: Whos On Trial, Eichmann or Arendt?
description: The new English translation of Bettina Stangneths Eichmann Before Jerusalem: The Unexamined Life of a Mass Murderer, is the latest in a long line of scholarship that aims to illuminate the inner life of Adolf Eichmann, one of Nazi Germanys most notorious, and most analyzed, figures. Based on troves of memoir, notes and interviews given by Eichmann in Argentina, where he lived under the pseudonym Ricardo Clement between 1950 and 1960, it is an impressive historical study  one that underscores the fanatical nature of Eichmanns anti-Semitism.

title: ISIS Forays Send Waves of Refugees Into Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Fighters from the Islamic State have been storming through Kurdish villages in northern Syria in recent days, clashing with Kurdish militias, terrifying residents and sending tens of thousands of new refugees fleeing across the border into Turkey.

title: White House May Check Tourists Blocks Away
description: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service is considering screening tourists and other visitors at checkpoints before they enter the public areas in front of the White House in response to the episode Friday in which a man with a knife managed to get through the front door of the presidents home after jumping over the fence on Pennsylvania Avenue, according to law enforcement officials.

title: The Great Pennsylvania Poultry Disaster
description: BUSHKILL, Pa.

title: Taking a Spin Through New York Citys History
description: The professor in History 3535 said some things that professors do not usually say during a history class, among them, Move over  we have to let the cab through. It was nearly 2 a.m., hardly the normal time to be lecturing 200 students.

title: The Great Beefsteak Raid
description: Since ancient times, men have stolen one anothers cattle. Theyve done so for various reasons: greed, hunger, adventure, prestige. In the Old West, cattle rustling was elevated to a fine art, involving mavericking and brand manipulation through the use of the proverbial long rope and a hot iron. But never in the history of cattle stealing in America has there been a more blatant display of strategy, nerve and determination than that shown by Gen. Wade Hampton and his force of rebel cow thieves.

title: Girl, 14, Is Killed by Gunfire on a New Jersey City Street
description: A 14-year-old girl was killed and another teenager was injured in a shooting on Saturday night in Paterson, N.J., less than three months after a 12-year-old was killed in another shooting, officials said.

title: Those Lazy Jobless
description: Last week John Boehner, the speaker of the House, explained to an audience at the American Enterprise Institute whats holding back employment in America: laziness. People, he said, have this idea that I really dont have to work. I dont really want to do this. I think Id rather just sit around. Holy 47 percent, Batman!

title: Warner Bros., After Shake-Up and Shaky Summer, Digs In
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Summer was brutal at Warner Bros., and not just because the thermometer hit 105 degrees on its sun-scorched lot here last week.

title: Spurred by ISIS Violence, Nations Mull How to Press for Justice in Conflicts
description: THE HAGUE  Western governments have begun private talks aimed at coming up with fresh strategies to speed the process of judging those responsible for grave crimes in the conflicts in Syria and Iraq.

title: Child Pornography Case Spurs Debate on Militarys Role in Law Enforcement
description: In a field office near Brunswick, Ga., a federal agent working as an undercover cybersleuth signed on to a large file-sharing network sometimes used by traders in child pornography.

title: Though Adversaries on the Surface, U.S. and Hezbollah Share a Goal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  They are sworn enemies who insist they will never work together, but in practice, Hezbollah and the United States are already working  separately  on a common goal: to stop the extremist Islamic State from moving into Lebanon, where Hezbollah is the most powerful military and political player and currently shares with Washington an interest in stability.

title: The Decision to Have an Abortion
Silver Lake Reaps a Golden Return on Its Alibaba Stake After the I.P.O.
description: The market debut of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet titan, hit the stock markets like a meteor last week, ending its first day of public trading on Friday worth a staggering $231 billion.

title: For Yankees, Farewell May Not Mean Goodbye
description: When Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera were celebrated by the Yankees during the current and previous seasons, they demonstrated the wisdom of advance planning.

title: Ways to Develop More Affordable Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Wartime Art Theft in Italy: Still an Unsettled Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Child Abuse Case: The Commissioners View
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefellers, Heirs to an Oil Fortune, Will Divest Charity of Fossil Fuels
description: John D. Rockefeller built a vast fortune on oil. Now his heirs are abandoning fossil fuels.

title: The Famous Can Present a Minefield for Doctors
description: As F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, "Let me tell you about the very rich. They are different from you and me. It is an observation that holds true, apparently, even in the operating room.

title: Feeding the Family, Feeding Resentment
From Pole to Pulpit, a Club and a Church Do Battle
description: WARSAW, Ohio  To shield churchgoers from the topless protesters, curtains are hung around the parking lot of New Beginnings Ministries. The pastor, William R. Dunfee, said families including children have been entering through a back door.

title: Childrens Health Insurance at a Crossroads
description: Federal financing for a beneficial health insurance program for low-income children, known as the Childrens Health Insurance Program or CHIP, will run out next year unless Congress agrees to extend it. Bills are pending in both the House and the Senate to extend financing for four years, to 2019. Congress should approve the extension in the lame-duck session after the midterm elections so that families and state officials will know what the future holds. The program needs to be maintained amid uncertainty as to whether other good coverage will be available for these children.

title: A Shaky Step Forward in Afghanistan
description: Afghans got a new president on Sunday, following a bitter fight over the fraud-plagued runoff election on June 14. The outcome was a brokered political accommodation that was far from democratic, but it nonetheless set the stage for an important milestone: a transfer of power that gives the government a fighting chance of containing the Taliban and mending a nation scarred by decades of war.

title: With One Battle Over in Scotland, Another Begins
description: AUCHTERARDER, Scotland  With one struggle concluded and another set to begin, this ancient slate-gray town in the russet-leaved approaches to the Scottish Highlands has been busy in recent days, swapping the political passions of last week for the breezier enthusiasms involved in preparing for what many local residents regard as the greatest sporting event ever to be staged in Scotland.

title: Candidates 1998 Strip Club Visit Stirs Kansas Governors Race
description: The Democratic candidate for governor in Kansas found himself on the defensive this weekend after acknowledging that he was caught up in a police raid of a strip club years ago.

title: EMC Said to Have Held Talks Over Merger of Equals With HP
description: The EMC Corporation, the computer storage company now facing pressure from a big activist hedge fund, had held discussions with Hewlett-Packard about a merger, though those talks have since ended, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

title: On One Brooklyn Block, Two Violent Crimes Bring Broader Scourge to Surface
description: By day, the handsome block of Irving Place that runs between Gates and Putnam Avenues in Brooklyn projects a vibrant wholesomeness. Women push strollers past the red-brick Mount Zion Tabernacle Church; young couples tote Trader Joes bags past a photo gallery; and watchful neighbors walk dogs in front of Public School 56.

title: Browns Recall Glory, Then Keep It at a Distance
description: CLEVELAND  The Cleveland Browns, a proud but forlorn N.F.L. franchise, had hoped to provide fans with a signal that positive change was on the way for a team  and a city  that has not won a major professional championship in any sport in 50 years.

title: For Migrants, a Difficult Journey Through Mexico
description: Mexico is trying to disrupt the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States. Many are determined to make the trip anyway.

title: A Chance at College for Ex-Offenders
description: There is a widely overlooked obstacle to higher education that confronts at least 70 million Americans who have criminal records  often for relatively trivial transgressions in the distant past. Many colleges ask applicants about criminal convictions before deciding on their suitability as students. And since criminal records are often inaccurate and misleading, these screening systems are inherently unfair.

title: Jerry Brown Seeks More Electric Cars in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Jerry Brown of California has signed several bills to help build the market for electric cars in his state, two days ahead of speaking alongside world leaders at the United Nations this week for a summit meeting on climate change.

title: Soldiers Graves Bear Witness to Russias Role in Ukraine
description: SELIZOVO, Russia  In a far corner of a small cemetery outside this tiny village by the Oka River, a black flag proclaiming the military might of Russias tank forces ripples in the wind above the recently dug grave of Sgt. Vladislav A. Barakov. A photograph of the baby-faced soldier in full dress uniform sits propped against a wooden cross with a small plaque that says he died on Aug. 24. He was 21.

title: Boardwalk Empire Recap: Jesus Was Wrong
description: Season 5, Episode 3: What Jesus Said

title: Filling a Prescription for a Dog
description: Dear Diary:

title: Fall TV Season Has Buzz, but Its Growing Softer
description: It is a throwback, an archaic model, a vestige of a fading business. So why does a ripple of excitement continue to surround the start of another television season?

title: In the Rhine Valley, Clamoring for Relief From Ramped-Up Rail
description: LINZ AM RHEIN, Germany  The bluffs along Germanys Rhine Valley have attracted tourists since the Romantics sung of their rustic beauty in the mid-19th century. Around the same time, the first railways were built, bringing visitors who admired the crumbling castles atop the vine-clad banks, as well as the regions white wine.

title: Mexico Makes Route Tougher for Migrants
description: TIERRA BLANCA, Mexico  Soon after crossing from Guatemala into Mexico last week, the group of Honduran migrants spotted the police swarming the freight train known as The Beast that has dangerously but reliably ferried tens of thousands of people north, clumped atop and hanging off box cars.

title: Siemens Agrees to Buy Dresser-Rand, an Oil Services Company, for $7.6 Billion
description: Siemens, the German engineering conglomerate, announced late Sunday a deal for the Dresser-Rand Group, an oil products and services company.

title: Damning Testimony and Telling Emails in Rowland Trial
description: NEW HAVEN  He was a thrice-elected governor, and last week he became a twice-convicted felon. Watching John G. Rowland come and go each day for his 13-day trial in federal court here offered some surreal moments, and not just because the people of Connecticut had seen this story unfold before.

title: U.S. Ramping Up Major Renewal in Nuclear Arms
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  A sprawling new plant here in a former soybean field makes the mechanical guts of Americas atomic warheads. Bigger than the Pentagon, full of futuristic gear and thousands of workers, the plant, dedicated last month, modernizes the aging weapons that the United States can fire from missiles, bombers and submarines.

title: Report Found Distorted Data on Jail Fights at Rikers Island
description: After years of teenage inmates being slashed, stabbed and maimed, it appeared that the jail for adolescents at Rikers Island had finally been brought under control. In April 2011, a new warden and deputy warden were named, and almost immediately, official tallies of inmate fights fell by two-thirds.

title: Growing Imbalance Between Germany and France Strains Their Relationship
description: BERLIN  It was a clear illustration of the dysfunction of the French-German partnership, the axis that for decades kept Europe on a united and dynamic track.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 21, 2014
Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 22, 2014
description: Apparently there is an unspoken order to deny losses and hide graves.

title: Russians Protest Putins Stance on Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Thousands of Russians marched through Moscow on Sunday in an antigovernment demonstration criticizing President Vladimir V. Putin for what they saw as his warmongering in Ukraine.

title: In Tense Woods, Pennsylvania State Police Shift From Prey to Hunters
description: CANADENSIS, Pa.  The Pennsylvania State Police recommend that you remain in your homes. That you not go into the surrounding woods. That you lock all doors and vehicles, keep the exterior of your home well lit, and if you see a shed open that you remember having closed, report it immediately.

title: Publications See Pinterest as Key Ally
description: Autumn is not yet upon us, but Jill Waage, a top editor at Better Homes and Gardens, has already predicted some of the biggest trends of the coming holidays. Painted pumpkins are about to replace carved pumpkins. Snowman cookies with jiggly eyes will overtake traditional gingerbread men. And decorative ribbons on Christmas presents are going to get much more creative.

title: Oculus Brings the Virtual Closer to Reality
description: LOS ANGELES  Virtual reality is virtually here  although its first incarnation will come with short battery life, images that do not quite track eye movements and a tendency to induce motion sickness.

title: Sounding Off on Climate Change
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Manhattan for a rally to demand action on climate change.

description: Warning: Contains spoilers about the new age of television.

title: The Good Wife Recap: Season 6 Begins With a Big Twist
description: Season 6, Episode 1, The Line

title: Masters of Sex Recap:  Some Ties That Bind
description: Season 2, Episode 11: One for the Money, Two for the Show

title: Familys Video Appeals to Iran for Release of American
description: Anticipating the arrival of Irans president in New York on Monday for the annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, the family of Amir Hekmati, a former United States Marine incarcerated in Tehran for three years, has called attention to the case by releasing a video in which his father, who has terminal brain cancer, appeals to Iranian leaders for Mr. Hekmatis freedom.

title: Sharing Economy Faces Patchwork of Guidelines in European Countries
description: LISBON  Start-ups like Uber and Airbnb want European consumers to embrace their companies. Yet when it comes to persuading policy makers, these companies have run into regulatory hurdles that have exposed the European Unions uneven response to technological innovation.

title: De Blasio Turns Slow Day Into Adventure
description: It was looking like a slow Saturday for Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: Promises of Greater Home Rule for Scots Turn Contentious
description: LONDON  When more home-rule powers were offered to Scotland in the heat of the countrys independence referendum campaign, the promises came with rare and unqualified support from the three main British political parties, all desperate to avert a Scottish breakaway.

title: Robert E. Poli, Leader of Pivotal Strike by Air Traffic Controllers, Is Dead at 78
description: Robert E. Poli, who led the tumultuous 1981 air traffic controllers strike, which prompted President Ronald Reagan to dismiss 11,500 controllers and is viewed as a pivotal moment in the decline of organized labor, died on Sept. 15 at his home in Meridian, Idaho. He was 78.

title: Kenny Wheeler, Influential Sound in Jazz, Dies at 84
description: Kenny Wheeler, a jazz trumpeter, flugelhornist and composer who was as comfortable improvising with uncompromising avant-gardists like the saxophonist Anthony Braxton as he was writing challenging arrangements for a big band, died on Thursday in London. He was 84.

title: A Beauty Line Rooted in the Amazon Rain Forest Introduces a Body Collection
description: The eco-conscious brand Rahua boasts the ultimate in natural resources, the Amazon rain forest, as the foundation of its hair products. There, women in the Quechua-Shuar tribes have cultivated rahua oil, derived from the rare Ungurahua nut, for centuries. That they have long, silky hair is no coincidence  the oil tames and fortifies strands, even in the regions hot and humid climate. About two decades ago, the hairstylist Fabian Lliguin began using it on his clients in New York. He even bottled it to create a 100 percent natural line of hair products: shampoos, conditioners, treatments and sprays. And today, his company introduces its first set of potions for the body  a shower gel ($30), body lotion ($48) and oil ($57)  infused with additional ingredients indigenous to the Amazon rain forest such as Sacha Inchi and Buriti oils.

title: A Topsy-Turvy Take on Existence
description: The American artist Joel Morrison sees a fragile order behind Mary Jo Bangs spectral meditation on an unseen photograph.

title: Behind the Groundbreaking Design of Aphex Twins Record Covers
description: Ever since a distinctive three-armed logo appeared in the early 90s on the sleeves of the albums of Aphex Twin  the alias of the prolific electronic music producer Richard D. James  it has remained a vital emblem for dance music fans around the world. So when a lime-green blimp bearing that insignia appeared over London (and mysterious stencils of it appeared on sidewalks around Manhattan and Brooklyn) back in mid-August, electronic music fans rejoiced, knowing that after 13 years, a new Aphex Twin album was coming. Since his disappearance from public view, Jamess influence has only grown: His example led Radiohead to embrace electronic music throughout the aughts, hes been sampled by Kanye West and the electronic dance music poster boy Skrillex has called the Aphex Twin track Flim his favorite of all time.

title: A Globalizer for N.Y.U. in Abu Dhabi
description: Six years ago, Bill Bragin, the music programmer whose hyper-multicultural lineups put Joes Pub on the international map, surprised the New York arts world by moving uptown to Lincoln Center. Now he is making an even bigger move, to Abu Dhabi.

title: A Better Baby I.C.U.
description: By many measures, a neonatal intensive care unit, or NICU, with single-family rooms produces better results than one with a shared, open-bay arrangement, a new study has found.

title: Word of the Day | insurgent
description: insurgent \in-sr-jnt\ adjective and noun

title: A Half-Marathon Record
description: Deena Kastor, 41, set a Masters world record in the half-marathon, finishing the Rock n Roll Philadelphia Half Marathon in 1 hour 9 minutes 36 seconds. Her time was 20 seconds faster than the mark set by Irina Permitina of Russia in 2008.

title: Softening the Blow
description: Some examples of edits ordered by Dora B. Schiro, then the New York City Department of Correction commissioner, to a 2012 report drafted by investigators.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING BRIGITTE BARDOT Turner Classic Movies celebrates the 80th birthday (its actually not till Sunday) of Ms. Bardot, the French actress for whom the term sex kitten was coined, with five of her signature films. The tribute begins with And God Created Woman (1956), which helped rocket Ms. Bardot to international stardom  and popularized the bikini in the process  in her role, directed by Roger Vadim, as a wanton teenage orphan in love with one brother (Jean-Louis Trintignant, above, with Ms. Bardot) but married to the other (Christian Marquand). This round and voluptuous little French miss is put on spectacular display and is rather brazenly ogled from every allowable point of view, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, calling her a phenomenon you have to see to believe. The lineup continues with Michel Boisronds Une Parisienne (1957), with Ms. Bardot as a daughter of the French president who falls in love with his chief of staff (Henri Vidal) and flirts with a prince (Charles Boyer), at 9:45; Marc Allgrets Plucking the Daisy (1956), in which she portrays a provocative Parisian schoolgirl, at 11:30; The Night Heaven Fell (1958), with Ms. Bardot, whose marriage to the films director, Mr. Vadim, ended in 1957, as a convent girl who moves in with relatives in Spain and romances a murderer (Stephen Boyd), at 1:30 a.m.; and Jean-Luc Godards Contempt (1964), in which a film adaptation of The Odyssey produced by an American (Jack Palance) and directed by Fritz Lang (as himself), causes friction between a screenwriter (Michel Piccoli) and his wife (Ms. Bardot), at 3:15.

title: Popular Demand
description: Buyers of new compact S.U.V.s are mostly 45 and older. Only the Outlander and the Encore drew less than a 20 percent share of buyers between 45 and 64, and among Encore buyers, 23.5 percent were 65 to 74.

title: Walls of Photos Uniting Little Italy
description: Last November, I got a call from Msgr. Donald Sakano, the pastor of the Basilica of St. Patricks Old Cathedral in Manhattan, about a former parishioner, Dom Quartuccio. Dom was born and raised in Little Italy and has enjoyed a successful career as a commercial photographer. But now, at the age of 90, he was concerned about his legacy.

title: Upstart Bank Aldermore to List Shares in London
description: LONDON  Aldermore said on Monday that it intended to pursue an initial public offering later this year, becoming the latest challenger bank to Britains traditional financial powers to seek to list its shares in London.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Matt Bai on Gary Hart and the Journalism That Brought Him Down
description: Matt Bai wrote the Sept. 21 cover story about the scandal that ended Gary Harts presidential campaign in 1987. Bai is the national political columnist for Yahoo News and former chief political correspondent for The New York Times Magazine. The article is an adaptation from his coming book, All the Truth Is Out: The Week Politics Went Tabloid.

description: Good morning.

title: Rural Library Chain Closes, Citing Tremendous Pressure
description: A nongovernmental organization that had run a rural library project with as many as 22 libraries across China has announced that it is closing down, citing tremendous pressure from the local authorities.

description: Tom Watson can only hope his pairings strategy lasts longer this week than the one he tried the first time he was United States Ryder Cup captain.

title: Should We Continue to Prosecute Nazi War Criminals?
description: The recent conviction of a 93-year-old Auschwitz guard reignited a debate about prosecuting the remaining few Nazi war criminals. Most observers call for a no-holds-barred hunt for the Holocaust perpetrators who have evaded justice for decades, but otherspoint to their old age, legal issues and difficulty in proving the crimes, arguing that after nearly 80years, the pursuit should come to a conclusion.

description: Googles problems in China just got worse, Keith Bradsher and Paul Mozur report.

description: HONG KONG  Thousands of Hong Kong university students abandoned classes on Monday to rally against Chinese government limits on voting rights, a bellwether demonstration of the citys appetite for turning smoldering discontent into street-level opposition.

title: Study Finds Small-Business Health Plans Are Cheaper on SHOP
description: On Thursday, in a post answering basic questions about how the Affordable Care Act affects small business, we raised the issue of how insurance premiums purchased on the marketplaces set up for small businesses, known as SHOP exchanges, compare to premiums for insurance purchased off the exchanges. It was something of an unsatisfying discussion.

title: Morning Agenda: Alibabas I.P.O. Aftermath
description: ALIBABAS I.P.O. AFTERMATH | For months, investors eagerly awaited the Alibaba Groups public market debut. Now, with the Chinese e-commerce giants first day of trading solidly in the rearview mirror, nearly everyone is likely breathing a sigh of relief. After pricing at $68 a share, Alibabas stock finished Friday up 38 percent, at $93.89, giving the company a market value of $231 billion, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. The company officially set the record for the biggest initial public offering ever, after its bankers on Friday decided to exercise a so-called green shoe option, allowing them to increase the size of the deal by 15 percent, from $21.8 billion to $25 billion.

title: In Context, Health Premium Increases Dont Actually Look Like Increases
description: In the Affordable Care Act marketplaces, which now serve 7.3 million Americans, some premiums are going up while others are going down. Based on data available so far, we reported last week that the average premiums for last years most popular plans would rise 8.4 percent, but that people willing to switch plans could get much better deals  an average 1 percent increase, and even decreases in some markets.

title: A History of the United Nations in Pictures
description: A look at the visitors and the activities at the United Nations over the years.

title: Schools Under Fire for Too Much Pomp in Military Training
description: College administrators in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui have come under criticism for conducting reviews of students participating in military-style training in a style reminiscent of a head of state. At two private colleges in Hefei, school officials rode in black Audis, the car favored by government cadres, and one of the officials parroted lines that could have come from the Chinese presidents mouth on a National Day celebration.

title: Mitsubishi to Buy Salmon Producer for $1.39 Billion
description: Cermaq, a Norwegian state-controlled salmon producer, has agreed to be acquired by the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan for $1.39 billion.

title: First Drafts First Day
description: Carl Hulse is The Timess chief Washington correspondent and managing editor of First Draft, a political news stream and morning email that began today. He explains what went in to beginning the new project:

title: Alaska Ad Finds a Target in Begichs Support of Gun Rights
description: Senator Mark Begich of Alaska was one of just five Democratic senators who voted against a bipartisan gun control bill last year, helping to ensure its failure.

description: In a new Insider feature, Pamela Paul, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, extends the By the Book column to Times writers and editors.

title: Auxiliums Board Rejects Takeover Approach From Endo
description: Auxilium Pharmaceuticals said on Monday that its board of directors had rejected an unsolicited takeover approach from Endo International, a pharmaceutical company that struck an inversion deal last year and reincorporated in Ireland.

title: Tesco Says It Overstated Profit Forecast
description: LONDON  Tesco, the large British grocery retailer, disclosed on Monday that it had overstated its expected half-year profit by about $400 million and that it had suspended four senior executives.

title: First-Weekend Sales of Apples iPhone 6 Models Top 10 Million
description: Apples investors obsess over early iPhone sales like Hollywood producers tracking opening ticket sales for a blockbuster movie.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Tibetan Student Burns Himself to Death in Protest
description: BEIJING  A Tibetan student burned himself to death last week in protest of Chinese rule in the first self-immolation in five months, an international human rights organization reported on Monday.

title: Life in Belle Epoque America
description: The Atlantic has an article about a website that sets up mutually beneficial relationships between wealthy older men and college students. Yes, its prurient, and Im probably a dirty old man for even linking to it  although what really caught my eye was just how closely reality echoes Woody Allens (speaking of dirty old men) story The Whore of Mensa.

title: Ready for Impact: The Clintons Annual Extravaganza
description: What do you get when you put Hollywood starlets, a couple of Nobel Peace Prize winners, chief executives of several multinational corporations, the king of Jordan and a current, a former and a potentially future United States president together in the lobby of a middling Times Square hotel?

title: Explosions Kill at Least 2 in Restive Region of China
description: BEIJING  A series of explosions in the Xinjiang region of northwest China has killed at least two people and caused an unknown number of injuries, state news media reported Monday.

title: Verbatim: Bloomberg on Balancing Work and Life
description: Because the alternative was staying home and talking to Diana about feelings  Michael R. Bloomberg, explaining why he returned recently to the company he founded. He was referring to Diana Taylor, his girlfriend.

title: A Super-Simple, Step-by-Step Guide to Determine if Your Team Mascot Is Offensive
description: There has been a lot of debate in the news about whether the team name of the Washington N.F.L. team is racially offensive and ought to be changed. On Friday, David Leonhardt saw a reason to predict that the team name Redskins was not long for this world.

title: A Nosedive in Public Approval for Obama on Immigration
description: President Obamas poor approval ratings have been widely reported. But what is especially striking, in a recent New York Times/CBS survey, is how precipitously the president has fallen on the issue of immigration.

title: The Temporary-Equilibrium Method (Very Wonkish)
description: David Glasner has some thoughts about macroeconomic methodology, reacting to my own previous piece, that I mostly agree with, but not entirely. So, a bit more.

title: In Milan, Sneakers and Slides
description: Designers are eschewing the towering stilettos of yore for flat footwear.

title: A Tower Will Rise Next to, and Over, a Paint-Spattered Landmark
description: In a city built on unlikely juxtapositions, there may be no odder neighbors than the Art Students League, which occupies an ornate French Renaissance-style building at 215 West 57th Street, and the Nordstrom Tower, an ultramodern pillar, at least 1,500 feet tall, that will rise beside it.

title: The 70s in Milan
description: The ubiquity of the decade in both catwalk and accessory presentations this week was almost unprecedented.

title: An Article on Shonda Rhimes Rightly Causes a Furor
description: The article on the television producer Shonda Rhimes hadnt yet appeared in Sundays paper, but the virtual world was ablaze in protest over it on Friday after it was published online.

title: P2 Capital Partners Raises Pressure on Epiq, a Maker of Legal Software
description: After several months of discussions, Epiq Systems, a software company that provides legal documents for bankruptcy and class-action cases and discovery, rejected a $1.1 billion offer from the hedge fund P2 Capital Partners to take the company private.

title: The White House Front Door, When Entered Properly
description: The White House door that a knife-carrying fence jumper waltzed through on Friday night, prompting a review of procedures by the Secret Service, is not just the entrance to one of the nations most supposedly secure facilities. It is also one of the most famous entryways anywhere, where world leaders are greeted and departing presidents meet their successors.

title: 1889: Five Miles a Minute
description: After the telephone and the phonograph one can believe almost any imaginable electrical miracle, and therefore the claim that an electric railway motor has been invented which, on a specially constructed road, can whisk passengers and freight along at the rate of 300 miles an hour does not seem incredible. In fact, it is asserted that a speed of 180 miles an hour has already been attained on an experimental road. Should the invention prove successful, it will bring London within an hour of Paris  exclusive of the Channel passage  and will enable the Londoner to do business in the city and to sleep in the Scottish Highlands every night.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 23, 1889

title: Final Trends and Tidbits to Know From Milan
description: The reports have been written, the reviews are in, but after the sensory extravaganza that was Milan Fashion Week, some outstanding questions may still be niggling. In an effort to wipe the slate clean and to allow us all a fresh start in Paris, here are four questions that bubbled up in conversations from the catwalk to cocktails, and responses to keep you in the know:

title: Nothing Natural About This
description: From a PVC raincoat to a bonded latex cable-knit, synthetic materials are making a range of everyday fashion staples feel unexpectedly subversive.

title: Ask Us Anything: First Drafts Politics Help Line
description: Have a question about what seems to be an exaggerated claim in a campaign advertisement? Or the accuracy of a statement made on the trail?

title: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to Open United Nations Meetings
description: On Monday at the United Nations, the first world conference on indigenous peoples began, the day before Ban Ki-Moon, the United Nations secretary general, opened the Climate Summit. Wednesday, the secretary general opens the 69th session of the General Assembly. It has been an important week for the United Nations, and for Mr. Ban, who will speak before the General Assembly meeting.

title: Spanking Isnt Culture. Its a Cycle of Abuse.
description: As the debate rages over Adrian Petersons child abuse charges, his defenders, including Charles Barkley, have suggested that this particular kind of discipline  lashing a child with a switch  is cultural and therefore beyond reproach.

title: What to Wear This Week: Sept. 22
description: During the recent New York spring shows, Marc Jacobs presented several cargo looks that seemed to borrow from a police officers uniform. There were also military-inspired dresses at No. 21 and Gucci. Then, at Milan Fashion Week, we saw a similar idea at the Salvatore Ferragamo show.

title: 1939: Line of Demarcation Decided
description: Following the departure from Moscow yesterday morning of a German military mission charged with the negotiation for the partition of Poland between Germany and Russia, the D.N.B., official German news agency, announced that both governments had fixed the line of demarcation between the German and Russian armies, a Havas dispatch from Berne said. According to the D.N.B. communiqu, Germany abandons the idea of re-establishing the German and Russian occupation zones agreed upon in the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk in 1917.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 23, 1939

title: Medicaid Gives the Poor a Reason to Say No Thanks
description: There are generally two ways that people with insurance pay for health care in the United States: premiums, which get you insurance before you receive care, and a variety of cost-sharing mechanisms  like deductibles, co-pays and coinsurance  that come into play when you do receive it.

title: First Draft | Biden on Gridlock
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. says a main reason for gridlock in Washington is that politics have become too personal.

title: The Voices Secret to Longevity
description: After a press lunch the other day with cast members from The Voice, NBC sent everyone home with goodie bags. The contents included a bottle of Ketel One vodka, around which was tied an index card containing a recipe for Carson Dalys Hangover-Curing Magical Bloody Mary.

title: First Draft Video: Biden on Fixing Washington
description: As a four-decade veteran of the Senate and now the White House, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been in the middle of plenty of political scuffles and has seen Washington at its worst up close.

title: What Is the Right Way to Travel?
description: Wherefore the bucket list? Rebecca Mead recently wrote a blog post for The New Yorker about Kicking the Bucket List, a plea for abolishing the practice of seeking experiences for the sake of accomplishment. Instead, Ms. Mead lobbies in favor of an approach to life that engages deeply with a smaller range of experiences.

title: Hong Kong Students Rally for Reform
description: Pro-democracy protesters explain why they gathered at the Chinese University of Hong Kong for the start of a week-long boycott of classes.

title: Woman Hit by a Bicyclist in Central Park Dies
description: A woman whom a cyclist struck in Central Park last week died Sunday night, her family said on Monday

title: Today in Small Business: How a Store Smells
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Wine as the Supporting Player in an Ensemble Cast at Home
description: People who love wine generally consume more of it at home than anywhere else. And regardless of the quality of their glasses or the extent of their cellars, those who most enjoy wine at home share one attribute: a commitment to drinking it.

title: Seeking a Same-Sex Marriage Case Fit for History
description: WASHINGTON  The jockeying among the titans of the Supreme Court bar for a place at the lectern when the justices hear the next same-sex marriage case is as understated as it is unmistakable.

title: Theatrics to Come on the U.N. Security Council
description: There could be major drama on the United Nations Security Council next year if, as widely expected, Venezuela gets a seat adjacent to that of its nemesis, the United States, to represent Latin American and Caribbean nations.

title: What Wake-up Call? Catering to Sleepers-In
description: The travel industry is geared toward early risers: activities and tours tend to begin in the morning, and breakfast is usually served for a limited time. Thats finally changing with more hotels, cruise lines and tour companies catering to travelers who like to sleep in or want a leisurely start to their day.

title: Climate Change Protesters Tangle With Police at Wall St.
description: About 100 climate change protesters were arrested on Monday as hundreds marched through the streets of Lower Manhattan, at one point clashing with the police as they tried to push through barricades sealing off Wall Street.

title: Prosecutor Warns That Rikers Island Problems May Prompt U.S. Lawsuit
description: As alarm mounted this year over conditions at the Rikers Island jail complex, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio largely managed to escape scrutiny, because the problems were rooted in its predecessor.

title: Iggy Pop to Lecture at British Radio Festival
description: Iggy Pop has been lots of things  a thrashing founder of punk rock, a film and television actor, the author of an autobiography, a radio show host and even an opera singer (in John Morans avant-garde opera The Manson Family). But if you were looking for someone to deliver a lecture, he might not leap immediately to mind.

title: Why Is Unemployment High? Lazy Americans, Boehner Says
description: Speaker John A. Boehner opens virtually every news conference with, Mr. President, where are the jobs? a dig at an Obama economy that he says is still not working. But last week, he appeared to undermine his own message when he suggested that the unemployed were not victims of failing economic policies, but of sloth.

title: Gary Hewitts Numberplay Comment Enhancer
description: The New York Times Numberplay blog, like many blogs featured in The Times online, offers a terrific way to connect with a community of passionate and articulate readers from around the world. Numberplay conversations are a lot like those youd find gathered around any blog, with a couple additional features: The conversations are about math, which means formulas may be sprinkled into the mix, and theyre also highly collaborative.

title: A Light Touch
description: Cedric Hartmans understated floor lamp became an immediate design classic when it launched in 1966  and has never fallen from favor.

title: Charles Plosser and Richard Fisher, Both Dissenters, to Retire From Fed
description: WASHINGTON  Two Federal Reserve officials who have warned loudly and persistently that the Fed is overreaching in its economic stimulus campaign plan to retire next year after completing terms on the Feds policy-making committee.

title: Gary Hewitts Train Puzzle
description: Before we get to this weeks puzzle  several days ago I asked Donald Knuth, the legendary computer scientist currently at Stanford University, how he would have solved our recent Bugs on a Square problem, which is a classic among software engineers. He responded by saying he would have worked the problem out with algebra (and not a simulation, which surprised me). And then he followed with a fitting analogy for the kind of puttering that defines Numberplay.

title: Many Americans Want More Religion in Their Politics
description: The Pew Research Center reported Monday that 72 percent of Americans believe religion is losing its influence on American life, a striking development in a nation where religious arguments, religious leaders and religious voting blocs have long played an important role.

title: Morgan Exhibition Will Feature Lincolns Words
description: The Abraham Lincoln juggernaut that will get under way next year  on the 150th anniversary of his assassination and the end of the Civil War  will include a major component in New York, centered around perhaps Lincolns greatest legacy: his words.

title: In the Studio | Alber Elbaz of Lanvin
description: Alber Elbaz, the creative director for Lanvin, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his all-black office in Paris is the only place he feels skinny and beautiful.

title: A Quick Lesson in Politics for Donald Trump
description: First Draft context: If the Republicans were to win control of the Senate in November, Senator Mitch McConnell would most likely become Senate majority leader, not speaker of the House.

title: Weeks of U.S. Strikes Fail to Dislodge ISIS in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  After six weeks of American airstrikes, the Iraqi governments forces have scarcely budged the Sunni extremists of the Islamic State from their hold on more than a quarter of the country, in part because many critical Sunni tribes remain on the sidelines.

title: ScienceTake | Ice Fish Dont Melt
description: Natural antifreeze in the blood of Antarctic fish also keeps ice crystals from normal melting.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Jonathan Adams joined Maxus, part of the GroupM unit of WPP, in a new post, chief digital officer for North America, based in New York. He had been senior vice president and lead for North American media at iCrossing, part of the Hearst Corporation. At iCrossing, Christine Bensen was promoted to succeed Mr. Adams with the title of senior vice president for media and head of the media practice.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Valuing SoftBank in Alibabas Aftermath
description: Alibabas runaway initial public offering has turned the spotlight back onto SoftBanks valuation quandary. Following the Chinese e-commerce companys successful New York listing, the Japanese conglomerates 32 percent stake eclipses the value of its other businesses. The 5 percent drop in SoftBanks shares on Monday is a reminder that the investment is both blessing and burden.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case a Chance to Make History
description: When the Supreme Court finally takes up the issue of same-sex marriage, it will no doubt make history. And the battle for the history books is a fierce one for Americas legal luminaries.

title: Cash-Stuffed German Companies on a Global Buying Spree
description: Germanys businesses have been the rare bright spot in the European economy in recent years, generating jobs and profits even as neighboring countries face persistent unemployment.

title: An Attack on Guns Tests Good Will Toward Giffords
description: Gabrielle Giffords is about to find out just what sort of leeway being the nations most recognizable  and well liked  gunshot victim gives you when it comes to political attack ads.

title: Portraits of Women Take Over an Oxford Dining Hall
description: Hertford College, one of the first colleges at Oxford University to admit women for both housing and instruction, is celebrating 40 years of coeducation by belatedly giving women a full place at the table, figuratively speaking.

title: Testing Future Conditions for the Food Chain
description: SAVOY, Ill.  From afar, the three young men tramping through a corn field here looked like Midwestern farm boys checking their crop. And a fine crop it seemed to be, with plump ears hanging off vibrant green stalks.

title: Humanitys Long Climate and Energy March
description: The Peoples Climate March, a globe-spanning set of demonstrations centered in Manhattan, was a testament to environmentalists fortitude and organizational skills and a spreading sense that humanitys fossil-fueled path  and, for some, the economic model underpinning it  is not sustainable.Iwas glad to see big contingents of students in the crowds, representing the generation that inherits the epic task of shifting humanitys energy menu.

title: Jack Ma on Alibaba, Entrepreneurs and the Role of Handstands
description: Bill George is a professor of management at Harvard Business School and a former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic.

title: White House Will Use Locks More Often
description: Updated, 2:34 p.m. |

title: New Initiative for Special Olympics Aims for More Spontaneity, Less Marketing
description: A red ball is the star of a campaign for the Special Olympics, aimed at youth around the world, that seeks support and encouragement for people with intellectual disabilities.

title: Michigan Music School Concert to Feature Gershwins Piano
description: The last piano George Gershwin owned and performed on  a Steinway Model A, made in 1933 and delivered to Gershwin in January, 1934  will make its 21st-century public debut in a free concert at the University of Michigans School of Music, Theater & Dance, in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Oct. 10, the university announced.

title: At a New Amsterdam Pop-Up, Dining Among Rembrandts in the Sky
description: Cooking is like painting with taste, so I was fascinated by the idea of creating a menu based on Rembrandts work, says the Dutch chef Wilco Berends, explaining why he chose to head the kitchen at Heavenly Rembrandt, a pop-up dinner-only restaurant that is set to be one of the most intriguing events in Amsterdam this fall. The interdisciplinary project, which opens tonight, is a collaboration between the Het Rembrandthuis museum, which occupies the house where the painter lived and worked from 1639 to 1658; Berends, who normally cooks at his Michelin-starred De Nederlanden restaurant in Vreeland; and the Rembrandt Tower boardrooms, a plush suite of private meeting rooms atop the 35-story, 500-foot-tall Rembrandt Tower, the citys tallest building.

title: Movie Review: Tracks
description: The Times film critic Manohla Dargis reviews Tracks.

title: Leading French Chef Has Plans for New York
description: Anne-Sophie Pic, one of only a few female chefs in the world to be awarded three Michelin stars, for her restaurant in the South of France, will extend her reach to New York City next year.

title: Raids by ISIS Push Flood of Refugees Into Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey  More than 130,000 refugees have flooded into Turkey from Syria in recent days, fleeing attacks by Islamic State militants on their villages, Turkeys deputy prime minister said on Monday, though local officials in Syria said Kurdish militias had blunted the militants advance there.

title: Verbatim: The Clinton Family Business
description: Bill Clinton, on why Chelsea and Hillary Clinton are taking a bigger role in the familys philanthropic foundation.

title: Criticism of Study Detecting Ripples From Big Bang Continues to Expand
description: Stardust got in their eyes.

title: Barclays Hires Former Citigroup Banker to Head Wealth Management
description: LONDON  The British lender Barclays said on Monday that it had hired a former banker at Citigroup to head its wealth management business.

title: No Comment Necessary: Officer-Involved Shooting  You Can Win With the Media
description: Post-Ferguson, the St. Louis County and Municipal Police Academy is offering a training course on how to win with the media, which promises numerous practical tips for handling the media in an officer-involved shooting.

title: Pennsylvania State Police Say They Are Close to Capturing Suspect in Troopers Shooting
description: BLOOMING GROVE, Pa.,  Pennsylvania authorities said Monday that they believed they were closing in on a self-taught survivalist accused of killing one state trooper and wounding a second during an ambush earlier this month outside a police barracks in the Pocono Mountains.

title: Hurd: Oracle Takes On Microsoft in the Cloud
description: Not to give too much away, but Mark Hurd, the newly minted co-chief executive of Oracle Corporation, is ready for a battle. It starts this Sunday night, and it features his boss, Lawrence J. Ellison, throwing down against Microsoft for control of corporate cloud computing applications.

title: Talk in Synagogue of Israel and Gaza Goes From Debate to Wrath to Rage
description: With the war in Gaza still raging, Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum offered an unusual prayer for peace last month during a Friday night service at the large predominantly gay synagogue she leads in New York. Cautioning her flock not to harden our hearts against any who had suffered, she wove throughout the prayer the names of young Israeli soldiers  as well as Palestinian children  who were killed in Gaza.

title: Muti Withdraws From Rome Opera Performances
description: ROME  Riccardo Muti will not conduct two operas scheduled for the upcoming season at the Teatro dellOpera di Roma, citing recent, persistent problems at the storied  and strike-plagued  theater. Carlo Fuortes, the operas general manager, announced the split on Sunday, citing a personal letter by the maestro stating that conditions at the theater did not guarantee the serenity I need to ensure the success of the performances.

title: If Nothing Else, a Speech From Obama on Climate
description: When President Obama addresses the United Nations Climate Summit on Tuesday, he wont be announcing a breakthrough on environmental policy. Opposition in Congress to carbon taxes remains high, and expectations for progress around the world are low, as rich and poor countries continue to clash over long-simmering environmental disputes.

title: Picking the Right Hedge Fund Involves More Than Looking in the Past
description: Early in my career, I worked at a large brokerage firm. My job included answering calls from people with questions. One question kept coming up: What does your Individual Retirement Account return? The first few times, I thought it was a joke. But it didnt take long for me to realize that people just didnt understand the difference between an I.R.A. and the investments held in an I.R.A.

title: Pursuit of Individuals in Corporate Misconduct Still Arduous
description: The Justice Department went on a bit of a charm offensive last week to emphasize to the public that prosecutions for corporate misconduct should not end with just a settlement with the company, which these days usually means paying a hefty fine that causes its stock price to rise. Instead, prosecutors want to focus on reaching individuals within an organization who are responsible for the wrongdoing, including those in the so-called C-suite, where senior officers preside over the operation.

title: Portland Will Still Be Cool, but Anchorage May Be the Place to Be
description: Alaskans, stay in Alaska. People in the Midwest and the Pacific Northwest, sit tight.

title: A Reading of Long-Exposure Photograph of a Man by Mary Jo Bang
description: The American poet reads her verse on an unseen photograph.

title: New Chief of Spy Unit Is Appointed in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military chief, Gen. Raheel Sharif, on Monday appointed a close ally as head of the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence spy agency, consolidating his power at a time of sharp tension with the countrys civilian leaders and fluctuating policy toward the Taliban.

title: Veteran Bon Appetit Writer Named as Editor in Chief of Saveur
description: The food magazine Saveur has announced that Adam Sachs, a veteran writer of GQ and Bon Appetit, will become the magazines next editor in chief.

title: For Polar Bears, a Climate Change Twist
description: LA PROUSE BAY, Manitoba  The sea ice here on the western shore of Hudson Bay breaks up each summer and leaves the polar bears swimming for shore. The image of forlorn bears on small rafts of ice has become a symbol of the dangers of climate change.

title: Fast Food for Polar Bears
description: Polar bears have become a symbol of the danger of climate change, but in the Western Hudson Bay, scientists have found that our understanding of climate change may not be as simple as it seemed.

title: Obama Not Bailing on a Judicial Nominee
description: As First Draft reported this morning, Michael Boggss prospects of being confirmed to the federal bench in Georgia are not looking good.

title: Draghi Pessimism on European Recovery Stirs Expectations of Stimulus
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, gave a more pessimistic view of the eurozone economy on Monday than he did just a few weeks ago, in a statement that could encourage speculation that a stronger stimulus plan is in the works.

title: In California, a Marriage of Dance and Design
description: In 1966, the landscape architect Lawrence Halprin and the dance pioneer Anna Halprin invited 40 young people to Northern California to participate in a roving summer workshop. Moving from San Francisco north to Sea Ranch, the modernist coastal development master-planned by Mr. Halprin, the architects, artists and dancers investigated the common ground between the couples two professions: the environment. They staged a happening in Union Square, took blindfolded walks, built a village of driftwood and dropped paper from trees. A new exhibition at the Graham Foundation in Chicago, Experiments in Environment: The Halprin Workshops, 1966-1971, explores the Halprins interdisciplinary creative process through photographs, films, drawings and the scores that gave the participants movement a shape and a purpose. Mr. Halprin died in 2009, but Ms. Halprin, 94, spoke about the workshops and her continuing dance practice earlier this month. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Weekly Quandary: Whose Last Name?
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, follow up on the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary came via email, but it was an email with a specific source: an article about a couple in Tennessee, Kim Sarubbi and Carl Abramson, who combined their surnames to give their first two children a single, blended last name instead of a hyphenated one.

title: Air France Pilots Vow to Extend Strike Indefinitely
description: PARIS  Air France pilots rejected a proposal from management on Monday and vowed to extend indefinitely a strike that has grounded tens of thousands of passengers over the last week and threatens to wipe out tens of millions of dollars in revenue.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Chris Brown
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the challenges of appraising Chris Brown.

title: A Mother in Jail for Helping Her Daughter Have an Abortion
description: On Sept. 12th, Jennifer Whalen, a 39-year-old mother of three in the rural town of Washingtonville, Pa., went to jail to begin serving a 9-to-18-month sentence. Whalens crime was, in effect, ordering pills online that her older daughter took in the first several weeks of an unplanned pregnancy, when she was 16, to induce a miscarriage. The medication was a combination of mifepristone (formerly called RU-486) and misoprostol. The drugs have been available from a doctor with a prescription in the United States since 2000 and are used around the world to induce miscarriage.

title: The Collapse of Western Civilization
description: Naomi Oreskes talks about her new book that attempts to imagine how historians of the future might view our actions  or lack thereof  to combat climate change.

title: Amazon Workers Strike in Germany
description: Workers of the online retailer took action again on Monday in a long-running dispute over pay and conditions.

title: The Legacy of a Falling Spider
description: One of my frugal trademarks is being willing to sleep just about anywhere. A Chinese hotel stinking of cigarettes with a mattress as soft as quarried granite, a jail-cell-size Guatemalan room with filthy walls for $6, the passenger seat of a compact rental car on the side of a Puerto Rican highway, its all good.

title: Fullscreen Sells Control to Joint Venture Between AT&T and Chernin Group
description: The Fine Brothers, Connor Franta and Our2ndLife may not ring a bell to people over the age of 30.

title: Hamilton Wins in Singapore and Logano in New Hampshire
description: Lewis Hamilton on Sunday won the Singapore Grand Prix, taking over the points lead for the 2014 Formula One drivers championship.

title: Klinghoffer: An Opera and a Protest
At Mets Opening Night, Protesting a Production
description: Some traditions of opening night at the Metropolitan Opera go back decades, like beginning with The Star-Spangled Banner, while others are more recent, like showing the operas free on outdoor movie screens at Lincoln Center and Times Square. When operagoers arrived for opening night on Monday, they were greeted with an even newer tradition: street protests.

title: Amazon Workers Walk Off the Job in Germany Over Wage Dispute
description: BERLIN Amazon employees in Germany, frustrated by the companys refusal to hold wage talks, walked off their jobs Monday in a coordinated strike at four of the companys distribution centers.

title: Piagets Groundbreaking 1970s Cuff Watch, Renewed
description: If there ever was an object that perfectly captured the louche sexiness and that somehow tremendously appealing drab green of the 70s, this Piaget watch is it. Inspired by similar designs in its archive, the Swiss jeweler has created this decadent cuff to commemorate its 140th anniversary. The watch has a natural jade dial and is set in a gold cage with 236 brilliant-cut diamonds that give the illusion of rising from the wrist like a great pyramid.

title: Why Are We So Obsessed With Gilmore Girls?
description: After the WB series Gilmore Girls concluded in 2007, I gradually managed to acquire all seven seasons on DVD, unable to part with the quirky but infinitely relatable characters, the charming small town I wanted to live in and the lightning-speed dialogue peppered with references waiting to be decoded. As soon as I had the entire collection, the 42 discs started disappearing in my friends homes. To this day, they claim innocence.

title: Beauty in the Beets
description: I sometimes wonder when Ill run out of ideas for beets, as year after year around this time Ive devoted a weeks worth of Recipes for Health to beets and their greens. But it hasnt happened yet. Beetroots, whether roasted, steamed or raw, easily find their way into new salads, side dishes and main dishes. They are friendly with Mediterranean seasonings of all kinds: Greek, Middle Eastern, North African, Italian and Provenal. The greens are interchangeable with other mild-tasting greens like Swiss chard and spinach; one bunch of beets gives you two vegetables to work with. With the beets and their greens you get two sets of nutrients: anthocyanins and betalains, known for their antioxidant properties, from the beetroots, and vitamins K and A, as well as other phytonutrients  lutein and zeaxanthin  from the greens. Both are excellent sources of folate, and beets are a very good source of manganese, potassium and copper.

title: Popcast: What We Talk About When We Talk About Chris Brown
description: Chris Browns new album, X, has been a long time coming  it was first announced a year ago, before he served a few months of jail time unrelated to his 2009 felony charges for assaulting his then-girlfriend, Rihanna. Jon Caramanica wrote about X this week, but our Popcast conversation is less about the album than the complicated task of writing about Mr. Brown as a music critic.

title: Staying Cool When the Fat Hits the Fire
description: When Im with a chef, I always ask for the secret to good cooking.

title: New Super PAC Aims for Better Beer
description: A reminder that all you need to form a super PAC is a bank account and a stamp: Three Pennsylvania law students have formed Americans for Better Brewing, a new super PAC presumably devoted to, well, higher quality beer. The committee, also known as Six-PAC, is based in Newville, Pa., not far from Penn States Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, where the PACs officers are students, according to postings on various social networks. No word on whether student beer money will be used to provide funding.

title: When Johnny Came Questioning Home
description: When the stage lights go up at the Acorn Theater on Harry Feiners set for Almost Home, a dingy Bronx apartment kitchen in 1965, every prop looks period-perfect. As the play unfolds, Michael McDonalds costumes and Quentin Chiappettas subtle but evocative sound design prove just as commendable.

title: Dispute Over High Schools Canceled Spamalot Leads to Directors Departure
description: Controversy is intensifying in South Williamsport, Penn., over a high school principals cancellation of a student production of the acclaimed musical Spamalot. School officials on Friday dismissed the shows director after months of back-and-forth arguments  which drew unflattering media attention  over whether the principal canceled Spamalot because of the shows gay content. Supporters of the production are organizing a rally for Monday evening before the meeting of the towns school board, while the theater director is considering options in response to her firing.

title: Human Role in Warming of Northwest Played Down
description: A new and most likely controversial analysis of Pacific Ocean weather patterns concludes that a century-long trend of rising temperatures in the American Northwest is largely explained by natural shifts in ocean winds, not by human activity.

title: Outgrowing Childhood Horrors in Beslan
description: Ten years after Chechen separatists took over a school in Beslan, resulting in the death of 186 students, the survivors find a way forward.

title: Battling Red Tape, in America and China
description: We all carry stereotypes, especially of people we have yet to meet and places we have yet to visit. Sometimes these stereotypes are reinforced by movies and literature, which makes me cringe: I hate to think that foreigners might conclude that Mrs. Cleaver of Leave it to Beaver is representative of American women or that John Waynes callused tough guys who grit their way through anything are typical of American men.

title: White House Intruder Arrested in July With Cache of Weapons
description: The man who scaled the White House fence on Friday and ran into the front door of the presidential residence had been arrested by Virginia State Police in July with a cache of automatic weapons, a sniper rifle and a map of Washington, D.C., with writing and a line drawn to the White House, law enforcement officials said.

title: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Cancels Concerts
description: The management of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra announced on Monday that because of ongoing labor negotiations with its musicians, it has canceled the first seven weeks of its season, from Sept. 25 through Nov. 8.

title: In Stand-Up and Sitcoms, Nonchalantly Blazing a Path
description: Mark Whitakers biography of Bill Cosby is, like its subject, old school. Its square, competent, gentle, G-rated, dignified and, in the end, a bit distant.

title: Antifreeze Proteins Keep Antarctic Fish Alive and Icy
description: Fish in McMurdo Sound and elsewhere in the seas around Antarctica have to survive in temperatures below freezing. Its not surprising, then, that they have evolved natural antifreeze proteins.

title: White House Intruders Past Raises Concern
description: WASHINGTON  Secret Service officers stopped Omar Jose Gonzalez last month as he carried a hatchet in front of the White House, but let him go even though he had been arrested this summer in Virginia with a mini-arsenal of semiautomatic weapons, a sniper rifle and a map clearly marking the White Houses location.

title: Magic, With Four Main Ingredients
description: Open your refrigerator: how many bottles of salad dressing are lurking in the door? If youre an average American shopper, you add one or two bottles to that sticky collection every couple of months.

title: Three Divergent Visions of Our Future Under Climate Change
description: First, some cheerful news from the Future of Western Civilization Department: Cliff swallows in the Great Plains are evolving to have shorter wings. This helps them to swerve more easily away from speeding cars on the interstate. Over time, a behavioral ecologist at the University of Tulsa says, weve begun to notice that we were seeing fewer dead birds on the roads.

title: Poroshenkos Presence at U.N. General Assembly Is in Doubt
description: The foreign minister of Ukraine said Monday that it was unclear whether President Petro O. Poroshenko would travel to New York to deliver his scheduled address before the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday. It is possible, Foreign Minister Pavlo Klimkin told reporters, there will be a change in the program. He offered no details except to say that the crisis in the country could compel Mr. Poroshenko to remain in Ukraine.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted September 10 through 14 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States.

title: The Secret History of Mexican Cooking Was Written by Women
description: As my taco pilgrimage through Mexico with the Danish chef Ren Redzepi of Noma was winding to a close in the languorous city of Mrida, I was starting to worry that we were going to miss out on one of the dishes I was most looking forward to. By then we had chewed and slurped our way through everything from the tasting menu at Pujol, chef Enrique Olveras gastronome-magnet in Mexico City, to fresh coconuts bought by the side of a jungle road. But we still hadnt had cochinita pibil.

title: Will Lee Named Editor of People.com
description: People on Monday announced a crucial hire who will help determine the magazines digital future.

title: Obama to Meet With Netanyahu at White House
description: The White House said Monday that President Obama would meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Oct. 1 in Washington.

title: Global Warming Concerns Grow
description: While few Americans regard the environment as the nations foremost challenge, most say it should be a priority, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. And more than half say global warming is caused by human behavior, the highest level ever recorded by the national poll.

title: An Animal Gamble in the Arctic
description: The Arctic is changing  fast. Two experts who have spent decades working there believe that the marine mammals who call the high latitudes home are now locked into a human-forced ecological game of chance.

title: Woman Arrested at Kennedy Airport With Marijuana and Guns, Officials Say
description: A 24-year-old woman was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday morning after the authorities discovered two handguns, hundreds of rounds of ammunition and 33 pounds of marijuana concealed in her luggage.

title: A Future as Clouded as Their Past
description: We wont ever know what the Anasazi were thinking on the eve of the 13th century when they abandoned the cities they had worked so long to build on the Colorado Plateau. The reasons had something to do with climate  a great drought and, perhaps on top of that, a mini ice age. If that wasnt enough to defeat a thriving culture, there was the turmoil that came from just not knowing. Why were the sky and earth behaving so strangely? Why wasnt the old magic working anymore?

title: U.N. Food Program Warns of Cuts to Its Relief Efforts
description: UNITED NATIONS  Just months after a United Nations Security Council resolution pressed Syria to open several of its border crossings to humanitarian aid convoys, money has dried up and allotments of grain and lentils are set to shrink significantly next month, the head of the World Food Program said Monday.

title: BlackRock Urges Overhaul of Corporate Bond Trading
description: The giant asset manager BlackRock is initiating an aggressive call for the overhaul of a bond market that sits at the center of the United States financial industry and many retirement portfolios.

title: Kissing Congressman Enlists Wife in Campaign Ad
description: The kissing congressman is hoping family forgiveness translates to forgiveness among the Louisiana electorate.

title: A New High Mark for Lion King
description: After nearly 17 years of performances in New York, The Lion King is still frequently the top-grossing show on Broadway each week, as it was last week. But now the musical holds the global box-office record as well.

title: The Top 10 Moments From Spring/Summer 2015 Milan Fashion Week
description: Ts senior market editor rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

title: Arab Bank Liable for Supporting Terrorist Efforts, Jury Finds
description: A federal jury on Monday found Arab Bank liable for knowingly supporting terrorism efforts connected to two dozen attacks in the Middle East, the first time a bank has ever been held liable in a civil suit under a broad antiterrorism statute.

title: Congress to Weigh In on White House Security
description: After the latest incursion at the White House, the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform has scheduled a hearing on Secret Service operations for next Tuesday.

title: How Will the U.N. Address Ocean Policy?
description: Q.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, China, Spain and Pakistan.

title: Disputing Report, Steve Bisciotti Says Ravens Didnt Seek Leniency for Ray Rice
description: The Baltimore Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti, responding to an investigative report released Friday, said his team did not lobby the league to be lenient in punishing running back Ray Rice after he was arrested and charged with assaulting his fiance in February.

title: Walkabout: Air France Strike Continues
description: Deadlock The strike by Air France pilots,already considered one of the most disruptive in the history of the company, will trigger the cancellation of at least 62 percent of the airlines flights worldwide on Monday.(Forbes)

title: High Above the Earth, Hoping for Turbulence
description: NORMALLY, pilots are happy to keep thunderstorms at a good distance, but that wasnt the case on board a twin-engine Convair 540 turboprop airplane that I took a demonstration flight in last month. Up in the cockpit, 21,000 feet above Texas, Markus Johnson and Joe Duval were actually looking for trouble in the form of bad weather.

title: During the Bustle of Travel, Moments of Kinship
description: I GREW up in California, and nearly every year I would fly across the county to visit my grandparents, who lived in Washington and Chicago.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: In Performance | Andrew Rannells
description: Andrew Rannells performs the song Midnight Radio from the musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch, with the shows composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar. Hedwig is on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.

title: How I Spent My Weekend: Booker the Biker
description: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

title: 3 Missing Afghan Soldiers Turn Up at Canadian Border
description: Three Afghan soldiers in the United States on a training exercise were located Monday at a Canadian border crossing near Niagara Falls, two days after disappearing from a Massachusetts shopping mall, officials said Monday.

title: A Watchdog for the Police Is Accepting Complaints
description: For months now, Mayor Bill de Blasio has peppered his remarks on improving relations between the police and the community with references to the new office of the inspector general for the New York Police Department. The office, the mayor has suggested, would be an early warning system for potential flare-ups of the sort that engulfed the department over its stop-and-frisk policies.

title: She Came to Do Good and Stayed to Do Well
description: Disney, never a stranger to princesses, crowns another as it ventures further into Bollywood with Shashanka Ghoshs romantic confection, Khoobsurat, a variation on Hrishikesh Mukherjees 1980 film, Khoobsoorat. And the studios specialty proves a pretty good fit.

title: MGM Buys Big Stake in Mark Burnetts Reality TV Production Company
description: LOS ANGELES  Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer became a reality TV giant on Monday.

title: A New Home Page Feature
description: Marcus Mabry is an editor at large at The Times.

title: Sale of a Landmark Skyscraper Puts Spain on the Map of Chinese Investors
