description: MADRID  In June, one of Chinas richest men, Wang Jianlin, bought a landmark office tower in Madrid that had stood empty for years. The Franco-era building, Spains tallest skyscraper when it opened in 1953, had become a symbol of the Spanish real estate markets collapse in 2008.

title: On the Cusp of Climate Change
description: Animal and plant species around the world may be threatened by warmer global temperatures.

title: On This Day: Lincoln Frees (Some of) the Slaves
description: PhotoCredit

title: Hotels Use Online Reviews as Blueprint for Renovations
description: When it was time for Omni Hotels and Resorts to start a new round of renovations, executives made a point of installing more electrical outlets and better bathrooms.

title: Deconstructing the Whole to Reveal the Sum of Its Parts
description: An orchestra is like an organism, people say when they want to illustrate the tightness and unity of a groups playing. But on Saturday evening at the Juilliard School, the New Juilliard Ensembles performance of Harrison Birtwistles Cantus Iambeus (2005) was a reminder that an organism is hardly a unified thing.

title: Composing Outside the Lines
description: Verboten often becomes the first word to impress itself on the mind of a visitor to Germany, so numerous  and explicit  are the rules. Its also a word that the South Korean composer Unsuk Chin encountered early on when she moved to Hamburg in 1985 to take up studies with Gyorgy Ligeti, the restlessly innovative Hungarian composer who was a dominating figure in 20th-century music.

title: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: Every year, Americans dispose of about 1,000 pounds of garbage apiece  the coffee grounds, takeout containers, candy wrappers, used Huggies, empty syringes and old sock monkey puppets we entrust to our local sanitation workers and never think about again.

title: A Marathon Mash-Up of Two Creative Worlds
description: Some of the most spellbinding dancing New York has seen all year occurred last week during Trajal Harrells seven-part series, Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church. The series also contained other performances that were extraordinary in nondance ways. Four dancers (Rob Fordeyn, Thibault Lac, Stephen Thompson, Ondrej Vidlar) were phenomenal, redefining grace before our eyes, and the drag artist Franois Chaignaud, though at his worst when dancing, compellingly and bewilderingly demonstrated multiple layers of identity.

title: Milan Fashion Week Social Media Roundup
description: Not 24 hours after London Fashion Week concluded, the fashion crowd had already migrated to Italy for Milan Fashion Week. As the world hurtled forward at a look-there-or-youll-miss-it pace driven by the Scottish referendum, the Alibaba I.P.O. and the release of the latest iPhone, Italian designers slowed down and plumbed the past for inspiration  out of nostalgia for the heyday of Italian fashion, perhaps? Not all were looking backward: Fendi existed distinctly in the moment, and a contemporary Barbie seemed to be Jeremy Scotts latest muse at Moschino. One change in attendance was notable and noticed: Though celebrity models like Naomi Campbell and Kendall Jenner stalked the catwalk, actual celebrities were mostly missing from the front row.

title: Obama Defends the Secret Service
description: After two incidents involving security breaches at the White House over the weekend, President Obama said he was grateful for the Secret Service and the protection it provides.

title: Opera Singers Try a More Intimate Genre
description: There are certain styles that are difficult to convey well: Most competent pianists, for example, can play Chopin decently, but it takes a more particular gift to win over an audience with Bach or Boulez. On the vocal front, the intimate, enigmatic French art song  a genre (like chamber music) that is often best suited to salon-style formats  can be challenging to render convincingly.

title: Serving Up Gumshoes and Gumbo
description: Eggs Creole sounds pretty good. Adding andouille sausage is probably a tad more than a healthy breakfast needs, but, whatever, this is New Orleans. Its the rmoulade sauce on the side that suggests that NCIS: New Orleans, a new entry in the hit CBS franchise that begins on Tuesday, is trying a little too hard to live up to a recipe.

title: S.E.C. Makes Largest Ever Whistle-Blower Award
description: The identity is a mystery, but someone who provided important information to regulators in a securities fraud enforcement action is suddenly $30 million richer thanks to a federal whistle-blower law.

title: Climate Change Underfoot
description: Some species being displaced by rising global temperatures are not easy to see, but scientists still worry that the impact on ecosystems could be significant.

title: Q. and A.: Jrg Wuttke on the Future of Chinas Economy
description: After decades of a golden age fueled by cheap manufacturing and exports, Chinas economy may have entered a more mature silver age, says Jrg Wuttke, president of the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China. Like any maturity, this phase, which President Xi Jinping has spoken of as the new normal, is marked by complex challenges.

title: Cyberheroes in Disguise, Toiling at Dull Day Jobs
description: Nothing says CBS like the ratings for Person of Interest. Last season, this surveillance-age thriller was the fourth-most-watched network drama in prime time, behind two NCIS shows and The Blacklist. But among younger viewers  the 18-to-49 demographic  it fell all the way to 16th, behind shows like Sleepy Hollow and Chicago Fire.

title: When Cooking, Invest Time. Or Work. Not Both.
description: We could talk about cooking as a function of chemistry and physics. Better to talk about elbow grease. Specifically, a physical theory of everyday cooking, The Time-Work Continuum.

title: Albums by Leonard Cohen, Otis Brown III and Lee Ann Womack
description: LEONARD COHEN

title: Seeding a Slogan? Clinton Talks Up Choice and Chance in Email Blast
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has said that shell likely announce a decision about running for president sometime next year. But from the sound of things, she might be trying out a campaign slogan already.

title: As Blondie Turns 40, a Look Back Through Chris Steins Lens
description: Since Blondie formed 40 years ago, one thing has remained constant: if the bands co-founder Chris Stein isnt onstage with a guitar slung around his neck, chances are hes off somewhere with a camera, taking pictures. Now, the results of his four-decade-long hobby have been compiled in a new book, Chris Stein/Negative: Me, Blondie, and the Advent of Punk (out tomorrow from Rizzoli), and will appear in an exhibition curated by Jeffrey Deitch at the Chelsea Hotels Storefront Gallery alongside band memorabilia and images by the likes of Annie Leibovitz and Robert Mapplethorpe. I was just in the middle of this milieu and I took pictures, Stein says matter-of-factly on the phone from Vienna, a recent stop on Blondies anniversary tour.

title: A Microscopic Issue of Unknown Consequences
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Even the microbes, it seems, may be on the move.

title: Bad Boy Theater, With Cocaine as Co-Star
description: AMITYVILLE, N.Y.  Im gonna pick one person, Stitches said. Out in the Sunday night crowd at the Amityville Music Hall here, several young men  and one or two young women  were thrusting their hands to the sky, clamoring for a shot at immortality. Or at least a chance at touching a modern starburst, which here meant having Stitches  the Miami rapper whose manic, pneumatic-intensity video for Brick in Yo Face has been one of this years most unlikely viral phenomena  throw a brick in their face, and have it explode in a puff of powder.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,333 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Defamation Law Reminds Critics of Indonesias Past
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  When an Indonesian law student posted an online rant saying the historic city of Yogyakarta in Central Java was poor, stupid and uncultured, she earned more than the ire of its residents. She ended up in a police detention cell, charged with cyberdefamation.

title: U.S. Acts to Curb Firms Moves Overseas to Avoid Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew announced rules on Monday that are aimed at making it more difficult for American companies to lower their tax bills by relocating overseas and that would wipe out the benefits for those that do. It is the administrations latest move to sidestep a paralyzed Congress and tackle a politically charged element of President Obamas agenda.

title: Kerry Participates in Unesco Event
description: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | Three years after the United States pulled its funding from Unesco over the admission of Palestinians as full members, Secretary of State John Kerry made an unusual appearance Monday evening alongside the agencys executive director, Irina Bokova, to draw attention to one of Unescos principal mandates: the need to protect antiquities.

title: Milan Fashion Week Street Style
description: Here are our highlights from show-goers style.

title: Deaths From Faulty Switch in G.M. Cars Edge Higher
description: The death toll from accidents involving General Motors cars with a defective ignition switch has edged up again. In a weekly update of claims filed to the victim compensation program run by the compensation expert Kenneth R. Feinberg, the program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than Mr. Feinberg found eligible a week ago and significantly more than the 13 deaths the company had estimated for months. G.M. has given Mr. Feinberg sole discretion to determine the number of eligible claims for deaths and injuries associated with the faulty switch, which can cause power to cut out in a moving car, disabling air bags, power steering and power brakes. G.M. recalled 2.6 million cars with the switch this year, more than a decade after engineers inside the company first spotted a problem. The latest numbers show a total of 16 eligible injury claims, including four in the most serious category of injury  those resulting in quadriplegia, paraplegia, double amputation, permanent brain damage or pervasive burns.

title: Jack Black, Diane Keaton, Marisa Tomei and a Host of Artists Turn Out in L.A. to Support Reproductive Rights
description: WhoA potpourri of artists, collectors, celebrities and executives of Planned Parenthood Los Angeles (PPLA), the beneficiary of live and silent auctions organized by the gallerists Davida Nemeroff and Mieke Marple of L.A.s critically beloved Night Gallery. Diane Keaton mingled with the artist Mary Weatherford and the curator Paul Schimmel, of Hauser, Wirth & Schimmel. Marisa Tomei posed for photographs while the gallerists David Kordansky and Sarah Gavlak mixed with noteworthy artists like Nicole Miller, Alexandra Grant, Sam Falls, Sayre Gomez, Lisa Anne Auerbach, Jonas Wood, Kaari Upson, Piero Golia, Kour Pour, Sam Durant, Rosson Crow, Casey Jane Ellison and Math Bass. The award-winning choreographer Ryan Heffington could be seen getting costumed dancers ready. Jack Black hosted.

title: Better-Than-Bush Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: False Report on Fukushima: The Company Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Botox Maker Allergan Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Salix
description: Allergan, the Botox maker fending off a hostile bid by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management, had had talks to acquire Salix Pharmaceuticals, another drug maker, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Scandal Isnt Just a Thrill Ride. Its an Education.
description: The characters on Shonda Rhimess Scandal have fixed presidential elections, murdered Supreme Court justices and had affairs in the White House. But the writers room, she said, is even wilder.

title: For Most Women in Film, Their Roles Are Silent
description: Women are more seen than heard in movies worldwide. A tiny fraction of them are cast as lawyers or doctors. Women and girls are twice as likely as men and boys to be shown on screen naked, partially clothed or in sexually revealing clothes.

title: Its Not Genghis Khans Mongolia
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia  For all of his victories and skills, Genghis Khan always insisted that the god Tengri  the Eternal Blue Sky  deserved the credit for his triumphant success in uniting the vast Mongol Empire in the early 13th century.

title: Shining Star Power on a Crucial Subject
description: Harrison Ford is struggling to keep from jumping out of his chair.

title: Forecasts: Hopes and Fears About Climate Change
description: Two dozen scientists, authors, and world and national figures answered two questions: What is your greatest worry about climate change? What gives you hope? Here are some of their answers, condensed for space.

title: Venezuela: Clorox Plans to Leave Over Price Controls
description: The Clorox Company said Monday that it was shutting down its business in Venezuela because government price controls on its products had led to millions of dollars in losses. The company said it was pulling out of the country entirely and would sell its assets. It has three factories, about 450 employees and annual sales of about $77 million in Venezuela. Clorox, which is based in California, said in a statement that for nearly three years it had to sell more than two-thirds of its products at prices fixed by the government, even as high inflation caused its costs to rise sharply. It said recent price increases were nowhere near sufficient. Clorox sells bleach and other household cleaning products in Venezuela. Venezuela suffers from inflation of more than 60 percent a year and shortages of many basic goods, a situation that could be exacerbated by Cloroxs exit. President Nicols Maduro, a socialist, says the economic woes are caused by capitalists and political opponents waging an economic war against the country.

title: Album Review: Bernard Sanderss We Shall Overcome
description: Theres nothing apolitical about We Shall Overcome, the album Bernard Sanders, the independent senator from Vermont, recorded in 1987 when he was the mayor of Burlington, Vt.

title: New Leader for Council in Charge of Public Service Ads
description: THE ADVERTISING COUNCIL, the organization that has worked with Madison Avenue since 1942 on public service campaigns for charities, nonprofits, social causes and the federal government, is naming a new leader who has experience in all three of its constituencies: agencies, marketers and the media.

title: Mets Said to Be Near a Contract Extension for Sandy Alderson
description: The Mets are working toward completing a three-year extension for General Manager Sandy Alderson, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Obama Judicial Choice Is Urged to Withdraw
description: WASHINGTON  In a setback for the White House, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, has determined that Michael P. Boggs, an embattled judicial nominee from Georgia, does not have the support to clear the committee, effectively killing his nomination.

title: Climate Solutions: From Marches to Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Times Cybersecurity Reporter Protects Her Data. And What You Can Do to Protect Yours.
description: Nicole Perlroth covers cybersecurity and privacy. Last week she wrote on Home Depots confirmation that hackers had broken into its in-store payments systems in what could be the largest-known breach of a retail companys computer network. She shares her thoughts on security and personal data with Times Insiders.

title: HealthCare.gov Is Given an Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is redesigning HealthCare.gov and says that 70 percent of consumers will be able to use a shorter, simpler online application form to buy health insurance when the second annual open enrollment period begins in mid-November.

title: Will Radcliff, 74, Creator of the Slush Puppie, Dies
description: Flavored ice drinks had been around since the Romans, and machines had been churning them out under various brand names for almost as long, it seems, when Will Radcliff, a peanut salesman, had the ice beverage inspiration that made him rich.

title: Black Bear Kills Rutgers Student During a Hike in New Jersey
description: A Rutgers University student was killed by a black bear over the weekend, the police said on Monday, the first such recorded death in New Jersey.

title: Obama Isnt Finished Yet
description: WASHINGTON  ON Sept. 18, 1986, more than two years before the end of Ronald Reagans presidency, the columnist George F. Will, one of Reagans earliest and strongest supporters, pronounced the Reagan administration dead. When an administration collapses, quickly and completely, Mr. Will wrote, a reasonable surmise is that the administration, like a balloon, had nothing in it but air.

title: Inside the Quartet
description: The Kronos Quartet explains the special mystery of how a quartet communicates.

title: Top Republicans Send Warning  and Appeal  to Donors
description: Nearly every election year, often about this time, top officials in one of the two political parties fret publicly about being at a financial disadvantage.

title: Monitors of Afghan Vote Are Said to Back Secrecy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The decision by Afghan election officials to announce a new president on Sunday without releasing the final vote count came as a result of pressure from senior Western officials, including the head of the United Nations mission that sponsored a total audit of the vote, according to three Western diplomats and three senior election officials.

title: Yoshiko Yamaguchi, 94, Actress in Propaganda Films, Dies
description: Yoshiko Yamaguchi, a singer and actress who starred in Japanese propaganda films during Japans brutal military occupation of China in the 1930s and 40s and who, after narrowly escaping execution by the Chinese after the war, helped normalize relations between the nations, died on Sept. 7 in Tokyo. She was 94.

title: The Price of Abandoning Yemen
description: DOHA, Qatar  IN 2011, Yemenis rejoiced at the toppling of their dictatorial president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who had ruled for 33 years. It was the third successful revolution of the Arab Spring, following the overthrow of dictators in Tunisia and Egypt. But, as elsewhere, reconciliation did not follow revolution.

title: What to Expect From Narendra Modi at the United Nations
description: What should we expect from Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New York?

title: Ukraines Neglected and Battered Army Inspires Citizens to Pitch In
description: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  Well-wishers mill around the entrances of the two main hospitals in this city in east-central Ukraine  men who greet friends with hugs and backslaps or share a cigarette, women who arrive to visit the wounded, sorting food parcels and pouring cups of sweet tea.

title: Fraternities at Wesleyan Are Ordered to Become Coed
description: After a series of high-profile episodes and calls from its student government for change, Wesleyan University has announced that its residential fraternities must all admit women as members and residents.

title: Giants Ground Game Sharpens Eli Mannings Aim
description: The Giants new quarterback coach, Danny Langsdorf, said during training camp that the team wanted Eli Manning to complete 70 percent of his passes in the regular season. It is an understatement to say that Langsdorfs comment produced something of an uproar. Nationwide, the remark elicited mostly guffaws. Manning had completed only 57.5 percent of his passes the previous season. His career completion percentage was 58.5, and his career high in any season was 62.9 percent in 2010.

title: Months After Buying Beats, Apples Plans for Its Music Service Remain Unclear
description: When Apple agreed in May to pay $3 billion for Beats, it acquired not only a successful headphone line but also a fledgling online music service, a move that many analysts interpreted as a move into the fast-growing world of streaming music.

title: Group Backing Islamic State Vows to Kill French Citizen
description: A jihadist group in North Africa aligned with the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of a Frenchman in a mountainous region of Algeria, hours after the Islamic State called for attacks on Westerners. In the video released Monday, the little-known group Jund al-Khilafah said France had 24 hours to halt attacks on the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, or see its citizen executed.

title: Plaintiffs Claim Bias During Closing Argument Against Texas Voter ID Law
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex.  A law requiring Texas voters to show government-issued identification before casting a ballot is the latest example of the states long history of discrimination against minorities and puts unjustified burdens on the right to vote for more than half a million Texans, lawyers challenging the law told a federal judge here on Monday.

title: Aging Tech Giants Like EMC Look to Deals to Help Bolster Revenue
description: Investors expected a noisy fight over breaking up the EMC computer storage company when the hedge fund Elliott Management surfaced in July as the companys big new shareholder.

title: Gotham Recap:  Batman Before Batman
description: Season 1, Episode 1

title: Climate Protesters Clash With Police
description: Demonstrators protesting the financial industrys role in climate change rushed barricades the police had set up near Wall Street.

title: Fresh Graves Point to Undercount of Ebola Toll
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  The gravedigger hacked at the cemeterys dense undergrowth, clearing space for the days Ebola victims. A burial team, in protective suits torn with gaping holes, arrived with fresh bodies.

title: A Tailor-Made Publisher Taking Over Jeff Bezos Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON  Frederick J. Ryan Jr. juggles black-tie invitations, while Jeff Bezos shuns the social limelight for reading about space travel.

title: Before Yankees Take Field, Crack of Derek Jeters Bat Earns Cheers
description: Nick Galasso did not have many luxuries growing up, but few things made him happier as a child than coming to Yankee Stadium to watch Mickey Mantle take batting practice.

title: High Hopes for Russia Are Fading on Wall St.
description: Goldman Sachs has an office in Moscow. So do Citigroup and Morgan Stanley. JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America Merrill Lynch, too.

title: In East River, Bangladeshi Women Find Their Catch of the Day
description: It may seem like an unusual spot to catch dinner, across the East River from Manhattans imposing skyline. And the tiny fish that a group of fisherwomen trap in these waters may not seem like dinner at all.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 22, 2014
Behind the Chevron Case
description: I am the target of what is probably the most well-funded corporate retaliation campaign in U.S. history, Steven Donziger emailed me early Monday afternoon.

title: Snap Out of It
description: Ive been living in and visiting New York for almost a half-century now. One thought occurs as I walk around these days: The city has never been better.

title: Backsliding on Nuclear Promises
description: For much of the past six years, President Obama has talked about working toward a world without nuclear weapons. Yet his administration is now investing tens of billions of dollars in modernizing and rebuilding Americas nuclear arsenal and facilities, as The Times reported in detail on Monday. And after good progress in making nuclear bomb material more secure around the world, Mr. Obama has reduced his budget requests for that priority. This is a shortsighted and disappointing turn.

title: Airstrikes by U.S. and Allies Hit ISIS Targets in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and allies launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in Syria early Tuesday, unleashing a torrent of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs from the air and sea on the militants de facto capital of Raqqa and along the porous Iraq border.

title: Finding Risks, Not Answers, in Gene Tests
description: Jennifer was 39 and perfectly healthy, but her grandmother had died young from breast cancer, so she decided to be tested for mutations in two genes known to increase risk for the disease.

title: Oleg Ivanovsky, Soviets Space-Age Designer, Dies at 92
description: Oleg Ivanovsky, a Russian engineer in the early years of the space race who helped design Sputnik, the first satellite to orbit Earth, and Vostok 1, the craft that carried the astronaut Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, died on Thursday. He was 92.

title: John Lewis: Comic Book Hero
description: Representative John Lewis spoke at the 1963 March on Washington, worked alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and serves as senior chief deputy whip in Congress. On Thursday, he got on Facebook to talk about a new passion: comic books.

title: Turkish President Hints That Prisoner Exchange Won Release of Hostages Held by ISIS
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said Monday that Turkish and American officials were in discussions about how to battle the Islamic State militant organization, now that his government had secured the freedom of 49 Turkish citizens held hostage by that group in Iraq for more than three months.

title: Another Explanation for Ineptitude? Save It
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Heres a message to every N.F.L. and team official who has been involved, even tangentially, in the Ray Rice scandal: Please stop talking.

title: U.S. Asks U.N. to Add Names to Sanctions List
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States and France are asking the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions on as many as 15 suspected terrorist fighters, recruiters and fund-raisers, including some connected to the Islamic State, American officials said on Monday.

title: A Marriage in Trouble, in Triplicate
description: This is the way we were, and the way we are, and the way we will be. And we are fools if we think we can separate any of these versions from the others.

title: Valuable Finds
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Sometimes you have to mine deeply to find the GOLD NUGGETs in the lode. We have six of them in todays puzzle, if you dont count the central revealer at 38 Across.

title: Sleepy Hollow Recap: Horseman With No Head; Ben Franklin With No Breeches
description: Season 2, Episode 1, This Is War

title: Submit Your Questions on the United Nations Meetings
description: With the opening of the United Nations climate summit and the start of the 69th session of the General Assembly, the international community prepares to address an agenda that includes a daunting set of issues: Global warming, combating the march of the militant group the Islamic State and the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa dominate the agenda. We invite you to submit questions for New York Times reporters on these and other issues throughout the week of United Nations meetings when we provide live coverage.

title: For Many, a Nation That Seems Less Free From Moscows Dominance Than Ever
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukrainians have been promised sweeping change in the seven months since their collective anger chased the last president out of his mansion.

title: Ravens Owner Says He Learned Lesson
description: Steve Bisciotti, the Baltimore Ravens owner, said that if cases similar to Ray Rices arose in the future, his team would not make the same mistakes.

title: Mayor de Blasio Takes On Climate Change
description: Mayor de Blasio Commits to 80 Percent Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions by 2050, said the Sunday news release, outlining what would be a truly impressive feat if he actually were able to make good on that promise. But there is not going to be any 89-year-old, 10-term mayor named de Blasio declaring a local victory in the battle to save the planet. This is a long march to a distant goal. The commitment Mr. de Blasio made over the weekend  an excellent and necessary one  was to do his part now to keep the city moving in the right direction: Promised Land, that way.

title: Hiring a Woman for Her Womb
New York and New Jersey Getting U.S. Aid to Protect Transit Networks Against Storms
description: With the two-year anniversary of Hurricane Sandy approaching, federal officials announced on Monday that New York and New Jersey will receive about $3.3 billion to prepare their transportation networks against future storms.

title: Record of Abuse Accusations Preceded Florida Killings
description: MIAMI  The Florida man who killed his daughter, her six children and himself on Thursday was accused of hitting one of the children with a belt last year, according a report by the state child welfare agency, which said there was an open investigation into the family at the time of the killings.

title: U.S. Strikes Follow Plea by Syrian Opposition Leader on Behalf of Kurds
description: The leader of the moderate Syrian opposition appealed Monday for American airstrikes to halt the fierce attacks by militants from the Islamic State against Kurdish communities in northern Syria, just hours before the United States and allies began a campaign against the terrorist group.

title: A Mentor Whose Experience Goes Far Beyond Pitching
description: The oldest pitching coach in the major leagues might also be the most grateful. Dave Wallace, who turned 67 this month, will be coaching in the playoffs next week.

title: The New York Jail Scandal Continues
description: A Justice Department investigation that last month uncovered a chamber of horrors at the Rikers Island jail in New York City was bad enough in its depiction of corruption and brutality in the city jail system. Now comes the news that the Department of Correction had sanitized a 2012 report that it later turned over to federal investigators, eliminating passages recommending demotion for two officials who were derelict in their jobs and failed to supervise the jail they oversaw.

title: Health Agencys New Assessment of Epidemic Is More Dire Still
description: New figures published Monday by the World Health Organization reveal a far worse outlook than it had previously anticipated for the Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

title: With Brodeur Gone, Elias Is Steadying Influence on Devils Roster
description: NEWARK  Devils forward Patrik Elias is used to watching teammates come and go.

title: As U.S. Bombs Fall, British Hostage of ISIS Warns of Another Vietnam
description: As American airstrikes began raining down on the de facto capital of the Islamic State in Syria on Monday night, the militant group issued a new installment in its lecture series delivered by a British hostage, John Cantlie.

title: Derek Jeter Shares Spotlight in Yankees Victory
description: Jose Pirela made his major league debut for the Yankees on Monday and became the 57th person to play for the team this season, setting a club record. Now, 56 people can say they played with Derek Jeter in his final season.

title: Program to Give Legal Help to Young Migrants
description: The New York City Council and two philanthropic foundations are combining forces to provide legal representation and other services to some 1,000 unaccompanied immigrant children facing possible deportation under a new accelerated court process.

title: Royals 11-Minute Loss Precedes a Win Against the Indians
description: CLEVELAND  Once the Kansas City Royals-Cleveland Indians game ended Monday evening, fireworks went off; Indians employees ran on top of the dugouts waving flags; and Scott Atchison, the pitcher who got the save, was interviewed on the field.

title: Warming Temperatures Threaten Fragile Balance in Canadian Arctic
description: Ellesmere Island, Nunavut  Its August, and theres snow on the ground. The six-week summer has already passed; our 24-hour daylight will drop to 16 in just a months time. Small, brittle leaves crunch underfoot as I walk across tundra thats already beginning to freeze for the long winter ahead.

title: In the Navy
description: Open up to the elegant subtlety of a watch with a dark blue face and band.

title: Word of the Day | protuberance
description: protuberance \pro-t-b(-)rn(t)s, -ty-\ noun

title: With Talko App, Ray Ozzie Creates a Permanent Voice
description: If you want to really change the world, Ray Ozzie has concluded, change the conversation. In this case, change it into a medium in which wireless speech becomes a durable, searchable part of the computer world.

title: Modicum of Suspense as Mets Year Winds Down
description: We interrupt Derek Jeter Week with an unexpected announcement: The Mets  yes, the Mets  have suddenly put some suspense into the final week of their season.

title: Health Researchers Will Get $10.1 Million to Counter Gender Bias in Studies
description: In an effort to begin addressing persistent gender bias in laboratory research, the National Institutes of Health announced Tuesday that it will distribute $10.1 million in grants to more than 80 scientists studying a diverse array of subjects, including drug addiction, fetal development, migraines and stroke.

title: Hapless in Big Moments, Jets Fall to the Chicago Bears
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rex Ryan windmilled his arm and stamped his foot and flung his hat to the turf, and at that moment it required a supreme amount of willpower for him not to run on the field, gather the Jets and give them an impromptu lesson in fundamentals.

title: Why Senate Control Matters
description: The Democrats need to find a way to succeed in two red states this year. If they can do that  preventing Republican victories in some combination of Alaska, Arkansas, Kansas, Louisiana or North Carolina  Democrats can pull off a modest upset and keep control of the Senate this year. Otherwise, Mitch McConnell will probably achieve his dream of becoming Senate majority leader.

title: TV Ratings Soar Amid N.F.L.s Woes
description: The N.F.L generates the highest ratings in sports, and even the leagues mishandling of its domestic violence crisis seems to have done little to change that.

title: North Carolina, in Political Flux, Battles for Its Identity
description: SILER CITY, N.C.  In Raleigh, conservative Republicans may be running North Carolina like they own it, but go almost anyplace in the state, even to this former textile town that looks like a movie-set re-creation of an older, more traditional South, and the political picture quickly blurs.

title: Where Sex Is Just Part of the Act
description: Jokes about the stupidity of particular groups of people are generally a no-go in these days of political correctness. But it is still open season on one unfortunate subset of humanity.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICAN MASTERS: THE BOOMER LIST Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, above with Amy Tan, traverses the baby boomer generation with the help of 19 celebrities  one born each year, from 1946 to 1964  as the last members turn 50. Subjects including Samuel L. Jackson (born in 1948), Billy Joel (1949), Ms. Tan (1952), Eve Ensler (1953), Kim Cattrall (1956), Rosie ODonnell (1962) and John Leguizamo (1964) discuss their achievements, struggles and identities, as well as the movements that have shaped their lives in the environment, civil rights, politics, technology and the arts. In Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work (2010), at 10:30 on Channel 13, Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg tagged along with their subject, racking up miles and yowzah moments in her relentless pursuit of fame, money, attention, love, kicks, masochistic thrills or whatever it is that makes Ms. Rivers, ne Joan Alexandra Molinsky, run, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Following Ms. Rivers the year she turned 75 (she died on Sept. 4 at 81), they begin by moving in close to her cosmetically altered face  without makeup. To their credit, Ms. Dargis said, the filmmakers dont try to make her look good, and while they omit some of her uglier routines, they dont (perhaps cant) ask you to love her.

title: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
description: Finally, at long last, theyve arrived  or have they?

title: Hong Kong Protesters Take Inspiration from Paris to Taipei
description: Angus Li, a 19-year-old sociology major at Hong Kong Baptist University, does more than take part in student demonstrations: He accessorizes for them.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 23, 2014
description: We will need much more space.

title: Corrections: September 23, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jets Replay: Week 3
description: The error-prone Jets quickly fell behind against the Bears, and their attempt at a rally fell short in a loss at MetLife Stadium.

title: China Sentences Uighur Scholar to Life
description: ALTAY, China  A university professor who has become the most visible symbol of peaceful resistance by ethnic Uighurs to Chinese policies was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday after being found guilty of separatism by court officials in the western region of Xinjiang, which Uighurs consider their homeland.

title: Omar J. Gonzalez, Accused of White House Intrusion, Is Recalled as Good but Troubled Neighbor
description: COPPERAS COVE, Tex.  To his neighbors in this military town at the edge of Fort Hood, Omar J. Gonzalez was friendly and big-hearted, an Iraq war veteran who read stories to the neighborhood children and was quick to respond whenever someone needed help carrying groceries or a jump-start for a troublesome car.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 2 Palestinian Suspects in Murders of Jewish Teenagers
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli troops closed a significant chapter in the summers bloody escalation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on Tuesday by cornering and killing the two men they suspected of kidnapping and murdering three Israeli teenagers in June.

title: Jimmy Choo, Luxury Shoe Brand, to List Shares in London
description: Updated, 8:09 p.m. | LONDON  The luxury shoe company Jimmy Choo, which shot to fame on the feet of the stars of Sex and the City, said on Tuesday that it planned to pursue an initial public offering later this year in London.

title: Philippines Pulls Troops From Zone Near Syria
description: The four-decade-old United Nations peacekeeping operation in the Golan Heights region between Israel and Syria, largely curtailedlast week because of Syrias civil war, was further undermined on Tuesday with confirmation thatthePhilippines contingent was going home.

title: As Chinas Antigraft Efforts Increase, a Call for Padded Interrogation Rooms
description: The rooms are padded, but not for anyones comfort. The announcement from the anticorruption authorities in Beijing that all of the capitals districts and counties must install at least three discussion rooms was instead meant to drive home the governments unrelenting resolve in prosecuting corrupt officials.

title: Test Yourself | Pool Parties and River Rides on Campus
description: Below are the first seven paragraphs of a Sept. 19 article, Making a Splash on Campus.

title: The Jimmy Choo I.P.O. and the Era of the It Shoe
description: The news that Jimmy Choo would become the first stand-alone luxury footwear brand to list on the London Stock Exchange (or any stock exchange for that matter) is sure to send reverberations through the fashion world  and not just the accessories part of the fashion world.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Art Man of Alcatraz
description: In the article Art Man of Alcatraz, Jori Finkel writes about a new exhibit at Alcatraz by the Chinese activist Ai Weiwei.

title: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Militant Cell Said to Plot an Attack Against the West
description: WASHINGTON  American forces took advantage of the airstrikes against the Islamic State extremist group in Syria to try to simultaneously wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell of veterans of Al Qaeda that the White House said Tuesday was plotting an imminent attack against the United States or Europe.

title: How a Lopsided Recovery Fueled the Dollar-Store Wars
description: Matthew Guzman has been shopping at the FamilyDollar store in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, since he was a kid, but lately something feels different. The service has gotten worse, the lines have grown longer and shoppers have responded accordingly. It used to be packed here, Guzman told me on a recent Saturday. But it died out. Guzman, who finished high school this year and makes $9.50 an hour as an assistant manager at an outsourcing company, ought to be right in Family Dollars core customer group. But that day, he opted out. Cringing at the $4.25 price tag on a broom, he walked across the street to a local 99-cent store instead.

title: Are You a Nerd or a Geek?
description: Gadget wristwatches are all the rage. The Big Bang Theory often tops TV ratings. Gaming is definitely mainstream. Has society embraced geek culture?

title: 1939: Sigmund Freud, Psychoanalyst, Dies Refugee in England at 83
description: Sigmund Freud, originator of psychoanalysis and considered by many as the greatest single influence on the thought of the twentieth century, died at his home in Hampstead, England, early yesterday morning at the age of eighty-three. He had been in poor health since leaving Vienna, after the 1938 Anschluss, and taking up his residence in England. In September last year, he had undergone a serious operation.

title: Outgrowing Childhood Horrors in Beslan
description: Every year, as the anniversary of the 2004 terrorist attack on a Russian school in Beslan nears, photographers descend on the small town to document the lingering effects of the hostage crisis in which 331 people  186 of them students  were killed. The surviving children, many of whom were injured, are usually photographed looking somber, often inside the schools ruins.

title: Philips to Split Into Two Companies as Part of Overhaul
description: LONDON  Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Tuesday that it planned to split itself into two companies: one focused on health care and technology, and the other on lighting.

title: Eurozone Growth Is Slowing, Survey of Purchasing Managers Suggests
description: PARIS  The eurozones economic expansion continued to lose traction in September, a private-sector report said on Tuesday, the latest indication that the stagnation of the second quarter might be taking hold.

title: Season Opens, and the Intrigue Is at Last Onstage
description: That the Metropolitan Opera opened its season as scheduled on Monday night with a new production of Mozarts Le Nozze di Figaro was good news, no matter what your take on the show. This summer, as acrimonious contract negotiations between the administration and the unionized workers reached a bitter impasse, the possibility of a lockout that could threaten the season was all too real.

title: Fertilizer Makers Yara and CF Industries Discussing Merger of Equals
description: Updated, 9:56 a.m. |

title: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: President Obama to Address U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday
description: President Obama will address the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday a day after the U.S. and allies launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in Syria. He is also scheduled to preside over a special meeting of the Security Council.

title: New York Today: The Women Who Built the City
description: Good chilly Tuesday morning. Welcome to fall.

title: Does Online Education Widen Offline Gaps?
description: The value of online education at the college level has been a subject of much dispute. But at The Daily Dot, Cabell Gathman considers the role of the Internet in teaching high school kids  and raises larger questions about how online resources might amplify some inequities even as they lessen others.

title: Four Reasons the G.O.P.s National Edge Isnt Translating to Senate Races
description: Republicans have taken a clear lead over the last month on the question of whether likely voters favor a Republican-controlled Congress or one dominated by Democrats. Some polls using this generic question show the Republicans ahead by as many as 7 points among likely voters, a tally rivaling the polls immediately before the Republican landslide in 2010.

title: Daily Report: Future of Beats Music Service Remains Unclear Under Apple
description: When Apple agreed in May to pay $3 billion for Beats, it acquired not only a successful headphone line but also a fledgling online music service, a move that many analysts interpreted as a move into the fast-growing world of streaming music, Ben Sisario and Brian X. Chen report.

title: British Regulators Fine Barclays $61.6 Million Over Account Issues
description: Updated, 12:50 p.m. |

title: On the U.N. Climate Change Summit
description: Not everyone has the same perspective.

title: Democrats See Early Edge in Iowa Senate Race
description: Early voting doesnt begin in Iowa until Thursday, but Democrats say they already have an advantage in a crucial Senate race.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 16-22, 2014
description: Have you followed the news in the past week?

title: Movies for Entrepreneurs: We Are the Dreamers of Dreams
description: Last week I shared my admiration for all things Rocky. This week, I thought I would finish the job by noting seven other movies that offer insights or inspirations that I have found applicable to business.

title: Rights Groups Say China Exports Tools of Torture
description: BEIJING  Chinese companies, some of them state-owned, are profiting from the production and export of law enforcement equipment that can be used for torture, fueling human rights abuses in Africa and Asia, two international human rights organizations said in a report released on Tuesday.

title: 1889: Pining for Italian Annexation
description: SUAKIN  Owing to the unjust policy alleged to be pursued by the Egyptian officers, the inhabitants of Agig have petitioned the Italian authorities in East Africa to annex that place. If the Italians should take Agig, there is no doubt that English commercial prospects in that quarter will be adversely affected. Some dervishes made a raid yesterday upon cattle near Suakin, but a body of native cavalry recovered possession of the animals. A sure sign of the peaceful intentions of most of the natives of the Eastern Soudan is furnished by the fact that the inhabitants of Tokar, Khor, Arbat and Odrus intend to grow cotton this season.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 24, 1889

title: Obama Faces the World After Bombs Fall in Syria
description: PhotoFighters from the Nusra Front among destroyed buildings south of Damascus, Syria, on Monday. Airstrikes were focused on fighters from the Nusra Front in northern Idlib Province. Credit Rami Al-Sayed/Agence France-Presse  Getty Images

title: New CO2 Emissions Report Shows Chinas Central Role in Shaping Worlds Climate Path
description: While President Obama and more than 100 other heads of state are expected to participate in the United Nations Climate Summit today, President Xi Jinping of China, the country making by far the biggest contribution to the atmospheric buildup of greenhouse gases, will not appear.

title: Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Inversions
description: U.S. CRACKS DOWN ON INVERSIONS | Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew announced rules on Monday that are intended to deter United States companies from relocating overseas through mergers to lower their tax bills in a maneuver known as an inversion, Julie Hirschfeld Davis reports in The New York Times. The rules are intended to make inversions more difficult and less profitable.

title: First Draft Focus: Biden Meets a Cabinet Secretarys Daughter
Flipping Scanned Images
description: Flipping Images

title: Larry Ellison Bought an Island in Hawaii. Now What?
description: Henry Jolicoeur is a retired French Canadian hypnotherapist and a glass-products importer who enjoys making very low-budget documentary films. In the summer of 2012, Jolicoeur read that Larry Ellison, a founder of the Silicon Valley giant Oracle and the fifth-richest man in the world, had bought 97 percent of the Hawaiian island of Lanai  not a 97 percent stake in some kind of company, but 97 percent of the physical place. Jolicoeur was curious, so he booked a flight and packed his camera.

title: In Performance: Andrew Rannells and Stephen Trask of Hedwig and the Angry Inch
description: This weeks video features the number Midnight Radio from the Broadway musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch, performed by the actor Andrew Rannells with the shows composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar. Mr. Rannells, who replaced Neil Patrick Harris in the title role, is scheduled to star through Oct. 12, after which he will be replaced by Michael C. Hall. The show is at the Belasco Theater.

title: Do the Math
description: Like names and dates, numbers are among the most basic facts The Times reports  and getting those facts right is the foundation of our journalism. Many errors, and many blows to The Timess credibility, could be avoided if writers and editors took more care to make sure the numbers are right.

title: Federal Prison Population Drops for First Time in 34 Years
description: The federal government will end its fiscal year next week with 4,800 fewer prisoners, the first time since 1980 that the inmate population has declined from year to year. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will trumpet the decline Tuesday and release Justice Department figures projecting a continued decline of 2,000 prisoners next year and 10,000 the following year.

title: U.S. Will Do What Is Necessary to Fight ISIS, Obama Says
description: Updated, 10:32 a.m. | President Obama on Tuesday hailed the American-led coalition that conducted airstrikes in Syria against the Islamic State on Monday night, declaring that were going to do what is necessary to take the fight to this terrorist group.

title: Coming: The Boom in Third-Party Speculation
description: Remember Unity 08, Draft Bloomberg or Americans Elect? Most Americans dont either. The hype built up around these efforts to launch centrist third-party presidential campaigns came to naught.

title: Ackman Threatens to Sue if Allergan Proceeds With Salix Deal
description: Updated, 10:19 a.m. |

title: Benchmarks: Obama vs. Bush vs. Clinton
description: For all of President Obamas recent success in placing federal judges on the bench, he could still end up leaving a smaller imprint on the judiciary than either President Bill Clinton or President George W. Bush.

title: Where Sex Is Just Part of the Act
description: Jokes about the stupidity of particular groups of people are generally a no-go in these days of political correctness. But it is still open season on one unfortunate subset of humanity.

title: Footage of U.S. Missiles Aimed at ISIS
description: Video released from the United States Navy shows missiles being launched off a Navy ship, bound for Islamic State targets in Syria.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: At U.N., de Blasio Warns of Existential Threat From Climate Change
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York warned a United Nations summit meeting on climate change on Tuesday about the reckless way in which we live, and of the dangers of humanitys dependence on fossil fuel consumption and other environmentally damaging habits.

title: A California Query
description: Dear Diary:

title: Marella & Me
description: A writer celebrates her aunt, a famous Italian socialite of great privilege, exquisite taste  and surprising good sense.

title: Netanyahu Discusses Downed Syrian Plane
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel confirmed on Tuesday that his military had shot down a Syrian aircraft over the Golan Heights.

title: Reminiscences of a Cold War Breakthrough
description: Ken Adelman yearns for the days when politics was more of a bare-knuckled affair that allowed for officials to stray from their talking points and make unexpected moves.

title: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar, on Life Under Scrutiny in China
description: In recent years, as China has been buffeted by surging violence in the far western region of Xinjiang, foreign journalists seeking analysis from local scholars relied on one man to make sense of news events: Ilham Tohti, the Uighur economics professor who could always be counted on to give an insightful and spirited assessment of the central governments latest development initiative in Xinjiang  or the most recent strike hard security clampdown. The reliance on one person was not ideal, but pervasive fear long ago persuaded other Uighur academics to keep their mouths shut.

title: Terrorists Threaten Collapse of U.S., Scott Brown Ad Says
description: After Congress voted last week to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels in the fight against the Islamic State, political operatives prepared for more ads featuring the militant group. After all, nothing lends itself to an attack spot more than an incumbent candidate with a voting record on a tough issue.

title: Amateur Video of Airstrikes in Syria
description: Several videos posted online purported to show the aftermath of United States missile strikes against targets in the Syrian border province of Idlib.

title: German Prosecutors Charge Deutsche Bank Executives
description: FRANKFURT  German prosecutors filed criminal charges on Tuesday against the co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Jrgen Fitschen, and several former bank leaders, accusing them of colluding to give false testimony in a long-running lawsuit over the collapse of a bank clients media empire.

title: Should Writers Avoid Sentimentality?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Roland Barthes said, It is no longer the sexual which is indecent, it is the sentimental. This week, Zo Heller and Leslie Jamison debate whether sentimentailty is a cardinal sin for writers.

title: Ebola Cases Could Reach 1.4 Million Within Four Months, C.D.C. Estimates
description: Yet another set of ominous projections about the Ebola epidemic in West Africa was released Tuesday, in a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that gave worst- and best-case estimates for Liberia and Sierra Leone based on computer modeling.

title: 1914: Prussian Women in Resistance
description: PETROGRAD  The Army Gazette has information that the Austro-German General Staff is now engaged in the formation of purely German and Hungarian regiments from the Landwehr and Landsturm, in order to counteract and outnumber the Slav regiments. A correspondent of the Retch declares that there are many women among the prisoners from the East Prussian frontier, captured for taking part in fighting.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 24, 1914

title: Ukraines Best Pitch Might Come From the Sidelines
description: Ukraine plans to haunt this years gathering of world leaders at the United Nations like the ghost of the organizations charter. Article 2 of the charter states that all member states will refrain from the use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state.

title: Brain Trauma Extends Reach Into Soccer
description: Bellini, a Brazilian soccer star who led the team that won the 1958 World Cup and was honored with a statue outside the Estdio do Maracan in Rio de Janeiro, had a degenerative brain disease linked to dozens of boxers and American football players when he died in March at age 83.

title: Abu Ghaith, a Bin Laden Adviser, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: A Kuwaiti-born cleric who sat with Osama bin Laden in an Afghan cave hours after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and later became a fiery spokesman for the Qaeda leader, was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

title: Startling Sight Where Blasts Are the Norm
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  When the predawn blasts rattled their windows and jolted them from sleep, residents of Raqqa, the Syrian city that is the de facto capital of the Islamic State, thought they were in for a new round of airstrikes from the Syrian government.

title: FIFA Set to Approve Stoppages for Head Injuries
description: Faced with increasing criticism regarding its handling of head injuries, FIFA, world soccers governing body, is expected to confirm a new policy this week that will allow referees to stop games for up to three minutes so that an injured player can be examined by a team doctor.

title: A Twitter Oops From Gingrich
Ordering Abortion Drugs for Her Daughter Earns a Mother Jail Time
description: On Sept. 12th, Jennifer Whalen, a 39-year-old mother of three, went to jail to begin serving a 9-to-18-month sentence. Whalens crime was, in effect, ordering pills online that her older daughter took in the first several weeks of an unplanned pregnancy, when she was 16, to induce a miscarriage. The drugs have been available from a doctor with a prescription in the United States since 2000 and are used around the world to induce miscarriage. Read more.

title: Tool Called Dataminr Hunts for News in the Din of Twitter
description: Earlier this year, several producers at CNN received an alert from a new digital news-gathering tool that they were testing: A teenager in Los Angeles had posted a tweet saying that the pop music heartthrob Justin Bieber had been arrested.

title: In Farewell Speech, Karzai Calls American Mission in Afghanistan a Betrayal
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In his nearly 13 years as the leader of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzais most memorable public stances always seemed driven by some deep emotion, and an almost compulsive need to express it. There was heartbreak for families killed by errant airstrikes, outrage at the scheming of hostile neighbors, palpable longing to preside over a peaceful end to the Taliban insurgency.

title: Obama Comments on Strikes Against ISIS

This was in an era when Facebook groups existed mainly as quirky avatars of real-life groups of friends, not as message boards for organizations or marketing for companies. It was a large group comprising people who didnt necessarily know one another.

But this time he carries a lofty title: Madrids first honorary ambassador of tourism.

title: Bargains From MossPOP, Garnet Hill and Others.

title: Ebola: A Grave Site Report
description: Adam Nossiter, The Timess West and Central Africa bureau chief,  reported on Tuesday from Freetown, Sierra Leone. He spoke with gravediggers there. Mr. Nossiters conversations with the burial teams point to a severe undercount in the Ebola death toll. The reporter provides a sense of his experience at the Freetown burial site.

title: Make Dinner: A Home Cooking Manifesto
description: Just cook. That is the message of the moment, the act to embrace. Just cook dinner. It is a habit as easy to form as a bad one, and more beneficial by far.

title: A Debut Video From Laetitia Sadier of Stereolab
description: The French chanteuse and multi-instrumentalist Laetita Sadier is perhaps best known as the front woman of the sprawling avant-pop outfit Stereolab, whose dozens of EPs and albums through the 1990s and 2000s set her multi-lingual, explicitly politicized vocals to a backdrop blending Krautrock, minimalist composition, bossa nova and northern soul, among other genres. When the band went on hiatus in 2009, Sadier began releasing records under her own name. Her newest effort, Something Shines, is out on Drag City today. Sadier describes its sound as a 70s-style production that is rich, luxuriant, powerful and free.

description: Updated, 3:15 p.m. | The New York Timess Coral M. Davenport is at the United Nations Climate Summit, where the secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, and other world leaders are addressing issues of global warming. Ms. Davenport and Mark Lander report that President Obama, emboldened by the use of his executive powers to fight climate change at home, sought to marshal world leaders on Tuesday behind a vast international effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions and curb global warming. Read more.

description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat and favorite of progressives, says she thinks the deck is stacked against ordinary Americans in the way Washington does business.

title: Tanya Tagaq Wins Canadas Polaris Prize
description: If you are among the many music fans who complain that music award shows are too predictable, you might consider keeping tabs on the Polaris Music Prize from now on. The prize is for the best recording of the year made by a Canadian musician or group, and there were some big names on this years short list  Drake and Arcade Fire, most notably. But the winning work, selected by an 11-member jury of Canadian critics and announced at a gala concert in Toronto on Monday evening, was Animism, by Tanya Tagaq, an Inuit throat singer. The prize is 30,000 Canadian dollars (about $27,000). The four-hour concert can be seen on YouTube.

title: Soda Makers Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Dr Pepper Join in Effort to Cut Americans Drink Calories
description: The three largest soda companies  Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and the Dr Pepper Snapple Group  have pledged to cut the number of sugary drink calories that Americans consume by one-fifth in about a decade, through a combination of marketing, distribution and packaging.

title: Into Syria
description: There isnt that much to say, now that bombing has officially begun, that I didnt say in my skeptical blog post following the presidents initial announcement of a wider war, and my skeptical Sunday column on the same subject. You can read Dan Drezner and Jeffrey Goldberg for cautiously pessimistic and cautiously optimistic takes, respectively; my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Omar Al-Jawoshy have a not-entirely encouraging take on the tactical state of play in Iraq;Daniel Trombly and Yasir Abbas have a very interesting piece in The Daily Beast on what it would actually mean to degrade the Islamic States fighting capacity; andDexter Filkins on the Kurds in theNew Yorker is the higher-level must-read of the week.

title: Vitamin E and Selenium Fail to Prevent Cataracts
description: Many health supplement companies, and some medical experts, have recommended vitamin E and selenium for reducing the risk for cataracts. But a large new study has found they are unlikely to provide benefit, though selenium might have a small effect.

title: Ban Ki-Moon: Extremist Groups Pose an Immediate Threat
description: The United Nations secretary general said Tuesday that even though airstrikes by the United States and its allies were not carried out at the request of the Syrian government in Damascus, large parts of that country are out of the governments control.

title: Rick Owens: Secure in His Own World
description: PARIS  In another in a video series of designers in their offices, we go behind the scenes with Rick Owens, an American in Paris who lives and works in his own building. Here, he discusses renovation, responsibility and the importance of rocks. And thats just the stuff that didnt make it into the video. (The conversation has been edited and condensed.)

title: In the Studio | Rick Owens
description: Rick Owens chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his creativity used to thrive on chaos before he transformed his five-story building in an upscale Parisian neighborhood into an open ascetic space.

title: Where the Heart Is
description: To feel more at home, a distinguished German family gave up one of the grandest houses in London for a former whaling cottage on the East End of Long Island.

title: Students and Residents Air Concerns After High Schools Cancellation of Spamalot
description: Updated, 3:42 p.m. | At a school board meeting on Monday night residents and students of South Williamsport, Pa., spoke out about the controversy over the cancellation of the high schools planned production of the Broadway musical Spamalot. According to an article on Tuesday in The Williamsport Sun-Gazette, students focused less on Spamalot  which had been canceled by school administrators because of a gay subplot  than on their split feelings regarding the director of the musical, Dawn Burch.

title: Hannahs Self-Aware Alter Ego
description: Smart, funny women writers love to dispense advice.

title: Behind Jean Paul Gaultiers Goodbye
description: PARIS  When Jean Paul Gaultier announced at the beginning of the womens wear seasons four-ring, four-week circus that this Saturdays show would be his last ready-to-wear collection, and that he was going to concentrate on couture and fragrance and special collaborations like costumes and interiors instead, it seemed like the end of an era.

title: A Landmark Bar Is Moving Again
description: Milk & Honey 2.0 lasted less than two years.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Words to Remember Him By
description: The news that Jean Paul Gaultier was shutting down his ready-to-wear business, with his last show scheduled for Saturday in Paris, prompted recollections from industry notables who have long considered Mr. Gaultier one of the more original people in fashion  on and off the runway.

description: Facing a tough race against Senator Kay Hagan, Republican challenger Thom Tillis has been bringing in some big political guns in hopes that their star power will rub off.

title: Restaurant Report: Westward in Seattle
description: The appeal of Seattles waterfront restaurants  with views of freshwater lakes and majestic Puget Sound  often starts and ends with those vistas. Westward, which opened last September, doesnt fall into that category. The views are spectacular; located on the north shore of Lake Union, the restaurant overlooks the lake and, beyond it, the Space Needle and city skyline. But it is whats on the menu that bumps Westward into a different tier.

title: Giving the Paris Cafe Scene a Jolt
description: A decade ago, Channa Galhenage, a Londoner, moved to Paris to work in human resources. A longtime coffee devotee, he was shocked by the espresso he tasted in many French cafes.

title: Journalist Kidnapped in Somalia Is Released
description: BERLIN  A German-American journalist who was abducted more than two years ago while in Somalia researching a book about piracy was freed by his captors on Tuesday, German officials said.

title: Today in Small Business: Why Jewelry Stores Hide the Price Tags
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: DSouza Avoids Prison in Campaign Finance Case

description: Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon, two of the worlds most sought-after ballet choreographers, will create a new work for Wendy Whelans farewell performance with New York City Ballet on Oct. 18, the company said.

title: Cadillac Tries to Make a Fresh Start in New York
description: The last time Cadillac, a symbol of American success, was the top-selling luxury car brand in the United States was in 1997. Since then, its executives have tried seemingly everything  from new models to new management to new marketing  to revive its flagging fortunes, with little to show for it.

description: This is the first in what will be an ongoing effort at conversation between readers and the Timess political unit. A reader asked:

title: When in Love With an Egyptian Queen, Go Bold
description: Passions, power, allegiances  everything shifts during Shakespeares Antony and Cleopatra. In a staging directed by Emily Mann at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, the only constant is the production itself  its always beautifully bold.

title: Guido Palau and David Sims on What Changed Fashion Photography
description: The fashion world often revolves around creative alliances. And in the case of the British photographer and T contributor David Sims and the hairstylist Guido Palau, early collaborations proved to be the spark that ignited their careers. Both hail from similar backgrounds, having grown up around not sophisticated London, as Palau describes it, listening to a lot of David Bowie, punk and New Wave music. They formed an easy friendship in the mid 80s and soon teamed up behind the lens, building a portfolio of test pictures that would define their respective styles: Sims would often cast lanky kids off the street, letting them do whatever they felt like in front of the camera, while Palau created non-hair that was usually messy, unwashed and always offhandedly cool. The look was a precursor to grunge and quickly caught the attention of Calvin Klein, who hired the duo to shoot his CK campaign featuring Kate Moss in 1993. It was a pivotal moment for Sims and Palau, yet neither realized it at the time. I didnt think even for a minute wed end up making anything like a living from it, says Sims. Or be successful, adds Palau.

title: PATH Service Between Midtown and New Jersey to Be Suspended
description: PATH train service between Midtown Manhattan and New Jersey will be suspended through Tuesday night while crews try to again repair power cables that caught fire in a tunnel beneath the streets of Chelsea on Sunday.

title: Obama Presses Chinese on Global Warming
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China on Tuesday to make the same effort to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions and join a worldwide campaign to curb global warming.

title: Fall Television Season Opens With Strong Ratings
description: In as big an affirmation as the television business might be able to offer that strong programming still can draw a real crowd, the 8 p.m. hour of television Monday night attracted about 50 million viewers on the four broadcast networks, with another 14 million or so watching football on ESPN.

title: For Cardinals, Success by Way of Castoffs
description: In 2012, the Arizona Cardinals won only five games, prompting the organization to make significant changes. Steve Keim was promoted to general manager on Jan. 8, 2013; nine days later, Bruce Arians was hired as coach. Keim and Arians immediately helped turn around the Cardinals: Despite being in the N.F.L.s toughest division, Arizona surprisingly won 10 games in 2013. And with a 3-0 start this season, Keim and Arians are again exceeding expectations.

description: MOSCOW  Russias Parliament passed a preliminary bill on Tuesday that would limit foreign ownership of Russian media outlets to 20 percent, targeting several prominent publications critical of the government and extending the Kremlins control over the nations independent news media.

title: First Draft Focus: A Receiving Party
description: President Obama never has to walk alone. At Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, he is greeted by a receiving party of Col. John Millard and his wife, Jamie. The colonel greets Mr. Obama when he travels though Andrews, but his wife is only present when Michelle Obama is there. They walk with the first family between aircraft, and the stroll is usually bookended by a salute at each end.

title: U.S. Curbs on Inversions May Deter Some Pharmaceutical Deals
description: The clampdown by the United States on tax-driven cross-border mergers and acquisitions should deter half-baked pharmaceutical deals. Some American-led transactions, like AbbVies recent agreement to buy its British rival Shire, may survive on strategic logic. But pure tax-avoiding combinations look tricky.

description: While running backs were the priority on the fantasy football waiver wire last week, this week points toward quarterbacks and wide receivers for quality pickups.

description: Fordham Universitys new law school and residence hall building, designed by Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, has been completed opposite Damrosch Park, the first phase of Fordhams 15-year master plan for its Manhattan campus adjoining Lincoln Center.

title: At Paris Fashion Week, Hedi Slimanes Sonic Exhibit Opens
description: Rock n roll has arrived, to a reverential hush, at the Fondation Pierre Berg-Yves Saint Laurent. Sonic, an exhibition of black-and-white photographs taken by the Saint Laurent designer, Hedi Slimane, opened on Sept. 18 and will be on view through Jan 11.

title: The Benefits of Easing Climate Change
description: On Tuesday, more than 100 world leaders gathered at the United Nations to open a climate summit meeting that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon hopes will provide momentum to a new round of negotiations toward a global environmental agreement to be signed in Paris next year.

title: Rocket Internet of Germany Sets Price Range for Its I.P.O.
description: LONDON  German technology initial public offerings are like city buses. You can wait ages for one to show up, and then two come by at once.

title: Damien Hirst Collaborates With Deyrolle, Pariss Treasure Trove of Taxidermy
description: Deyrolle, the storied Paris taxidermy and entomology shop, has been cataloguing specimens of the natural world since 1831, providing a resource for researchers, scientists and artists  including Salvador Dal and Jean Dubuffet  along the way. Now, just in time for Paris Fashion Week, the boutique is showcasing a collaboration with the artist Damien Hirst, whose work addresses themes of mans relationship to nature. Hirst has assembled a cabinet of curiosities  titled Signification (Hope, Immortality and Death in Paris, Now and Then)  drawn from Deyrolles collections. In it, his favored leitmotifs (butterflies, skulls) are mixed with manmade objects (bottles of Raid and the British household cleaning product Domestos), teasing out themes of nature versus manufacture, the organic versus the inanimate.

title: From Nuclear Freeze to Global Warming  and Back
description: In June 1982, up to a million demonstrators gathered in Central Park calling for a nuclear freeze. They were protesting the Reagan-era nuclear arms buildup and other developments they saw, not unreasonably, as a threat to civilization and to life on Earth, including talk by some Reagan aides about fighting and winning a nuclear war.

title: Colin Farrell and Vince Vaughn to Star in Season 2 of HBOs True Detective

title: Flooding Risk From Climate Change, Country by Country
description: More than a quarter of Vietnams residents live in areas likely to be subject to regular floods by the end of the century. Four percent of Chinas residents  50 million people  live in the same kind of areas. Across the globe, about one person in 40 lives in a place likely to be exposed to such flooding by the end of the century, absent significant changes.

title: Getting Value Out of Old iPhones After Upgrading

description: MADRID  Gala Lens appointment as Spains first female Davis Cup captain could be a milestone for women in Spanish sports. For now, though, it has instead fueled a debate about whether a woman is fit to coach a man.

description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus  As I drove into Chapel Hill, N.C., on Route 15-501 recently, I was starkly reminded of how different I am now from when I would make that same drive as a student and soccer player at the University of North Carolina. Sometimes, the best way to evaluate how youve changed is in relation to what stays the same.

description: Speaker John A. Boehner has a message for the Department of Veterans Affairs: Dont do the standard government once-over when it comes to assessing the agencys long-troubled health care system.

description: SPECIAL POST  The Puzzles and Games team is interested in your opinion. Competitive play is coming to the web version of the crossword, and were doing some housekeeping before we launch.

title: On a Russian Farm, Where Frustration Grows
description: Chekhov didnt make it to the Peoples Climate March that flowed through Midtown Manhattan on Sunday  being dead does get in the way  but he was with the environmental activists in spirit. In Uncle Vanya, which opens the season at the Pearl Theater Company, this playwrights 19th-century worries over an ailing earth are startlingly contemporary.

title: Chinese President Sends Signal Against Political Change in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  President Xi Jinping of China has used a meeting with some of Hong Kongs leading industrialists to reinforce Beijings unyielding position against political change in the former British colony, lending his personal authority to the governments efforts to undermine the pro-democracy movement here and to signal to the citys business elite that it should toe the official line.

title: A Family Rooted in Two Realms
description: A lot of people in the television business are said to be curious to see how black-ish, ABCs new comedy, is received when it has its premiere on Wednesday night. What they should really be curious about, though, is where the series goes after its funny but talking-point-heavy first episode.

title: Recording Academy to Honor Dylan

MusiCares is a charitable arm of the Recording Academy, the organization that presents the Grammy Awards; its tribute concert is among the events leading up to the 57th Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 8.

description: Some unlikely groups marched side by side among the estimated 300,000-strong Peoples Climate March, organized to put pressure on politicians gathering at this weeks United Nations Climate Summit.
