description: Alfa Romeo, which left the United States market two decades ago, makes a powerful return with its light, lithe 4C sports car.

title: Yet Another No. 1 for Streisand
description: Another decade, another album, and yet another No. 1 for Barbra Streisand.

title: Making Adjustments in the Search for the Perfect News Feed
description: PEOPLE who frequent social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have come to rely on the news feed as a crucial filter that sifts through news, personal stories, trends and facts on their behalf.

title: Stevens Says Ford Was Behind Crucial Affirmative Action Brief
description: The most influential friend-of-the-court brief in living memory has an unlikely history, Justice John Paul Stevens said in a speech on Tuesday night.

title: High School Tech, in Football Playbooks and Classroom Lesson Plans
description: The world of Texas high school football described in my article today is indeed rich in technology. But it reflects the way we increasingly live our lives on screens.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 4 Matchups
description: We expected volatility at running back in 2014, but there were supposed to be some safe fantasy options, those backs taken in the first round of drafts.

title: Apple Pulls iOS 8 Software Update After iPhone Problems
description: Updated to add instructions for removing iOS 8.0.1.

title: A Very British Dining Destination Pops Up on the Lower East Side
description: In England, a dinner series hosted by four British cousins has taken Londoners on culinary trips to Gothenburg, Beirut, Palermo, Maputo and Malaga all without actually leaving the country. The themed meals, which popped up in various secret locations across the city and hark back to the golden age of travel (when jaunts required dressing a certain way and smoking wasnt prohibited in flight), quickly began selling out. And so the founders of the project, dubbed Mile High, decided to bring its performance dinners stateside.

title: Balenciaga: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Security Council Passes Resolution to Thwart Foreign Fighters
description: Thirteen presidents and prime ministers sat around the horseshoe-shaped table at the Security Council on Wednesday afternoon to adopt a legally binding resolution compelling countries to prevent and suppress their citizens from traveling abroad to join terrorist organizations. President Obama, who led the meeting, said it was only the sixth time since the Council first met in 1946 that it held a session with so many member states top leaders.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Thursday and Friday
description: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Obama Calls for Action Over Words on Terrorism
description: President Obama is taking a rare turn at leading a United Nations Security Council meeting, and he is pulling no punches on the need for a strong coalition to combat growing terrorist threats.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Balenciaga Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Sips From a Cider Spree in New York State
description: My boots were soaked, and the air reeked of overripe apples. I felt as if I were bathing in the cider Id come to drink. It was early October and steamy; if the leaves that blazed red from nearly every tree branch were seasonal stop signs, the gods of summer hadnt seen them. I was a few miles from Cayuga Lake, the second-largest of New Yorks 11 Finger Lakes, on a small but extraordinarily prolific orchard. The propertys fruit, which ranged from the palest wash of yellow to grapefruit pink to a purple so dark it looked like a fresh bruise, was hanging all around me and rotting underfoot.

title: Parks and Recreation Comes to Life in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The parks department just wanted to replace four grass soccer fields with artificial turf.

title: The Beauty of a Simple Ponytail at Rochas
description: At the spring 2015 Rochas fashion show in Paris today, the brands creative director, Alessandro DellAcqua, unveiled dreamy designs, including printed white dresses that look like they could have been plucked from the late 70s (the way it looked in Sofia Coppolas Virgin Suicides). Against all the embroidered flowers and lacy details, the simple ponytails  parted to the side and tied low on the back of the head  felt appropriately laid-back and youthful.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Turkey, Syria and India.

title: Calle 13 Leads Latin Grammy Nominees
description: The Puerto Rican group Calle 13 has been nominated for nine Latin Grammy Awards, including the prizes for the years best album (Multi_Viral), best record (Respira El Momento) and best song (Ojos Color Sol). That is one less nomination than the group garnered in 2011, but more than any other group or soloist on this years list.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: Middle East Rivals Trade Rhetorical Jabs at United Nations
description: Whether they bumped into each other back stage could not be confirmed. But the General Assembly on Wednesday afternoon saw a parade of regional rivals coming in quick succession to the podium.

title: Ex-Investor Relations Executive Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: Michael A. Lucarelli, a former executive at an investor relations agency, admitted on Wednesday to insider trading based on information in news releases that had not yet been released.

title: What the Indictment of The Situation Tells Us About the Tax Code
description: Somehow, the most shocking thing about the indictment of Michael Sorrentino for tax fraud is not that the Jersey Shore star may have been less than punctilious about paying the taxman. After all, Mr. Sorrentino, known as The Situation, has never projected the levelheaded public image youd associate with careful income tax compliance. (Here is a video in which he slams his head into a wall. Here is the 911 call from when he was in a brawl at a tanning salon).

title: Reading The Times With Ben Cole
description: Ben Cole is the mobile product lead at Google.org. He was a technology pioneer in Ghana and worked on Google Docs in Mountain View, Calif. Now he heads One Today, a mobile app that connects Google users with causes to create a more socially aware and engaged world. He read todays Times on his mobile phone.

title: Yankees Miss Consecutive Postseasons for First Time in Two Decades
description: For several weeks, the Yankees held on to the belief that they could defy the odds and carry Derek Jeter to one more postseason. With their mediocre record, it was almost impossible. But they felt that if any team could generate such an improbable run, it would be a team with him on it.

title: Newly Released Books
description: WITTGENSTEIN JR.

title: A Multitude of Voices for a Busy Young Pianist, From Bach to Liszt to Jazz
description: Inon Barnatan is ubiquitous this season. An Israeli-born New Yorker, Mr. Barnatan is the New York Philharmonics first artist in association. So hes at the piano for a chamber recital with Philharmonic instrumentalists in December, and makes his full Philharmonic debut in March. Hes a guest artist with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with a concert in November. Hes resident pianist for the Jerusalem Quartets Brahms survey at the 92nd Street Y in October. And, lest downtown feel left out, he was the star attraction at SubCultures second PianoFest on Tuesday night.

title: Music Born of Dreams, a Concerto of Many Moods
description: The conductor Alan Gilbert, exuding excitement, looked almost relieved to be on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall with the musicians of the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday night. The occasion was the first of the orchestras subscription series programs this season, offering the American premiere of Unsuk Chins haunting Clarinet Concerto and a formidable account of Mahlers First Symphony.

title: Recalling Old Dreams in the Old Neighborhood
description: Randy Graff fondly remembers that halcyon time when Brooklyn was Brooklyn. Ms. Graff, 59, who won a Tony for her role in the 1989 Broadway musical City of Angels, has put together a show, Made in Brooklyn Revisited at 54 Below that celebrates the borough and the creative talent nurtured there before the invasion of hipsters, double-wide strollers and artisanal this and that. Ms. Graffs grandparents came to Brooklyn from the old country (her words).

title: Soul Man With a Scottish Burr
description: Moments after he stepped onstage at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night, Paolo Nutini was optimally unkempt. His hair had been pre-touseled, his body was tensed, and his face was contorted in concentration as he gripped his microphone and worked from croon to rasp in Scream (Funk My Life Up). Soon enough, one side of his shirt would come untucked from his jeans. Mr. Nutini, a Scottish songwriter, is a first-rate student of vintage American soul, and the Apollo stage was a historically apt place to prove it.

title: Indias Top Court Revokes Coal Leases
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias top court on Wednesday canceled years worth of coal field leases, a judgment that drew wide attention in a nation with persistent fuel shortages.

title: Synergy and Dissonance, Amid the Weight of History
description: Its a big deal in contemporary dance circles to be anointed a resident commissioned artist at New York Live Arts. On Tuesday the latest recipient of this honor, Kyle Abraham, unveiled The Watershed, the first half of what hes been working on throughout that two-year, generously funded residency. (A second program of three shorter pieces opens on Thursday.)

title: Balenciagas Beaded Pair of Cool, Neutral Flats
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: E.P.A. Unveils Second Phase of Plan to Reverse Great Lakes Damage
description: The federal government issued a new blueprint Wednesday for its efforts to restore the Great Lakes, including plans to clean up 10 contaminated rivers and harbors and step up its attack on poisonous algae blooms that coat parts of three lakes each summer.

title: Building a Force Field to Attain Higher Bliss
description: Its important to remember that music has both aesthetic value and use value, though at live performances, its generally the first of those things that gets priority. But people turn to music for plenty of reasons  sometimes they want to be entertained, sometimes they want to be healed, sometimes they want to be told theyre healable.

title: From the Upshot: Senate Model Update
description: With 40 days to Election Day, todays forecast from the Upshot Senate model gives the Republicans a 59 percent chance of taking control of the Senate.

title: First Draft Focus: Traveling With the President
The Klinghoffer Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Beatings: Social and Psychological Effects
Eliciting False Confessions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Librarys Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfair Laws on Surrogacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Council Tries to Stop Militants
description: President Obama presided over a meeting of the Security Council to pass a binding resolution compelling countries to prevent their citizens from traveling abroad to join militant groups.

title: A Deal From the Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships
description: On Sept. 14, the last day of the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships, held in Glasgow, there was a Swiss Pairs event. This consisted of eight six-board matches.

title: Minimal Handbags
description: Luxury carryalls dont have to trumpet their provenance.

title: Whit Stillman, Director of The Cosmopolitans, on Pariss Most Timeless Places
description: I found the economics of Manhattan just  impossible, said the American director Whit Stillman, seated at a caf in Paris. It was an exceptional time when Paris was a lot cheaper than living in New York. Stillman moved to France in 1998 after making a trio of movies that examined the group dynamics of hyper-articulate youth: Metropolitan, Barcelona and The Last Days of Disco. During nearly a decade there, he explained, he started having a social life in Paris with these expat types  colorful Fritz types.

title: In Fighting Tigers, Xi Inspires the Masses
description: Xi Jinping recently saved my family 20,000 renminbi. Thats $3,255  useful money. He saved the family of a man I met in Zhuhai last week 30,000 renminbi  even more useful money.

title: Turkeys President Erdogan at the U.N.
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Dont Execute Those We Tortured
description: AFTER years of legal battles, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, will finally be put on trial before a military commission at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, though a trial date hasnt yet been set. If he is convicted, as expected, he will almost certainly face the death penalty. And, assuming one believes in the death penalty, it would be hard to think of a stronger candidate for its use.

title: A Suffragists Start
description: Birdsall Otis Edey (1872-1940) was not quite in her teens when she made a paper dolls house from cutup magazines and catalogs. She grew up to be a suffragist and a president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., wrote plays and poetry, and built a theater that seated 150 on her property in Bellport, N.Y. But it was the doll house collages that impressed Eric Boman when he saw an exhibition about Ms. Edeys life at the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society. Mr. Boman, a photographer and writer, turned the artwork into a book, The Paper Dolls House of Miss Sarah Elizabeth Birdsall Otis, Aged Twelve, which will be published next month (Thames & Hudson, $30). If Mrs. Edey had followed the path suggested by her dream home, she might have become an interior designer whose style was elegant, playful and scaled for drama. But why did she choose collage as her mode of expression? Girls would draw and paint a dolls house, Mr. Boman said, but this girl, I think, she didnt think her handiwork was up to snuff. Information: thamesandhudsonusa.com.

title: When Blogging Becomes a Slog
description: It started so innocently.

title: Out of Detroit, Designs and Pride
description: Michele Varian is hosting a pop-up shop in the basement of her Howard Street store, left, featuring goods from about 20 Detroit companies. A Detroit native, Ms. Varian said her origins have always been a point of pride, before it was cool to the rest of the world. The designs for sale include furniture by Alex Drew & No One; vessels by Adora Bella Ceramics, bottom right; metalwork from Smith Shop, top right; and terrariums by Lead Head Glass. Simply being made in Detroit did not qualify an object for admission, Ms. Varian emphasized; the goods also had to meet her rigorous style standards. Everything in the show is something Id buy for the store, she said.

title: Fewer Hero Points for Bed-Making Husbands
description: Having lived in Switzerland, where he mastered the domestic arts by osmosis, my husband is a superior bed maker. I put him in charge of testing the Crane & Canopy Nova duvet cover, which promises to cut the time it takes to make your bed by 80 percent. The sample we received, Hayes Nova Grey, unfolded into a lustrous field of 400-thread-count, charcoal-colored cotton with white piping. A white panel about a foot wide was layered over the top, mimicking the look of a folded flat sheet while concealing a zipper. Using the standard inversion method, my husband turned the fabric envelope inside out, reached inside, plucked two corners of our duvet and gave a mighty shake. A tuck, a zip, a toss and some smoothing, and the bed was made, looking far more finished than usual. Time: 1 minute 44 seconds. A queen-size cover is $149; king, $169; matching shams, $60 a pair. Information: 888-686-8586 or craneandcanopy.com.

title: Art, From Classic to Quirky
description: On Saturday, Stair Galleries in Hudson, N.Y., will offer highlights from the wildly diverse collections of Ashton Hawkins, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts former counsel, and his husband, Johnnie Moore, from the couples homes in Manhattan and Athens, N.Y. The trove includes 18th- and 19th-century Russian silver, classical bronzes, Victorian and modern furniture and contemporary works by Jasper Johns, Alfred Stieglitz, Helen Frankenthaler, Paul Cadmus and David Hockney. On the block will be a screen-printed Campbells Soup Can T-shirt signed by Andy Warhol, a gift from the artist that is estimated to fetch $1,000 to $1,500; Sin, an unusual screen print ($6,000 to $10,000) by Ed Ruscha; a quirky portrait of Alfred Hitchcock by Hunt Slonem ($4,000 to $6,000); and Alfred Stieglitzs Steerage, a large-format photogravure dated 1907 that has been hailed as one of the finest and earliest works of modernism in photography ($12,000 to $18,000). Information: 518-751-1000 or stairgalleries.com.

title: Suffering for Her Art, and Beckett
description: CAMBRIDGE, ENGLAND  First comes a layer of thick black grease, applied from the neck to just below the eyes. The lips are carefully painted red. Then a blindfold, then clinging black fabric wrapped around the head. At that point, Lisa Dwan is guided up steps to a wooden board, her arms pinioned through metal brackets on each side, her head fitted into a small opening and secured in place by thick straps that cover her ears. Unable to see, unable to hear, she takes a deep breath and opens her mouth.

title: On Patrol With the Weed Warriors
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.  Kathleen Nelson cant tell a Ford from a Chevy, but she can spot mile-a-minute weed 100 yards away.

title: New Offerings for a New Season
Bags That Dont Brag
description: When Tyler Ellis describes Tyler Alexandra, her three-season-old line of handbags, she talks about anonymous branding. The interior of the elegant Tyler Alexandra doctors bag shown here is bright blue suede; it rests on tiny pinecone feet.

title: Spirits They Can Live With
description: For the residents of Provincetown, Mass., the old Martin House conjures up a variety of impressions. Some see the shingled structure, built in 1750, as a place where fishermen once lived. Others identify it as the home of abolitionists. Still others will tell you its populated by ghosts.

title: Watering Cans: A Garden of Delights
description: Fall is an important time for gardens. Youre cleaning up and preparing for the spring, as well as preparing the garden for winter, said Camilla Hammer, a garden designer and urban farmer. But you also have to continue tending gardens planted earlier in the year, like the one that she and Julia Sherman, the author of the blog Salad for President, created on the roof of MoMA PS1, which is still going strong.

title: Verbatim: DSouza Sentencing
description: Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, before sentencing conservative author Dinesh DSouza to probation for violating federal campaign finance laws.

title: Big iPhone 6 Bulges in All the Wrong Places
description: Its the ultimate first world problem. You go to the Apple store, drop $400 for an iPhone 6 and then discover it doesnt fit in your pocket.

title: Travelport Prices Shares at Top of Range in I.P.O.
description: Eight years after being purchased by private equity firms, Travelport Worldwide is set to make its public markets debut.

title: Uighur Scholars Life Sentence Is Seen as Reining in Debate on Minorities in China
description: BEIJING  The news that a Uighur academic, Ilham Tohti, had been sentenced in China to life in prison on charges of separatism drew a torrent of international outrage this week. President Obama called for his release, the European Union condemned the sentence as totally unjustified, and rights advocates said they could not recall a similarly harsh penalty for a prominent intellectual whose main offense, it appeared, was criticizing government policies.

title: Plans to Rebuild Our Nuclear Arsenal
A Transformational Festival
description: Lightning in a Bottle in Bradley, Calif. is one of the larger and more influential of these transformational festivals.

title: The Progeny of Burning Man
description: It was 3 a.m. in Bradley, Calif., in the middle of a dusty dry lake bed, and Carl Weiseth, 33, was shoeless, shirtless and regaling a gathering crowd about last nights escapade. I didnt make it back from the dance floor until the sun was starting to rise, he told his audience, adding that he passed out to the gentle vibrations of thumping electronic music for three to four hours.

title: Going the Distance to Lead the Faithful
description: Rabbi Rami Schwartzer, a Connecticut-born fourth-year rabbinical student at Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, wont be spending the High Holy Days as he usually does. Instead, he has traveled nearly 1,600 miles to spend the Jewish New Year, which began Wednesday evening, in Cypress, Tex., leading services for a bunch of strangers with a borrowed Torah in a rented clubhouse.

title: Me and the Universe
description: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.

title: Me and the Universe
description: Three diagrams explaining how I fit in, from the Big Bang to the apocalypse. Read more

title: Biotech Firm Adaptimmune Attracts $104 Million Investment
description: New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm that has backed the likes of Groupon and Salesforce, is now investing in a biotechnology company developing a treatment for cancer.

title: Parental Politics in Colorado
description: Spouses and mistresses have long been fair game in politics, but parents have largely been off limits.

title: Trying on a Persona
description: There, at the rear of the new 3.1 Phillip Lim store: a big ol blanket coat, in a dry burgundy, made of a scratchy alpaca-mohair-and-so-on blend, deliberately oversize, cinched at the waist with a hidden drawstring. It is, if not the most expensive mens item in the new store, certainly the most visually arresting. It is set apart, high on a platform, like the Christ the Redeemer statue that gazes out over Rio.

title: Ukraine Picks Motley Group to Exchange for Prisoners
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  At first glance, the prisoner swap between the Ukrainian government and pro-Russian separatists appeared fair enough: On a deserted stretch of highway along the front line, each side released 28 captives, observing a principle of numerical parity.

title: How Hip Are Cold Hands? Not Very
description: Telfar Clemens of the hip unisex label Telfar, which is practically a household name among in-the-know night-life and fashion sets, designs streetwise garments that dont require being the coolest kid in school to pull off. Mr. Clemens likes to tweak utilitarian basics, adding pockets to sweaters and jackets (the man loves a pocket) or thumb holes to oversize turtlenecks because he likes to have his hands covered in the winter. The label is a hit at retail, too: Opening Ceremony hosted a pop-up for the designer in August; Vfiles stocks the line. Theres also a fragrance in the works. Im ready for people to start smelling like Telfar, he said.

title: Store Openings, New Collections and Sales Starting Sept. 25
description: Openings and Events

title: Film on Lost Boys of Sudan Uses Keys to Stand Out
description: THE creators, producers and distributors of a new film are hoping that keys will be the key to helping their movie stand out in a crush of fall releases.

title: Marathon Bombings Trial Will Remain in Boston
description: BOSTON  The trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the Boston Marathon bombings, will take place in Boston but will be delayed two months and is to start in January.

title: Drag Performers Fight Facebooks Real Name Policy
description: Earlier this month, a drag performer in San Francisco named Lil Miss Hot Mess received a notice from Facebook. Her account had been suspended because she was not using what the company considered a real name. Lil Miss Hot Mess could not gain access to her posts, messages or photos.

title: Lithuania Feels Squeeze in Sanctions War With Russia
description: ZIBENAI, Lithuania  In the sanctions war between Russia and the West, Kasia Jankuns 80 dairy cows seem to be losing.

title: With China Set to Open Stock Trading, Investors Lay Groundwork
description: OConnor, the $5.6 billion hedge fund owned by UBS, has been expanding its presence in Asia. It has hired traders from UBSs proprietary trading desk to work in its Hong Kong and Singapore offices. In August, it hired John Yu, a former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors

title: At amfARs Fashion Gala, Euros and Cocktails Flow Freely
description: MILAN  If youre at a Milan Fashion Week party, expect late hours.

title: Are Bees Back Up on Their Knees?
description: IN 2006, beekeepers in Pennsylvanias apple country noticed the first sign of many bad things to come. Once thriving beehives were suddenly empty, devoid of nearly all worker bees, but with an apparently healthy, if lonely, queen remaining in place. Over a period of just three months, tens of thousands of honeybees were totally gone. Multiply this across millions of beehives in millions of apiaries in the more than 22 states that were soon affected, and suddenly we faced a huge, tragic mystery. Up to 24 percent of American apiaries were experiencing colony collapse disorder (C.C.D.).

title: David Macklovitch of Chromeo: Against the Tide in a Stylish Manner
description: There was a time, before artisanal cocktail bars dotted Bedford Avenue and Pilates studios popped up along the Brooklyn waterfront, when David Macklovitch, one half of the electro-funk duo Chromeo, might have blended into Williamsburg. Tall and lanky, partial to black leather and dark Wayfarers, he brings to mind the type of guy who rides a motorcycle to gigs and chain-smokes between sets  or as he puts it, a French rocker from the 80s.

title: Jack Bryan: A Little Philosophy, A Lot of Filmmaking
description: AGE 29

title: Joining With Rival Sony, Movie Executive Jeff Robinov Starts Studio 8
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  In his 17 years in the movie division of Warner Bros., Jeff Robinov went in for the kill against Sony Pictures Entertainment time and again, competing for scripts, access to top filmmakers and prized release dates.

title: Bill Simmons Suspended by ESPN for Tirade on Roger Goodell
description: On Monday, ESPNs Bill Simmons challenged his employer to discipline him for excoriating N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodells handling of the Ray Rice domestic violence case. Simmons, on his Grantland.com podcast, repeatedly called Goodell a liar for saying that he had not seen the elevator video of Rice punching his fiance.

title: Big Data in the Classroom
Cooking Videos Bring the Pros to Your Kitchen
description: Meghan Gourley is an assistant editor and video producer for the food department.

title: Hassan Rouhani, President of Iran, Experiences Rare Unscripted Moment
description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has been busy since his arrival in New York for the United Nations General Assembly with interviews and speeches. He will address the General Assembly on Thursday morning. So far, he has been repeating his countrys talking points on nuclear negotiations with the six world powers, the war in Syria and the Wests newfound anxiety over the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, ISIL and Jaish, which Iran also considers a terrorist organization.

title: Navajo Nations Complaint Against the U.S.
description: The Navajo Nation will receive $554 million after agreeing to end its claim that the federal government mismanaged tribal resources.

title: Navajos to Get $554 Million to Settle Suit Against U.S.
description: BOULDER, Colo.  In the largest settlement obtained by an American Indian tribe from the federal government, the Navajo Nation will receive $554 million to end a lawsuit alleging that the government mismanaged the communitys assets for more than 50 years.

title: Montanas Trail House in Bushwick, Brooklyn
description: A taste of country living has taken root in deep Brooklyn. Opened in June, Montanas Trail House recreates a sliver of the backwoods in a former auto repair shop.

title: Leaders Speeches at U.N. Show Delicacy of Mission Against ISIS Militants
description: UNITED NATIONS  Turkey berated other countries for not doing more to stop their citizens from leaving home to join terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq. Qatar cautioned that a new global war on terrorism ought not to stabilize the government of Syria. China welcomed American leadership on staunching the recruitment of foreign fighters for terrorist organizations, seizing on the moment to call for stricter rules to rein in the Internet.

title: To Tuscan Wine Makers, a Preservation Plan Takes On Acrid Undertones
description: MONTALCINO, Italy  Its gentle sloping hills, olive groves, cypresses and sunflower fields have made Tuscany a muse to writers and artists for centuries. But the region is equally renowned for its verdant vineyards and their wines, some of the most prized in Italy and the world.

title: In Israel, Values of a Holy Respite Are Adapted for a High-Tech World
description: JERUSALEM  The printers at Energiya Global sit idle as the company, which promotes solar power in developing countries, tries to go paperless. Energiya is also throwing open the doors to its funky, colorful headquarters for yoga workshops and Talmud classes. And instead of ordering in for the weekly staff lunch, employees this year will rotate cooking duties, donating the savings.

title: Judge Denies BPs Request to Recoup Overpayments to Oil Spill Victims
description: The oil giant BP cannot recoup hundreds of millions of dollars it claims to have overpaid victims of a 2010 Gulf Coast oil spill, a federal judge ruled Wednesday.

title: Report Rebukes Treasury for Bailout Pay Packages at G.M. and Ally Financial
description: Top executives at General Motors and Ally Financial, both of which received bailouts from the United States Treasury Department in 2009, were paid excessively even as taxpayers lost money, according to a special inspector general report.

title: De Blasio Walks Tightrope Between Municipal Politics and International Influence
description: He has bonded with the socialist mayor of Paris, tutoring her on the nuances of the American term retrofit. He has met with Italys foreign minister three times in the past four months. This week, he walked in the Peoples Climate March in Manhattan alongside the United Nations secretary general and talked shop with the leaders of Buenos Aires, Melbourne and Rio de Janeiro.

title: Arizona States D. J. Foster Draws Inspiration From Guardian Angel
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  D. J. Foster, Arizona States star running back, has a tattoo above his heart with Sweet Dreams inscribed below the smiling face of his sister, Jennifer.

title: Treasury Imposes Terrorism Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Wednesday imposed sanctions on 11 people and one entity it said were sending financial and other support to terrorist groups, including the Islamic State. The sanctions are aimed at the funding streams that have allowed the terrorist organizations to flourish and recruit fighters from the Middle East, Europe and North Africa.

title: Iraq: Militants Destroy Historic Church
description: Islamic State militants on Wednesday blew up an important site in early Christianity known as the Green Church in Tikrit. The group, also known as ISIS, has driven thousands of Christians and other religious minorities from their homes as it has consolidated its hold on a broad section of Syria and Iraq. It has destroyed or defaced several historic churches as well as many Muslim shrines that it considers prohibited by its puritanical version of Islam. After capturing the city of Mosul this summer, the Islamic States fighters took a sledgehammer to the tomb of the biblical figure Jonah. It replaced the cross above the historic St. Ephrems Cathedral in Mosul with its black jihadi flag, and it also destroyed a statue of the Virgin Mary.

title: Florida Goes Down the Drain
description: On Miami Beach, rising sea levels have interesting consequences. The ocean periodically starts bubbling up through local drainpipes. By the time its over, the concept of going down to the water has extended to stepping off the front porch.

title: The Ebola Fiasco
description: The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is a tragedy. But, more than that, the response to it has been a gross failure.

title: Warnings on Big Medical Bills
description: Its not an uncommon situation for patients to be billed by doctors for costly services they did not request or, in some cases, were not even aware they had received.

title: Court Returns Inquiry Into Walkers Finances to Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE  A federal appeals court on Wednesday removed an injunction halting an investigation into whether the campaign of Gov. Scott Walker illegally coordinated with conservative groups on fund-raising and spending as he sought to overcome a recall effort two years ago.

title: Long Lines at Minority Polling Places
description: Some of the longest lines on Election Day occur at polling places in black and Hispanic neighborhoods. A new report says thats not a coincidence.

title: An Ouster on Derek Jeters Way Out
description: Derek Jeter has played 1,390 regular-season games in the Bronx, and in every one of them, the Yankees have been alive for a playoff spot or have already clinched one. That could change on Thursday, when Jeter is set to play his first and only home game with the Yankees eliminated from the postseason.

title: A New Focus on Foreign Fighters
description: In response to President Obamas reassertion of American leadership in the Middle East, the United Nations Security Council moved to stanch the flow of foreign fighters, including those joining the Islamic State, by demanding that nations adopt laws to prevent their citizens from traveling abroad to join these groups.

title: Iranian President Praises Cooperation in New York
description: In two days of back-to-back interviews, speeches and meetings in New York this week, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has gone to some lengths to sound much like President Obama in describing the need to defeat Islamic radicals and to seize what may well be a last opportunity over the next two months to reach an accord with the West over Irans nuclear program.

title: Browns Rape List, Revisited
description: Brown University faces questions about how it responds to a students charge of sexual assault, two decades after similar accusations sparked a national reform movement.

title: Ned Yost, the Royals Rugged Leader, Looks Inward
description: CLEVELAND  In late September 2008, after Ned Yost was fired as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers with 12 games left in the season, he went home to Georgia. He did not watch baseball or follow the playoff race. Instead, he worked on his 700-acre farm, building feeders.

title: The Remote Repo Man
description: As auto lenders reach out to those with poor credit, they are increasingly using starter interruption devices, technology that allows them to remotely disable a car, to spur timely payment.

title: Emissions From India Will Increase, Official Says
description: In a blow to American hopes of reaching an international deal to fight global warming, Indias new environment minister said Wednesday that his country would not offer a plan to cut its greenhouse gas emissions ahead of a climate summit next year in Paris.

title: Browns Rape List, Revisited
description: So much of the public debate about sexual assault on college campuses revolves around the definition of consent. This Op-Doc video has a different focus. After a university finds a student responsible for sexual misconduct, what happens next?

title: Jeb Bush Returns to Fray and Finds Going Rough
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  In one of his first public appearances of the 2014 campaign, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida had a vivid preview Wednesday of the challenges he would face with his partys conservative base should he seek the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

title: Tossing the Ryder Cup Script, Phil Mickelson Injects Some Drama
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland

title: In Sunset Park, Videos of Confrontations Elevate Mistrust of Police
description: For the second time this month, video of a violent confrontation between the police and residents in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, has aroused concerns in the neighborhood about arrest tactics.

title: More Power, and a New Name, for the Mercedes-AMG C63
description: Mercedes-Benz will formally introduce the new Mercedes-AMG C63 on Oct. 2 at the Paris auto show; in the meantime, the company has released a number of details about the model, which will succeed the C63 AMG.

title: Miss a Payment? Good Luck Moving That Car
description: The thermometer showed a 103.5-degree fever, and her 10-year-olds asthma was flaring up. Mary Bolender, who lives in Las Vegas, needed to get her daughter to an emergency room, but her 2005 Chrysler van would not start.

title: At 39, a Rookie at the Ryder Cup Carries a Scottish Torch
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland  This Ryder Cup will be the first in Scotland in 41 years, and the only Scot who will be playing is Stephen Gallacher, a 39-year-old rookie who required a captains pick to make it to Gleneagles.

title: In a Mississippi Jail, Convictions and Counsel Appear Optional
description: RALEIGH, Miss.  Sheila Burks has not seen her nephew Octavious much over the past few years.

title: 2 Governors Announce Extra Security at Transportation Centers
description: Citing international conflicts and the persistent threat of terrorism in the metropolitan area, Govs. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Chris Christie of New Jersey on Wednesday ordered a more pronounced security presence across their states, with an increase of uniformed officers at airports, train stations and other key hubs.

title: Unframed, a JR Installation on Ellis Island
description: The French artists new exhibition in the former Ellis Island Immigrant Hospital features images made from archival photos taken in and around the facility.

description: 8:25 p.m., CBS and NFL Network

title: About the Khorasan Terror Cell
description: The jihadi groups origins and why United States forces attacked it alongside ISIS.

title: A Terror Cell That Avoided the Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  Some time last year, a Kuwaiti man in his early 30s who had spent more than a decade hiding from the American government arrived in northwest Syria, where he met up with other members of Al Qaeda who had begun putting down roots in a country torn by two years of death and chaos.

title: Iranian President Praises Cooperation in New York
description: Iranian President Praises Cooperation in New York

title: F.B.I. Confirms a Sharp Rise in Mass Shootings Since 2000
description: WASHINGTON  A report released by the F.B.I. on Wednesday confirmed what many Americans had feared but law enforcement officials had never documented: Mass shootings have risen drastically in the past half-dozen years.

title: The Destruction of Gog and Magog
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  If I said to you that todays constructor has let us know that he has left 10 body parts scattered around his grid, what would your first reaction be? Curiosity? Horror? An uncontrollable urge to call the police?

title: Affordable Care Act Reduces Costs for Hospitals, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration increased the pressure on states to expand Medicaid on Wednesday, citing new evidence that hospitals reap financial benefits and gain more paying customers when states broaden eligibility.

title: White House Issues New Regulations for Dangerous Biological Research
description: The Obama administration on Wednesday issued new guidelines intended to strengthen the oversight of federally funded biology research that could inadvertently produce bioweapons.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 24, 2014
Eisenhower Memorial Moves Forward
description: WASHINGTON  A federal commission on Wednesday endorsed a design for the proposed Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial that Eisenhower family members have criticized as undignified and too costly.

title: Malloy Says Rail Service in Connecticut Will Expand
description: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut announced a pre-Election Day present for beleaguered commuters on Wednesday in the form of additional train service between the New Haven station and Grand Central Terminal.

title: From Expanded Home, Celebrating the Cultures of the African Diaspora
description: When Marta Moreno Vega walked through the old firehouse, tattered pinups littered the floor, rats scurried along cracked walls, and parts of the Romanesque ceiling had fallen to the floor. But still she saw her dream: A space that could, once again, become an anchor in its East Harlem community.

title: In M.T.A. Capital Budget, a Reappearing Cash Gap
description: Every five years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveils a glossy long-term plan for its vast system of trains, buses and bridges. This week, the capital proposal it released put the cost of keeping the aging system in working order at $32 billion.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: You come from a great tradition that stands for education, not ignorance; innovation, not destruction; the dignity of life, not murder. Those who call you away from this path are betraying this tradition, not defending it.

title: Joseph D. McNamara, Father of Community Policing, Dies at 79
description: Joseph D. McNamara, a onetime New York City patrolman who earned a doctorate from Harvard and went on to become a California police chief whose pioneering embrace of community policing and diversity in the ranks helped catalyze broad changes in police practices nationwide, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 79.

title: Security Pact Will Be Signed After Afghan President Is Inaugurated, Official Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  A new security agreement authorizing the presence of American forces in Afghanistan after 2014 will be signed just days after the nations new president is inaugurated on Monday, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

title: Team Loses Case Against U.S.T.A.
description: A judge ruled against a senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members in its case against the United States Tennis Association. The team, which had qualified for the U.S.T.A. Eastern Adult Section Championships, filed a lawsuit against the association in the Southern District Court of New York over the associations refusal to change a tournament schedule to accommodate the players observance of the Sabbath. The tournament will be held as scheduled in Schenectady, N.Y., from Sept. 27 to 29.

title: On His Own Terms
description: Stephan Janson might have followed in the footsteps of his idol Yves Saint Laurent, but instead chose a quieter life away from the frenzy of the fashion world as a couturier to some of the most discerning women in Europe.

title: A Luddites Intimate Portraits of an Internet Sensation
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Boehner Out to Defeat Europe (In Golf)
description: Speaker John A. Boehner may be out hustling for Republican House candidates in New England, but he is also gearing up for the Ryder Cup, the always intense golf competition between the United States and Europe that begins Friday in Scotland.

title: Holder Backs Suit in New York Faulting Legal Service for Poor
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who last year declared a crisis in Americas legal-defense system for the poor, is supporting a class-action lawsuit that accuses Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the State of New York of perpetuating a system that violates the rights of people who cannot afford to hire lawyers.

title: A Doctor, a Rabbi and a Chicken
description: Doctor, is it O.K. for our rabbi to visit my father?

title: Word of the Day | mountebank
description: mountebank \maun-ti-baNk\ noun

title: South Carolina: Charges for Trooper Who Shot Unarmed Man in Traffic Stop
description: A South Carolina state trooper who was fired for shooting an unarmed man during a Sept. 4 traffic stop was arrested on Wednesday. The trooper, Lance Cpl. Sean Groubert, 31, was charged with assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, according to The State, a newspaper based in Columbia, S.C. He was being held on $75,000 bond after a video of the stop was played at his bond hearing. The video showed him shooting a motorist who was reaching into his truck after the trooper had asked for his license and registration. The motorist, Levar Jones, 35, was released from a hospital after being treated for a gunshot wound to his hip.

title: The Little Writing Prize That Could
description: In the thick of the literary awards season, as the National Book Foundation, the Man Booker judges and the Nobel committee all prepare to announce winners in coming weeks, an unlikely institution has bestowed a new prize on writers: Amtrak.

title: Kay Hagans Surprising Strength
description: If there is any state where the Democrats are defying expectations  and where Republicans should be kicking themselves  its North Carolina.

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) HOW TO GET AWAY WITH MURDER This latest entry from ShondaLand  Shonda Rhimess production company  to join ABCs Thursday night lineup stars the Oscar-nominated Viola Davis as Annalise Keating, an intimidating law professor at a Philadelphia college, the likes of whom hasnt been seen since Prof. Charles Kingsfield (John Houseman) caused the knees of aspiring legal eagles to knock in The Paper Chase. Aja Naomi King, Alfred Enoch, Jack Falahee, Karla Souza and Matt McGorry play Keatings prized pupils, first seen toting a dead body in a rug around campus. Peter Nowalk created this series, which shuttles between the past and present as, thread by thread, it unravels who did what and why. In Greys Anatomy, leading in at 8, Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) seeks to regain control of her life as a new doctor (Kelly McCreary) comes on board and Derek (Patrick Dempsey) pushes to move to Washington. And in Scandal, at 9, Fitz (Tony Goldwyn) begins his second term in the White House determined to make a positive impact on the country; Mellie (Bellamy Young) copes with the loss of her son; and everybody tries to figure out where Olivia (Kerry Washington) and Jake (Scott Foley) have run off to.

title: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
description: The fashion world meets in Paris. The global tour has convened the front-row troops, but its not only the spectators who travel. The designers have to show up, too.

title: Corrections: September 25, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Russia Uses Its Natural Gas to Play the China Card, Again
description: Ahead of a key meeting of global leaders in Beijing, Russian officials say that negotiations are heating up with China for a possible second major energy deal this year. If signed, the pact would authorize a new pipeline that could double the amount of natural gas Russia is scheduled to export to China and elevate Russia into a major supplier there.

title: Swiss Pilots to Fly Solar Plane Around World
description: Last year, two Swiss pilots became the first to fly across the United States in a featherweight plane using the power of the sun.

title: Test Yourself | A Six-Hour Concert Consisting of a Single Song
description: Below are seven paragraphs of a Sept. 19 article, A Concert Not Live, but Always Living.

title: David Cameron to Apologize for Saying Queen Purred Over Scottish Vote Result
description: LONDON  By the arcane protocols governing monarchs and ministers, it was a moment that should never have happened.

title: R.B.S. Chairman to Step Down
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that its chairman, Philip Hampton, would step down from its board next year and would join the British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline.

title: 6 Qs About the News | In Colorado, a Student Counterprotest to an Anti-Protest Curriculum
description: In the article In Colorado, a Student Counterprotest to an Anti-Protest Curriculum, Jack Healy writes about a student protest in response to a school district proposal to oversee a curriculum that would promote patriotism and respect.

title: Where Texas Is a Dream State
description: Nancy Newberry wanted to make pictures of Texas that went past the facile folklore of the homestead, past the stereotypes of tumbleweeds and ten-gallon hats. Put in decidedly nonfolksy terms, she was fascinated by disjunctive cognition, that phenomenon in a dream where you simultaneously recognize something is and isnt. In other words, something familiar  but just shy of normal.

title: What Television Shows Have Mattered to You?
description: The new television season is beginning, with new shows like black-ish debuting, and old favorites like The Big Bang Theory returning.

title: Throwback Thursday | 1976 Book Bans
description: In honor of Banned Books Week, we feature this 1976 article from the Times archive in which Kurt Vonnegut, Bernard Malamud and Desmond Morris write about having their books banned from school libraries that year.

title: Xinhua Details Charges in Case Against Ilham Tohti
description: Chinas state news agency, Xinhua, published on Wednesday a lengthy account of the trial of Ilham Tohti, the Uighur intellectual who was sentenced to life on charges of separatism. The sentencing of Mr. Tohti on Tuesday prompted condemnation from the European Union, the United States and other governments.

title: Hassan Rouhani Hints at ISIS and Nuclear Gaps to Be Bridged
description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran offered some insight Wednesday into what he would say Thursday in his speech at the United Nations General Assembly, telling an audience of foreign policy intellectuals that he welcomed the Wests new alarm over the Islamic State militant group, disagreed that bombing Syria was the answer, and reminded the world that Iran was the first to help its neighbor Iraq when Islamic State fighters invaded three months ago.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: The Rain Weve Missed
description: Good morning on this drippy Thursday.

title: DHL to Begin Deliveries by Drone in Germany
description: LONDON  In the world of drones, Europe is out to show that whatever the United States can do, it can do better.

title: In Hong Kong, Is Limited Democracy Better Than None?
description: Thousands of Hong Kong university students abandoned classes Monday to rally against Chinese government limits on voting rights, report Chris Buckley and Alan Wong for The New York Times, a bellwether demonstration of the citys appetite for turning smoldering discontent into street level opposition.

title: Roland Mouret: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: British Police Arrest 9 in Antiterror Sweep
description: A day after Prime Minister David Cameron pledged British support for the American-led air campaign in Iraq, the counterterrorism police in Britain rounded up nine men suspected of having links to a banned Islamist group and searched 18 buildings across the capital and in the English Midlands.

title: Daily Report: Shedding Light on Hidden Bias at Google
description: Google, like many tech companies, is a mans world, Farhad Manjoo reports.

title: Carven: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Philippines Says Local Terrorist Group Is Not Linked to ISIS
description: MANILA  The Philippine military said on Thursday that there were no ties between domestic extremist organizations and the Islamic State, despite a threat by local rebels to kill two German captives if Germany continued to support the United States-led military campaign against the group, also known as ISIS.

title: The Woman Who Walked 10,000 Miles (No Exaggeration) in Three Years
description: A hundred years ago, when Robert Falcon Scott set out for Antarctica on his Terra Nova expedition, his two primary goals were scientific discovery and reaching the geographic South Pole. Arguably, though, Scott was really chasing what contemporary observers call a sufferfest. He set himself up for trouble: Scott brought Manchurian and Siberian ponies that quickly fell through the snow and ice; he planned, in part, for his crew to man-haul, meaning that the men would pull sleds full of gear, instead of relying on dogs. Even when Scotts men faltered, they continued collecting specimens, including rocks. The expedition ended terribly; everybody who made the push to the pole died. Miserable, starving and frostbitten, one of Scotts last four men killed himself by walking into a blizzard without even bothering to put on his boots.

title: The Look of Paris
description: Fashion week began with collections from Dries Van Noten, Hood by Air, Anthony Vaccarello, Christophe Lemaire and more.

title: Its Hard for Start-Up Owners to Find Good Advice
description: A lot of people want to tell me how to run Posse.

title: Today In Politics
description: Boehner Says New Congress Should Debate Military Action

title: Covering Derek Jeter
description: Derek Jeter is playing his last game at Yankee Stadium tonight. We asked Tyler Kepner, the national baseball correspondent for The Times, what it was like to cover the polished and poised shortstop.

title: Morning Agenda: Devices Fuel Subprime Auto Boom
description: DEVICES FUEL SUBPRIME AUTO BOOM | Subprime lenders are increasingly relying on technology that allows them to track and disable delinquent borrowers vehicles with just a tap of a smartphone app, bringing auto loans into the lives of people with low credit scores, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write as part of DealBooks Driven Into Debt series. One mother could not get her 10-year-old daughter to an emergency room after her lender remotely activated a device in her cars dashboard that prevented her car from starting. Another borrower contends that her lender shut her car down while she was driving on the highway.

title: Ebola Death Toll Is More Than 2,900, W.H.O. Says
description: GENEVA  The number of people killed by the Ebola outbreak in West Africa has reached at least 2,917, driven by the continuing rapid spread of the disease in Liberia and Sierra Leone, though in Guinea the number of new cases appears to have stabilized, the World Health Organization reported Thursday.

title: Air France Scales Back Transavia Plan, Giving In to Striking Pilots Demands
description: PARIS  Despite bowing to an important union demand, Air France-KLM remained crippled on Thursday by an 11-day-old pilots strike.

title: Afghanistans Failed Transformation
description: On Sunday, after months of bitter wrangling, the two leading candidates in Afghanistans presidential election agreed to form a national unity government. Ashraf Ghani, a Pashtun technocrat, is to be president, and Abdullah Abdullah, a former foreign minister of mixed Tajik and Pashtun descent, is to be chief executive, a newly created post akin to prime minister. The power-sharing agreement came after an audit of the ballots cast in a June runoff, in an election widely believed to have been partially rigged. It has no basis in Afghanistans election law. And given the rancor that has come before, it may not hold very long.

title: Guangdong Sees Surge in Dengue Fever Cases
description: The southern Chinese province of Guangdong has seen a surge in dengue fever cases this year, raising fears that factors such as climate change and urbanization have accelerated the spread of the mosquito-borne disease in the region.

title: Warner Holds a 9-Point Lead in Virginia, Poll Finds
description: Senator Mark R. Warner, the Democratic incumbent in Virginia, has opened up a 9-point lead over his Republican opponent, Ed Gillespie, according to a poll released on Thursday by Quinnipiac University.

title: 1889: Wissmann Plans Attacks
description: The German Captain Wissmann has been at Bagamoyo for some time, and all the tailors in Zanzibar have been busy, making white cotton uniforms and bags for provisions. He is organizing a force of 2,000 men, with which he announces that he intends to proceed into the interior and attack Bushiri, who appears to be encamped somewhere near Mpwapwa. After defeating the Arab who has given him so much trouble, and hanging him if he falls into his hands, Captain Wissmann will proceed to Kilima Njara.  The New York Herald, European Edition, September 26, 1889

title: Empire Renewed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Forget the new Star Wars movie for now. At Lucasfilm headquarters here, the pressure is arguably more intense on a new animated TV series: Rebels, making its cable debut early next month, not only represents a dramatic shift back to non-prequel stories  for the first time since 1998  it also formally ushers in the studios Disney era.

title: Doubt as a Sign of Faith
description: Certainty is so often overrated.

title: David Cameron Addresses General Assembly
description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: FiveStars, a Consumer Loyalty Start-Up, Raises $26 Million
description: FiveStars, a start-up that creates customer loyalty programs for small businesses, said on Thursday that it had raised $26 million as it sought to expand its presence in what the company said was a $60 billion market.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Nigerian President Addresses U.N.
description: President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: About Last Night: Obamas Dine in Style at Estela
description: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

title: Keeping the City Clean, but Not Now
description: Dear Diary:

title: Home Design Objects That Move Away From Minimalism
description: Objects in playful patterns and vibrant colors are a lighthearted break from the tyranny of too much refinement.

title: Hootsuite Allows You to Call Customer Service From a Tweet
description: Twitter has transformed our ability to get customer service from big companies.

title: At Least 50 Killed in Xinjiang Violence, Officials Say
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities provided new details on Thursday about a violent clash in the Xinjiang region of western China last weekend that they said had left 50 people dead and more than 50 others injured.

title: Britain Seeks to Widen Law Against Rigging of Financial Benchmarks
description: The British government announced on Thursday it would increase its oversight of a broad array of financial benchmarks in the foreign exchange, fixed income and commodity markets, including making it a criminal offense for traders to manipulate them.

title: Jeb Bush Strikes Hawkish Tone on ISIS
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, making one of his first appearances on the campaign trail this year, got a taste on Wednesday in North Carolina of what may await him if he seeks the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

title: British Roadside Assistance Company RAC Decides Against I.P.O.
description: LONDON  RAC, the British roadside assistance company, called off its plans on Thursday for a possible initial public offering after Singapores sovereign wealth fund agreed to take a stake in the company.

title: Womens Rights Activist Executed by ISIS in Iraq
description: GENEVA  An Iraqi lawyer known for her work promoting womens rights has been killed by Islamic State fighters, the head of the United Nations human rights office said on Thursday, continuing a pattern of attacks on professional women.

title: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 4
description: For Week 4, Eddie Lacy, Philip Rivers and Michael Crabtree are among the players in position to put up big fantasy football numbers.

title: Ukrainian President Sets Sights on Closer E.U. Ties
description: MOSCOW  Proclaiming that the main, most dangerous part of the war is already in the past, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said on Thursday that his office was in constant communication with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to sustain a truce in eastern Ukraine, and that Ukraine was now looking ahead to pursue membership in the European Union.

title: Steven Pinker: By the Book
description: The author of The Language Instinct, The Blank Slate and, most recently, The Sense of Style: The Thinking Persons Guide to Writing in the 21st Century has never gotten in trouble for reading a book. Just for writing them.

title: Not an August Wilson Kind of Boyhood
description: When Billy Porter was a freshman at Carnegie Mellon University, he took an unusual approach to an essay for a history class. Instead of topic sentences and footnotes, he wrote a short story about a fictional character on a quest that covered the points of the assignment. He no longer remembers the specifics  it was 1987  but he has never forgotten his professors reaction.

title: Text to Text | The Bill of Rights and The Bill of Rights We Deserve
description: The Bill of Rights protects some of our most basic freedoms, such as the right to practice a religion, to assemble peaceably and to speak freely. Sometimes, however, our society seems to prioritize other freedoms not enshrined in the Constitution, such as the right to buy what we want, eat what we want and even binge-watch what we want. These are individual liberties that Sam Apple safeguards in his satirical The Bill of Rights We Deserve, which we pair with the original Bill of Rights in this Text to Text.

title: Eric Cantor, Wall Street Defender, Gone But Not Forgotten
description: There was no great ceremony when Eric Cantor departed Congress for a plush job on Wall Street this month. No need for tearful goodbyes for a politician who failed electorally but morphed into an instant multi-millionaire when a New York investment bank snapped him up as vice chairman.

title: Unseemly Notes
description: Something I didnt know: David Brookss column that, among other things, lamented the failure of the wealthy to follow a code of seemliness was actually part of a broader complaint to that effect among conservative intellectuals. For example, Charles Murrays Coming Apart is mainly about what has gone wrong with working-class values, but he devotes a fair bit of space to the unseemly ostentation of the elite; strange to say, he focuses on Hollywood producers rather than private equity managers, but still.

title: Asymmetric Monetary Risks
description: How much slack is there in the U.S. labor market? Good question. The measured unemployment rate is fairly low, but labor force participation also seems low, and I have doubts about studies purporting to say that its overwhelmingly long-term demographics. Wage gains are still slow. My guess is that theres considerably more slack than the unemployment number might lead you to suspect, but the truth is that I dont know.

title: Ann Demeulemeester: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Fashion Week: The Runway Revisited
description: During February and September 2013, the photographer Jennifer S. Altman followed a group of models as they walked the runway during New York Fashion Week. Here is where they are a year later.

title: A Bit More Cash to Pave the Way for a Clinton Candidacy
description: The super PAC Ready for Hillary plans to convene as many as 400 donors and supporters in Manhattan in November, a last-ditch effort to raise money and lay the groundwork for Hillary Rodham Clintons increasingly likely 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Ebola Epidemic Worsening, Sierra Leone Expands Quarantine Restrictions
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  Acknowledging that the Ebola epidemic sweeping Sierra Leone was worsening, officials here put hundreds of thousands more citizens under quarantine on Thursday, sealing off more than a quarter of the country and warning travelers not to get out of their vehicles in the districts under isolation.

title: Eric Holder Resigns, Setting Up Fight Over Successor
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas announcement on Thursday that Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would leave the administration sets up an election-season scramble for a replacement to carry on Mr. Holders civil rights crusade, wage rhetorical combat with Congress and manage the legal complexities of a presidency increasingly drawn into war with terrorists.

title: Buoyant Dollar Recovers Its Luster, Underlining Rebound in U.S. Economy
description: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | President Obamas handling of the economy may be reviled by his political opponents, but he is receiving support from a surprising quarter: foreign exchange traders.

title: My Fathers A.L.S.
description: When I was in college, my father David started walking with an odd, barely perceptible limp. He was in his mid-40s, a gregarious physician, teacher and researcher who was always upbeat. He told his four kids that he had a back problem  a deliberately vague cover story that I, for one, was willing to believe.

title: Irans President Says Wests Blunders Aided Rise of Islamic State
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Hassan Rouhani of Iran delivered a searing indictment of Western and Arab states on Thursday in his annual speech to the United Nations, blaming them for sowing the seeds of extremism in the Middle East with strategic blunders that have given rise to the Islamic State and other violent jihadist groups.

title: Upper Manhattan Nest for a Mother and Son
description: The Greenwich Village apartment where Laura Martin lived with her son, Dax Roy, couldnt have been more convenient. It was across Sixth Avenue from his elementary school. On school mornings, Ms. Martin would walk Dax across the street and then return home.

title: Paco Rabanne: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Diana Krall Tour and Album Delayed by Illness
description: Suffering from complications of pneumonia, the jazz singer and pianist Diana Krall has decided to postpone the release of a new album, Wallflower, and a United States tour, which was to have begun in Phoenix on Nov. 7. The album, which was scheduled to be released Oct. 21 and will be her 12th studio album, will be delayed until Feb. 3 of next year.

title: 1964 at the U.N.: A Dispute With the Soviets and a Che Guevara Sighting
description: The United Nations General Assembly convened in New York starting this week. Fifty years ago, the Assembly almost didnt meet at all.

title: A Recipe for Air Rage
description: Why do some travelers squabble about overhead bin space? Or feud over an armrest? Why, when a passenger reclines his seat, does another respond with rage befitting the pages of Lord of the Flies?

title: In a Video, Police Chief of Ferguson Apologizes
description: Chief Thomas Jackson of the police force in Ferguson, Mo., issued a stark apology to the family of Michael Brown on Thursday, saying in a videotaped statement that he was sorry for the death of their son and for the four hours that the body of the unarmed 18-year-old lay in the street after he was fatally shot by a police officer.

title: A Favorite Dane at Lincoln Center
description: During his time with the New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein was a champion of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen (1865-1931). He recorded three of Nielsens six symphonies and two of the three concertos with the Philharmonic and won new admirers for Nielsen through his exciting performances.

title: Art-Science Mix, Accelerated
description: Research on the Higgs boson isnt the only work to come out of CERN, the worlds largest particle laboratory, in recent years. In 2011, the organization announced a new program, Collide@CERN, to support collaboration between artists and physicists on its campus in the suburbs of Geneva. The first two recipients of these creative residencies were the Swiss choreographer Gilles Jobin and the German visual artist Julius von Bismarck, who pooled their investigations to create Quantum.

title: Showing a Career, From the Legs Up
description: One of the seasons most eagerly anticipated exhibitions opens Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art: Robert Gober: The Heart Is Not a Metaphor is the first museum retrospective in the United States for the influential, critically acclaimed sculptor and installation artist. Mr. Gober rose to prominence in the 1980s on the strength of sculptures made with scrupulous craftsmanship in the form of old-fashioned, white enameled sinks. Variations on domestic objects like cribs, playpens and dog beds followed. Then came expansive installations like one with a wrap-around, hand-painted mural of a New England forest punctuated by sinks with running water and barred windows affording glimpses of blue sky.

title: Grown Accustomed to Her Phone

title: Big Sound at a Big House

His music is geared for mass events with dizzying lights and bone-rattling sound systems like his marathon Bass Center VIII, which commandeers Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

title: Housewives, Newly Desperate
description: The most intelligent man in contemporary cinema wrote Jean-Luc Godard of the Hollywood director Joseph L. Mankiewicz in 1958. That assessment is borne out by the classic All About Eve (1950) with its great performances and witty, literate dialogue that set the template for the way sophisticated theater people are viewed. But a previous Mankiewicz movie, the lesser-known A Letter to Three Wives (1949), which is being celebrated in a New York Film Festival retrospective, Joseph L. Mankiewicz: The Essential Iconoclast, is just as perfect.

title: I Tried to Make a Search Engine Write Me a Poem
description: Before I started writing this, I took a creativity test. Many different such tests exist, but I took one of the best-known ones: Guilfords Alternative Uses Task, which simply requires that you come up with as many applications for a particular object as possible. I picked a paper coffee cup. After 10minutes (an amount of time Id arbitrarily chosen), I had 39 uses, from the prosaic (hold coffee) to the probably impractical (poke holes in the bottom and it could be a shower head for a short amount of time before it collapses).

description: Anyone who has ever traded in a car to an automobile dealer wonders: Could I have made more money, if Id sold it myself?

description: The announcement Thursday of the resignation of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. touched off questions about his replacement and the timing of any Senate confirmation, given the possibility of a Republican takeover of the Senate in January.

title: Athleisure-Appropriate Hair at Paco Rabanne
description: The clothes have a cool, sporty vibe, so I wanted the models hair to mirror that, said the hair stylist Paul Hanlon backstage at todays Paco Rabanne spring/summer 2015 show. The resulting creation: a low-slung, textural spin on the timeless gym-class ponytail, meant to give the impression of a girl whos just finished her daily run in the park. Shes strong, shes not afraid to get outdoors and really immerse herself in the elements, he explained, gesturing to a few small, glossy strands strewn across the forehead. Before securing lengths with a small black elastic tie, Hanlon added a mist of Toni & Guys Sea Salt Texturising Spray to the ends and worked Toni & Guys Groupie spray wax into the roots to make the hair looked lived in and a little sweaty. The final touch? A quick blast of LOreals classic Elnett, and thats it, he said. Shes good to go.

Mr. Waksal, the former ImClone boss who went to prison for an insider trading scandal that also ensnared Martha Stewart, said on Wednesday that he planned to take his latest venture, Kadmon, public this year. title: No Job, No Money and Now, No Wife
description: Gone Girl, the latest from that dark lord of cinema, David Fincher, opens with a man softly talking about his wifes head. The image of his hand caressing a womans sleek blond hair in close-up indicates that its a lovely head, a lovely wife, too. Yet the violence of his words  he speaks of cracking her skull open and unspooling her brain  wakens an unease that trembles throughout this domestic horror movie. Those familiar with Mr. Finchers work may wonder, perhaps with a shudder or a conspiratorial smile, whether this head will share the fate of another head belonging to another pretty wife, a gift that was boxed and delivered in one of the hellish circles girdling his shocker Seven.

title: 1964: Kenya Battling Somali Rebels
description: GARISSA, Kenya  A few hundred armed fanatics have paralyzed normal life in almost half of Kenya since it attained independence in December. These tough guerrillas are Somalis, bent on forcing the Kenya government to cede to the neighboring Somali Republic the Somali-occupied northeastern part of Kenya in which about 250,000 of their countrymen live. There is no doubt in Nairobi that the Somali government in Mogadishu provided the terrorists with arms, ammunition and other supplies. There are about 800 of these so-called Shifta, operating in small groups of 30 or 40 men.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 26, 1964

title: Revisiting the Original Classics of Surf Cinema
description: Surfing is back in a big way, and with it, a renewed interest in artifacts from the original heyday of surf culture. Early films like Albert Falzons Morning of the Earth (1971) and Crystal Voyager (1974) marked a moment when wholesome 60s representations of surfing (the Beach Boys, Frankie Avalon) gave way to depictions that were entwined with the counterculture. Both films featured exhilarating camerawork (by the surfer George Greenough, also responsible for inventing the modern surfboard fin), heady but mellow psych-rock soundtracks and an underlying message about the sanctity of nature. This month, the boutique imprint Anthology Recordings, part of the influential Mexican Summer label, reissues these two rare film soundtracks on heavyweight wax. And tonight, the label is screening a rare archival print of Morning of the Earth at Anthology Film Archives in New York (no relation to the record label). A song from the soundtrack, Open Up Your Heart by G. Wayne Thomas, plays here with footage from the film.

The free tickets, a program being started with the help of TodayTix, a theater ticket app, will be handed out both through a mobile lottery, which will begin a week before each preview performance, and through lotteries to be held in the lobby of the Public, at Astor Place and Lafayette Street.

title: Nine Publishers to Visit at the New York Art Book Fair
description: Every fall, the galleries of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, a former public school building, return to their roots when the museum is filled with books for the NY Art Book Fair (Sept. 2628, with a preview Sept. 25), an annual event put on by the art book nonprofit Printed Matter. Tens of thousands of visitors mill through the buildings halls, courts and rooms, and the throngs are a testament to the quality of the publications for sale. This years edition, the ninth to date, will feature more than 350 booksellers, antiquarians, artists, institutions and independent publishers from 28 countries, including Estonia, Australia and South Korea. Here, some of the first-time, exclusive and lesser-known vendors not to be missed this year.

description: Alfa Romeo left the United States market in 1995, after a year in which the Italian company sold only 523 cars. For comparison, Ford sells three times that many F-Series trucks every day. Alfa simply couldnt justify the huge investment needed to comply with ever-tighter American safety and emission standards.

title: A Chekhovian Bird of a Different Feather
description: The cast list for Days and Nights, a modern reworking of Chekhovs The Seagull, is so juicy that I approached the movie with lip-smacking expectations of scenery being chewed and spit out with histrionic gusto. Even at its worst, how bad could an updated version of the play be, if actors of the caliber of Allison Janney, William Hurt, Cherry Jones and Mark Rylance had signed on? The answer is worse than you could imagine.

title: New and Old Media Artworks at Museum of Modern Art
description: Life has been busy for Stuart Comer, who arrived in New York from London just a year ago. Not only was he one of the three curators who put together the 2014 Whitney Biennial, but for his day job as the Museum of Modern Arts chief curator of media and performance, he has also been quietly organizing a show that chronicles the evolution of the media arts through the museums recent acquisitions.

title: Every Word Borges Wrote, Writ Large in Brooklyn
description: In his fiction, the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges conceived of such poetic paradoxes as an infinite library, a single point that contains the universe, and a map of an empire at the exact scale of that empire. The artists Daniel Temkin and Rony Maltz have fashioned a clever homage to him in Borges: The Complete Works, part of the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn this weekend. Their piece is a twist on the word search: that staple of elementary school, in which actual words are embedded in a grid of seemingly random characters. Their 135,000-character puzzle (actually two, one for the original Spanish and another in English translation) contains every word Borges ever wrote. It can be reached via the web, where participants can find and circle words, using a keyboard. An image of the word search will be projected onto the Manhattan Bridge, and updated every 30 seconds to reflect newly circled words. Participation is free and open to all.

title: In the Air | Clouds
description: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.

title: The Cairo Geniza, Under Piecemeal Restoration
description: Experts at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan are puzzling over curly bits of ancient paper recovered from a closet in a Cairo synagogue. Boxfuls of the formerly soggy and bug-infested fragments are undergoing delicate repairs and digitization in the hope that the texts can be reunited, at least virtually, with the rest of their manuscript pages, which are scattered at institutions worldwide.
