title: Matthew Warchus Narrates a Scene From Pride
description: The British drama Pride looks at a group of gay and lesbian activists from London who reach out to support a town of miners in Wales during their strike in 1984. In this video, the director, Matthew Warchus, discusses a scene in which the miners hold a dance in their community hall. One of their new supporters, Jonathan (Dominic West), takes to the dance floor to show the locals some moves.

title: Siah Armajani: The Tomb Series
description: Siah Armajani was born in Iran in 1939 and came to the United States in 1960 to attend Macalester College in Minnesota. He settled in Minnesota and has lived there ever since, becoming an American artist of a kind we rarely find anymore: one steeped in Americas pro-democracy literary and philosophical traditions. Much of his work has taken the form of sculptural monuments, some realized on an architectural scale, celebrating historical figures he admires, from Whitman and Thoreau, to John Dewey and Frank OHara.

title: Nights Hero: Who Else?
description: He almost started crying as he drove himself to Yankee Stadium in the afternoon. He had to turn away from his teammates before the game when they presented him with gifts, so overcome was he by the emotion. In the first inning, he said, he barely knew what was happening, and later, in the top of the ninth, his eyes welled with tears to the point that he worried that he might break down in front of the crowd of 48,613.

title: Monika Sosnowska: Tower
description: Monika Sosnowskas Tower, a massive steel sculpture that cuts a 110-foot swath across the main gallery of Hauser & Wirth, is a cautionary symbol of the changes occurring in Chelsea. Officially, its modeled on the framework Mies van der Rohe used for his famed Lake Shore Drive Apartments, with an eye to the impact of the International Style on Soviet-era architecture in Poland, where Ms. Sosnowska was born. But its difficult to look at it without thinking about the luxury condos going up right outside the gallery, along 10th Avenue, or about the way that works of such dehumanizing scale have come to seem banal in this art district.

title: The Terrible Two
description: Jared Bernstein asks why the Fed (and just about all of its counterparts abroad) targets 2 percent inflation. I did some digging on this very issue in my paper for last springs ECB conference, and found that 2 was a convenient round number that seemed to provide a reasonable resolution to the conflict between the price stability crowd and economists worried about the two zeroes.

title: Dan Colen: Miracle Paintings
description: Dan Colen has dialed back the artistic swagger endemic to his 2010 debut with the Gagosian Gallery. Hes sized down the gallerys big box space by about two-thirds  which should become a trend. Gone is the heavily ironic stance. Ditto the huge paintings festooned with swaths of chewing gum in lieu of brush strokes; trompe loeil canvases seemingly drizzled with confetti that conjure 1970s Lyrical Abstraction; and ostentatious ready-mades, including an inverted halfpipe and customized motorcycles tipped over like dominoes.

title: Obama Can Still Earn His Nobel
description: You remember 2009 and the glow from Oslo  Barack Obama, Nobel Peace Prize winner. Wow. Less than a year into his presidency, he joined an elite group: Nelson Mandela, Lech Walesa, Martin Luther King Jr., Mother Teresa, the Dalai Lama. And for what? As near as anybody could tell, it was the only Nobel ever given for future good intentions.

title: For the Aged, a Shrinking World
description: THE LITTLE BEDROOM

title: Tourists Urged to Avoid Ebola Zone in West Africa
description: The Ebola outbreak has gripped broad swaths of West Africa, reaching Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Nigeria and Senegal.

title: Lanvin: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Jim Shaw: I Only Wanted You to Love Me
description: The uncannily imaginative Los Angeles painter and sculptor Jim Shaw has what the Romantic poet John Keats called negative capability: the ability to be in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact and reason. He also has exceptional drawing skills, an expansive sense of humor, an acute moral compass and a connoisseurial eye for weird kitsch.

title: As Bubba Watson Leads U.S. Charge at Ryder Cup, the Question Is to Where
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland  Bubba Watson will have on the same pants, shirt and sweater combinations worn by his American teammates in this weeks Ryder Cup, but do not be fooled. The coordinated outfits cannot hide the plated suit of armor Watson wears to protect himself from expectations, scrutiny and rejection.

title: Recognizing a Vibrant Underground
description: In 1962 the film critic Manny Farber published the provocative essay White Elephant Art and Termite Art, in which he distinguished two types of artists: the White Elephant artist, who tries to create masterpieces equal to the greatest artworks of the past, and the Termite, who engages in a kind of squandering-beaverish endeavor that goes always forward, eating its own boundaries and, likely as not, leaves nothing in its path other than signs of eager, industrious, unkempt activity.

title: Alcohol and Excess During Thanksgiving Break
description: NOT COOL

title: A Stars Wonderland of Space, Nature and Song
description: BJRK

title: An Eggplant Parmigiana Recipe to Match Cornas
description: Summer turns gloriously Indian. Some of the harvest lingers, notably eggplant and the last of the zucchini, so its not too late to present Jonathan Bennos handsomely made eggplant and squash alla parmigiana. And as this hearty baked vegetable dish suits the season, so does a sturdy red wine like Cornas, a regal expression of the complexity, dark fruit and spice of the syrah grape. Assembling the dish takes time. A wine that can age beautifully for decades deserves the effort. The eggplant can be prepared in advance and reheated. Serve it with grilled lamb chops strewn with black pepper, or by itself as a first course.  FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: On a Bloody Road Trip to Exorcise a Demon
description: ASMODEXIA

title: 104-Year-Old Portal Bridge Presents $900 Million Problem for Rail Commuters
description: It carries more passenger trains than any other railroad bridge in the Western Hemisphere, yet few people beyond those who rely on it have heard of it. It goes largely unnoticed, unless something goes wrong, which happens with irritating frequency. After all, the bridge is 104 years old.

title: A Tiny Emissary From the Ancient Past
Cornas Is No Country Bumpkin
description: Of all the elements that go into producing great wine, one of the most crucial is also one of the most overlooked, except by those who provide it: sweat.

title: A Malevolent Consort, Utterly in Command
description: For months, there had been so much buzz over how Anna Netrebko would fare this season when she sang Lady Macbeth for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, you would have thought that she was a highly anticipated newcomer rather than a house favorite who had sung there 134 times since 2002.

title: What Becomes a Woman Most?
description: I saw all these incredibly dressed older women on the streets, says Ari Seth Cohen, a photographer who recalls being very close to his grandmothers. His photos inspired a blog, a book and now a documentary, Advanced Style. Simon Doonan, the fashion pundit, calls Mr. Cohens concept quite anarchic, so it must be fabulous.

title: A Stubborn Mother and Her Supplicant
description: The lachrymose British drama Lilting pivots on the prickly relationship between two people who are mourning a third. Junn (Cheng Pei Pei) is a Cambodian-Chinese woman who cant understand English, and Richard (Ben Whishaw) is a plaster saint who struggles and struggles to be understood. With infinite patience, moist eyes and trembling lips and lashes, Richard attempts to overcome the differences  linguistic, cultural, generational and temperamental  between him and Junn, who doesnt grasp that he also loved her dead son, Kai (Andrew Leung).

title: Ad Attacks Skinny-Dipping Congressman
description: A new ad from Kelly Kultala, a Democrat running for Congress in Kansas, fleshes out the issues facing the state while also criticizing her opponent for some high jinks on an overseas congressional trip.

title: A Brothers Betrayal, in Darkly Comic Tones
description: Abner Roth (Michael D. Cohen) has a birthday tradition: Every year, he and his brother, Tom (Aaron Abrams), go to see On the Waterfront at the Fox Theater in Toronto. (You presume that the movie house knows to program that film every year.) Like Marlon Brandos character, Abner feels the sting of his brothers betrayal. The day he turns 40, Abner learns that Tom is dating the love of Abners life, Madeleine (Anna Hopkins).

title: Who Speaks for Dying Patients?
France Proposes Tough Antismoking Measures
description: PARIS  The French government on Thursday announced a plan to curb smoking that would introduce plain packaging for cigarettes, ban smoking on playgrounds and make it harder to use electronic cigarettes in certain public settings.

title: Playing at the New York Film Festival
description: Images of films in the New York Film Festival.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Trailer: New York Film Festival
description: A preview of films playing in the 52nd New York Film Festival.

title: A Four-Work Leap Into the Forefront of Classical Ballet
description: On Wednesday evening, New York City Ballet, in a quadruple bill of works choreographed to Tchaikovsky music by its co-founder George Balanchine, and plunging its audience into the quintessence of classical ballet, strongly suggested that it has again become the worlds foremost ballet company. And perhaps the best news is that the troupes orchestra, led on this occasion by Clotilde Otranto, played the Tchaikovsky scores with a greater tonal beauty and eloquence of phrasing than I have heard from it. These scores are familiar, but the evening had moments when phrases seized the heart anew.

title: A Music Lover Down to His Roots
description: THIS AINT NO MOUSE MUSIC!

title: With a Loss, the Mets Are Guaranteed a Losing Record for the Sixth Straight Season
description: Someday, the Mets will finish above .500 again. But not this year. Instead, their 3-0 loss to the Washington Nationals on Thursday night, in the second game of a doubleheader, guaranteed that they would end with a losing record for the sixth straight season.

title: Lessons by a Master and Teacher
description: Steve Coleman began his early set at the Stone on Tuesday night with bright, slow, clear, solo alto-saxophone lines. They were rhythmic and unresolving, dealt out mostly in short or modest-length notes, and sounded like a teacher giving a demonstration.

title: Frieze Art Fair Founders Step Aside for a New Director
description: LONDON  In a surprise move, Frieze art fair announced on Thursday that in 2015 Victoria Siddall will become director of Frieze London and Frieze New York.

title: Grab Some Popcorn, Settle Down, Start Debating
description: Each of the worlds major film festivals has a special flavor and purpose. Some arrange the crown jewels of world cinema in a fancy European setting. Others line up horses for the Oscar race or parade indie darlings through the snow. The New York Film Festival, whose 52nd edition begins on Friday, takes its name and inspiration from the world capital of talk, and its clear and consistent ambition has been to start as many arguments as possible.

title: You Can Make It Here, You Can Make It Anywhere
description: PRINT THE LEGEND

title: When Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Mortgage rates have remained relatively low this year, and little changed, despite previous predictions of an inevitable rise. Borrowers, though, may be wondering how much longer this environment can last.

title: The Dismal Science
description: The economics profession has not, to say the least, covered itself in glory these past six years. Hardly any economists predicted the 2008 crisis  and the handful who did tended to be people who also predicted crises that didnt happen. More significant, many and arguably most economists were claiming, right up to the moment of collapse, that nothing like this could even happen.

title: A Radical Response
description: Martin Wolf is as grand and important as an economic journalist can ever become. A respected economist in his own right, Wolf has had top-level access to economic policy makers for decades now, seeing generations of finance ministers and central bank governors come and go. All of them care, deeply, about what he thinks and what he writes, and they tend to spend as much time as they can trying to persuade him of their point of view. The result is a classic virtuous cycle: Hes well informed because hes extremely influential, and hes influential because hes extremely well informed.

title: At Carven, Snakeskin Mary Janes With a Racing Stripe
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: A Titan of Blues, Folk and Rock
description: HARLEM STREET SINGER

title: Attention Must Be Paid
description: Reggie Shaw is the man responsible for the most moving portion of From One Second to the Next, the director Werner Herzogs excruciating (even by Werner Herzog standards) 35-minute public service announcement, released last year as part of AT&Ts It Can Wait campaign against texting and driving. In the film, Shaw, now in his 20s, recounts the rainy morning in September 2006 that he crossed the line of a Utah highway, knocking into a car containing two scientists, James Furfaro and Keith ODell, who were heading to work nearby. Both men were killed. Shaw says he was texting a girlfriend at the time, adding in unmistakable anguish that he cant even remember what he was texting about. He is next seen taking part in something almost inconceivable: He enters the scene where one of the dead mens daughters is being interviewed, and receives from that woman a warm, earnest, tearful, cathartic hug.

title: A Tour Guide Goes Above and Beyond
description: Its hard to read the first exchange of looks that sets The Two Faces of January down its satisfying, shivering path. The vacationing American tourist, Chester MacFarland (Viggo Mortensen), is walking around the Acropolis with his wife, Colette (Kirsten Dunst), when he notices the other man observing him. Its a glorious day, and the Americans are, true to the early 1960s time frame and their station, formally attired. Shes wearing a dress and hat, and carrying gloves and a purse. Hes wearing a tie, a three-piece suit, a straw hat and a pair of very dark glasses.

title: No Pain, No Game
description: The libertine, wrote Simone de Beauvoir, in hurting the object that serves him, tastes all the pleasures which a vigorous individual feels in making full use of his strength; he dominates, he is a tyrant.  She was quoting, indirectly and then directly, the Marquis de Sade.

title: A Visionarys Mark Is Still Being Seen
description: Ignore the cheeky title, with its official hashtag (#WWMWD). What Would Mrs. Webb Do? A Founders Vision, at the Museum of Arts and Design, is a traditional and slightly stuffy complement to the manic, over-designed exhibition Makers, in the last few weeks of its run on two other floors of the museum.

title: Recapturing the Spirit of That California Sound
description: If you attended Rita Wilsons opening night show at the Caf Carlyle on Wednesday evening and closed your eyes at certain moments you could imagine you were cruising down a Southern California highway in the early 1970s. Sandwiched between the music of Joni Mitchell and Jackson Browne on the car radio was a promising new voice whose sound fit right in with theirs. Maybe that voice wasnt as strong or as distinctive but it embodied the laid-back (pardon the vintage slang) spirit of soft rock from lotus land at a moment when the California dream still beckoned like a mirage.

title: Tubercular or Penniless, Theyll Always Have Paris
description: The Metropolitan Operas production of La Bohme, Puccinis masterpiece of emotional manipulation, is like any institution: it transcends the people, good or bad, who move through it. Before this seasons revival closes in January, the show, originally staged in 1981 by Franco Zeffirelli, will have gone through at least five cast configurations, and its teeming and colorful enough to survive any and all of them.

title: A Potential Disaster in Any Language
description: Hes a modern-day Noah, looking to ride out the next great flood in an ark made of rotting plastic. Small balloons tethered to his jacket float jauntily above his head as he applies for a loan to build the boat. Turned down, he vows to go straight to the people.

title: Ferguson Police Chiefs Sad Excuse for an Apology
description: It took four hours for the police in Ferguson, Mo., to remove the body of Michael Brown, the unarmed teenager killed by a police officer, from the street where it lay. It took the police chief nearly seven weeks to issue an apology to Mr. Browns family. His videotaped comment was late, oddly staged and very unclear about what exactly he was apologizing for and why (apart from perhaps a desire to keep his job).

title: The Pleasure of Being a Difficult Woman
description: On a recent morning in the backyard of a Brooklyn coffee shop, the British actress Romola Garai apologized, sincerely and often  for repeating herself, for liking poetry, for criticizing sexism in the entertainment industry. Sorry, she said. This is so boring.

title: A Prodigal Son of Jazz Returns to Pay a Visit
description: Wow, its been so long since Ive been in this place, the pianist Kirk Lightsey said after taking the stage at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. Surveying the room, he chortled, wearing a look of beatific astonishment. He introduced the members of his quartet, and then restated the obvious: Im so happy to be back in town; Im just giddy.

title: Masters of Charity (and Deception)
description: BELIEVE ME

title: Punch Lines, Reverberating in the Ruins
description: Some 20 years ago, whenever the self-styled King of Simon Says (a.k.a. Allan Tresser) performed in the Catskills, he would display a pasteboard panel boasting of his television credits: As seen on The Jack Paar Show! And Wonderama! And ... well, I forget the rest, but not the idea: The kings prime was decades past. And the billing presumed a similar vintage for his listeners as they prepared to obey whatever Simon Says  or doesnt. But if Mr. Tresser had long since peaked, hadnt the Fallsview Hotel of Ellenville, N.Y., in which he was resident tummler, also seen far better years? And the Nevele? And Kutshers? The last was celebrated in an elegiac 2012 documentary, Welcome to Kutshers: The Last Catskills Resort, which is being updated in December with a final section chronicling the hotels demolition to make way for a yoga retreat. In the 1980s, when films like Dirty Dancing or Sweet Lorraine were set in such hotels, they were already relics from another era.

title: Interview: John Ridley
description: The writer and director John Ridley discusses his film Jimi: All Is By My Side.

title: Looking for Comedy In All the Wrong Places
description: In the underground theater of the Abrons Arts Center on Wednesday, all the right ingredients seemed to have been assembled for an evening of fun and maybe of magic. There was a fog machine, a wind machine, a rack of outr clothing. There were two microphones, two laptops stocked with music. Most important, there were two performers experienced in the risk-taking of improvisation.

title: The Year When the Guitar Licks Ignited
description: A kaleidoscopic, impressionistic portrait of the artist as a far-out genius, Jimi: All Is by My Side doesnt profess to be either the first or last word on James Marshall Hendrix. Rather, it looks at the year he went from discovery to detonation. It happened fast: In 1966, Hendrix  played with dreamy reserve here by Andr Benjamin, a.k.a. Andr 3000 of Outkast  was a cool cat who was calling himself Jimmy James and playing with Curtis Knight and the Squires, an R&B band. The following year he was off to London, where after changing his name and threads, he emerged as the star child Jimi Hendrix.

title: A Career of Toasting Rebellions
description: PHILADELPHIA  Queer is here to stay. So are feminism, art history, unruly flesh, anarchic laughter and painting. Youll find them all in Dear Nemesis, Nicole Eisenman 1993-2013, at the Institute of Contemporary Art here, a spicy and tightly edited midcareer survey of one of the most interesting New York artists to come out of the 1990s.

title: Sharing a Sofa With Dinosaurs
description: GETTING from here to there can be hard enough. But it has taken Richard McGuire 25 years to do something even more complicated: get from here to here.

title: The Story Behind Manhattans Original Fine-Dining Chinese Restaurant
description: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out whats new with the people behind them.

title: Theater Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Chrysler Recalls 349,000 Vehicles for Faulty Ignition Switch
description: Chrysler announced on Thursday that it would recall 349,442 vehicles worldwide for faulty ignition switches that could cause cars to suddenly turn off while driving, adding to the recent wave of automobile recalls related to ignition problems.

title: Underground Folk, Foraging for a Home
description: In The Boxtrolls, old-fashioned stop-motion animation is combined with new-style 3-D cinematography to charming effect. The film, based on the book Here Be Monsters! by Alan Snow, tells a familiar story with familiar themes and characters  misunderstood monsters; a repulsive villain with comical henchmen; a hero with an identity crisis  but it does so with refreshing wit and energy. At times it might be a little dark and scary for the very youngest viewers, but their slightly older siblings are likely to appreciate the way this movie balances the silly and the sinister, the creepy and the cute, the nasty and the nice. Adults may also find themselves amused. This one did, at any rate.

title: Made in the U.S.A., but Banked Overseas
description: Imagine how frustrating it would be to have billions of dollars in cash but be unable to spend it as you wish unless you paid a large part to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Movie Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: The Medieval Festival

title: Finding Humane Care at the End of Life
Spare Times for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Chile Pepper Festival and Harvest Festival (Saturday) This 22nd annual celebration of the sweet and sassy capsicums at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is a sure sign that harvest time is here. Red, yellow and green beauties are the stars, along with the spicy chocolates and hot sauces in which they appear. Tasting is encouraged, as well as listening to music ranging from Cajun tunes to Latin American dance rhythms.

title: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
description: 80 YEARS AGO

title: Heroically Handy With a Corkscrew
description: Perhaps the best thing about The Equalizer is how long it takes to reveal what everyone watching it knows from the start. Directed by Antoine Fuqua and starring Denzel Washington, the movie was inspired by a 1980s television series about an elite C.I.A. assassin (played by Edward Woodward) who found a second career as a freelance vigilante, specializing in payback and in pre-emptive violence in defense of the innocent. Each bit of information in the previous sentence  to say nothing of the trailers and advertisements  is a clue that Mr. Washingtons character, Robert McCall, is not the bookish, solitary Boston guy he at first seems to be.

title: A Side Dish of Confusion in Board Fight at Darden Restaurants
description: The fierce battle for control of the board of Darden Restaurants heated up on Thursday, while also gaining an element of confusion.

title: How Does Islam Relate to Christianity and Judaism?
description: This is the 11th in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Sajjad Rizvi, a professor of Arab and Islamic studies at the University of Exeter and the author of Mulla Sadra and the Later Islamic Philosophical Tradition.

title: Pop Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Teaching Parents to Help Stop the Summer Slide
description: Last summer was the second one Tayonna Taylor, an incoming second-grader, spent working with a reading tutor: her mother. Tayonna, who wears glasses and had the sniffles, sat with her mother, Tasia Carlton, in late July in Emily Roggies classroom in Wissahickon Charter School in northwest Philadelphia.

title: Sequoia Capital Returns to Investing in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Sequoia Capital, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, is bringing money back to Brazil.

title: Jazz Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Cause Unites Unlikely Partners in South Wales
description: The classic union anthem Solidarity Forever, sung by Pete Seeger, introduces Pride, a stirring film about the uneasy coalition of British mineworkers and gay and lesbian activists during a labor strike in the mid-1980s. Directed by Matthew Warchus (Matilda the Musical), it is the kind of hearty, blunt-force drama with softened edges that leaves audiences applauding and teary-eyed.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
description: Art

title: Gay Africans Seeking Asylum in Brooklyn
description: Gay men have fled Nigeria and sought asylum in the United States, settling into a Brooklyn residence where they seek to live freely and openly.

title: Politics Helpline: History Between White House Intruder and Secret Service
description: As part of our ongoing political helpline, were taking questions and answering them as fast as we can. A reader asked:

title: Pakistan: Police Investigator Survives Attack in Karachi
description: A senior police investigator survived an assassination attempt on Thursday in Karachi after a bomb hit his convoy, police officials said. The investigator, Farooq Awan, a senior superintendent who leads a unit that tracks terrorists and militants, was wounded, as were seven other people, and a civilian passer-by was killed. Police officials said that according to an initial investigation, a vehicle filled with explosives was detonated by remote control as the convoy passed. Jundullah, a militant group that operates mostly in Karachi, claimed responsibility, according to local news media reports.Mr. Awan has been involved in the arrests of several high-profile militants, including Omar Saeed Sheikh, who was convicted in the 2002 killing of Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal correspondent.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Sept. 26
description: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes scenes from the Peoples Climate March and the United Nations.

title: One Small-Timer Finds His Posse
description: HELLAWARE

title: France Asks Veto Wielders to Stay Their Hands
description: Each of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council has always had a diplomatic weapon as powerful as the thunderbolt of Zeus: a veto over any measure it doesnt like. The most common targets are draft resolutions that threaten the members national interests or those of its most vital allies.

title: Eric Holder to Step Down
description: Eric H. Holder Jr., the first African-American to serve as United States attorney general, announced his resignation in a ceremony at the White House.

title: This Weeks Movies | Sept. 26, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review The Equalizer, The Boxtrolls and Gone Girl.

title: Parliament in Indonesia Rolls Back Election Rights
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias outgoing Parliament unexpectedly passed legislation early Friday eliminating direct elections for provincial governors, district chiefs and mayors, a move denounced by critics as a major setback for the countrys democratic transition and a naked power grab by its wounded political elite.

title: Clip: Hellaware
description: A scene from the film.

title: Drone Exemptions for Hollywood Pave the Way for Widespread Use
description: LOS ANGELES  The commercial use of drones in American skies took a leap forward on Thursday with the help of Hollywood.

title: A Call to Action Against a Predator Fish With an Import Ban, an App and Even Rodeos
description: MIAMI  They eat anything that fits in their mouths. They reproduce copiously and adapt effortlessly. And they have become as ubiquitous and pesky as rats  only prettier and more conniving.

title: Woman Hides Camera to Reveal Life Under Islamic State Rule
description: Before an American-led coalition launched airstrikes on Islamic State militants in the Syrian city of Raqqa this week, a female student there documented life under Islamist rule by concealing a video camera in the folds of the full-length cloak she has been compelled to wear since the fundamentalists seized control.

title: With Whimsy, Burts Bees Introduces Its First TV Campaign
description: LIP balms, as the names of some of the older products in the category make clear, were historically marketed to treat ailments: ChapStick, introduced around 1912, was for chapping, and Blistex, introduced in 1947, was for blisters and sores.

title: As Era Ends, Derek Jeters Fans Fill the Seats, No Matter the Cost
description: Being a baseball fan is like going on a diet or practicing politics: There are several different levels of extremity.

title: U.S. Music Sales Drop 5%, as Habits Shift Online
description: As the music industry evolves, there has been no doubt that online streaming services like Spotify, Pandora and YouTube are growing fast, and generating more revenue for artists and record companies.

title: In Chile, an Animal Whose Numbers Please No One
description: CERRO SOMBRERO, Chile  The guidebooks for Tierra del Fuego somehow fail to mention the gunfire.

title: Francis Removes Bishop Under Cloud in Paraguay
description: ROME  In another sign of his willingness to exert discipline in the church hierarchy, Pope Francis removed a conservative bishop in Paraguay on Thursday who was seen as a renegade by his fellow bishops and had sheltered a priest accused of molesting seminarians in several countries.

title: Man Faces Second Trial in Killing of Florida Teenager
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Nearly eight months after a jury here deadlocked over his guilt in the killing of an unarmed teenager, Michael Dunn faced a second set of jurors on Thursday who will decide whether he fired a gun in self-defense or murdered the teenager during a dispute over loud rap music booming from a parked car.

title: The Show-Off Society
description: Liberals talk about circumstances; conservatives talk about character.

title: A Murky Process Yields Cleaner Professional Records for Stockbrokers
description: As a former stockbroker whose regulatory file included 41 customer complaints and a job termination, Kathleen J. Tarr was concerned that her reputation had been hurt by accusations that she had disputed. So, like an increasing number of brokers, she sought to have some negative information expunged from her record.

title: Eric Holders Legacy
description: By any measure, the nearly-six-year tenure of Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. has been one of the most consequential in United States history. His decision to resign, which he announced on Thursday, was long anticipated; he has said he will stay on through his successors confirmation. It is hard to imagine that anyone who could make it through the current Senate would have an impact comparable to Mr. Holders.

title: Yahoo Faces Moment of Decision, Again
description: Yahoo, more than any other investor, should have benefited from the public market debut last week of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant.

title: Outbreak of a Respiratory Illness Escalates Among Children and Mystifies Scientists
description: An outbreak of respiratory illness first observed in the Midwest has spread to 38 states, sending children to hospitals and baffling scientists trying to understand its virulent resurgence.

title: Locker Room Cultivates a Reluctance to Criticize
description: As doping grew pervasive in cycling in recent decades, riders banded together and protected one another, even as laws were broken. The omerta permeated baseball, too, when players rarely grumbled publicly about their peers use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Clashing Goals in Syria Strikes Bedevil Obama
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Obama said the American-led airstrikes in Syria were intended to punish the terror organizations that threatened the United States  but would do nothing to aid President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who is at war with the same groups.

title: Detroits Leaders Regain Some Power
description: CHICAGO  The mayor and City Council of Detroit regained most of their decision-making authority on Thursday, a symbolic milestone in a financially beleaguered city that cleared the way for an end to nearly 18 tense months of oversight by a state-appointed emergency manager.

title: Militant in Beheading Videos Has Been Identified, F.B.I. Chief Says
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence agencies believe they have identified the Islamic State militant who appeared on two videotapes in which American journalists were beheaded, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said Thursday, but he declined to name the man while agents from the United States and Britain were searching for him.

title: The Good Order
description: When she was writing, Maya Angelou would get up every morning at 5:30 and have coffee at 6. At 6:30, she would go off to a hotel room she kept  a small modest room with nothing but a bed, desk, Bible, dictionary, deck of cards and bottle of sherry. She would arrive at the room at 7 a.m. and write until 12:30 p.m. or 2 oclock.

title: Events in New Jersey for Sept. 28-Oct. 4, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: N.F.L. Examines Its Record on Hiring of Women in Wake of Ray Rice Case
description: When N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was asked last week whether any women had helped him decide to suspend the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice two games for punching his then-fiance, he sheepishly said no.

title: Facebook Lawsuit Over Search Warrants Can Proceed, a Court in Manhattan Rules
description: An appeals court ruled on Thursday that a lawsuit filed by Facebook against the Manhattan district attorneys office can proceed, paving the way for oral arguments over whether prosecutors violated the constitutional rights of 381 users by obtaining search warrants for nearly everything in their files.

title: A Step Closer to Banning Landmines
description: Anti-personnel landmines have been repudiated for the heavy toll they take on civilians and the lingering threat that buried munitions pose long after hostilities have ceased. Yet, the United States is among the few countries that have not signed a 1997 treaty banning their use.

title: Solar Company and Bronx College Plan a Technology Hub
description: It has lit up the Budweiser warehouse in Hunts Point with solar energy, helped thousands of homeowners cut their electricity bills, and designed a 12-acre solar field on top of a closed landfill in Rockland County to power nearby towns.

title: Events on Long Island for Sept. 28-Oct. 4, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Fostering National Identity but Not Nationalism

title: In U.N. Talk, Japan Leader Makes Pitch to Neighbors
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan sought on Thursday to counter the deep-seated anger among some other Asia-Pacific countries over his governments militaristic shift, using a visit to the United Nations to denounce war culture and express a desire to improve relations with Japans neighbors, in particular China and South Korea, where memories of Japanese wartime atrocities are never far from the surface.

description: The N.F.L.s chief of security denied Thursday that he had received a copy of a video that showed the former Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice knocking out his then-fiance in an elevator in Atlantic City.

description: A small number of young immigrants who grew up in the United States without legal status will be allowed to join the military and have a fast-track pathway to citizenship, Pentagon officials announced Thursday, the first time those young people have been able to enlist.

He was 91 last year when he told the story again, propped in a wheelchair in the rehabilitation unit of a nursing home where it seemed as though age and infirmity had put a different kind of price on his head.

title: With Climbing Graduation Rates Come Renewed Doubts
description: AUSTIN  A decade ago, Texas was often cited as an example of the ills that contributed to a national high school graduation crisis. As the state weathered scandals over the way some districts calculated graduation rates, it became identified in national reports as the epicenter for chronically underperforming schools known as dropout factories.

title: On the Border, Military Gear Inspires a Mix of Reactions
description: EL PASO  A federal program that transfers surplus military equipment to local communities  and is under review by the Obama administration  is drawing mixed reactions from border officials whose regions have benefited from the initiative.

title: Derek Stepan and Rangers Upbeat Despite Injury
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers were philosophical Thursday about the top-line center Derek Stepans fractured left fibula, which he sustained during conditioning drills the previous day. There were no long faces, even from Stepan.

title: Obama Expands Marine Preserve in Pacific, Making It Worlds Largest
description: President Obama on Thursday signed a proclamation expanding a protected marine reserve in the Pacific Ocean, putting a total of 370,000 square nautical miles off limits to commercial fishing. The designation makes the Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument six times larger than it was and will protect the coral reefs and unique marine ecosystems threatened by fishing and the effects of climate change. Mr. Obamas action creates the largest marine reserve in the world and builds on his efforts to deal with environmental issues through executive action in the face of stiff Republican opposition in Congress.

title: Report of Islamic State Terror Threat to Subways Met With Doubt
description: The assertion by Iraqs prime minister that his government had gathered intelligence indicating that the Islamic State was planning to attack targets in Europe and the United States, including subways, was greeted with some skepticism by American intelligence officials on Thursday.

title: Farewell to a Fellow Officer
description: Members of the New York Police Department turned out in force on Thursday for the funeral of Officer Michael Williams in LaGrangeville, N.Y. Mr. Williams, a 25-year-old rookie officer, died on Sunday when a Police Department van crashed in the Bronx.

title: Christopher Hogwood, Early-Music Devotee, Dies at 73
description: Christopher Hogwood, whose Academy of Ancient Music was a key ensemble in the period-instrument movement, striving to perform early music as the composer intended and as audiences were first presumed to have heard it, died on Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 73.

title: J. California Cooper, Award-Winning Writer, Dies at 82
description: J. California Cooper, an award-winning writer whose black female characters confront a world of indifference and betrayal, but find kinship there in unexpected places, died on Saturday in Seattle. She was 82.

title: John Slattery, a Longtime TV Newsman, Dies at 63
description: John Slattery, a television newsman who reported on New York City and its environs for 35 years, covering stories from petty crimes to the destruction of the World Trade Center towers, died late Wednesday or early Thursday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 63.

title: Alastair Reid, a Restless Poet and Essayist, Is Dead at 88
description: Alastair Reid, a Scottish-born, insistently peripatetic poet, translator and essayist who wrote of far-flung places (among other things) for The New Yorker over more than half a century, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 88.

description: Brussels-based designers Jorge Almada and Anne-Marie Midy couldnt help but return to the remote beauty of his childhood home in the Sonoran desert to stake a claim of their own.

title: The Brains and Braun of Dieter Rams
description: Chances are if youve shaved with an electric razor, blow-dried your hair or sparked up a cigarette in the past 60 years, you owe a debt of gratitude to Dieter Rams. During his four-plus decades working for Braun, many of which he also spent creating furniture for the British company Vitsoe, the German designer, 82, made a staggering number of stripped-down home goods and gadgets, many of which are as relevant now as the day they were conceived. Case in point: The same modular 606 Universal Shelving System bought in 1960 can still be seamlessly added to today and is as coveted by design aficionados as ever. But it is his ability to both inspire and confound successors like Jasper Morrison and Apples Jonathan Ive  spurred on by his prophetic principles of good design  that may be his greatest legacy. Describing Ramss humble CSV 12 amplifier rotary switch in the foreword to the book Dieter Rams: As Little Design as Possible, Ive writes, It could not be better, simpler, clearer or more beautiful. In other words, less, but so much more.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET IN CONCERT WITH THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC Live From Lincoln Center kicks off its 40th-anniversary season with Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheelers musical thriller, starring the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel as the bloodthirsty barber and the British actress Emma Thompson as the adoring pie maker Mrs. Lovett. There are trade-offs in seeing Sweeney Todd in concert, of course, Charles Isherwood wrote in The New York Times about this production, conducted by Alan Gilbert. The plots intricate comings and goings are not easy to delineate clearly, and the horrific action is impossible without a full stage of scenery. But the upside to seeing (or rather, hearing) Sweeney played by a world-class orchestra made up for such awkwardness, he added. Mr. Sondheims score seems to grow more majestic each time you hear it (and more boisterous with raucous good-bad spirits), and the forward thrust of the drama as it reels into nightmare territory remains a model of musical theater writing. Johnny Depp takes on the title role and Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett in Tim Burtons film version, at 1:45 p.m. on IFC.

title: Support for Full Cost Scholarships at South Carolina
description: South Carolina announced Thursday that it would guarantee four-year scholarships for football and mens basketball players and would offer students getting full scholarships the full cost of attendance, an amount several thousand dollars higher than a current scholarship, should the N.C.A.A. make that permissible.

title: U.S. Court Issues Summons to Modi in Lawsuit Over 2002 Riots

That means a height of 160 to 175 centimeters (5-foot-3 to 5-foot-9) for women and 170 to 185 centimeters (5-foot-7 to 6 feet) for men.

title: Morning Agenda: Yahoos Decision Point
description: YAHOOS DECISION POINT | Whats next for Yahoo? After it sold shares worth $6 billion after taxes in the Alibaba Group, which went public last week, the once-mighty Internet giant is at a crossroad, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles write. Yahoo could use the proceeds from the Alibaba share sale to go on an acquisition spree to help reinvent itself and regain relevance. But the companys previous takeover efforts have yielded few obvious gains, leaving shareholders more eager to receive the bulk of the cash rather than see it used for acquisitions.

title: Pynchons Cameo, and Other Surrealities
description: Halfway through a long lunch at Tavern on the Green on a sunny September day, the trim, tanned filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson, dressed in a Southern California beach bums uniform  Quiksilver shorts, faded blue T-shirt, crumpled white bucket hat  went silent. Mr. Anderson, 44, had been asked a simple question: Does Thomas Pynchon, the reclusive author of Gravitys Rainbow, Mason & Dixon and The Crying of Lot 49, make an on-screen cameo in Mr. Andersons Inherent Vice, the first movie adapted from one of the writers celebrated novels?

title: Something in Common With His Mentor
description: Dear Justin, an elderly man recites, challenges are a part of life, as you know. Your mind is a powerful asset. Use it for positive thoughts and youll learn what I learned. I believe in your talents and I believe in you.

title: No Longer Lost, Hes Taking the Lead
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  By the age of 14, Ger Duany had wandered barefoot for hundreds of miles through his native Sudan, spent four years in Ethiopian refugee camps and fought as a child soldier. On one occasion, he walked for so long that all his toenails fell off; on another, he fled from soldiers by swimming across a river choked with corpses. But Mr. Duany, one of thousands of so-called Lost Boys left homeless by a Sudanese civil war that began in the 1980s, isnt one to complain.

title: They Say Goodbye. We Say Hello.
description: Some movies are born significant, some achieve significance, and some have significance thrust upon them  not always in the way their makers would have wished. An intended lament for the death of the hippie, The Big Chill (1983), directed and written (with Barbara Benedek) by Lawrence Kasdan, celebrated the birth of the yuppie instead.

title: Bollywood Is Prancing Far Abroad
description: MUMBAI  Shah Rukh Khan has many titles.The 48-year-old Bollywood superstar is known as King Khan, King of Bollywood and Bollywood Badshah (or emperor). This summer Mr. Khan became a knight. In a glittering ceremony in Mumbai, the French foreign affairs minister, Laurent Fabius, conferred Frances highest civilian honor  the Knight of the Legion of Honor  on Mr. Khan. In the official news release, Mr. Fabius said, The French people hail Shah Rukh Khans talent and generosity, which transcend cultural and historical differences.

title: Lykke Li on U2, Heartbreak and Washing Her Undies
description: Since bursting on the scene with her 2008 album Youth Novels, the Swedish chanteuse Lykke Li has carved out a niche with her mix of pulsating beats, hypnotic rhythms and coquettish vocals. But 2014 is serving as a banner year for the 28-year-old. In May, she released her third album, I Never Learn, which spawned the hit singles No Rest for the Wicked and Gunshot (a remix of which, by the Swedish producer Chords, premieres here). She also just kicked off a nationwide tour (which hits Radio City Music Hall on October 4) and is gearing up for an upcoming collaboration with the Swedish clothing line & Other Stories, which opens its first stateside store next month in SoHo. Here, Li talks about I Never Learn, appearing on U2s new album and personal hygiene.

title: A Museum Is in Aspen, but Not of It
description: Aspen, Colo.  The trend in boutique museum building reached a chilly, sun-gilded peak a few years ago and has leveled out, at least in the United States. These days we mostly get unsexy makeovers and add-ons, and the critical conversation has moved on. Still, celebrity commissions appear. A Renzo Piano-designed satellite for the Whitney Museum of American Art is underway in Lower Manhattan. And last month, a new home for the Aspen Art Museum designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban, winner of the 2014 Pritzker Prize, made its debut here.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Republicans Rally Base at Values Summit
description: There is a lot of conservative star power shining out of the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington on Friday morning. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Sarah Palin are just a few of the Republican Partys luminaries headlining the Values Voter Summit, which is running through the weekend.

title: Ticking Time Bomb
description: Among people who routinely deal with violence, pain, cruelty and injustice  domestic violence counselors, aid workers, paramedics, public defenders, immigrant advocates  theres a phenomenon known as secondary trauma. Its also sometimes called vicarious trauma, or empathic strain. In her book, Trauma Stewardship, Laura van Dernoot Lipsky, a former social worker, defines it as being unable to live with the knowledge that, despite our best efforts, most of the worlds suffering goes unnoticed and unattended. Still, she writes, people who are working to help those who suffer . . . must somehow reconcile their own joy  the authentic wonder and delight in life  with the irrefutable fact of suffering in the world.

title: Say Youre One of Them
description: In one of the many startling scenes in Island of a Thousand Mirrors, Nayomi Munaweeras first novel, a Sri Lankan girl riding the train to school is suddenly surrounded by a machete-wielding mob, who demand proof she isnt Tamil. In her panic, she recites the Buddhist sutras preaching unattachment, impermanence, the inevitability of death, an unholy trinity that could apply to all civil wars. This chilling exchange reminded me of a conversation I once had on a London bus with a Somali refugee, who swerved from banal chitchat into dark reminiscence. He recalled a moment in Mogadishu when he was forced to recite his genealogy, the string of grandfathers names that place all Somalis within their clans, and he borrowed a school friends lineage, as his own would have marked him for death.

title: Road to Calabria
description: Joseph Luzzi takes the title of his brief, bittersweet new book, My Two Italies, from Shelley, who, in a letter of 1818, distinguished between the Italy of the green earth and transparent sea, and the mighty ruins and the human reality he encountered there: The one is the most sublime . . . the other is the most degraded, disgusting and odious.

title: Inside the List
description: The Dead: Nonfiction books usually rely on fairly pedestrian titles and subtitles to tell readers whats inside  see for instance The Roosevelts: An Intimate History, by Geoffrey C. Ward and Ken Burns, No. 6 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. But every now and then a book arrives that reminds you naming can be an art in itself; the best subtitles work almost like line breaks in poetry, forcing you to re-evaluate what came before. So lets pause a moment to appreciate Caitlin Doughtys Smoke Gets in Your Eyes, new at No. 14, which has the sit-up-and-take-notice subtitle And Other Lessons From the Crematory. Doughty is a young undertaker from Los Angeles who has made it her mission to demystify death, encouraging customers and the public at large to embrace a D.I.Y. approach to funerals. They are grossed out, she told The Atlantic in a recent online interview, but thats because theyve been told their whole lives that death and bodies are best kept to the professionals and that they are dangerous. Most corpses are safer than living bodies. Corpses dont decompose immediately. Theyre not a time bomb of deadness waiting to attack. Theyre your mom or your husband, or the shell of them, at least. . . . Your average corpse is completely safe. Im not sure how soothing I find this pep talk  its not putrefaction I fear, its death  but I do admire Doughtys cheerful sang-froid. I bet shes excellent at her job.

title: Letters: World Order
description: World Order

title: Disquiet on the Set
description: Werner Herzog: A Guide for the Perplexed, the newly revised and expanded collection of interviews with the adventurous filmmaker, might leave readers even more perplexed but will entertain them along the way.

title: All Atwitter
description: I seem to be in the middle of a minor Cronenberg moment. I recently pinned my thumb in a car door, so tightly I had to click the door open again to get it out. Days later the pain had faded, but the nail had turned black. After a few weeks growth, a feeble dividing edge of torn nail has crept from my cuticle, as the dead nail begins its crawl out, to be replaced by  what? A new nail, I hope. (Stay tuned.)

title: Hedge Funds Lose Calpers, and More
description: Assets at hedge funds, once a niche investment vehicle for ultra-wealthy investors, hit a record $2.8 trillion this year. There are now more than 10,000 hedge funds and counting. Their steep fees have minted scores of billionaire managers and spawned not a few criminals in what has turned into a gold rush of the 21st century.

title: Love and Fascism
description: Audrey Magees debut novel is a love story. Or it would be, if deep emotions were allowed to enter into it. Peter Faber is a soldier desperate to escape the fighting. Katharina Spinell is a typist desperate for some financial security. Brought together by an agency, they marry in separate simultaneous ceremonies. He gets honeymoon leave; she gets the promise of a widows pension if he dies. When they meet, they find that theyre attracted to each other  an attraction so intense that it survives years of wartime separation. They also happen to be Nazis.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: A Closet With a View
description: The term literary historical fiction might be used for noncommercial novels set in the past and full of thoughtful allegorical implication. Or one could employ it for a highly specific subgenre, that portion of fictional biography consisting of novels about real-life writers. This territory seems to be expanding of late, with Colm Toibins re-creation of Henry James (The Master), Jay Parinis incarnation of Melville (The Passages of H. M.) and David Lodges imagining of H. G. Wellss energetic sex and writing lives (A Man of Parts).

title: The Longest Game: Williams vs. Amherst
description: The final score was 73-32. Almost four hours had elapsed before the struggle was over.

title: Court Upholds Ban on Uber in Berlin
description: LONDON  Germany cant seem to make up its mind about Uber, the ride-sharing service.

title: 1914: British Take Orange River
description: CAPE TOWN  The important strategic position of Ramans Drift, on the Orange River, has been occupied by British forces. The attack was made at daybreak. The Wachtmeister made a gallant attempt to hold the blockhouse commanding the Drift after his men had evacuated it, but he eventually surrendered. The patrol was then despatched up river. The Germans were discovered in a position from which they were dislodged after a smart skirmish and they retired. The South African force lost one killed, one wounded and two horses killed. The patrol then fell back. Regimental Sergeant-Major Thomas, of the 5th Regiment, behaved with the greatest gallantry, picking up a wounded rifleman and removing him out of danger while under heavy fire. Subsequent scouting disclosed the fact that an important grazing and watering station some miles within the border was held by the enemy.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 27, 1914

title: New York in 101 Objects
description: A new book and exhibition at the New-York Historical Society portrays some of the 101 objects that define New York.

title: University of Chicagos Relations With Confucius Institute Sour
description: The University of Chicago has suspended negotiations to renew its agreement with the Confucius Institute, a global network of Chinese government-affiliated language and culture centers, in a setback for the controversial program ahead of its 10th anniversary on Saturday.

title: An Upper West Side Boomlet
description: Downtown may be enjoying more buzz. But the Upper West Side, that not-too-edgy, not-too-bland land of large parks and elegant prewar facades, is holding up its end of the conversation.

title: Certainties, Uncertainties and Choices with Global Warming
description: Steven E. Koonin, once the Obama administrations undersecretary of energy for science and chief scientist at BP, stirred up a swirl of turbulence in global warming discourse this week after The Wall Street Journal published Climate Science is Not Settled, his essay calling for more frankness about areas of deep uncertainty in climate science, more research to narrow error ranges and more acknowledgement that societys decisions on energy and climate policy are based on values as much as data. (The Journal seems to keep this headline on file; heres a 2009 essay, Climate Science Isnt Settled, by the M.I.T. climatologist Richard Lindzen.)

title: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Political Compromise in Hong Kong
description: With students taking to the streets this week in Hong Kong and pro-democracy protesters planning to stage a sit-in protest in the coming week in the heart of Asias leading financial center, one of the most vocal and articulate supporters of greater democracy in Hong Kong, the former Chief Secretary Anson Chan, is trying to find some room to compromise with the pro-Beijing camp on how to elect the territorys leader, the chief executive.

title: Letting Go
description: At the end of DARKNESS, DARKNESS (Pegasus Crime, $25.95), John Harvey advises us that this will be the final novel in his masterly series featuring Inspector Charlie Resnick. Is there any way we could take a vote on that? Wed hate to lose this Nottingham policeman whose love of jazz and compatibility with cats (named after the likes of Miles Davis and Dizzy Gillespie) distinguish him as the mellowest of detectives.

title: The Melting Pot  La Mode
description: PARIS  Its hard not to wonder sometimes, as we sit idly by waiting for a show to start in, say, the Tuileries (where Nina Ricci was held) or the cole des Beaux-Arts (Lanvin) or a hidden courtyard of the Louvre (Dior) or the Palais de Chaillot (Rick Owens)  or, indeed, any of the many historic French institutions where prt--porter can be found  what Marine Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front, preacher of France for the French, euro-skeptic and increasingly popular potential presidential candidate, would think.

title: Legal Battle Over French Comic Series Astrix Ends
description: PARIS  A lengthy legal battle involving the illustrator of the fabled French Astrix comic series ended Friday when an appeals court here rejected his only daughters claims that he was incapable of handling his literary estate.

title: Artifacts That Encapsulate New York City
description: What began as an article in the Metropolitan section has now, thanks to input from Times readers, grown into a book. A few years ago, the British Museum and BBC produced A History of the World in 100 Objects. But New York needed 101. From the iconic (the subway token and the Spaldeen) to the ironic (a draft for a musical version of Romeo and Juliet called East Side Story), A History of New York in 101 Objects explores the transformative, quirky, surprising and provocative artifacts that have defined the city over four centuries.

title: Businesses Raise Alarms About Londons High Cost of Housing
description: LONDON  Earlier this week, London knocked Hong Kong out of first place as the most expensive city in the world to live and work, according to Savills, a British real estate agency.

title: Why We Sit Back and Let Apps Do Our Chores
description: Near the top of the list of tiresome tasks that the Internet has yet to solve is this one: trekking to the post office.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Loewe Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Justin Bieber, Oncologist
description: Also, a spell cast for British unity; chatty cabbies.

title: Steal This E-Book
description: Ive recently been buying physical copies of books and then illegally downloading electronic versions of the same books, so I can read them on my Kindle when its more convenient. Is this stealing? NAME WITHHELD, CHICAGO

title: Who Made That Charcoal Briquette?
description: In the summer of 1919, a Michigan real estate agent named Edward G. Kingsford was invited on a camping trip by his wifes cousin, the industrialist Henry Ford. In addition to Ford, the adventurers included Thomas Edison, the tire magnate Harvey Firestone and the naturalist John Burroughs. Although the group called themselves the Vagabonds, they traveled with chauffeurs and a chef in a convoy of six vehicles, one of which was a fully equipped kitchen truck.

title: Clay Aiken Takes Lessons From American Idol to the Campaign Trail
description: The former-TV star talks to Jim Rutenberg about getting into politics, Keith Criscos death and why he wont sing on the campaign trail.

description: LENA DUNHAM IS NOT DONE CONFESSING

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Texting While Driving
description: This week, Matt Richtel and Mark Edmundson.

title: Striving for New Ideas at Loewe
description: PARIS  There is probably no better example of the ever-growing United Nations that is French fashion than the fact that one of the most anticipated shows of the week was Loewe, a Spanish brand owned by a French conglomerate (LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton) unveiling its new look under the British designer Jonathan Anderson.

title: Inside the Times 100: Tig Notaro
description: The New York Times recently asked some of the artists and performers on the Times 100, a curated guide to highly anticipated fall events, to talk about some of the works that theyre most excited to see this fall. Previously we spoke to the playwright Sarah Ruhl.

description: Paris

title: Acquainted With the Dark
description: Toward his critics, Louise Glck wrote in one of her best essays, the artist harbors a defensive ace: knowledge that the future will erase the present.

title: Luxury Condos in the Woolworth Building
description: A deal was struck two years ago to turn the neo-Gothic tower of the Woolworth Building into luxury condominiums, creating an unusual opportunity for wealthy apartment-hunters to own a piece of one of New Yorks most recognizable landmarks.

title: Historical Fiction
description: THE MINIATURIST  By Jessie Burton  Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.

title: Parsing Steve Colemans Genius
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the jazz saxophonist, a recent winner of a MacArthur genius grant.

title: A Crisis of Faith in Bill Gross, Pimcos Prophet of Bonds
description: For decades, the investor William H. Gross was celebrated as his mutual fund ballooned in size, drawing investors attracted by its excellent returns.

title: How Medicaid Expansion Helps Hospitals
description: Governors and legislative leaders in the (mostly red) states that have refused to expand their Medicaid programs have another good reason to regret their choice.

title: Cruz Reveals a Darker Past: My Parents Drank Far Too Much
description: Senator Ted Cruz lifted the curtain on a very personal and painful time in his early childhood, telling a group of Christian conservatives on Friday that his parents heavy drinking almost ruined their lives.

title: Why Government Websites Are Terrible and How to Fix Them
description: Your social security number (SSN) will be used to check identity read the online application for Californias food-stamp program. However, providing your SSN is not required when you first submit your application. But also we can deny you or any member of your household benefits for failing to provide an SSN. Confused yet?

title: Paperback Row
description: WHITE GIRLS,  by Hilton Als. (McSweeneys, $16.) Als, a staff writer for The New Yorker, weaves together analyses of literature, art, film and music with insights on the cultural and racial implications of white womanhood. (In these deeply personal essays, white girls is an expansive category, encompassing Louise Brooks and Truman Capote, Flannery OConnor and Richard Pryor.) Our reviewer, Rich Benjamin, praised these kaleidoscopic portraits as effortless, honest and fearless.

title: Isabel Marant: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Two Critical Voices Speak Out on Allergan, Maker of Botox
description: Updated, 3:26 p.m. |

title: Popcast: Parsing Steve Colemans Genius
description: The saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman became a MacArthur Fellow last week  joining the ranks of so-called genius grant winners  and is coming to the end of a two-week residency at the Stone in the East Village. Mr. Coleman has become of the most influential improvisers of the last half-century  mostly through decades of functioning as a one-man, nonacademic academy, the teacher of his own system. His sound, or his thought, can be traced through some of the other recent recipients of the award: Miguel Zenn, Jason Moran, Vijay Iyer and Dafnis Prieto, who have all played with him at one time or another.

title: Regulatory Changes Could Restrict Pool of Private Investors
description: DAVID VERRILL considers himself a savvy, educated investor. Since the year 2000 he has been part of a group that has invested $25 million in 35 start-up companies around New England. He has an M.B.A. from M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management in Cambridge, Mass., where he is executive director of the schools Center for eBusiness.

title: Kosher Accommodations in Costa Rica
description: Extra sunscreen, extra bathing suit, extra pots and pans? For strictly kosher families, planning a vacation in an exotic destination means making room in luggage for what seems like half the kitchen.

title: India and China Step Back From Standoff in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  India and China have agreed to defuse the nearly three-week-old standoff between troops in the disputed border region of Ladakh, Kashmir, the Indian foreign minister, Sushma Swaraj, told reporters on Friday after meeting in New York with her Chinese counterpart.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SHORT AND TRAGIC LIFE OF ROBERT PEACE: A Brilliant Young Man Who Left Newark for the Ivy League,  by Jeff Hobbs. (Scribner, $27.) A heartbreaking journey from a New Jersey ghetto to Yale to a drug-related murder.

title: British Regulators Discuss Settlement With Banks in Currency Case
description: Six of the worlds biggest banks met with British regulators this week to discuss a potential settlement of a sweeping investigation into suspected manipulation of the foreign currency market, according to people briefed on the matter, a new sign that the case is ramping up this year.

title: Big Ticket | Penthouse With Star Power for $20 Million
description: A lavishly renovated duplex penthouse at the 76 Crosby Street Condominiums, a 19th-century brick warehouse whose post-condo-conversion aliases include the Bayard and 81 Spring Street, sold for $20 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: A D.C. of Pink Wigs, Lime Graffiti and, Yes, Business Cards
description: Washingtonian magazine held its annual salute to the citys style setters on Thursday, with an almost-swanky cocktail party at Pinea, a new restaurant inside the W Hotel, just steps from the White House. The nights honorees included the usual boldface names, like Linda Daschle  the lobbyist and wife of former Senator Tom Daschle  but also upwardly mobile transplants who have made this town their oyster.

title: Christophe Lemaire: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: House Tour | Ben Pentreath
description: Ben Pentreaths London home and shop are warm, a little quirky and full of the things that have made him a favorite decorator among Englands aristocrats.

title: G.D.P. Report Emphasizes the Problem of Conflicting Economic Signals
description: Friday mornings revised G.D.P. report provides yet another reminder of just how hard it can be to figure out whats actually going on in the economy. Depending on which numbers you emphasize, the economy is either going gangbusters, simply chugging along in its groove or has hit a rut.

title: Police Behavior in Ferguson Draws Attention of Justice Department
description: The Justice Department on Friday pressured the Ferguson Police Department to stop its officers from wearing bracelets stamped with the message I am Darren Wilson, in solidarity with the police officer who is being investigated for shooting an unarmed black 18-year-old, and from covering up their name plates with tape.

title: Plain English
description: Cozy, quirky, very British interiors  an abundance of printed wallpapers, flowers in pots, funny old things and lots of books  are precisely what draw aristocrats and royals, the Duchess of Cambridge among them, to the services of the decorator Ben Pentreath. Here, his own home.

title: A Stolen Video of My Daughter Went Viral. Heres What I Learned.
description: When my oldest daughter turned 9, I stopped sharing new pictures and videos of her on my blogs Facebook page. She was growing up and looking more and more like the teenager she would eventually become, and I didnt want strangers to recognize her out in public. I didnt think it would be right if her friends could go online and see pictures I was posting on my public sites.

title: Activist Hedge Fund Pushes Yahoo to Weigh a Deal With AOL
description: Updated, 5:40 p.m. |

title: A Sizzling Cocktail That Serves as a Climate Warning
description: The planets atmosphere is heating up, and fast. There is broad scientific consensus that as humans keep pumping carbon dioxide from burning coal and oil into the atmosphere, the gases will trap heat and drive the global average temperature up by more than 2 degrees Celsius (around 5 degrees Fahrenheit).

title: Stuff We Liked
description: The Upshot staff comes across a lot of cool stuff other folks do every day online. Here are links to some of the charts and articles that made us pause and take a gander:

title: Letter From the Editor: The Larger Meaning of Risk
description: We spent a lot of time this week thinking about risk.

title: Republicans Have Reopened Lead in Battle for the Senate
description: If the polls of early September were a reminder that the Democratic path to 50 seats remains open, then the last two weeks were a reminder of how quickly that path could close.

title: Ford Recalls 745,000 Vehicles for Fault That Could Disable Air Bags
description: Ford is recalling about 745,000 sedans and sport utility vehicles in the United States for a problem with an electronic module that could prevent the air bags from deploying in a crash, the automaker said Friday. The action covers 2013-14 Ford C-Max, Fusion, Escape and Lincoln MKZ models.

title: ISIS Lieutenant Emerges From Australian Red-Light District
description: SYDNEY, Australia  In Kings Cross, this citys bawdy, alcohol-infused red-light district, Mohammad Ali Baryalei once patrolled the sidewalk outside the Love Machine club, his basso voice luring customers in, his muscle keeping the unwanted out. For a time, the police said, his was a world of prostitutes, drugs, gangs and gambling.

title: 1939: French Ban Communism
description: The Daladier Cabinet yesterday decreed the dissolution of the French Communist party, the most powerful foreign section of the Comintern since Hitler suppressed its German branch six years ago. Communism now ceases to exist as an organized force in any major country of Europe with the exception of course, of Soviet Russia. The action of the French government in proscribing the Communist party comes as no surprise. It had been foreseen for weeks, ever since Soviet Russia signed the non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany and followed it up by making an agreement with that country for the partition of Poland. Even Leftist papers like LOEuvre have been advocating the Abolition of the French Communist party since the outbreak of the war. Leon Blum, the Socialist party leader, in Le Populate made an urgent appeal to the French Communists to save their party, by formally renouncing their allegiance to Moscow.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 27, 1939

title: Janus Capital, Bill Grosss New Firm, Has a Troubled Past
description: It was stunning enough for Wall Street to learn that William H. Gross, the founder of the giant asset manager Pimco, handed in his resignation on Friday. But still more perplexing was his choice of a new employer: a relatively obscure mutual fund firm called the Janus Capital Group.

title: The Benefits of Economic Expansions Are Increasingly Going to the Richest Americans
description: Economic expansions are supposed to be the good times, the periods in which incomes and living standards improve. And thats still true, at least for some of us.

title: Upper West Side Rowhouse With a Rather Severe Haircut
description: The remarkable Clarence True, the West Sides most inventive architect, almost always worked the side streets, designing rows of houses by the half-dozen; thats where the developers were. But he did leave a remarkable corner with his trademark ebullient Flemish tops, at West End Avenue and 90th Street. Will they ever recover from the butchering of the roof line in the 1950s?

description: The domestic style of Harlems elite will be on exhibit starting this weekend in five designers vignettes at Macys, and in real life at the second annual Strivers Row Home Tour in Harlem on Oct. 5.

description: A journey through the state, featuring Jimmy Carter, Civil War re-enactors and newborn Cabbage Patch Kids.

title: Palestinian Leader Urges U.N. to Press for Deadline to End Israeli Occupation
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, accused Israel on Friday of failing to negotiate in good faith, saying any return to negotiations would be nave at best, and called on the United Nations Security Council to press for a specific deadline to end Israeli occupation.

title: The Business Case for Diversity in the Tech Industry
description: This week I wrote about Googles efforts to increase the number of women and minorities who work at the company. Among other programs, Google is running a series of workshops to help employees understand and combat their unconscious biases. Google hopes the plan will put people on alert to the many small ways that its culture may make outsiders uncomfortable.

title: Readers Respond to Tactics of Subprime Auto Lenders
description: An article about subprime auto lenders that was published Wednesday night in DealBook drew over 1,000 comments in less than 24 hours. The story centered on a piece of technology called the starter interrupt device, which allows lenders to remotely disable the engines of borrowers who dont pay on time as well as to track those cars movements with GPS  raising questions about the price of privacy.

description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Under Cover: Desert Voyages in Colored Hues
description: Deserts are places for pilgrims and mystics, settings for odysseys and renewals, spaces to journey through and be changed by. You can see the light there. The photographer David Benjamin Sherry hauled his large-format 8-by-10 camera into Death Valley last year and brought back some of that light on film. Then he went into the darkroom and, using color, added his own light, his own emotions  to instill fear or joy, in his words. One of the resulting images now illuminates the cover for the Sept. 28 Voyages Issue. Sherrys images belong to a larger body of work, Wonderful Land, for which he spent months visiting well-known vistas around the West. His landscapes, colorized with hues not seen in nature, conjure clarity and disorientation, making the familiar strange again  which just happens to be what all good voyages do.
