It seems the government of President Xi Jinping is so determined to crack down on dissent that it is even willing to stifle commerce and scientific research.

title: Dismal Lessons From Libya and Yemen
description: As the United States barrels into a new war against Sunni extremists in Iraq and Syria, it has been easy to overlook the unraveling of Libya and Yemen.

title: A Group Shout on Climate Change
description: The marchers and mayors, the ministers and presidents, have come and gone. So what is the verdict on Climate Week, the summit meeting on global warming convened by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, in New York?

title: From Pen and Phone to Bombs and Drones
description: WASHINGTON  THE president was at the United Nations on Wednesday urging young people across the Muslim world to reject benighted values, even as America clambers into bed with a bunch of Middle East potentates who espouse benighted values.

title: Who Had It Easier, Reagan or Obama?
description: OVER the past few weeks Ive been reading Ken Adelmans fascinating history Reagan at Reykjavik: Forty-Eight Hours That Ended the Cold War. Adelman, who led Reagans arms control agency, was an adviser at Reagans 1986 Iceland summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Using some newly declassified documents, Adelman fills out the extraordinary dialogue between the two leaders that set in motion a dramatic cut in nuclear arms.

title: Counting the Hungry
description: Buenos Aires  WE dont know who they are. The people suffering from hunger are not our relatives, friends, co-workers; they probably dont read this paper. We dont know them, but at the very least we ought to know how many of them there are, because policy and aid decisions depend on that number; because very often their lives depend on that number. But we dont know, because the hunger statistics reported by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization are flawed.

title: The Wilds of Education
description: WHEN it comes to bullying, to sexual assault, to gun violence, we want and need our schools to be as safe as possible.

title: The Cult Deficit
description: LIKE most children of the Reagan era, I grew up with a steady diet of media warnings about the perils of religious cults  the gurus who lurked in wait for the unwary and confused, offering absolute certainty with the aftertaste of poisoned Kool-Aid. From the 1970s through the 1990s, from Jonestown to Heavens Gate, frightening fringe groups and their charismatic leaders seemed like an essential element of the American religious landscape.

title: God, Darwin and My College Biology Class
description: EVERY year around this time, with the college year starting, I give my students The Talk. It isnt, as you might expect, about sex, but about evolution and religion, and how they get along. More to the point, how they dont.

title: Judges on the Campaign Trail
description: WASHINGTON  FEDERAL judges are appointed for life and insulated from politics, and most of them do not think much of the distinctively American practice of electing judges. They make this clear by insisting that those elections, which take place in 39 states, be as political as possible.

title: Like Father, Like Daughter, Like Son
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I DONT remember when I learned to draw. By kindergarten, I knew what a maulstick was, and stick figures were not in my repertory. An education in art was something I acquired from my father, among the many things he has given me for life, like the shape of my feet and my quirky, maneuverable eyebrows.

title: Object Lessons in History
description: FIVE years ago, the BBC and the British Museum collaborated on a hugely successful radio series and book called A History of the World in 100 Objects. Last week, the Smithsonian followed up with its History of the World in 1,000 Objects.

title: Building an Ark for the Anthropocene
description: WE are barreling into the Anthropocene, the sixth mass extinction in the history of the planet. A recent study published in the journal Science concluded that the worlds species are disappearing as much as 1,000 times faster than the rate at which species naturally go extinct. Its a one-two punch  on top of the ecosystems weve broken, extreme weather from a changing climate causes even more damage. By 2100, researchers say, one-third to one-half of all Earths species could be wiped out.

title: A Refugee Crisis at the Turkish Border
description: As Syrian Kurds fled Islamic State forces, Turkey was caught between conflicting interests in the fighting.

title: Learning to Love Criticism
description: A NEW study by the linguist and tech entrepreneur Kieran Snyder, done for Fortune.com, found two differences between workplace performance reviews given to men and women. Across 248 reviews from 28 companies, managers, whether male or female, gave female employees more negative feedback than they gave male employees. Second, 76 percent of the negative feedback given to women included some kind of personality criticism, such as comments that the woman was abrasive, judgmental or strident. Only 2 percent of mens critical reviews included negative personality comments.

title: The Deposed Queen of NinjaVideo
description: Hana Beshara, a founder of NinjaVideo, once a popular illegal video downloading site, was known as Queen Phara to its users. Now shes putting her life back together after 16 months in prison.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Comme des Garons Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Air France Pilots Extend Strike After Request for Mediation Is Denied
description: PARIS  A costly strike by Air France pilots appeared ready to continue through the weekend after the French government said that it would not mediate the dispute, which has grounded more than half the airlines flights for almost two weeks.

title: For Muslims, Social Media Debate on Extremism Is Reflected in Dueling Hashtags
description: LONDON  With concerns growing in the West about the recruitment of young people by extremist Islamic groups, President Obama brought new attention last week to Muslims who have condemned the radical movement when he singled out a British group for praise in his speech at the United Nations.

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: In a fervent speech to the United Nations on Wednesday, President Obama vowed to dismantle and destroy the Islamic States network of death. Antony J. Blinken, the deputy national security adviser, will discuss the presidents strategy on the Sunday network shows, including CBSs Face the Nation, CNNs State of the Union and Fox News Sunday.

title: As an Analyst, Jon Gruden Needs a Lot of Coaching
description: Jon Gruden is in his sixth season with ESPNs Monday Night Football, and Im still waiting for him to become an interesting and entertaining analyst.

title: The Maverick Inside the Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phil Jackson remains a tall, inimitable presence when entering a room, his stiff-legged gait, thinning gray hair and no-longer-lean body notwithstanding. Alongside the new Knicks coach, Derek Fisher, a smaller, younger man whom he has mentored, and Steve Mills, a general manager whom he has inherited, Jacksons rsum and reputation loom large.

title: 4 College Softball Players Killed and 11 Others Are Injured in Oklahoma Crash
description: Four college softball players were killed and 11 others were injured on Friday night in Oklahoma after the bus they were riding in collided with a semitrailer truck, officials said.

title: Yankee Hatred Is Losing Its Point
description: Its not clear whom my father hated more, the Yankees or Judge Judy. Theres no question whom he hated longer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Dodger Die-Hard Can Admire Jeter

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Major Allergan Investor Joins Chorus Against Salix Deal
description: A third Allergan shareholder has come forward to insist that the Botox maker not agree to an all-cash acquisition that would thwart a takeover offer before a special meeting scheduled for Dec. 18.

title: Tom Watson Not Showing the Same Steadiness He Did as a Player
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland  Say this for Tom Watson: He has remained true to himself during this Ryder Cup week even if he has not always been forthright with everyone else. The famous detachment Watson displayed as a player has been his calling card, where, as the captain of the United States squad, he has kept his players and the news media at a clubs length.

title: Not-So-Classic Loafers at Acne Studios
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Indian Prime Minister Addresses U.N.
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India spoke on Saturday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: As Jeter Ends Farewell Tour, Yanks Plan a Welcome Party
description: BOSTON  Even before Derek Jeter plays his final game for the Yankees, which is scheduled to take place here Sunday, the focus has turned from Jeter to Alex Rodriguez  from a cherished star to a tarnished one.

title: In Alaska, a Battle to Keep Trees, or an Industry, Standing
description: THORNE BAY, Alaska  The Tongass National Forest, a panoply of snow-dusted peaks and braided rivers, slender fjords and more than 5,000 islands draped over a stretch of Pacific coastline, is widely viewed as one of Americas great natural treasures. Under pressure from environmentalists, the Obama administration pledged four years ago to phase out logging of virgin woodlands here.

title: James A. Traficant Jr., Cast Out by Congress in Bribery Case, Dies at 73
description: WASHINGTON  James A. Traficant Jr., a flamboyant Democrat who was expelled from the House of Representatives after a bribery conviction in 2002, died on Saturday in Youngstown, Ohio, four days after he was injured in a tractor accident on his familys farm. He was 73.

title: The Unrepentant Bootlegger
description: Early in the morning of June 30, 2010, Hana Beshara woke to a sharp rapping on the door of her condo in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: South Sudans President Addresses U.N.
description: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan spoke on Saturday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Four by Four
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Thank goodness for Sunday puzzle titles, or I might have missed this one completely.

title: A Rare Arctic Land Sale Stokes Worry in Norway
description: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway  For anyone in the market for a majestic waterfront property with easy access to the North Pole, Ole Einar Gjerde has a deal. We will throw in the polar bears for free, said Mr. Gjerde, pitching the attractions of a huge tract of Arctic land two and a half times bigger than Manhattan but considerably less noisy. It has a human population of zero.

title: Music Row Hopes to Keep Recording
description: A historic recording studio in Nashville is fighting for survival after being scheduled for demolition to build luxury condominiums.

title: As Music Row Shifts to Condo Row, Nashville Cries in Its Beer
description: NASHVILLE  To bolster his argument that the cavernous and almost-famous music room known as RCA Studio A should be spared from the wrecking ball, Mike Kopp, an artist manager, dropped a needle onto an LP, playing one of the thousands of songs recorded here over the last half-century.

title: As Tailgate Hits Rails, What Else to Do but Chug?
description: Cursed with a mediocre football team until recently, South Carolina fans developed one of the most opulent ways to ensure a good time on Saturdays (and, perhaps, to drink enough to make the teams performance irrelevant).

title: Todays Police Put On a Gun and a Camera
description: PULLMAN, Wash.  Amateur videos of police officers doing their jobs have become part of the fabric of urban democracy, with embarrassing or violent images spreading via social media in minutes.

title: Indian Leader Narendra Modi, Once Unwelcome in U.S., Gets Rock Star Reception
description: The Indians who draw crowds of adoring fans are usually tall and sultry, with washboard abs and elaborate outfits, Bollywood stars like Shah Rukh Khan  described by some as the Brad Pitt of India  or Priyanka Chopra, the bombshell actress, singer and model.

title: Russian Diplomats Speech Depicts the West as Hypocritical
description: Russias foreign minister delivered a strident denunciation of the United States and its allies on Saturday, using his speech at the annual United Nations General Assembly session to depict the West as an arrogant and hypocritical arbiter of what is good or evil.

title: Colleges Make It Easier for Students to Show, Not Tell, in Their Applications
description: TOWSON, Md.  Madeline McDonough had a wistful what if? moment, pondering the offer that her school, Goucher College, has made to applicants: Instead of showing us your grades, send us a video.

title: Michael Harari, Israeli Agent Likened to James Bond, Dies at 87
description: Michael Harari, an Israeli intelligence agent who led the hit squad that was sent to avenge the murders of 11 Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, died on Sept. 21 in Tel Aviv. He was 87.

title: Gerald Larue Dies at 98; Early Advocate of Right to Die
description: Gerald A. Larue, an ordained minister, scholar and eventual agnostic who, as the first president of the Hemlock Society, was an early and leading advocate of giving the terminally ill the option to end their own lives, died on Sept. 17 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 98.

title: Tanaka Insists He Feels Fine After Struggling
description: BOSTON  The whirlwind rookie season of the Yankees Masahiro Tanaka ended with a thud Saturday at Fenway Park. Tanaka  who signed a $155 million contract, made the American League All-Star team, tore an elbow ligament and returned  collected just five outs in a 10-4 thumping by the Red Sox.

title: Advocates for News Media to Meet Turkish Officials
description: An international delegation representing two leading press-freedom advocacy groups left Saturday for a weeklong visit to Turkey, where it plans to talk with Turkish officials, possibly including President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, about harassment and persecution of foreign and domestic journalists whose reporting is deemed hostile or unfair by the government.

title: Then a Royal, Now a Political Player
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At a corner deli near his childhood home, Frank White joked with the police major ahead of him in line, discussed roof repairs with a deacon from the Baptist church he has attended for decades, politely declined one fans invitation to speak at a coming event and still managed to eat a corned beef sandwich.

title: Remembering Jim Traficant
description: Former Representative James A. Traficant of Ohio, who died Saturday, left behind a vivid record during the almost nine terms he spent in the House, many of those moments coming during one-minute House speeches.

title: Dinosaurs, Upstarts and a Push for Change
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: A Texas Officials D.W.I. Case Is Being Seen in a Softer Light
description: AUSTIN  A top state official is stopped for drunken driving and refuses breath and blood tests. Police cite erratic driving and uncooperative behavior, and critics say the official is unfit to serve in public office.

title: Royals Revel in the Climb After Vanishing Into Crevasse of Mediocrity
description: CHICAGO  In the visitors clubhouse Saturday, only subtle clues remained from the Kansas City Royals celebration the night before. Everyone looked weary. The carpet was damp. And three Champagne bottles sat on a table in the middle of the room; everyone on the team was supposed to sign them.

title:
Private Bank Fuels
Fortunes of Putins
Inner Circle
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Weeks after President Vladimir V. Putin annexed Crimea in March, an obscure regulatory board in Moscow known as the Market Council convened inside an office tower not far from the Kremlin to discuss the countrys wholesale electricity market. It is a colossal business, worth 2 percent of Russias gross domestic product, and a rich source of fees for the bank that had long held the exclusive right to service it.

title: Austin City Limits, Now 40, Feels Younger Than Ever
description: When Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds taped an appearance on the music television series Austin City Limits, the programs longtime producer, Terry Lickona said, Can you believe, after 40 years for Austin City Limits, 30 years for Nick Cave, this is the first time theyve been on the stage in front of our cameras?

title: Debating What Is More Sacred: Private Land or Public Beaches
description: AUSTIN  Texas has long prided itself on its Open Beaches Act, which guarantees public access along most of the states 367-mile Gulf Coast.

title: Jameis Winston, Standing Out for Positive Reasons, Leads Florida State Rally
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Jameis Winston may have already cost himself millions in N.F.L. money as his draft status plummets with each new drama. It is fair to say he has cost Florida State as well with a series of transgressions.

title: Players for Hire Take European Club Title
description: The European Club Cup is one of the more unusual team events because it turns the worlds best players into chess mercenaries.

title: In A.C.C., the Irish Go Far Afield To Retain a Sense of Independence
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A typical college football regular season is 12 games, with most top programs figuring out a way to have seven home games.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I know the progress is great. This is my hometown, and I love to see it grow and expand. But Id sure hate to see Music Row not be Music Row 20 years from now.

title: 2011 White House Security Breach Left Obamas Angry at Secret Service
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were angry at the Secret Service for the way it handled a 2011 incident in which a gunman fired shots that hit the White House while one of their daughters was at home, The Washington Post reported on Saturday night.

title: An Officer Is Shot in Ferguson, Mo.
description: A Ferguson, Mo., police officer was shot on Saturday night, in an altercation that authorities said was unrelated to continuing protests over the death of a teenager shot by a police officer there last month.

title: Clouds Roll In
description: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.

title: A Golden Age of Design
description: Thanks to a convergence of creativity, technology and big money, the Golden Age of Design may finally be upon us.

title: Courtenay Swasey, Peter Crawford
description: Courtenay Biehl Swasey and Peter Murray Crawford were married Saturday at Christ Church Greenwich in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Dr. James C. Zwernemann, a Lutheran pastor, taking part.

title: Malaika Scott-McLaughlin, LaMon Bland
description: Malaika Nzinga Scott-McLaughlin and LaMon Darrell Bland were married Saturday evening at St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts III, the Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Katelyn Kiernan, Andrew Brooks Jr.
description: Katelyn Chenet Kiernan, a daughter of Vera H. Kiernan and Gregory F. Kiernan of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married Saturday to Andrew Murray Brooks Jr., a son of Elizabeth Hayward Nufer of New York and Mr. Brooks Sr. of Baltimore. The Rev. Mark Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt., assisted by the churchs pastor, the Rev. Gordon McClellan, a Lutheran minister.

title: Victoria Wyeth, Alan Maringer
description: Victoria Browning Wyeth and Alan Isaac Maringer are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Max Hausen will officiate at the Ballroom at the Ben, an event space in Philadelphia.

title: Jesse Ford and William Harbison II
description: Jesse Lee Ford and William James Harbison II were married Saturday evening at the Cordelle, an event space in Nashville. The officiant was Judge Pamela L. Reeves of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee.

title: Catherine Guimaraes, Richard Hoggard
description: Catherine Elizabeth Guimaraes and Staff Sgt. Richard Paul Hoggard were married Saturday at Our Lady of Grace Catholic Church on Fishers Island in New York. The Rev. Anthony J. DiMarco, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Convergent Paths to the Altar
description: Katharine Montecillo Abadilla and Brian Edward Burke were married Saturday evening at the Allegria Hotel in Long Beach, N.Y. Archbishop Louis E. Milazzo, pastor of St. Lucy Old Roman Catholic Cathedral in Brooklyn, officiated, with Steven Rosner, an uncle of the groom, leading prayers and the ring ceremony.

title: Max Dyksterhouse, David Roady
description: Dr. Robert Max Dyksterhouse and David Browning Roady were married Saturday at their weekend house in Hillsdale, N.Y. Eric S. Von Stroh, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Megan Easley, Gregory Schmidt
description: Megan OHara Easley and Gregory Howard Schmidt were married Saturday in Aurora, N.Y. Judge Richard C. Wesley, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, officiated at the Aurora Inn.

title: Jessica Quimby, Mark Fox
description: Jessica Lee Quimby and Mark Charles Fox were married Saturday at Priam Vineyards in Colchester, Conn. Ryan Noggle, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Megan Thomas, Thomas Bodenberg
description: The Rev. Megan Evans Thomas and Thomas Michael Bodenberg were married Saturday at All Saints Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Hugh E. Brown III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Ma and John Mistovich
description: Emily Hornor Ma, the daughter of Jill A. Hornor and Yo-Yo Ma of Cambridge, Mass., and John Matthew Mistovich, a son of Linda A. Mistovich and Eli Mistovich Jr. of Londonderry, N.H., were married Saturday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Michael Tuck, an Episcopal priest, led the ceremony, with the Rev. Christopher J. Waitekus, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: Jennifer Fernandez and Shawn Hardie
description: Jennifer Marie Fernandez and Shawn Clive Hardie were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Paul B. Milholland, a Lutheran minister, at Trinity Lutheran Church in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Jacqueline Gran, Aaron Strauss
description: Jacqueline Louise Gran and Aaron Ben Strauss are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb at the Farm at Broad Run in Broad Run, Va.

title: Talia Kasher, James Rasulo
description: Talia Claire Kasher, the daughter of Yocheved Weinfeld and Steven L. Kasher, both of New York, was married Saturday to James Manuel Rasulo, the son of Myriam O. Rasulo of San Marino, Calif., and James A. Rasulo of Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Stephen A. Carey, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York, with Rabbi Bradley N. Bleefeld taking part.

title: Eleanor Terry, Timothy Vierling
description: Eleanor Casey Terry and Timothy Jon Vierling were married Saturday at Club Getaway, an adventure sports resort in Kent, Conn. Ruth Epstein, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Megan Maraynes, Christopher Sullivan
description: Dr. Megan Elizabeth Maraynes, the daughter of Bitsy and Allan Maraynes of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married Saturday to Christopher Michael Sullivan, the son of Patricia and Barry Sullivan of Cape May, N.J. Aaron L. Bloch, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the brides parents, with Sean B. Maraynes, a brother of the bride, taking part.

title: Kyle Koeppel, Alberto Mann
description: Kyle Gail Koeppel and Alberto David Mann were married Saturday evening at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space in Brooklyn. Joseph L. Spieczny, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Emily Dyson and Paul Seary
description: Emily Anne Dyson, the daughter of Patricia Dyson and Deryl L. Dyson of Huntington Beach, Calif., was married Saturday to Paul Anthony Seary, the son of Phyllis M. Seary and Lawrence A. Seary of Beechhurst, Queens. Pastor Kurt Goble, a nondenominational Christian minister, officiated at the Ponte Winery in Temecula, Calif.

title: Stephanie Selmer, John Doyle
description: Stephanie Erin Selmer and John McKinstry Doyle were married Saturday at Lincoln, a restaurant in Washington. Judge Liam OGrady of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia officiated; in 2012 and 2013, the groom was his clerk in Alexandria, Va.

title: Elisabeth Alba, Scott Murphy
description: Elisabeth Elvira Alba and Scott Robert Murphy were married Saturday in Coxsackie, N.Y. Debra Stafford, the marriage officer for the town, officiated at Owls Hoot Barn.

title: Bailey Woodhull, Dustin Hilt
description: Elizabeth Bailey Woodhull and Dustin Douglas Hilt were married Saturday. The Rev. Richard S. DenUyl Jr., a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Conanicut Yacht Club in Jamestown, R.I.

title: Alexis Kearney, Stuart Wehrly
description: Dr. Alexis Siobhan Kearney and Stuart Brokaw Wehrly were married Friday at Kinney Bungalow at Sunset Farm, an events space in Narragansett, R.I. Robert Hines, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Andrew Brady and Benjamin Fishel
description: Andrew Siman Brady and Benjamin Leo Fishel were married Saturday just off Pilot Knob, N.Y., on Lake George. Paul E. Boivin, a Progressive Universal Life minister, officiated aboard the Morgan, a cruise vessel that he captains.

title: Yuna Larrabee, Travis Smith
description: Dr. Yuna Choi Larrabee and Travis William Smith were married Saturday. Emory M. Fanning, who became a Universal Life minister for this occasion, officiated at Prospect House, an events space on the campus of Princeton University.

title: Cara Petonic, Christopher Prieto
description: Cara Dorean Petonic and Dr. Christopher Charles Prieto were married Saturday at St. Patricks Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Daniel Mackle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Bienstock, Charles Belmonte
description: Emily Meredith Bienstock and Charles Belmonte were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas A. Cardone, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, with Cantor Leslie Friedlander taking part.

title: Erin Macbeth, Spencer Rubin
description: Erin Leigh Macbeth and Spencer Perry Rubin were married Saturday at the Okemo Mountain Resort in Ludlow, Vt. Sanju Kumar, a friend of the couple who received temporary authorization from Vermont, officiated.

title: Pamela Brown, Gordon Olson
description: Pamela Howe Brown and Gordon Eugene Olson were married Saturday at the Fort Orange Club in Albany. Kathy Sheehan, the mayor of Albany, officiated.

title: Katherine DeConti, Elijah Duckworth-Schachter
description: Katherine Elizabeth DeConti and Elijah Sloane Duckworth-Schachter were married Saturday at St. Columbas Chapel in Middletown, R.I. The Rev. Richardson W. Schell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Erica Furfaro, Matthew Naidorf
description: Erica Rogers Furfaro, the daughter of Audrey R. Furfaro and John P. Furfaro of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Scott Naidorf, the son of Dr. Ellen Naidorf and the late Dr. Kenneth F. Naidorf of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Joshua Davidson officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Meghan Knutson, Travis Vanderbilt
description: Meghan Marie Knutson, a daughter of Debra L. Knutson and Terry K. Knutson of Burnsville, Minn., was married Saturday to Travis Murray Vanderbilt, a son of Alison Platten Vanderbilt and Alfred G. Vanderbilt III of Norwalk, Conn. Jordan B. Hansen, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated at Albert A. Kordiak Park in Columbia Heights, Minn.

title: Rachel Kennedy, Lartif Thornton
description: Rachel Anne Kennedy and Lartif Lorenzo Thornton were married Saturday by Donna Katsuranis, a Connecticut justice of the peace, at La Cupola Ristorante & Inn in Litchfield, Conn.

title: Marietta Whittlesey, Stanford Meigs
description: Marietta Hill Whittlesey and Stanford Jonathan Meigs were married Saturday at the brides home in Gallatin, N.Y. The Rev. Douglas Grandgeorge, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Diane Paragas, Thom Zimny
description: Diane Paragas and Thom Zimny were married Saturday at the Vinegar Hill House, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Matt Levy, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Olivia Oran, Gregory Beaton
description: Olivia Zandra Oran, the daughter of Hilary B. Oran and Stuart I. Oran of New York, was married Saturday evening to Gregory David Beaton, a son of Ann R. Beaton and Neal N. Beaton of New York. Rabbi Robert Levine officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street, with Cantor Rebecca Garfein participating.

title: Marisa Fegan, Peter Dooney
description: Marisa Anne Fegan, the daughter of Mary Ellen Siebert of Greenwood Village, Colo., and Dr. James R. Fegan of Houston, was married Saturday to Peter Dewart Dooney, the son of Mary Louise Dooney of Hobe Sound, Fla., and H. Peter Dooney of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. W. Alfred Tisdale Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Watch Hill Chapel in Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Meredith Stebbins, Joost Gieskes
description: Meredith Pheatt Stebbins and Joost Johan Gieskes were married Saturday evening at the Coral Beach and Tennis Club in Paget Parish, Bermuda, by the Rev. Anthony D. Pettit, an Anglican priest.

title: Marilla Hiltz and Miklos Vasarhelyi
description: Marilla Jennings Hiltz and Miklos Chai Vasarhelyi were married Saturday evening at the summer home of the brides family in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Ted Pardoe, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Caroline Porter, Joshua Moshier
description: Caroline Ralstin Porter and Joshua Campbell Moshier were married Saturday. The Rev. Jason D. Harris, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Armstrong Chapel United Methodist Church in Cincinnati, with the Rev. Gregory D. Stover, the senior pastor of the chapel, taking part.

title: In Softbank, DreamWorks Animation May Have a Suitor
description: LOS ANGELES  Roughly a year and a half after ending an unsuccessful search for a buyer in Hollywood, DreamWorks Animation has ended up with a surprise suitor: SoftBank Corporation, the Japanese telecommunications and Internet giant.

title: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
description: Among the grievances editors love to share during Paris Fashion Week, few are bemoaned with as much as zest as the traffic. The city residents, for their part, are usually happy to exacerbate the issue with a street-blocking demonstration (here, called a manifestation) or two.

title: Roche Breast Cancer Drug Perjeta Appears to Greatly Extend Patients Lives
description: A drug used to treat advanced breast cancer has had what appears to be unprecedented success in prolonging lives in a clinical trial, researchers reported on Sunday.

title: Corrections: September 28, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 1914: German Offensive Checked in Belgium
description: ANTWERP  The following communiqu has been issued here : Yesterday [Sept. 26], a detachment of German troops, comprising a brigade of infantry, two regiments of cavalry and six batteries of artillerytwo of which were heavy artillerywas surprised in its march from Brussels on Termonde, via Alost. Attacked in front and on their flank, the German troops retired in disorder toward Assche, leaving in our hands many prisoners and wounded as well as several caissons. To-day, apparently with the intention of avenging this defeat, Malines was bombarded by long-distance guns and important forces made a general movement along our front. Between Malines and Alost the several German attacks against us failed. Toward Alost, our division of cavalry succeeded in taking the German left wing in the rear. In short, the German attack has failed and our troops have without difficulty preserved the positions acquired from Antwerp to Malines. There, however, the station has suffered severely. Many houses have collapsed, others are on fire. A dozen civilians have been killed. The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 29, 1914

title: Indelible Photos of Derek Jeter
description: By his count, Barton Silverman has been blessed by the photo gods four times. They came in the form of larger-than-life subjects who can make or break a photographers career: Joe Namath, Wayne Gretzky, Michael Jordan and most recently, Derek Jeter, whose final innings on a Boston diamond today conclude a storied 20-year career.

title: Crackdown on Protests by Hong Kong Police Draws More to the Streets
description: HONG KONG  Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest, inciting public fury that brought tens of thousands of people onto the streets of a city long known as a stable financial center.

title: Kenzo: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Dozens of Hikers Feared Dead on Japanese Volcano
description: TOKYO  Thirty-one hikers were feared dead near the peak of a volcano in central Japan on Sunday, a day after it suddenly erupted, a police spokesman said. However, the danger of another eruption and of a release of toxic gases made it impossible to bring most of them down and confirm their deaths.

title: 1964 at the U.N.: A Dispute With the Soviets and a Che Guevara Sighting
description: 1964 at the U.N.: A Dispute With the Soviets and a Che Guevara Sighting

title: 1964: Ex-President Of Syria Slain in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Ex-President Adib Shishakli of Syria was shot dead yesterday [Sept. 27] on a street in the Brazilian town of Ceres, a radio station reported today. It said it was believed the killing was for political motives. Brig. Shishakli had been living in Brazil for some four years and operated a rice plantation. The shooting occurred in mid-afternoon in the middle of the main street. The assassin was described as a dark-haired young man of medium height wearing dark glasses and a green shirt. Police said he had lunched with Brig. Shishakli in a restaurant shortly before the shooting. Restaurant witnesses said the assailant seemed to be a well-educated, well-mannered youth who had not been seen before in this sparsely-settled cowboy country west of Brasilia. Police said he fled the town in an automobile. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 29, 1964

title: The Google Formula for Success
description: Can Googles winning ways be applied to all kinds of businesses? The authors of How Google Works, Eric Schmidt, Googles former chief executive, and Jonathan Rosenberg, a former senior product manager at Google, firmly believe that they can.

title: Home Alone at 7, Safe and Learning to Stay That Way
description: Theres that scene in the Pixar movie The Incredibles in which Elastigirl is flying a jet toward the island where her husband, Mr. Incredible, is being held by the evil Syndrome. Missiles are coming toward the jet, and with no other options, Elastigirl turns to her daughter, Violet, for help.

title: Air France Pilots End Two-Week Strike
description: PARIS  The union representing thousands of striking Air France pilots said on Sunday that it would end a crippling two-week strike in the interest of passengers and the company, although it stopped short of accepting managements plans for expanding a low-cost subsidiary.

title: Cline: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Officials Say Shooting of Ferguson Police Officer Is Not Linked to Protests
description: Law enforcement officials said Sunday that the weekend shooting of a Ferguson police officer was unrelated to weeks of protests over the death of an unarmed black teenager who was shot by a white officer here last month.

title: Bronx Boy Is Stabbed to Death at a Party
description: A 14-year-old boy died early Sunday morning and three other teenagers were in the hospital with injuries after they were all stabbed while attending a birthday party in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Kenzo Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Nina Westervelt.

title: Dont Do the Things You Love
description: Do you like ice cream? Then dont eat it  at least not every day.

title: Ryder Cup 2014: Europeans Make Easy Work of U.S. for Third Straight Victory
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland  It has become a rite of autumn: European golfers sinking putts, and Americans, and then showering one another with compliments and champagne.

title: Want a Robot Pen Pal?
description: Robots may not be writing science fiction just yet, but they can write you a letter.

title: Activist Is Celebrated at the College He Helped Save
description: Ramon J. Jimenez insists he does not live in the past, even if his office furniture does. Dingy and worn, it is vintage 1970s dcor, evoking the era when he arrived in the South Bronx. He was an Afro-wearing, radical, Harvard-trained lawyer for whom causes and people were more important than billable hours and prestige.

title: Synth Interlaced With a Personal Purgatory
description: Disorientation, tolling piano chords, austerity, loops, malaise, bittersweet melody  yes, theres a new album by Thom Yorke of Radiohead, Tomorrows Modern Boxes, which he suddenly released on Friday on BitTorrent Bundle, through file-sharing software. The album costs $6, of which Mr. Yorke receives 90 percent. Its the same percentage hed get on the more established Bandcamp, but with less tech fanfare.

title: Dividing Along Tribal Lines
description: PARIS  Isabel Marant, whose name has become shorthand for a certain brand of messy-haired Parisienne chic, took inspiration for her new collection, she said, from the tribes of Africa.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Celine Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Chlo: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: 15 People Wounded After Shooting at Miami Nightclub
description: Fifteen people were shot and wounded, one critically, at a nightclub in Miami early Sunday, officials said.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE PARADISE, SEASON 2 Joanna Vanderham, above, returns as Denise Lovett, an ambitious country girl who last season took a job at a Victorian department store in a booming northern British city in this Masterpiece Classic adaptation of the 1883 mile Zola novel Au Bonheur des Dames. Soon she had caught the eye of John Moray (Emun Elliott), the handsome if enigmatic owner of the establishment, whose affection was pursued by Lady Katherine Glendenning (Elaine Cassidy). But eventually Morays love for Denise won out, and he left Katherine at the altar. The new season picks up a year later as Moray pines away in Paris for Denise, who is back at the Paradise, their romance tested by the stores regime of Katherine and her new husband, Tom Weston (Ben Daniels). In Miss Marple, Season 7: Endless Night, at 9, Agatha Christies spinster sleuth (Julia McKenzie) meets a chauffeur (Tom Hughes) who recounts his romance with an American heiress (Ms. Vanderham) and her death, foretold by a Gypsy, shortly after their marriage. And in The Mystery of Agatha Christie With David Suchet, at 10:30, Mr. Suchet, who starred in the long-running series Agatha Christies Poirot, ponders the writers life and legacy.

title: In Kabul, Cuomo Seeks Insights on Terrorism
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Invoking one tragedy to warn of the prospect of another, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Sunday that the rise of the Islamic State had revived the trauma of the Sept. 11 attacks among New Yorkers while creating a fresh danger for their city.

title: Obama Acknowledges U.S. Erred in Assessing ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama acknowledged in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the United States had underestimated the rise of the Islamic State militant group, which has seized control of a broad swath of territory in the Middle East, and had placed too much trust in the Iraqi military, allowing the region to become ground zero for jihadists around the world.

title: Denzel Washington and The Equalizer Lead Box Office
description: There are few sure things in Hollywood, but Denzel Washington is certainly one of them. The Equalizer (Sony), starring Mr. Washington as a retired mercenary pitted against ultra-violent Russian gangsters, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $35 million. The Equalizer, which reteamed Mr. Washington with the director Antoine Fuqua, cost Sony and Village Roadshow roughly $55 million to make. Sony, which is counting on the film to make up ground from some under-performing summer releases like Sex Tape, boasted on Sunday of its no-holds-barred marketing campaign for The Equalizer and called the results spectacular.

title: Golden Ring Barrettes at Cline
description: Phoebe Philos spring/summer Cline collection shown today embodied modernity  from the feminine yet clean-lined clothes to the graphic simplicity of the hair accessories. Models sported shiny, slightly wavy locks that were brushed back and secured with simple golden ring barrettes that mimicked the hardware on bags.

title: First to Break 2:03, Kenyan Shatters Marathon Record
description: World records at the Berlin Marathon are not so much set as incubated in laboratory conditions.

title: Runner-Up in Afghan Elections Threatens to Boycott Inauguration
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdullah Abdullah, the runner-up in Afghanistans presidential election, is threatening to pull out of the inauguration on Monday of the countrys new leadership, which could imperil the national unity government he has agreed to join with the winning candidate, Ashraf Ghani.

title: Pauline Hoarau Transforms at Kenzo
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Pauline Hoarau before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Anthony Turner.

title: For Cameron, Tory Convention Gets Off to Rocky Start
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain faced a double embarrassment on Sunday, as his Conservative Party opened its final convention before Mays general election trailing the opposition Labour Party in the polls.

title: Akris: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Radical Monk in Myanmar Pledges to Protect Global Buddhism
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  A radical monk from Myanmar who has preached hatred toward Muslims and is the spiritual leader of a movement to boycott Muslim businesses said Sunday that his movement would join hands with a Sri Lankan group to protect Buddhism around the world.

title: On the Hunt for a Sprite on a Midsummers Night
description: LAMY, N.M.  Every summer evening at 7 oclock, Thomas Ashcraft receives a personalized weather report. It is monsoon season, and he is getting advice from a meteorologist in Colorado on where to look for the massive thunderstorms that erupt over the western High Plains.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Chlo Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Advertising Week 2014: Exploring the Future of Television
description: THOSE who remember the 1960s  putting aside the quip that if you remember the 60s, then you really werent there  will recall a declaration that The revolution will not be televised. Decades later, it is television that is being revolutionized, effecting profound changes in how the advertising business operates and tries to make money.

title: Excerpt: You Cant Take It With You
description: James Earl Jones, Karl Kenzler and Will Brill in a scene from the Broadway revival of the Kaufman and Hart comedy, at the Longacre Theater.

title: Excerpt: The Money Shot
description: Elizabeth Reaser, Gia Crovatin and Fred Weller in a scene from the new Neil LaBute play at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: Protesters Clash With Hong Kong Police
description: Thousands of pro-democracy protesters gathered in the business district, Central, in Hong Kong on Sunday as police tried to disperse the crowd using tear gas.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 27, 2014
A.I.G. Bailout Lawsuit, Eurozone Stimulus and U.S. Jobs Data
description: LAWSUIT OVER A.I.G. BAILOUT BEGINS

title: Derek Jeter Ends Yankees Career With Single Against Red Sox
description: BOSTON  Derek Jeter played his last game Sunday, ending his career with a play typical of his time in the majors, in which he hustled out an infield single for his 3,465th hit.

title: Givenchy: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Encouraged by a Strong September, the Mets Can Hardly Wait Till Next Year
description: The summertime conditions may have confused some Mets fans who did not seem to want to leave Citi Field on Sunday afternoon. They waited as the players completed their postgame victory handshakes and Manager Terry Collins jogged out to center field to wave goodbye. Then they lingered in the parking lots. They wanted to see more baseball.

title: Reminders of the Protest Era Stirred Into a Postmodern Gumbo
description: In the eight years since he founded his company, Abraham.In.Motion, Kyle Abraham has been mixing modes of movement to form his own; he cleverly calls his choreography a postmodern gumbo. Its sources range from ballet to Brazilian capoeira, from the Lindy Hop to the 90s raves where, growing up in Pittsburgh, he got his start as a dancer. He has hallmarks, favorite moves: a head roll casting ripples down through the shoulders and arms; floor-skimming scoots with one leg in arabesque; squalls that erupt from the torso while the feet stand their ground, the body fighting against itself or something unseen.

title: Workouts for the Mind, Dressed in Cheeky Humor
description: The Dutch choreographer Jan Martens does not put on airs. At the Abrons Arts Center on Friday, he introduced himself to New York in shorts and sneakers, sitting onstage taking selfies with a laptop. The images were projected on the wall behind him, along with the words he typed: a list of 10 fairly simple things he was attempting in the solo he was performing.

title: With Perspective From Both Sides of His Desk, F.C.C. Chairman Ponders Net Neutrality
description: WASHINGTON  As a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, Tom Wheeler played a role in shaping almost every major telecommunications policy and innovation over the last three decades.

title: A Conductor Tries to Soar Amid High Expectations
description: BOSTON  The Andris Nelsons era at the Boston Symphony Orchestra began on Saturday night when this exciting Latvian conductor led a festive program at Symphony Hall to begin his tenure as the ensembles 15th music director. Though just 35, Mr. Nelsons has become one of the most respected and sought-after conductors in the field. The buzz in Boston and the extensive media coverage his arrival has generated show that music lovers in this city are grateful to have him. As he walked to the podium on Saturday he was greeted with a long, rousing ovation; many people were on their feet.

title: Jets and Geno Smith Picked Apart by Lions, and Fans
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The crowd chanted for Geno Smiths backup. Smith cursed at a heckling fan. Sheldon Richardson afterward told those who booed to shut up.

title: Woman Caught in the Paradox of Being Adrift and on a Journey
description: With her flawed but poignant new book, Lila, Marilynne Robinson has returned to the central characters in her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, Gilead (2004)  the aging minister John Ames and his much younger wife, Lila  and to the themes of alienation and separateness (and the possibility of belonging) that animated her astonishing debut novel, Housekeeping, more than 30 years ago.

title: Police Officer Is Shot in Ferguson
description: The police said that the shooting of an officer in the Missouri town appeared unrelated to the protests over Michael Browns death.

title: A Half-Century of Intellectual History
description: Robert Silvers has assigned thousands of pieces for The New York Review of Books, so why not a documentary film? The 50 Year Argument, showing Monday on HBO, originated along the same lines as one of the lengthy, learned articles in The Review: Mr. Silvers sought out a talented essayist, in this case Martin Scorsese, and asked him to explore a subject  the magazines 50-year history  that he was passionate about but not expert in.

title: A Vengeful Ranger Full of Attitude and on a Mission
description: Im not sure how old I was when I first tried to play a Lord of the Rings video game, but I suspect I wasnt yet 10. It was in the 1980s, and my dad had brought home a computer cast off from his workplace. The machine was beige with a monochromatic green screen that sat above two floppy disk drives.

title: A Free-Spirited Tribute to a Master of Jazz
description: During his introductory remarks at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Saturday night, Henry Threadgill succinctly noted that no amount of accolades could mean more to him than the support of a community of musicians engaging with his work. That reasonable assertion helped set the terms for Very Very Threadgill, an ambitious two-day festival of his music, and a celebration of his legacy and influence in the American avant-garde.

title: Wales in the Qualifying Stages at Commonwealth Nations
description: Every Daily Bulletin at the Fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships in Glasgow this month contained a card-play problem. This deal, from the qualifying stage of the main event, could have been used.

title: Over-the-Knee, Over-the-Top Boots at Givenchy
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: In Pakistans Tribal North, U.S. Drone Strike Kills Four
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An American drone strike in northwestern Pakistan killed at least four people suspected of being militants, Pakistani officials said Sunday.

title: Local Success Story
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Lets talk about Derek Jeter some more, just because hes so awesome. No really, I can make this work. We can connect this to todays puzzle. First, though, Id like to personally thank Eric Sydney Phillips, who is making his New York Times debut with this 1516 grid today, and Will Shortz for giving me the opportunity to once again point out how incredibly awesome Mr. Jeter is.

title: Sectarian Violence in Myanmar Threatens Livelihood of Muslims
description: MANDALAY, Myanmar  It has been more than a month since Mandalay, Myanmars second-largest city, was rocked by deadly anti-Muslim riots. Broken windows and large dents in the facades of a dozen small Muslim-run businesses are the only visible reminders of when about 300 radical Buddhists rode into town wielding swords and bricks, killing two people.

title: Turning a Book Tour Into a Literary Circus (and a Hot Ticket)
description: Last month, the writer, actor and producer Lena Dunham started an ambitious project. Nearly 600 people responded to an open call for video auditions on her website, including a sand artist, a ukulele player, a cappella singers, gymnasts, performance artists and stand-up comics, even some exceptionally charismatic babies.

title: A Great Lawn for a Global Cause
description: Definitionally, there is a certain amount of pill-swallowing at a concert like the Global Citizen Festival, which on Saturday  for the third year in a row  brought 60,000 people to the Great Lawn at Central Park.

title: Harmonious in a Language That Needs No Translation
description: During a concert of new works composed for the Talea Ensemble on Friday evening at Roulette, it sometimes seemed that limited material was being stretched to fill the time allocated by a commission, instead of being used more effectively in shorter works.

title: Indias Budget Mission to Mars
description: India joins the space club.

title: Vigil Is Planned for Uighur Writer
description: The PEN American Center will hold a vigil for the Uighur writer and academic Ilham Tohti on Monday evening in response to his being sentenced to life in prison. Mr. Tohti, left, an economics professor and vocal critic of the Chinese government on human rights and social issues, was sentenced last week by China on charges of separatism. The court stated that Mr. Tohti bewitched his students and exploited foreign forces to create pressure to make Xinjiang an international matter. Since his arrest in January, Mr. Tohti has received global attention from free-speech activists around the globe. In May he was awarded the 2014 PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom to Write Award. Of the 38 writers who were in prison at the time they received the award, 35 have been subsequently released. The candlelight vigil on Monday is to feature the novelist Barbara Kingsolver, who will read a statement Mr. Tohti wrote in 2013, specifically in the event of his arrest. The vigil is scheduled for 8 p.m. outside the New School in New York.

title: Wynton Marsalis to Open St. Louis Jazz Center
description: Wynton Marsalis will bring his Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra to St. Louis to open that citys new jazz center on Thursday. The center, newly remodeled and renamed the Harold & Dorothy Steward Center for Jazz, will be a hub and education space for a city that birthed jazz greats like Miles Davis and Clark Terry. The center, which previously housed Jazz at the Bistro, underwent a $10 million renovation this year in hopes of creating a counterpart to New Yorks Jazz at Lincoln Center and San Franciscos SFJazz. In addition to the main concert space, the center will contain rehearsal and practice rooms for instruction sessions. We have to make sure its not just a question of preserving our jazz heritage, Gene Dobbs Bradford, executive director of Jazz St. Louis, told The Associated Press. We have to educate and train the next generation of great St. Louis musicians. Other coming performers include a St. Louis native, David Sanborn; Joshua Redman; and Joey DeFrancesco. The space is named after the parents of Dave Steward, who is the chief executive of World Wide Technology and was the projects lead donor.

title: Downton Abbey Star to Tour With Band
description: American fans of the hit PBS show Downton Abbey will be able to see one of its stars, Elizabeth McGovern, both on TV in English formal wear and live holding a guitar this winter. Ms. McGovern, acclaimed for playing Countess Cora Crawley on Downton, will embark on her first United States tour with her folk-rock band, Sadie and the Hotheads, The Associated Press reported. Ms. McGovern has been on Downton since the shows inception in 2010 and has received Emmy and Golden Globe nominations for her work. Sadie and the Hotheads formed three years earlier and has since featured performances by another Downton star, Michelle Dockery. The group will release its third album, Still Waiting, on Thursday, and the bands tour is scheduled to begin on Dec. 4 in Washington. The Season 5 premiere of Downton Abbey in the United States will arrive one month later.

title: Refugees Flood Turkish Border as Islamic State Steps Up Attacks on Syrian Kurds
description: MURSITPINAR, Turkey  Shelling intensified Sunday on Kobani, the Syrian town at the center of a region of Kurdish farming villages that has been under a weeklong assault by Islamic State militants, setting fire to buildings and driving a stream of new refugees toward the fence here at the border with Turkey.

title: China's Fruitless Repression of the Uighurs
description: Last week, a court in Chinas far western Xinjiang region sentenced Ilham Tohti, a member of the Uighur minority, to life in prison for the crime of inciting separatism. The conviction of this moderate scholar elicited international condemnation; the sentence was an order of magnitude longer than those given to other Chinese dissidents. But, far from being a show of strength, the sentence is a sign of the confusion and desperation behind the governments policies toward Uighurs.

title: Shiites in a Battered Neighborhood of Baghdad Fault One of Their Own
description: BAGHDAD  Families venture out only by day and as little as possible. Shopkeepers watch the curbs more than their stores, to prevent anyone from parking. The police have erected checkpoints on the avenues and closed the side streets, but more bombs keep coming.

title: Downhill on a Forest Road
description: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Sept. 29
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Georgia Colleges Prohibiting Tobacco, but Questions About Enforcement Linger
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Amid carefree talk of starting lineups, one public notice to the Sanford Stadium crowd on a recent Saturday stood out: Beginning Oct. 1, the University of Georgia will be among the academic institutions in this state that prohibit tobacco products from its campuses.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Givenchy Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Legacy of a Venerated Magazine Editor Lives Large on the Newsstand
description: When Adam Sachs was named editor in chief of Saveur last week, he became the head of an award-winning food magazine. He also became something else: the latest in a long line of magazine chiefs who worked under Art Cooper, a legendary former editor of GQ.

title: The Benefits of Binocularity
Narendra Modi Outlines Goals for India on Eve of a Visit With Obama
description: Narendra Modi, the prime minister of India, sold himself on Sunday as a onetime tea vendor who wanted to lift India to glory by cleaning up the country, clearing the way for business and preparing its young citizens to be the work force of an aging world. His speech at Madison Square Garden telegraphed a wish list on the eve of his first meeting with President Obama, while also deftly rallying an influential diaspora to his side.

title: Open Mind Host Continues Grandfathers Vision for New Generation
description: This summer, Alexander Heffner, a 24-year-old journalist just a couple of years out of Harvard, became the host of a talk show on public television. But a new media venture this is not.

title: Growling by Comcast May Bring Tighter Leash
description: Comcast has a long corporate tradition of smiling and wearing beige no matter what kind of criticisms are hurled at it. That public posture is in keeping with the low-key approach favored by Brian L. Roberts, the companys chief executive, as he seeks to take over the world. Its worked very well so far.

title: The Mystery of the Missing Bees
description: The mystery of Colony Collapse Disorder has brought honeybees into the public eye. But the story of their plight  and its impact  is more complicated.

title: At Madison Square Garden, Chants, Cheers and Roars for Modi
description: They wore his face on their chests, waved it on posters, chanted his name and quoted his slogans, 19,000 fans drawn to a single star. His image stared down from the big screen at Madison Square Garden and emerged on canvas in a live speed-painting onstage. And when the man himself emerged, the capacity crowd on Sunday in New Yorks most storied arena roared as one, as if all the Knicks, all the Rangers, Billy Joel and Bruce Springsteen had suddenly materialized.

title: Finally, the Truth About the A.I.G. Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  TODAY is the start of the trial in Starr International Co. Inc. v. United States, the case alleging that the governments 2008 bailout of A.I.G. amounted to an unconstitutional plunder of the companys shareholders. Starr, a firm run by the former A.I.G. chief executive Maurice R. Greenberg, was the insurers largest single shareholder at the time. It saw the government grab almost 80 percent of its common stock amid the bailout (a proportion that eventually rose to 92 percent), and is asking for a cool $40 billion to make it whole.

title: New York Media Outlets Revamp Site for Schools
description: The New York public radio station WNYC and the commercial television station WNBC have forged an unusual relationship in recent months, sharing investigative coverage on air and online. Now the two are teaming up, along with WNBCs Spanish-language sister station, WNJU, and The Daily News, on a reintroduction of SchoolBook.org, a WNYC-owned site offering news and data on the New York City public schools system.

title: For the Poor, Culture Shock on Campus
Jose Altuve Wins Batting Title on the Field
description: The Houston Astros incited outrage from some of their fans when their All-Star second baseman, Jose Altuve, was initially left out of the starting lineup against the Mets on Sunday, in the final game of the season.

title: No Faith in Government
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Tappan Zee
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus on Gun Trafficking
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Press for Advantage as Politicians Work on Maneuvers in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan security forces managed to defeat a weeklong Taliban assault on a strategic district in central Afghanistan, provincial officials said over the weekend, though the victory was tenuous and the toll was high. At least 64 people were killed, including some civilians who were beheaded by the insurgents, and a number of homes were torched.

title: The Head-Scratching Case of the Vanishing Bees
description: In 1872, a merchant ship called the Mary Celeste set sail from New York, and four weeks later was found by sailors aboard another vessel to be moving erratically in the Atlantic Ocean 400 miles east of the Azores. Curious, those sailors boarded the Mary Celeste, only to find nary a soul. The cargo was intact, as were supplies of food and water. But there was no sign of the seven-man crew, the captain, or his wife and daughter, who had gone along for the journey. To this day, what turned that brigantine into a ghost ship remains a maritime mystery.

title: Swimming Through Garbage
description: CAPE TOWN  YOU get a good feel for the health of the oceans when you stick your head in them for four weeks. This summer, I swam long distances in the Seven Seas: the Mediterranean, Adriatic, Aegean, Black, Red, Arabian and North Seas. The longest swim was 37 miles and took me two days.

title: Nursing Homes Behind Bars
description: After declining for three years in a row, the nations stubbornly huge prison population has crept back up again. About 1,574,700 people were in prison at the end of 2013, up 4,300 from 2012. (While the federal population actually dropped for the first time in more than 30 years, it was offset by a larger increase in state prisoners.)

title: Fumbled Bid for Governor Imperils Ohio Democrats
description: DAYTON, Ohio  With a wounded candidate at the top of their ticket, Democrats in Ohio have been forced to adopt a Plan B as they seek to avoid a disastrous shutout in elections for governor and other statewide offices.

title: Iraq Army Woos Deserters Back to War on ISIS
description: QUSH TAPA, Iraq  The Iraqi military command has begun a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units, a crucial step in its effort to rebuild an army that has been routed in battle after battle by Islamic State jihadists.

title: Can We Do Without a Global Climate Treaty?
You Call This Thai Food? The Robotic Taster Will Be the Judge
description: BANGKOK  Hopscotching the globe as Thailands prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra repeatedly encountered a distressing problem: bad Thai food.

title: Our Invisible Rich
description: Half a century ago, a classic essay in The New Yorker titled Our Invisible Poor took on the then-prevalent myth that America was an affluent society with only a few pockets of poverty. For many, the facts about poverty came as a revelation, and Dwight Macdonalds article arguably did more than any other piece of advocacy to prepare the ground for Lyndon Johnsons War on Poverty.

title: Costs Can Go Up Fast When E.R. Is in Network but the Doctors Are Not
description: When Jennifer Hopper raced to the emergency room after her husband, Craig, took a baseball in the face, she made sure they went to a hospital in their insurance network in Texas. So when they got a $937 bill from the emergency room doctor, she called the insurer, assuming it was in error.

title: For a Worker With Little Time Between 3 Jobs, a Nap Has Fatal Consequences
description: She would give anyone anything she could.  Glen Carter, 33.

title: New Era Begins, and Yankees Hope It Starts Lasting Into October
description: BOSTON  Derek Jeter took off his Yankees uniform for the final time on Sunday and with that the last player from the glory teams spanning the 1990s and 2000s is gone. The dynasty is finally over, and the record shows it.

title: After Fire, Chicago Flight Delays Bleed Into Third Day

title: Solitary Confinement to End for Youngest at Rikers Island

title: Colbert and Carell, Together Again Soon
description: Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell have been comedic peers since the early 90s, when they performed in the improvisation troupe Second City in Chicago; later, they were correspondents on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart. The pair will be reunited once again for this years Montclair Film Festival fund-raiser in New Jersey, organizers are to announce on Monday. The event, A Conversation With Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell, is scheduled for 8 p.m. on Nov. 21 at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. These comedians are having busy fall seasons: Mr. Colbert is hosting The Colbert Report while planning for his move to Late Show on CBS, while Mr. Carell (above right with Mr. Colbert) is drawing Oscar buzz for his role in Bennett Millers Foxcatcher, which is scheduled to reach American movie theaters in November. The Montclair Film Festival event will include highlights of the two together at Second City as well as conversation on their formative years on The Dana Carvey Show. Mr. Colbert and his family live in Montclair, and his wife, Evie McGee-Colbert, is the vice chairwoman of the film festivals board of directors. The fourth Montclair Film Festival will be in May.

title: Morning Agenda: Bond King Quits
description: BOND KING DEPARTS | William H. Gross, who built Pimco from scratch into one of the biggest money managers in the world, made waves in the business world on Friday when he abruptly quit the firm he founded to join the Janus Capital Group, DealBooks Matthew Goldstein writes. The exit came after Mr. Gross learned in recent weeks that top executives at Pimco and Allianz, the German insurer that owns it, had grown tired of his leadership and were weighing a change. In particular, there were concerns that his eccentric management style  he wore sunglasses while giving a presentation at a conference and used his monthly investment letters to share intimate details  was becoming a distraction.

title: 1939: Nazis War Production Hurt

As Hitlers war machine is mainly built on coal and iron, the French advance, which has brought mines, steel mills and textile factories under French guns, has seriously crippled Germanys war production in one of its most vital centers.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 30, 1939
