title: Review Suggests Extending Time for Setting Benchmark Currency Rates
description: LONDON  Britains Financial Stability Board said on Tuesday that the window for determining currency benchmark rates should be widened, one of a series of proposals the board made to change currency markets in the wake of investigations into whether those markets were manipulated.

title: In Performance: Anthony Wayne of Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical
description: This week the actor Anthony Wayne and the pianist Anthony Miller perform You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real) from Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical, a show about the androgynous pop-funk-disco star Sylvester, whose signature falsetto was a sonic staple on dance floors in the 70s and 80s. The song, released in 1978, was a Top 40 hit for Sylvester. Mighty Real, directed by Mr. Wayne and Kendrell Bowman, continues through Sunday at the Theater at St. Clements.

title: Games People Play, Both Online and Off
description: Men, Women & Children, Jason Reitmans glum and thoughtful new film, is not quite as comprehensive as its title suggests. Based on a novel by Chad Kultgen, it surveys a handful of white, middle-class households in a suburban Texas town, each one including a teenager with a smartphone, an Internet connection and some of the attendant problems. Every kid seems to suffer from some kind of digital malaise, and the parents are hardly immune to the seductive, soul-imperiling glow of the interactive screen.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: Words are not horseshoes; we get no points for coming close to the mark.

title: Amazon Is Not Holding Back on Paul Ryan
description: All Hachette authors are equal, but some are more equal than others.

title: Chinese Umbrellas for Hong Kong?
description: In Chinas heavily censored media, a symbol of Hong Kongs democracy protests  the umbrella  made an occasional appearance on Tuesday, leaving the impression that some people were watching and offering a subtle comment on developments in the city.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Valentinos Spring 2015 Collection at Paris Fashion Week
Chanel: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Morning Agenda: Lehman Revisited
description: Could Lehman Brothers have been saved? Government officials have argued that the Federal Reserve did not have the legal authority to rescue the big investment bank, leaving it instead to die overnight. Now, new accounts of events from 2008 are casting the firms collapse in a different light, James B. Stewart and Peter Eavis write in The New York Times. The decision not to rescue Lehman, in hindsight, let problems at one bank snowball into a full-blown panic. Why, given all that happened, was Lehman the only bank that was not too big to fail?

title: More Groups Join Project on the Brain
description: The Obama administration plans to announce Tuesday that it has recruited new federal agencies and a number of universities, foundations and businesses to help pursue the goals of the Brain Initiative, which the president started in 2013.

title: Support Strong for Regulating Politics and Nonprofits
description: When the Internal Revenue Service proposed new rules earlier this year to rein in political activity by nonprofits, it caused an unusual meeting of the minds between the right and the left in opposition to the proposal, which was eventually withdrawn by the agency.

title: Kirkus Announces Finalists for Book Prizes
description: The literary journal Kirkus Reviews has announced the finalists for its first annual book prizes. The honors for fiction, nonfiction and young readers literature each come with a $50,000 award, making them among the most lucrative in the literary world.

title: Communication Failure at the Museum
description: Dear Diary:

title: Remind, a Start-Up That Links Teachers and Parents, Raises $40 Million
description: The simple act of connecting teachers with students and parents may not seem like a revolutionary business. But Remind, a start-up built around using smartphones to link the three groups, has gotten a big financial vote of confidence from prominent investors.

title: Cat Kicker Incites Aggressive Prosecution: A Reporters Notebook
description: This story is an example of why court coverage can be so interesting. I live in Brooklyn and find that almost every issue that touches lives here  including gun control, gentrification, housing, pay and relationships  comes through the courts one way or another.

title: 1939: British Unmask Reich Defenses
description: LONDON  With French artillery pounding at German positions on the Western front and the British Expeditionary Army nearly ready to go into action, the Air Ministry disclosed today [Sept. 30] that an almost endless series of British reconnaissance flights over the Siegfried Line during the first month of war enabled the British high command to build up a comprehensive picture of German defenses. British pilots have combined leaflet-dropping with high-speed camera work that has resulted in a remarkable series of air photographs showing in clearest detail some of the most strongly fortified zones of the Siegfried Line. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Oct. 1, 1939

title: How Cigarettes and Sexual Frustration Got Me Through 26.2 Miles
description: Ive entered the New York City Marathon lottery several times since moving back to New York six years ago. Ive been dying to see what it would be like to run in a place where the crowds cheer you on and carry you forward.

title: Whats the Matter With Alabama?
description: Bloomberg has an interesting map showing state job gains and losses since the pre-recession peak:

title: Hong Kong Protesters Defy Demands to Leave
description: Pro-democracy demonstrations continued as leaders threatened to expand their presence in response to the governments orders to return home.

title: The Giving Tree: Tender Story of Unconditional Love or Disturbing Tale of Selfishness?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Shel Silversteins The Giving Tree was published 50 years ago. This week, Anna Holmes and Rivka Galchen debate whether the book is a tender story of unconditional love, or a disturbing tale of monstrous selfishness.

title: Hong Kong Protests Are Leaderless but Orderly
description: HONG KONG  They sleep by the thousands on what are normally the busiest boulevards of this crammed, nonstop city. They live on crackers, bananas and bottled water. They clean up their trash, even taking the time to pick out plastic and paper for recycling. Their shield of choice, and the symbol of their cause, is the umbrella: protection against the sun, rain  and pepper spray used by the riot police.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Biotech Company Alios BioPharma
description: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that it would pay $1.75 billion in cash for Alios BioPharma, a private biotechnology company that is working on treatments for viral diseases.

title: Watch the House Hearing on White House Security Breach
Flag on Praying Muslim Player Was an Error, the N.F.L. Says
description: The N.F.L. said Tuesday that Kansas City Chiefs safety Husain Abdullah was mistakenly penalized by a game official when he knelt to pray after scoring a touchdown Monday night.

title: Lawmakers Rebuke Secret Service Chief Over White House Breach
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress declared Tuesday that they had lost confidence in the Secret Service to protect President Obama and his family and raised serious doubts that Julia Pierson, the director of the agency, was the right person to confront what they called systemic problems and a striking lack of candor about recent security breaches.

title: Uber Improves Life, Economists Agree
description: Its like Uber, for economists.

title: Doctors Find Barriers to Sharing Digital Medical Records
description: As a practicing ear, nose and throat specialist in Ahoskie, N.C., Dr. Raghuvir B. Gelot says that little has frustrated him more than the digital record system he installed a few years ago.

title: EBays PayPal Plans Bolster Goldmans Status as Top Spinoff Adviser
description: EBay finally listened to the call of Carl C. Icahn and others in deciding to split off its enormous PayPal payments unit as a separate public company. And aiding the e-commerce titan in its decision-making is the most practiced adviser in the world of corporate spinoffs.

title: Lindsey Vonn, Before Returning From Knee Injuries, Puts Her Competitors on Notice
description: For the first time in 10 months, Lindsey Vonn plans to ski again Wednesday when she makes a few modest turns on an Austrian training slope. It will be a cautious first step as Vonn tries to return from two devastating knee injuries, but it is meaningful progress, since Vonn senses that many in the ski community are discounting her comeback.

title: How Do You Beat Amazon? Try Joining Congress
description: Amazon Is Not Holding Back on Paul Ryan

title: Paris Fashion Week: Chanel Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Wall Streets Young Bankers Are Still Mostly White and Male, Report Says
description: Wall Streets gender diversity problem is not confined to the top executives. Even at the entry level, investment bank employees are overwhelmingly men, according to a report by Vettery, a start-up recruiting firm.

title: Hong Kong Leader Reacts to Protests
description: Leung Chun-ying, the Beijing-selected chief executive of Hong Kong, said the central government will not back down in the face of protests, calling them illegal.

title: Inside the Times 100: Corey Stoll
description: The New York Times recently asked some of the artists and performers on the Times 100, a curated guide to highly anticipated fall events, to talk about some of the works that theyre most excited to see this fall. Previously we spoke to the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the comic Tig Notaro.

title: Charges Are Dropped, and Identity of Accuser, Shrouded by City, Is Sought
description: For five years, Kenneth Creighton was held in jail, suspected of involvement in the killing of a bystander outside a bodega in the Bronx.

title: The Revolution Will Be Televised, Sort Of
description: Transparent, a new, 10-episode series from Amazon Studios, has made quite asplash. The storylinefollowsthe Pfeffermans, a family of fast-talking Angelenos led by Mort, a divorc and recovering womanizer who, in the pilot episode, tries and fails to come out as transgender to his three children.

title: Nigerias Actions Seem to Contain Ebola Outbreak
description: With quick and coordinated action by some of its top doctors, Nigeria, Africas most populous country, appears to have contained its first Ebola outbreak, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Tuesday.

title: Debate Brews Over Disclosing Warrantless Spying
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration lawyers have been debating whether the Treasury Department must inform the people or groups it lists as foreign terrorists when it relies on warrantless surveillance as the basis for the designation, according to officials familiar with the deliberations.

title: Reinventions, Just in Time
description: PARIS  On Tuesday, the Apple Watch finally made it to Paris. Be still, fashions rapidly beating heart.

title: Kurds in Iraqs North Make Gains Against Islamic State
description: BAGHDAD  Kurdish fighters opened offensives against Islamic State militants in several parts of northern Iraq on Tuesday, seizing control of a border crossing with Syria that has been a major conduit for the insurgents, officials said.

title: Who Is Julia Pierson?
description: After a three-decade career in the Secret Service, the agencys first female director, Julia Pierson, got the spotlight treatment Tuesday in front of the House Oversight Committee.

title: Mending Alliance, U.S. and Afghanistan Sign Long-Term Security Agreement
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American and Afghan officials signed a long-term security pact here on Tuesday, nearly a year after the agreement was cast into limbo by a breakdown of trust at the highest levels of each allied government.

title: Seatbelt Could Have Prevented Tracy Morgans Injuries, Walmart Says
description: Walmart said that injuries sustained by Tracy Morgan and other comedians traveling with him in a June car crash involving a Walmart driver could have been prevented if the performers had been wearing seatbelts. Mr. Morgan, a former star of Saturday Night Live and 30 Rock, was critically hurt, and another comedian, James McNair, was killed on the morning of June 7 when the luxury van they were riding in on the New Jersey Turnpike was struck and overturned by a Walmart tractor-trailer. Ardie Fuqua, a comedian, and Jeffrey Millea, Mr. Morgans assistant, were also injured.

title: A Conspicuous Absence on Israels List of Top Baby Names
description: JERUSALEM  Muhammad was by far the most popular name for babies born in Israel last year: 1,986 boys shared the name of the Muslim prophet, nearly twice the number of the top girls name, Tamar, at 1,092.

title: Valentino: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Many Strikeouts, Fewer Runs as Pitchers Take Control
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A baseball dropped out of the sky without warning beyond the right-field wall of AT&T Park. It splashed into McCovey Cove, an inlet of the San Francisco Bay named for a former Giants slugger.

title: Detailing Financial Links of Doctors and Drug Makers
description: Pharmaceutical and device makers paid doctors roughly $380 million in speaking and consulting fees, with some doctors reaping over half a million dollars each, during a five-month period last year, according to an analysis of federal data released Tuesday. Other doctors made millions of dollars in royalties from products they helped develop.

title: Clinton Skips Events to Spend More Time with Her Family
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton scratched another midterm event off her itinerary to spend time with her granddaughter.

title: Houses Built on Gossamer Wings
description: How much does your house weigh? Buckminster Fuller asked in the 1920s, showing off his three-ton hexagonal Dymaxion House. He believed the technology used to mass-produce cars may as well be applied to houses, driving prices down and increasing mobility. Since then, many designers have wrestled with the size, cost, manufacturing and, indeed, heft of homes. In Superlight: Rethinking How Our Homes Impact the Earth (Metropolis Books, $35), Phyllis Richardson offers a global, contemporary perspective, highlighting recent projects from Chile to Vietnam. She also reconsiders what makes a project light, expanding the definition from pounds or kilograms to impact on the site, energy consumption (or generation) and the ability to cope with climate change. She spoke from London, where she lives in a Victorian house  with a polycarbonate and aluminum addition. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

title: Recalling the Empress of Radio Jazz
description: At her most compelling, the pop-jazz singer Stacy Sullivan has a voice so sultry that her sound might be described as heavy-lidded. Applied to a song like Stranger in a Dream, a haunting little-known ballad composed by the jazz pianist Marian McPartland with lyrics by Irving Caesar, she transports you to a twilight zone of wistful reflection that recalls the dreamier side of Peggy Lee.

title: Rolling on the (Mekong) River
description: Question: If youre a successful businessman in Lima, with a stable family life and kids in a good school, whats your next move?

title: The Power of Place: One Last Thought on Moving
description: Places do things to you, Mohsin Hamid wrote in The New York Times Book Review when asked, How does place influence writing? Its a question Ive been pondering in a broader context lately: How does place influence living?

title: A Needleful of Skepticism to Deliver Us
description: The summer of 2010 was a bummer for many reasons. Heat waves stewed the East Coast into submission.  Harvey Pekar and Tony Judt died. WikiLeaks dumped so many anxiety-inducing classified Afghan war documents that this sprig of dialogue from Gravitys Rainbow seemed freshly plucked: Everything is some kind of plot, man.

title: Secret Service Chief on Security Lapses
description: Julia Pierson, the director of the Secret Service, testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on the recent security lapses at the White House.

title: Winners Chosen in Program to Aid Female Composers
description: The League of American Orchestras and EarShot, the organizations administering a new program to provide commissions and premieres for scores composed by women, announced the winners of its commissions on Tuesday. They are Julia Adolphe, 26, a composer, writer and producer who lives in Los Angeles, and Melody Eotvos, 30, an Australian-born composer of both multimedia and traditional works who lives in Bloomington, Ind.

title: With Big Pawprints to Fill, Zoo Prepares for Grizzlies
description: Some animals are tough acts to follow, even if youre an animal.

title: Verbatim: Protecting the White House
description: Representative Stephen F. Lynch, Democrat of Massachusetts, to Julia Pierson, the Secret Service director. He said he did not believe the Secret Service takes seriously its duty to protect the president.

title: Jack Kirby Finally Gets His Due
description: The Marvel entertainment juggernaut averted what could have become a nasty Supreme Court throw down last week when it settled a copyright lawsuit with the heirs of the legendary illustrator Jack Kirby, also known as The King of Comics. Kirby was the defining talent at the Marvel shop during the halcyon years that produced iconic characters such as the X-Men, Iron Man, The Fantastic Four, Spider-Man, Thor, the Silver Surfer and The Incredible Hulk. He never received the credit or money he was due and died in 1994.

title: Doctors Fault Assumptions of Settlement With Retirees
description: A leading brain injury advocacy group said the proposed settlement between the N.F.L. and nearly 5,000 former players who sued the league for hiding from them the dangers of concussions is flawed because the definitions of eligibility are too narrow.

title: The Voice of a Hong Kong Student Leader
description: A look at the fears and motivations driving the anti-Beijing protests in Hong Kong.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Advocacy Groups Challenge Studios Over Smoking in Youth-Rated Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  The major media companies are coming under renewed attack by a group of faith-based shareholders who say they want more progress in limiting the cigarette smoking that young people see in movies.

title: 1964: Duvalier Gets Smuggled Planes
description: WASHINGTON  In the face of a strict U.S. ban on all military equipment bound for Haiti, a group of Texas pilots is busily smuggling T28 fighter planes out of this country and into dictator Franois Duvaliers eager hands. Over the last ten days at least two T28s have been flown from Texas airports into Mexico and then to Port-au-Prince, the Caribbean republics capital. The brutal Duvalier is anxious to use the planes to help in his fight against two bands of anti-government guerrillas who now virtually control the southern section of the country. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Oct. 1, 1964

title: Secret Service Hearing Yields New Information on White House Security Breach
description: Lawmakers elicited several new disclosures on Tuesday from Julia Pierson, the Secret Service director, in the first two hours of a hearing into problems at the agency, including about the handling of the recent White House security breach. Among them:

title: Discounts at Ameico, Thomas Paul, Seminole and Walker Zanger
description: Ameico is taking 30 percent off Serafino Zani Bon Appetit cookware, and 40 percent off Side by Side home goods, while supplies last (an 8-inch Bon Appetit pot, with lid, by Ettore Sottsass, shown, originally $200, is $140; a Side by Side teapot warmer by Christoph Matthias, originally $80, is $48; a Side by Side wood piggy bank by Markus Glaser and Jan Eilts, $65, is now $39); 29 Church Street (Main Street), New Milford, Conn.; 860-354-8765, ameico.com.

title: F.C.C. Eliminates Its Sports Blackout Rule, Rebuffing N.F.L.s Push
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously Tuesday to eliminate its sports blackout rule, which for nearly 40 years has prevented cable and satellite systems from televising some National Football League games.

title: Icahn Praises Breakup of eBay
description: EBay may have taken more than nine months to listen to the activist investor Carl C. Icahn and prepare a spinoff of its PayPal payments unit. But Mr. Icahn is happy that the company listened to him all the same.

title: Oklahoma Man Is Charged in Beheading of Co-Worker
description: An Oklahoma man was charged Tuesday with first-degree murder in the beheading of a co-worker, but federal officials said they had found no links between him and Islamic extremist groups that have beheaded several Western hostages in the Middle East and North Africa in recent weeks.

title: Piers Morgan Will Write for The Daily Mail
description: Piers Morgan, the British tabloid editor who replaced Larry King on CNN only to have his show canceled three years later, will join the American website of The Daily Mail as an editor at large, the newspaper said Tuesday.

title: Today in Small Business: Paper or Plastic?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Pimco Perplex
description: Its fairly clear that the events of 2011 are a large part of the story of Bill Grosss abrupt departure from Pimco; as Neil Irwin says,

title: First Draft Focus: Getting Out of the White House
How Fast Is It?
description: Zoooom! Bloooeep.

title: Iris van Herpen: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Seattle Start-Up Factory Hires Former Amazon and Microsoft Executive
description: SEATTLE  Ivy Softworks is a new start-up factory that has devised what its founder says is a better way to create tech companies. Now the plan has attracted Brian Valentine, a prominent engineer and executive who worked for years at Microsoft and Amazon.

title: Catalan Leaders Suspend Plan for Ballot on Secession From Spain
description: MADRID  Catalonias regional government on Tuesday suspended its campaign for a planned independence vote in accordance with a ruling issued a day earlier by Spains Constitutional Court.

title: Gone From Office, Bloombergs Still a Lightning Rod in Ad Wars
description: Michael R. Bloomberg may have returned to corporate America, but politics has not forgotten him.

title: Tall and Spiked, but Little Deterrent to Intruders
description: The White House perimeter fence is nearly eight feet high and adorned with ornamental spear-like tips. They are decorative but sharp enough to puncture the skin, as Diane Wilson learned last year.

title: A Startling Look at How Profits Elude the Taxman
description: Statistics cited in debates about tax reform often have a sleep-inducing effect. But Jason Furman, the chairman of the presidents Council of Economic Advisers, recently offered some eye-popping numbers to underscore just how much revenue the United States loses when American corporations shift part of their operations abroad to avoid paying taxes at home.

title: New Michelin Guide Has New York Star-Studded
description: The 2015 New York City Michelin Guide has upgraded Aquavit, Blanca and Ichimura to two stars, up from one star last year. The new rankings, released today, have New York rolling in stars, with 20 places newly anointed or promoted. More than half are in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Dallas Symphony Aims to Develop Musical Leadership
description: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra, in a partnership with the University of Texas at Dallas and several conservatories around the world, is starting an unusual program meant to turn music students on the threshold of professional careers into potential leaders and entrepreneurs in the music world. The D.S.O./Jaap van Zweden Scholars Program, as the enterprise is called, is named for the orchestras music director and is supported by a $10 million gift from Margaret McDermott, who also endows a scholars fund at the university.

title: Wheelies: The Diesel Ram Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Hotel Review: The Line Hotel in Los Angeles
description: Rooms start at $249.

title: Insider Case by S.E.C. Is a Step Removed From Herbalife Itself
description: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | The hedge fund world often finds itself at the center of insider trading investigations after profiting from corporate secrets. But for the first time, regulators are saying that a hedge funds investment plan itself can be the secret.

title: Chicken Fingers Are Off the Menu
description: When a friend mentioned last year that her 7-year-old daughter had gone vegan, I stifled a sigh of relief. Thank God Im not raising children in Brooklyn, was my smug little thought.

title: New York Film Festival: A Genius Grant Winner and His Unblinking Camera
description: No documentary in recent years has had a greater impact on both the public and filmmakers than Joshua Oppenheimers The Act of Killing, an examination of government-directed mass killing that took place in Indonesia in 1965. At the Toronto International Film Festival this month, no less than Martin Scorsese said he found the movie, which was nominated for an Oscar earlier this year, haunting and inspiring.

title: Swedish-Owned Firm Defends Bid for Sensitive U.S. Phone Contract
description: WASHINGTON  A technology company vying to win the job of routing the countrys tens of millions of phone calls and text messages accused a competitor on Tuesday of using scare tactics and spreading misinformation by raising the specter of national security threats if the deal goes forward.

title: Does the Cat-Kicker Deserve Jail?
description: Most people who saw the video of Andre Robinson viciously kicking a stray cat were justifiably horrified. He actually laughed at the cats misfortune.

title: On the Trail of an Online Pirate
description: Last Sunday Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter, profiled Hana Beshara, a founder of NinjaVideo, a now-shuttered streaming website. She discusses the challenge of tracking down Ms. Beshara, who served a prison term for her role in running the illegal site, and of describing a culture with a different understanding of copyright law.

title: Reaffirming Vow, Prosecutor Says Rikers Reform Will Happen One Way or Another
description: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan reasserted on Tuesday that he expected reforms to be made at Rikers Island and that he was prepared to go to court, if necessary, to accomplish them.

title: In Tel Aviv, a Holy Day Is a Biking Day
description: For one day each year, Tel Aviv, the cosmopolitan and cultural heart of Israel, seems still.

title: Leading the League? Theyre Dominating It So Far
description: As the calendar turns to October, 26 of the N.F.L.s 32 teams have played a quarter of their season. That makes this a good time to hand out awards for the top players from the leagues first month.

title: An Ever-Expanding List of Unwelcome Visitors to the White House
description: WASHINGTON  American presidents like to refer to the White House as the peoples house, and over the past two centuries, a surprising number of uninvited people have made their way in.

title: The Battle Against Herbalife
description: The billionaire William A. Ackman has mounted a $1 billion wager against Herbalife, a giant diet supplements company.

title: California Will Allow Family Members to Seek Seizure of Guns
description: LOS ANGELES  California will be the first state in the country to allow private citizens to ask a court to seize guns from family members who they believe pose a threat to themselves or the public, under a measure signed into law by Gov. Jerry Brown on Tuesday.

title: Heirloom Popcorn Helps a Snack Reinvent Itself
description: SHELLSBURG, Iowa  Corn confronts you at every turn in Iowa. It blurs past the car window for hours. Stop for gas and youre likely to find a patch growing out back.

title: Popcorn Recipes: Tips for Popping Heirloom Corn Varieties
description: Cooking a pan of popcorn is so simple and satisfying that Im always surprised when people say it seems like too much trouble. The results are far superior to anything that comes from a microwave or a bag.

title: Moon Juice Debuts Wellness Products and an E-Commerce Site
description: The Moon Juice founder Amanda Chantal Bacon has developed a cult following in Los Angeles and beyond for raw juices and organic vegan foods that promise good health. And Bacon (oh, the irony) may be her own best advertisement. Standing in her Silver Lake shop, which opened last year at a spot between the nearly three-year-old original location in Venice and the month-old kiosk at the Ace Hotel Downtown, the mother of one is all shiny chestnut hair and glowing good looks. And thats due at least in part to the products on the shelves across from the juice bar: flower remedies, house shea butter and rose body balms, ayurvedic toothpastes and a few jumbo-size crystals for good measure. The items are part of Moon Juices new Apothecary offshoot, a platform that functions as a curation of my medicine cabinet, drawer of bathroom goodies and kitchen cabinet, Bacon says. It is the best way I can answer the thousands of questions we get about what toothpaste to use and why, or more effective options for skin care that are edible.

title: Excerpt: Indian Ink
description: Romola Garai and Firdous Bamji in a scene from the Roundabout Theater Companys revival of Tom Stoppards drama.

title: Excerpt: A Walk in the Woods
description: Kathleen Chalfant and Paul Niebanck in a scene from the Keen Company revival of Lee Blessings two-character drama.

title: 2014: Paul on Congressional Gridlock
description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, says term limits for members of Congress are one way to help fix Washington.

title: An Impresario Shines His Light on the Customer
description: We were halfway through appetizers at Cherche Midi, passing the steak tartare and spreading anchovy toasts with softly jiggly Parmesan custard, when one of my guests suddenly tilted his head and listened. He looked like the boy in a tornado movie who notices that the birds have stopped singing.

title: Alexander McQueen: Spring 2015 RTW
description: Paris

title: Brooklyn Teacher Is Accused of Abusing Girls for 3 Years
description: The investigation began with one explicit picture, sent by a teacher at one of New Yorks elite public high schools to one of his female students through a messaging app.

title: A Bass Voice, Contained but Inviting
description: Is there a singer on the Metropolitan Operas roster more deserving of a solo recital on its stage than Ren Pape, who received that honor on Sunday afternoon? After nearly 20 years and 200 performances with the company, this German basss steady, wine-dark voice and suave presence have become indispensable.

title: First Draft Video: Paul on Fixing Washington
description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is the latest in the Fixing Washington video series here on First Draft, where he explains that his colleagues arent as smart as they think they are.

title: Sweet Ankle-Strap Shoes at Chanels Riot in the Streets
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Excerpt: Mulaney
description: The new Fox sitcom stars the comic John Mulaney and Martin Short.

title: Keeping the Creeps From Getting Too Close
description: Can no one make a television show thats not full of women being murdered, raped and terrorized? Perhaps something good will come of Stalker, a police drama that begins on Wednesday night on CBS: Maybe its excesses will be the tipping point that reins in this deplorable trend.

title: Jol Robuchon to Reopen LAtelier in Battery Park City
description: Headliner

title: Modi Meets With Obama at White House
description: In September, during his first visit to the White House, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India discussed clean energy, trade and security issues with President Obama.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Jon Mooallem on Larry Ellisons Learning Curve for Island Ownership
description: Jon Mooallem wrote the Sept. 28 cover story about the Hawaiian island Lanai, which is almost entirely owned by the tech billionaire Larry Ellison. Mooallem, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of Wild Ones and American Hippopotamus.

title: The Collapse of the Secret Service
description: When Omar Gonzalez vaulted the White House fence, pushed past a Secret Service guard and carried a knife all the way to the ceremonial East Room on Sept. 19, he did more than threaten the life of the first family and some of the nations highest officials. He shattered the idea that the White House is a sacred civic space, protected by the worlds most impenetrable security force.

title: Europe Tries to Stop Flow of Citizens Joining Jihad
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  European countries pressed ahead on Tuesday with efforts to deter the growing numbers of their citizens seeking to join radical Islamic movements in Iraq and Syria, as some experts warned that the United States-led military campaign against the Islamic State increased the risk that the groups would turn their attention to attacking Western targets.

title: A $100 Weekend in Chicago
description: Even the best-funded traveler cant conquer Chicago in a weekend, or, for that matter, cover the basics: deep-dish pizza, Chicago-style hot dogs, skyline views, troves of historic architecture, Millennium Park, Wrigley Field (the second most charming baseball stadium in the country, at least to this Red Sox fan), a fine arts scene, famed Chicago blues and much more.

title: Photos of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Hong Kong, Turkey, Washington and India.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres what you need to know from NYT Now:

title: A Toeshoe Marks the Spot of Color
description: When the visual artist Suzanne Bocanegra was a girl, she was fascinated by Seurats 1890 painting Young Woman Powdering Herself. She also identified with Little Dot, a comic-book character, created in 1949, obsessed with dots, and as she gazed at the Seurat, an image composed of thousands of dabs of color, she imagined how fun it would be to count and sort them.

title: A Prickly Friendship Endures, Even as Luck Wears Thin
description: Chinese Coffee, at the Roy Arias Stage II Theater, is an actors evening. Its directed by a wonderful one, Louise Lasser (an ad for her acting studio is on the back of the program); features a very busy one, Austin Pendleton (himself a fine director); and was performed on Friday night for an audience stocked with lots of other ones, overheard discussing rehearsals, the odd one-woman musical and excellent directors around town.

title: If You Have Unlimited Vacation, Will You Take It?
description: Last week, the Virgin Group founder Richard Branson announced hed be giving his employeesunlimited time off  and in so doing, inciteda debate about whether theyd actually feel they could take it.

title: Massacre at Centralia
description: By the time Confederate Maj. Gen. Sterling Price invaded Missouri in September 1864, he had earned a reputation for his mens lack of discipline. After authorizing the invasion, Prices superior, Gen. Kirby Smith, felt it necessary to add, You will scrupulously avoid all wanton acts of destruction and devastation. Restrain your men.

title: A Crispy Okra Recipe, a Loewy Casserole and More New York Food News
description: To Snack: Recipe Puts Crispy Okra on Your Table

title: Serving Without Protecting
description: My mother used to leave the front door unlocked. She used to leave the side and back doors unlocked, too. This was mostly a function of sloppiness  she had four kids, three pets and a whole lot else on her mind  but when pressed about it, she reasoned that anyone bent on intrusion would find a way and that it was all a matter of chance in the end.

title: Behind the Scenes at Paris Fashion Week With a Rising Model and Native
description: One of the most striking new faces in Paris this week has been that ofAmalie Gassmann  a San Franciscoborn, Paris-raised 18-year-old signed with IMG Models, for which shell work during a gap year before enrolling at Bard College next fall.(She also happens to be the daughter of the T contributing editor Gay Gassmann.) This season, however, Gassmann opted to work the front rows instead of the runways, taking in some presentations and openings while making a few pit stops at her favorite Paris cafs. Above, she recounts her whirlwind week.

title: A Photographers Guide to Nocturnal Life
description: Traer Scott had to find her own path as an artist. She found it at night, making portraits of nocturnal animals.

title: A River Trip in Tulip Season
description: Amras Cruises, a new Boston-based travel company operating cruises designed for English-speaking travelers, will offer a trip called the Tulip Serenade, a weeklong cruise through the waterways of the Netherlands and Belgium during flower season.

title: Modern-Day Princess Hair at Valentino
description: With its sumptuous embroidery and vibrant prints, Valentinos spring/summer 2015 collection felt at once romantic and ultramodern. And the same was true of the models half-up hairstyle. Locks were twisted together with gold charms and wrapped around the back of the head for a fresh, festive update on the classic fairy-tale coif.

title: In Chicago, a Tasting Tour of Barrel-Aged Beer
description: About an hour after my flight touched down at OHare, and five blocks after I hopped off the Els Blue Line stop at Logan Square, Chicago embraced me with a warm hug in the form of a barrel-aged doppelbock  a mini goblet of sweet vanilla lusciousness with a boozy note of rum.

title: Forsaking an Orb to Pursue the Light of His Life
description: The shaggiest dog youll ever see makes a late entrance in PigPen Theater Companys enchanted The Old Man and the Old Moon, at the New Victory Theater. Its a highly companionable creature who resembles (and, in fact, may be) an animated white bath mat. But it isnt there just to charm us.

title: How a Meteor Rose From a Hotbed of Hip-Hop
description: NAS

title: New Sitcom Tries Old Form: Laughs Allowed
description: Its hard enough to establish a comedy series in the current climate of network television without disturbing the universe at the same time.

title: Fantasy Football: Waiver Wire Picks for Week 5
description: With four weeks of claims gone, our waiver wire cupboard is getting a little bare. But there are still some good options floating around as we all scramble to fill in the holes during bye weeks.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: Doting Father, Loving Husband, Nazi Leader
description: THE DECENT ONE

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Ebola Is Diagnosed in Texas, First Case Found in the U.S.
description: A man who took a commercial flight from Liberia that landed in Dallas on Sept. 20 has been found to have the Ebola virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday. He is the first traveler to have brought the virus to the United States on a passenger plane and the first in whom Ebola has been diagnosed outside of Africa in the current outbreak.

title: September Was Warm on Broadway, Too
description: September is no longer the month that Broadway dreads.

title: Three Ballet Theater Principals to Retire
description: American Ballet Theater will celebrate its 75th anniversary this season by performing key dances from its past, staging a new production of The Sleeping Beauty choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, and appearing as the subject of a new public television documentary by Ric Burns. But it will also close a more recent chapter of its history, as three ballerinas retire.

title: Illuminating a Life Made Visible by Death
description: Rachel Swarns is a writer for the Metro section. On Monday, in her Working Life column, she reported on the death of a woman who died in her car while napping in between shifts for two of her three jobs. The article struck a chord and has gotten a huge response. Ms. Swarns discusses why the story touched her and many readers.

title: Chains Spurn Netflix Plan to Screen Crouching Tiger Sequel
description: Two major theater chains, Regal Cinemas and Cinemark, said Tuesday that they would not screen next years sequel to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, the first major motion picture that will make its debut simultaneously on Netflix and on a select number of Imax screens.

title: Modern Voice, Ancient Origins
description: In his youth, Chou Wen-chung, the 91-year-old subject of a Composer Portrait at the Columbia University Miller Theater on Thursday, had many strict teachers. One was Edgard Varse, the temperamental French-born Modernist and godfather of electronic music, who once showed his displeasure by throwing a score of Mr. Chous on the floor and ordering him to urinate on it. Then there was Bohuslav Martinu, the Czech symphonist, who reacted to a fugue Mr. Chou had written using Chinese melodic material with a single, withering, Why?

title: Looking at Two Sides of Rock Royalty
description: Prince has made his career as syncopated as his music, juggling silence and noise, arena sellouts and secretive recordings. His latest confounding move is the simultaneous arrival of two albums: Art Official Age, a studio production billed as his first solo album since 2010 (though he had help) and PlectrumElectrum, on which hes backed by the three-woman rock trio he has been touring with, 3rdEyeGirl.

title: Christopher A. Meyers
description: Mr. Meyers, 46, is the managing principal of Houlihan Lawrence, a family-owned residential real estate brokerage firm that focuses on the northern suburbs of Westchester, Dutchess and Putnam Counties in New York and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

title: Microsoft Windows 10 Displays a Familiar Look
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft believes the next version of its operating system is such a big change that its calling the software Windows 10, skipping the more logical product name, Windows 9, entirely.

title: In a Long Island Hamlet, a Downtown Is Being Built From Scratch
description: WYANDANCH, N.Y.  For years, this Long Island hamlet has been caught in the grip of poverty, blight and crime while the nearby Hamptons and other New York City suburbs in Suffolk County prospered.

title: Should a Cat-Kicker Go to Jail? Readers Respond
description: On Monday, The New York Times wrote about a man charged with animal cruelty who is about to go on trial. The charges came soon after a video surfaced of him kicking a stray cat.

title: Now as Provocateur, Summers Says Treasury Undermined Fed
description: Lawrence Summers, the former chief economic adviser to President Obama, said on Tuesday that the Treasury Department had undermined the Federal Reserves stimulus campaign and that doing so was a large and expensive mistake.

title: Ethics Office Urges Inquiry of Petri, Wisconsin Republican
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, may have violated House conflict of interest rules when he repeatedly intervened on behalf of a Defense Department contractor in which he owned more than $250,000 in stock, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

title: In Trying to Save Darden, a Board Sealed Its Own Demise
description: Gestures of futile nobility seem mostly confined to the movies these days. And yet the directors of Darden Restaurants, the owner of Olive Garden and other quintessentially American restaurant chains, may have decided that they would rather commit corporate suicide than give in to the demands of two activist shareholders, Starboard Value and the Barington Capital Group. It would be touching if it didnt appear to be so inexplicably foolish.

title: Capitalized Clues to a Glitch
description: Advance reading copies of books  uncorrected proofs distributed to booksellers, editors and other interested parties before publication  usually contain little mistakes: stray typos, misspelled words, oddly formatted paragraphs.

title: George Shuba, 89, Dies; Handshake Heralded Racial Tolerance in Baseball
description: George Shuba, the Brooklyn Dodgers outfielder who played in three World Series during the 1950s but who was best remembered for his welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson at home plate on the day Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseballs color barrier, died on Monday at his home in Youngstown, Ohio. He was 89.

title: In a First for Cornell, a Woman Is Appointed as Its Next President
description: Elizabeth Garrett, the provost of the University of Southern California, will become the next president of Cornell University, the first woman to hold that position, Cornell announced on Tuesday.

title: Turkey Makes Bid to Expand Military Role
description: The Turkish government sought a mandate from Parliament on Tuesday to expand cross-border military operations into Iraq and Syria, signaling that it will play a more active role in a United States-led international military campaign to combat Islamic State militants.

title: East Jerusalem Area Sees Influx of Jewish Settlers
description: Jewish settlers moved earlyTuesdayinto 26 apartments in seven buildings in a politically delicate, predominantly Palestinian neighborhood of East Jerusalem. Activists opposed to the move described it as the largest influx of settlers into the area in decades. The neighborhood, Silwan  just south of the Old City in territory Israel captured in the 1967 war then annexed  is home to about 50,000 Palestinians. It is also the site of archaeological ruins believed to be the City of David, a Jewish historical landmark. The Palestinians claim East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state, and most of the world considers it to be illegally occupied. A private investment company bought the properties over several years with the help of Elad, a settler organization dedicated to preventing any political division of Jerusalem. The Jewish population in the area is now expected to increase to 700 from 500, according to an Elad representative.

title: Where Horses Run Wild
description: A growing number of wild horses in the Western United States pose a threat to ranchers and raise questions about how to control them.

title: Beating of African Students by Mob in India Prompts Soul-Searching on Race
description: As Indias prime minister visited the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial with President Obama in Washington on Tuesday, a debate about racism was taking shape in the Indian news media, prompted by video of an angry mob beating three African students in a New Delhi metro station this week.

title: As Wild Horses Overrun the West, Ranchers Fear Land Will Be Gobbled Up
description: BEAVER COUNTY, Utah  When he was a boy on a 150,000-acre ranch here in the desert mountains, which are so remote that there is no power line and electricity comes from a turbine in a mountain spring, Mark Wintch would thrill at the sight of a rare band of wild horses kicking up dust as they disappeared over a rise.

title: C.D.C. Announces First U.S. Ebola Case
description: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the infected individual came to the United States from Liberia.

title: New School Evaluations Will Lower Test Scores Influence
description: New York City is overhauling its system for evaluating schools, de-emphasizing test scores in favor of measures like the strength of the curriculum and the school environment, and doing away with an overall A-through-F grade for each school, the schools chancellor, Carmen Faria, said on Tuesday.

title: The Destruction of Mecca
description: WHEN Malcolm X visited Mecca in 1964, he was enchanted. He found the city as ancient as time itself, and wrote that the partly constructed extension to the Sacred Mosque will surpass the architectural beauty of Indias Taj Mahal.
